DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien has been tapped to serve as next president of the watchdog Control Yuan.
The China Times:
Fredrick Chien is expected to head the new Control Yuan.
The United Daily News:
Core policymakers have tentatively decided that Fredrick Chien will be next Control Yuan president.
The Liberty Times:
National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien will head the new Control Yuan, while incumbent Minister of Examination Chen Chin-jang will fill the post to be vacated by Chien.
The Independence Morning Post:
The central government will undergo a partial reshuffle after the Dec. 5 three elections.
The Commons Daily:
80,000 riot police have been posted in Taipei to prevent any possible post-elections disturbances.
The China Post:
New Party's Wu may give up Kaohsiung mayoral bid.
The China News:
Exxon-Mobil merger is a done deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA DEMOCRACY PARTY ADVOCATES OBSERVING TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Five members of the China Democracy Party (CDP) arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to observe the Dec. 5 elections, according to sources from the New York-based CDP Information Center.

The five were Tang Jie and Jin Xiuhong, members of the CDP Overseas Preparatory Committee; Lu Jie and Huang Yuanzhang, members of the CDP Hong Kong Preparatory Committee; and Yang Nong, a member of the CDP Taiwan Preparatory Committee, the sources said.
They will observe the three-in-one elections for the Republic of China's legislature, the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, and city council seats in those two cities.

In addition to observing the elections, the five Democracy Party advocates will also meet with officials and candidates from the ruling Kuomintang, and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and New Party to exchange views on democratic evolution and political issues.

During their 10-day stay in Taiwan, the CDP group will also meet the media at a press conference to publicize the CDP's founding ordeal in mainland China, the party's current development, and assistance rendered to mainland China's democratic movement from Chinese democracy campaigners overseas.
The New York CDP Information Center said the CDP members' visiting Taiwan promises to provide certain experiences that will help ignite democratic progress in mainland China.
Meanwhile, the center sources said, another six-member delegation from mainland China's National Taiwan Research Institute has also arrived in Taiwan to observe the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC OBTAINS EXCLUSIVE RIGHTS TO SELL GERMAN COMPANY'S CONVEYER BELTS

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) signed a cooperation contract with Germany's largest conveyer belt maker, Transport Gummi Blankenburg (TGB), on Wednesday, said one CSC representative.
According to CSC, it has obtained monopolistic status in selling TGB's conveyer belts in Taiwan, mainland China and Southeast Asian countries.

CSC said on Wednesday that upon attaining the exclusive rights to sell TGB's conveyer belts, CSC will do its best to expand the market and promote the products via agents in Hong Kong and Japan. It is predicted that there will be an estimated NT$8 billion (US$247 million) worth of business opportunity annually, said CSC.

TGB has made conveyer belts for 75 years. The conveyer belts TGB produces include steel and canvas ones, with a maximum width of 250 centimeters. TGB's annual volume of business is estimated to be 1.5 billion marks (US$2.54 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CROSSES SEA TO STUMP FOR KMT CANDIDATE
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, concurrently chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, led a KMT campaign "oil tank" mission Thursday to the front-line Quemoy, better known as Kinmen, to stump for KMT legislative candidate Chen Ching-pao.

Lee and the KMT campaign group flew across the Taiwan Strait to Kinmen, located just 2.4 kilometers off the mainland Chinese coast, to drum up support for Chen, currently a legislator who appealed for help to turn around his "critical" situation as a result of dogfighting competition.

The visit to Kinmen marks the last leg of Lee's islandwide "oil tank" campaign forays in the run-up to three-in-one elections for the Republic of China's legislature, the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, and city council seats in those two cities, slated for Saturday.

During a rally, Lee urged the Kinmen voters to cast their ballots for Chen, whom, Lee said, will keep his promises to develop a commercial port in Kinmen, subsidies to Kinmen's self-defense squads, the overhaul of the Kinmen airport, and the building of a cross-sea bridge between Kinmen and Liehyu Islet.

Lee, meanwhile, also spoke to drum up support for Tsao Er-chung, a KMT legislator representing Matsu who is seeking re-election. Matsu is another ROC-held small island group located offshore of mainland China.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang was among the KMT officials accompanying Lee on the offshore trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY BOTHERED BY FOREIGN WORKER PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Central Taiwan's Taichung County, which so far has introduced more than 18,000 foreign workers, has been hit by increasingly serious instances of workers running away.
Taichung County police said on Thursday that 988 of the introduced laborers have run away from their contract jobs, and their whereabouts have so far not yet been discovered.
Moreover, the police indicated, 430 cases of foreign laborers running away occurred in the county from January to November, while during the period, 11 crimes involving foreign workers were reported.

Although the latter figure is a 0.6-fold decrease from the same period last year, crime involving foreign workers has become a thorn in the side of law enforcement authorities, the county police said.

Since Taiwan opened the island's labor market in 1989, Taichung County has been permitted to import more than 50,000 foreign workers, while so far more than 18,000 persons have come in, a figure larger than the entire population of the county's Shihkang village, according to the Taichung County Department of Labor Affairs.

The introduction of foreign laborers has brought tough troubles to managers of foreign workers in the central Taiwan county, while reports of workers' staying for prolonged periods on expired visas, illegally working, running away and committing criminal activities were consistently reported since their introduction, labor officials of the county said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S DEC. 5 ELECTIONS: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is concerned about the three critical elections to be held in Taiwan on Saturday, said ROC Representative to United States Stephen Chen on Wednesday.

"According to my contacts and talks with Americans in various fields, I feel that the Clinton administration and many Republican and Democratic politicians are highly concerned about our Dec. 5 three-in-one elections," Chen told a news conference at Twin Oak.
The de facto ROC ambassador said most Americans think that Taiwan's upcoming elections symbolizes a "democratic China in practice."

Chen further said many Americans are curious about Taiwan's political development in the wake of Saturday's elections for its national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of its two special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung.
According to Chen, nearly all major American news organizations, including the Washington Post, have sent journalists to Taiwan to cover the hotly contested mayoral and parliamentary elections.

Chen said the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. will set up an information center on Saturday to offer up-to-the-minute election-related news services to the Chinese community and American people in the greater Washington area.
Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), is expected to visit the center on Saturday to get first-hand information about the election returns, Chen said.
"Bush is also expected to deliver a brief comment on the elections based on his observation," said the ROC envoy.
AIT is a quasi-official US organization authorized to handle substantive relations with the Republic of China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN; FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices shrank on Thursday in a light session, with the weighted price index, the market's leading barometer, losing 17.11 points to close at 7,140.11.

The bourse opened at 7,182.44 and fluctuated in low territory as investors stayed on the sidelines ahead of weekend elections for the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, city council seats in the two cities and the legislature.
A total of 2.28 billion shares exchanged hands on a market turnover of NT$69.76 billion (US$2.15 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 231 to 177, with 83 issues unchanged.

Textile stocks registered the largest fall at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which dropped 1.2 percent; plastic and chemical shares, 1.1 percent; banking stocks, 0.4 percent; and cement issues, 0.3 percent.
Electronic engineering shares rose 0.3 percent, and construction stocks moved up 0.1 percent. Paper-making issues remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, the island's futures market opened low and also traded in low territory on Thursday.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December slid 59 points to close at 7,321, with 1,844 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for January fell 54 points to 7,371, with 97 transactions, while those for March moved down 58 points to 7,372, with 11 contract transactions; and those for June rose 17 points to 7,340, with two transactions.
No record was registered on trading for September.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,380 points for December; 7,425 points for January; 7,430 points for March; 7,323 points for June; and 7,310 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER MUM ON NEW ASSIGNMENT

TEXT.P: National Assembly (NA) Speaker Fredrick Chien kept mum Thursday about allegations of his appointment as president of the Control Yuan, the Republic of China's top watchdog body.

Chien, the ROC's foreign affairs minister before assuming the NA speakership in 1996, declined to comment on the allegations. He said it is President Lee Teng-hui's privilege to nominate a candidate for the Control Yuan leadership, which shall be consented to by the National Assembly before the appointment takes effect.
Chien, 63, said it is his moral principle to respect the political system by not making any remarks about the appointment before the Presidential Office makes an announcement.
He also refused to comment on his willingness to head the Control Yuan, saying only that it is improper to utter any personal opinions on public arrangements that are not formally publicized.
Control Yuan President Wang Tso-yung, 79, is retiring.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN STANDARD OF LIVING SLIPPING, OECD WARNS

TEXT.P: The Canadian standard of living could fall sharply during the next two decades, and the main cause is the decline of productivity, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warned Wednesday.

In its annual report on Canada, the Paris-based think-tank said that unless action is taken, the Canadian standard of living could drop substantially in comparison with the other 28 countries in the organization.

"The lack of productivity advancement combined with both the slow growth of labor inputs and the capital stock could, if ongoing, lead to a substantial decline in Canada's per capita income (measured in purchasing power parities) relative to the OECD average," said the report.
One possibility envisaged by the report's authors is that the Canadian standard of living could drop from about 110 percent of the OECD average to just below the average.

The report noted that compared with the major and the fast-growing smaller OECD countries, "Canada has not kept pace on several accounts over the 1990s." Those factors include a decline in productivity, a situation unique to Canada among OECD members.

The report suggested a number of policy priorities are needed to "arrest, or at least slow," the anticipated fall in living standards. One is that Canada's different levels of governments should consider cutting taxes as long as the fiscal situation in the country continues to improve.
It also urged Canada to take measures to discourage people from retiring early -- or even at 65 -- to forestall a projected decline in the labor force.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS OF TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 3, or Oct. 15 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1919: French impressionist painter Pierre Auguste Renoir, who was born in 1841, dies aged 78.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington, and London.
1944: US forces cross the Saar River in Germany in World War II.
1954: The Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty is signed in Washington.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macao imposes curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Chinese communists.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir; India declares state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy, and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1983: The ruling Kuomintang wins a landslide victory in the supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 contested seats in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats, while the independents take three.
1984: In Bophal, central India, hundreds are reported dead and several thousand injured after inhaling poisonous cyanide gas which leaked from a Union Carbide insecticide factory.
1989: US President George Bush and USSR leader Mikhail Gorbachev end their summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, ending the Cold War and entering a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spills into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Sui-bian and Wu Den-yi win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1997: South Korea signs letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help tide South Korea over its financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC ECONOMY LOOKS GOOD IN NEXT TWO YEARS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland China is forecast to lead Asian countries in economic growth in 1999 and 2000 while Taiwan and India are rated among higher-growth countries in 1999 with South Korea predicted to recover at a faster pace by the turn of the century.

In an article titled "Economies Slated for 2000 Recovery" in The Australian on Thursday, the Australian's Asia business editor, Geoff Hiscock, quoted Andrew Freris, managing director of the Hong Kong-based Bank of America's global capital markets group, as forecasting that every economy in Asia, except Japan and Indonesia, will show positive economic growth rate in 1999 and even these two countries should recover in 2000.

But Freris predicted the economic performances across the region will vary dramatically in the next two years with mainland China taking the lead with a growth of 8 percent in 1999 and 8.5 percent in 2000.
Taiwan was ranked second, with expected growth of 5 percent in 1999 and 2000, according to Freris.

India was ranked third with a growth rate of 4.7 percent in 1999, and its growth will further pick up to 5.5 percent by 2000. Korea is expected to grow only 1 percent in 1999, but its growth will surge to 5.5 percent in 2000, according to Freris.
The Philippines is expected to rank fourth in 1999 with a growth rate of 2.5 percent and a rate of 4 percent in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA EXPECTED TO ACHIEVE ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Australia government is expected to revise its forecast of gross domestic product (GDP) growth higher in fiscal 1998-99 and the official interest rate cut is seen as a signal of slower economic growth in the following year.

Federal Treasurer Peter Costello said the robust activity in the third quarter of 1998 meant there was an "upside risk" to the government's forecast of 2.75 percent GDP growth over the course of 1998-99.

"We are living in difficult times. We haven't lived through an Asian financial crisis before and it has global implications. And to have weathered the first year with such exceptional strength in the economy has been a major achievement," he told the Parliament on Wednesday.

Economists expect the federal treasury to revise its forecast for 1998-99 GDP growth up to at least 3.25 percent soon. But Costello and Governor Ian Macfarlane of the Reserve Bank of Australia warned that a downturn in the global economy over the next year was likely to drag Australia's growth rate down.
Economists said the official rate cut of 0.25 percentage points to 4.75 percent from 5 percent was a preemptive strike against slower economic growth in 1999.
Prime Minister John Howard on Wednesday described the current strong performance of Australia's economy as "the most golden of days for the Australian economy."
But Macfarlane warned the world economy was bound to slow next year and it would drag Australian growth down, causing the country's current account deficit to widen further.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DETAINS LEADERS OF NEW OPPOSITION PARTY

TEXT.P: "In a wide-reaching crackdown on one of the Beijing regime's first opposition parties, police in three cities have detained ten of its leaders, and the tearful wife of one of the activists accused the communist regime today of 'cheating its people and cheating the world,'" according to Wednesday's Los Angeles Times.
The report, titled "Beijing detains leader of new opposition party," said the crackdown indicated that any anti-Communist group "will not be allowed to exist."

Maggie Farley, a Times' staff writer stationed in Shanghai, reported that the roundup came just days after Li Peng, the leader of mainland China's Parliament, declared that any group opposing the Communist Party "will not be allowed to exist," signaling the official closing of a brief window of political tolerance in mainland China.

Intellectuals, artists and a handful of others have been allowed to explore political pluralism in the past year or so. But with the arrests of the members of the fledgling "China Democracy Party", Beijing's leadership appears to have drawn a line between discussion of political openness and actual organization to promote it.

On Monday night, police entered the Beijing home of the chairman of the party, Xu Wenli. They confiscated his computer, fax machine, videotape and personal phone lists, his wife said, and took him away.

The same day, authorities arrested or detained at least nine other members of the party in Wuhan and Beijing, charging some with conspiring to overthrow the regime, a serious offense that could bring a life sentence.

In Washington, the State Department criticized Xu's detention. "We conveyed our strong views to officials in the (Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs) today in Beijing and urged the authorities to release Xu immediately," said State Department spokesman James Rubin.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA CONTINUES TO DETAIN MAINLAND CHINESE FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada Wednesday said he has yet to decide on whether or not to free the 20 mainland Chinese fishermen arrested by the navy for poaching near Mischief Reef.

The chief executive said the request is currently under review by the Department of Justice (DOJ) and still awaiting their recommendation along with that of the Department of Foreign Affairs and National Defense.
"I will refer it to the DOJ who is studying the case, they will give a recommendation to me by tomorrow. We will study first," Estrada said.
A spokesman of the mainland Chinese foreign ministry, in a press conference in Beijing, urged the Philippines to immediately release all the detained mainland Chinese fishing boats and fishermen.

Mainland China has proposed to share with the Philippines the use of the fishermen's shelter they built at Mischief Reef, one of the cluster of reefs in the Spratlys, which the Philippines is claiming as part of its territory.
Estrada said the government is likely to adopt mainland China's proposal to share the use of the structure to ease tension between two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TINY BAND OF DEMOCRACY-SEEKERS GIVES BEIJING JITTERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities have launched a major crackdown on dissidents trying to set up an opposition party, detaining at least six members of the group in three cities, The Globe and Mail reported Wednesday.

The Canadian newspaper said the detentions of the six and the official arrest of China Democracy Party founder Wang Youcai are seen as the Communist Party's attempt to squelch any notion that a non-sanctioned political party can be set up in mainland China.

By crushing a fledgling opposition movement, Beijing was accused of violating "the basic criteria of human rights," the daily said. It quoted protesting dissidents in Beijing as saying, "This contradicts the international covenant on civil and political rights China has just signed (in October)."
Arrested were, among others, Xu Wenli, 56, and Qin Yongmin, 44. "They are among the most influential figures in China's fractured dissident community," the Mail noted.

It said the tiny band of democracy-seekers has given Beijing the jitters. For example, the CDP, launched in June, has only 500 official members in a country of 1.2 billion ruled for 49 years by the Communists. Its open attempts to recruit ordinary mainland Chinese have made the Communist Party nervous, particularly in mainland China's present economic climate, the daily added.
The National Post, another major daily in Canada, also gave a prominent place to the reports, "Chinese police move against six dissidents" and a "new party [is] muffled."
The Post quoted the United States as saying, "It's a serious step in the wrong direction." Washington urged Beijing to free Xu at once, the newspaper noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OFFERS TO HELP INDONESIA HOLD ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Australia is offering Indonesia help on how to hold its first democratic elections in 1999, in which up to 130 million people will vote for their leaders.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told the federal Parliament on Wednesday that Australia would be willing to offer technical help in the massive task of running the elections and advice on how to develop a code of conduct to resolve differences and prevent disputes in the conducting of the poll.

Downer said Australian Electoral Commissioner Bill Gray recently went to Jakarta to make a preliminary assessment of what was needed for the 1999 elections in Indonesia, Australia's largest neighboring country.

"Australia after all is one of the world's oldest continuously operating democracies and we have a lot to offer," Downer said. "Our experience in holding elections means we are well placed to assist in areas such as computerization of the compilation of results and practical planning procedures for voting."
He said Australia was ready to help Indonesia "through this difficult transition to genuinely democratic administration."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE COPS STEP UP HUNT FOR SUSPECTED LETTER BOMBER

TEXT.P: Australian police have launched a hunt for a man believed to be in a car in Sydney on Wednesday after extensive searches located at least 25 letter bombs mailed from Canberra, one of which exploded while being handled by a mail sorter.

Police said 21 letter bombs were intercepted in Canberra, each wrapped in white paper, measuring 11 cm by 11 centimeters by 2 centimeters, all carried the home addresses of Canberra-based people, understood to include tax office and child support agency staff.

The letter bomb was devised from a soda siphon bulb with some mechanical device to cause it to trip -- and it had a quantity of smokeless powder inserted in it, Police Commissioner Bill Stoll told reporters.
He warned more bombs could be in the mail heading for private addresses in Sydney, New South Wales and Melbourne, and all of the letter bombs came from Canberra.

He said the dramatic event was unraveled after a female sorter in Canberra suspected a small white parcel weighing about 100 grams and threw it into an empty wheelie bin. The computer disk-shaped parcel exploded, sending small chips flying through the room, injuring postal workers slightly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN HIGH VALUE-ADDED INDUSTRIES TO INCREASE IN 1999

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) stipulated on Thursday that investment in high value-added industries is predicted to increase in the 1999 fiscal year.

In order to implement the Executive Yuan's Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center scheme, MOEA will select several high value-added, technology-intensive and less-polluting industries with market potential for promotion, said one MOEA representative.

According to the MOEA's estimation, the number of industries under promotion will reach 98, with a total investment value of NT$87.6 billion (US$2.7 billion) in the 1999 fiscal year. This represents 54 percent growth compared with 1998's figure.
Meanwhile, some 75 products will involve technology transformation in 1999, a growth of 6 percent over 1998's figure.

High value-added industries the MOEA have selected mainly include aviation and space and high-quality screen industries. In addition, promotion groups for information, biochemical technology, pharmaceutical and precision industries will be respectively established, one MOEA representative said.

The utmost responsibilities of the promotion groups are to make policies concerning the industry's development, technology research and development, and investment in related industries, said the MOEA. Other duties include creating a development environment and exploring and integrating resources that are required by industries.

There have been 35 investment projects under promotion as of the end of October in the 1999 fiscal year, with a total investment value of NT$32.67 billion (US$1 billion), the MOEA pointed out. Moreover, exploration projects of 14 new products have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELIGIBLE LEGISLATIVE VOTERS TOTAL 14.96 MILLION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission announced on Thursday that 14.96 million eligible voters in Taiwan, Matsu and Kinmen will elect 225 legislators out of 499 candidates in the national-level legislative elections on Saturday.
Of the 14.96 million eligible voters, 12.05 million will be in Taiwan province, with the remainder in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities and in Kinmen and Matsu counties of Fujian province.

Of the 225 legislative seats, 168 will be elected from among 383 candidates from local constituencies, 41 out of 87 candidates from proportional party representation, eight out of 15 candidates from aboriginal constituencies, and eight out of 12 candidates from overseas Chinese communities.

On the same day, a total of 1,868,860 voters in Taipei City will elect 52 councilors. They will also choose one of three candidates -- Ma Ying-jeou (Kuomintang), sitting Mayor Chen Shui-bian (Democratic Progressive Party) and Wang Chien-shien (New Party) -- for mayor.

Meanwhile, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, 1,004,872 voters will elect 44 councilors and choose the mayor from among four candidates -- incumbent mayor Wu Den-yih (KMT), Hsieh Chang-ting (DPP), Wu Chien-kuo (New Party) and Cheng Teh-yao (independent).
A total of 20 legislators will be elected from Taipei City, while 11 will be chosen from Kaohsiung City.
From Taipei County, the largest constituency in the Republic of China, 27 legislators are expected to be elected by 2.32 million voters.
From the northern county of Taoyuan, the second-largest constituency with eligible voters totaling 1.07 million, 12 legislators will be elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP'S CAMPAIGN MANAGER FACES LIBEL SUIT

TEXT.P: An independent Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Thursday accused New Party election campaign manager Jaw Shau-kong of libel.

Against the backdrop of a Kaohsiung election campaign fraught with libel suits, Cheng Te-yao, an independent candidate bidding for the municipality's mayorship, also went with the tide and filed a libel suit against Jaw.
Cheng was accompanied by a dozen supporters as he made the accusation at the local procuratorate, though without as much fanfare as other candidates.

Cheng said that Jaw's description of the campaign as a "dirty mudslinging fight" among rival candidates in the southern port city was an insult to both Kaohsiung's mayoral candidates and citizens of the city.
NP's Jaw should apologize to all citizens of Kaohsiung, stressed the independent candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT GIVES 18 YEARS TO TSINGHUA UNIVERSITY GRAD

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court on Thursday sentenced murder suspect Hung Hsiao-huei, who allegedly murdered and disfigured her classmate, Hsu Chia-chen, to 18 years in prison and a deprivation of her civil rights for 10 years.
The sentence includes a 15-year imprisonment for an "obvious intention of murdering" and 3.6 years for disfiguring the body.

The judgment of the High Court is basically identical to that of the Hsinchu district court, despite different opinions as to whether Hung had the intention of murdering. But this did not affect the final decision.
The Hsinchu district court considered Hung's intention as "unclear" while the High Court reckoned that Hung intended to kill Hsu.
The High Court believed that what led to the murder was Hung's unauthorized use of Hsu's credit card.

Regarding Hung's intent to murder, it was based on the fact that the victim was brutally beaten before she had poured upon her a powerful corrosive chemical, which disfigured her body and led to her death, at the crime scene. The alleged murderer furthermore dragged her body to the rear of the auditorium to keep it from being found.

This cold-blooded and shocking murder happened in Hsinchu last March. Hung, a graduate of National Tsinghua University's radiobiology institute, allegedly murdered and disfigured the body of Hsu, who was also a rival in a love triangle.

The Hsinchu district court sentenced Hung to 18 years' imprisonment, yet the prosecutor considered the conviction too lenient and appealed to the Supreme Court. Hung also appealed to the Supreme Court, believing her sentence too harsh.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar fell UT$0.016 against the New Taiwan dollar in the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at 32.404, the lowest level in nine months.
The greenback had a high of 32.428 and a low of 32.39 after opening at 32.401.
Interbank transactions expanded to more than US$300 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CANDIDATE FOR TAIPEI MAYORSHIP TALKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate for the Taipei City mayorship on Thursday stressed that the development of cross-strait relations should be promoted under circumstances in which Taiwan's dignity and safety is maintained.
Ma Ying-jeou said that if he wins the weekend election, he will lead Taipei to engage in city-to-city diplomacy with mainland China.

Ma made the remarks during a press conference at his election campaign headquarters, in which the hopeful introduced his experience in joining the government's works on mainland affairs, including the establishment of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the semi-official Strait Exchanges Foundation.

He has also participated in drafting the "Guidelines for National Unification," which outline the principles and steps that both sides across the Taiwan Strait can take to expedite China's reunification, and the "Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area" covering administrative, civil and criminal affairs, the former MAC vice chairman said.

With experienced knowledge on mainland affairs and contributions to building systematized channels for cross-strait dialogues, the KMT candidate introduced himself as one of the experts who can offer suggestions on the government's current mainland policy.
Ma stressed Taipei can never accept Beijing proposed "one China, two systems" formula, while Taiwan must insist on its equivalent status to mainland China as both sides seek China's reunification.

"This is reality, not merely an opinion," Ma stressed, noting he believes that the central government should be fully responsible for the initiation and implementation of mainland policy, while the Taipei mayor should not take part in making policy.

The candidate for the city mayorship added, however, that if he is elected to serve the position, he is willing to visit the mainland in his capacity as city mayor as soon as the government ends its ban on mainland China visits by local government leaders.

But his visit must be on equal footing, meaning that if the mainland side invites him on a mainland Chinese trip by merely titling him "Taiwanese celebrity Ma Ying-jeou," he will never accept the invitation, Ma stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES INCREASE US$4 BILLION IN TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves increased US$3.83 billion in the last two months, the highest rise since the Asian financial turmoil began in the latter half of 1997, according to government statistics.

Reserves as of the end of November stood at US$88.07 billion, the highest level for 16 months, and an increase of US$1.52 billion over the previous month, breaking the record for single-month growth since the start of the Asian crisis, according to the figures released by the Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China (CBC).

The Asian financial turbulence caused Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves to drop continuously since the second half of 1997, plunging to US$82.92 billion at the end of October 1997 from July's US$90.25 billion.
Recovery did not begin until the latter half of 1998, when the reserves increased to US$84.25 billion by the end of September, and rose again to US$86.56 billion at the end of October.

Looking forward to the end of December, officials of the foreign exchange department said that as long as the NT dollar remains strong against the greenback, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves should break the US$90 billion mark again. Taiwan still enjoys the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves.

The CBC's continuous purchase of foreign exchange, in addition to incessant inflow of foreign capital into the domestic stock market, were cited by foreign exchange traders as the reasons behind the huge increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA DELEGATION TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Secretary-General Ricky Y.S. Kao is to lead a delegation of local semiconductor makers on a visit to California's Silicon Valley.

Twelve of Taiwan's leading semiconductor firms, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronix International, United Micro Electronics, and Winbond Electronics Corp., will be represented by the delegation.
Business turnover of these 12 companies accounts for 58 percent of the total output of the island's semiconductor industry, according to figures from the semi-official CETRA.

CETRA said that Kao and several Taiwan industry leaders will give keynote speeches to introduce Taiwan's semiconductor sector, and the delegates will introduce their newest products and services at the Westin Hotel in Santa Clara on Dec. 9.

The trade promotion body will also sponsor a seminar on Dec. 10 with the aim of forging cooperative ventures between Taiwan and the United States. More than 200 representatives from 140 US companies, including IBM, HP, Cirrus, and Oracle, will be seeking business opportunities at the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETURNING ROC EXPATRIATES ADD TO ELECTION FEVER

TEXT.P: A number of ROC expatriates have returned in the past week to campaign for their favorite candidates in the three critical elections scheduled for Saturday, immigration sources said on Thursday.

As the Dec. 5 elections for the national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of the island's two special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- are expected to have a significant impact on Taiwan's future political development, many ROC nationals residing abroad have decided to make best use of their voting rights.
"The return of overseas eligible Taiwan voters has added to the election fever here and is expected to reach a peak on the eve of election day," said an immigration official.

According to the official, the number of inbound passengers from the United States has increased by about 10 percent in recent days, while trade sources said many Taiwan business people in mainland China have either already returned or will return before Friday evening to exercise their "sacred right" to vote.

Industry sources said the tight Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral races are a primary driving force behind the recent "homecoming rush" among mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen, particularly those in southeastern coastal mainland provinces.

Some Taiwan businessmen are only expected to stay in Taipei overnight, and will return to the mainland as soon as they have cast their ballots on Saturday, due to their busy schedules, industry sources said.

They further divulged that the hotly contested Taipei mayoral race, and the recent spate of local corporate financial crises, have been the hottest topics in the Taiwan business communities in southeastern mainland provinces in the past few months.

A senior executive with a Taiwan investors association in the southern mainland city of Shenzhen told a local newspaper that most mainland-based Taiwan businessmen are concerned about the island's political development.
"Most of them would like to see Taiwan continue to develop in a secure, stable environment," said the executive, who preferred anonymity.
Meanwhile, airline sources said many ROC expatriates residing in the United States and Europe have also returned in recent weeks to take part in the elections.

One airline executive said that while the pre-Christmas period is usually an off-peak season for US-Taiwan flight services, occupancy rates for Taiwan-bound flights from the United States have remained high in the past few weeks.
China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's former flag-carrier, said it has offered special discounts for US-based ROC expatriates who are eligible to vote.
"Market response to our promotional program has been very encouraging. The overall occupancy rate has increased by about 10 percent compared with the same period of last year," said a CAL spokesman.

EVA Airways said even though it has not offered any special promotional package, the number of its Taiwan-bound passengers from the United States has also registered a 10 percent rise in recent weeks.
The Overseas Affairs Department of the ruling Kuomintang has worked hard over the past few months to mobilize eligible overseas Chinese to return to campaign and vote.

KMT officials said a number of overseas Chinese in 28 countries around the world have returned to campaign for KMT candidates, including a 212-member group from the US west coast which returned earlier this week to campaign for Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT's candidate for the Taipei mayorship.
On the other hand, more than 200 supporters of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have also returned to canvass votes for incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a DPP stalwart.
Meanwhile, airline sources said a record number of candidates for the three elections and their campaign aides have also made reservations for overseas trips after the vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Grand Justice Weng Yueh-sheng and National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien will be named presidents of the Judicial Yuan and the Control Yuan, respectively.
The China Times:
President Lee Teng-hui nominated Grand Justice Weng Yueh-sheng as president of the Judicial Yuan.
The United Daily News:
The central government will undergo a partial reshuffle, with Grand Justice Weng Yueh-sheng and Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo serving as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, while National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien and Control Yuan Member Chen Meng-ling as president and vice president of the Control Yuan.
The Liberty Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS OF TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 4, or Oct. 16 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek leaves Loyang for Sian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang Army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular instead of Latin in the Sacraments.
1963: A Kuomintang Central Standing Committee meeting approves the resignation of Premier Chen Cheng (concurrently vice president), and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7" which orbits the earth for a new record of 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guards arrest communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han, and Wan Li.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes Central African Kingdom and President Jean Bedel Bokassa crowned king.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing all aboard.
1989: East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, chairman steps down.
1991: Terry Anderson, the last of a group of Americans held hostage by Shiite kidnappers since March 16, 1985, is released in Beirut, Lebanon.
1994: US Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first US secretary to carry out the new US policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD HELP ACCELERATE TAIWAN'S WTO ADMISSION: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States should free itself from its political bondage with Beijing and accelerate its push for Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), an Asian analyst with a Washington think-tank said on Thursday.

Greg Mastel, vice president of the Economic Strategy Institute (ESI) in Washington, said the United States should accelerate efforts on Taiwan's WTO admission not only because the Taiwan markets are open enough to qualify itself for WTO membership, but because the admission is in line with President Clinton's "three noes" policy toward Taiwan.
Most importantly, Mastel noted, the United States' acceleration on Taiwan's WTO admission can result in more pressure on Beijing to open its own markets.

At an ESI-sponsored workshop on mainland China's joining the WTO, Mastel professed that the United States plays the "Taiwan card," saying that it is time for the Clinton administration to push forward with Taiwan's bid to join the WTO.

Mastel, an economist whose expertise includes US trade policy, also wrote in The Commercial Times recently to urge Washington to vigorously support Taiwan's bid to join the WTO. By doing so, he said, Washington is intensifying the United States' long-heralded policy of opposing political intervention in WTO operations and simply considering the business and trade conditions of the applicant nations.

He noted that the United States' attempt to have Taiwan admitted into the WTO before mainland China may not succeed, but Washington is sending a strong message regarding its determination simply by making the move.

Mastel said since the United States has already expressed the belief that Taiwan's trade regime is open enough to qualify itself to enter the WTO, Washington should not be restricted by political barriers from Beijing in the regard.

Moreover, he said, Taiwan is applying for a membership under the name of a single customs territory, which does not run counter to President Clinton's "three noes" policy of not supporting Taiwan's independence, "one China, one Taiwan" or Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood.

As Washington-Beijing bilateral consultations on mainland China's WTO admission have stagnated, Mastel said the United States should push for Taiwan's early WTO admission to intensify pressure on Beijing on the one hand, while using trade weapons, such as its "301 list" to push mainland China to further open its markets on the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: WENG WILL DO A BETTER JOB: SHIH CHI-YANG

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui nominated on Thursday senior Grand Justice Weng Yueh-Sheng as Judicial Yuan president, according to a news release from the presidential office.

Incumbent Judicial Yuan President Shih Chi-yang said on Friday that he is glad to be leaving the post and strongly believes that Grand Justice Weng will do an even better job than Shih as Judicial Yuan president.

Both Shih and Weng graduated from the law department of National Taiwan University, where Shih was two years ahead of Weng. In addition, both of them pursued their graduate study in Germany's Heidelberg University, where Weng was one year ahead of Shih. In addition to having been friends for a long time, the two have also been schoolmates and even roommates.

Shih will still be a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui after his resignation. Shih asserted that judicial reform can never slow down and he will continue to promote this idea in academic circles.

Weng and some other grand justices called on Shih on Friday morning to show their respect. "President Lee considers judicial reform as important, and expects that judicial reform could be accelerated," said Weng. Weng added that while he has less experience in judicial administration, he will definitely do his best in this post.

Concerning Shih's measures to promote judicial reform, such as holding national judicial reform conferences and imposing restrictions on the chief justice's term of office, Weng pointed out that his policies cannot be announced until the National Assembly formally approves his appointment.

Weng was born in the countryside of Chiayi in southern Taiwan in 1932. He was first appointed grand justice during the Council of Grand Justice's third term and was re-appointed an unprecedented three times. The senior-most grand justice, Weng is highly respected in academic and legal circles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST SEMICONDUCTOR CONFERENCE IN US

TEXT.P: Taiwan will host the Taiwan-US Semiconductor Conference of 1998 from Dec. 9 to 10 in Santa Clara, located within the United States' Silicon Valley, to help promote cooperative relationships between semiconductor businesses and manufacturers in Taiwan and the United States.

The two-day conference is being sponsored by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Committee for Information Industry Development, with the support of several Republic of China commercial and industry associations, including the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA), the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association and the Monte Jade Science and Technology Association (MJSTA).

TSIA and MJSTA leaders have been invited to deliver speeches during the conference on Taiwan's current semiconductor development. Conference attendees will include representatives from various fields within the semiconductor and electronic system industries.

CETRA will lead a delegation comprising representatives from Taiwan's top 12 enterprises in the semiconductor industry to the high-profile meeting, in which the representatives are to present their company's latest developments in areas such as integrated circuit (IC) design, manufacturing, packaging and testing, as well as global logistics and service.

The companies are also scheduled to hold one-on-one meetings with participating US businesses during the conference to discuss technology transfers, procurement issues, joint ventures and original equipment manufacturing (OEM) business opportunities
Around 200 representatives of 140 US businesses are expected to participate in the conference, which will be presided over by CETRA General-Secretary Ricky Kao.

Taiwan companies participating in the meeting are Acer Semiconductor, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronix International, United Micro Electronics, Powerchip, Winbond Electronics, Global Uni Chip, Integrated Technology, Worldwide Semiconductor, Orient Semiconductor, Advanced Semiconductor and Walsin Advance, according to CETRA.
The combined output of those 12 companies accounts for 58 percent of the total output from Taiwan's semiconductor industry, CETRA said.

Taiwan's semiconductor production value is the fourth largest in the world, following the United States, Japan and South Korea. Its share of the global market, however, totals only 3 percent, which means there is still ample room for Taiwan to push into global markets, CETRA officials said.
Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers have to globalize and enhance their competitiveness by forging cooperation and strategic alliances with large enterprises worldwide, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CORRECTS ANTI-DUMPING DUTIES FOR TAIWAN STEEL PRODUCTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The US Commerce Department announced on Thursday a reduction on anti-dumping duties on imported stainless steel plates in coils from Taiwan from 67.68 percent to 3.08 percent.

The department explained that the initial percentage was the result of negligence in the filling out of administrative paperwork. Due to this error, however, Taiwan's steel exports could not get through customs until the guaranty money was paid.

The department made a preliminary determination of anti-dumping duties on Oct. 28, when it levied duties on imports from Taiwan, South Korea, Belgium, Italy, Canada and South Africa. The duties resulted from the United States' belief that those countries were dumping stainless steel plates in coils on the US market at unfairly low prices. The duties varied among countries, and Taiwan's was the highest among the group.

Tachen International Stainless Steel Co., a US-based affiliate of Tachen Stainless Steel Co., was accused by the US steel industry of helping its mother company and another Taiwan company to sell their steel at unfairly low prices. The department determined Tachen International was dumping steel on the US market, and as a result, preliminary anti-dumping duties were also applied to this affiliate.
A public hearing will be held in the middle of December to listen to legal consultants from Tachen and the US steel industry before a final decision on the matter is made.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE STRESSES ACADEMIA'S NEUTRALITY IN POLITICS

TEXT.P: As a member of the Republic of China's foremost academic research body, Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee on Friday stated his position that academia should be neutral when it comes to politics.

Lee, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986, said in a formal statement he was in no way involved with campaign advertisements that have appeared recently which show him supporting Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian.
Lee called the ads the "personal actions of the candidate."

Lee made the statement after being besieged with phone calls and inquiries about his political affiliation in the wake of the appearance of ads, both in print and on television, showing him speaking in support of Chen, a Democratic Progressive Party candidate seeking re-election.
He stressed that the campaign ads were Chen's doing and that his stance on remaining neutral in politics has never changed.

The ad depicts Lee praising Chen as a good mayor and is based on footage obtained during a ceremony marking the inauguration of an Academia Sinica activity center in Nankang, suburban Taipei, earlier this year.
"It is not a good phenomenon, dragging me into the elections," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH STOCK AND FUTURES PRICES RISE

TEXT.P: Share prices climbed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, the last trading day before the island's "three-in-one" elections on Saturday.
The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rose 55.13 points to close at 7,195.24 during the three-hour session.
A total of 2.65 billion shares exchanged hands on a market turnover of NT$94.42 billion (US$2.9 billion), compared with NT$69.76 billion in the previous session.

Losers and gainers were mixed among the eight major stock categories, with construction issues posting the largest growth at 1.7 percent; meanwhile, electronic engineering shares rose 1.2 percent, plastic and chemical stocks grew 0.9 percent, financial issues moved up 0.8 percent and cement stocks posted a modest gain of 0.1 percent.
Paper and pulp issues dropped 0.3 percent, and both foodstuff and textile shares fell 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's stock index futures also saw light gains in Friday's session.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December moved up 63 points from the previous session, closing at 7,384, with 2,017 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for January rose 64 points to 7,435, with 180 contract transactions, while those for March climbed 47 points to finish at 7,419, those for June surged 102 points to 7,420 and those for September soared 148 points to 7,400.
Transactions for these three months totaled nine, three and one, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,321 points for December; 7,371 points for January; 7,372 points for March; 7,318 points for June; and 7,252 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO MAKE TRANSIT STOP IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By David Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Lien Chan will make a transit stop in New York on his way to a four-country Central American visit, reliable sources said on Thursday.
According to the sources, Lien will arrive in New York on Saturday (local time) and is scheduled to leave for Nicaragua via a chartered plane on Monday.
Lien is expected to abide by a tacit agreement with the US State Department that he will neither engage in any public activities nor meet with journalists during his transit stay in New York.

Nevertheless, Chinese-language media and Taiwan journalists stationed in New York are still gearing up in preparations for Lien's arrival. They hope to know whether Lien will secretly meet with any VIPs during his New York stay.

Taiwan journalists stationed here also plan to ask Lien about his comments on the outcome of the island's Dec. 5 elections for the national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung, the island's two largest cities.
Lien will leave Taipei right after casting his ballots for the three critical elections. He is expected to be informed of the election returns on his flight to New York.
The Chinese community here is concerned about the election outcome as it is expected to have a significant impact on Taiwan's future political development.
Lien will visit four hurricane-stricken countries -- Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador -- on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui.
In addition to extending the ROC government and people's concern to the four Central American allies, Lien will discuss with their top leaders feasible ways to assist them in reconstruction.
Lien will be accompanied by a small entourage on his Central American tour. Key members of his entourage will included Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to President Lee.
Following his four-leg Central American visit, Lien will also make a transit stop in Los Angeles on Dec. 12 on his way home.

It remains unclear whether Lien has any undisclosed itinerary during his upcoming overseas visit. In the past, Lien had often made impromptu, unofficial visits to countries which recognize Beijing instead of Taipei.

In the face of mainland China's diplomatic strangulation strategy against Taiwan, senior ROC officials have often had to keep their overseas visits secret. In some cases, they were forced to cancel their travel plans because of Beijing's protests to host countries.

The Republic of China government has offered a total of US$2.6 million in relief aid to the four Central American countries after they were ravaged by the hurricane. Moreover, several large Taiwan charity organizations have also launched fund-raising campaigns to pool private resources for various relief programs.

The ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs also hosted a fund-raising dinner earlier this week to help Central American victims. Many local celebrities reserved seats at the NT$10,000 (US$308) per plate dinner at Grand Hyatt Taipei hotel to throw their support behind the fund-raising drive.

The ministry has also launched a separate campaign dubbed "Sending Our Love to Central America," to raise funds for the hurricane victims, and has opened special accounts with the International Commercial Bank of China and the Post Office, to which members of the public can remit donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR AUSTRALIAN NEWSPAPER TAKES NOTE OF TAIWAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The election battle in Taipei between Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Ma Ying-jeou was featured as a highlight recently in the largest business newspaper in Australia, and the daily regards the competition as a possible warm-up for Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.

Australian Finanical Review correspondent Rowan Callick reported the focus is in Taipei where Chen, the highest-profile figure in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is competing against Ma, a popular and glamorous politician with the Kuomintang.
Whereas the DPP favors independence for Taiwan, the KMT prefers eventual reunification with mainland China.
The daily reported both Chen and Ma are regarded as likely candidates to replace President Lee Teng-hui in 2000 when the next presidential election takes place.

Callick's three-column article, titled "The Bad Blood in Taipei," appeared on the "World Page" of the newspaper on Friday, along with a Reuters picture showing Ma holding incense and praying to Kuan Kung, a Chinese deity, for the good luck on election day, Dec. 5.

The daily quoted Martin Lee of Hong Kong's Democratic Party as saying, "We always look at the mainland, Taiwan and Hong Kong together in terms of fundamental democracy, and of course here (Taiwan) clearly ranks No. 1."
The daily also mentioned Taiwan's economic growth of 5 percent this year and its huge foreign exchange reserves, one of the biggest in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN OLYMPIC COMMITTEE ALLOWED TO SEARCH ATHLETES' BAGS

TEXT.P: The Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) has won the right to search Australian athletes' bags and clothing for banned drugs at the 2000 Games in Sydney in a move to fight doping.

AOC President John Coates said on Thursday his committee has put a new clause in its Athletes Agreement for the 2000 Olympic Games, a contract all athletes must sign before they are selected for Australia, which gives the committee "search and seizure" powers.
Coates said the search will also apply to team officials, because the measure would prevent drug trafficking by the team and protect athletes who may inadvertently pack a banned substance.

Coates said the AOC would not use the power lightly. "We will be very, very cautious about doing it. It's certainly not something we would do as a matter of routine, but it does address difficulties Australian cycling had in America and Italy this year," he said.
