DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS MALAWIAN DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday met with visiting Malawian Defense Minister Joseph Petro Kubwalo and his wife at the Presidential Office, where they exchanged views on issues of mutual concern.
Lee expressed appreciation for the Malawian government's strong support for the Republic of China on Taiwan in the international arena.

Lee said the ROC and Malawi have maintained close and cordial relations. The ROC, besides striving to further develop itself, is also highly willing to help out other friendly countries, he said, adding that Taipei is particularly willing to offer agricultural and medical aid to Malawi. The government will also continue to encourage more Taiwan investment in the African country, he said.
As an agronomist before turning to politics, Lee said he is very concerned about Malawi's economic and agricultural development, adding that how to help Malawi has always been on his mind.

For his part, Kubwalo expressed Malawi's appreciation for the Republic of China for its long-term aid and assistance. He said Malawi has been and will be the ROC's staunch and faithful friend, and that it will continue to voice its support for the Republic of China in the international community.

Kubwalo, who along with his wife is visiting Taiwan for five days as a guest of ROC Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling, said Malawi hopes that the Republic of China will also share with his country its experience in military development, even though the southern part of Africa, where the country is located, is currently at peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES US CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui received US congressman Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), on Friday and said that he hopes the United States will maintain its defense committments to Taiwan.
"The Republic of China is already a real democratic and liberal country," said Representative Rohrabacher, who is in Taiwan to observe the island's "three-in-one" elections on Saturday.

In the aftermath of US President Clinton's state visit to mainland China, the US Congress approved an unanimous resolution reaffirming its support of the Republic of China, said President Lee, adding that this resolution will greatly contribute to balancing US policies toward mainland China and Taiwan.

"Communist China has never renounced its use of force against Taiwan and even intimidated Taiwan through military exercises during the 1996 ROC presidential election," said Lee. Lee said he expects the United States will continue to provide defensive weapons to Taiwan.

Rohrabacher, a strong supporter of Taiwan in the US Congress, said Taiwan should be considered the focus of the United States' security concerns in Asia. He has also given full support to a proposal to include Taiwan in the US anti- ballistic missile defense system.

Rohrabacher also talked to President Lee about holding a "Free Asia Concert" in Taipei, which would bring to Taiwan popular music stars from the United States as well as Asia. President Lee replied that music is the best international language and that he is looking forward to the realization of this concert.

Rohrabacher was accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee Tawei and Darryl Johnson, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, during his call on Lee. Also present at the meeting were National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mao-shih and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC PREDICTS ABOVE 80 PERCENT TURNOUT FOR TAIPEI MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of registered voters in Taipei are expected to take part in Saturday's mayoral election, a voter turnout higher than those in the 1994 mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the top official of the Central Election Commission (CEC) predicted Friday.

Chien Tai-lang, CEC's secretary-general, said that since the three candidates in the upcoming Taipei mayoral election are all considered outstanding, voters are particularly inclined to go to the polls.
The total population of Taiwan as of June 30, 1998, numbered 21.83 million, of which 14.96 million were eligible voters, according to statistics released by the CEC.

On Saturday the 1,868,860 residents of Taipei City eligible to vote will choose from among three candidates -- Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang, sitting Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Wang Chien-shien of the New Party (NP) -- for mayor.

Meanwhile, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, 1,004,872 registered voters will elect a mayor from among four candidates -- incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yih of the KMT, Hsieh Chang-ting of the DPP, Wu Chien-kuo of the NP and independent candidate Cheng Teh-yao.

In view of the fact that 80.65 percent of Kaohsiung's voters and 78.54 percent of Taipei's voters took part in their cities' respective mayoral elections in 1994, while 76.12 percent of voters took part in national legislative elections, it is evident that Taiwan has traveled quickly along the road of democracy, said Chien.

Looking ahead to the forthcoming three-in-one elections -- mayoral and city councilor elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, and national-level legislative elections -- Chien pointed out that the intense competition among candidates will surely stimulate voter turnout. He predicted voter turnout on Saturday could hit a record high of 82 percent.
The current record is the 80.65 percent turnout recorded in Kaohsiung's 1994 mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS SHOULD NOT STUMP FOR CANDIDATES: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Friday it is inappropriate for foreign nationals to stump for candidates in Taiwan's political elections.

Shen Lyu-shun, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, made the statement in response to reports that Austrian Trade Delegate to Taiwan Ingomar Locheshmidt stumped for Frank Hsieh, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for the Kaohsiung City mayorship, on Thursday evening.

Shen said he will have to investigate further to determine whether or not Locheshmidt's action violated Republic of China law. "Nevertheless, even if such a move was legal, it was not appropriate," he noted.

Shen went on to say that some American and Canadian nationals have voluntarily organized observation groups to watch the run-up to the ROC's Dec. 5 elections for the national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung, the island's two special municipalities.
"MOFA has not extended invitations to them, but we welcome their visits," Shen said, adding that the ministry has adopted a neutral, impartial stand in receiving foreign observation groups.

For example, if a foreign group has asked to visit a specific political party's campaign headquarters, the ministry has consistently arranged for the group to also visit the campaign offices of other major political parties.

Many observation groups from mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau have also come to Taiwan in recent days to see for themselves the island's three critical elections which are expected to have a significant impact on the island's future political development.

In addition, major news organizations in Hong Kong, Japan, the United States, Europe, and many other countries have also sent journalists to Taiwan to cover the elections, particularly the hotly contested Taipei mayoral race.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER URGES WIDENING OF IT APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Friday urged the information technology (IT) industry to improve Taiwan's competitiveness by expanding the applications of information technology.
Liu made the statement during the inauguration of an "IT Month Exhibition."
The total output of Taiwan's IT hardware products ranks third worldwide, yet Taiwan's IT industry produces only 6 percent as much software as it does hardware.
A widening of IT applications is needed, Liu said.
To achieve this goal, the government has planned to spend NT$ 8.7 billion to speed up the construction of a national information communication network.
The island's communication network is expected to be completed by the end of 1999, by which point all elementary schools will be equipped with the necessary facilities for web surfing, Liu said.

The number of people in Taiwan who use the World Wide Web is expected to reach 2.8 million by the end of 1998, yet the number of people in Taiwan who use other computer applications -- such as word processing, video conferencing and e-mail -- lags far behind those of other technology advanced countries, Liu added.

It is critical for Taiwan to adapt to future challenges, such as the Y2K crisis, brought about by the advent of information society. The Republic of China government is drafting contingency plans in anticipation of these challenges, Liu said, as he urged industries to face these challenges with greater concern.

The exhibition has entered its 19th year. It is the world's third-largest computer exhibition, trailing only the Comdex Show in Las Vegas of the United States and an annual IT exhibition in Hanover, Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HITS NEW HIGH IN 9 MONTHS ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar hit a new high in nearly nine months against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday to finish at 32.36, UP NT$0.044 on the previous day's close.
Interbank US dollar transactions amounted to US$589 million, the highest level in two weeks.
The local currency opened at 32.386 and fluctuated between 32.315 and 32.395.
The NT dollar's going strong Friday attributed mainly to heavy selling pressure of the US dollar and the continuous inflow of the hard currency from abroad.
The local currency has got its stream for four consecutive trading sessions with a cumulative gains of NT$0.069.

Dealers said that the Central Bank of China will probably intervene by buying the greenback in the next trading sessions in a bid to prevent the NT dollar from appreciating too fast, a factor that may cause a negative influence on the growth of Taiwan's exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN HEROIN SMUGGLER ARRESTED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A Malaysian man carrying heroin and traveling on a fake passport was arrested at the Kaohsiung airport on Thursday as he tried to enter the country on a flight from Thailand.

The Malaysian was carrying a counterfeit passport in the name of Hong Chang-wen, and the airport police bureau has requested the assistance of Malaysian representatives in Taipei to ascertain his true identity.

The suspect was detained and searched after airport police became suspicious of his passport, which contained a flawed rubber-stamp. A package of heroin weighing 712.46 grams was subsequently found inside his underwear.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1999 MACROECONOMIC POLICY HIGHLIGHTS ECONOMIC UPGRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has initiated "economic upgrade," "government reform," and "social reform" as three key components of the country's 1999 macroeconomic policy.

The government, meanwhile, is also urged to make more efforts to expand the nation's diplomatic relations and to improve the links between Taiwan and mainland China, according to the CEPD's newly completed 1999 National Development Plan.

The CEPD, the designer of Taiwan's economic development policy, pointed out in the plan that the island's economy will continue to be hammered by the continuing Asian financial crisis and that the island will have to further strengthen development and accelerate its national modernization to tide over the crisis.

In order to achieve this, promoting a comprehensive economic upgrade, expanding domestic consumer demand, and building up an effective crisis management mechanism will be the top priorities in the effort to stabilize economic growth.

"Economic upgrade" was especially highlighted in the national development plan, through an improved environment for scientific and technological development, construction of science-based industrial parks, and promotion of the development of the high-tech and value-added industries.

In addition, to further open the financial market and strengthen the island's financial operation systems and legal controls, along with continuing to promote the 12 major construction projects and set up islandwide modern transportation networks, are also leading tasks for the country's economic establishment in the coming year, according to the plan.

Under the heading "government reform," efficient service and healthy financial administration are the principal goals, while tasks for "social reform" include the improvement of social order, the promotion of social welfare, and educational reform.

As to how to expand the nation's diplomatic profile and improve cross-strait relations, the national plan suggests the maintenance of a powerful military deterrent force, while keeping up the efforts to participate in international activities and promote cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS STAND CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: The biggest setback for the United Nations' system for protection of human rights was mainland China's successful lobbying to persuade its Western trading partners to abandon any effort at a resolution at the Commission on Human Rights session in Geneva critical of its practice, according to the Human Rights Watch.

The human rights watchdog group noted in its World Report 1999 released Thursday in Washington,D.C. that despite some encouraging developments, mainland China's human rights practices remain cause for concern.

On the positive side, this past year intellectuals had greater freedom to debate political and economic reform; some notable prisoners were released, including the 1989 student leader Wang Dan; community-based organizations continued to emerge; and the Beijing government signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

At the same time, however, the annual report said, strict controls remained on expression, association and assembly, with political and religious dissidents, labor activists, and supporters of nationalist movements often facing arrest and detention.

Western governments seized on tentative signs of tolerance to strengthen calls for engagement, a desirable goal, but one that in policy terms all too often meant silence on mainland China's egregious human rights record. Visits of world leaders to mainland China were marked more by symbolism than substance and were often accompanied by preventive detention of known dissidents.

In general, the Human Rights Watch wrote, mainland China "played an obstructionist role in efforts to strengthen international human rights," most notably in discussions on the International Criminal Court. The government in Beijing took a largely hands-off approach to the Special Administration Region (SAR) of Hong Kong, but this may have been due to the generally pro-Beijing policies of the SAR government.

While the annual commemoration of the June 4 Tiananmen Square massacre passed without incident in Hong Kong, and demonstrations in general were permitted to go forward, many pointed out that no incident had occurred in 1998 that really tested the "one country, two systems" principle. As the economy continues to worsen and the prospect of social unrest increases, "the test might not be long in coming," noted the organization.

President Jiang Zemin's apparently successful consolidation of power during the year and the appointment in March of Zhu Rongji as premier led to speculation that the two might work in tandem to promote limited political reform.

The human rights world report said the appearance of books that would earlier have been banned, such as one linking corruption to the lack of checks in the political structure, and greater tolerance of public demonstrations during the year seemed to point in that direction.

But mainland China specialists pointed out that such openings, followed by crackdowns, have happened so often in mainland China at times when they served the interests of those in power that "it would be foolhardy to conclude that this represented any lasting liberalization."

Greater scope for scholarly discussion of reform did not mean increased tolerance of political dissent. Those who publicly challenged the Communist Party, organized petitions to senior officials on political issues, maintained links to dissidents abroad, or had contacts with the foreign media were particularly vulnerable to arrest and detention, added the report, citing many such incidents.

The Human Rights Watch continued that a few notable prisoners were released at politically opportune moments, but hundreds, perhaps thousands, of prisoners were still serving long sentences for non-violent activities, and many dissidents were sentenced during the year to re-education through labor.

The human rights situation in Tibet also remained a major source of concern, according to the report. At the end of 1997, Beijing government officials made clear that a campaign against the Dalai Lama and pro-independence forces would continue.

Throughout 1998, a campaign was carried out to force Tibetans, especially monks and nuns, to denounce the Dalai Lama, accept the child recognized by mainland Chinese authorities as the Panchen Lama, and admit that Tibet has always been a part of mainland China. Monks and nuns who refused to be re-educated faced expulsion.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S ARREST OF DISSIDENTS COULD HURT TIES WITH US

TEXT.P: Mainland China's arrests of key dissidents and crackdown on an infant opposition party is set to sour its relations with the United States.
Beijing authorities have accused one of the arrested dissidents, Xu Wenli, of breaching mainland Chinese law, meaning he could face another lengthy prison term.
The crackdown has stunned the United States with the White House lodging a strong protest through its embassy in Beijing over the arrests of Xu and his fellow veteran activist, Qin Yongmin.
The US State Department also condemned the arrests, according to a report by The Sydney Morning Herald from Beijing on Friday.

The 55-year-old Xu is probably the highest-profile political dissident remaining in mainland China, according to the daily. He has served 12 years in prison after taking part in the ill-fated 1979 Democracy Wall Movement.
Despite the US protests, Beijing has warned Washington not to interfere in mainland China's domestic affairs.
The daily quoted foreign diplomats as saying that the relations between Beijing and Washington could turn sour following the arrests of political dissidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS DOWN DOWN UNDER

TEXT.P: About 7.1 million Australians, more than a third of its total population of 18.5 million, used antidepressants between 1990 and 1997, according to a survey.

The survey shows the use of antidepressants surged 47 percent in seven years as the introduction of Prozac and other new drugs spurred an unprecedented demand for medication, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Friday.

Only 5.1. million Australians used antidepressants in 1990, according to figures from the Commonwealth's Drug Utilization Subcommittee. The figures will be presented to a pharmacology conference in Sydney next week.
Professor Philip Mitchell of the University of New South Wales predicted that antidepressants use would plateau, but could not predict when this would happen.
He said antidepressants have been used to treat a wider range of illnesses, including panic disorders and obsessive and compulsive disorders.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE EXPATRIATES ALERTED AS SITUATION WORSENS IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australian expatriates in Indonesia were put on alert by their ambassador as violence and lawlessness rise in Jakarta and other cities in the world's biggest Islamic country.

In a dispatch from Jakarta, Sydney Morning Herald correspondent Louise Williams reported Australian Ambassador to Indonesia John McCarthy had urged more than 3,000 Australian expatriates to be prepared for emergency evacuation if violence and lawlessness Spread out of control in Jakarta and other cities.
Hundreds of Australian expatriates packed a Jakarta hotel ballroom on Wednesday night to hear McCarthy advise them to review emergency procedures.
Resident Australians, estimated to number more than 3,000, probably face a higher risk from criminal gangs than from political demonstrations, McCarthy said.
In May this year, thousands of Australians joined an exodus of foreigners during protests that forced former President Suharto to resign.
It was understood that the Royal Australian Air Force had its helicopters on standby at an Indonesian air base in case foreigners had to be shuttled out of the city to Jakarta's airport.
Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged Australians at home to avoid unnecessary travel to Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA ACTIVE ON FOREIGN POLICY FRONT IN 1998

TEXT.P: The activism that mainland China has brought to its foreign policy this year has eclipsed anything seen since the Communists came in power in 1949, an influential European newspaper said Thursday.
The latest manifestation was the six-day trip by Jiang Zemin, mainland China's president, to Japan, which ended Monday.

"The trip was not a success -- the two sides argued about Japan's behavior in the second world war -- but the mere fact that Mr. Jiang chose to go there at all was significant: He was the first Chinese head of state to visit Japan in his country's thousands of years of history," The Financial Times said.
"His visit reveals a new extroversion in Chinese diplomacy and made the visit a milestone in an annus mirabilis for China's foreign relations," according to the paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO PROTEST BEIJING ARRESTS OF DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: Canada is going to protest mainland China's arrests of dissidents in spite of a warning from Beijing that other countries have no right to interfere.

A Canadian Foreign Affairs Ministry official was quoted as saying on Wednesday: "We deplore the reported arrest of political dissidents in China. We urge China to release all persons who have been detained for the expression of their political beliefs."

The National Post quoted the spokesman, Sean Rowan, as adding that Canada's embassy in Beijing is requesting an urgent meeting with mainland Chinese officials to lodge a formal protest with mainland Chinese authorities.
The Post said Monday's arrests of leading members of the fledgling China Democracy Party has brought an abrupt end to a brief but flourishing period of political moderation and public debate.

At the same time, the arrests are a slap in the face to Western leaders, like Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien, who have publicly urged mainland China to adopt a more tolerant and transparent approach to political dissent, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA SAYS CATHAY MAY YET BUY INTO PAL

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada said Thursday Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways is willing to reopen negotiations to buy into Philippine Airlines (PAL).

In a press conference at his Greenhills, San Juan, residence, the president said Cathay's management wrote him a letter about its willingness to hammer out a deal with PAL management on a recovery program for the financially distressed airline.
Estrada said he will wait for PAL Chairman Lucio Tan, who is now in Guam, to return so the meeting can take place, but pointed out that the actual negotiations could take weeks or even months.
"So let us not lose hope. I'm just waiting for the return of Mr. Tan. I'll talk to him, maybe there's still a chance for them to come to an agreement," he said.
"I hope that PAL will have enough money to continue its operations. So I'm not giving up because the management of Cathay wrote a letter and said they are willing to renegotiate," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE LETTER BOMBS FOUND IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Thousands of Australians have been evacuated from their workplaces on Thursday as more suspicious packages, including some letter bombs, were discovered in Sydney, Melbourne, Darwin, Bendigo and Queensland.
Police have a 43-year-old suspect, who was sacked from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) after being accused of harassing a female colleague.
So far 26 letter bombs have been discovered and destroyed.
The letter bomb terror has spread across the nation, as police are unsure how many bombs were allegedly sent by the suspect before he fled his Canberra home.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT MISSION CONCLUDES VISIT TO AUSTRALIA, NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: A trade promotion mission led by Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruey-long concluded a visit to Australia and New Zealand on Thursday after striking business deals worth more than US$16 million in the two countries.
The delegation, jointly organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taipei Import-Export Association, was composed of 70 representatives of 51 Taiwan businesses.

The mission conducted the deals in the Australian cities of Sydney and Melbourne, and in New Zealand's Auckland after hosting trade promotion seminars in the three cities attended by more than 500 local businessmen in search of business opportunities.

On-the-spot deals worth about US$2.2 million were made during the actual trip, with about US$14.5 million-worth of future orders received, according to the BOFT. Most of the delegates were newcomers to Australia and New Zealand, and were said afterward to be satisfied with the outcome of the trade promotion activities.

While in New Zealand, Chen also took part in the sixth ROC-New Zealand economic trade consultation meeting on Wednesday in Wellington, during which he and ROC officials stationed in New Zealand signed an accord with their local counterparts on protection of industrial products, the BOFT said.
The two sides also discussed issues related to bilateral cooperation on a wide range of industries ranging from tourism to biochemistry, and reached many points of consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO HELP ROC DEVELOP WEATHER SATELLITES

TEXT.P: The United States is to assist the Republic of China in developing and launching eight small satellites to upgrade Taiwan's weather forecasting capabilities, National Science Council (NSC) officials said on Friday.

The NSC's National Space Program Office (NSPO) will sign a cooperative agreement with the US National Science Foundation in the near future on the development of a constellation observation system for meteorology and ionospheric climate (COSMIC), the officials said.

Under the accord, the officials said, the US foundation will help Taiwan manufacture and launch the eight satellites to collect high-altitude temperature data and upgrade Taiwan's capabilities in weather forecasting and global climatic change research.

The NSC officials said the NSPO will employ personnel and equipment used in the production of the ROC's first self-developed research satellite -- ROCSAT-1 -- to manufacture the eight COSMIC-related satellites. ROCSAT-1 will be launched in the United States next month.

Meanwhile, the NSC, Academia Sinica, and the Ministry of Education will co-sponsor a ceremony on Dec. 22 to mark the successful linkup between the two countries' very High-Speed Backbone Network Services (vBNS).

Taiwan will be the fifth country in the world to link up with the US National Science Foundation's vBNS system, NSC officials said, adding that the linkup will enable Taiwan to conduct state-of-the-art technological research and help boost the effects of Taiwan's national information infrastructure construction.

In addition, Taiwan is negotiating with the US Federal Emergency Management Administration (FEMA) on the signing of a cooperative agreement. Taiwan hopes to introduce FEMA's anti-disaster and emergency rescue systems to help improve Taiwan's capabilities in disaster control and relief work.
Moreover, the United States will also assist the ROC in establishing an advanced aviation weather forecasting system to minimize flight risks.
The ROC's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has commissioned the US-based University Corporation for Atmospheric Research to develop an Advanced Operational Aviation Weather System (AOAWS).
The system is expected to effectively reduce climatic change-related flight risks for Taiwan's civilian and military aircraft, CAA officials said.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, scientific and technological cooperation between the ROC and the United States has continued to grow since the two countries signed a bilateral scientific cooperative pact in January 1969.

Taipei and Washington have since signed a total of 106 cooperative accords in various scientific and technological fields, including physics, biology, medicine, environmental science, nuclear energy, water resource technology, meteorology, and seismology.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS GO TO THE POLLS SATURDAY (1)

TEXT.P: Voters on Taiwan, the Republic of China, will go to the polls Saturday to elect members of the Legislative Yuan, as well as the mayor and city councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

The three-in-one elections are widely seen as a very important event, because the results of the elections may have a strong impact on the political situation in Taiwan. Some political observers believe that the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) may gain a great momentum in the Presidential election in March, 2000 if it wins the elections this Saturday. The DPP is known for its pro-Taiwan independence position.

Voters will cast ballots from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday to fill the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan, the nation's parliament. Of the 225 seats, 41 will be allocated to major political parties under the proportional representative system, and 16 will be reserved for representatives of the aboriginal people and overseas Chinese. A total of 383 candidates are competing for the remaining 168 seats.

Most of the candidates are fielded by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), the DPP, and the New Party. Candidates of the Taiwan Independence Party, the New Country Alliance, the Democratic Union of Taiwan, and a few independent candidates are also competing in the election for a four-year term. There are 14,962,000 eligible voters.

The KMT has been the ruling party in Taiwan for nearly 50 years, during which time Taiwan grew up from the rubble of the Second World War and became one of the four "little dragons of Asia." Established in September, 1986, the DPP has become the second largest party in the Legislative Yuan. In the last legislative election held in December, 1995, the DPP won 33.2 percent of the vote, compared with the 46.1 percent for the KMT. Formed by several former leaders of the KMT in August, 1993, the New Party is the third major party, which garnered 13 percent of the vote in the last election.

The Taiwan Independence Party and the New Country Alliance were formed separately by former leaders of the DPP, while the Democratic Union of Taiwan was established by local political figures who broke away from the KMT. These three political groups are very young and tiny.
Officials of the ruling party said earlier this week that they believe the KMT will win more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS GO TO THE POLLS SATURDAY (2)

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT is running to unseat the incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP. Born in 1950, Ma graduated from the National Taiwan University with a bachelor degree in 1972, from the New York University with a master's degree in law in 1976, and from the Harvard University Law School with a Ph D in 1981. He served as minister of justice and minister of state from 1993 to 1996, and has taught at the National Chengchi University in Taipei since 1996.

A prominent leader of the DPP, Chen graduated from the National Taiwan University with a bachelor degree of law in 1974. Born in 1951, Chen served as a member of the Taipei City Council from 1981 to 1985, and as a member of the Legislative Yuan from 1989 to 1994. He has been a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee since 1987. He was elected Taipei Mayor in 1994.
Recent surveys indicated that the two candidates are neck and neck, while candidate Wang Chien-shien of the New Party is lagging far behind.

Taipei is the capital city with a 2.62 million population, while Kaohsiung is the second largest city in Taiwan with 1.45 million people. The two cities are different from other cities in that they are the only two cities under the direct jurisdiction of the central government. The KMT is trying hard to regain control of Taipei in this election.
In the southern city of Kaohsiung, DPP candidate Frank C. T. Hsieh (Hsieh Chang-ting) is running hard to unseat the incumbent mayor Wu Deng-yih of the KMT.

Born in 1948, Wu graduated from the National Taiwan University with a BA degree in 1970. He worked as a journalist from 1971 to 1973, as a member of the Taipei City Council from 1973 to 1981, as magistrate of Nantou County in central Taiwan from 1981 to 1989, and as chairman of the KMT Taipei Municipal Committee from 1989 to 1990. He has served as Kaohsiung mayor since 1990.

Hsieh served as a member of the Taipei City Council from 1981 to 1989, as a member of the Legislative Yuan from 1990 to 1996, and as a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee from 1986 to 1994. He has been chairman of the DPP Central Advisory Committee since 1996. Born in 1946, he graduated from the National Taiwan University with a bachelor degree in law in 1970 and with a master's degree in law in 1974. He also studied in a doctoral law program at the Kyoto University of Japan in 1975.
Recent public opinion polls indicated that he and Wu are neck and neck. Candidate Wu Chien-kuo of the New Party and independent candidate Cheng Teh-yao are lagging far behind.
Saturday's polls will also send 52 councilors to the Taipei city council and 44 councilors to the Kaohsiung city council.

Economic and social development prompted Taiwan to lift martial law and the restrictions on formation of new political parties in the late 1980s. Elections of all members of the Legislative Yuan were held for the first time in December, 1992, and the president of the Republic of China was elected by direct popular vote for the first time in 1996. Taiwan has thus transformed into a full-fledged democracy.

Taiwan's free election has made Beijing nervous and interested many foreign mass media and scholars of political science. Mainland China has sent dozens of researchers to Taiwan to observe Saturday's elections and campaign activities. More than 150 foreign journalists are also coming to cover the event. They are from the world's leading news media, including New York Times, USA Today, CNN, BBC, and the Voice of America.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON HIGH-TECH PRODUCT DUTIES MISS DEADLINE

TEXT.P: Senior officials from 44 nations have failed for the third time this year to meet a deadline for a pact to remove all duties on a wide range of high-technology products, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

The talks' chairman, Martin Harvey, a New Zealander, has set Dec. 11 as the new deadline for an agreement on what he termed a "modest" list. The new draft list contains only about 200 items, in contrast to more than 400 originally demanded by participants, the WTO report said.

The Information Technology Agreement II (ITA II) talks failed last month to meet demands set by developing nations. In particular, Asian developing countries such as Malaysia and Thailand, hit by the financial crisis, charged that the product list did not contain many of their priority items, like color television picture tubes, loudspeakers, and other consumer electronic items.

Picture tubes have been kept off the list largely because of pressure by the European Union, which has been lobbied by France, Germany, the Netherlands, and other members, WTO trade officials said. Manufacturers in those nations are seeking to protect themselves from competition from Japan and the United States.

As part of a trade-off, the EU would no longer insist on pushing the United States to include fiber optics on the product list, the officials said. A senior US official said "a lot of progress" was made in the latest round of talks, but admitted more time might be required to secure a deal.

Disagreement also surfaced over radar and navigational equipment and satellite parts, inclusion of which is favored by Canada, Israel, Norway, the United States, and other nations, but opposed by India. That country expressed "serious concern" about the presence of these products on the list.
To entice developing nations to support the package, a four-phase tariff elimination period, scheduled to begin on Jan. 1, 1999, and end in January 2002, will now not begin until next July 1.
Moreover, the accord gives developing countries, in the case of select products, until 2007 to phase out all duties.

The original ITA I, brokered in 1997, called for the removal of all duties on about 90 percent of global trade in high-tech items, worth more than US$600 billion annually, and the ITA II is aimed at extending the product list.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC EXPLAINS INTERVENTION IN NT DOLLAR EXCHANGE RATE

TEXT.P: An official of the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Friday that the CBC's moderate intervention in the new Taiwan dollar's exchange rate is carried out mainly to prevent the nation's economic prosperity from suffering.

In a regular news conference, Hsu Yi-hsiung, vice governor of the CBC, said that in light of the recent oversupply of the US dollar in the local foreign exchange market, the CBC has no choice but to intervene in order to avoid the rapid appreciation of the local currency.
Taiwan's exports in the first 10 months of this year declined more than 8 percent, Hsu pointed out, adding that if the local currency appreciates too rapidly, export growth will be directly affected.

In response to criticism from the United States that the island's CBC intervenes in the foreign exchange rate, Hsu claimed that the central bank of any country would do likewise if necessary. The main purpose of such behavior is to maintain order in the foreign exchange market, he said.

Asked if the CBC's continuous selling of the NT dollar and buying of the US dollar will result in an oversupply of the NT dollar, Hsu replied that the CBC would hedge against a local currency glut by issuing negotiable certificates of deposit.
Hsu indicated that heavy selling of the greenback resulting from its weakness has led to the natural appreciation of the NT dollar.

The NT dollar hit a new high in nearly nine months against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday to finish at 32.36, up NT$0.044 on the previous day's close. Interbank US dollar transactions on Friday totaled US$589 million, the highest single-day level in two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING MINISTER RESPECTS DECISION TO PROMOTE HIM

TEXT.P: Brushing off criticism that he was a stopgap removed barely five months after taking up his portfolio at the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), outgoing Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said on Friday that he respected the president's decision to reassign him.
Cheng, who took over the helm of the ministry on July 15, was named vice president of the Judicial Yuan by President Lee Teng-hui on Friday.

In a press conference called by the Government Information Office to introduce new appointees to head the Judicial Yuan and the Control Yuan, Cheng said that as a political official, he must obey the head of state's decision to transfer him to a new job.

At the request of the reporters present, he assessed his own performance in his short-lived tenure as "not up to an acceptable standard" because many of the tasks he envisioned have not been completed.

Describing a meeting with the president earlier this week, he said Lee is very concerned about the lack of success of the ministry's campaign to crack down on gangsters, illegal arms, drugs, and vote-buying, and cautioned him that the public seem unimpressed with recent judicial reforms.

As a matter of fact, Cheng said, the basic justice system under the MOJ is quite sound, and needs only some technical improvements. However, he went on, the Judicial Yuan needs an urgent revamp, but said he would reserve judgment on this until he has taken office.

Meanwhile, Chen Jui-jen, the founder of a prosecutor's group aimed at reforming the judicial system, admitted that Cheng's promotion could snuff out the burgeoning "Five-year Judicial Reform" program initiated by his group.

He said he failed in an attempt earlier in the day to lobby Cheng to stay in his post at the ministry until the full implementation of the program which calls for an increase in the number of government attorneys, an increase in the ministry's budget, and an improvement in prosecutors' crime-investigation techniques.

Criticizing Cheng for having set a bad example by pursuing a higher position rather than addressing the problems at hand, Chen said that his group, the Reform Association of Prosecutors, has come to realize that judicial revamping lies more in the hands of rank-and-file law enforcers than with the judicial head.

He said the group will now weigh the idea of calling on future justice ministers to sign a written promise not to use their office simply as a step on the promotional ladder toward a more desirable sinecure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDATES RALLYING FOR VICTORY ON EVE OF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Braving pouring rain, more than 100,000 enthusiastic supporters geared up at the plaza of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei on Friday evening to rally for Ma Ying-jeou, the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for Taipei mayor.

Ma appeared on a stage erected at the center of the plaza at around 8 p.m., drawing several rounds of hearty applause from the public, who waved banners and flags and chanted slogans in praise of Ma, who is posing a serious threat to the re-election bid of the incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui also appeared to stump for Ma, provoking further waves of applause and jubilant cries from the spectators.

Also noteworthy was the fact that backers of the pro-unification New Party, brandishing the New Party's yellow flags, were also seen among Ma's supporters, an indication that he has also attracted many supporters from the pro-unification opposition party.

Expressing his appreciation for the New Party supporters, and stressing that he is fighting for all Taipei's citizens, Ma begged the public to rally behind him and cast their ballots for him to ensure his victory on Saturday.
The New Party's hopeful for Taipei mayor, Wang Chien-shien, has come under strong pressure to quit the race to help Ma defeat Chen.

In his final campaign rally held at the Hsing Sheng Park in downtown Taipei, Wang emphasized that the New Party is the sole genuine opposition party, and the country's only remaining counterbalance. With tears in his eyes, Wang vowed that he will stay in the race until the last minute, and urged his supporters to maintain a solid foundation for the ROC with their vote.

Meanwhile, Chen, a DPP heavyweight, also appeared on three occasions, including a mass rally with his supporters at the plaza in front of the Taipei City Government, in a last-ditch effort to defend his chance at a second term in the post.

It is estimated about 100,000 attended the rally during which several DPP heavyweights, including party chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and former chairman Hsu Hsin-liang called on DPP supporters to rally behind Chen to ensure the party's continued ruling status in the capital city of Taiwan.
The latest public opinion polls showed Ma leading Chen by a small margin.

Voters in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities, will go to the polls on Saturday to elect a new mayor and city council, while voters in the rest of the island will elect the country's new legislators.

Earlier in the day, President Lee and Vice President and KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan stumped for the KMT's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, Wu Den-yih, who is competing fiercely against DPP challenger Frank Hsieh.
Wu, who has been in the post for two terms, or eight years, appealed to Kaohsiung citizens to give him another four years to allow him to accomplish several unfinished projects.

Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, in conjunction with DPP magistrates and township chiefs, also asked for public support for Hsieh at their last campaign activity in the runup to Saturday's election.
The function was packed by thousands of DPP supporters, and traffic in the surrounding area was paralyzed by the crowd.
Both candidates, in addition to New Party contender Wu Chien-Kuo, also launched caravan parades around Kaohsiung City to solicit votes during the day.

The New Party candidate categorically denied that he had backed out of the competition, and a large number of backers gathered in front of his headquarters to show their support for him. They later conducted a torchlight parade through the city streets.
Although there are four candidates for Kaohsiung mayor, Wu and Hsieh are seen as the most likely contenders after one month of campaigning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 68,000 POLICE TO MAINTAIN ELECTION SECURITY

TEXT.P: A police force of more than 68,000 will be deployed to maintain security on Saturday for the 11,173 legislative election polling stations islandwide.
The figure does not include the force deployed by the two municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung under the direct jurisdiction of the Central Government.

The police will concentrate their efforts inside and outside polling stations in Pingtung, Ilan, and Yunlin counties, amid rumors that candidates in the three counties will install micro cameras on the top of polling stations to monitor voters as they cast their ballots.

The Department of Police Affairs (DPA) under the Taiwan Provincial Government said that the DPA will deploy 6,474 of its own police, reinforced by voluntary police and civil defense personnel for a total of 68,000 officers.
The DPA said that among the 318 legislative candidates, 128 have applied for police bodyguards, while 22 bulletproof vests have also been lent out.

DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 5, or Oct. 17 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the best position to capture Lisoon, west of the port city of Talien.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the "Chaoho" warship. His attempt fails the following day.
1926: French impressionist painter Claude Monet, who was born in 1840, dies at the age of 86.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States abrogates a 14-year-long prohibition on alcohol.
1946: Strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1950: North Korean and communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang, and the forces of the United Nations are forced to withdraw to the south.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan goes to the polls on Saturday; major parties went all out on the eve of elections.
The China Times:
Taiwan voters go to the polls to election new legislators and mayors and councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
The United Daily News:
The three-in-one elections were held on Saturday; the results would restructure the legislature's party map.
The Liberty Times:
Both the ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made last-ditch efforts on Friday night to shore up support for their candidates.
The Independence Morning Post:
Taiwan goes to the polls for three critical elections.
The Commons Daily:
If the DPP loses both Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, Taiwan's democratic development would suffer a serious setback.
The China Post:
President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui said only the KMT can preserve stability.
The China News:
Campaigning closes with a bang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ DENOMINATED GOVERNMENT BONDS RECEIVE HIGH CREDIT RATING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Moody's Investors Service Inc. on Friday affirmed its credit ratings at Aa3 for Republic of China government bonds, a rating which means their risk of running bad debts is extremely low.
Despite the fact that cross-Taiwan Strait political relations are still unstable, Taiwan's financial situation is more sound than other countries with similar credit ratings, Moody's said.

This sound situation can be attributed to the vigorous and flexible economy, and the well-managed microeconomic situation, which have allowed Taiwan to be resilient to the impact of the Asian financial turmoil, according to Moody's.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S THREE-IN-ONE ELECTIONS END WITHOUT INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Voting in Taiwan's legislative, mayoral and city council elections, which began at 8 a.m. on Saturday, ended at 4 p.m. with no reported incidents, the Central Election Committee (CEC) said early on Saturday evening.

Ballot counting began as soon as the polling stations closed, but although the results are expected before 11 p.m., the official lists of the winners will not be published until Dec. 11, said the CEC.

Three candidates from three different parties were competing in the fierce competition for Taipei city mayor -- the ruling Kuomintang's Ma Ying-jeou, incumbent mayor Chen Shui-bian of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Wang Chien-shien of the much smaller opposition New Party.
In the race for Taipei City councilors, 110 hopefuls were vying for 52 seats.
Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, has 1.86 million eligible voters.

In the southern city of Kaohsiung, four mayoral hopefuls were competing for the city's top administrative post -- incumbent KMT mayor Wu Den-yih, the DPP's Hsieh Chang-ting, the New Party's Wu Chien-kuo, and independent candidate Cheng Teh-yao.
The 44 city council seats were being contested by 105 candidates seeking votes from 1 million eligible voters.
Meanwhile, in the competition for the legislature, 498 hopefuls were vying to be elected by the 14.96 million eligible voters to a total of 225 seats.

Early results showed that in Lienchiang County of Fukien Province, incumbent KMT legislator Chao Erh-chung won reelection with 2,443 votes in an uncontested race, while KMT candidate Lin Bing-kun was almost certain of victory in Penghu County, with 22,300 votes, almost double the number gained by his DPP rival Hsu Pi-lung, after 80 percent of the votes had been counted at 5 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: 26 PEOPLE INJURED IN BLAST AT FPG CHEMICAL PLANT IN TEXAS

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Vice Chairman Wang Chin-shu said on Saturday that all 26 FPG employees injured in an explosion at the company's plant in the southern US state of Texas are receiving proper care, and are now all in stable condition.

Wang said that FPG, Taiwan's largest private conglomerate, has authorized its Texas plant management to handle the aftermath of the incident, including the care of the employees, none of whom were seriously injured.
Wang further said the FPG head office is still awaiting a detailed report on the accident from its Texas-based personnel.
According to a UPI report, an explosion and fire rocked the FPG's ethylene dichloride (EDC) plant in Point Comfort, some 160 kilometers southwest of Houston, at 8:45 a.m. on Friday (Texas time).

The blast at the rear of the EDC plant caused minor injuries to 26 factory workers, the report said, adding that the injured were first treated by a medical team at the plant and then transported to area hospitals as a precautionary measure.

The report quoted a plant spokesman as saying that the explosion was in either the crude EDC tank or in a pipeline to the tank. The spokesman further said that downwind air monitoring showed that the level of EDC was well below Occupational Safety and Health Administration levels for plant employees.
The fire was extinguished by 11 a.m., according to the report.
As a safety precaution, the report said, the entire FPG complex along the Texas coast was shut down, and all employees were evacuated. By 10 a.m., they began returning to restart operations.
The US Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board says it will investigate the cause of the accident.
The raw material produced at the FPG plant is used in polyvinyl chloride resin that is a component of roofing, piping, surgical gloves, and other products.

FPG executives said earlier this year that the US federal government and the Texas state government had already approved the group's application in May this year to build a second naphtha cracker at its Point Comfort chemical complex.
Before giving the green light, the US authorities published a notice in major Texas newspapers to soliciting residents' opinions about the FPG's expansion project.

"The US approval indicates that our plant operations and environmental protection measures have met strict American standards, and that Texas residents are not opposed to our US$750 million expansion project," said an FPG executive.
Construction of the new naphtha cracking plant is scheduled to start early next year, and it is expected to become operational by the turn of the century, the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SWEEPS LEGISLATIVE RACE IN THREE OFF-SHORE ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang swept the board in the legislative race on three off-shore islands on Saturday.

Cheng Ching-pao, an incumbent KMT legislator, beat four contenders to win election in Kinmen County, while his party colleague Chao Erh-chung won in Lienchiang County in an uncontested race, and Lin Bing-kun beat DPP rival Hsu Pi-lung in Penghu County.
Taiwan's offshore islands are traditional ruling party strongholds.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAI, HUANG ELECTED IN CHIAYI CITY

TEXT.P: Huang Min-hui of the ruling Kuomintang and Trong Chia of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were elected legislators on Saturday in this southern Taiwan city.
Vote counting by the Central Election Commission showed that Huang had gained 40,877 ballots, followed by Chai with 35,349 ballots, beating out four other candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIST OF ELECTED CANDIDATES TO BE PUBLISHED ON DEC. 11

TEXT.P: The final results of Saturday's "three-in-one" elections will not be made public until Dec. 11, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said.
The CEC estimated that the results will be out before 11 p.m. on Saturday, as the voting around the island ended smoothly at 4 p.m.

Voting opened across the island at 8 a.m. for the people of Taiwan to choose a fourth legislature, as well as mayors and city councilors in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities, which account for a quarter of the island's 21 million population.

More than 1.86 million eligible voters in Taipei will elect a new mayor from among the three hopefuls -- incumbent Mayor Chen Shiu-bian of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang, and Wang Chien-shien of the pro-unification New Party -- and 52 city councilors from 118 candidates.

About 1 million Kaohsiung voters will decide who will be the next mayor from four contenders -- incumbent KMT Mayor Wu Den-yih, DPP challenger Frank Shieh, Wu Chien-kuo of the New Party, and independent Cheng Teh-yao, in addition to electing a 44-member city council from 105 candidates.
A 225-seat parliament contested by 498 hopefuls will also be elected by nearly 15 million eligible voters across the island.
The CEC had estimated earlier that voter turnout in both Taipei and Kaohsiung would surpass 80 percent, while the rate in the rest of the island would hit around 65 percent.

Ranking government officials, including President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, and Premier Vincent Siew, all went to the polling stations near their residences in Taipei to cast their ballots on Saturday morning, while Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong cast his ballot in central Nantou City.

In the tight Taipei race, Mayor Chen, who is seeking a second term, urged Taipei citizens to treasure his performance and hard work over the past four years, and appealed for continued support to allow him to carry out uncompleted missions.

After casting his vote at the polling station near his residence in the Wenshan district, KMT mayoral contender Ma said he is confident of winning the race, as many enthusiastic supporters have been campaigning for him.

Meanwhile, Wang of the tiny New Party strongly criticized Liu Cheng-wu, a prosecutor of the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office, for stumping for Chen on Friday night. Prosecutors should remain politically neutral in an election, and such behavior has gravely violated this principle and tainted the image of law enforcement authorities, Wang claimed.
In the southern port city of Kaohsiung, all four mayoral candidates called for support and urged the voters to use their votes.

In related news, the National Police Administration mobilized nearly 60,000 police to help maintain order and security at the more than 14,000 polling stations across the island. Prosecutors also inspected polling stations in their districts to try to keep vote buying and other irregularities out of the elections, and no major incidents had been reported by the time polling wrapped up at 4 p.m.

State Public Prosecutor General Ru Ren-fa called on the public and all contenders to remain calm after the election results are released. Any illegal activities will be harshly punished by judicial authorities, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GADGETS USED IN TAICHUNG COUNTY HELPING THE BLIND TO VOTE

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) provided special equipment in Taichung County in Saturday's legislative election to allow the blind to cast their votes without assistance for the first time.
The "blind voter's helper" was not only praised by Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yun-lai, it was also acclaimed by the blind voters who tried it as very convenient to use.
The gadgets were provided by the CEC at every Taichung County voting booth in the fourth national legislative election.

Tsai Sheui-sun, a blind masseur who used the gadget at a polling station at Fungyuan Elementary School, said after casting his vote that in previous elections, he required assistance from his relatives or his son, but that now he can cast his vote by himself.
He added that the new equipment better guarantees the interests of the blind.
