DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA WINS FISH WAR WITH SPAIN

TEXT.P: The World Court in The Hague has thrown out Spain's challenge against Canada for actions that sparked an international turbot war in 1995, saying it does not have the authority to hear the dispute.
Spain said Canada had violated the international law when it seized a Spanish fishing trawler in international waters off the coast of Newfoundland.
The International Court of Justice's ruling supported Canada's position that the court could not hear Spain's case because it does not have jurisdiction over Canada on this matter.
Canada's agent to the court, Phillippe Kirsch said: "This is the end of the matter as far as the international court is concerned." Spain cannot appeal the court's ruling.

Canada justified the arrest by alleging the trawler was using illegal nets. Canadian officials chased the boat and eventually boarded it after warning shots were fired across its bow. The trawler was seized and escorted into a Canadian harbor.
Canadian authorities made the arrest under the Coastal Protection Act, which gives officials the power to manage fish stocks in areas that straddle international boundaries.
Spain said the incident violated international laws which protect freedom of fishing on the high seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ONE OF WORLD'S FREEST ECONOMIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is one of the top ten freest economies in the world, and mainland China remains one of the least, according to the 1999 Index of Economic Freedom just published by The Heritage Foundation and the Wall Street Journal.

The annual survey measures how well 161 countries score on a list of 50 independent criteria divided into ten broad economic factors: trade policy; taxation; government intervention in the economy; monetary policy; capital flows and foreign investment; banking; wage and price controls; property rights; regulation; and black market.

The survey shows that Hong Kong ranked first with a score of 1.25, followed by Singapore (1.30), Bahrain (1.70), New Zealand (1.75), Switzerland (1.85), and the United States (1.90). Taiwan, with 1.95, shared seventh place with Ireland, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom.

Despite several years of progress, economic freedom decreased rapidly in Asia in 1998, according to the survey. Of the 32 countries graded, only seven improved their scores, while the others regressed.

Four of the top ten freest economies in the world are in Asia -- Hong Kong, Singapore, New Zealand and Taiwan. However, it is increasingly clear that some fallout from the Asian financial crisis is resulting in decreased economic freedom for many Asian countries, said the Washington-based think tank.

The Heritage Foundation noted that Hong Kong, which consistently has ranked first in previous indexes, appears in danger of surrendering that position. In August 1998 and the weeks that followed, the Hong Kong government spent some US$15.2 billion to "ward off speculators" by buying private stock in the Hong Kong stock exchange.

Not only has the Hong Kong government failed to allow its currency board to function properly, it has violated an important rule of free-market economics: governments should avoid direct ownership of private companies. In so doing, Hong Kong has demonstrated that its commitment to the market may be weakening.

The survey report added that most of the world's freest economies are in North America and Europe, while most of the world's most economically repressed countries are in Africa and the Middle East. But North Korea and Cuba were at the bottom of the listing of 161, with identical scores of 5.00, following Iraq, Laos, and Libya.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN GOVERNMENT TO CREATE NEW `PEOPLE'S ECONOMY'

TEXT.P: Indonesia is embarking on a new program to restructure the country's economic wealth, with the aim of creating a "people's economy" or "ekonomi rakyat," according to Singapore's The Business Times.

The economic blueprint calls for at least 50 percent of the country's distribution network to be in the hands of cooperatives and small enterprises -- a move that would sideline the country's large conglomerates controlled by ethnic Chinese Indonesians, it said.
But officials of President B.J. Habibie's administration, led by Minister of Cooperatives Adi Sasono, insist that the program is not based on ethnic considerations.

However, the proposals of "ekonomi rakyat" would see the nation's assets and wealth redistributed to the 52,000 state-owned cooperatives which have 39 million owners, who happen to be mostly indigenous Indonesians.

Frans Seda, economic adviser to Habibie, told the newspaper that the concept of a "people's economy" is still being fine-tuned, but forms the backbone of the reform process and the country's new development strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITARIANISM NEARLY OVER IN EAST ASIA: RAMOS

TEXT.P: The time of authoritarianism is past in East Asia, and popular participation in national politics has become the wave of future, according to former Philippine President Fidel Ramos.
He pointed out that over the past 20 years, Taiwan, Thailand, South Korea, and the Philippines have all made the transition from authoritarian to democratic regimes.
He also said mainland China has introduced village-level elections and is considering elections at the next level -- for township and provincial chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS IMPORTANT FOR AUSTRALIA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan held three-in-one legislative, mayoral, and city council elections on Saturday, the outcome of which may be important to Australia, according to the Australian Financial Review.
In a dispatch from Taipei, the daily reported that Taiwan's continued well-being is vital for Australia because it is the fifth-biggest buyer of Australian exports, chiefly mineral products.
The daily reported that Taiwan has evolved a unique style of electoral politics: personalized, in-your-face, and of course expensive.

The daily said that Saturday's poll results will resonate far beyond the island's 21 million people because their choices will help frame the environment for cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which in turn have a direct effect on stability in the Asian region.
Neither the ruling Kuomintang nor the opposition Democratic Progressive Party want to antagonize mainland China, which refuses to drop its threat to use force to take Taiwan, the daily reported.
The KMT claims to favor ultimate reunification once mainland China is fully democratic, while DPP favors formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: INITIAL RESULTS OF LEGISLATIVE RACE

TEXT.P: Three hopefuls from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) were elected lawmakers on Saturday in central Taichung City.

Shen Chi-hui, Lu Hsiu-yien and Huang Hsien-chou of the KMT; Tsai Ming-hsien and Wang Shih-hsun of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); Shieh Chi-da of the pro-unification New Party; and Huang Yi-chiao, an independent, were the seven winners out of 20 contenders in Taiwan's third-largest city.

In southern Chiayi County, three hopefuls from the ruling KMT -- Hsiu Ten-kung, Hsiao Yun-yu and Cheng Ming-wen -- and Her Chia-jung of the pro-independence DPP beat six other challengers to win legislative seats.
In neighboring Tainan County, Hung Yu-chin of the KMT grabbed the highest number of ballots, 55,988, of the nine candidates elected out of a total 16 contenders.
Hung was followed by Su Huan-chih of the DPP with 54,972 ballots and Chou Wu-liu of the KMT with 48,226 ballots.

Meanwhile, Ke Chien-ming of the DPP won the highest number of ballots, 35,948, in northern Hsinchu City. Lin Cheng-tze and Chang Tsai-mei of the ruling KMT gained 32,800 and 28,731 votes, respectively, to rank second and third in the race among seven contenders.
In eastern Hualien County, Cheng Li-teh and Chang Fu-hsing, both from the ruling KMT, defeated four other candidates to win legislative seats.
In neighboring Ilan County, Lin Chien-jung and Lu Yi-feng of the KMT, as well as Chen Ting-nan and Chang Chuan-tien of the DPP, managed to win out of a total of six challengers.
The list of elected lawmakers for the 225-seat fourth legislature will be officially made public by the Central Election Commission on Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN LEAVES FOR CENTRAL AMERICAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan left for New York Saturday evening for a transit stop on his way to four hurricane-hit Central American allies of the Republic of China.

Lien will visit Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui to express the ROC government and people's concern for the four Central American countries which were hit hard by hurricane Mitch a few weeks ago.

"I'll meet with the top leaders of the four countries to extend our love and concern for their people," Lien said prior to his departure, adding that he will tour hurricane-stricken areas near the four countries' capital cities to look into their reconstruction needs.
Lien said the ROC government plans to assist the four countries in building schools and hospitals, and in repairing damaged bridges and highways.
If necessary, Lien said, the government will also present financial aid or loan programs through the ROC's International Cooperation and Development Fund.

Lien was accompanied by a group of senior ROC officials, including Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Director-General Chan Chi-shean of the Department of Health and Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to President Lee, on his Central American visit.

Representatives of several domestic charity and religious organizations, including Chen Chang-wen, vice president of the ROC Red Cross Society, World Vision Taiwan President Shao Ching-ming and an executive of the International Fo Kuang Shan (Buddha Light) Foundation, are also accompanying Lien on his overseas tour.

Lien traveled to the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday afternoon to stump for incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih. Upon his return to Taipei early Saturday morning, he rushed to cast his ballot for the Taipei mayoral election.

Lien, a Kuomintang vice president, has campaigned strenuously for KMT candidates for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, Ma Ying-jeou and Wu Den-yih. He would be informed of the election returns on his flight to New York.

Lien is scheduled to leave New York for Nicaragua on Dec. 7via a chartered plane. He will also make a stransit stop in Los Angeles on his way home. The US government will offer Lien courtesy treatment during his transit stay in New York and Los Angeles.

The ROC government has offered a total of US$2.6 million in relief aid to the four Central American countries after they were ravaged by the hurricane. Moreover, several large Taiwan charity organizations have also launched fund-raising campaigns to pool private resources for various relief programs.

The ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs also hosted a fund-raising dinner earlier this week to help Central American victims. Many local celebrities reserved seats at the NT$10,000 (US$308) per plate dinner at Grand Hyatt Taipei hotel to throw their support behind the fund-raising drive.

The ministry has also launched a separate campaign dubbed "Sending Our Love to Central America," to raise funds for the hurricane victims, and has opened special accounts with the International Commercial Bank of China and the Post Office, to which members of the public can remit donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VIETNAM TIES CLOSER DUE TO INCREASED TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has become the second-largest investor in Vietnam, Director Hung Dun-jen of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Branch Office In Ho Chi Minh City said on Friday.
The ROC is also Vietnam's third-largest trading partner, with some 180,000 Taiwan businessmen visiting Vietnam annually, Hung said, adding that the ROC-Vietnam relations have intensified as a result.

Since Vietnam began switching to a market economy ten years ago, it has been a rising market for foreign investors, said Hung. Eight years ago, CETRA set up its branch office in Ho Chi Minh City in order to attract Taiwan investment, making the ROC one of the first countries to invest in the Vietnam market, he added.

According to official statistics, Taiwan investment in Vietnam amounts to US$4.26 billion, while unofficial statistics put the figure as high as US$7 billion. In addition, the number of Taiwan companies in Vietnam is estimated to be around 1,000.

Hung pointed out that Taiwan's investment in Vietnam is mainly in labor-intensive industries such as garment and shoe manufacture, and cited examples such as Pou Cheng Corp., which employs some 10,000 workers on its enormous shoe production line, and Hualon Textile Corp., which has started operating an artificial fiber factory with US$200 million-worth of investment.

In addition to export-oriented industries, some Taiwan businessmen are also targeting Vietnam's domestic market, Hung said. For instance, President Enterprises Corp. plans to invest US$140 million in three factories producing cooking oil, instant noodles, and flour.

Moreover, China Steel Corp. has signed a memorandum of understanding with Vietnam, with the intention of setting up a joint venture among Taiwanese, Japanese, and Vietnamese downstream steel producers, Hung explained.

Successful Taiwan investments in Vietnam to date include Vedan Enterprise Corp.'s MSG production facility, with annual business of US$185 million, while a Taiwan Sugar Corp. hog farm in the suburbs of Ho Chi Minh City is also slated to start operations in January 1999.

Because Taiwan businessmen have become increasingly predominant in Vietnam, and because marriages between ROC and Vietnamese nationals have increased in frequency, ROC-Vietnam ties are expected to intensify, Hung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE RACE, KMT WINS IN MOST CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN COUNTIES

TEXT.P: In Saturday's legislative elections, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) won more than half the seats contested in the counties of Kaohsiung, Yunlin, Miaoli and Hsinchu.
The ruling party, however, failed to capture half the seats in Tainan County and lost outright in Taitung County.

In southern Kaohsiung County, the KMT swept the board, capturing all six seats available. The six winners were Wang Jin-ping, Hsiao Chin-lan, Lin Yuan-shan, Chung Shao-ho, Lin Yi-shih and Wu Kuang-hsun.
In central Yunlin County, the KMT grabbed five out of six seats while the Democratic Progressive Party won one.
The KMT winners were Lin Ming-yih, Tseng Tsai Mei-tso, Hsu Shu-Po, Ho Hui-hsian and Liao Fu-peng.
The sole Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) winner was Lin Kuo-hua.

In central Miaoli County, two KMT candidates -- Liu Cheng-hong and Ho Chih-hui -- snapped up two of the four seats available. The two others went to independent Chen Chao-ming and Democratic Alliance member Hsu Chen-kun.
In northern Hsinchu County, two KMT members -- Chiu Ching-chun and Cheng Yung-chin -- won two out of the three seats contested, with the other going to Chang Hsueh-shun from the DPP.

In southern Tainan County, DPP members Tang Pi-o, Lai Ching-teh and Lin Nan-sheng won three of the six contested seats, while KMT members Chen Jung-shen and Wang Yu-ting won seats as well. The other seat went to New Country Alliance member Hsu Tien-tsai.
In eastern Taitung County, the only seat being contested went to Democratic Alliance member Hsu Ching-yan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SURE TO RETAKE TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is almost sure to retake Taipei, which it lost to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) four years ago.
With the vote counting nearly finished, KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou has received 743,973 votes against incumbent DPP Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who has garnered 641,395.
Recapturing the largest city in Taiwan will be of great significance to the KMT, which has been undertaking a series of reforms initiated by Republic of China President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LOSES KAOHSIUNG TO DPP

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Saturday won Kaohsiung's neck and neck mayoral race, unseating incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yih of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Vote counting was a sea-saw ride between Hsieh and Wu. With the process drawing to end, Hsieh led Wu 387,797 to 383,232.

Wu held the reins of southern Taiwan's largest city for eight years. He won the city's first mayoral election four years ago, beating the DPP's Chen Chun-hsiung. Before that he served a four-year term as Kaohsiung's mayor by appointment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW LAUDS VOTERS FOR THEIR DEMOCRATIC SPIRIT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Saturday praised voters for their democratic character as shown during Taiwan's three-in-one elections.

Siew made the remarks during an inspection tour of the vote-counting center of the Central Election Commission (CEC) under the Ministry of the Interior. He said the elections show the Republic of China's democracy has become more mature.

Accompanied by Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, who is concurrently chairman of the CEC; Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fung-chen; Lin Cheng-chih, chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs; Chao Yang-ching, chairman of the Fair Trade Commission; and Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office, Siew inspected the center at the Police College.

The premier stressed that due to the good demeanor of the candidates and the highly democratic spirit of voters, the elections ran smoothly and peacefully. They will enable the nation to travel farther down the road of democracy in the 21st century, he said.

Siew later extended his congratulations to all the winning candidates in the elections. He also consoled those who lost, told them not to be disappointed and urged them to respect the choice of the voters.
The focus of the election for mayors, city council members and national legislators had been on the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

The Kuomintang (KMT) appeared headed to retake control of Taipei City as early returns in the mayoral polls showed its candidate ahead of incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
As of 10:30 p.m. Saturday, KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou lead Chen by 78,000 votes. Early results showed Ma with more than 764,000 votes and Chen with 686,000.

In Kaohsiung incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yi of the ruling party and DPP's Hsieh Chang-ting were on a see-saw ride, with Hsieh leading Wu by some 5,000 votes as of 10:30 p.m., when Hsieh had 387,000 votes and Wu 383,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTIONEERING CULTURE HINGES ON AWAKENING OF MASS MEDIA: NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: The three-in-one election on Saturday can be called satisfactory; however, Taiwan's electioneering culture hinges on the awakening of the mass media, which has been in these elections an "accomplice" of those demonstrating unseemly campaign practices, said the New Party's Taipei mayoral candidate, Wang Chien-shien.

Wang said on Saturday that campaign activities on the eve of election day by the other two candidates -- one each from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- were covered by the mass media, even though the events violated election regulations by continuing past 10 p.m.
Taiwan's mass media has become an "accomplice" to the KMT and DPP "bandits," remarked Wang.
Of the nearly two dozen penalty tickets issued by the Central Election Commission under the Interior Ministry, incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP received 16, said Wang.
The top official of Taipei's municipal government being at the forefront of those violating regulations is woeful, said Wang.
Wang expressed his hope that the media should censure those who violated the rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS SEATS IN CHANGHUA COUNTY AND KEELUNG CITY

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) gained a majority of seats in both Changhua County and Keelung City in legislative elections, according to election results.

Ten legislators were elected from among 20 candidates in Changhua County, where Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member Wong Chin-zhu won the largest number of votes, while KMT candidates Lin Chin-chun and Hsie Yen-hsin finished in second and third place, respectively.

The eight other elected legislators in Changhua County are Chen Chen-hsiung (KMT), Yiu Yueh-hsia (KMT), Chen Chao-jung (KMT), Huang Ming-ho (independent), Chen Chin-ting (Democratic Alliance), Hsieh Chang-chieh (KMT) and Hong Hsing-jung (KMT).

In Keelung City, both of the KMT's candidates, Liu Wen-hsiung and Hsu Shao-ping, won legislative seats, with Liu winning the most votes. DPP member Wang Tuo finished second, while Hsu took the third and final seat up for grabs.
Compared with the results of the last legislative elections, the KMT won 18,887 more votes this time around, while the DPP and New Party lost 35,884 and 24,108 votes, respectively, in Keelung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS FRAUGHT WITH SURPRISES

TEXT.P: The results of the hotly contested legislature elections were fraught with surprises, with many veteran politicians unexpectedly losing their electoral bids.
Among them was Chang Wen-ying, a former two-term independent Chiayi city mayor, who failed to win a seat in the new Legislative Yuan.

Former Taipei County Magistrate You Ching, who also once served as a Control Yuan member, lost his legislative election bid in the Taipei County constituency. You, a stalwart of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), headed the Taipei County government for two-term eight years.
You's younger brother, You Hung, an incumbent DPP legislator, also lost his re-election bid in the southern Kaohsiung County constituency.

In the same Kaohsiung County constituency, incumbent Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien's elder sister Yu Ling-ya, an incumbent DPP legislator, also lost her re-election bid, while his younger brother, Yu Cheng-tao, an incumbent Taiwan Provincial Assembly member, managed to win a seat in the new legislature.

Meanwhile, two founders of the minor opposition New Party, incumbent Legislator Yok Mu-ming and New Party National Development Commission Convener Chen Kuei-miao, lost their legislative bids in the Taoyuan County and Tainan City electoral districts, respectively.
On the other hand, incumbent Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan and his niece Liu Chuan-chung both won their legislative election bids in the Taichung County constituency.
Incumbent independent Legislator Luo Fu-chu, allegedly an underworld gang leader, and his son Luo Ming-tsai also both won their legislative bids in the Taipei County constituency.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC ALLIANCE FAILS TO REACH THRESHOLD

TEXT.P: Candidates of the Democratic Alliance (DA) won four seats in Saturday's legislative elections islandwide, but failed to surpass the 5-percent threshold for the seats for proportional representation.

Election results released by the Central Election Commission showed that DA candidates garnered 374,559 votes, or 4.22 percent of the total ballots cast across the island for the 225-seat legislature.

DA Executive General Chen Wei-chien lamented the outcome of the elections, saying that they had hoped to win at least 10 seats in order to break the 5-percent threshold required for proportional representation.

Stressing that the DA will focus more on policy making than on ideology in the future, Chen said the DA will continue to join forces with legislators who share the same aspirations as them to fight for the well-being of all the people of Taiwan.
The DA, composed mostly of former members of the ruling Kuomintang and the tiny opposition New Party, was set up recently in the run-up to the Dec. 5 elections.

Of the 21 DA members who took part in the legislative elections, Lin Chih-chia won the fourth-highest number of votes in Taipei County, while DA President Hsiu Cheng-kun also managed to score a victory in central Miaoli Country. Chen Chin-ting in central Changhua County and Hsiu Ching-yuan in eastern Taitung County were also elected.
DA hopefuls in central Nantou, Yunlin and Taichung Counties were defeated by only small margins.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SAYS HIS DEFEAT SYMBOLIZES 'TAIPEI IS A GREAT CITY'

TEXT.P: Incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said after losing his re-election bid that his defeat indicates that Taipei citizens expect even higher quality of municipal administration.
Chen said "sorry" to a large crowd of his supporters for his electoral defeat. "I feel sorry for failing to live up to your expectation."

Chen, a stalwart of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), then offered his felicitations to his ruling Kuomintang challenger Ma Ying-jeou, who won the tight mayoral race with a lager-than-expected margin.
Chen also offered his congratulations to his DPP commrade Frank Hsieh, who managed to defeat incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to win the control of the island's second largest city.
Chen said although he lost his re-election bid, it didn't mean that his municipal government team was a failure.

"During my four-year stint, the city government staff have worked hard to make Taipei become one of the most liveable Asian cities, and the city government's approval rating has consistently stood above 70 percent," Chen said. "This means that the city government team has not owed a debt to Taipei residents."
Chen said the late British Prime Minister Winston Churchill lost his presimership shortly after he led Britain to weather through his country's darkest period and win World War II.

In his farewell speech, Churchill said heartlessness to an outstanding prime minister was a symbol of a great people. Chen said he thought Churchill's remarks probably could also describe his electoral defeat. "Heartlessness to the progressive, hard-working city government team symbolizes that Taipei is a great city," he noted.
Chen said his defeat does not mean a setback to administrative reforms. "On the contrary, it indicates that Taipei residents want even faster, greater progress."
Chen said he hopes his successor will lead the city government to an even brighter and more excellent direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WELCOMES RESULTS OF ELECTIONS, NEW PARTY ADMITS FAILURE

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang welcomed Saturday night the results of the elections for legislators, mayors and city council members, saying it gave a small boost to the party.

In a statement issued after ballot counting drew to a close, Chang said the KMT's share of votes had improved from 46 percent in the last round of legislative elections to 51.27 percent, vindicating the moderate and rational path followed by the party.

Although the party's candidate lost the race for Kaohsiung mayor, the KMT won back the mayorship of Taipei from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian. The KMT also captured 97 of 176 contested legislative seats.
The number of seats won by the KMT rises to 123 after taking into account the seats awarded to political parties according to the number of total votes they garnered.
Chang said that 124 seats will give the ruling party a comfortable majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan and ensure a stable Cabinet and more efficient legislative process.

Chang regretted the party's loss in Kaohsiung, where an incumbent KMT mayor lost to a DPP challenger by only 4,565 votes, saying that the party respected the voters' choice and would re-examine its policy.
The party official, however, took comfort in the fact that the KMT held onto its majority in Kaohsiung's city council and achieved a 47-percent share in Taipei's city council.
He said that the KMT would work to maintain voters' approval with policies that are well thought out.

Meanwhile, New Party campaign manager Jaw Shau-kong said that he accepts all the blame for the party's failure in the election. The number of seats held by the New Party fell from 21 to seven, though it will receive an additional four because of the number of total votes the party obtained.

Jaw admitted that the New Party's poor showing in the elections rules out the possibility of it playing a vital role in the legislature or of being a king-maker in the next presidential election in 2000.
The founder of the New Party, however, said the group will stick to its aim of being a party for ordinary citizens to win back its supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RETAINS CONTROL OF ROC'S LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Kuomintang (KMT), said on Saturday the ruling party will retain control of the Legislative Yuan by winning 124 seats, compared with the 116 seats held by the party in the present legislature.
He made the remark after more than 60 percent of Taiwan's 14.9 million eligible voters went to the polls to elect candidates to the legislature, which is being expanded from 164 to 225 seats.
Of the total, 176 were directly elected, while 41 will be allocated to parties according to the number of votes they obtain and eight others will be awarded to representatives overseas.

With the results still coming in, the KMT had already won some 100 of the 176 seats chosen directly by voters, while about 40 seats had gone to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and more than 20 to smaller parties, such as the New Party.
In Taiwan province alone, the ruling party won 58 percent of the votes by capturing a total of 83 seats out of the 143 seats being contested.

The heat generated by the mayoral races in Taipei and Kaohsiung may have stolen thunder from the legislative elections, as voter turnout averaged 65.11 percent, compared with 67.75 percent in the last legislative elections.
Changhua County had the highest turnout rate at 77.08 percent, while Hsinchu City had the lowest at 51.99 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WINS IN COUNTIES OF KAOHSIUNG AND TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) performed well in islandwide legislative elections in the opposition stronghold of Kaohsiung Country, southern Taiwan, and in Taipei Country in northern Taiwan.

In Kaohsiung County all six ruling Kuomintang candidates -- incumbent Legislative Yuan Vice President Wang Jin-ping, Hsiao Chin-lang, Lin Yuan-shan, Chung Shao-ho, Lin Yi-shih and Wu Kuang-hsun -- won in the legislative elections.
The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had to settle with the remaining three seats out of the nine contested.

In Taipei County the KMT won 13 of 27 contested seats, while the DPP grabbed nine and the New Party won one, The remaining four seats went to members of two minor political parties and to an independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ADMITS DEFEAT

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) admitted on Saturday that it suffered a defat in the hotly contested three-in-one elections.
DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said the loss of Taipei mayorship to the ruling Kuomintang marked a significant setback to his party's drive to become a governing party.
Incumbent DPP Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian's defeat also dealt a blow to Taiwan's democratic reforms and the DPP's efforts to promote "Taiwanization," Lin said.
Lin said the DPP also performed poorly in the national legislative elections.
The pro-independence party garnered only about 31 percent of the vote in the legislative elections, lower than 33 percent recorded in the last parliamentary elections.
The DPP managed to win 52 regional seats in the new legislature, Lin said, adding that if at-large seats are caculated, the party will have only 70 to 72 seats in the new legislature.

"The DPP can only find a bit comfort from Frank Hsieh's win in the Kaoshiung mayoral race," Lin said. "With Hsieh's win, all city and county governments in southern Taiwan now are controlled by the DPP."

The DPP headquarters will call a meeting next week to review the party's performance in the just-concluded elections for the Legislative Yuan and the mayorships and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Lin said he should take the balme for the party's latest electoral defeat, adding that he will decide whether to resign over the defeat next week.
Lin further said the DPP should learn a lesson from its latest defeat. "The party should redouble its efforts in order to win evn more popular support in the future elections."
Lin also expressed his regret over the rampant "negative" campaign strategy, such as mudslinging and violence, seen in the run-up to the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTA HEAD QUITS OVER ELECTION RESULTS

TEXT.P: New Taiwan Alliance (NTA) head Peng Pai-hsien announced on Saturday resignation from his post within the pro-independence group after candidates fielded by the group suffered a humiliating defeat in two local elections.

Expressing deep regret and sorrow in a public declaration, Peng, who is also the incumbent Nantou County chief, said he decided to quit the post to assume responsibility for the group's sweeping defeat in Saturday's polls.

The NTA, a splinter faction of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), fielded 13 candidates for the first time in the islandwide legislative race and five hopefuls in city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities. Only one NTA candidate was elected in the legislative poll.

Urging NTA members to continue fighting for the future of Taiwan, Peng said he is gravely worried about Taiwan's future, as the election results showed that Taiwan's political activities are not running on the right track and are symbolized by figureheads, black money and factional struggles.

NTA Secretary-General Hsiu Tien-tsai, a legislator representing southern Taiwan's Tainan City and the only NTA candidate to win legislative re-election, expressed surprise at the group's landslide defeat in Saturday's elections.
Public opinion polls prior to the voting showed that half the NTA's candidates were likely to be elected, but the final outcomes were a far cry from what they had imagined.
Describing the NTA's defeat in Saturday's elections as a major setback to Taiwan's democratic movement, Hsiu said that it is an indication that room for "clean politics" in Taiwan is limited.

Hsiu, however, said the NTA has no regrets over what it has fought for, despite the group's electoral losses, because he is confident that the NTA will continue to exist as a ray of hope in Taiwan politics.

Meanwhile, Lee Ching-hsiung of the Taiwan Independence Party, managed to win a legislative seat for the DPP splinter party in Kaohsiung's first electoral district. Lee ranked at the bottom among six elected lawmakers.
All other Taiwan Independence Party candidates in both the legislative and city council elections were eliminated.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULTS OF LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS IN TAIPEI AND KAOHSIUNG

2. Wang Hsueh-fung (DPP): 80,978.
