DOC.HEADLINE: 3-IN-ONE ELECTIONS SYMBOLIZE TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIC MATURITY: AIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The just-concluded three-in-one elections indicated that Taiwan has become a mature democracy with a multi-party political system, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said on Saturday.
The top American liaison officer with Taiwan made the statement at an election returns information center set up by the Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C.
Bush said Taiwan voters have made their choices in Saturday's elections for the island's national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of its two largest cities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung.
"It is the most important that people's free will can be expressed," Bush said.

Commenting on Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian's defeat, Bush said as Chen, a stalwart of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is young, he will still have a bright political future.

Meanwhile, ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said the smooth, peaceful conclusion of the three-in-one elections marks a step forward in Taiwan's democratic development. "We take pride in our progress in this regard," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S POWER MORE SOLID AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Significant gains in the Legislative Yuan will strengthen the ruling Kuomintang's leadership and will boost its chances of winning the next presidential election in 2000, said party Secretary-General John Chang on Saturday.

Jubilant over the party's better-than-expected showing in the elections of legislators, and its win the in race for Taipei mayor, Chang said the election results will give the party a strong leadership position in the legislature and an advantage in the race for president in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP EXCHANGE CONTROL OF TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) exchanged control of the island's largest two cities in Saturday's mayoral elections.
Ma Ying-jeou retook Taipei for the KMT, unseating incumbent DPP Mayor Chen Shui-bian, while in southern Taiwan, incumbent KMT Kaohsiung Wu Den-yih lost to DPP challenger Frank Hsieh.
Chen beat the KMT's candidate, Huang Ta-chou, to grab Taipei's mayorship, while Wu defeated the DPP's Chang Chun-hsiung in the last mayoral elections four years ago.

Celebrating his victory with thousands of supporters who gathered at his headquarters, Ma said that his victory is a milestone for the social integration. "It's a victory not for me, but for all the citizens."

Saying his election demonstrates the people's confidence in the reform programs initiated by Republic of China President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, Ma vowed to do his utmost to serve Taipei citizens.
He proclaimed that he will adopt some of the campaign promises of other candidates, as long as they are feasible and good for the city, in promoting the city's development.

Outlining his "city government team" -- or the lineup of the new city government -- Ma said that he will recruit talents, regardless of their party affiliation and gender, as long as they are able and uphold high moral standards.
Chen meanwhile, admitted his failure as thousands of enthusiastic supporters shouted "President Chen! President Chen!"
Chen has been widely considered the most likely DPP candidate in Taiwan's next presidential election, slated for 2000.
Chen lost despite a 70-percent approval rating, as measured in recent polls.

"The relentless decision of the voters towards his 'progressive city government team' just says that the citizens of a great city are expecting much more and greater administrative efficiency from the city government," Chen said.
While congratulating Ma for the victory, the New Party's Taipei mayoral candidate, Wang Chien-shien, urged Ma to take better care of less fortunate groups in the future.
Wang, a former finance minister, said that although he lost, he succeeded in encouraging a "clean election" culture.
Wang, who co-founded the New Party, said he would no longer assume any post within the NP, but would instead help with the development of the party as a volunteer.

While in Kaohsiung, the DPP's Hsieh said that will enhance Kaohsiung city's cooperation with the four other counties and cities under the control of the DPP to establish a "new southern world" to correct the long-standing imbalance between the development of northern and southern Taiwan.
In addition to Kaohsiung City, the DPP now governs Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pingtung counties and Taiwan City.

Describing his victory as "a miracle," Hsieh said every vote he has received represents the "deep expectation" of the voters, adding that he would try his utmost to promote the development of the city.
A disappointed Wu said that he hopes the mudslinging and trading of accusations among candidates during the campaign period "will soon be over" and that peace and calmness will return to the city.
"We shouldn't try to find any excuse for the setback -- it's me who should be blamed," Wu told his supporters.

Wu, who has been governing the southern Taiwan port city for eight years, extended his appreciation to Kaohsiung citizens for giving him the chance to serve them. "I promised to be a Kaohsiung man for the rest of my life and will always be concerned about, and dedicate myself to the development of, the city," he said.

Meanwhile, both the NP's Wu Chien-kuo and independent Cheng Teh-yao said that their loss were not "beyond" estimation. Wu said he will in the future serve as a voluntary worker and Cheng said he may take part in other elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LITTLE CHANGE IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCILS

TEXT.P: Results of Saturday's elections showed little change in the structure of city councils in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

In Taipei, the Kuomintang (KMT) controls 23 of 52 seats in the new city council, while the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has 19 and the New Party has nine, in addition to one seat which went to an independent.
In the current council, the KMT holds 22 seats; the DPP 18; the New Party 11; and independent one seat.

In southern Taiwan, the KMT and the DPP won 24 seats and 10 seats, respectively, the same number as they held before the elections. The number of seats held by the NP fell to one from two, the Taiwan Independence Party lost its only one seat, while independents gained two more seats, from seven to nine.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING KMT WINS 123 SEATS IN LEGISLATIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: After a heated but rational competition, 68.09 percent of 14.9 million eligible voters turned out on Saturday to elect 225 legislators.
The ruling Kuomintang won a total of 4,659,679 votes, or 46.42 percent of the total votes cast, capturing a total of 123 seats in the legislature, well beyond the 113 needed for a majority.
Of Taiwan's opposition parties, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) fared best, capturing 29.56 percent of the vote, or 2,966,835 votes, and winning 70 seats.

The DPP was followed by the New Party, which received 7.06 percent of all ballots cast, or 708,465 votes, and gained 11 seats; the Democratic Alliance, which won 375,117 votes, or 3.74 percent of the total, and four seats; the Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP), which won 145,118 votes, or 1.45 percent, and one seat; the Nonepartisan Alliance, which won 66,033 votes, or 0.66 percent, and four seats; and the New Nation Alliance, which won 157,826 votes, or 1.57 percent, and one seat.
Independents won a total of 946,431 votes, or 9.43 percent, and 12 seats.

Of the 225 seats in the legislature, 176 were directly elected and 41 will be filled by appointment to represent the nationawide constituency. Another eight seats to represent overseas Chinese will also be allotted proposionaltely by party appointment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S RULING PARTY WINS IN ELECTIONS (1)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Saturday won an absolute majority in the Legislative Yuan, maintained its control of Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils, and reclaimed Taipei city, but lost the mayorship of Kaohsiung in elections.

Voters in Taiwan, the Republic of China, went to the polls in the day for the election of 225 legislators, 52 members of the Taipei City Council, 44 members of the Kaohsiung City Council, and the mayors of the two cities.

Many political analysts see the KMT's victory in the elections as an indication of Taiwan people's desire to maintain the status quo of cross-strait relations and their confidence in the ruling party. The KMT has been in power here for nearly 50 years, during which time Taiwan developed from a poor agricultural economy after the second world war into one of the world's major trading nations.

The legislative election has been a focal point of attention. It is generally believed that the election result may affect the development of cross-strait relations, because there is a clear difference in the policies of the KMT and the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) towards mainland China. The KMT favors unification with mainland China in the future when it becomes a free and democratic country, while the DPP prefers a permanent separation from the Chinese mainland. It is feared by many people that a victory for the DPP in the legislative election may push Taiwan to confrontation with mainland China.

The Legislative Yuan, the nation's parliament, has 225 seats. It takes 113 seats to win an absolute majority. In Saturday's legislative election, the KMT won 46.43 percent of the vote, or a total of 123 seats, exceeding the threshold for an absolute majority by 10 seats. Voter turnout in the legislative election was 68.09 percent.

In addition to the KMT and the DPP, four other political organizations fielded candidates for the elections. They are the New Party, the Taiwan Independence Party, the New Country Alliance, and the Democratic Union of Taiwan.

Established in 1986, the DPP has become a major challenger to the KMT in national elections. It won 70 seats, or 29.56 percent of the vote in Saturday's legislative election. The New Party, which was established by several former leaders of the KMT in 1993, is the third largest party. It won 11 seats, or 7.06 percent of the vote Saturday. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S RULING PARTY WINS IN ELECTIONS (2)

TEXT.P: The three other political groups are rather new and small. The Taiwan Independent Party and the New Country Alliance, which were formed recently by former leaders of the DPP, won just one seat each in the Legislative Yuan Saturday. The Democratic Union of Taiwan, established by local politicians who broke away from the KMT, obtained four seats. Independent candidates won the remaining 12 seats.

The Taipei mayoral race is also a focal point of attention, because it is believed by many observers that the DPP may gain a great momentum in the Presidential election to be held in March, 2000, if mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP is reelected. However, in Saturday's election, KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou won 766,000 votes to the 688,000 votes taken by incumbent mayor Chen.

Ma, 48, is a US-trained scholar and politician. After graduation from the National Taiwan University in 1972, he won a master's degree in law from New York University in 1976, and a Ph D from the Harvard University Law School in 1981. He served as minister of justice and minister of state from 1993 to 1996.

Candidate Frank C. T. Hsieh (Hsieh Chang-ting) of the DPP successfully unseated mayor Wu Den-yih of the KMT. Hsieh was elected Taipei city councilor in 1981 and member of the Legislative Yuan in 1990. He has been chairman of the DPP Central Advisory Committee since 1996. Born in 1946, he graduated from the National Taiwan University in 1974 with a master's degree in law. He also studied in a doctoral law program at the Kyoto University of Japan in 1975.

Taipei and Kaohsiung are the two largest cities of Taiwan. They are different from other cities on the island in that they are directly under the jurisdiction of the central government. The KMT tried very hard to reclaim Taipei, which was lost to the DPP in 1994.

There are 52 seats in the Taipei city council. In Saturday's election, the KMT won 23 seats, while the DPP and the New Party took 19 and 9 seats respectively. The remaining one seat went to an independent candidate. The KMT obtained 24 out of the 44 seats in the Kaohsiung city council.

Secretary General John Chang of the KMT said in the evening that Saturday's successful elections are indications that Taiwan has made considerable progress in democratization, and that the ruling Kuomintang has won the confidence of the people in its various moderate and effective policies.

Economic and social developments enabled Taiwan to lift martial law and the restrictions on establishment of new political parties in the late 1980s. Taiwan has transformed into a modern democracy as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
@The Central Daily News:
Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh elected Taipei and Kaohsiung mayor, respectively, while Kuomintang dominates legislative, and Taipei, Kaohsiung city council seats.
@The China Times:
Mayorships change in Taipei and Kaohsiung. Kuomintang retains control in Kaohsiung city council, while none of three major parties manages to win half the Taipei city council seats.
@The United Daily News:
KMT's Ma Ying-jeou wins Taipei mayoral race, and DPP's Frank Hsieh beats incumbent KMT Kaohsiung mayor Wu Den-yih by narrow margin. KMT still fails to hold half of Taipei's city council seats. New Party supporters apparently divided.
The Liberty Times:
'Skies changed' in Taipei and Kaohsiung. KMT comes back, DPP suffers slight defeat and New Party nearly collapses.
The Independence Morning Post:
Political landscape changes sharply in Taipei and Kaohsiung. KMT wins overwhelming victory in Legislative elections by grabbing 123 seats as compared with 70 by DPP and 11 by NP.
The Commons Daily:
Taipei mayor Chen shui-bian defeated, mainly because of Kuomintang and New Party supporters collaboration. Kaohsiung mayor Wu Den-yih was beat by tape scandal.
The China Post:
Taipei: Ma Ying-jeou, Kaohsiung: Frank Hsieh. Ma defeats Chen by over 78,000 votes; Hsieh edges out Wu by a narrow margin.
The China News:
KMT storms back. Ruling party holds majority of legislative seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS OF TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 6, or Oct. 18 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1917: Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1921: Britain signs peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Teheran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts to muster its reservists, for the first time in the history of ROC military service.
1971: South Korea's President Park Chung-hee warns of danger of invasion from the north and declares a national emergency.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: US President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for US air and naval basses there.
1979: The Chinese communists ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, chairman asks police to maintain order for the first time.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S CHAIRMAN CARD, NEW PARTY DESERTION SAID TO COST CHEN RACE

TEXT.P: Incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian lost his re-election bid because of the "chairman card" played by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and because many New Party (NP) members abandoned their party's candidate in favor of the KMT's, Chen's campaign chief, Luo Wen-chia, said Sunday.

KMT Chairman and Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's strong promotion of the party's candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, played absolutely the key role in Ma's victory, Luo said, citing surveys that indicated about 60 percent of the city's voters who had remained undecided up until the end had voted for Lee in the last presidential election.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- of which Chen is a member -- also miscalculated the number of votes that would go to NP challenger Wang Chien-shien, Luo said. The DPP had estimated Wang would receive at least 5 percent of the vote, though he ended up receiving only 2.9 percent.
"It's really beyond our expectations," said a downtrodden Luo, who was the executive secretary-general of Chen's campaign headquarters.

He noted, however, that the number of votes Chen received in Saturday's election rose 3 percent over the number he received four years ago. The additional votes meant that Chen's support among the middle-class increased, Luo said, adding that this indicates Chen's administration was respected.
That increased support was the most important factor for Chen's camp in the race, Luo said.
Chen, who lost to Ma by more than 78,000 votes, did not appear at his campaign headquarters Sunday, but instead drove to Tainan, southern Taiwan, to visit his father-in-law, who is ill.
According to Chen's campaign base, he will begin a citywide tour to thank his supporters Monday, and the tour will last three days.
He is also scheduled to hold a party next Saturday evening to thank those who voted for him, according to his headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUPS SAY EXECUTION KILLS 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS'

TEXT.P: Human rights groups say the execution of a man in mainland China on Sunday means the end of the concept of "one country, two systems" in Hong Kong, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported Saturday.
The CBC was referring to the execution of Cheong Tze-keong, the leader of a crime syndicate in Hong Kong, the former British territory that has no death penalty.
It quoted human rights activists as saying that Cheong should have been tried where he committed most of his crimes -- Hong Kong.

Cheong and 35 of his gang members were convicted of arms smuggling and of the kidnappings of two Hong Kong property tycoons. Those kidnappings were never reported to Hong Kong police, according to the CBC.

Cheong and his gang were captured in the mainland Chinese city of Guangzhou. The Hong Kong government did not seek extradition of Cheong, saying it had no evidence of the kidnappings. Besides, Hong Kong does not have an extradition agreement with mainland China.
The CBC quoted lawyer and Legislator Martin Lee as saying that in this case the Hong Kong government is sending out the wrong signal and should have argued strenuously for Cheong's return.

"The rule of law is the last ditch in our defense of human rights in Hong Kong, and if that is the way the Hong Kong government plays with the law, then I think we are in a very, very sorry state," Lee was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY SUPERSTAR REGAINS GLORY FOR KMT

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the golden boy of the ruling Kuomintang who announced his candidacy so late that prospects of winning the Taipei mayoral race were considered shaky, upset the city's incumbent mayor with an overwhelming victory in Saturday's elections.

Although other KMT members were considered running as the party's candidate in the Taipei mayoral race, Ma, 48, had long been regarded as the trump card in the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) efforts to unseat the formidable incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Ma defeated Chen, who has ruled Taipei City since 1994, by more than 80,000 votes, a surprise to all parties involved in the election.

Ma did not announce his candidacy until late May on the grounds that he saw no evidence of support from members higher up in the party's hierarchy, which had him fearing there was "no goal to fight for."
After some serious soul searching, Ma announced his "sacred mission" in May after hearing -- and heeding -- the "continuous calls from ordinary citizens appealing to him to run."
At an election victory press conference, Ma credited his victory to all the citizens of Taipei and to President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui's latest speech on the "new Taiwanese."
Ma said the concept of the "new Taiwanese" espoused by President Lee during his last campaign rally won wide recognition from Taipei citizens, leading to his final victory over the incumbent mayor.
While one of his opponents challenged him over his ethnic background, Ma said, President Lee's timely statement of the "new Taiwanese" helped clear up confusion.

Ma said although his parents are "mainlanders" who moved to Taiwan after the Republic of China relocated its government seat to Taipei in 1949, he considers himself a native Taiwanese after living in Taipei for more than four decades.
During the campaign, Chen, who is native Taiwanese, pointed out Ma's mainland roots on several occasions.
President Lee's concept of the "new Taiwanese," which refers to all Chinese people who have settled in Taiwan -- however recently or long ago -- is a doctrine full of tolerance and respect, Ma noted.
He said the day of his election represents the beginning of a new integration of ethnic groups in the city. "Ethnicity as an issue is now history in Taipei," he stressed.
At the press conference, Ma also credited those New Party supporters who were willing to bury the hatchet on Ma's behalf.

According to a post-election public opinion poll conducted by The United Evening News, 77 percent of New Party supporters cast their votes for Ma instead of New Party candidate Wang Chien-hsien, who was running a distant third in the mayoral race.
Only by voting for Ma could we voters recover Taipei from the rule of the pro-independence DPP, New Party supporters said.

Ma was particularly effusive in his appreciation of senior Presidential adviser Wu Poh-hsiung. Ma said Wu has always been his fan and supporter, even during Ma's time in the political wilderness after leaving his post as justice minister. Ma's thanks to Wu underlined previous speculation that Wu had been highly instrumental in persuading Ma to enter the race.
Ma shed tears when he was greeted by wheelchair-bound former Premier Sun Yun-suan at his final campaign rally. Sun was stricken by an apoplexy during his tenure as premier in 1984.

Ma promised his voters that he will be a mayor who welcomes input from all parties. All individuals of integrity and with ability may be members of his staff, no matter what their political affiliation, Ma noted. (to be continued....)

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY SUPERSTAR (II)

TEXT.P: Ma said he does not exclude the possibility of inviting his New Party rival, Wang Chien-hsien, to serve as an adviser to his city administration after he is sworn in on Dec. 25.

Wang, formerly finance minister, is a man of integrity with high-caliber expertise in finance, Ma said, adding that Wang could lend expertise and experience to the new Taipei city government in financial matters and in its efforts against corruption.

Ma, a graduate of National Taiwan University, obtained an LLD from Harvard University. He was the English translator and secretary for late President Chiang Ching-kuo and became deputy bureau director of the Presidential Office at the age of 31.

Ma, who was fawned over in women's magazines for his charisma, sense of humor and boyish good looks, was appointed to a ministerial-level position at 38, making him the youngest Cabinet member in the Republic of China. A charismatic official who regularly jogs in the morning and maintains close relations with the public, Ma has long been a superstar in Taiwan's political arena.
Two years ago, at age 46, Ma was stripped of his post as Justice Minister and was appointed minister-without-portfolio, possibly for trying to go too far too fast in his campaign to fight crime.
His war on crime and corruption had many skeptics, many of whom thought Ma was a conscientious man who had been stuck with a difficult -- or even impossible -- task.

Ma, a soft-spoken man, said he considered quitting public service once and for all after he was ordered to step down as justice minister, a post in which he had been able to launch a nationwide war against drugs and to step up law enforcement efforts to eradicate violence and corruption.

He told then Premier Lien Chan that he would give himself one year to see how he could adjust to a situation that he considered tantamount to "removing a player from the court." He overcame his personal objections, accepting the minister-without-portfolio post without letting any signs of discontent show for almost a year.

But before a year had passed, however, Ma resigned as minister-without-portfolio. The resignation was prompted by changing political ethics and by a protest march by more than 50,000 people in Taipei who were demanding an apology by President Lee Teng-hui and the resignation of the premier for Taiwan's worsening social order.

Although Ma had been widely considered the only challenger with the potential to unseat Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian in the 1998 mayoral election, he had never been the "king's man," and had received limited support from the power center in a potential election.

Ma's father, who retired many years ago from a senior KMT position, once said that it would be a mistake for Ma to refuse to run while still politically influential, but that it was a mistake for the KMT to ask Ma to run after stripping him of all his political resources.

After resigning his minister-without-portfolio post, Ma did not remain idle. He was a familiar face at more than 10 social organizations, including the World Vision of Taiwan, the Garden of Hope Foundation -- a prime mover behind Taiwan's anti-child prostitution drive -- and several groups for the disabled.

Ma also accepted a teaching post at National Chengchi University. He never ceased in his academic research efforts, and he is considered one of the most influential experts on the Tiaoyutais, a chain of tiny islets in the East China Sea claimed by Taiwan, mainland China and Japan, which have been a focus of on-and-off diplomatic disputes over the last several decades.

Not even Saturday night's election victory and a celebration that lasted into the early hours of Sunday morning were enough to throw Ma off track. Sunday morning he showed up at the park for his customary morning jog, just like clockwork.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S SELF-IDENTIFICATION INCREASING: US OBSERVER

TEXT.P: A US scholar on Sunday said the victory of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections would relax those from Beijing and Washington who were worried that pro-Taiwan independence forces would dominate the island.

Andrew Nathan, a professor at Columbia University in New York, made the remarks at a conference on post-election effects in Taipei. Though the results of the election will dispel some worries, he cautioned against dumping all the aspirins, as some headaches will remain.

Nathan reasoned that the current KMT is different from the one in the past, saying the difference can be sensed from the "Taiwan First" policy of Ma Ying-jeou, who beat a strong rival from the opposition Progressive Democratic Party (DPP) in the Taipei mayoral election.

The more democratic processes that the Taiwan people experience, the greater their degree of identification with the island, Nathan said, explaining that he believes the development will gradually lead to a widening of distance between Taiwan and mainland China.
Attention should be paid to this trend, he said.
The election observer, meanwhile, noted that during this year's elections, Taiwan voters enjoyed flexibility, meaning they did not feel locked in to a single party or bloc of candidates.

Nathan also foresees an atmosphere of "bi-party politics" gradually shaping up in Taiwan, while the 15 independents elected to the legislature must decide whether to ally themselves with the pro-reunification KMT or the pro-independence DPP.

As to the fact that Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the DPP lost his re-election bid, the US political observer said that is not necessarily a setback for the party, because Chen won a 46-percent share of the votes in the election, up from a 43-percent share in 1994. In legislative elections, this time around the DPP won 31 percent of the vote, down only slightly from the 32 percent they won in the last legislative elections.

Nathan's opinion was echoed by Chu Yun-han, a political science professor at National Taiwan University, who said in the conference that the DPP has enjoyed an average support rate of 36 percent in the capital over the past 10 years.
Also noting that Chen received 46 percent of the vote in Saturday's elections compared with 43 percent four years ago, Chu said that fact indicates Chen fought a successful campaign battle.

Overall the KMT's performance in the "three-in-one" elections was mixed, Chu said. The ruling party won back some supporters of the New Party, a splinter group of the KMT, but lost votes to independent candidates, he said.
The "three-in-one" elections comprised elections for the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayorships, for city council seats in those two cities and for the national legislature.
Kaohsiung's mayorship was taken by the DPP's Frank Hsieh, who beat incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yih of the KMT by about 4,500 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS WHIP URGES CHAIRMAN TO QUIT FOR DEFEAT IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, Chou Po-lun, on Sunday urged DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsung to resign to assume responsibility for the party's loss in the Taipei mayoral election and its loss of seats in the national legislature.
Chou also called for incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who is still highly popular in the DPP, to run for the DPP's chairmanship and to run for president in 2000.
Chou made the statements at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

The KMT won sweeping victories in Taipei mayoral and legislative elections, while the DPP's share of seats in the legislature declined to a record low of 29.55 percent. Chou described it as a devastating defeat and urged Lin to set a good example by stepping down as chairman.
Despite the KMT's victory in the elections, there are plenty of conflicts within the KMT, Chen should therefore lead a united DPP against the KMT and on to the presidency, Chou added.
The DPP said they would discuss the future of Chairman Lin next week.

But Chou said the matter was one of personal responsibility and should not be settled by the party. He noted that two former DPP chairmen, Shih Ming-teh and Hsu Shin-liang, resigned to accept responsibility for election defeats.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS PROMINENTLY REPORTED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Hong Kong news media have prominently reported and gave positive evaluations on the free elections held in Taiwan Saturday.

Voters in Taiwan went to the polls in the day for the election of the mayor and city councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as the members of the Legislative Yuan. In the elections, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) won an absolute majority in the Legislative Yuan, the nation's parliament, retaining its control of the city councils of the two biggest cities of Taiwan, and reclaimed Taipei, but lost the mayorship of Kaohsiung.

The Oriental Daily News reported that the KMT took over 50 percent of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, and said editorially that the elections have ushered "Chinese democracy" into a new era. Hong Kong people are proud of Taiwan's success in promoting democracy, since people on Taiwan are also Chinese, the editorial said.
Ma Ying-jeou's election as the mayor of Taipei will be conducive to the KMT's success in the presidential elections to be held in March 2000, the newspaper said.

The Ming Pao Daily News reported that the KMT won the Taipei mayoral race and took more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan. The newspaper also said in an editorial that Ma's victory in the race will help cross-strait relations, and enhance the KMT's political position. The Sing Tao Daily News said editorially that people in Hong Kong, Macao, and mainland China are very concerned about the elections, because the election results may have an impact on Taiwan's presidential elections in the year 2000 and the development of cross-strait relations.
Hong Kong Standard, the South China Morning Post, the Apple Daily, and three other newspapers of Hong Kong have also reported the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT LIEN CHAN MAKES TRANSIT STOP IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan arrived in New York Saturday for a one-day transit stay before heading for Nicaragua, to which he is bring humanitarian aid from the Republic of China.
Lien will visit Nicaragua and three other ROC allies in Central America, all among those hardest hit by Hurricane Mitch a few weeks ago.

Just as in May when he stopped in New York en route to Costa Rica for the inauguration ceremony of President Miguel Angel Rodriguez, Lien kept a low profile regarding his Saturday New York transit to avoid irritating Beijing, which has tried hard to isolate the Republic of China in the international community.
Under a tacit mutual understanding, Lien and his party engaged in no public activities or press conferences during their two-night stay in New York.
Before arriving in New York, Lien and his entourage made a brief stop in Seattle on the United States' West coast. During the stay, he kept abreast of the latest election developments in Taiwan.

He said he was thrilled to learn that Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou defeated incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian with an overwhelming victory, while he felt sorry that Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, also a KMT member, was upset in his re-election bid by Democratic Progressive Party challenger Frank Hsieh.

Lien is scheduled to fly to Nicaragua on a chartered flight Monday morning on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui to express the concern of the ROC government and its people for Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala.
Lien said the ROC government plans to assist the four countries in building schools and hospitals, and in repairing damaged bridges and highways.

The ROC government has offered a total of US$2.6 million in relief aid to the four Central American counties after they were ravaged by the hurricane. Moreover, several Taiwan charity organizations have also launched fund-raising campaigns to collect aid.

Lien was accompanied on his trip by a group of senior ROC officials, including Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean, and Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to President Lee.
Also among his entourage were World Vision of Taiwan President Shao Ching-ming; Chen Chang-wen, vice president of the ROC Red Cross Society; and representatives from several religious groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATURDAY'S ELECTIONS MAY IMPROVE TAIWAN'S IMAGE: BELLOCHI

TEXT.P: Saturday's elections may help improve Taiwan's image as a democratic country, Nataleh H. Bellochi, former board chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said here Saturday.
Voters on Taiwan went to the polls Saturday to elect the mayor and city councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as the members of the Legislative Yuan.

Bellochi said that Taiwan's democratic image is in sharp contrast to the situation in mainland China, and that Beijing must quicken its path of reform, otherwise the gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will become even wider.
When American people talk about Taiwan, they think of its vibrant democracy nowadays, he said, adding that when they talked about it 10 years ago, they thought of the goods "made in Taiwan".

He pointed out that voter turnout in Saturday's elections exceeded 80 percent, indicating democracy is flourishing in Taiwan. This is a good development, and a good condition for improvement of relations between the United States and Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN LITERATURE HELPED HSIEH UNSEAT WU: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: The narrow victory enjoyed by the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, Frank Hsieh, over incumbent mayor Wu Den-yih of the Kuomintang can be attributed largely to Hsieh's election literature, which stressed the need for a change in leadership, analysts said on Sunday.
A member of Wu's camp said before Saturday that if Wu were defeated, it would largely be the result of an eight-year incumbency that has caused people in Kaohsiung to lose curiosity in him.
Voters took to heart Hsieh's propaganda, and Wu was defeated by himself rather than by Hsieh, analysis added.

Wu's propaganda -- most notably a videotape voluntarily shot by actress Pai Ping-ping in which she denounces Hsieh for acting as a defense attorney for one of her daughter's killers, Chen Chin-hsing -- also played a critical role in unseating Wu.
Pai in the tape describes Hsieh as an accomplice of Chen.
The kidnapping and murder of Pai's daughter, as well as the pursuit of the killers, was one of the most significant events in Taiwan last year.
This videotape, originally conceived as Wu's trump card in his propaganda war against Hsieh, ended up costing Wu votes.

Even more damaging to Wu was a tape that purportedly contained a conversation between Wu and a paramour. Even though analysis of the tape indicated it may have been edited, the tape cost Wu 2 percent of his supporters, according to a pre-election poll. The damage was greatest among women voters.

"Since the campaign became a war of words, there were no so-called campaign strategies. All the municipal policies put forward were waiting to be shown, but it was too late," said Chen Cho-ming, Wu's campaign manager.
According to Saturday's vote count, Wu beat Hsieh in only four of the city's 11 districts. Four years ago Wu swept all Kaohsiung's districts.
Putting the wrong people in the wrong positions in Wu's election camp also cost him, said one member of Wu's staff.

Many chiefs and important staff members in Kaohsiung's city government who campaigned for Wu knew nothing about communications, despite their competence on the job. As a result, many proved unpopular. Even worse, many bureaucrats enjoyed making tempests in teacups and exploiting civil servants in the city' government.

Hsieh, who moved to Kaohsiung only two years ago and was not highly popular among city residents, recruited former KMT members to run his campaign. The former KMT members knew how the party campaigned and helped Hsieh take over the reins of the southern port city by a narrow margin of 0.58 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui's 'New Taiwanese' slogan heralded internationally.
The China Times:
The Cabinet is not considering reshuffle nor resignation en masse, says Premier Vincent Siew.
The United Daily News:
No need for the Cabinet to resign en masse nor reshuffle, says Executive Yuan.
The Liberty Times:
Plans on composite tax relief will be broached by the Ministry of Finance by the end of December.
The Independence Morning Post:
Premier Vincent Siew says the Cabinet is not resigning en masse.
The Commons Daily:
Chen Shui-bian now heading for presidential bid, says scholar Tien Hung-mao.
The China Post:
Ethnic political rift over after Taipei win: Ma.
Stunning KMT victory seen as new symbol of integration.
The China News:
Taiex expected to rally on KMT win.
Market support and bailout measures will remain after elections, says finance minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULTS OF TAIWAN ELECTIONS SEEN AS POSITIVE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The results of Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections on Saturday are a setback for pro-independence political powers on the island, a development that is conducive to stabilizing cross-Taiwan Strait relations, sources from Beijing's academic sector said on Monday.

Professor Yu Keli of the Institute of Taiwan studies under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences said the election results will help stabilize cross-strait relations as the Kuomintang's ruling power is seen to be consolidated. A strengthened KMT will help ensure there is "less chance for the unexpected to occur," Yu said.

Yu said he is not sure whether the ruling KMT will actively improve cross-strait ties after the elections. Nevertheless the results will "not have an adverse impact" on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait, he said.

Professor Xu Bodong of Beijing University's Taiwan Research Office, whose research focuses on Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian's defeat represents the squelching of the DPP's ruling ambitions, which "makes me happy." Xu said Chen is firm on Taiwan independence and is opposed to the establishment of the so-called three links across the Taiwan Strait.

Other DPP spin-off parties, including the Democratic Alliance, and the New National Alliance, were also badly defeated in the elections for city council seats in Taipei and Kaohsiung and for national legislators, Xu noted.
Xu said the DPP's narrow-mindedness, both internationally and in cross-strait relations, resulted in the opposition party's loss in the elections.

Professor Huang Jiashu of the Chinese People's University of Public Security said the DPP's loss deals a death-blow to the party's presidential aspiration in the 2000 elections. By comparison, Huang said, Beijing is more friendly toward the KMT, which at least has been willing to talk about cross-strait relations, while the DPP has always referred the cross-strait relations as "the relations between two countries."

Huang accused Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of trying to play the ethnic card in the race and said some of Chen's slogans -- such as one indicating two mainlanders were ganging up on Chen in the race and one saying the other two major parties in the election intended to sell out Taiwan -- were unjustifiable lies.

The parents of both Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT, who successfully wrested control of the city from Chen, and Wang Chien-shien, the Taipei mayoral candidate fielded by the New Party, were born in mainland China.
Professor Fan Xizhou of Xiamen University said Chen's defeat is a great defeat for the DPP, as Chen represents the pinnacle of the DPP and Taipei the pinnacle of the island's voting constituencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS OF TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 7, or Oct. 19 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin, prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking which saw the burning of the imperial summer palace by invading troops.
1887: The first US hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey, and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat to Taipei.
1951: Chinese communists launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: Unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1975: US President Gerald Rudolph Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms new Cabinet.
1978: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from a money-transporting truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1985: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1985: The first summit meeting of the seven South Asian nations opens in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: Massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes constitutional guarantee of communist supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1994: In Namibian national elections, President Sam Nujoma's ruling South-West Africa People's Organization wins more than two-thirds of the vote.
1996: Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after nearly 18 days aloft, ending the longest space shuttle flight ever.
Confucius: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still it is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you because of your attainments. But he is truly a wise and good man who feels no discomposure even when he is not noticed of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S VOTERS APPROVE OF KMT'S STEADY POLICIES: NEW YORK TIMES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By David Wang and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Prominent newspapers in New York credited the performance of Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) in Dec. 5 elections, saying that voters in Taiwan have approved of the KMT's firm and steady policies to lead the island into the 21st century.

The New York Times pointed out that the victory of KMT Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou has frustrated the political future of Chen Shui-bian, the incumbent Taipei mayor and Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) prospective candidate in March 2000 presidential election.
The Times noted that if Chen, the DPP's powerful prospective candidate and one who has always propagated Taiwan independence, becomes president, cross-strait ties would become strained.

Many supporters of the pro-unification New Party abandoned the party's candidate in the race for Taipei mayor, Wang Chien-shien, and instead cast their votes for Ma, the Times noted. The KMT's election wins will help the party overcome the crisis of confidence it encountered in the last Taipei mayoral election. The paper also noted with amazement how deeply rooted is Taiwan's democratization, which is only 10 years old.

Meanwhile, New York's Newsday carried on Sunday a story titled "Taiwan is not ready for independence," in which it noted that Chen was expected to win a second term and run in the 2000 presidential election after President Lee Teng-hui's term ends.

New York's Newsday noted that the KMT has added to its majority in the Legislative Yuan in addition to unseating Taipei's mayor. This has shown that Taiwan's voters support the KMT's "big-stick and suspicious engagement policy" toward mainland China. In the meantime, the outcome of the election may calm Beijing or even Washington and Tokyo, according to the paper.

The Chinese-language "World Journal" published a commentary titled "New Taiwanese are molding the next presidential hopeful." In it the paper argued that Chen would still be the DPP's candidate in the 2000 presidential election, despite his failed re-election bid.
Meanwhile, incumbent Vice President Lien Chan is a prospective candidate for KMT. The commentary claimed Lien and Chen will battle each other over "ethnicity," "image" and cross-strait relations.

The Hong Kong-based "Ming Pao Daily News" thinks that the KMT's win in the three-in-one election means that the majority of Taiwan's voters support its policies. As for the loss by the KMT's candidate in Kaohsiung's mayoral election -- incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yih -- the paper noted that he was hurt by a tape that purportedly contained a conversation between Wu and a woman with whom he was allegedly having an affair.

Wu was also hurt by his circulating a video made by television actress Pai Ping-ping in which she called the DPP's candidate in the city's mayoral race -- Frank Hsieh -- an accomplice in the murder of her daughter.
Hsieh acted as a defense attorney for one of the alleged killers, Chen Chin-shin.
Voters faulted Wu for circulating the tape in an attempt to sully Hsieh's character.

His failure to keep promises made when elected to a second term in 1994 and a lack of support by three of the city's more prominent families -- the Chen family, the Wang family and the Chu family -- hurt him as well, according to the paper.
According to the paper, the victory in the Taipei mayoral race by Ma was due to, as Ma asserted, the widespread acceptance of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's ideas on the "new Taiwanese."

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIZENS OF TAIPEI VOTE FOR STABILITY: NEWSWEEK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The results in the election for Taipei's mayor indicates that city residents prefer a stable living environment to exposing themselves to the danger of attack by mainland China, according to US-based Newsweek magazine.

In its newest issue, the magazine reported that the victory by Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) over incumbent Mayor and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member Chen Shui-bian is a barometer of public opinion.

The magazine said voters' rejection of Chen, whose pro-independence position tends to irritate mainland authorities, in favor of Ma means they are inclined to maintain the status quo and desire peaceful relations with the mainland.
Ma's victory may encouarge the belief by the mainland that Taipei is not practicing democracy at the expense of its own security, Newsweek added.

The magazine also offered an overview of the DPP, from its days as an underground opposition party that fought against the KMT in the 70s to its evolution into a legitimate party that won over many supporters in the 80s, to its zenith -- Chen's election as Taipei mayor in 1994.

Although Chen has during his term tried to tone down the party's independence overtures-- such as the holding of an islandwide referendum to decide Taiwan's future-- and tried to obscure his pro-dndependence leanings while serving as a mayor, it has not been enough, according to the magazine. His failed re-election bid may prompt the party to keep silent on the issue of independence in the next presidental election in 2000.

As for Ma, whose parents are from mainland China and is therefore regarded as "mainlander" as well, Newsweek attributed his victory to the endorsement he received from President Lee Teng-hui and to the willingness of Taiwan's people to include non-native Taiwanese in the establishment of the island's identity.
The election results may also relieve slightly the Beijing authorities, but the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are still far from making peace.
And despite Ma's mainland roots, he is not expected to be any less wary of the mainland than are native Taiwanese, the magazine noted.

"What the people in Taiwan really want is peace and stability," Ma was quoted as saying. He is proved right by his victory, which also shows Beijing that democracy does not necessarily mean chaos, Newsweek said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN TAKES A DAY OFF IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan successfully ridded himself of reporters and enjoyed a day of rest in New York on Sunday.

Lien is leading an ROC delegation via New York to Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala, four ROC allies in Central America that were hard hit by Hurricane Mitch several weeks ago. Lien and his delegation were slated to leave New York for Nicaragua on Monday morning to convey the ROC's concern over the devastation and to offer assistance.

Lien left his hotel early Sunday morning, before reporters for New York-based Chinese-language media showed up. Lien left the hotel accompanied by Charles Teng, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York. That evening he appeared at a banquet that Teng had arranged to welcome Lien's group.

Members of the ROC mission, as well as officials in the ROC's New York trade office, were unwilling to reveal Lien's schedule on Sunday to the media. They said his activities that day were all private.

The reporters who were waiting in vain for Lien at his hotel Sunday morning were greeted by a casually attired Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who refused to answer questions from the media and said he was preparing to go shopping.

Other members in Lien's delegation besides Hu are Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean, Public Construction Commission Chairman Ou Chin-der, Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR ON DOWNWARD TREND DUE TO WEAK COMMODITY PRICES

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar is on a downward trend again and moving toward 60 US cents because of a slump and weakening commodity prices in the world market, experts said.
Australia is one of the world's major producers and exporters of commodities.

They said the fortune of the Australian currency started waning last week as the threat of a blowout in the current account deficit emerged once again and official interest rates fell by 02.5 percentage points.
The Australian dollar fell considerably last week and closed at 61.75 US cents on Friday, and it was trading at 61.65 US cents on Monday morning.
The Australian dollar plunged to a record low of about 55 US cents in August this year.
Analysts predicted the outlook for commodities remains now bleak with the global economy expected to slow significantly in 1999.

"We think the Australian dollar has some further weakness in the new term. The major factor is the weakness in commodity prices. The second factor is the likelihood of further (Japanese) yen weakness or US dollar strength," said Saul Eslake, chief economist at ANZ Investment Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS TENNESSEE GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that Taiwan voters demonstrated their political maturity and sense in the just-concluded "three-in-one" elections, which marked another step forward in the Republic of China's democratic development.
Lee said that although the campaign process was at sixes and sevens -- fraught with noise and hullabaloo -- it also indicated the Taiwan people's enthusiastic participation in democratic politics.
Lee made the remarks when he met with Don Sundquist, governor of the US state of Tennessee, who is currently visiting Taipei.
The president praised candidates in the election for removing so quickly the campaign banners, flags and signs that have engulfed the city's buildings, streets and sidewalks in recent weeks.
Candidates were required to pay to the election commission a clean-up deposit to be refunded after their campaign material has been removed.
The quick removal of the banners has returned the city to its normal state, and it indicates that the city and people of Taipei are socially well developed, Lee noted.
During the meeting, Lee expressed a hearty welcome to Sundquist and called for closer bilateral investment and trade exchanges between Taiwan and Tennessee.

Sundquist said he was impressed with the high voter turnout in the Dec. 5 elections, which he said is living proof of Taiwan's success in democratic reform, an achievement worth emulation by other fledgling or aspiring democracies.

Tennessee and Taiwan province have maintained close and cordial relations since the two knotted sisterhood ties, Sundquist said. Both are blessed with low tax rates, hard-working people, entrepreneurial spirit, free markets and free societies, and the two should further bolster cooperation and exchanges, the governor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION RESULTS OFFER REBIRTH FOR TAIWAN'S NATIONALIST PARTY

TEXT.P: The ruling Nationalist Party (Kuomintang) of the Republic of China on Taiwan found its hand considerably strengthened on Sunday, a day after elections that endorsed its moderate policies toward mainland China and steady management of the economy, one of Turkish main newspaper reported Monday.

According to what observers called a rebirth for the 104-year-old party that has ruled Taiwan since its leaders fled the Chinese mainland 49 years ago, the election results mean President Lee Teng-hui can deal with mainland China from a position of increased strength by ignoring critics who have called for more aggressive moves towards reunification as well as those who want formal independence, The Turkish Daily News, whose readers mostly belong to the diplomatic service and the intelligentsia, said.

As to perspectives on Saturday's election, the paper quoted a Taiwanese political science professor as saying that this election confirmed the Nationalist leadership and strengthened its bargaining position when negotiating in the future with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WIN MARKS END OF ETHNIC RIFT

TEXT.P: The success of the ruling Kuomintang in last Saturday's three-in-one elections marks the end of ethnic politics in the island and the beginning of a New Taiwanese identity, according to a consensus among politicians, observers and the media, reported Singapore's Straits Times on Monday.

In Saturday's Taipei mayoral election, the most significant race in the elections, the KMT's Ma Ying-jeou won a hard-fought battle to wrest the Taipei seat from incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Ma on Sunday said his victory signified the end of an ethnic rift that has marked Taiwan's politics over the past five decades. He garnered 51.3 percent of the vote, compared with the 25.89 percent his party took in the last mayoral race in 1994. Chen took 45.91 percent, up from the 43.76 percent he bagged four years ago in Taipei's first direct mayoral elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FIRMS FORCED TO BORROW AT HIGHER COSTS AFTER US BOND RETREAT

TEXT.P: Australia's large businesses now face higher costs when they turn to borrow from domestic banks thanks to a shrinking US corporate bond market and the withdrawal of a handful of foreign banks via the Asian financial crisis.

The Australian Financial Review on Monday reported overseas markets and foreign lenders in early 1990s have forced Australian banks to cut margins on corporate loans to such an extent that they were yielding negative returns.

But these banks are now back in the driver's seat, forcing even their biggest customers, including Broken Hill Proprietary Pty (BHP) and North Ltd., to accept significantly higher borrowing costs, the daily reported.
Analysts attributed the higher borrowing costs to the loss of the US corporate bond market, which has provided more than US$15 billion in capital in 1992 on easier terms than Australian banks.

But since July this year, the US markets, panicked by global uncertainty, have effectively cut themselves off from all but the most highly rated foreign bond issuers and forced most Australian corporations to revive their relationships with domestic banks.

The daily reported competition in the Australian banking industry has also been reduced by the departure of half a dozen Japanese banks. France's Credit Lyonnais is also on the way out with the assets of several still in search of a buyer and at a deep discount to their face value.

Major foreign banks, including UBS, Bank America and Deutsche, were burned by the twin disasters of the collapse of the Russian bond market and the troubles encountered by Long-Term Capital Management, adding to the scrutiny on the profitability of new loans, the daily reported.

Only two years ago, BHP paid a spread of between just 17.5 and 22.5 basis points over a five-year term for a loan of US$2 billion. But now the biggest firm in Australia is willing to pay 50 basis points over the bank-bill swap rate. But the local banks want 65 basis points, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA SET TO BEGIN ACTING ON CAMPAIGN PROMISES

TEXT.P: Making Taipei a place where women and children will no longer be afraid is the first task to which Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou will commit himself after his swearing-in ceremony Dec. 25.

Other campaign promises on which Ma is expected to deliver include the reimbursement of up to NT$400 million (US$12.35 million) in fees collected from motorists whose cars were towed over the past year. People whose cars were towed were fined up to NT$2,000. Ma has vowed to provide reimbursements of up to NT$1,500 per ticket for what he has called excessive handling fees.

Ma has also vowed that up to 300 licensed prostitutes whose licenses were to be revoked will be granted a two-year grace period in which to look for new work. At the end of the two years, however, the government will nullify all licenses in the trade.

He has promised that city residents who use the mass rapid transport (MRT) system will be given free bus rides and that bus fares will not be raised for at least eight years. Ma said he intends to raise the number of city residents who use public buses or the MRT from the current 23 percent to 50 percent.

In urban development, Ma has said he will focus development efforts on the city's dilapidated western district -- home to many of the city's older communities -- rather than the eastern part of the city.

In addition, Ma promised that by the end of 2000, the Taipei city government will be fully computerized, enabling city residents to obtain official copies of census reports, birth and death certificates and other documents via personal computers at home.
Ma's city government will also establish an economic development council and will develop two to three intelligent industrial complexes across the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MUNICIPAL TEAM TO BE UNVEILED ON DEC. 25

TEXT.P: The new lineup for the Taipei City Government will be unveiled on Dec. 25 when Taipei Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou officially takes office.

Ma, who defeated incumbent Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party in Saturday's election with a 51 percent majority, said he has not ruled out the possibility of selecting a woman as deputy mayor. He also made it clear that he is willing to retain municipal bureau chiefs who have a high moral standard and performed well over the past four years.

Speaking in interviews with UFO Broadcasting Co. and Voice of Taipei Broadcasting Co., Ltd., Ma said he is fully aware of that Taipei citizens voted for him because they have high expectations in his leadership.

Ma said he will do his best to live up to the expectations of voters, adding that he understands that this is a very important aspect of his responsibilities. He said he is determined to act as the public's spokesman.

Acknowledging that many of Taipei's problems cannot be solved overnight and many challenges lie ahead, the mayor-elect vowed to serve as a bridge of communication and urged Taipei residents to continue supporting him and giving him advice.
With the backing of some 760,000 voters, Ma called on the public to have confidence in him and help him build a better Taipei.
He also revealed that he had met with President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday evening for over an hour after being assured that he had won the hotly-contended race.

According to Ma, President Lee not only congratulated him on his victory, but also encouraged him not to dismiss the contributions made by his predecessor and urged him to do his utmost for the well being of Taipei residents.

Ma said he promised President Lee that he will continue to promote all types of projects initiated by former Mayor Huang Ta-chou and outgoing Mayor Chen as long as they are feasible and beneficial to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AN EXCEPTION TO ASIA'S BLEAK ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Australia's trade minister expressed pessimism over the short-term economic prospects in Asia but said Taiwan is an exception, in an interview with the Australian.
Tim Fischer, who also serves as deputy prime minister, has a bleaker assessment than his department's East Asia analytical unit which predicted the region's revival within the next two to five years.
While some analysts predict light at the end of the tunnel for South Korea's economy -- Australia's number two market -- Fischer said, "It is still a very long tunnel."
An official at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said Taiwan was an exception and defied the Asian crisis prospect in its trade relations with Australia.
Trade ties between Taiwan and Australia remained considerably steady, he told the CNA on Sunday night. "Taiwan remains the fifth largest export market for Australia," he said.
Fischer said serious conditions remain in the Asian economies which could have potential impact on Australian exporters. Australia's exports to Asia account for about 60 percent of its overall sales.

"At the end of the day, we are of course tied to a circumstance where five of our key markets are in recession," Fischer said. He cited figures of minus 8 percent growth for Hong Kong, minus 6 percent for South Korea and minus 2.6 percent for Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICTORY EXPECTED TO PLEASE CHINA: AUSTRALIAN MEDIA

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's victory in elections over the weekend offered a measure of satisfaction to Beijing and marked a setback for the pro-independence movement, Australian media reported on Monday.

While opposition Democratic Progressive Party incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian lost to Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou and the KMT won 123 seats in the 225-seat legislature, incumbent KMT Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih lost to DPP Frank Hsieh after serving nearly two terms.

In an article headlined "Taiwan poll result a winner with Beijing," The Australian said the KMT's victory is expected to please the mainland leadership who feared a Chen victory would have boosted the pro-independence advocate's presidential aspirations in 2000.

Last week, Beijing issued a veiled warning to the DPP that official separation from mainland China was impossible. On Sunday, Beijing remained silent after the KMT won the elections in Taipei and the majority of legislative seats.

In an article titled "Taiwan keeps its distance from Beijing in polls," the Australian Financial Review reported the KMT's victory in two of the three elections at the weekend provided a measure of satisfaction for Beijing, which regards the KMT as the party it can best deal with efforts to reunify Taiwan.
However, the daily reported that the voting for the mayors of the major two cities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- and for the Legislative Yuan, saw Taiwan slip even further from the mainland's grasp.

The Review said the smooth conduct of the weekend elections, 70 percent voter turnout and Taipei Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou's comment last week that there was no need for an already independent country to declare independence, indicated that unification is not necessarily a foregone conclusion. (By Peter Chen) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP016 12-07-98 TAIWAN DOLLAR AND MARKET RISE ON KMT'S VICTORY IN ELECTIONS
Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.01 to close at a nine-month high of 32.35 against the US dollar on Monday.

The NT dollar opened low and dropped to US$32.40 before rebounding, cheered by the ruling Kuomintang's victory in legislative and local elections over the weekend. The currency closed at US$32.35 and traded between US$32.32 and US$32.40 with a turnover of US$37.5 million. It ended at US$32.36 in the previous trading session.
The election outcome also helped prop up local stock market with share prices closing 1.4 percent higher and the Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index rose 101.50 points to end at 7,303.34.
A total of 3.2 billion shares were traded with a value of NT$127.27 billion (US$3.93 billion) compared to the previous session's NT$94.42 billion.
Advancers outnumbered decliners 350 to 97, with 49 stocks unchanged.
Of the eight major stock categories, only textile issues registered a decline with a drop of 0.5 percent.

Pulp and paper shares climbed 3.3 percent; cement issues rose 2.4 percent; plastic and chemical issues as well as construction shares gained 2.2 percent; foodstuff issues jumped 2 percent; and financial shares were up by 1.1 percent.
Trade in the Over the Counter (OTC) market opened high and ended 4.58 points higher to close at 180.75 points with a turnover of NT$4.6 billion. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY TO FORGE SISTER-CITY TIES WITH GAMBIA'S KANIFING

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan will forge sister-city relations with Kanifing in the Republic of the Gambia.
A four-member delegation composed of Kaohsiung County officials and councilors is scheduled to leave for the Gambia on Saturday for the signing ceremony establishing Kaohsiung-Kanifing ties.
The delegation will arrive in Kanifing on Dec. 14.

Kanifing, located 11 kilometers south of Banjul, the Gambian capital, occupies 73 square kilometers and is populated by about 288,000 people. It is one of the most developed industrial districts in the West African country.
Key industries in Kanifing include printing, cosmetics, logging, as well as steel and metal refinery.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN TO REMAIN DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung is not expected to resign despite the party's defeat in Saturday's election as several DPP heavyweights said Lin's resignation may spark a power struggle.
You Hsi-kun, president of the Taipei Mass Transit Corporation, is said to have visited Lin on Monday morning on behalf of outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, asking Lin not to quit.
Former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh said Lin should remain chairman to maintain the power base within the party. "Resigning now is not necessarily a gesture of responsibility," he noted.

Meanwhile, Lin said he has convinced DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen, to stay at his post. Other issues related to the election losses will be discussed at the regular meetings of the party's policy-making body, Lin added.
Both Lin and Chiu offered to resign to assume responsibility for the poorer than expected showing of the major opposition party in Saturday's "three-in-one" elections.

Incumbent DPP Mayor Chen was defeated by Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang, while the number of DPP seats in the Legislative Yuan dropped to 70, or 29.6 percent of the 225-seat legislature. The KMT grabbed 123 seats, or 46.4 percent of the total.
Sisy Chen, former head of the DPP's Propaganda Department, said the DPP's "party contra party" campaign strategy dealt a fatal blow to the DPP in Taipei's mayoral election.
Four years ago, the DPP and the New Party together fought against the KMT, but this time the KMT and the New Party joined forces in battling the DPP, she pointed out.
The DPP's major problem is the large number of figurehead party members and the lack of enthusiasm among party members for party activities, according to Chen.

However, some DPP deputies at the National Assembly argued that the ethnic issue played a critical role in Chen's defeat in the Taipei mayoral race and they said Lin should step down as chairman over the DPP's election losses.

They said the "New Taiwanese" concept raised by President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui successfully attracted support from native Taiwanese for Ma, while Chen's emphasis on ethnic differences and independence sentiment in his campaign scared away many potential supporters.

Under such a backdrop, the DPP should adjust its policy to win mainlanders' identification, DPP National Assembly Deputy Chiu Yi-shan said, otherwise the DPP is doomed to lose again in the future presidential elections.
