DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WORKERS' YEAR-END BONUSES REMAIN AT CURRENT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Year-end bonuses for military personnel, civil servants and teachers in 1998 will remain at the current month and a half level, the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) said on Monday.
Officials of the CPA, the Ministry of Finance, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, met to discuss a proposal over government workers' year-end bonuses.

In view of the fact that the nation's year-end bonuses for military personnel, civil servants and teachers has always been fixed at one and a half months and has always been offered equally in the past, the head of the CPA suggested that year-end bonuses be offered on a flexible basis.

Wei Chi-lin, director general of the CPA, suggested that all government organizations' budgets for year-end bonuses remain at the one and a half month level while the Cabinet should authorize heads of all government organizations to offer year-end bonuses according to their staff's performance.
According to the planned new regulations, from the end of 1999, the highest year-end bonus level a government staff member can get will be three months, the lowest will be one month.
The 1998 year-end bonuses and the proposal will be submitted to the Executive Yuan in the next few days for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, EU JOIN FORCES AGAINST US FOR 2000 WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Japan and the European Union (EU) have agreed to work together against the United States and some developing countries on a wide range of World Trade Organization (WTO) issues to be discussed in 2000.
The two sides reached the agreement in Tokyo and the EU agreed to meet once every two or three months during which they may decide to draft a joint position paper, a WTO report said on Monday.
Both sides reaffirmed that they will not accept a US-led demand to begin the WTO talks earlier than scheduled.
They also agreed to press for a "comprehensive, single undertaking" formula in the next WTO talks instead of a US-proposed "sector-by-sector" negotiations, the WTO report said.
Regarding the farm sector, Japan and the EU agreed that negotiations should address many aspects of the sector and not focus only on the issue of tariff cuts.

They also found common ground on various other areas, the WTO report said, including industrial goods tariffs, intellectual property rights, services, electronic commerce, public-sector procurement, competition policy, and an overhaul of the WTO dispute settlement mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAGES INCREASINGLY COMPETITIVE IN ASIAN ECONOMIES

TEXT.P: Real wages in some Asian countries are becoming even more competitive against the four "tiger" economies as rising inflation compounds the effect of currency depreciation, the results of a recent survey indicated.
The Corporate Resources Group (CRG) found that wages in the four tiger economies -- measured in US dollars per hour -- far outstripped those in other Asian countries.

Wages in Hong Kong were the highest in Asia for workers, professionals and managers, while South Korea came in second and Taiwan third. Singapore wages were the fourth highest in the survey, which did not take into account recent cost-cutting measures.
Mainland China lagged far behind in fifth place with its wages for office workers at roughly half those of Singapore's.
Elaine Ng, CRG's regional director for North Asia, attributed the high wages in Hong Kong to "past rising wages and the non-devaluation of the Hong Kong dollar."
"Hong Kong and China stand out as very expensive, compared to other Asian countries," she said.
Taiwan and Singapore wages were also higher as their currencies have depreciated by 15 percent against the US dollars. The South Korean won, however, fell 30 percent since the start of 1997.
The survey found that apart from currency depreciation, wages in other Asian economies were being eroded as rising inflation undermined the purchasing power of workers.
In Indonesia, for example, average salaries rose 17.4 percent last year, but these were eroded by hyper-inflation of 85 percent.
In Malaysia, Thailand and South Korea, inflation also outstripped pay increases. Therefore despite nominal wage rises, real wages fell between 1 percent and 7 percent, the survey showed.
CRG is a human resources consultancy specializing in compensation management. It polled 1,200 companies in this latest survey on compensation trends in Asia.
It found that real wage increases -- nominal wage rises less inflation -- are expected to fall in 1999 in all 11 economies surveyed.

Even in mainland China -- where real wages are rising the fastest -- higher inflation will mean a slower rise in real pay next year at 5.6 percent compared to 10.9 percent in 1998. Real wages are expected to grow 3 percent in Hong Kong and fall nearly 5 percent in Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH ROTARY INTERNATIONAL CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday received visiting Rotary International Chairman James Lacy and his wife.

Lee said he admired Lacy for his enthusiasm in taking an active role in international welfare activities, and added that the Rotary International's contributions have helped promote the well-being of people all over the world.

The president also made special note of the Rotary International's efforts in helping eliminate poliomyelitis, a disease which sometimes leads to paralysis in infants and young children. He also praised the organization for supporting anti-drug and anti-smoking campaigns and taking care of children and the elderly.

During the meeting at the Presidential Office, Lee stressed that Taiwan should learn from the Rotary International's charitable acts which are based on humanity and compassion. He noted that both Taiwan's public and private sectors must strengthen their welfare work for the underprivileged and disabled.
The ROC Rotary Club now has 381 branches and more than 15,000 members. It is currently helping promote the Rotary International's global project to rid the earth of polio by 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAO SHOU-PO NAMED TAIWAN GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday nominated Chao Shou-po, a minister without portfolio, Taiwan governor.

The nomination, made in accordance with the Provisional Statute Governing the Adjustment of Taiwan Provincial Government's Organization and Functions, has yet to be approved by President Lee Teng-hui.
Chao will succeed incumbent Governor James Soong, whose tenure expires on Dec. 20. Soong is the first and only elected Taiwan governor.

After taking office, Chao will head a provincial government which will no longer enjoy the right of autonomy according to revisions to the Republic of China's Constitution, under which the governor will be a political appointee rather than an elected official, as it is now.

Chao, born in 1941, graduated from the Central Police Academy and earned a doctoral degree in law from the University of Illinois in the United States. He has previously served as director of the Taiwan Provincial Government's Information Department and Social Affairs Department, director of the Kuomintang Social Affairs Department, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, and secretary-general of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES JOURNALISTS FROM CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told visiting journalists from Central and South America the Republic of China enjoys profound and cordial ties with their countries established through close exchanges.

Due to the severe havoc Hurricane Mitch caused in Central America recently, President Lee asked Vice President Lien Chan to visit four of the island's allies in the region on his behalf to convey his concern and discuss ways Taiwan can assist in the reconstruction process.
The journalists visited the Presidential Office accompanied by Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office.

They included Octavio Amat, Celso Chavez, Hector Arnoldo Salvatierra, Reinaldo Lewis Peart, Joel Gutierrez, Boris Eduardo Zealada Soto, Arlete Salvado, Altagracia Ortiz Gomez, Yuri Rolando Mora Carias, Jorge Ricardo Sanpedro, Werther Luciano Sandoval, and Pablo Soto.

Representing Panama, Paraguay, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Brazil, Dominica, Honduras, Argentina, Venezuela, and Chile respectively, the journalists were in Taiwan to cover the three-in-one elections.

President Lee told his guests that in the past 10 years, the Republic of China has accomplished its aspiration of democratic reform. He added that the elections of legislators, city mayors and city councilors, which were smoothly conducted two days ago, will further enhance the foundation of democracy.

The president expressed the hope that the ROC and their allies will work together and contribute to world peace, cooperation and prosperity. He also asked his guests to provide the ROC with valuable suggestions after their tour to gather first-hand information on the development of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR SHOWING IN ELECTION REINFORCES HSU'S CALL FOR PARTY TRANSITION

TEXT.P: The worse-than-expected performance of Taiwan's main opposition party in Saturday's elections have reinforced the calls of the Democratic Progressive Party's former chairman for transition within the party.

Hsu Hsin-liang, who stepped down in August from the post due to growing criticism, predicted prior to Saturday's elections that public support would drop to about 30 percent if the DPP were to continue its ideological struggle against the ruling Kuomintang.
The DPP's support declined from 43.32 percent in the 1997 elections for county heads to 29.56 percent in the weekend's elections for legislators.
Hsu said on Monday in an interview that his calls to move away from the party's internecine ideological battle with the KMT were mostly ignored by party candidates.
He said he regretted that the DPP has been downgraded from a legitimate power on the verge of taking over ruling-party status to a mere opposition after Saturday's polls.
The legislative elections were a litmus test of the party's path, the former DPP chairman said, and it indicates he is correct in his efforts to transform the party.

Hsu has made no secret of the fact that he would like to run on the party ticket for president in 2000 despite calls to groom the party's star Chen Shui-bian -- who lost in his reelection bid for Taipei mayor -- as the DPP's candidate for president. As it stands, Hsu said he would wait and see before he makes any formal decision.
In a separate interview on Monday, Hsu said Premier Vincent Siew and his Cabinet should resign en masse to set a constitutional precedent of accountability.

Prior to an amendment to the Constitution last year, the legislature was required to approve of the Cabinet's leader. However, owing to the comfortable majority the KMT now enjoys in the legislature, Siew announced on Sunday that he would not resign as a legislative confirmation is no longer necessary.

Although the KMT controls 123 seats in the 225-seat legislature and is therefore able to approve of any party-selected premier, the resignation of the Cabinet is necessary to establish a practice in which the legislature is duly respected by the executive branch, Hsu said.

This is especially true when the legislature was first elected under the revised Constitution, said Hsu who led the DPP in working out the principles of Constitutional reform at the National Development Conference in 1996.

Hsu said the aim to get rid of the legislature's confirmation right is to prevent lawmakers from blackmailing the administration by using the right as a bargaining chip rather than to give the head of state the privilege of ignoring the legislature's political makeup.

To support his argument, Hsu said the French Constitution, on which he said the ROC Constitutional amendments were modeled after, also requires a vote of confidence by the parliament on the Cabinet despite of the fact that French president has the sole power to name a premier without the parliament's approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC CUTS REDISCOUNT RATE AND SECURED LOANS RATE BY 0.25%

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) cut its rediscount rate and interest rate on secured loans by 0.25 percent each, effective beginning on Tuesday, CBC Deputy Governor Shea Jia-dong said on Monday.
During a news conference, Shea said the new rate will be 4.75 percent for rediscounting and 5.125 percent for secured loans, both of which are the lowest rates ever.
He said the move was in step with the European Union members who cut their key rates to 3 percent on Thursday which will hopefully lead to a decline of the prime rate at commercial banks.
Shea said the decision was made last week to give the economy a boost and the announcement was made after Saturday's elections in Taiwan to avoid any political overtones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1999 ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO RISE: CEPD

TEXT.P: A ranking economics official on Monday expressed optimism that Taiwan's economic growth, which has been projected at 5.1 percent for 1998, will increase next year.
Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), stated that Taiwan's economic growth in 1999 is expected to surge based on global economic growth.

The CEPD has predicted that Taiwan will sustain a 5.1 percent growth in 1998, down from 6.8 percent in the previous year due to lower exports and government investments, Schive reported in an Executive Yuan meeting.

He cited CEPD statistics as saying that Taiwan's foreign trade suffered declines from January to October. Based on such activity, the CEPD has formulated a series of plans aimed at expanding domestic demand to pump up the island's energy for economic activities.

With regard to Taiwan's future economic development, Schive said global exports are expected to gradually increase next year, with the exception of exports to Hong Kong and mainland China which will continue to be affected by the Asian financial meltdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CABINET RESHUFFLE EXPECTED: GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Cabinet is not expected to be reshuffled following the legislative elections over the weekend, said Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office.
Chen said Premier Vincent Siew is satisfied with the performances of his Cabinet members and called them a "very good team," therefore there is no plan for a Cabinet reshuffle in the near future.

The government spokesman said under the revised articles of the ROC Constitution, the Cabinet is named by the president and the Legislative Yuan no longer has the right to consent to the appointment of the premier.
Under this circumstance, he said, there is no need for the Cabinet to resign en masse after Saturday's election.
However, Chen said that it was up to the president to decide whether the Cabinet should resign en masse or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
US CONGRATULATES TAIWAN ON SUCCESSFUL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The US State Department on Monday issued a message of congratulations to the people of Taiwan for holding another successful election which it said reflects Taiwan's democratic development over the last 11 years.
In a prepared statement to reporters' questions, the State Department said, "The United States has strongly supported the process of democratization on Taiwan."

The State Department also reiterated the US position that Taiwan's future should be decided by the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. The United States has also insisted that any resolution be peaceful.
"We do not favor one political party over another or one candidate over another," it added.
Saturday's election results have been interpreted in the United States as a vote for the status quo and for the course taken by the ruling Kuomintang.

Tuesday's edition of the Washington Times said that the results must have been greeted in Washington "with a good deal of relief, given Taiwan's status is by far the touchiest issue affecting relations between the United States and mainland China."
The conservative paper said in an editorial that, for now at least, it seems clear the Taiwanese do not want anyone to rock the boat in their relations with the mainland.
