DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS GIVE CHINA MIXED SIGNALS

TEXT.P: Elections in Taiwan on Saturday have highlighted a widening gulf between the political cultures of mainland China and Taiwan, the Globe and Mail said on Monday.

In the past few weeks as Taiwan politicians prepared campaigns in the run-up to elections, Beijing authorities rounded up dissidents who were trying to form a political party in a crackdown that emphasized its one-party dictatorship, the paper reported.

While the ruling Kuomintang's victory in elections is good news for Beijing, as the party advocates in theory eventual unification of the two sides, the ideological differences will be difficult to bridge as Taiwan matures as a democracy, according to the Globe.

Analysts were cited as saying that Beijing's goal of peacefully absorbing Taiwan may be more likely today after Taiwan voters handed the KMT a larger majority in the legislature and elected one of its stars the mayor of Taipei.

Ma Ying-jeou's defeat of incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is seen as proof that the KMT has reinvigorated themselves with a new generation of leadership, the paper said.
While Beijing may be pleased with the overall election results, it may run into trouble in its current dialogue on reunification with the KMT government, analysts said.

In his victory speech, Ma signalled a go-slow approach on the unification issue. If that theme is picked up by other KMT leaders, China may face years of frustrating talks with Taiwan, the Globe said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITC VOTES TO CONTINUE TAIWAN DRAM DUMPING CASE

TEXT.P: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) on Monday ruled to continue an investigation into dumping charges of Taiwan-made dynamic random access memory semiconductors (DRAMs).
The ITC voted 5-0 in favor of going past the preliminary phase of a dumping investigation. The case involves DRAMs of one megabit and above from Taiwan.

In a news release, the commission said it found reasonable indication that the US semiconductor industry was materially injured by Taiwan DRAMs which were allegedly sold in the United States at below reasonable market prices.
The US Department of Commerce will continue its investigations with a preliminary determination due on or near March 31, 1999.
The ITC instituted the investigation on Oct. 22, 1998 in response to a petition by Micron Technology, Inc., Boise, Idaho, the top DRAMs producer in the United States.

According to the ITC, US imports of DRAMs of one megabit and above from Taiwan in the January-September period of 1998 amounted to US$290 million. Taiwan is the third largest supplier of DRAMs in the United States, behind only South Korea and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN WILL NOT VIE FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian reiterated on Tuesday that he will not vie for the chairmanship of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen, who returned to Tainan to attend his father-in-law's funeral, praised current DPP Chairman Lin Li-hsiung as the sole qualified figure to lead the DPP into the next millennium.

Chen, who was defeated by Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang in Saturday's Taipei mayoral election, said Lin should not step down to resume responsibility for the defeat as the DPP still needs a capable leader after Saturday's elections.
Lin is a man of high moral standard and talent, Chen said, and is the right person for the post. He added that he fully supports Lin retaining the chairmanship.
Chen also said he hoped DPP supporters would not lose confidence or be disappointed with the DPP over the party's poor showing in the weekend elections.
The outgoing mayor urged the public to continue to support Lin. Meanwhile, he said he would now take some time for some self-reflection, rest, and to think about his future options.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$10 M. TO NICARAGUA FOR POST-MITCH RECONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By C. P. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Monday pledged to donate US$10 million to Nicaragua to help with the reconstruction of infrastructure damaged by Hurricane Mitch recently.

ROC Vice President Lien Chan, who flew into the Nicaraguan capital city on Monday, presented a US$2.5 million check to President Arnoldo Aleman to accelerate the post-disaster reconstruction. The US$2.5 million is the first installment of a US$10 million donation the ROC government promised to Nicaragua over a one-year period.
Meanwhile, the ROC's International Cooperation and Development Fund had earlier promised to grant a low-interest, 20-year loan of US$6 million to Nicaragua to expedite the reconstruction.
The ROC donation and loan are so far the largest cash aid Nicaragua has received from around the world since Hurricane Mitch left 4,000 people dead and 100,000 homeless.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Nicaraguan counterpart Eduardo Montealegre both signed a memorandum on ROC aid in a ceremony held at the Nicaraguan Presidential Office. President Aleman and Vice President Lien witnessed the ceremony.

During the ceremony, Aleman expressed Nicaragua's gratitude to the ROC government and people, saying that Taiwan's assistance has helped Nicaraguans feel that they were not alone. He said the cash aid will be efficiently used to restore drinking water sources and electricity systems, and rebuild roads, houses as well as other infrastructure development.
Upon his arrival in Managua, Lien presented 24 metric tons of medicine to the Nicaraguan government as a token of goodwill from the ROC government and people.
Lien was met at the airport by Nicaraguan Vice President Enrique Bolanos Geyer and other ranking officials.

Lien told his Nicaraguan friends that in addition to US$6 million that Taiwan has pledged to dispatch to Nicaragua in loans, Taiwan will donate an additional US$10 million to Nicaragua to help the Central American country.

Besides that, Lien noted, the ROC Foreign Ministry has also launched a separate campaign dubbed "Sending Love to Central America" to raise funds for hurricane victims, and has opened special accounts with the International Commercial Bank of China and the post office, to which members of the public can remit donations.
Meanwhile, Chen Chang-wen, vice president of the ROC Red Cross Society, also donated US$30,000 to Nicaragua on behalf of the philanthropic organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 8, or Oct. 20 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: The United States Labor Union is established.
1914: Britain's Royal Navy destroys a German naval squadron off the Falkland Islands.
1938: "The Count of Chaplin," the first German aircraft-carrier, is launched at the port of Kiel.
1941: The United States, Britain, and Australia declare war on Japan.
1944: US forces attack Iwo Jima, 750 miles south of Tokyo, to begin the longest, fiercest battle in the Pacific War.
1949: The United Nations National Assembly asks world powers to recognize political independence of China, as the ROC government moves to Taiwan.
1953: The United States proposes in the United Nations General Assembly international control of atomic energy.
1958: The first African People's Convention opens in Accra, the Republic of Ghana.
1962: Rebellion in Brunei collapses after British intervention.
1966: Greek ferry sinks near Melos Island, killing 234.
1974: Greece votes to become a republic, abolishing a 142-year-old monarchy.
1978: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Foreign Exchange Management Regulations under which the new Taiwan dollar is no longer pegged to the US dollar.
1978: Golda Meir, who resigned as Israel's first woman prime minister in April 1974, dies at the age of 80.
1980: John Lennon, one of the four Beatles, is shot and killed in New York.
1986: The ROC and the United States reach agreement on tobacco and wine. The ROC's Ministry of Finance announces that from January 1987, US cigarettes and alcohol are free to enter the Taiwan market.
1990: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan resigns, but is reappointed within 24 hours.
1991: Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine form the "Commonwealth of Independent States" with its capital in Minsk.
1993: Kao Chun, a young mainland Chinese, hijacks Northern Airlines flight to Taiwan.
1995: The World Health Organization announces that a new case of the Ebola virus, which killed 250 in Zaire earlier in 1995, has been confirmed in the Ivory Coast.
1995: Flight services between Taiwan and Macau begin.
Confucius: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING' STATE COUNCIL COMMENTS ON TAIWAN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's State Council on Tuesday said in a statement that Beijing "fully respected" Taiwan's political activities over the past years but has consistently opposed splitism within the island.

While Beijing closely watched Saturday's "three-in-one" elections in Taiwan, the Taipei mayoral race was of particular interest. Mainland authorities believe the race is related to Taiwan's presidential elections in 2000.
The State Council said it welcomes learned Taiwan individuals who have great perspective to promote peaceful unification of China.
It also said that Beijing is against anyone who advocates separatism in Taiwan in the name of democracy.

On reports that newly-elected Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has turned down an invitation to visit Beijing as a "renowned figure" from Taiwan, State Council officials said they learned about the reports but declined to comment on it. Ma was quoted by the reports as saying that he would like to visit Beijing only in his capacity as the mayor of Taipei.

Despite their close scrutiny, mainland Chinese authorities intentionally treated the Taiwan elections in a low profile manner, and there was no significant coverage of the elections in media in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: US APPROVES OF TAIWAN'S ACHIEVEMENTS IN DRUG CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: While the United States praised Taiwan for its anti-drug smuggling efforts, the island continues to be listed as a major narcotics producer or transshipment hub, Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao said on Tuesday.
In an open letter to US Congress, US President Bill Clinton praised Taiwan's efforts in stamping out drug trafficking, Chiang said.
Clinton took both Iran and Malaysia off the list of major drug producing or transshipment countries while Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam were kept on the list.

A prime reason why Taiwan remains on the list is the strategic location of the southern Kaohsiung Port, Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials said. The huge quantities of containers loaded and unloaded at the dock far exceeds the handling ability of the port to check every container, they noted.
The MOJ is determined to strengthen its efforts to eradicate drug trafficking by boosting information exchanges and cooperation with its foreign counterparts, Chiang noted.

Over the past six months, Taiwan's law enforcement authorities seized over 55 kilograms of heroin, 322 kilograms of amphetamines, and about two kilograms of marijuana, statistics compiled by the MOJ showed. During the same time, 45 persons suspected of involvement in 16 drug smuggling cases were arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREPARATIONS FOR 2000 GAMES TO INCLUDE AIRPORT EXPANSION

TEXT.P: The Sydney Airport will undergo a US$380 million expansion in preparation for the influx of visitors during the 2000 Olympic Games, officials from the New South Wales government said.

The first phase of the plan will be completed in the second quarter of 2000. The second phase will add 66 check-in desks, improved baggage handling facilities, 30,000 meters of floor space and 10 new aircraft gates at the international terminal.

The number of aerobridges -- the moving corridors through which passengers board aircraft -- will be increased by 12 and all aerobridges will be upgraded to improve disabled access, the officials said.

The upgrade will also include new parking areas for aircraft, a redeveloped forecourt at the international terminal with new taxi and bus facilities, new roadways, larger car parks and an overhead roadway at the domestic terminal.

After the expansion project is completed, officials expect 105,000 passengers will be able to go through the airport during peak arrival traffic and 130,000 on peak departures or about double the current normal traffic.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY PURCHASES FROM US MAY CHANGE TO FOCUS ON SOFTWARE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan military is considering substantially expanding a bilateral training program with the US Department of Defense, the Defense News reported in its latest issue.

The bilateral training project indicates that the Pentagon's efforts in recent years to persuade Taiwan to shift its arms purchase focus from hardware to software is now bearing fruit, the article said.

For years, Washington has tried to convince Taiwan to turn its military purchase focus on highly-controversial large-scale arms purchases to less prominent but more militarily significant 4CI -- command, control, communications, computers and information.

The article quoted reliable military sources from the United States and Taiwan as saying that the two sides intend to initiate a new cooperative project before mid-1999, probably involving US provision of training to Taiwan's Army personnel on intelligence collection and electronic warfare.

The sources quoted John Daniele, chief of security assistance at the US Simulation, Training and Instrumentation Command (STRICOM, Orlando, Florida), as saying that the US$400,000 training program is aimed at providing STRICOM strategy know-how to the Taiwan Army in a comprehensive perspective, enabling the ROC Army to acquire its own STRICOM-related caliber, rather than giving training to individuals on certain systems.
Daniele said the ROC Army may become the first non-US military unit to receive the STRICOM training.

Taiwan and the United States are currently engaged in an collaborative training program in the air forces. A Taiwan F-16 squad is receiving piloting and logistics training at an Arizona air base at the cost of US$280 million, according to the Defense News article.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TYCOON HOPES TO RETURN HOME BEFORE END OF 1998

TEXT.P: Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por-yen, who has been detained by Taiwan authorities for nearly a year, told a reporter recently that he is eagerly looking forward to returning to Hong Kong soon, hopefully before the end of 1998.

Lim, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Lai Sun Group and a major shareholder of Hong Kong's Asia Television (ATV), said his trial is scheduled to restart on Wednesday and he hopes it will be concluded by the end of December.

Lim was arrested last December on charges of bribery. According to chief prosecutor Hsueh Wei-ping, evidence showed that Lim offered some NT$300 million to Taipei County government officials so that his Dollar Textile Manufacturing Company which occupied several hectares in Sanshia, Taipei County could be rezoned to be included in an area earmarked for development of the proposed National Taipei University.

Hsueh said Chuang Yu-kun, director of the Taipei County Land Administration Bureau, who was detained prior to Lim's arrest was involved in another land rezoning scandal. Chuang reportedly received NT$100 million from Lim for help in rezoning Lim's factory from cheap industrial land into commercial and residential land.

Lim admitted last year that after he received exceptionally high compensation in the amount of NT$880 million for the acquisition of his textile plant, he issued four checks with a total value of HK$55.68 million to a broker named Lin Chin-jung as a commission.
Lim claimed that he did not know Lin actually worked for Chuang and that Lin remitted part of the money to the Taipei County official.

Lim's family members, who failed to seek bail for the Hong Kong business tycoon due to his high blood pressure and other ailments, wrote to Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa earlier this year asking for help.
Tung passed the letter to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait as the case involved civilian relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Tung said although he is concerned about Lim's case, he also respects Taiwan's judicial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 32.343.
The local currency opened at 32.353 and was traded between 32.331 and 32.37.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$287 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET FALLS 1.2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 1.2 percent on Tuesday as a result of profit-taking.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index fell 90.66 points to close at 7,212.68 after registering a 1.4 percent increase in the previous trading session in response to the Kuomintang's victory in parliamentary and local elections on Saturday.
The index opened higher buoyed by the central bank's announcement on Monday of a cut in the rediscount rate and gains by US stocks, but profit-taking set in to wipe out early gains.
The index fluctuated between 7,355.63 and 7,198.02 throughout the trading day.
Volume reached 2.56 billion shares worth NT$95.64 billion (US$2.96 billion), compared to the previous session's NT$127.28 billion. Decliners led risers 334 to 90, with 67 stocks unchanged.
All of the eight major stock categories closed lower, among which foodstuff issues and construction shares listed the largest drop, both of which declined 1.7 percent.

Cement issues declined 1.5 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues and electronic engineering stocks both of which fell 1.3 percent, financial stocks dipped 1.2 percent, textile shares dropped 1 percent while pulp and paper issues fell 0.7 percent.
The Over The Counter (OTC) market opened slightly higher, but fell 3.57 points to 177.18 points upon closure with a turnover of NT$3.42 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ADVISOR URGES AUSTRALIA TO RECONSIDER NUCLEAR WASTE SITE

TEXT.P: A high-ranking adviser to US President Bill Clinton has urged Australia to reconsider an international plan to establish a disposal site for the world's nuclear waste, the Australian reported on Monday.

Robert Gallucci said Australia was in a "unique position" to help solve one of the world's biggest problems -- providing safe storage for nuclear waste and plutonium from bombs dismantled at the end of the Cold War.
"If Australia could appreciate the concept, and decide it was in the national interest, there would be enormous benefits for the world," he said.
Gallucci is Clinton's special envoy on weapons of mass destruction and is intimately involved in international efforts to find a secure home for nuclear waste.

His comments added weight to a plan for the disposal site that has been quietly promoted for two years in Australia by Seattle-based Pangea to use Australia as a dumping ground for nuclear waste. Pangea was forced to go public with its plan last week after interest groups were leaked a promotion video extolling Australia's qualities as a possible site.

The Australian government has turned down proposals and requests for the disposal site of the nuclear waster in Australia because any formal consideration of the plan would attract intense opposition from environmental groups and the Australian Labor Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTERS LEANING TOWARD STATUS QUO: LE MONDE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Saturday's elections in Taiwan have affirmed the establishment of democracy on the island and the election results have helped maintain the status quo as well as stability, the French newspaper Le Monde reported on Monday.

Frederic Bobin, the paper's Beijing correspondent, was in Taiwan to report on the elections. He wrote that ruling Kuomintang Ma Ying-jeou's victory in the Taipei mayor race, and opposition candidate Frank Hsieh's victory in the Kaohsiung mayor election implies that voters have confidence in the KMT but expect the DPP to act as a check and balance for the KMT.

Regarding the KMT's comfortable majority in the newly-elected legislature, Bobin said voters showed their appreciation to the ruling party for their economic management amid the region's financial turmoil. Voters also indicated a preference for the KMT's moderate policies in handing relations with mainland China to the pro-independence agenda of the DPP.

The KMT's overwhelming victory also hints at the rejection of hardline pro-reunification and pro-independence sentiments by Taiwan voters. Beijing and Taipei authorities can therefore follow fixed communication channels to discuss the future of both sides, the paper said.
Voters also highly identified with "the new Taiwanese" concept, a phrase President Lee Teng-hui coined during the election campaign.

President Lee should take the credit for having transcended provincialism by raising the issue of a new Taiwanese identity. Any attempt by Beijing to ease tensions under the "new Taiwanese" concept has been made more difficult.

Beijing's goal of reunification, either by negotiations or the use of force, will also be made more difficult as Taiwan's democratic development advances, the paper reported. A notable result of the elections was the dismal performance of the New Party which strongly supports unification with the mainland.

Bobin indicates that Beijing's only move now is to exert even more pressure to isolate Taiwan in the international arena. In doing so, Beijing may find Taiwan struggling even harder against this pressure which will inevitably lead to a stalemate in cross-strait relations.
Bobin predicts that the critical debate for independence and unification will emerge in the next presidential election in the year 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK QUESTIONS 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' FOLLOWING EXECUTIONS

TEXT.P: The execution on Saturday of notorious Hong Kong mobster Cheung Tze-keung and his accomplices in the mainland have raised doubt in the "one country, two systems" policy, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

Human rights groups, pro-democracy advocates, and legal experts said they were alarmed that the trial which led to the execution of Cheung, also known as the Big Spender, set a dangerous precedent as the offenses were mostly committed in Hong Kong.

Amnesty International's Hong Kong branch chairman Alan Abrahams told reporters that the Hong Kong government should have asked Beijing to extradite Cheung so he could be tried in the jurisdiction where the major offenses allegedly occurred.

"What alarms us is the government seems incapable of recognizing the problem," he said. "The crimes for which he's been executed were committed in Hong Kong. These are very real concerns for people who travel and do business in the mainland. Every time there is a cross-border crime it could happen again," he added.

In a cross-border crime spree, Cheung's gang reportedly extracted more than US$200 million in ransom for the return of kidnapped tycoons Victor Li Tzar-kuoi, the son of magnate Li Ka-shing and property baron Walter Kwok Ping-sheung, the daily reported.
Cheung and his gang were also accused of smuggling ammunition and 800 kilos of explosives into Hong Kong along with other offenses that included robbery.

After the execution, the Hong Kong government released a statement that said, "As these people were tried and convicted in the mainland for offenses committed there under the mainland's criminal laws, the mainland's laws regarding penalties for criminal offenses apply."
But there were suspicions among Hong Kong lawyers that the outcome suited the post-colonial government, the kidnap victims and mainland authorities, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA EXCLUDES ETHNICITY AND PARTY AFFILIATION IN STAFF RECRUITMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou said on Tuesday he will not discriminate against ethnicity, birthplace nor party affiliation in the formation of his staff.

Ma said he has already called on several current city government officials, including Bureau of Transportation Director Ho Cheng-tan and Bureau of Finance Director Lin Chuan, to remain in their post. Both Ho and Lin tend to decline Ma's offer.
The incoming mayor said in an interview with the Broadcasting Corporation of China that his recruitment process depends solely on capability, personal character and expertise.

When asked about possible conflict between central and local governments, Ma said Taipei City is under the jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan so it should do its best to cooperate with the central government. Any dispute between them should be solved by conciliation and Taipei residents' interests must be the top priority, Ma said.

In response to questions over whether Ma would be able to realize some of his campaign promises due to a shortage of city funds, he said the ruling party's management fund can be appropriated to solve budgetary problems.

During the campaign, Ma came under fire for having few supporters within the city's cultural circle. Ma said he would make an effort to make more friends among cultural figures and his cultural policies will be made by cultural experts.

He also pointed out that on-going cultural activities will be carried out as long as they help improve the quality of culture in Taipei. Cultural activities should not be short-lived, but they must take place for a long time to become a part of citizens' lives, Ma said.

Some people have attributed Ma's clean image to his indifference to public conflicts. In response, Ma said as the minister of justice, he helped put 5,000 criminals into jail in a bribery case during legislative elections three years ago. However, the public appears to have little recollection of this effort, he said.
The public should evaluate a mayor strictly according to his performance, Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNOR APPROVES TALLEST TOWER PROJECT FOR MELBOURNE

TEXT.P: Victoria State Premier Jeff Kennett has given the greenlight to a US$1 billion project to build the world's tallest tower in Melbourne.

At 560 meters or 120 stories tall, the tower will more than double the height of Australia's current tallest building -- Realto, which is also in Melbourne. Construction magnate Bruno Grollo, who built the Realto in the 1980s, is behind the plan.

The tower is due to be completed in five years and will surpass the Patronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur in height by more than 100 meters. However, it pales in comparison with the 677-meter-high World Center for Vedic Learning planned for India by Grollo's fellow transcendental meditation proponent, the Maharishi Yogi.

The approval was met with mixed reaction from architects and community members. Some labeled the tower as brave and progressive while others expressed concern that the project would not fit in with Melbourne's existing landscape and cafe culture.

With the site at the Docklands near Melbourne Port, the tower will contain 450 residential units, 320 six-star hotel room, 60,000 square meters of office space and 12,000 square meters of retail space.
So far hundreds of people, including Crown Casino boss Lloyd Williams, have submitted deposits of US$3,125 each to buy residential apartments.
Grollo must prove within four months that he has enough financial backing to pay for the tower construction before the Docklands Authority of Melbourne offers its final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S EXPORTS REACH OVER US$10 BILLION IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export volume for the month of November reached US$10.44 billion with a trade surplus of US$1.58 billion, the highest since June 1997, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) statistics indicated.

Based on statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, MOF Department of Statistics Director Hsu Kuo-chung predicted Taiwan's total export volume will decrease by 9.3 percent in 1998 while imports by 9.4 percent, the largest decreased rates in 18 and 16 years respectively.

The reason for decreased exports and imports in November compared to November 1997, is while Europe-bound exports have increased slightly by 3.3 percent, exports to the United States, Japan and ASEAN countries have all decreased. Moreover, a decreasing rate of imports from Europe reached 26.4 percent.
Hsu said that average daily value of goods passing through customs was US$475 million, the highest since December 1997.

Due to Asia's financial turmoil, global economies are in recession and world trade is slowing down, said Hsu. Compared to 1997 figures, the ROC's export volume from January to November in 1998 has decreased by 8.9 percent, with Asian-bound exports decreasing by 18.3 percent.
Hsu added that since the United States and Europe are less hurt by the financial crisis, the ROC's exports to the United States remain stable while exports to Europe have declined by 7.5 percent.

Meanwhile, the ROC's import volume has increased due to the government's policy to expand domestic demand. Imports of capital and facilities have increased by 14.5 percent while imports of raw materials for agriculture and industry as well as consumer products have declined as a result of a domestic recession.
The ROC's exports are expected to increase if Southeast Asian economies recover from the crisis in 1999, said Hsu.

Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association of Philadelphia predicted that the world economic growth rate will increase from 1.9 percent in 1998 to 2.5 percent in 1999, and global trade volume will also increase from 4.1 percent in 1998 to 5.0 percent in 1999. Taiwan's exports are expected follow the global trend and recover steadily, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTIONS PROVES CHINESE DEMOCRACY WORKABLE: WASHINGTON POST

TEXT.P: While mainland China's leadership threatens Taiwan with missiles, Taiwan threatens them by setting a democratic example, the Washington Post said in an editorial Tuesday after Taiwan's three-in-one elections.

The editorial noted that while mainland Chinese authorities were scheduling the trial of Wang Youcai, whose "crime" consists of peacefully attempting to register a democratic political party, Taiwan's authorities were analyzing weekend elections in which 80 percent of Taiwan's eligible voters participated.
The Post pointed out that Taiwan's elections last Saturday for parliamentary and municipal offices were its ninth successful round of elections since a multi-party system was legalized in 1986.
"This one, like the others, was free, fair and peaceful," according to the editorial.

In the past Beijing's dictators used cultural differences as an excuse for not permitting a multi-party political system, but the Post said that the remarkable voter turnout in Taiwan's elections suggests that there is nothing "Western," nothing particularly suited to one culture or another, in people's desire to have a say in their own governance.

The editorial indicated that Taiwan's election results were said to be reassuring to mainland China's leadership. The ruling Nationalist Party handily defeated the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which has been more outspoken in its calls for Taiwanese sovereignty. But the facts are not so simple, the Post noted.

It said that few Taiwanese today favor an outright declaration of independence, but few favor unification with the mainland either -- at least not as long as Beijing remains a dictatorship. In fact, the Nationalists gained popularity because of their firm stand against mainland Chinese bullying.

The editorial said US President Clinton, in his eagerness to woo Beijing's leaders, slapped down during a visit to mainland China earlier this year Taiwan's ambitions to play a larger role in the world. The message discouraged many Taiwanese, but it did not knock them from their democracy-building path, according to the paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CRISIS PUTTING PRESSURE ON ASIAN GOVERNMENTS: US ADMIRAL

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has contributed to increased instability in the region, the commander in chief of the US Pacific Command told the Australian Financial Review on Monday.
Admiral Joseph W. Prueher, who is currently in Sydney, said Indonesia was "very fragile economically, politically, militarily -- there are no constants, everything is in flux right now."

Although President B.J. Habibie and the Indonesian Parliament are working on plans for political reform, he said, they are hindered by demonstrators' challenges to their legitimacy as remnants of Suharto's rule.

"The strategic location of Indonesia is important. If there were to be more instability in Indonesia, it could manifest in the sea lanes that are so important to all of us in Southeast Asia. We need to not interfere but look for opportunities to be as helpful as we can," he was quoted as saying.

Responsible for US forces across 259 million square kilometers of the Pacific and Indian Oceans, Prueher, who is based in Hawaii, said he would meet Australia's Defense Minister John Moore during his visit to Australia to discuss ways to strengthen cooperation in collecting more information from troubled areas. He will also discuss ways to maintain "inter-operability" of the two countries' forces in the face of fast-changing technologies.
The US currently relies on Australia for some 80 percent of its intelligence on Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TAIWANESE ARRESTED IN PHILIPPINE WATERS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Sun Ting-wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Six Republic of China nationals were arrested by Philippine immigration authorities Tuesday in territorial waters north of the Southeast Asian country.

Philippine officials in charge of immigration affairs said that the six were arrested for sailing in waters off the coast of Calveria in Cagayana province, northern Luzon, without official entry permission.
The six were identified as Si Chin-lung, Chen Wen-liang, Si Chin-fang, Hwang Mao-jung, Si Chin-hsien and Hung Wang-ting.
Cagayana province is an area that officials said they believe is being used by foreign smugglers, especially ones from mainland China and Taiwan, who often pose as fishermen.
Philippine authorities are investigating whether the six arrested Taiwanese have been involved in any smuggling activities in that northern Philippine area, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN OF TAIWAN NAMED COMPANY OF THE YEAR 1998

TEXT.P: Britain's "Containerisation International" magazine has named Evergreen Marine Corp. of Taiwan as "Company of the Year 1998."

Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yong-fa appears on the front cover of the magazine's December issue, which includes a report tracing Evergreen's development from a small business 30 years ago to the multinational corporation it has become.

According to a press release from Evergreen's public relations division, four big enterprises vied for company of the year honors in 1998. Evergreen beat out Maersk of Denmark and two English companies: P&O Nedlloyd and Freightliner.

An Evergreen spokesman said the company's outstanding operational efficacy and innovation, as well as its efforts to continue upgrading its service quality were the major factors behind its being named company of the year.

Evergreen Marine Corp. formally acquired Lloyd Triestino di Navigazione S.P.A. of Italy on Oct. 5, when Chang signed an acquisition agreement in Trieste, the headquarters of Lloyd Triestino, in southern Italy.
The shipping tycoon said Evergreen would send its fully automated ships to Lloyd Triestino in the future to help upgrade its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S FOREIGN MINISTRY HOPES RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN WILL 'FLOURISH'

TEXT.P: Japan hopes to continue to have non-governmental-level, but still flourishing relations with the Republic of China, a spokesman for Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Sadaaki Numuta, MOFA's director-general for press and public relations, made the remark at a regular press conference for foreign journalists.

When asked about the recent elections in Taiwan, which the ruling Kuomintang won impressively, Numuta offered no direct answer, but instead stressed that Japan's position in regard to Taiwan was made clear during the recent visit of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

"Our basic position toward Taiwan is reflected originally in the Joint Communique of 1972 with PRC and that position has been basically reaffirmed on the occasion of Jiang's visit," said the MOFA spokesman.

"We expect to continue to have the sort of relations that we have enjoyed with Taiwan since that time, that is our relations at the non-governmental level -- non-governmental working relations, but still flourishing relations, and we hope to continue to have this relationship with Taiwan," noted the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM'S PRIORITY: PROMOTING A SPEEDY WTO ENTRY FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The newly elected president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) stressed on Tuesday that promoting Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) as early as possible has been a priority for AmCham.

AmCham President Paul Cassingham added that the chamber also supports Taiwan's joining the World Health Organization and other international organizations, and will encourage US Cabinet members to visit Taipei periodically.
Cassingham made the remarks at a news conference, during which he stated key issues related to AmCham's future activities.

The president, who visited Washington in September on AmCham's annual lobbying mission, said that both the Clinton administration and the US Congress desire to help speed up the process of Taiwan's WTO entry as Taipei has already completed agreements with Washington on its terms for WTO membership.

Cassingham pointed out, however, that Washington cannot control the pace of Taiwan's accession into the world trade regulatory body once its membership application enters the multilateral examination portion of the application process.
During that period, all WTO members, such as the European Union acting as a whole and Japan, can influence to as great a degree as the United States the pace of the application process.

Different political and diplomatic powers are expected to interfere with the current ongoing review of Taiwan's WTO application, he said. He added, however, that the United States' stance on the issue has been very clear -- it supports Taiwan's entry into the international organization at the earliest possible date.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCSAT-1 BEING DELIVERED TO US FOR JANUARY 1999 LAUNCH

TEXT.P: A China Airlines cargo plane is expected to deliver to Cape Canaveral in Florida early Wednesday morning ROCSAT-1, a satellite scheduled for launch late next January and aboard which a variety of scientific experiments will be carried out.
The 21-ton satellite and related surface support equipment, packed into a total of 46 crates, were transported to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on Monday.

Hsu Chia-ming, director of the preparatory office for the establishment of a space planning department under the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), said the satellite is scheduled to be launched into space by US-based Lockheed Martin Corp. on Jan. 27, 1999.
The ROCSAT-1 satellite will be stationed at a plant belonging to US-based Astrotech Corp. during pre-launch preparations.

It will cost US$18 million to launch ROCSAT-1. Add to that the US$61.5 million spent on building the satellite and on its three payloads and the total cost of the project is about US$82 million, Hsu said.
The NSC has taken out an insurance policy, with a premium of NT$116 million (US$3.59 million), on the satellite with a London-based insurance company.
The policy covers the entire launch process, as well as the positioning of the satellite into orbit and its ability to maintain a safe orbit for one year.
The major parts of ROCSAT-1 were built by US-based TRW Corp. It was delivered to the NSC's integration and testing plant in May last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESHUFFLE TO BE DECIDED BY PRESIDENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew reiterated on Tuesday that any decisions as to the possible reshuffling of his Cabinet would be made by the president and based on the revised Republic of China Constitution.
Siew made the comments while responding to a remark made during a meeting at the legislature that the Cabinet should resign en masse since a new legislature has been elected.
In the past, the premier was nominated by the president, but was subject to legislative approval.

Siew explained, however, that under a 1997 revision to the ROC Constitution the Cabinet is named directly by the president and that Cabinet appointees do not need to be confirmed by the Legislative Yuan.

Under these conditions there is no need for the Cabinet to resign en masse ahead of the convening of the new legislature on Feb. 1, 1999, the premier said. He added that he would respect the president's decision regarding any reshuffling of the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR MAKES SUGGESTION ON CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: US Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., suggested on Monday that the US Congress' mainland China policy should include three provisions: opposition to Beijing's use of force against Taiwan, a commitment to safeguard US economic interests and an emphasis on human rights issue.
Lugar made the remarks at a seminar held at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale, Illinois.

The seminar, titled "Building New Bridges for a New Millennium," opened on Dec. 6 and was attended by more than 100 people, including politicians, scholars and students from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Stephen S.F. Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, also spoke during the seminar on peace and prosperity in the Republic of China and introduced recent political, economic and social developments in Taiwan.
He said that if both sides of the strait can reach more accords and cooperate in the international scene, it would be more possible to achieve peaceful unification.
Richard Bush, chairman of the board and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, spoke at the seminar on the United States' role in the "Taiwan Strait Issue."
He told participants to the seminar that the United States' role regarding the Taiwan Strait issue can be defined by five key principles:
--The United States insists that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved peacefully;
--The administration believes that constructive and meaningful dialogue is the best way to resolve cross-strait differences;
--It believes that these differences should be resolved by the two sides themselves;
--The United States will remain even-handed in its approach to cross-strait dialogue and not apply pressure to either side;
--The administration believes that any arrangement concluded between Beijing and Taipei should be on a mutually acceptable basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS TWO GOLDS, POISED FOR TWO BRONZES IN DAY TWO OF GAMES

TEXT.P: Taiwan pocketed two gold medals and appeared sure to claim at least two bronzes in the second full day of the Asian Games on Tuesday, boosting its medal count to two gold, two silver and six bronze.

Taiwan swimmer Tsai Shu-ming was the island's only swimmer to find gold in the swimming pool, as she finished first Tuesday in the women's 200-meter freestyle competition. Meanwhile Tang Hui-wen also won a gold in the women's taekwondo fly-weight division.

Two other Taiwan athletes reached the taekwondo semi-finals and were guaranteed to bring home at least a bronze each. The two are Sung Cheng-hsian in the men's light-weight division and Hsu Chil-ling in the women's light-weight division.
Taiwan garnered one gold, two silvers and three bronzes on the first day of the games.
The gold was won by Chang Ko-ping and Li Chu-chung, who claimed top honor's in the standard dance competition. Dance is a demonstration event at the games.

Tsai Jui-feng and Chiu Shu-chen earned a silver in the Latin American-style dance competition, while Wang Hsing-yuan won a silver in the 56-kg division of the men's weightlifting competition by lifting a total of 267.5 kilograms.

The three bronzes were won by Chiang Tsu-ying, Lin Chi-chen and Kuan Chia-hsian in the women's 4 x 200-meter freestyle swimming competition; by Chi Shu-ju in the fin-weight division of the taekwondo competition; and by Chen Ju-miao in the women's downhill mountain bike cycling competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NEW TAIWANESE' NOT JUST A CAMPAIGN NOTION: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: The term of "New Taiwanese" was coined not only to bolster support for ruling party during the elections but also to boost the country's status, said President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday.

In an official session at which Lee heard advice on national policy from members of the National Assembly, he said that the term is neither new nor designed specially to drum up support for the ruling party's candidate for Taipei mayor, Ma Ying-jeou.

Rather, it is an idea he has repeated many times out of fear that the rift between different ethnic groups in Taiwan would be used by some candidates to muster votes at the peril of the country's solidarity, said Lee.

Lee is credited with having contributed significantly to Ma's win in Saturday's election by calling for the unity of all "new Taiwanese" while stumping for Ma. "New Taiwanese," he said, refers to all the people who live in Taiwan, no matter when they immigrated to the island.

Ma, whose parents fled to Taipei from mainland China in 1949, was considered by the majority of Taiwan people whose ancestors came to the island from mainland China hundreds years ago as an outsider. But Lee's support was considered an endorsement of Ma's legitimacy.
Lee said at the National Assembly that the idea of the "new Taiwanese" would help people to unite to face the threat from Beijing, and solidify the country's status in the international community.
Lee made the comments in reply to questions from National Assembly members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui says 'New Taiwanese' theory a cure for two-way extremists.
The China Times:
Cabinet reshuffle to be decided by President Lee Teng-hui, says Premier Vincent Siew.
The United Daily News:
'New Taiwanesism' workable both at home and abroad, says President Lee Teng-hui.
The Liberty Times:
US preliminarily rules that Taiwan dumps DRAMs in the United States.
The Independence Morning Post:
President Lee Teng-hui defines 'New Taiwanese' theory.
The Commons Daily:
Defeat of Chen Shui-bian's mayoral election in Taipei conducive to his 2000 presidential bid, says Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang.
The China Post:
Chinese Taipei bags three golds in Asian Games.
The China News:
Trade surplus hits record levels -- projected figures show greatest ever annual decline in Taiwan's exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT BRINGS CASH AID TO HONDURAS
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan flew into Honduras Tuesday, bringing nearly US$20 million cash aid to the Central American country to help with reconstruction efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Mitch.

Lien met with Honduran President Carlos Flores Facusse immediately upon his arrival in Tegucigalpa and signed a cooperative memorandum, under which the Republic of China pledges to donate US$12 million to Honduras and grant it US$6 million in low-interest long-term loans.

Honduras was the hardest-hit of all Central America nations after Mitch ravaged the region between Oct. 25 and Nov. 2. The hurricane left 5,600 people dead, more than 8,000 missing and 1.4 million homeless, according to official reports.
Honduras was the second leg of Lien's four-nation whirlwind trip to Central America, aimed at bringing ROC relief and conveying its concern to its allies in the region.
At the memorandum signing ceremony, Lien presented a US$3 million check to President Flores as the first installment of the US$12 million donation.

Before flying to Tegucigalpa, Lien and accompanying ROC officials and religious and charity representatives visited Nicaragua. There Lien on behalf of the ROC government and the people of Taiwan pledged a US$16 million cash aid, 24 metric tons of medicine and other relief package to Nicaragua.
Accompanied by Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Eduardo Montealegre, Lien visited rural regions of the country where he saw for himself the utter devastation Mitch wreaked in the country.
Wearing a cap with the ROC national flag and the Red Cross Society's emblem, Lien was interviewed by the Cable News Network (CNN).
Lien told CNN that the Republic of China is more than willing to extend a helping hand to needy countries and peoples.

In addition to Nicaragua and Honduras, Lien and the ROC mission will also visit El Salvador and Guatemala on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui to express the ROC government and people's concern for the four Central American countries, all of which were hit hard by Mitch.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 9, or Oct. 21 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "The Lost Paradise," is born in London.
1625: England and the United Provinces agree to subsidize Denmark's King Christian IV in his campaign against Germany.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the child-labor act, prohibiting the employment of children under 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Peiping (Beijing) to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The 8th British Army begins an offensive in North Africa in World War II.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany, and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1972: Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord for military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1976: The UN General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with US President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the US-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1988: West Germans want curbs on NATO military flights over their country.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1992: US forces land in Somalia, and 35 nations take part in the "hope restoring" military action.
1994: The Irish Republican Army talk peace with British officials after 25 years of violence.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
Confucius: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND HIJACKER MAY NOT BE REPATRIATED SOON

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese hijacker Yuan Bin, the pilot who hijacked a Beijing-based Air China airplane to Taiwan on Oct. 28, may not be repatriated in the near future, sources from the Prosecutor's Office of Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, said Wednesday.

The Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office on Tuesday completed an investigation into Yuan's hijacking. It recommended a "proper" penalty for Yuan, who "ignored passengers' and the flight's safety by conducting the hijacking."
The prosecutors, however, did not think that Yuan should be repatriated soon on the grounds that the "motives behind his action were simple and non-violent."
Yuan's wife, Xu Mei, who sat behind the co-pilot in the cockpit during the hijacking, was considered an accomplice to Yuan, and the prosecutors recommended a lighter penalty for her.
Chief Taoyuan Prosecutor Shih Mao-lin ruled out a speedy repatriation of Yuan and his wife -- as had been rumored -- so that a framework on the handling of cross-strait hijackings could be laid.
Shih said that during the Yuan investigation process the Taoyuan office had not received any instructions from government officials or from the judiciary as to how Yuan should be charged.
Yuan, 30, diverted Air China flight CA905 from Beijing to the southwestern city of Kunming in the morning of Oct. 28. The flight was originally destined for the Burmese capital of Rangoon.

A total of 95 passengers, including 20 foreign nationals and nine crew members, were aboard the Boeing 737. The plane left Taoyuan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for mainland China about seven hours after it landed in Taiwan. Yuan and his wife were taken away for questioning.
Yuan told investigators that he felt sad but not remorseful for what he did, adding that he would do it again given his personal feud with his airline's authorities.
He complained that he had been treated unfairly by the airline and that about half a month ago he and his wife concocted a plan to hijack the plane and fly it to Taiwan.
Yuan's co-pilot, Wen Fei, tried unsuccessfully to dissuade him from hijacking the plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLAZE CLAIMS LIVES OF TWO SCHOOLBOYS

TEXT.P: An early morning blaze on Wednesday in central Taiwan's Nantou County claimed the lives of two boys on a school graduation trip, while one other was left seriously injured.
The fire started at around 5 a.m. in a wooden cabin located within the "Little Shitou" resort village. It was believed to have been caused by a short circuit, according to teachers at the scene.

The dead were identified as Liu Hung-ming, 11, and Lee Ching-cho, 12, both of whom were students at Chiang Tsui Primary School in Taipei County. One of their classmates who shared a room with them at the resort village, 12-year-old Chen Yi-chin, was sent to Changhua Christian Hospital after sustaining severe burns.
Chen suffered second- and third-degree burns to 90 percent of his body, doctors said. He remained in critical condition as of Wednesday afternoon.
A total of 401 students, all of whom were soon to graduate, took part in the two-day travel, which was led by 24 teachers. They were scheduled to return to school Wednesday afternoon.
The incident cut short the trip, as students returned home early and as police launched an investigation into the exact cause of the fire.
Besides being the result of a short circuit, the fire could have been started by students playing with fire, police said.
Chiang Tsui school executives said every student on the trip is covered by a NT$2 million (US$61,700) insurance policy against accidental death and by NT$500,000 worth of student insurance.

As soon as he was informed of the incident, Taipei County Magistrate Su Cheng-chang instructed officials to visit the accident scene to help deal with the aftermath. He also extended his condolences to the parents of the victims and pledged to push for a complete review of the safety of tourist spots islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN REPRESENTATIVES HOLD YEAR-END PARTY WITH TAIPEI REPRESENTATIVES
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Some 40 members of the Canadian Parliament and Taipei's highest-ranking officials in Canada held a year-end party at Capitol Hill on Tuesday in celebration of the past year's steady relations between the Republic of China and Canada.

Paul Szabo, chairman of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, said he appreciated the support the group has received from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada. The office has helped Canada's members of parliament to understand bilateral commercial and tourist relations between the two countries.

Szabo wrote an article appearing in Canada's Hill Times newspaper, saying that while there are no formal relations between Taiwan and Canada, the group he chairs serves a quasi-diplomatic function in relations between the countries.

Taipei's representative to Canada, Fang Chin-yen, pointed out that after the severing of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Canada in 1970, neither side set up a representative office in the other's territory until 1990, when doing so came to be regarded as mutually beneficial.
Fang added that Taiwan has become Canada's fourth-largest trading partner in Asia and its ninth-largest worldwide, with a bilateral trade volume of more than C$5 billion (US$3.25 billion) in 1997.

Meanwhile, Canada is one of the main destination of Taiwan's emigrants, and an increasing number of Taiwanese are going to Canada to study or travel, noted Fang. He added that, as Szabo had previously pointed out, intensive people-to-people relations will help make up for the lack of formal relations between the Republic of China and Canada.

Also present at the party were Canadian Free Party member and House representative Derek Lee; Inky Mark, a representative belonging to the Reform Party; Madeleine Dalphond-Guiral, a representative from Quebec; and Conservative Party Senator De Nino Consiglio, who just returned from a visit to Taiwan to observe the country's recent three-in-one elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS RALLY TO MARK 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF UN RIGHTS DECLARATION

TEXT.P: In commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, International Action for Human Rights (IAHR) will hold a rally and vigil Thursday afternoon at 47th Street and First Avenue -- Dag Hammarskjold Park across from the United Nations.

They rally will commence with speeches by prominent politicians and human rights activists and conclude with a candlelight vigil in honor of all those still suffering under inhuman conditions around the world, IAHR said Tuesday in a press release.
Musician and activist Patti Smith will open the candlelight vigil with a poem at 5 p.m.

The goal of the rally is to encourage all nations to uphold and implement the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Representing more than 20 nations and millions of people, the rally will feature such prominent dissident figures as Harry Wu from mainland China, Hafsat Abiola from Nigeria, Durdak Nyima from Tibet and Oyunbinig from Inner Mongolia.

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted in 1948 by the United Nations General Assembly. All member nations pledge to achieve, in cooperation with the United Nations, the promotion of universal respect for and observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

IAHR is a coalition of organizations representing a variety of concerns and issues, including Tibet, East Timor, Nigerian democracy, Kurdish rights, Northern Ireland, Burma, Indonesia, the rights of Christians, Taiwan, mainland Chinese democracy, Burmese democracy, East Turkistan, Inner Mongolia and Haiti.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FACES HUGE TARIFFS ON ITS RICE EXPORTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Australia is bracing for up to a tariff of up to 1,300 percent on its rice exports if the Japanese government bows to strong domestic lobbying efforts to impose restrictions on foreign imports.

In a dispatch from Tokyo, The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported Japan is considering imposing a tariff of up to 1,300 percent on imported rice in a bid to limit its obligations under the minimum rice access provisions agreed under the Uruguay Round agriculture agreement.

The ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which derives its core support from rural Japan, is under immense pressure from the country's powerful farming union -- Zenchu -- to move quickly to impose the tariffs in order to protect the rice industry in that country.
Since Japan opened its rice market to foreign imports a few years ago, Australia, the United States and Thailand have been major exporters of rice to Japan.
Australian rice growers were hoping to increase their sales of rice to Japan by 50 percent from 90,000 tons in 1997 to 136,000 tons by 2000 under the minimum access provisions of the Uruguay Round.
"Rice and the rice lobby is fairly powerful and you can't just brush this tariff proposal aside," Richard Day, chief executive of the Australian Rice Growers Cooperative, told the daily.

Under the Uruguay Round agreement, Japan was obliged to import an amount of foreign rice equal to at least 4 percent of its annual rice consumption in 1995 and increase that amount by 0.8 percent a year to as high as 8 percent by 2001.

The daily reported the adoption of an early tariff plan would cut the final figure of minimum access for foreign rice to about 682,000 tons, which is only 76,000 tons less than the total imports under full minimum access.

That indicates how desperate Japan's farming union has become. The magnitude of increase in imported rice tariff could help protect domestic rice growers who are competing against foreign importers, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA REITERATES AUTONOMY, NOT INDEPENDENCE, SOUGHT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama indicated on Tuesday he remains optimistic regarding his struggle for Tibetan autonomy, as mainland China is undergoing profound changes.

He made the remark after lunching with French President Jacques Chirac and his fellow Nobel Peace Prize laureates at Elysee Palace on Tuesday. The exiled leader came to Paris to participate in the 50th anniversary celebration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Mainland China blasted France for inviting the Buddhist leader to attend the ceremony, saying he was an exile engaged in "splittist activities" and that he had violated human rights in Tibet.

To avoid friction with mainland China, President Chirac had planned to drop his lunch with the Dalai Lama, but kept the appointment after the media reported on the issue, which stirred up concern from human rights groups and other Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
Despite mainland China's protest, the Dalai Lama stressed he would not abandon his aim of Tibetan autonomy.
"My position remains the same. I am trying to promote meaningful self-rule, not independence, through dialogue," he added.

In light of mainland China's protest, a member of a Paris-based Asian human rights support group indicated that mainland China exerted pressure on France only to illustrate its fear of being exposed as the one who truly holds human rights in contempt.
Mainland China's behavior only complicates the Tibetan matter and has made the Dalai Lama a martyr in prompting self-rule for Tibet, the member added.

France and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization are co-hosting a series of celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of Universal Declaration of Human Rights, including academic seminars, concerts, parades and plays. The main commemoration event will take place Thursday at the Palais de Chaillot, where the declaration was signed 50 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PENSIONERS SAID WORSE OFF THAN OECD COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Australian pensioners have significantly lower incomes than their counterparts in most other developed countries, according to a new report on retirees by an adviser to the UK government.

Paul Johnson, who prepared the report for the Institute of Chartered Accountants, said his findings showed that Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries with good retirement policies mostly taxed superannuation savings at the end-benefit stage rather than when contributions were made as Australia did.

He said his report shows Australia makes poor provisions for retirees without private superannuation. Pensioners account for nearly half of the poorest 30 percent of people in Australia, a higher proportion than in any of the other nine OECD countries examined except Canada, he said.
Australian pensioner couples were by far the worst off among pensioners in OECD countries, with Australian pensioners receiving only 68 percent of the income of non-pensioners, he said.

But he said that is good news for the Australian government, as payments to pensioners accounted for only 2.6 percent of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP), compared with 13.3 percent in Italy. The payments are forecast to rise to 4.5 percent of GDP for Australia by 2050 compared with 20.3 percent in Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PETROLEUM STOCKPILES LEVELS TO REMAIN UNCHANGED BY LIBERALIZATION

TEXT.P: The Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday that it will amend existing measures to regulate Taiwan's export and import of petroleum as a temporary stand-in to the draft of Petroleum Management Law (PML) that is still pending in the Legislative Yuan.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hung Chi-chang and Kuomintang Legislator Ho Sheng-long expressed concern during Wednesday's review committee meeting over Taiwan's petroleum stock levels, sources said.
Existing regulations call for the storage of at least 60 days' worth of petroleum and at least 25 days' worth of liquid gas.
Hung asked MOEA officials about temporary measures that would regulate the volume of petroleum in stock if the Legislative Yuan does not approve the PML by January 1999.
MOEA Vice Minister Yin Chi-ming replied that minimum volume levels will not be changed until the Legislative Yuan approves the PML.
Executive secretary of the Energy Commission Chen Chao-Yih said that the substitution measures would amend the "Measures on Regulating Export and Import of Petroleum and Petroleum-related Products."

The market for petroleum for aircraft and fuel as well the market for liquid gas will be liberalized in January 1999, said MOEA officials. They added that private companies importing petroleum should abide by regulations to maintain stable prices in remote areas. The MOEA also noted that minimum levels of petroleum must be stockpiled to prepare for national emergencies.

According to the PML draft, importers and producers of petroleum-related products must pay taxes into a petroleum fund, while minimum storage levels would range between 60 days' and 90 days' worth of petroleum.
The Energy Commission expects the PML to be approved as soon as possible so as to provide laws to regulate the domestic petroleum market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MODEL GOOD FOR M'LAND, SAYS KOREA'S LEADING ECONOMIC PLANNER

TEXT.P: The South Korean model of economic development no longer suits mainland China, but the Taiwan model is good for the mainland, according to a leading Korean economic planner.

In an interview with The Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, Dr. Kim Kih Wan, South Korea's ambassador for economic affairs, said the so-called Korean model of state-led development was obsolete and that mainland China has been modeling itself on the Korean model.

Kim, who is currently visiting Sydney, said South Korea was badly hit by the Asian economic crisis as a result of its obsolete economic model, but it is now embracing a "new paradigm" of policies based not on protectionism and government intervention but on openness and market forces.
He recommended the more open and competitive Taiwan as a better model for mainland China to follow.
He also said that any country that decided to retreat from globalization was committing economic suicide.

He drew a parallel with the colonization of Asia in the 19th century: "Many countries in East Asia made a big mistake when they failed to adjust to the time called internationalization. When the Western powers arrived with their boats, their railways and their guns, they knocked on the doors of East Asia."

"The countries that said 'no thanks' -- like Korea or China -- what happened? We were colonized. But Japan, which adapted rather well to the change, did fairly well until World War II. The need today to adjust to globalization is even higher than the need to embrace 19th century internationalization." he said. "The country that refuses to embrace globalization is digging its own grave."

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA TO IMPOSE HIGHER LEVIES FOR NEW MINING LEASES

TEXT.P: The Indonesian government, hit hard by the Asian financial crisis, is planning to increase substantially the royalty it levies on new mining projects as part of its efforts to wield greater control over mining operations and over revenue to local communities.

In a dispatch from Jakarta, The Australian Financial Review reported hundreds of illegal miners last week attacked the facilities of a mining project owned by PT Aneka Tambang in West Hava and that the state-owned coal company PT Bukit Asam has also had trouble with illegal miners in Sumatra.

But the daily reported the changes do not appear to have hurt Australian corporate interest in Indonesia as about 50 Australian mining services companies dominated Indonesia's annual mining trade fair and conference last week.

The Indonesian government said that the mining royalties would be increased to 5 percent of sales in the next generation of mining contracts compared with the 1 percent to 3 percent royalties mandated under various existing contracts.

The new royalty system will apply only to licenses issued under a new eighth generation of contracts, meaning existing operations will continue to pay the various rates set by different regimes over the past three decades, the daily reported.

Rozik Soetjipto, director-general of mining in Indonesia, said the new royalty system would not discourage foreign investment because it was still competitive with other countries and because companies were more concerned about consistent regulations and harmonious relations with Indonesian communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21ST CENTURY WILL NO LONGER BE ASIA'S CENTURY: P.K. CHIANG

TEXT.P: The Asian financial turmoil that has evolved beyond Asian countries' control and has had a serious impact worldwide has frustrated Asia's attempt to reign in the 21st century, said P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, on Wednesday.

Chiang made the statement in a speech delivered at a meeting hosted by the Center for Insurance Business Development. He was invited to give a speech on how Taiwan has managed to survive the region's financial crisis.

The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum did not include substantial discussion on the burgeoning economic downturn last year, yet this year APEC paid close attention to the matter, underlining the influence the economic downturn has exercised and showing that APEC is aware of the gravity of the crisis, Chiang said.

In the past, it appeared to be natural to believe that Asia would rule over the 21st century, since the region's economy developed speedily. Many Asian countries therefore aimed to largely expand supply and demand but only ended up hurting themselves in the end, Chiang noted.

To deal with the crisis, Asian countries adopted various measures. Japan played the trump card of a tax cut that totaled 4 trillion Japanese yen, but the country still failed to survive the crisis unscathed.

Although Taiwan has suffered less amid the downturn, it has been seriously affected by Southeast Asia, which accounts for more than 50 percent of Taiwan's export markets. Taiwan's exports to the region dropped 9 percent for the first nine months of this year.
Chiang pledged the need for an expansion of both civil and public investments and an enlargement of domestic demand to boost the economy.
He claimed the government should be responsible for providing a complete environment and a sound "economic infrastructure" for enterprises.

Speaking on Taiwan's positive economic growth rate of 5.1 percent compared with the slight or even negative growth being experienced by neighboring countries, Chiang said Taiwan's growth can be attributed to its industrial and financial policies.

He blamed the region's financial turmoil on overindulgent financial liberalization that allowed for hot money flows but which forced stock and foreign exchange markets to bear the brunt of recessions, notably when foreign capital largely withdrew.

Taiwan's economy mainly is supported by small- and medium-sized enterprises, which differ from the conglomerates of Japan and South Korea. The share of self-financed capitals in Taiwan's enterprise is much higher than that of Japan's companies. These two factors have also contributed to Taiwan's being less affected by the crisis, Chiang said.
