DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK PRICES PLUNGE, FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday following drops on Wall Street.
Sales dominated the market amid profit-taking and the expectation of more losses, resulting in the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropping 94.77 points to close at 7,117.91.
The bourse opened at 7,126.21, and kept trading in low territory, bottoming out at 7,100.82 in the day's trading.
Turnover amounted to 1.75 billion shares with a value of NT$65.23 billion (US$2.01 billion), against the previous session's NT$95.64 billion.
Losers outnumber gainers 344 to 88, with 58 stocks unchanged.
All eight major stock categories sustained losses.

Construction issues registered the largest fall at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff and banking shares, both at 1.6 percent; plastic and chemical stocks at 1.5 percent; cement and electronic engineering issues both at 1.2 percent; paper-making shares at 0.5 percent; and textile stocks at 0.4 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a 1.66-point drop, finishing at 175.52 on a turnover of NT$2.98 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on stock index futures were mixed.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December lost 126 points to close at 7,226, with 2,646 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for January dropped 130 points to 7,325, with 723 transactions, while those for March moved down 95 points to 7,355, those for June declined 60 points to 7,350 and those for September rose 68 points to 7,350. The number of transactions for the three futures were 18, one and two.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,352 points for December; 7,455 points for January; 7,450 points for March; 7,410 points for June; and 7,282 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES TO NINE-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar gained NT$0.023 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday to close at NT$32.32, the highest level in the past nine months.
It was the seventh consecutive increase since the beginning of this month with an accumulated appreciation of more than NT$0.1.

Dealers predicted the local currency may continue to appreciate against the US dollar to test the 32 mark prior to the end of this year as exporters are expected to buy more NT dollars for year-end use.
The gradual weakness of the US dollar in international markets was also a factor pushing the NT dollar's rise, the dealers said.
The NT dollar opened at the day's low of 32.331 in Wednesday's session and traded at a high of 32.267.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$636 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE GIRL LIVING IN SWEDEN VISITING TAIWAN TO FIND PARENTS

TEXT.P: Hanna Andersson, an ethnic Chinese girl living in Sweden, returned to Taipei Wednesday to continue the search for her biological mother.
An earlier visit in October by Andersson -- or Hanna, as she is commonly known in Taiwan -- proved fruitless.
Andersson, a 22-year-old university economics major who has studied mandarin at a language school in Stockholm, came to Taiwan, alone, in hopes of finding her birth mother.

Andersson said at a press conference at the Swedish Trade Office in Taipei that her adoptive parents in Sweden have shown her tremendous love and affection. But inspired by Kartya Wunderle and Eimee Butler, a pair of ethnic Chinese teenagers living in Australia who came to Taiwan separately to search for -- and ultimately found -- their mothers, Andersson came to Taiwan in October to search for her parents.

Noting that her first visit was unsuccessful, Andersson said not all the adopted children she knew were as eager as her to find their biological parents. But she said she has long sought to find her mother and that her heart would not be at peace until she has done so.
Andersson showed her ROC passport which identified her -- then a two-month baby -- as Tseng Mei-li. As her birth certificate was found bogus, she has no way to trace her biological mother.

She was told that she was born out of wedlock to a 16-year-old girl from Tainan, southern Taiwan. Her mother was taken to the northern city of Hsinchu to give her birth, on June 22, 1976. The midwife sold the newly-born infant at NT$20,000 to a Swedish missionary couple. Later on she was taken to Sweden and given to the Andersson family.

Andersson said she worked at a haute couture shop for two years after graduating from high school to save money to travel to Taiwan to find her biological mother. She also enrolled in mandarin classes, so that she might someday speak to her mother in the Chinese language.

Andersson and her Taiwan friends provided phone numbers -- 02-27607160 and 0931064476 and e-mail address -- A 891@ms17hinet.net., hoping that her birth mother will come forward to meet her. She said she will not leave Taiwan until her mother is found.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC FILM PRODUCERS MAKE TAIPEI HOME TO THEIR SECRETARIAT

TEXT.P: The Federation of Motion Picture Producers in Asia-Pacific has decided to establish its standing secretariat in Taipei as a part of efforts to help invigorate Asia's movie industry.

Representatives from 12 member countries in the Asia-Pacific Film Festival Committee met in Taipei on Wednesday. During the meeting, members decided to give Taipei greater responsibilities for reviving the movie industry in the region by making Taipei home to the film producers' secretariat.
The committee selected Vietnam to host the 2000 Asia-Pacific Film Festival, marking a first such honor for that country. Thailand has been authorized to sponsor a similar festival in 1999.
All participating delegates agreed that the movie industry in their respective countries are in an unprecedented slump, particularly in the face of strong competition from Hollywood films.

As of today, 95 percent of motion pictures shown in Thailand are foreign made compared to a mere 5 percent of locally-produced films. In Japan, the ratio between foreign and locally-made films was 7-3, while in Taiwan and South Korea the ratio was 8-2.

On Wednesday, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen met with world-renowned veteran director Robert Wise, and other foreign movie heavyweights who have came to Taipei to take part in the 43rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival and the 35th Golden Horse Awards, slated for Dec. 9-12.
Chen extended a hearty welcome to Wise, and praised him for bringing extra glory to the annual events.
Wise for his part said he was thrilled to visit Taiwan again. He said he was in Taiwan to shoot a film several decades ago and has had a good impression of Taipei.

Other "bright stars," including Maki Miyamoto, best actress in the 1998 Tokyo Film Festival, Joan Chen, a famous Chinese actress who now resides in the United States, Sir Run Run Shaw, veteran producer in Hong Kong, will also be arriving for the festivals.
A total of 287 delegates from the 12 Asia-Pacific Film Festival Committee member countries are expected to take part in the two festivals.

Twenty-four feature films and 16 other short films and animated films have been entered in the 43rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival, while six feature films were selected as nominees for best picture in the 35th Golden Horse Awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CELLULAR PHONE MARKET EXPANDING
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: According to a recent market survey, some 2.9 million people in Taiwan currently own a cellular phone.

The survey, conducted by a Hong Kong market information company, indicated that the figure, which represents a market share of 24 percent, was far larger than the 8 percent market share registered in 1996.
According to projections based on the survey results, the number of cellular phone users in Taiwan will surge to 4.2 million people by 2000 and the market share is expected to reach 35 percent.
The most popular brand name phones among Taiwan consumers were Motorola, Ericsson and Nokia -- three of the world's top mobile phone manufacturers, the survey pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIGENIZATION NOT TANTAMOUNT TO SEEKING INDEPENDENCE: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's indigenization movement is not tantamount to seeking independence, a well-known international relations expert from Taiwan said here on Tuesday.

It is "basically a mistake" to think that Taiwan will move toward becoming an independent country because of its indigenization movement, as some mainland Chinese and foreign scholars have stated, said Y. M. Shao, director of the Institute of International Relations under the National Chengchi University.
Shao was speaking at a seminar held by a Chinese study center at Maryland University on Taiwan's recent "three-in-one" elections.

As Taiwan's inclination toward indigenous culture is natural, it should not be considered part of a separatist movement, Shao noted. The people of Taiwan are very practical because 80 percent of them are fully aware that pursuing independence will provoke serious political consequences, he added.

However, Taiwan also believes it must boost its own strength so it can have greater bargaining power in negotiations with mainland China, he stated, urging the mainland authorities to have a better understanding of the feelings of the Taiwan people.

Shao called on Beijing to thoroughly review why Taiwan cannot accept the "one country, two systems" scheme and its rhetoric that Taiwan is a province of mainland China. He proposed that Beijing adopt a more pragmatic position to deal with these issues.
As to the impact of the Dec. 5 elections, Shao said the most important is that Taiwan has transmitted a message that Chinese are democracy-loving people and are capable of implementing democracy.
Shao, a renowned mainland affairs and international relations expert, is currently visiting Maryland University as a visiting scholar, and will return to Taiwan soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES LITTLE HUMAN RIGHTS PROGRESS IN 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made little progress in improving human rights conditions in 1998, according to an annual report released on Wednesday by the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR).
The CAHR made public its eighth annual Taiwan Human Rights Index Report on the eve of the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Despite Taiwan's outstanding achievements in democracy, as well as economic and educational developments, there has been little progress in improving the rights of Taiwan citizens over the last eight years, CAHR Chairman Chai Sung-lin said.

The report's results were divided into eight categories and involved over 1,400 citizens islandwide. Respondents were asked about the human rights situation in politics, economics, society, culture and education, the judicial system, among women and children, as well as the situation among the elderly and Hong Kong citizens.
Report results showed that Taiwan flunked in all eight categories this year as it has in the past.
While the island demonstrated little progress for women, children, society, education and economy, Taiwan scored the lowest points in regard to the less fortunate groups in society.
There are no adequate nursing facilities and policy for the elderly in Taiwan, while women and children face an increasingly dangerous environment here, according to the report.

Based on a five-point measuring scale, Taiwan's human rights index for elderly people averaged 2.5, the lowest rank among the major eight human rights indexes. The index for nursing care for the elderly was given a low of 2.35 points.

The human rights index for women ranged between 2.12 and 3.18 points in six areas. While a 3.18-point approval rate was given to women's human rights index in education, the lowest level of 2.12 points was given to women in the area of their personal safety.

The government and society have failed to fully protect Taiwan women from sexual offenses and violence on both the public and domestic fronts, said Wang Li-jung, a professor of social science at National Taiwan University.

However, the most worrying finding was that Taiwan children are not happy as society expects them to be, pointed out Feng Yen, a National Taiwan University professor who was in charge of the report's investigation with children.

The average human rights index for Taiwan children in 1998 was 2.72 points, a slight increase of 0.06 points from a year ago, according to the report. But the index in the area of children's personal safety received merely 2.46 points as a result of a series of violent attacks against children over the past year.

In addition to physical abuses, children in Taiwan are constantly exposed to the danger of being abducted, kidnapped, and sold, the report warned. A strings of events involving baby selling and child abuse since the beginning of this year have eroded the confidence of the assessment team in the government's implementation of children welfare policy.

Meanwhile, the report gave 2.89 and 2.83 points to Taiwan human rights in society and education, while the indexes for economics and politics averaged 2.69 and 2.92 points, respectively, all below the 3-point approval rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD OFFERS TO RESIGN OVER ELECTION SETBACK

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung on Wednesday tendered his resignation to take responsibility for the party's setback in the three-in-one elections over the weekend.

At a weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee (CSC) dedicated to reviewing the party's poor performance in the elections, Lin abruptly read his letter of resignation and then immediately walked out of the meeting.
Lin's move surprised most of the members at the main opposition party's policy-making body. They later unanimously approved a resolution to retain Lin.
At a news conference after the meeting, the DPP said all CSC members will meet with Lin to urge him to stay on in his post.
Lin said in the letter that the DPP did not do well in the elections because of various factors.
"I hope my resignation will prompt party comrades to make a thorough review (of the setback) so as to create a promising future for the party," he said.
The DPP lost the mayorship of Taipei to the ruling Kuomintang but it successfully captured the mayorship of Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan.

The DPP has been divided on whether or not Lin should quit to shoulder responsibility for the party's dismal showing. However, Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who lost his reelection bid, said the DPP needs Lin, who has a high moral standard, to lead the party into the next century. A majority of DPP factional leaders are also in favor of having Lin remain party chairman.

In the legislative election, the DPP won 29.66 percent of the votes cast, or 70 out of 225 seats in the expanded next legislature. The results compare to 33.2 percent of votes or 54 out of a total of 164 seats in the current legislature which was elected four years ago.

However, DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen said unless Lin withdraws his written resignation personally, the resignation should be considered valid. Chiu added that chances are very slim that Lin will continue as party chairman as he appears determined to quit.
Chiu a by-election for chairman will take at least one and a half months to complete.
Lin was elected DPP chairman in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3-MILLION-YEAR-OLD HOMINID FOSSIL REMAINS FOUND IN SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: Researchers from the South African University of Witwatersrand have reportedly discovered almost complete fossil remains of a hominid believed to be 3 million years old.

South African Press Association reported on Tuesday that South African Post, Telecommunications and Broadcasting Minister Jay Naidoo said in India "this week we will announce the discovery of humankind's most distant ancestors. Remains of an almost complete skeleton dating back 3 million years have been discovered in South Africa."
Naidoo revealed the find in a speech in New Delhi where some of the world's top anthropologists, scientists, historians and international media are gathered.

Anthropological Professor Phillip Tobias said Ron Clarke's discovery was of such importance that "we are talking about here about world-impact news -- nothing like it of such a great age has ever been found."
Clarke has for years been instrumental in the discovery of important fossil remains which pointed to the evolution of man from apes.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA HELPS BOOST SALARY OF AUSTRALIAN WORKERS

TEXT.P: An unexpected side effect of the virility drug Viagra's introduction to the Australian market is a pay raise for workers trying to meet the growing demand for the popular drug.
Pfizer, the drug's producer, has signed a two-year agreement with 150 workers at its Sydney plant offering a huge pay raise in exchange for higher production volumes.

"Pfizer saw it was coming into a time where Viagra was now on the market (in the US), and they were thinking of bringing it here and also supplying a lot of Asian markets, as well as South American markets," said Hugh McDermott, organizer of the Australian Workers Union in New South Wales.
"As such they needed to get the workforce into a position where they could work the hours they needed to work and really get the product going," he said.
The pay increases were made to allow increased flexibility in work hours and to knock down demarcations among highly trained workers, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: P.K. CHIANG CALLS FOR ENHANCEMENT OF ECONOMIC FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China must emphasize strengthening its economic foundation to better cope with the challenges of the new millennium, according to the ROC's top economic planner.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks on Wednesday at a Kuomintang Central Standing Committee meeting.

Chiang pointed out that the ROC, which has suffered relatively little among Asian countries struck by the economic crisis that began last year, performed relatively well and its economy remains healthy and solid.
However, he said, problems within several local companies recently have revealed that Taiwan's current economic regulations and systems still urgently need to be seriously reviewed and reformed.

The CEPD chief offered three main suggestions on how best to enhance continued economic growth. They include creating a market system full of vitality; improving the construction of a complete infrastructure; and establishing a social environment full of concern.

Chiang noted that the suggestions are aimed at fully implementing the three administrative policies identified by Premier Vincent Siew -- rebuilding government, boosting the economy, and reconstructing society.
The economic planner said at present, the government is actively engaged in various activities such as speeding up the reorganization of government, manpower and the revision of regulations.
Chiang added that the government will accelerate the implementation of public construction projects to stimulate domestic demand and improve the climate for business operations.

He predicted the international economic situation will improve next year and the ROC economy will also perform better in 1999, turning from "outside cold and inside warm" to "outside warm and inside warm".

The CEPD chief urged enterprises at home to be steady in their business operations, pay attention to technological innovation, show concern for society, and continue to maintain competitive superiority in order to reach another economic summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 FILM FESTIVALS KICK OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 43rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival and the 35th Golden Horse Film Festival began in Taipei on Wednesday as celebrities pressed their hands into wet concrete to kick off the festivities.
An opening ceremony was held at the eastern branch of the Shin-Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store at 3 p.m. The festivals are set to continue until Saturday.

Representatives from countries attending the Asia-Pacific Film Festival and Chen Mei-fong, Taiwan's goodwill ambassador to the festival, have offered their hand prints which are currently on display for charity sale.
The festivals have been divided to include the following:
-- an exhibition of motion picture equipment provided by domestic firms; and
-- a charity sale with motion picture-related products provided by domestic firms which are currently on display.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 1 MORE GOLD, 6 BRONZES IN ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Wei Shu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan athletes won one gold and six bronze medals on Wednesday, the third day of the third Asian Games currently being held in Bangkok.
Wu Fu-lung walked away with the gold medal in men's bowling while Chen Chiu-ping won a bronze in the 70-kg women's judo event, followed by another bronze by teammate Wu Mei-ling in the 63-kg event.

Tsai Shu-min garnered a bronze in the women's 400-meter freestyle swimming. She later won another third-place medal along with teammates Chiang Tze-ying, Kuan Chia-hsien, Lin Meng-chieh in the women's 400-meter freestyle relay.
Huang Chih-yung pocketed Taiwan's fifth bronze of the day in the men's 100-meter freestyle swimming.
Meanwhile, Kao Ching-yi garnered a bronze in the women's taekwondo event.
So far, Taiwan athletes have won a total of four golds, three silvers and nine bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INVITED TO IDB MEETING IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been invited to attend a meeting in Washington aimed at helping hurricane-ravaged Central American countries rebuild, the vice foreign minister said on Tuesday.
ROC International Cooperation and Development Foundation (ICDF) Secretary-General Luo Ping-chang will represent the ROC at the meeting slated for Friday, Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou said.

Both Luo and Ou are currently accompanying ROC Vice President Lien Chan on a visit to Central America to express Taiwan's concern for Taipei's storm-hit allies -- Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala and El Salvador. The mission arrived in Honduras on Tuesday for the second leg of its four-nation tour.
Luo will submit Taiwan's aid project plans for the region's post-disaster rehabilitation at the Washington conference which will be hosted by the Inter-American Development Bank, Ou said.

While Taiwan is not an IDB member, it is a close ally of several IDB member nations which were devastated by Hurricane Mitch in October. Taiwan's friendship with Central American countries and its role as a source of aid allowed it to take part in the Washington conference, Ou said.
Beijing, which has been suppressing Taiwan's participation in international activities, was not invited to the meeting, Ou added.

The ROC vice president on Tuesday signed a cooperative memorandum with Honduras under which the ROC government pledged to donate US$12 million to the Central American ally and grant it US$6 million in low-interest long-term loans provided by the ICDF.

Ou told CNA that Honduran authorities have decided to use the loans to build new houses and they have asked the IDB to monitor the construction. Meanwhile, the use of the donated funds will be decided after the Washington meeting.

Honduras was the hardest hit of all the Central American countries after Hurricane Mitch devastated the region between Oct. 25 and Nov. 2. The hurricane left 5,600 people dead, more than 8,000 missing and 1.4 million homeless, according to official reports.

Before flying to Tegucigalpa, Lien and the ROC mission comprised of officials as well as religious and charity representatives visited Nicaragua where Lien pledged a US$10 million cash donation on behalf of the Republic of China government and the people in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM IN INDIA COULD GENERATE 8 MILLION JOBS

TEXT.P: Travel and tourism in India could create 8 million jobs and account for 12 percent of the country's exports by 2010 if the country were to implement a long-term strategy.
The suggestion was made by Geoffrey Lipman, president of the World Travel and Tourism Council (WTTC).
Travel and tourism currently accounts for 10 percent of India's exports and such activities are growing faster than the world average, Lipman said.
A WTTC study found that the industry's contribution to exports was expected to grow from US$5.4 billion to US$37.3 billion by the year of 2010.
"This is not a leisure pursuit of the elite, it is a business that drives economies and changes societies for the better," Lipman added.
He called on India to involve the private sector in focusing on training, developing infrastructure and liberalizing airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP ROC HEALTH OFFICIAL CALLS FOR WHO COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tegucigalpa, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A top health official from the Republic of China on Wednesday called for cooperation between the World Health Organization (WHO) and the ROC in helping ease the health problems in countries hit by Hurricane Mitch.

Chan Chi-shean, director-general of the ROC Department of Health, urged Honduras and its neighboring countries recovering from the hurricane to call on the WHO to work with Taipei in addressing the poor health conditions caused by the devastation in October.

Chan, a member of ROC Vice President Lien Chan's mission to four storm-hit allies in Central America, suggested that governments of those countries ravaged by Mitch make the call to WHO via the Pan-American Health Organization so that the world's top health body may pay due attention to Taiwan's efforts.

He said Taipei offered to provide vaccines and relevant medical aid to countries in Central Asia in 1994 when the region was hit by deadly epidemics. However, the efforts hit a snag because of Beijing's intervention, he noted.

Similar past cases of Taiwan being turned down simply because of Beijing's intervention are numerous, Chan lamented. He said he is planning to file a complaint to WHO's administrative head, asking the health organization to acknowledge the fact that Beijing's efforts to block Taiwan is hampering its efforts to help needy people around the world.

The ROC mission, currently visiting El Salvador, has pledged to donate cash and other aid packages to Honduras and Nicaragua to help them rebuild health and medical facilities as well as infrastructure. The mission is scheduled to proceed to Guatemala after visiting El Salvador.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN PLEDGES SUPPORT FOR PHILIPPINES WITH LOAN PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Japan has reaffirmed its pledge to help the Philippines overcome difficulties caused by the Asian financial crisis with the approval of a US$949 million loan package and other forms of financial assistance.
The announcement was made during a call by Kyosuke Shinozawa, president of the Overseas Economic Development Fund, to Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Tuesday.
Shinozawa said Japan is ready to help fund a number of Estrada's special programs during the financial crisis.

A Japan mission arrived in the Philippines earlier to discuss the details of the Philippines' share of a US$30 billion aid package aimed at speeding up the recovery of Asian economies battered by the region's economic and currency crisis.
Estrada said his administration will use the loan to finance rural infrastructure, socialized housing and other pro-poor programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIANS BET C$6.8 BILLION LEGALLY EVERY YEAR

TEXT.P: Canadians spent C$6.8 billion (US$4.7 billion) on government-run gambling operations last year, making legalized gambling one of the fastest growing industries in Canada.
Statistics Canada (Statscan) said on Wednesday the figure represents a threefold increase in legalized gambling in Canada since 1992.
Residents of Quebec wagered an average of C$348 each in various games of chance in 1997. Prince Edward Islanders were next, betting an average C$340 each, according to the statistics.

The federal agency said in a report that provincial revenue from government-regulated casinos and video lottery terminals have more than doubled in the past five years. Last year alone, the provinces raked in about C$4 billion in profits, up from C$1.7 billion just five years ago.
The report noted that casinos and video lottery machines accounted for 60 percent of all gambling activities in Canada in 1997, up from only 10 percent in 1992.
It said employment in the gambling industry has tripled in the five-year period, to 35,000 full-time jobs. In fact, Statscan noted, it accounted for 2 percent of all job growth between 1992 and 1997.
While gambling revenue is booming, critics said no one seems to be keeping tracks of the social cost of gambling. Provincial governments are only now beginning to work on treatment programs.
The provinces defended the gambling business, saying the revenue supported health care and other social programs.
Anther attraction for the government is, unlike taxes, the money they raise from gaming is voluntary, critics pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIMES HIDING BEHIND ASIAN VALUES CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Australia's foreign minister, in a speech marking the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in Sydney on Wednesday, criticized Asian leaders who used Asian values as justification to limit democracy.

Alexander Downer condemned authoritarian leaders who "would challenge the universality of human rights ... in terms of cultural relativism" -- a clear signal that Australia now feels less restrained about openly criticizing its repressive neighbors.

"For too long there have been people in Asia and elsewhere who have clung to the misguided notion of 'Asian values' as a justification for clamping down on democratic movements or the natural inclination of people to participate in the democratic process.

"They have also used so-called Asian values as an excuse for not allowing for an appropriate evolution of an open society. It is only an open civil society which can be inclusive, tolerant and truly outward-looking," he said.

Without mentioning which country, Downer said, "It is not enough for governments merely to hold elections to qualify as democratic. If they follow those elections by erecting barriers to civil society -- such as suppressing dissent, hobbling the judicial system, cracking down on the media or inhibiting transparency -- they are weighting the scales unfairly and undermining democracy."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CRITICISM OF AUTHORITARIAN REGIMES SUPPORTED

TEXT.P: Analysts have come out in support of Australia's criticism of authoritarian regimes which use Asian values as an excuse to continue political repression and human rights abuses, the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.
The concept of Asian values was particularly seductive to politicians, officials and businessmen who were anxious to exploit Asia's economic boom, they were cited as saying.

Over the past 20 years of Asia's economic growth, four Asian countries have replaced authoritarian regimes with democratic ones. They are two of Asia's largest economies -- Taiwan and South Korea -- and two smaller Southeast Asian economies -- Thailand and the Philippines.
Since the economic crisis began, Indonesians have removed former President Suharto from power and ushered in a new era, they noted.

The trend toward democracy can occur during good or bad weather. Only Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has increased the level of repression, the analysts stated, adding that they hoped he would fail.

Authoritarianism has never been an authentic Asian value, they argued. Leading Asian scholars pointed out that the supposed father of Asian values -- Confucius -- wrote about the importance of individual freedoms while Mencius, a famous Confucius disciple, first coined the phrase "people's power."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOUD MUSIC CAN CAUSE PREMATURE DEAFNESS: SCIENTISTS

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have reconfirmed most people's suspicions that listening to personal stereos at high volumes could lead to premature deafness.

New testing techniques have revealed that those listening to personal stereos at volumes loud enough for a person nearby to hear could cause premature loss of the outer hair cells in the ear, which under certain circumstances can explode, Eric LePage of the Hearing Australia center said.
The damage caused by personal stereos can be just as bad as that caused by industrial noise, he added.

LePage and his team conducted a study of the aural health of 1,700 people in Australia. They compared the hearing of those who have never used personal stereos with those who sometimes used them and to those who were frequent users.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS COMMISSION NOT BE ABOLISHED

TEXT.P: The ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) will not be sacrificed in the government reforms aimed at improving administrative efficiency, the commission's minister asserted on Thursday.
Chiao Jen-ho said there is a "consensus" among the ROC leadership that the organization will be maintained. The minister was responding to CNA questions over the possible abolishment of the OCAC.

The OCAC was established to serve the interests of Chinese nationals in foreign countries and areas, and to maintain cultural solidarity with overseas Chinese. It plays the role of gluing the strength of Chinese people who live all over the world, Chiao said.

Maintaining and strengthening the OCAC's functions, which include providing financial, investment, and educational assistance, has been a consensus of the government, Chiao told CNA ahead of his departure for Malaysia to meet with overseas Chinese who had been educated in Taiwan.

Chiao noted that he has been minister of the OCAC for 10 months and five days, during which he has come into contact with Chinese nationals all around the world. Through such interaction, he has found his work very meaningful, Chiao said.

For example, in Malaysia there are over 30,000 Chinese descents who had studied in Taiwan. Those overseas Chinese have established a gathering every year which reflects their attachment to the Republic of China, Chiao said.
At present, around 2,800 overseas Chinese students from countries worldwide will come to study in Taiwan every year, Chiao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 10, or Oct. 22 under the Lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: France, headed by Napoleon Bonaparte, annexes nothern Hanover, Bremen, Hamburg, Lauenburg and Lubeck, Germany.
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War, with Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines ceded to the United States for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: The Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in Southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1919: Australia's Smith brothers complete the first long-range flight from Eangland to Australia.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused massive split within the communist party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Winsor.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan province, to Taipei.
1952: The government of the Republic of China drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1967: The world's first commercial thermonuclear blast takes place in the US state of New Mexico, providing access to natural gas from underground deposits.
1976: The Soviet Union announces 200-nautical mile economic sea realm.
1979: The "Formosa incident," during which Formasa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The indigenous defense fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named by President Lee Teng-hui as "Ching-kuo" class fighters.
1989: The first non-communist government in 41 years is set up in Czechoslovakia, as Vaclav Havel succeeds Gustav Husac in the so-called "Velvet Revolution."
1993: ANC leader Nelson Mandela says he and President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democartic, non-racial South Afirca.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established; The Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP), a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) splinter group, is established.
Confucius: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES DROP; FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Share prices on Thursday dropped on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX), the third consecutive decline due to low investor confidence after weekend elections.
The decline was also triggered by drops on Wall Street, dealers said.
The TAIEX weighted priced index, the market's key barometer, fell 69.34 points to close at 7,048. The bourse opened at 7,118.27.
A total of 1.64 billion shares exchanged hands on a market turnover of NT$59.3 billion (US$1.84 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 328 to 87, with 74 stocks unchanged.

All eight major stock categories saw losses. Construction issues slumped the largest margin at 2.1 percent, followed by textile shares which moved down 2 percent; paper-making issues 1.9 percent; plastic and chemical stocks 1.5 percent; financial shares 1 percent; cement stocks 0.9 percent; electronic engineering issues 0.7 percent; and foodstuff shares 0.6 percent.
The over-the-counter market posted a 1.31-point loss, closing at 174.21, with a turnover of NT$2.65 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures saw both declines and gains.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December slid 40 points to finish at 7,186, with 2,171 contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for January moved down 55 points to 7,270 with 867 contract transactions, while those for March posted a drop of 85 points to close at 7,270, with 51 transactions.
No trading was registered for June, while the TAIEX Index Futures for September rose 89 points to 7,245, with three transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday registered 7,226 for December, 7,325 for January, 7,355 for March, 7,284 for June, and 7,156 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF VOICES CONCERN OVER BOA'S PLANS TO SELL TAIWAN OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Thursday urged the Bank of America (BOA) to protect its clients' rights after the bank announced it would sell its Taiwan retail operations.

As a part of plans to streamline its businesses in Asia after merging with Nations Bank, BOA will sell off its consumer banking activities in Taiwan, Singapore and India, while boosting operations in Hong Kong and Macau, bank officials said on Thursday.
BOA promised to keep its existing services in Taiwan unchanged prior to any takeover by other institutions.

As of late November, BOA in Taiwan issued 230,000 credit cards, accepted NT$30 billion in deposits and provided NT$800 million in loans. The retail business in Taiwan is estimated at about US$700 million

Vice Finance Minister Sean Chen indicated that BOA had engaged in wholesale operations and did not open business in retail banking services until 1994. He added that it was a pity that the bank which had been performing so well in Taiwan had to quit.
The MOF also questioned BOA's withdrawal of capital, implying the bank was operating at a deficit, but BOA has denied this speculation.

Meanwhile, Bank SinoPac has expressed interest in taking over the market BOA is leaving, saying that they are confident of being able to manage the operations since SinoPac has acquired Australian and American banks previously.
SinoPac said it would take several months to cope with the acquisition before the terms could be settled. The bank was also convinced this acquisition would be a boost SinoPac.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERTS SEE CHEN AS STRONG PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, despite having lost his reelection bid, is still the strongest presidential candidate in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, prominent US experts said.
US observers of Taiwan's three-in-one elections which were held on Dec. 5 gathered at a seminar in Washington D.C. to discuss the election results.

Robert Sutter, researcher at the US Library of Congress, said Taiwan Vice President Lien Chan will likely be nominated by the ruling Kuomintang as its presidential hopeful, but Lien may lose in a race against Chen who is popular in southern Taiwan.

"Lien Chan is not seen as a vote-getter and is someone who is not a charismatic type of political leader," Sutter told seminar members. "In fact, it's quite possible he would lose (in a contest with Chen)."

The researcher also noted that Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who is set to step down from his post in accordance to the ROC's constitutional amendment, may take part in the presidential election without the KMT's approval.
"The scenario of a three-way race is something that we should watch very carefully," Sutter noted, especially those in Washington who are worried about Taiwan moving toward independence.
It is worth noting whether or not the KMT will be able to consolidate its members in time for the election, Sutter said.
Ralph Clough, professor at the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, agreed that Chen would be the DPP's candidate for president.

Clough added that Chen's failure in the mayoral election "releases him from the pledge" that if he were reelected he would serve out his second four-year term. As it stands, Chen now has the time to dedicate himself to the 2000 presidential campaign.

Taipei's representative to the United States Stephen S.F. Chen said at the seminar the election results have shown that neither pro-independence nor pro-unification radicals have gained popular support in Taiwan.

Also present at the seminar was US House of Representative Gerald B.H. Solomon (R-New York). He praised the KMT's performance in the recent election and noted that while Taiwan was conducting free elections, mainland China was arresting those trying to establish an opposition party.

Other notable members at the seminar included China affairs expert Nancy Tucker who is a historian at George Washington University, and Kenneth Leiberthal, head of the Asian Affairs Department of the US National Security Council.
On the issue of the "new Taiwanese," a phrase coined by ROC President Lee Teng-hui during the campaign, Sutter said the concept gained widespread support from voters.

Saturday's elections have also made it less likely that the United States will do anything to harm Taiwan's interests while dealing with the mainland, Sutter commented, as democracy in Taiwan has taken off to the extent that the US government is unable to amend its policy toward Taiwan in relation to the mainland.
Taiwan's image as a "mature and responsible democracy will be a more and more important factor in the American China policy calculus," the researcher said.

While Sutter and Tucker believed the US would have to change its policy toward Taiwan due to its newly established engagement policy with Beijing, Leiberthal argued that he does not see the US altering its relations with Taiwan.

The election outcome should calm both Beijing and Washington's fears over the possibility of Taiwan declaring independence, and strengthen the concept of self-rule among the people of Taiwan, Clough commented.
After the election, Taiwan is seen moving to the center, Sutter noted, "but the center is moving away from the mainland."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENJOYS GROWTH IN PRIVATE INVESTMENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: Despite a drop in the total value of imports in November compared to October, the private investment sector has shown signs of steady growth, Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Thursday.
The value of Taiwan's imports for November totaled US$8.86 billion, a decline of 12.6 percent from the previous month.
On separate terms, the import of consumer goods registered a drop of 42.3 percent compared with the month-earlier level, while that for agricultural and industrial materials fell by 15.4 percent.
However, Taiwan's import of capital equipment in November jumped 18.3 percent from the October level, the CEPD statistics indicated.
Growth in this area indicates that local investment has not been affected by sluggish economic development triggered by the Asian financial crisis, CEPD officials said.
The officials added that private investment is expected to remain the island's key to economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN EL SALVADOR
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan arrived in El Salvador on Thursday on the third leg of a four-nation tour of Central America to bring relief aid to countries hit hard by Hurricane Mitch.

Upon his arrival at the San Salvador International Airport, Lien and acting El Salvadoran President Enrique Borgo Bustamante signed a memorandum on cooperation which mainly features a US$2 million donation and US$4 million in low-interest long-term loans from Taiwan to help El Salvador rehabilitate.
President Armando Calderon Sol is currently visiting Washington, D.C. to take part in the first meeting of the International Donor Community.

Lien, who was posted in San Salvador as ROC ambassador to El Salvador 23 years ago, said he was saddened by the fact that many of his old friends who he met here were killed in civil wars over the past two decades.
Later in the day, Lien and his mission visited a refugees shelter in urban San Salvador to meet with people who fell victim to Mitch.

Lien, speaking in fluent Spanish, told the El Salvadoran people that he is bringing the concern and aid from the ROC government and people to El Salvador with the hopes that the people and the country will soon recover from the worst disaster in recent years.
Before arriving in San Salvador, Lien and his mission, which includes government officials and representatives from religious and philanthropic groups, visited Nicaragua and Honduras.

Lien pledged, on behalf of the ROC government, US$16 million in cash aid and other relief packages to Nicaragua, and US$18 million in similar aid to Honduras, the country hardest hit by Hurricane Mitch in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDISH GIRL PROVIDES DNA SAMPLE IN BID TO FIND BIOLOGICAL MOTHER

TEXT.P: Hanna Andersson, an ethnic Chinese girl living in Sweden who has come to Taipei to search for her biological mother, on Thursday submitted a DNA sample.
The sample was submitted at the National Police Administration, along with that of Tseng Lee Jung-mei, the woman who is named as Andersson's birth mother in her adoption papers.

Tseng said that years ago she gave up her youngest daughter for adoption. Another infant, however, was adopted by a Swedish couple using her daughter's name. Tseng said she is not sure whether Andersson is the girl who was adopted under her daughter's name.
NPA officials said it would take several days for them to complete the DNA comparison, as the NPA lab currently has a heavy backlog.
Andersson, a 22-year-old college student majoring in economics, has studied mandarin at a language school in Stockholm. She came to Taiwan with her lawyer, in hopes of finding her birth mother.
Andersson said at a press conference in Taipei Wednesday that she was told that she was born out of wedlock to a 16-year-old girl from Tainan, southern Taiwan.

Her mother was taken to the northern city of Hsinchu to give birth, which occurred on June 22, 1976. A midwife sold the newborn for NT$20,000 to a Swedish missionary couple. Later she was taken to Sweden and given to the Andersson family.

Andersson said she was inspired by Kartya Wunderle and Eimee Butler, a pair of ethnic Chinese teenagers living in Australia who came to Taiwan separately to search for -- and ultimately found -- their mothers. Andersson came to Taiwan in October to search for her biological parents, but to no avail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1998 ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE BETTER THAN IN MOST ASIAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Thursday that if Taiwan achieves its predicted economic growth of 5.1 percent this year it would put the island ninth among world economies in terms of their performance this year.

Taiwan's economic growth figure, a decline from an earlier CEPD prediction of 6.7 percent, may still be larger than those of most East Asian economies, excluding mainland China, the CEPD predicted in its review on this year's key economic targets.
While Taiwan's economic development is expected to be sluggish this year, consumer prices will remain stable, said CEPD officials.

The CEPD review indicates Taiwan's consumer prices in the first 10 months of 1998 grew 1.4 percent compared with year-earlier levels, while annual growth this year is expected to amount to only 1.6 percent, below the government's ceiling of 3 percent.

In analyzing the impact of the Asian financial crisis on Taiwan's economy, the report said the financial sector was the first to be hit, with the New Taiwan dollar falling 14.3 percent over the past year and stock prices dropping 20.6 percent since last June.

The impact then expanded, as commodity exports during the January-October period plunged 9 percent from year-earlier levels, and commodity and service export growth rates fell by 5.6 percentage points.

Unemployment in the third quarter of this year reached 2.99 percent, the highest level since the fourth quarter of 1986, while the size of Taiwan's workforce, or its labor participation rate, fell to 58.01 percent of its total population aged 15 or older. That figure is the lowest level seen since 1983, the CEPD report showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR SURGES TO NINE-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged against the greenback Thursday for an eighth consecutive day due to the weakness of the US dollar.
The local currency climbed NT$0.025 against the US dollar on Thursday, closing at 32.295, the highest level in the past nine months.
The NT dollar opened at the day's low of 32.314 and rose as high as 32.233 in the day's trading.
Interbank US dollar trading expanded to US$790 million, the largest single-day amount in the past two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RECALLS RECORD OF HELPING MIGRANTS LEARN ENGLISH

TEXT.P: The Australian government has since 1948 helped 1.5 million migrants from many countries, including Taiwan, mainland China and countries throughout Southeast Asia, learn English so that they could settle in the country, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said on Thursday.
In a statement faxed to CNA Thursday afternoon, Ruddock launched celebrations marking the 50th anniversary of the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) in New South Wales.

"The AMEP is one of Australia's key migrant settlement schemes, which has helped 1.5 million migrants since it commenced in 1948. The program is going from strength to strength in helping vast numbers of adult migrants and refugees learn English and therefore settle more successfully in Australia, find employment and avoid social isolation," he said.

"The stories of these people tell all have one common thread -- the welcome and help they received through the AMEP program. Such success underpins the government's ongoing commitment to assisting the settlement of new arrivals to Australia through the allocation of A$95 million (US$60 million) per year to the AMEP," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN URGES SANCTIONS AGAINST MAINLAND CHINA OVER SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: US Rep. Dana Rohrabacher said Thursday he will urge all democratic nations to impose economic and political sanctions against mainland China for its continued military buildup in the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

"The presence of battle ships and structures constitute economic and political threats right now," said Rohrabacher as he referred to the continued mainland Chinese fortification in the Spratlys, where he conducted an aerial inspection of mainland Chinese-occupied Mischief Reef, which is within the Philippine's exclusive economic zone.
Rohrabacher said the Philippines and other democratic countries should take harsh measures to dismantle the military structures and to shoo away mainland Chinese naval ships in the Spratlys.
Rohrabacher said that economic and political sanctions against mainland China "are proper due to China's firm stand on Mischief Reef."
Sources at the US Embassy in Manila said peaceful and diplomatic efforts must first be exhausted to resolve the conflict in the South China Sea, which is a vital international sea lane. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NEW ZEALAND PRIME MINSTER A CLOSE SECOND IN RACE TO HEAD WTO

TEXT.P: Former New Zealand Prime Minister Mike Moore is running a close second in the race to head the World Trade Organization (WTO) after making the best impression on ambassadors in Geneva nearly a fortnight ago, officials said Thursday.
In a complex procedure that makes selecting a pope look simple, they said Moore could still win if he emerges as the compromise pick.
Thai Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panipchtpakdi is the front-runner to replace retiring Director-General Renato Ruggiero early next year.
But the final result depends on which candidate the world's biggest trading powers -- the United States and the European Union (EU) -- choose to back.
The officials said that although Moore has had good relations with the United States, where he made a good impression during a lobbying visit this year, it has yet to settle on a candidate.

They said the EU looks far from being in agreement on the trade watchdog's next leader, with about half of member countries, led by influential France, supporting Moroccan candidate Hassan Abouyoub. A few EU countries back the Thai candidate.
If the United States and the EU disagree over their preferred candidate, they would have to find a suitable compromise candidate.

Importantly for Moore, as a former trade minister, France has pledged not to veto his candidacy. It has turned the page on past differences over New Zealand's butter and lamb exports to Europe, and it seems untroubled by his free-trade stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ATTENDS IDB MEETING IN WASHINGTON AS OBSERVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Republic of China is in Washington, D.C. to attend an international meeting aimed at helping hurricane-ravaged Central American countries recover.

The meeting of the International Donor Community, the first of its kind, is beginning on Thursday in Washington, with the Republic of China attending as an observer under the name "Taipei, China" said Peter Bate, a spokesman for the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).

Bate said the ROC was invited to the IDB-sponsored donors meeting because it is a major donor and one of the countries that dispatched aid packages to the storm-hit Central American countries at an early stage.

Meanwhile, Bate said it is a compromise that Taiwan was invited to attend the meeting under the name of "Taipei, China" as Taiwan is not full member in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, or the United Nations, which maintain close links with the IDB.

Bate noted that the ROC government could launch a protest over the use of "Taipei, China" if it were unhappy with the arrangement. He added that if Taiwan were to issue a protest, it would be understandable.

Cheng Po-jeou, the ROC's deputy representative in the United States, and Luo Ping-chang, secretary-general of the ROC International Cooperation and Development Foundation (ICDF), will represent Taiwan at the donors summit meeting.
Luo is scheduled to present Taiwan's aid and relief packages as well as follow-up plans to the meeting on Friday. The packages include aid to Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala.
Delegates from 27 countries and areas, as well as representatives from 20-odd international organizations are expected to attend the two-day meeting.
The presidents of Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, Costa Rica and vice president of Guatemala will make speeches during the meeting.
Hurricane Mitch swept through Central America in mid-October, and left more than 10,000 people dead, several hundreds of thousand homeless and inflicted damages exceeding billions of US dollars.
US President Bill Clinton sent first lady Hillary Clinton to the region to inspect the aftermath of the devastation and pledged US$200 million in aid.

ROC Vice President Lien Chan is also leading a Taiwan mission to Taipei's four allies -- Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala -- and is offering cash and other aid packages to help the countries rebuild homes and infrastructure.

The IDB was established in December 1959 under the support of former Brazilian President Juscelino Kubitschek. A majority of its members are Central American, Caribbean and European countries with Japan being the only member from Asia. Neither Taiwan nor mainland China are members of the IDB.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REITERATES SUPPORT TO HUMAN RIGHTS PRINCIPLES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government Thursday reaffirmed its support to the principles enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the declaration by the United Nations.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release that the government will continue to respect and promote human rights according to these principles, hoping that human rights will prevail in the whole world in the next century.

The UN adopted the universal declaration on Dec. 10, 1948. It further adopted the International Convenant on Economic, Social, and Cultural Rights, as well as the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1967 to enhance the promotion of human rights in the world. Some 140 countries, including the Republic of China, have signed the convenants.

Because of obstruction by communist China, the Republic of China has not been able to participate in other UN human rights treaties since it lost its membership in the world body in 1972, but it will enact law to implement them, the MOFA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS DAY TO BE OBSERVED IN NY

TEXT.P: The International Action for Human Rights will sponsor a rally and vigil outside the United Nations Headquarters in New York Thursday to mark the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

A spokesman for the organization said many human rights promoters and political dissidents from more than 20 countries will take part in the activities to be held at the park in front of the UN headquarters.
The purpose of the activities is to call upon all nations in the world to respect and implement the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the UN on Dec. 10, 1948, he said.
Harry Wu and many other prominent human rights promoters and dissidents from mainland China, Tibet, Inner Mongolia, Nigeria, and other countries will deliver speeches at the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S 5.5% ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TARGET IN 1999 FEASIBLE: SIEW

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's 1999 economic growth target of 5.5 percent is feasible, Premier Vincent Siew said Thursday.

The target figure, set Thursday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), is slightly higher than 5.2 percent to 5.4 percent forecast by other domestic and foreign economic institutions.
The targeted economic growth rate was included in a 1999 national development plan filed by P.K. Chiang, head of the CEPD, at the Cabinet's regular weekly meeting.

According to the CEPD's forecast, the ROC's 1999 per capita gross domestic product (GDP) real growth rate will be 4.7 percent and its nominal per capita gross national product (GNP) will be US$13,196.
The CEPD set a maximum ceiling for consumer price growth in 1999 at 1.6 percent (excluding fresh vegetables, seafood and energy).
The Cabinet-level CEPD put the ROC's 1999 employment growth rate at 2.8 percent and its jobless rate at 2.7

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui stresses importance of helping minority groups on Human Rights Day, saying that human rights are the core of true democracy.
The China Times:
Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang hints possibilities of Cabinet resignation en masse, stressing that President Lee has repeatedly expressed determination not to seek re-election, and time is not ripe yet for direct presidential election among KMT party members.
The United Daily News:
Groundbreaking held in Green Island for the building of Asia's first human rights momument with nearly 100 ex-political dissidents and family members attending; Witnessing the ceremony, Premier Vincent Siew announces the arrival of 'human rights era.'
The Liberty Times:
Building of the first human rights monument in Asia kicks off.
The Independence Morning Post:
Taiwan and the United States agree to jointly expand undersea cable systems to upgrade telecommunications quality between the United States and Asian-Pacific countries.
The Commons Daily:
Groundbreaking of human rights monument on Green Island held.
The China Post:
President Lee Teng-hui says women's status part of democractic rights agenda.
The China News:
Sinopac makes move on BOA unit -- Leading local consumer bank seeks to expand retail operations with buyout.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW REITERATES CONSTITUTIONAL RULING ON CABINET RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The decision of whether the Cabinet should resign en masse following last week's elections for legislators ultimately resides with President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Siew said it was up to the president and not the Executive Yuan to initiate the Cabinet's removal in compliance with the Republic of China's Constitution.
The Constitution empowers the president to appoint the premier, the country's highest administrative official, who reports to the legislature.

Siew said since no rule in the Constitution stipulates that the Cabinet should resign after legislative elections, it would be a constitutionally important issue if a new amendment is added requiring the Cabinet to resign.
According to a recent poll, some 60 percent of those in the newly-elected legislature, which is scheduled to be sworn in on Feb. 1, 1999, said the Siew Cabinet should resign en masse.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT PROCEEDS TO GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan flew to Guatemala on Friday on the last leg of his four-nation tour of Central America to bring relief aid to countries hit hard by Hurricane Mitch.

Lien met with Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen over a luncheon. During the gathering, they signed a joint memorandum on cooperation which mainly features a US$2 million donation and US$4 million in low-interest long-term loans from Taiwan to help Guatemala rehabilitate from the devastation.

Lien's visit to Guatemala has two purposes, said ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who is along with other officials and religious and philanthropic delegates accompanying Lien on the current Central American tour.

In addition to bringing goodwill and cash aid from Taiwan to Guatemala in the wake of the devastation inflicted by Hurricane Mitch, Lien is trying to consolidate ROC-Guatemala ties as Beijing has stepped up efforts to win the ROC ally over to its fold, Hu said.
Other countries in that part of the world which Beijing has tried hard to lure away from the ROC also include Panama and Costa Rica, Hu added.

Hu quoted Lien as saying after the luncheon meeting with Arzu that the ROC-Guatemala ties are close and solid, and there are no signs indicating that bilateral relations are "shaky" due to Beijing's intervention.

Prior to arriving in Guatemala City, the ROC vice president and his mission visited three other ROC allies -- Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador. On behalf of the ROC government, Lien pledged US$18 million in cash aid and other relief packages to Honduras, the country hardest hit by Hurricane Mitch in October, US$16 million in cash aid and loans to Nicaragua, and US$6 million to El Salvador.

In November, the ROC government sent US$2.6 million in cash and 73 metric tons of medicine and other relief items to the four Central American countries. The cash was mainly collected from fund-raising activities throughout Taiwan.

Lien is scheduled to conclude his Central American tour on Saturday. En route home, Lien will make a two-day one-night stopover in Los Angeles, where he and members of his mission will not engage in any public activities nor meet the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN VISITS SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: US Congressman Dana Rohrabacher left a Philippine air force base south of Manila at 8:30 a.m. Thursday for the disputed Spratly Islands aboard a C-130 plane.

Rohrabacher, who was accompanied by Philippine Congressman Roilo Golez, a Philippine air force officer, US Embassy personnel, several US and Philippine journalists, said his trip to the Spratlys will help the US Congress assess the real situation in the South China Sea.
"The fortification and intimidation by the communist Chinese in the Spratlys only showed (that mainland China is) bullying the democratic Philippines," Rohrabacher said before boarding the plane.
"We cannot ignore this bullying by the mainland Chinese," said Rohrabacher who added "I expressed support to the government to President Joseph Estrada."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SMUGGLING RING SMASHED IN US, CANADA

TEXT.P: US and Canadian authorities broke a smuggling ring where hundreds of mainland Chinese were illegally brought to the United States through Canada along the St. Lawrence River, authorities said on Thursday.
Investigators arrested 23 people in the United States, five in Toronto and three in Cornwall, Ontario which borders the US. Warrants have also been issued for 10 additional suspects.

With the arrests, US and Canadian officials said they have broken up a major crime ring that smuggled hundreds of people from China's Fujian province into the United States via Canada. Each illegal immigrant paid about C$40,000 in the hopes of finding a better life in North America.
Smugglers made 33 runs in a recent two-month period, each time bringing eight to 24 people. Fake documents were used to bring the people into the United States, investigators said.
The suspects were to make their first court appearances on Thursday, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AID TO ALLIES NOT CONDITIONAL: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Enhanced ROC ties with the World Trade Organization (WTO) or the World Health Organization (WHO) is not a condition to the ROC's assistance to its allies, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu asserted on Thursday.

Hu was responding to questions surrounding suggestions made by ROC Department of Health Director General Chan Chi-shean that Honduras and Nicaragua and other allies in the region call on the WHO via the Pan-American Health Organization to work with Taipei in addressing the poor health conditions caused by Hurricane Mitch which devastated the region in November.
Chan's suggestion is by no means adding a condition to Taipei's aid efforts, Hu insisted.

Taipei's communications with functional international organizations are required for its bid to join these organizations, Hu noted, therefore Taipei is willing to receive feedback from the international community.

Beijing has not relented in its suppression of Taiwan in the international arena, the foreign minister said. For example, Taiwan is not even a member of the International Red Cross due to the mainland's boycott, Hu added.

On the issue of the ROC's efforts to enter the United Nations, Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will take a more active role in the bid rather than to wait for approval as has been the practice in the past.

Guatemala's Congress publicized their approval of a resolution on Thursday in support of Taiwan's membership in the UN as well as other international organizations. The announcement was made during banquet held in honor of the visiting ROC delegation led by Vice President Lien Chan.

Other guests at the banquet included ROC Public Construction Commission Chairman Ou Chin-der, Vice Minister of Economics Chang Chang-pang, Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung and National Health Insurance Bureau Deputy General Manager Chang Horn-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOMURA ACCUSED OF TRYING TO EAT AUSTRALIA'S PUBLIC COMPANIES

TEXT.P: An Australian Federal Court ruled that Nomura International Plc sought to ambush the Australian Stock Exchange and wipe out US$10 billion off the value of Australian public companies, the Sydney Morning Herald said on Friday.
The London-based company is accused of dumping portfolio shares worth US$460 million -- more than the normal total daily turnover -- in the closing minutes of trade on March 28, 1996.

The Federal Court was told that Nomura executives and traders in London and Hong Kong laughed and joked about instructions to 10 different brokers, which hoped to drive the stock exchange's All Ordinaries Index of 353 stocks down by as much as 10 percent.
Justice Ronald Sachville of the Federal Court said he found "Nomura engaged in deliberately misleading conduct designed to achieve illegitimate ends."

Nomura International is a division of the scandal-plagued Tokyo-based Nomura Securities Group, founded in 1872, which has US$100 billion in assets. Sachville said Nomura Australia Ltd., the Australian arm of Nomura, was not involved in the incident but is registered here as a dealer.

The Australian verdict is expected to trigger action against Nomura in the two cities from which the "sting" was organized -- London and in Hong Kong -- where legal action has been launched by the local securities regulators, the daily reported.

Alan Cameron, chairman of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, said the commission was unable to penalize Nomura International because it is not registered in Australia. But he expected that "our fellow regulators" in the UK and Hong Kong would consider suspending or heavily fining Nomura as a result of the Australian verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA WANTS TO SUBSTANTIALLY CUT NUMBER OF BANKS

TEXT.P: While Indonesia would like to reduce the number of banks from 200 to about 50, industry experts say the country can afford to sustain fewer than 10 under new requirements, the Australian Financial Review said on Friday.

Jakarta is planning to offer up to 80 percent of the new capital needed by about 45 private banks as long as they can raise the additional 20 percent and provide business plans for the next three years which move towards international capital adequacy standards, the paper reported.

The daily quoted Finance Minister Bambang Subianto as saying that of the 150 operating banks that had been audited, 54 had capital adequacy above 4 percent, 56 were in the category eligible for government capital assistance and 40 were below negative 25 percent, which meant they were destined for closure.
But the biggest burden comes from six state banks which will be recapitalized at a cost of about US$17 billion despite falling into the closure category for private banks, the daily reported.

Bambang said it was more effective to provide US$17 billion to the state banks than simply to liquidate them and pay off depositors an amount of US$44 billion. Four state banks are already being merged into one new institution.

Lippobank, owned mainly by ethnic Chinese in Indonesia, is regarded as one of the strongest of the large private banks and has kicked off the first rights issue capital raising to pave the way for eligibility for government funding, the daily reported.
Several prominent economists in Indonesia have warned against using a simple cut-off percentage to judge which banks were eligible for new capital, saying the government should be more selective.
