DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE RISES TO 8% IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 8 percent in November thanks to the decline of employment, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) said.
The unemployment rate jumped from an eight-year low of 7.7 percent in October to 8 percent due to a fall in employment by 49,800 in November.

The drop represented the largest monthly fall in more than five years and has raised doubts among some economists that a sustained fall in the jobless rate in 1999 is likely regardless of booming economic growth in Australia in recent months.
Federal Employment Minister Peter Reith on Thursday tried to downplay the significance of the rise in unemployment by referring to the volatility of the monthly figures.

But Labor Party's employment spokesman said the weak figures were a reflection of the government's failure on the employment front, pointing to the decline in the participation rate since the coalition government of the Liberal and National Parties were first elected to power in March 1996.
"Australians who have lost jobs and are unemployed have unfortunately clearly given up any hope of getting a job in the current environment," Labor's spokesman Martin Ferguson told reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 11, or Oct. 23 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: British restore Java, Indonesia to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton), resulting in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy in World War II.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin elected as speaker.
1961: Two US helicopter companies arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier in the first direct US military support for South Vietnam's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and misfeasance.
1972: The US Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer resigned in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish loose federation with common foreign policy and single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Incumbent President Jerry Rawlings is declared the winner in Ghana's presidential election.
Confucius: "A wise man who is not serious will not ispire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STANCE ON MAINLAND REMAINS UNCHANGED AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's policies on mainland China remain unchanged despite a decisive win by the ruling Kuomintang in elections held on Dec. 5, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official under the Executive Yuan said on Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said the government will continue to pursue the goal of a unified China featuring democracy, freedom and equitable distribution of wealth in accordance with National unification Guideline.
After the three-in-one elections, the mainland can consider Taiwan a democratic country, he added.

As to the government's future actions in its relationship with mainland China, Sheu said the MAC will continue to engage in a variety of exchanges and practical negotiations with the mainland. He also reiterated the government's pledge to improve the relationship across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan voters went to the polls on Dec. 5 to select legislators islandwide while Taipei and Kaohsiung residents elected mayors and city councils in their respective cities in what was called by local media three-in-one elections.
KMT candidates won 124 seats in the 225-seat legislature and KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou defeated incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DROPS FROM 9TH TO 10TH LARGEST EU TRADING PARTNER
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec.10 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan dropped in ranking from the European Union's (EU) 9th largest trading partner to its 10th, according to recent EU data.

The statistics, covering EU bilateral trade in the first eight months of 1998, indicated that EU exports to Taiwan fell slightly by 2 percent valued at 8.1 billion euros, while imports soared by 19 percent worth a total of 11.7 billion euros compared to 9.8 billion euros recorded last year.
According to figures, the EU suffered a trade deficit with Taiwan totaling 3.6 billion euros, an increase from 1.5 billion euros recorded last year.

Among the EU's 10 largest trading partners, the United States and mainland China accounted for the largest trade growth as exports were up by 15 percent and 17 percent respectively. Hong Kong, which was ranked the EU's 10th largest trading partner previously, failed to make the most recent top 10 list.
The EU's 10 largest trading partners are the United States, Switzerland, Japan, mainland China, Norway, Russia, Poland, Turkey, the Czech Republic and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO PROPOSE IMPROVEMENT MEASURES ON LATEST MRTS LINE

TEXT.P: Inspectors on Friday completed their examination of the Hsinchung Line on Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system and will report their findings to the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC).

Inspections took place beginning on Tuesday in five sectors -- administration, construction, machinery and electronics, train station and transportation management, an inspection committee member said.
Committee members will make their recommendations for improvements on the line to the Taipei city government in a meeting with MOTC officials.

Both the Mucha and Tamsui Lines started up less than three days after the Taipei city government completed required improvements, officials noted. However, before the Hsinchung Line can start operating, it must undergo a second MOTC inspection after the Taipei city government's MRTS and Taipei Rapid Transit Company (TRTC) implement proposed improvements, they added.

Based on previous inspections, the Hsinchung Line is scheduled to be up and running by the end of December. However, if a second inspection is made, the opening of the line may be delayed, officials said.
Both the MRTS and TRTC expressed confidence that improvements will be completed in the shortest amount of time and the Hsinchung Line will pass all its safety inspections.

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU DENIES RUMORS OVER NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER POST
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Thursday denied that he would seek the post of National Assembly speaker and said he would continue to work for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Incumbent National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien has been informally assigned as Control Yuan president, leaving the influential post of speaker open to fierce competition, news media reported. Hu, currently accompanying Vice President Lien Chan on his four-nation Central American tour, was named as one of the top contenders.

The foreign minister, who is also a member of the National Assembly, said he was surprised by the reports, noting that throughout the course of his political career he has never considered the post of National Assembly speaker.

However, Hu stated that members of the National Assembly should work harder to improve its efficiency and public image. He added that members of the assembly should not be considered "insignificant" and it is unfair that assembly deputies are seen as "monsters."
Hu said the rumors were unfounded, Hu reaffirmed to the public that he will remain at MOFA and dedicate himself to the job.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved up on the ninth consecutive trading on Friday, contributed by the US dollar weakness.
The local currency rose NT$0.011 against the greenback, finishing at 32.284, the nine-month high.
The currency value has climbed by NT$0.145 in the past nine days.
The NT dollar opened at 32.3 Friday, and was traded between 32.27 and 32.315.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$321.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AID TO HURRICANE-HIT COUNTRIES PRAISED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China aid assistance to the hurricane-ravaged Central American nations received high praise on Thursday from the United States and other American countries during an international meeting in Washington.

The two-day Consultative Group Meeting for the Reconstruction and Transformation of Central America, sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), began on Thursday in an attempt to integrate global efforts to help the recovery of countries devastated by Hurricane Mitch in October.

Delegates from 27 countries and areas, along with representatives from 20-odd international organizations including the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) attended the meeting, at which ROC representatives presented Taiwan's aid and relief packages as well as follow-up plans.

In an address to the meeting, Cesar Gaviria, secretary-general of the Organization of American States (OAS), highlighted Taiwan's contribution, saying the construction of 1,000 houses with resources provided by the ROC government, is already underway.

US Undersecretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs Stuart E. Eizenstate, who attend the meeting on behalf of US President Bill Clinton, told reporters outside the meeting that meeting participants "appreciated the fact that so many countries, including Taiwan, have contributed to this effort."
"Taiwan, Israel, European countries and Japan all made major contributions and they are very much appreciated," Eizenstate said.
Mitch left over 10,000 people dead, several hundred thousands homeless, and inflicted damages and losses exceeding billions of US dollars.
The United States, as well as Taiwan, were among the first countries to offer aid to the region soon after a call for assistance was made.

During the Washington meeting, Honduran President Carlow Flores Facusse showed a documentary featuring devastated areas and victims of the region's largest natural disaster in this century. Honduras was hardest hit by the hurricane.
Flores made special mention and expressed his deep-felt gratitude for Taiwan's donations and relief efforts in an interview with reporters after the meeting.

The acknowledgment means that Taiwan aid has been recognized and has won respect, said ROC International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) Secretary-General Luo Ping-chang, who took part in the meeting on behalf of the ROC government.

Luo said ROC Vice President Lien Chan is now in Guatemala on the last leg of four-nation visit to Central America. Prior to Guatemala, Lien visited Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador. He pledged on behalf of the ROC people and government a donation of US$10 million to Nicaragua, US$12 million to Honduras, and US$2 million to El Salvador, Luo said.

He noted that the ICDF will grant Nicaragua low-interest loans over 25 years worth US$6 million to rebuild homes, while providing the same loans to Honduras, and US$4 million in loans to El Salvador. The use of the loans will be monitored by the OAS, Luo said.
He added that ICDF Chairman Jason Hu, who also serves as ROC foreign minister, will hold a board meeting next month in Taipei to certify the loans and have them released as a priority.

Asked if the ROC was invited to the donors summit meeting under the name of "Taipei, China," instead if its official name of the Republic of China, Luo stressed the fact that he represented the ROC at the meeting regardless of what the country is called.
The most important issue is participating in the meeting and offer our assistance to our Central American allies, Luo said.

He stressed, "We are always the Republic of China. No matter what it is called by the rest of the world." Luo was accompanied to the meeting by Cheng Po-jeou, the ROC's deputy representative in the United States.

Meeting sponsor IDB Spokesman Peter Bate earlier said it was a compromise that Taiwan attended the donors meeting under the name of "Taipei, China" as Taiwan is not full member in the World Bank, the IMF, or the United Nations, which maintain close links with the IDB.

DOC.HEADLINE: 0.53 BABY BORN PER MINUTE IN TAIWAN: 1998 WORLD POPULATION DATA

TEXT.P: There are 4.3 babies born every second in the world and 0.53 babies delivered in Taiwan every minute, according to 1998 data released by US Population Reference Bureau Inc.

The statistics indicated that Taiwan's infant mortality rate has dropped to 6.4 deaths for every 1,000 births which is almost on par with that in North America and Europe. Meanwhile, Taiwan's average life expectancy is nine years over the world's average and ranks among the world's top 30.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development said Taiwan's crude birth rate for 1998 declined. They attributed the drop to the Chinese superstition that babies born in the year of the tiger on the lunar calendar, which falls on 1998, leads to ill fortune.

According to the data, the 1998 world population totaled 5.92 billion, an increase of 1.4 percent. The world's most populated countries are mainland China with 1.24 billion, India with 980 million and the United States with 270 million.
Taiwan's 21.87 million population places it as the 45th most populated among 201 countries worldwide.
A total of 136 million babies were born in 1998 with a crude birth rate of 2.3 percent while the world infant mortality rate stood at 5.8 percent.
The average fertility rate was 2.9 babies for every woman, a reduction from 3 babies recorded last year.

Taiwan's fertility rate was 1.5 babies, far below the world level of 2.1, figures showed. Fertility rates in Austria, Germany, Greece, Italy, Spain, Japan and Hong Kong were even lower than that of Taiwan.
Average life expectancy at birth was 66 years, or 64 years for men and 68 years for women. Life expectancy for Taiwan people was 75 years. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN GOVERNOR CHAO SHOU-PO TO TAKE OFFICE ON DEC. 21
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, central Taiwan, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Taiwan Governor Chao Shou-po is scheduled to take his office on Dec. 21 in a ceremony to be held at the archives of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
Chao will succeed incumbent Governor James Soong, formally ushering in the adjustment of the Taiwan Provincial Government's organization and functions.
Soong was the first -- and will be the last -- governor to be directly elected.

After taking office, Chao will lead a provincial government that will no longer enjoy the right of autonomy, as the result of revisions to the Republic of China Constitution, under which the governor will be appointed rather than elected.

Song's term expires Dec. 20. He began on Oct. 5 a farewell tour of 21 counties and cities under the jurisdiction of the Taiwan Provincial Government. He will complete the tour after visiting Nantou County on Dec. 14.

The Taiwan Provincial Government will hold a farewell party on Dec. 19, when Soong and provincial government employees will gather to say goodbye to one another. At the end of the party, provincial government employees will stand in a queue to see Soong off.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN, SOONG COULD STILL BE RUNNING MATES IN 2000 PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Although he has had a falling out with Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui, outgoing Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong could still end up the running mate of incumbent Vice President Lien Chan in the 2000 presidential election, said a Kuomintang heavyweight on Friday.

On a local radio program, Senior Adviser to the President and former KMT Secretary-General Wu Poh-hsiung said that a Lien-Soong ticket would be the best the KMT could present in the next presidential election.

Admitting that there is a "spat" between Soong and Lee, Wu brushed aside questions on its depth. Instead he held out hope that the dispute would not scuttle Soong's chances of appearing on the ticket, since the party's victory in the election would outweigh any personal considerations, he said.

Soong was elected Taiwan provincial governor, with Lee's strong endorsement, four years ago in Taiwan's first popular election for the post. Back then it was thought he might be the party's standard bearer in the 2000 presidential election, but he has been at odds with Lee since the end of 1997 over Lee's decision to downsize the provincial government and eliminate gubernatorial elections.
His excellent job performance as provincial governor and his willingness to challenge Lee won him approval around the island, especially among those opposed to the provincial government's downsizing.
The falling out, however, is thought to have hurt his chance of being selected as Lien's running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOA STRESSES CONFIDENCE IN TAIWAN ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite the decision to sell its retail business in Taiwan, Bank of America (BOA) still has strong confidence in the Taiwan economy, a spokesman for the second-largest bank in America said on Thursday.

The decision forms part of BOA's global restructuring program, the spokesman said, assuring that its customers, 580 employees and 230,000 credit card account holders in Taiwan will be fully protected after another bank buys BOA's retail business division.

So far, all BOA's operations in Taiwan have remained normal without any change, the spokesman added. He was reluctant, however, to comment on press reports that Taipei-based Bank SinoPac is interested in buying the BOA business.

BOA announced on Wednesday that it will end its retail banking and credit card services in Taiwan, India and Singapore. According to Taiwan media reports, the Republic of China Ministry of Finance was skeptical that BOA decided to pull out of Taiwan because of posting operating losses in the domestic market.
One quarter of BOA's 4,500 workers in Asia, including 143 in Singapore, will be laid off as a result of its restructuring efforts in the continent.

The spokesman told CNA that BOA was profitable in Taiwan since it entered Taiwan's consumer market in 1996. The bank decided to wrap up its consumer financial services in Taiwan due to its belief that BOA will fall short of becoming a dominant player in the Taiwan market in the long term.

A BOA press release made public on Wednesday said that the bank decided to shift its operations to other, more profitable, markets because BOA will fail to become a major player in the Taiwan retail financial services market.

Ken Lewis, head of BOA's consumer and commercial banking division, said BOA still gives positive marks to the Taiwan economy and that the bank is determined to further strengthen its bond and foreign exchange services to corporations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN YI-HSIUNG TO STAY AS DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung on Friday agreed to stay at his post, fending off a leadership crisis within the major opposition party.

Lin, who was elected to the DPP chairmanship in May, tendered his resignation at a weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee (CSC) Wednesday in what he called a move to take responsibility for the party's setback in Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections last weekend.

Lin's attempt to quit immediately caused trouble for the DPP, as it found party heavyweights, such as incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian who failed in his re-election bid, were unwilling to assume the chairmanship.
Lin was originally very firm in his decision to leave, even after the CSC, the party's policy-making body, passed a resolution urging him to stay.
But eventually, Chen and all the other CSC members persuaded Lin to continue serving his term to maintain party stability.
Although Lin will stay, a reshuffle of the DPP's other top posts seems inevitable, according to Chen and CSC members, who met with Lin for one and a half hours earlier in the day.
Party Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen will quit Saturday. He is likely to be succeeded by Taipei Mass Rapid Transit Co. Chairman and former Ilan County Magistrate You Hsi-kun.

Moreover, several department heads within DPP headquarters, including those in charge of women, youth and organization affairs, will be asked to step down for what some CSC members said was their poor performance in the elections.
The DPP under Lin's leadership will also establish a task force to reform party affairs and to map out a strategy for the party's participation in Taiwan's next presidential election in 2000.
In the just-concluded elections, the DPP lost the mayorship of Taipei to the ruling Kuomintang but successfully captured the mayorship of Kaohsiung, the second-largest city in Taiwan.

But in legislative races, the DPP won 29.66 percent of the votes cast, or 70 out of 225 seats in the next legislature. The results compare to 33.2 percent of the vote, or 54 out of a total of 164 seats in the current legislature, which was elected four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CALLS FOR WRAPPING UP OF PARLIAMENTARY REFORMS BY MID-1999

TEXT.P: Parliamentary reform should be finished no later than the middle of 1999, said President Lee Teng-hui on Friday.

Just as there are more than 10,000 cases pending trial in the courts, there are 1,193 bills held up by the Legislative Yuan, a fact that underscores the need to make adjustments to the Republic of China Constitution to beef up the efficiency of the parliament, said Lee at a regular meeting with members of the National Assembly.

Although five measures aimed at expediting the legislature's processes are now under consideration at the Legislative Yuan, structural reform is necessary to reshape the country's legislature and to solve the problems at their roots, said Lee.

He urged the National Assembly, which was mandated to revise the ROC Constitution, to study seriously a proposal submitted by a panel of its own members and to ensure its proposals represent a consensus of opinion among various political factions so that the changes can be wrapped up by mid-1999.
Friday was the last day of a four-day meeting between Lee and National Assembly members.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA CALLS FOR INNOVATIVE MEASURES TO SOLVE REGIONAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada called on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) on Friday to look beyond the current financial crisis and adopt innovative approaches to deal with emerging regional problems.

A few days before his departure to attend the sixth formal meeting of ASEAN heads of state, the president said the regional grouping "must be resolute in implementing economic, social and political measures that will project the association as a body with able mechanisms to respond to pressing issues in the region."
According to the chief executive, ASEAN should also acknowledge the importance of popular participation in governance and in regional efforts toward achieving the goals of the ASEAN vision 2020.
The president will leave Monday for Hanoi to attend the ASEAN summit, scheduled for Dec. 15 to 16.
After the summit, the president will make a state visit to Vietnam from Dec. 17 to 18. He will then proceed to Bangkok for a three-day state visit.
Estrada has made it a point to make state visits, especially to ASEAN member states.
Aside from President Estrada, those expected to attend the Hanoi summit are the leaders of Brunei Darussalam, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Laos and Myanmar.
Dialogue partners of ASEAN, which include the United States, Canada, mainland China, Japan, Australia and the Republic of Korea, are also expected to send representatives to the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA EXPECTED TO RAISE ISSUE OF SPRATLYS AT ASEAN MEETING

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada is expected to take advantage of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) leaders' forum that opens in Hanoi next week to drum up support for peaceful options to ease the renewed tension among the Philippines, mainland China and other countries that claim portions of the Spratly Island chain.

This comes even as Malacanang admitted that visiting US Rep. Dana Rorabacher asked the US government to exert economic and political pressure on Beijing. He said the comment "carries weight," but refused to comment further.

Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican on Friday said the Department of Foreign Affairs is likely to recommend that the president raise the Spratly issue so that ASEAN leaders can discuss among themselves what options to consider.
"It may be an appropriate forum for discussion of this and to look for some kind of peaceful ways to solve it," Barican said.
An exchange of views on international and regional political and economic developments is on the agenda for the meeting.

At least five of the six countries that claim all or part of the Spratlys will attend the ASEAN summit: mainland China, Malaysia, Brunei and Vietnam. Taiwan also claims sovereignty over the island chains in the South China Sea.

Earlier, the Philippines and mainland China agreed to convene an expert group that would work out confidence-building measures to ease the tension between the two countries over their territorial conflict.

Estrada broached the matter with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin when they had a bilateral meeting in Malaysia last month, but said he would bring it up again when he meets with Jiang at the ASEAN meeting.
Barican, meanwhile, said the US representative's comments should not be dismissed.

Rorabacher, who flew over the Spratlys together with several Philippine military officials, said the military structures built by Beijing are a "bullying" tactic, adding that they should be immediately dismantled.
"The Philippines refrains from commenting on the statements of US officials regarding their relations with another country," Barrican noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 2ND MOST VIGOROUS ECONOMY IN ASIA: PERC

TEXT.P: Over the shadow of Asia's financial crisis, the Taiwan economy has been rated the second most rigorous in Asia, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.

The MOEA, citing an October report by the Hong-Kong based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC), said Taiwan lags behind only mainland China, but is ahead of Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong, in that category.

The PERC gauges its economic vigor index based on each country's real growth potential in gross domestic product, inflation rate, risk in foreign exchange rates, growth potential in export and import, risk in foreign debts and risk in its current account.

In the category of investment risk, Taiwan was ranked fourth lowest among Asian countries, after Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan, but one notch ahead of mainland China. Malaysia was given the sixth spot, followed by the Philippines, South Korea, Thailand, India, Vietnam and Indonesia.
In the category of social and political systems, Taiwan was ranked third after Singapore and Japan, an advance of three notches from last year.

Unlike Japan's and South Korea's, Taiwan's economy is backed mainly by small- and medium-sized businesses, the PERC report said. The island has showed a high degree of economic clout and proved its sound structure amid Asia's financial turmoil, which has plagued most of the region's countries since the second half of last year.
The report, however, pointed out that politics sometimes interfere too much in the process of economic policy-making in Taiwan, singling out the case of the German-based Bayer Group.

The world-class biochemical giant was forced to withdraw an investment plan worth of billions of dollars in Taiwan last year as a result of a threat from the central Taichung County government to hold a public referendum to decide the fate of the project.

Taiwan's investment environment is freer than South Korea's, and the level of Taiwan's workforce is quite high, according to the report. Labor disputes do not occur frequently in Taiwan, while the strength of local labor unions are not so strong as in other countries.

For many Taiwan businesses, Taiwan's relations with mainland China play a critical role in their operations, but properly handling cross-strait ties will help Taiwan firms become more stable, the PERC commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEATS MAINLAND CHINA TO WIN GOLD IN TENNIS IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: After a 1-1 draw in the team division of women's tennis, Chinese Taipei fought down to the wire to win the event and the gold medal on Friday at the Asian Games.
Taipei's Lee Hui-chih defeated her mainland Chinese rival, Yi Ching-chien, in straight sets of 6-3, 6-4 in the first of two singles matches of the event, giving Taiwan a 1-0 lead.
But mainland Chinese player Lee Fang avenged the loss by beating Taiwan's Wang Shi-ting immediately in the second match 6-2, 6-1, which resulted in a 1-1 draw.
This set the stage for a showdown in the remaining doubles match, which pit Lee Hui-chih and Wang Shi-ting against Yi Ching-chien and Lee Fang.
The mainland players won the first set only to see Taiwan tie the score with a win in the second set.
In a nervous tie-breaking set, each side led alternately during the first four games. Taipei then won two games before losing one to Beijing.
In the ninth game, Taipei sealed mainland China's fate by ending its hopes of rallying from behind and winning the match.
Taiwan also brought home a bronze on Friday, Wu Mei-yi won a bronze in the 69-kg division of the women's weightlifting competition with a total lift of 225 kilograms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA YING-JEOU VOTED MAN OF 1998 BY HONG KONG NEWS WEEKLY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Newly elected Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has been voted the man of 1998 by a Hong Kong-based news weekly.

The Chinese-language Yazhou Zhoukan, in an article to be published Saturday, made the decision because of Ma's image of integrity and his charisma, which helped him defeat the also-popular incumbent mayor, Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Ostensibly, Ma's victory is his personal success. But it has helped check the momentum of the Taiwan independence movement, which is closely identified with the DPP's platform, and expressed the majority's sense of moderation. That should be helpful to peace on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the article said.

The article noted that Chen has suffered his first setback in a successful political career, saying the defeat is a blow to his attempt to ride into the 2000 presidential elections on the crest of a successful re-election bid as Taipei mayor.

The article said that the victory of Ma has drawn the attention of the media worldwide because the race was highly symbolic. The news media at home and abroad has interpreted the fierce contest as a warm-up to the presidential election in 2000.

Chen's winning the race would have been taken to mean that the middle-of-the-road are in favor of Taiwan independence. This would give the movement a major boost, and the independence wave would be unstoppable.
The victory of Ma will not only affect the fate of Taiwan, but will affect cross-strait relations, the article said.
The article said that Ma's victory will also result in delicate changes to Taiwan's political ecology and that Vice President Lien Chan should also jump on the wagon of democracy soon.

The article said that Ma, who earlier had said repeatedly that he would not run because he failed to see support from the KMT's top brass, announced his bid only in late May after responding to calls from the grassroots.
This kind of strong appeal from the grassroots has broken a long-standing KMT decision-making process in which decisions were traditionally made by only a few members.
The article also noted that Ma suggested after the election that the KMT should consider using popular elections to choose a party chairman.

The victory of Ma comes at a critical time, as the KMT begins to engage in reforms. His strong support from the grassroots, and the victories by most KMT Taiwan Provincial Assembly deputies in their bids for seats in the expanded legislature, has highlighted the democratic progress of the decision-making processes of the old grand party, the article said, This is the gist of Ma's victory, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW HERALDS MOVIE MAKERS AS ENGINEERS WHO MAKE DREAMS COME TRUE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday described people in show business around the world as "engineers who make dreams come true."
Premier Siew made the remark at a luncheon he hosted at the Grand Hotel to entertain representatives attending the 43rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival and the 35th Golden Horse Film Festival.
The award ceremonies of the two festivals are scheduled to be held simultaneously on Saturday night.
Siew said he was glad that on the eve of the award ceremonies of the two festivals people in show business -- both domestically and internationally -- could get together.

Siew said that the fascination of movies attracts people the world over. He quoted a movie maker as saying that to shoot a movie is a hard work; however, the only goal of movie makers is to make dreams come true.
He, therefore, commended world movie makers as engineers who not only make their dreams come true but also make the dreams of movie fans worldwide come true.

Siew also said that although the Asia-Pacific region has suffered from financial turmoil since the end of last year, which has resulted in fewer movies being produced, there are still a lot of excellent movies being shot by the world's movie makers.

Siew paid tribute to movie makers who have long dedicated themselves to the movies and hoped that through the two film festivals people can understand the development of the Asia-Pacific region's movie industry at the turn of the 20th century. He said he also hoped that through cooperation and exchanges of views, the Asia-Pacific region's movie industry could have a bright future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S WINE EXPORTS SURGE DUE TO CURRENCY DEPRECIATION

TEXT.P: The depreciation of the Australian dollar has helped boost the country's wine exports worldwide, but sales to its four major markets are showing signs of slowing, according to the Winemakers' Federation of Australia (WFA).
WFA Chief Executive Ian Sutton said wine exports from December 1997 to November 1998 registered a 26 percent surge to A$860 million (US$540 million) compared to the previous year.
He attributed the surge to the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which has dropped about 18 percent against the US dollar over the past year.
Sutton said the depreciation resulted in more competitive prices for Australian wines in world markets such as Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong.
Despite rising exports, wine sales to Australia's four major markets -- the UK, United States, New Zealand and Canada -- were rising modestly because of the global economic downturn.
Sutton said an advantage of the currency depreciation was that Japanese importers had switched their purchases to Australian wines from French ones as they sought to cut costs due to the recession.
Australian winemakers believed their exports would reach A$1 billion (US$625 million) by 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 12, or Oct. 24 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: German aeronautical engineer Hugo Junkers conducts a test flight of the world's first whole-metal plane, which he made.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1925: Reza Khan, a cavalry officer, becomes shah of Iran and establishes the Pahlavi dynasty.
1932: The Republic of China resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Sian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a US warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking, and issues statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nasha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steams Navigation Co. begins plying between Taiwan and the United States's East Coast, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1984: An extradition treaty between the Republic of China and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty the ROC signed.
1989: Petar Mladinov, first secretary of Bulgaria's Communist Party, announces free elections are to be held in Bulgaria, ending the party's monopoly on power.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian legislature for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: Chi Ta-chuan, a mainland Chinese, hijacks a Xiamen Airlines plane to Taiwan.
1994: The Lien Chan cabinet is re-organized and new cabinet members are sworn in on Dec. 15.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution at its meeting to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
Confucius: "A wise and good man, in matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be dilegent in business and careful in speech. He should seek for the company of men of virtue and learning, in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR-ELECT SHOULD VISIT HONG KONG: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By M. N. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou should visit Hong Kong to improve bilateral communication and understanding, ROC representative to Hong Kong Cheng An-kuo said on Saturday.
Cheng, who made the comments in an interview on a local radio station, said the Kuomintang's victory in Taiwan's Dec. 5 elections will help the island maintain political stability in the years ahead.

Ma, the KMT candidate in the Taipei mayoral race, defeated incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party by a wider-than-expected margin while the KMT grabbed 55 percent of the 225-seat legislature in the islandwide legislative elections, 53 seats more than the DPP garnered.

Cheng said the people of Hong Kong have an affinity for Ma as he was born in the former British colony. Cheng added that Ma has already voiced an interest in visiting Hong Kong since his election victory a week ago. The suggested visit has subsequently aroused a high degree of interest among the Hong Kong people.

According to Cheng, many Hong Kong residents do not understand why Ma was denied entry last year when the former British colony was to return to Beijing rule. Citing the results of a recent public opinion survey conducted by the Hong Kong University on the issue, Cheng said 78 percent of respondents thought the government should have allowed Ma to visit Hong Kong, while only 5 percent voiced opposition to such a visit.

Taiwan and Hong Kong should further boost bilateral exchanges as Taiwan has a lot to learn from Hong Kong's administration in urban development, public construction, finance, housing and traffic policies, harbor facilities, and its handling of garbage. Meanwhile, Taiwan is a good example for political reforms, as well as industrial, educational and high-tech policy development, Cheng noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON ISLANDS' MINISTERS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Solomon Islands Interior and Culture Minister Leslie Boset and Health Minister Dickson Warakohia are scheduled to visit the Republic of China from Dec. 14-18, the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said.
Both Boset and Warakohia are expected to call on MOFA, the Ministry of the Interior, the Executive Yuan's Council for Cultural Affairs, the Central Election Commission, and the Department of Health.
Boset, 56, was elected as a member of Solomon Islands' parliament in August 1997 and was appointed Minister of Interior and Culture later, a MOFA official said.
Warakohia, 44, was previously an agricultural and fishery official. He was elected as a member of parliament in August 1997 and was appointed as the country's health minister.

Solomon Islands is one of the ROC's four allies in the South Pacific, and has maintained close and cordial ties with the ROC, MOFA noted. It has supported the ROC in several international organizations such as the United Nations and South Pacific Forum.
Taiwan experts in agricultural development are working in the South Pacific islands to assist with local agricultural projects, efforts which have received attention from the Solomon government.

Several top-level Solomon officials have visited Taiwan in recent years. The prime minister headed a delegation to Taiwan in October 1997, while its agricultural and fishery minister as well as minister of state visited Taiwan in 1998.

ROC Premier Vincent Siew recently visited Solomon Islands as a special envoy of the Republic of China to attend celebrations marking the island state's 20th anniversary of independence and the first Melanesia Art and Cultural event.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND INTERNET NEWS SERVICE SIGNS CONTRACT WITH GTE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities in charge of an Internet news service have signed their first contract with a US Internet provider, GTE Corp. of Stamford, Connecticut, the Journal of Commerce reported on Friday.

The agreement with the China Internet Information Center (CIIC), an arm of the governing State Council's Information Office, "will allow CIIC to more easily provide information about China to Web users in North America and Europe using GTE's network," the Journal said.
One-quarter of the two million visitors to the CIIC Web site, which opened in January 1997, are in the United States, it added.

A survey by International Data Corp. (IDC) showed the Asia-Pacific region, excluding Japan, will have 35.3 million Internet users by 2002 up slightly from the current 12 million users. Japan is expected to increase from 7.35 million to 19.4 million over the same period.

IDC expects Australia to have 5.76 million users in 2002, 9.4 million in China, 3.3 million in Taiwan, and 2.43 million in Hong Kong. It also expects 1.37 million users in Singapore, 1.34 million in Malaysia and 900,000 in the Philippines.
The United States already has 56 million Internet users, and will have over 137 million in 2002, IDC said. Western Europe is forecast to have about 44.3 million by 2002, up from 28.9 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDOCH'S MAINLAND FREEZE THAWS IN MEETING WITH JIANG

TEXT.P: Australian-born media magnate Rupert Murdoch met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Thursday after a five-year grudge sparked by Murdoch's comments on satellite technology, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

In 1993, Murdoch reportedly told a News Corp. shareholders' meeting in Adelaide that satellite television was "an unambiguous threat to totalitarian regimes everywhere." His remarks made him unwelcome in Beijing and News Corp. was unable to conduct any business on the mainland.
After years of trying to open closed doors against him and his media empire, Murdoch's meeting with Jiang appears to have signaled a tacit approval of such efforts.

The meeting won coverage from the People's Daily, the official mouthpiece of the mainland. The report praised Murdoch for his objectivity and welcomed his efforts to expand cooperation with the mainland media.

To get back in the mainland's good graces, Murdoch first dropped the BBC from his Star TV service in North Asia in 1994 after the British broadcaster produced programs critical of the mainland. He also refused to publish a book written by former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten, who infuriated Beijing by introducing democratic reforms in the final years of colonialism.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S CRACKDOWN ON DISSIDENTS CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese prosecutors are preparing formal criminal charges against Xu Wenli, a key dissident who has been trying to establish an opposition party, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.
The move has forced Australia to lodge a formal protest over Xu's arrest, the paper said.

Hong Kong representative for Human Rights in China, Sophia Woodman was quoted as saying that the Chinese authorities had moved to crush the opposition party as soon as Beijing had satisfied its diplomatic goal of silencing criticism from Western governments over its human rights abuses.

The mainland's new assault on Chinese dissidents, which began last week, is an embarrassment to Western governments who had abandoned public criticism of China's human rights violations in favor of private, low-key dialogue with Beijing, the Herald reported.
The Howard administration this week was forced to condemn the crackdown and send officials from Australia's Embassy in Beijing to the Chinese foreign ministry to lodge an official protest.

Chinese authorities have rejected foreign protests from Australia and the United States as security forces intensify their sweep against the leaders of the new opposition party and their supporters, the Herald said.

Xu, 55, has already served 12 years in jail for his role in the 1979 Democracy Wall movement. He will likely face charges of incitement to overthrow the state government, an offense which carries a life sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFECTS OF INCREASED PUBLIC SPENDING TO SURFACE NEXT YEAR: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: The effects of government efforts to expand domestic demand and increase public spending will be apparent in the first half of next year, the Council for Economic Planning and Development chairman said on Saturday.

P. K. Chiang noted that although the regional financial crisis has affected Taiwan's economic growth, economic activities have returned to normal thanks to government efforts to expand domestic demand and the adoption of several measures to stabilize the economy.
He predicted that economic growth this year could reach 5.1 percent and 5.5 percent next year.
However, the government must continue to push for increased public construction to boost domestic demand and thus ensure stable economic growth of the nation, Chiang said.

According to current plans, the government will increase public construction spending by NT$63.8 billion (US$1.93 billion) next year which is expected to create 60,000 jobs and stimulate such local sectors as the cement and steel industries, and generate tax revenues estimated at NT$5 billion (US$1.5 billion), the chairman noted.
He added that the government is mapping out a new four-year project which will start by 2001.

Acknowledging a downturn in Taiwan's economy, Chiang said the island's trade surplus this year will likely be cut to US$6 billion and export declines will cause a negative effect on economic growth. But compared with South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and other Asian countries, Taiwan has no foreign debt and has a sound economic structure, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK WOES MAY TARNISH TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC LUSTER: REPORT

TEXT.P: Despite outperforming most of its neighbors amid the Asian financial crisis, recent signs may indicate growing problems for Taiwan's economy, the Los Angeles Times reported on Friday.

The high profile struggles of several large Taiwan business groups, the failure of two finance companies and a run on the regional Taichung Commercial Bank have all contributed to speculation that Taiwan has contracted the Asian disease.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu has emphatically said, "The situation is not directly related to the Asian financial crisis."

Other banking and financial experts agree, at least for the short term, but they warn that unless the island's banking system is consolidated and restructured, Taiwan could face serious economic problems by the middle of next year, the Times reported.

Unlike most of the other Asian trouble spots, Taiwan does not have a foreign exchange problem. It enjoys one of the world's biggest foreign reserves, at US$88 billion. It has almost no foreign debt due at least in part to its political isolation. Despite a 9 percent decline in exports, it still enjoys a healthy trade surplus, and consumer prices have remained remarkably stable.

However, some experts contend that Taiwan does have a crisis in its banking system, marked by a dangerous proliferation of nonperforming loans. Too many of Taiwan's new private commercial banks, brought into the system under banking liberalization policies in the early 1990s, are controlled by business groups that have dipped too far into bank assets.

The government has moved quickly and massively to stop the bleeding in its banking and financial sector. Early last month, the government issued a rescue plan calling for financial institutions to extend short-term loan deadlines by six months to give struggling businesses some breathing room. It also created a US$8.7 billion emergency stabilization fund to be injected into the economy or stock market where needed, the Times reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROMISES NEARLY US$50 MILLION IN AID TO CENTRAL AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Loh Ping-chang, secretary-general of the Taipei-based International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), said on Friday that the ROC government will provide a total of US$49.8 million in aid to hurricane victims in Central America.

Loh made the remarks in the closing ceremony of a two-day Consultative Group meeting for the Reconstruction and Transformation of Central America at the headquarters of the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) in Washington.

"The people and government of the Republic of China immediately joined the relief efforts for Central America. Cash donations of US$2.8 million was sent within days of the disaster. Material supplies, including medicine, food and clothing from our private sector people were air-freighted within one week. The supplies are still being shipped as an ongoing operation.

"We have begun our efforts for the reconstruction phase of the affected countries. President Lee Teng-hui has asked Vice President Lien Chan to visit Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala this week to finalize arrangements for grants and concessional financing for the reconstruction projects in these countries.

"As a result of Vice President Lien's discussions with presidents in Central America, agreements have been reached that a total amount of US$28 million in grants and US$20 million in long-term concessional credit will be applied to the construction of houses, medical facilities, roads, bridges, and to the rehabilitation of agricultural production. Together with the donations and supplies provided earlier, a total of US$49.8 million are being provided by the people and government of the Republic of China to Central America," Loh said in his three-minute speech.

The ICDF secretary-general also noted that the ROC government will closely cooperate with multilateral and bilateral donors. For instance, the governments of Nicaragua and Honduras have agreed that the Organization of American States be responsible for implementation of the housing projects financed by the ROC.
He also expressed the ROC government's hope of being able to work with World Health Organization and Pan-American Health Organization in carrying out health and medical projects.
IDB President Enrique V. Iglesias praised Taiwan's assistance to the hurricane-hit victims in Central American countries in a news conference following the closing ceremony.

He went on to say that after the two-day meeting, the international community has promised to provide US$6.3 billion in aid to central American countries affected by the hurricane. The IDB will hold the next Consultative Group meeting in Stockholm in May 1999 to review the reconstruction and transformation of Central America over the next six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR TO SUSPEND KAOHSIUNG-LA FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corporation on Friday announced that it would suspend its Kaohsiung-LA flights beginning Jan. 8, due to an internal business adjustment.

A number of Asian airlines have been beleaguered with huge losses due to the regional financial crisis, an airline representative said, but due to EVA's strong financial background and business operations, it has managed to keep its losses for 1998 at a minimum.
EVA must conduct an overall evaluation of its operations and make the required internal adjustments to increase profits, EVA said.
The Kaohsiung-LA thrice weekly flights will be suspended due to profit concern, leaving the Kaohsiung-Macau flights as the only EVA international flights leaving Taiwan's southern port city.

Meanwhile in a challenge to EVA's market share, Northwest Airlines announced that it will add a Kaohsiung-Osaka flight beginning on Jan. 17. Discounted tickets will be offered under specific conditions, the world's fourth largest airline said.
Passengers will be able to connect to destinations in the United States such as Los Angeles, Hawaii and Detroit from Osaka, a Northwest representative noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-USA SEMICONDUCTOR CONFERENCE FRUITFUL: CETRA
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Efforts by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) to promote Taiwan's semiconductor industry among US companies have proved fruitful, council representative said on Friday.

During the 1998 ROC-USA Semiconductor Industries' Strategic Cooperation Conference held in California's Silicon Valley from Dec. 9-10, 85 well-known US high-tech companies have expressed interest in cooperating with Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers. Such cooperative efforts will include the purchase and transfer of technology, CETRA noted.

Organizers expected about 200 representatives from 140 US companies attend the conference, but actual attendance reached almost 350. The high turnout indicated strong interest in US-Taiwan cooperation in the semiconductor industry, CETRA officials said.
More importantly, the firms represented in the conference included such high-profile companies as IBM, Intel, Hewlett Packard, Philips and GE.

According to CETRA opinion polls held during the conference, 164 out of 174 respondents indicated a willingness to attend a second conference in 1999. CETRA said similar conferences are expected to take place in Japan, Europe, and the United States in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN STAYS, ANNOUNCES NEW SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, said on Saturday he will remain in the post for the stability and long-term interests of the largest opposition party in Taiwan.
Lin, who earlier tendered his resignation to take responsibility for the DPP's setback in the three-in-one elections, made the remarks in a news conference.

He was accompanied by outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, National Assembly Deputy Chiu Yi-ying, and Liu Shih-fang, director of Bureau of Environmental Protection of Taipei City Government. Lin met with the prominent DPP members after disappearing from public eye three days ago.

Lin apologized over the uneasiness caused by his resignation. He said it was tradition for the chairman to resign after an election defeat, but he must stand up to his unshirkable responsibility to his party comrades and supporters.

The biggest challenges facing the DPP is the presidential elections in 2000, the chairman said, adding that he will establish a party development study team to map out a strategy to win the presidential election in 2000.
The team will hold its first meeting on Wednesday.
The nomination period for the DPP's candidate will be determined by the study team, he said, dismissing rumors that the nomination process will be delayed until next August.

Some DPP Central Standing Committee members have said that since the ruling Kuomintang will decide on its candidates for president and vice president in August, it is necessary for the DPP to make its selection process in August instead of March according to previous practice.

The DPP must begin preparing for the presidential elections at once, Lin said, adding that the party will contact cities and counties run by DPP members and reach out to the grassroots to unite the reform forces of society and address the needs of the public.
Lin also announced You Hsi-kun, chairman of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit Co. (MRT), as the DPP's new secretary-general. You will replace Chiou I-jen who resigned after the Dec. 5 election.
Lin described You, who will assume the new job on Jan. 1, as a trustworthy man who excels in coordinating operations.
Mayor Chen also lauded the former Ilan magistrate, saying that under You, the MRT has served 230,000 passengers so far.

Chen, who failed in his reelection bid for Taipei mayor, also said he was not anxious to seek a new post for the moment, and that he would be content in his work as a DPP Central Standing Committee member.

On whether he would run for president in 2000, Chen said he hopes there is not too much pressure for him to do so. He added that he needs time to review the past and determined why he failed and consider his future options.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA INCREASES MINIMUM INVESTMENT FOR IMMIGRANTS TO C$500,000

TEXT.P: Canada on Friday increased the minimum investment required of all investor immigrants to C$500,000 (US$325,000), regardless of which province receives the capital.
The Department of Citizenship and Immigration also increased the minimum net worth required of the investor to C$1 million -- to secure provinces and territories against possible loss.

The regulations governing the current investor program are repealed but will continue to apply to previously approved businesses and funds. The redesigned Immigrant Investor Program is expected to take effect on April 1, 1999.
In accordance with these new regulations, the federal government will act as an agent on behalf of the provinces and territories, who will determine where to invest the money.

The changes were designed to increase the benefits derived from the program, and to reduce the potential for abuse as well as the level of federal and provincial resources required to administer the program.
The new program will allow provinces to direct investor funds toward their own economic priorities.
The current program will be extended to March 31, 1999, to allow sufficient time for public comment following Friday's pre-publication of the new regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA TO SEEK ASEAN SUPPORT OVER SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: Manila is expected seek support of the Alliance of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) leaders for a joint declaration of concern over Beijing's naval intrusion into the Spratly Island's Mischief Reef, reports said on Saturday.
Philippine Senate Committee Chairman on Foreign Relations Blas Ople expressed support for President Joseph Estrada's efforts to keep the dispute over the islands an international matter.
ASEAN leaders cannot afford to ignore the dispute over the supposed oil-rich islands for the sake of stability in the region, Ople said.
"We cannot and should not keep this issue within bilateral channels, considering its grave international implications," he said.
Ople is part of the Philippine delegation that will travel to Hanoi for the ASEAN summit on Dec. 15. He heads the Senate delegation that includes Senators Francisco Tatad and Robert Jaworski.
The move is apparently aimed at keeping Beijing off-balance in its claim over the islands. Mainland China has insisted that Manila and Beijing discuss the dispute on a bilateral level.
On the other hand, senate leaders led by Ople have demanded that the Manila government bring the matter before the UN Security Council and other international bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REPRESENTATIVE CALLS FOR SANCTIONS AGAINST MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A US representative on Thursday urged all democratic nations to impose political and economic sanctions against mainland China over its intrusions in the Spratly Islands after an aerial inspection of the area.

"The presence of battle ships and structures constitute economic and political threats right now," US Representative Dana Rohrabacher said in reference to the continued Chinese fortification in the Spratly's Mischief Reef.
Rohrabacher said the Philippines and other democratic countries should take harsh measures to dismantle military structures and deter Chinese naval ships from the Spratlys.
He added that economic and political sanctions against the mainland are proper due to its firm stand on Mischief Reef.
Sources at the US Embassy in Manila said peaceful and diplomatic efforts must first be used to resolve the dispute in the South China Sea which is a vital international sea lane.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN MISSING AS TYPHOON FAITH HITS PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Seven people were reported missing, 231 families were evacuated and 16 million pesos worth of property was destroyed as Typhoon Faith battered Bicol and parts of the Visayas in the Philippines on Saturday.

Philippine President Joseph Estrada ordered Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense, who also chairs the National Disaster Coordinating Council, to be on a 24-hour watch over possible landslides, floods and other post-typhoon disasters.

The problems caused by the most recent typhoon resulted in fewer casualties and damage to property, infrastructure and agriculture than super typhoons that have hit the Philippines earlier this season, Mercado said.
The disaster council has so far relocated 1,396 persons or 231 families to eight evacuation centers in the typhoon-hit areas, he added.
The Philippine navy and air force have begun search and rescue operations for the seven reported missing, who are mostly fishermen caught at sea during the height of the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING TAIWAN GOVERNOR WOULD DEFEAT CHEN IN ELECTION: POLL

TEXT.P: According to the results of a recent opinion poll, Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong would defeat outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian in a presidential election.

If an election were held today between the Kuomintang's Soong and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Chen, Soong would receive 55.4 percent support compared to 23.7 percent for Chen, the poll indicated.

The survey, jointly conducted by Gallop (Taiwan) Organization Inc. and the National Open University, said Soong enjoys a high degree of popularity among the Taiwan population regardless of age, education level, ethnicity and area of residence.

If the KMT were to field President Lee Teng-hui in a race against Chen, Lee would receive 32.4 percent support, lower than Chen's 35.4 percent, according to the survey. If Vice President Lien Chan were to challenge Chen, the DPP stalwart would score a comfortable win by 43.8 percent against Lien's 25 percent.

The poll showed that Soong would be the sole challenger within the KMT capable of defeating Chen in the next presidential election. Chen may have a chance of winning the presidency if the KMT cannot field a "Lien-Soong" ticket, according to the survey results.

Soong will step down from his current post by the end of this year due to the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government. Chen was defeated by KMT contender Ma Ying-jeou in the Taipei mayoral race last week.

Although many of Chen's supporters have encouraged him to take part in the 2000 presidential race, the outgoing Taipei mayor has not yet made clear his intentions in this regard. However, Chen's post-election islandwide tour which will kick off in central Taiwan's Taichung on Saturday evening has been widely viewed as a move to gauge public response to his possible presidential bid.

Meanwhile, the survey also found that 60.3 percent of the public are satisfied or very satisfied with the performance of the current Cabinet led by Premier Vincent Siew. Siew's approval rate is higher than President Lee's 56.4 percent and Vice President Lien's 34 percent.
The poll was carried out from Dec. 7-9 after the Dec. 5 "three-in-one" elections. More than 1,500 Taiwan residents aged over 20 were surveyed, with an error margin of about 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA BIG WINNER AT ASIA-PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: An Indonesian film emerged as the big winner at the 48th Asia Pacific Film Festival which ended in Taipei on Saturday as it walked away with the awards for best actress and best film while a Malaysian film won for best actor.
The best director award went to Taiwan's Hou Hsiao-hsien while Japan swept the honors for best supporting actor, supporting actress and screenplay.
The winners are as follows:
Best Picture, Leaf on a Pillow (Indonesia).
Best Director: Ho Hsiao-hsien, Flowers of Shanghai
Best Actress: Christine Hakim, Leaf on a Pillow (Indonesia).
Best Actor: Khalid Salleh, Jogho (Malaysia).
Best Supporting Actress: Suaiko Fuji, Omocha The Geisha House (Japan).
Best Art Director: Hwang Wern-ying, Flowers of Shanghai (Taiwan).
Best Sound: Lee Suk-kyu, Beat (South Korea).
Best Music: Fan Tsung-pai and Pai Lang, Connection by Fate (Taiwan).
Best Editing: Nobuhiko Obayashi, Sada (Japan).
Best Screenplay; Euisin Chung, Begging for Love (Japan).
Best Short Film: Returning to Ngu Thug (Vietnam).
Best Animation: A Chinese Ghost Story-- The Animated Film (Hong Kong).
Special Jury Award: Cheng Ying-shu, Wen Yao-ting, Lin Jing-jie, Chan Ying-yu, Bad Girl Trilogy (Taiwan).
Grand Jury Award: Who is Running? (Thailand).
Grand Jury Award: Amy (Australia).
Also awarded during the ceremony were Taiwan's stop film prizes, the Golden Horse Awards, which recognized films made in Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Chinese-born actress-turned-director Joan Chen was the biggest Golden Horse winner as her first film Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl won in seven of the 11 categories it was nominated for including best picture, best director, best actor and actress, best adapted screenplay, best original music, and best original song.
Hong Kong-made City of Glass, which also earned 11 nominations, won for best original screenplay, best sound, best editing and best cinematography.
The Golden Horse winners are as follows:
Special Jury Award: Rene Liu, The Personals.
Grand Jury Award: Flowers of Shanghai.
Best Picture: Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Director: Joan Chen, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Actor: Lopsang, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Actress: Lu Lu, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Supporting Actor: Eric Tsang, Hold You Tight.
Best Supporting Actress: Qi Shu, Portland Street Blues.
Best Original Screenplay: Cheung Yuen-ting, Alex Law, City of Glass.
Best Adapted Screenplay: Joan Chen, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Cinematography: Ma Jingle, City of Glass.
Best Art Director: Hwarng Wern-ying, Tsao Chi-wei, Flowers of Shanghai.
Best Sound Effects: Kinson Tsang, City of Glass.
Best Visual Effects: Centro Digital Pictures Ltd., The Stormriders.
Best Editing: Maurice Lee, City of Glass.
Best Original Music: Johnny Chen, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Original Song: Johnny Chen, Xiu-Xiu The Sent Down Girl.
Best Action Direction: Jackie Chan Stuntman Team, Who Am I?
Best Documentary: A Secret Buried for 50 Years-- A Story of Taiwanese Comfort Women.
Best Animation: not awarded.
Lifetime Achievement Award: Tsou Tien-su.
In addition, festival audiences selected City of Glass as their choice for best film.
