DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 13, or Oct. 25 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: US President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first US president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty in Washington, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 defenseless Chinese.
1944: Japanese suicide plane crashes into the US cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crewmen.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her primitive and colorful paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber, Republic of China, announces the list of winners of the first "10 outstanding youth" awards.
1967: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last US moon mission, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, which became an independent country from a British crown colony in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1981: Communist martial law is imposed in Poland to crush the "Solidarity" movement.
1989: ANC leader Nelson Mandela meets with President F.W. de Klerk for the first time to discuss the prospects for negotiating an end to South Africa's racial conflict.
1991: An agreement to work toward the negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
Confucius: "If in governing you depend upon laws, and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment, and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN MINISTER TO PROMOTE TRADE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A high-profile official legislative mission form Outer Mongolia is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later this month to promote business and trade exchanges, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Sunday.

The Mongolian mission, to be headed by Mongolian Agriculture and Industry Minister Altankhuyag, will meet Republic of China officials from the MOEA and the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, as well as local business leaders, for a trade and investment promotion meeting on Dec. 21.

The visit of the Mongolian mission bears particular significance, as relations between Mongolia and Taiwan have been considered sensitive over the past years, MOEA officials noted. The officials attributed the sensitivity to the geographical and political characteristics of Mongolia, which is located between Russia and mainland China.

During the meeting, Altankhuyag will introduce the investment climate, relevant statutes and incentives to invest in Mongolia, while Da Ganbold, head of the Mongolian Parliament's Economics Committee, will speak on his country's economic policies and investment environment.

Former Mongolian Ambassador to the United Nations Erdenechuluun will broach the subject of Mongolia's political environment and Munkhbat, director-general of customs, will speak on the nation's investment tariffs and customs affairs.
Galbaatar, secretary-general of Mongolia's Academy of Sciences, will introduce Mongolian scientific and technological developments, as well as its high-tech industry.
According to MOEA officials, Mongolia has aggressively developed its economy and trade since the nation launched democratic reforms in 1990.

Taiwan businesses, particularly wool and textile manufacturers, are being urged to take the advantage of Mongolia's abundant wool supplies and other natural resources by relocating their production lines to Mongolia.
A relatively skilled yet inexpensive workforce in Mongolia is also something that should be attractive to Taiwan investors, MOEA officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By P.C. Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan arrived in Los Angeles on Saturday as he heads home after a four-nation Central American visit.

Lien will spend one night in the city and fly home on Sunday. He said during the flight to Los Angeles that he would like to show his appreciation to US authorities for providing the services for him to transit there en route to Taiwan.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who accompanied Lien to Central America, said in the Los Angeles airport that Lien does not plan to engage in public activities while in the United States.
Lien's Central American visit took him to Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala, four ROC allies who have suffered severe damage and loss of life at the hands of Hurricane Mitch.
During his one-week stay in the region, the ROC leader offered aid and relief packages on behalf of the ROC government to help the four counties recover.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE IN COMMERCIAL SHIPPING COULD BE MILITARY SERVICE ALTERNATIVE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is studying a proposal that would allow young men to serve aboard commercial maritime shipping vessels in lieu of compulsory military service.
If enacted, the proposal would likely ease manpower shortages in Taiwan's maritime transport industry.

The proposal was inspired by the introduction of other alternatives -- such as community service and research and development work in government-run scientific research institutions -- to mandatory military service, said officials with the MOTC's Navigation and Aviation Department.

An average of 500 people graduate each year from National Taiwan Ocean University and other marine technology colleges around the island, but less than one-tenth actually join Taiwan's maritime transport industry, they said.

Maritime regulations stipulate that all officers working aboard Republic of China ocean-going vessels must be ROC nationals. Many Taiwan shipping companies have been unable to recruit enough ROC nationals to serve as officers aboard their ships and, as a result, have been forced to have their vessels registered in foreign countries to get around the regulation.
To encourage more maritime college graduates to join the maritime transport industry, the MOTC officials devised the maritime service proposal.

As the proposal now stands, the graduates would be given the opportunity to serve aboard ROC vessels for four years instead of performing conventional military service, which usually lasts about two years.
Time spent aboard shipping vessels as interns would be counted as part of their four years of service, officials pointed out.
By the third year of service, maritime college graduates would receive an average monthly salary of about NT$70,000 (US$2,154).
Before the MOTC formally proposes the initiative, it will first consult local shipping companies and officials from the Ministry of the Interior on the feasibility of the idea, MOTC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND EU EXPECT TO UPGRADE BILATERAL RELATIONS: MOEA

TEXT.P: European Commission Vice Chairman Leon Brittan is expected to visit Taiwan next year for a Taiwan-European Union (EU) industrial round-table conference, said Wang Chih-kang, Minister of Economic Affairs, on Sunday.
The EU is considering whether to set up an office in Taiwan, which reveals the EU's interest in upgrading cooperation and relations with Taiwan, said Wang.

The EU has kept a distance from Taiwan because of pressure from mainland China. But, as Taiwan's economic development continues steadily and as its economy remains stable amid the region's financial turmoil, the EU has perceived the necessity of re-evaluating the bilateral relationship.

Taiwan has completed bilateral trade talks with the EU for its bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), and a formal agreement on the matter is to be signed in the near future, which will also strengthen the EU's ties with Taiwan.

Regarding the timetable for Taiwan's membership in the WTO, the EU has withdrawn its insistence that mainland China be admitted prior to Taiwan so that Taiwan will not be hampered by the mainland's sluggishness in opening its markets.

According to a news source, the European Commission is impatient with mainland China over its failure to open its markets widely enough to warrant WTO membership, while preventing others, such as Taiwan, from attaining membership in the body.

The EU has never openly expressed its willingness to establish an office in Taiwan, though Brittan said during a visit to Brussels by Wang last June that there is a high degree of interest in doing so.
Despite this, the proposal is still being evaluated, due to the sensitiveness of the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LIFELONG LEARNING TO MAINTAIN COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Sunday that the "lifelong learning" concept is the steppingstone for Taiwan to conquer new challenges to be encountered in the 21st century.
Only through lifelong learning can a society adapt to transitions and keep competitive, Siew added.
Siew made the remarks in a speech delivered at a conference at National Taiwan Normal University for educational and academic groups.

Taiwan has evolved into a country featuring economic prosperity and democracy, and what has contributed to this achievement is not its natural resources but appropriate educational policies. Maintaining Taiwan's competitiveness therefore lies in a series of promising educational policies, Siew noted.
He went on to say that the knowledge people receive becomes outdated within five to seven years from the time it is learned, which makes lifelong learning essential to avoid lagging behind.

Speaking of the universality of the lifelong learning concept, Siew cited the existence of programs in Japan, which promulgated in 1990 an act on lifelong learning; the United States, which in 1994 embraced the concept as one of six educational goals; and Singapore, which pledged to build itself into a "learning-type country."

Siew praised the Ministry of Education for having marked this year as the "year for lifelong learning." He also stressed that designing a series of suitable courses for people in all walks of life is a great task for all educators.
Education Minister Lin Ching-chiang and some 200 people in the educational sector were present at the conference, at which prizes for best teachers and best services were awarded as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAOHAN'S TAIWAN VISIT CONDUCIVE TO BETTER CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan next spring by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based intermediary Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will be conducive to better relations across the Taiwan Strait, a local expert on mainland Chinese affairs said Sunday.

Professor Pao Tsung-ho of National Taiwan University's department of political sciences said that if Wang, the top mainland Chinese negotiator with Taiwan, visits Taipei early next year as is widely expected, it would be tremendously beneficial to cross-strait relations, as Wang would probably exchange views on many key issues with Republic of China officials. He would also likely meet key leaders in Taiwan during his visit, Pao said.

Pao said Taiwan has demonstrated unprecedented sincerity and goodwill toward Beijing, before and after Taiwan's top negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, visited the mainland in mid-October. He said he hopes that mainland Chinese authorities will reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill gestures by arranging for a visit by Wang.
Koo, a Taiwan business tycoon and an adviser to president Lee Teng-hui, is chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, also said that Wang is widely expected to visit Taiwan in due time, as agreed upon by the two sides during Koo's visit to Shanghai in October.

During that visit, SEF and ARATS agreed to the resumption of a regular dialogue; the strengthening of exchanges of visits by SEF and ARATS personnel; an acceleration of exchanges of opinions and information on cross-strait incidents or accidents; and the acceptance by Wang of SEF's invitation for him to visit Taiwan in the following spring.

Meanwhile, Chang said, Taipei will continue promoting bilateral exchanges and negotiations with mainland China so that cross-strait ties will be further improved, paving the way for eventual reunification.

Speaking on the state of cross-strait relations, President Lee said in a recent speech to the National Assembly that equal footing for Taiwan and mainland China and mainland China's democratization are prerequisites to reunification.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZATION FOR INDEPENDENCE OF XINJIANG SET UP IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: Some 300 representatives of Xinjiang dissidents from 11 countries announced here Saturday the establishment of "East Turkistan National Center".
An informed source, who asked not to be named, said the goal of the national center is to "liberate East Turkistan." In other words, it will work for the independence of Xinjiang.

He said that the announcement was made at the end of their "Third National Conference," and that the national center will be a de facto "exiled government" of East Turkistan, which is also called Xinjiang in Chinese.
They are from Kazakhstan, Kirghizstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Germany, the United States, Australia, Sweden, Pakistan, Turkey, and mainland China, he said.

In Turkey there are more than 40,000 Uighur immigrants from Xinjiang. Most of them arrived in Turkey after communist troops took over the Chinese mainland in 1949. They have continued their effort to establish "East Turkistan" in Xinjiang since then, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO FREE ASIA TO BROADCAST UIGHUR-LANGUAGE PROGRAM
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-shin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: New York-based Radio Free Asia (RFA) will on Wednesday begin broadcasting an Uighur-language news and information program that will focus on Uighurs living in mainland China and in other countries and areas around the world.

This will be the world's first Uighur-language broadcast program, said an ethnic Uighur living in Turkey, who was on Saturday hired by the RFA as a Turkey-based reporter. The reporter is also an activist of Xinjiang.
The Uighur are a tribe of Turkic people mainly inhabiting the Xinjiang region in mainland China.

Turkey has been a gathering center for Uighurs from areas around Xinjiang, because of its geographical location next to Central Asia and because it is a place where people speak Turkic languages, such as Uighur.
At present more than 400 Uighur traders travel between Turkey and mainland China every year, said the RFA reporter.

They have provided the activist's Xinjiang organization with news and information related to Xinjiang, an area in which authorities in Beijing have been accused of violating human rights and of strictly censoring the press.
The RFA's Uighur broadcast will be in the program lasting 30 minutes. Eventually, the program will expand in length to 60 minutes and be broadcast daily, said the RFA reporter.

The RFA has been under the sponsorship of the US Congress, which was reported by The Los Angeles Times in its Saturday issue to have given US$390 million to the station to support its advocacy of human rights and democracy in communist countries, such as mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOMINATES ASIAN GAMES WOMEN'S GOLF COMPETITION
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Wei Shu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Women golfers from Taiwan on Sunday proved that they are the best in Asia by dominating all women's golfing events in the ongoing Asian Games in Bangkok.

Lu Hui-chuan clinched a gold for Taiwan in the women's individual competition with a four-day total of 288, followed by teammate Wei Yun-chieh with a silver at 289, and Lin Yu-ping with a bronze at 290.
Taiwan players also pocketed the team division title with a four-day total of 577.

Meanwhile Lai Chia-hsiung and Chang Kao-wei beat teammates Chao Feng-pang and Yang Ching-shun in the eight-ball billiards doubles division, adding one gold and one silver to Taiwan's trophy collection, bringing the total to 14 golds, seven silvers and 17 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS ACTIVISTS TO FORM ASIAN ALLIANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jie and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Human rights activists from various parts of Asia have agreed to establish an alliance to promote democracy and greater respect for human rights in this part of the world.

The decision was reached in Paris on Saturday at a meeting attended by top dissidents from mainland China, such as Wei Jingsheng and Tsai Chungguo; by Taiwan human rights promoter Huang Wen-hsiung; by representatives of Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama; and by Nobel Peace Prize laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, as well as by representatives of human rights groups in Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea and Hong Kong.

After one day of discussions on "Asian values and democracy" the participants issued a statement saying that they, as human rights activists, fully understand the desire of the people of the region, which accounts for-one quarter of the world's population.
They pledged to join hands to bring democratization to all parts of the region, enabling people to enjoy freedom of speech and religion.
They also called for the resolution of regional disputes by peaceful means.

They also decided to hold a series of rallies and activities in Paris next year to mark the 10th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananman incident, in which thousands of pro-democracy students and civilians were killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROLLS ROYCE, MOEA SIGN ALLIANCE ACCORD

TEXT.P: Rolls Royce Plc. on Monday signed a letter of intent to form a strategic alliance with the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.
The agreement was jointly signed in London Monday by ROC Deputy Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-min and by senior executives of Rolls Royce, MOEA officials told CNA.
Rolls Royce became the 61st strategic alliance partner of the MOEA for industrial and business cooperation.
Under the agreement, Rolls Royce will make inroads into Taiwan's electricity market, which is being liberalized.

Also under the agreement, Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) signed a memorandum with Rolls Royce to jointly develop co-generation engines for privately-run power companies, which are expected to mushroom around Taiwan in the near future.

Rolls Royce also signed a similar memorandum with Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), under which the British company is expected to obtain regular supplies of natural gas to beef up its power system development efforts in Taiwan.
According to the agreement, both Taiwan's MOEA and Rolls Royce will also work together to jointly develop Asia-Pacific and world markets.

Rolls Royce is famous throughout the world for its high-performance aircraft engines and power systems. The present company was formed through the absorption into Rolls Royce of Napier Aero Engines in 1961 and Bristol Siddeley Engines in 1966.

Rolls Royce has long been known as the producer of luxury automobiles, and today is one of the world's top three aircraft engine makers. The company markets its products throughout the globe and has authorized manufacturers and cooperative research and development partners in more than 80 countries.
Deputy Minister Yin is currently leading an ROC trade promotion mission to Europe. After visiting London, the group is expected to proceed to France and the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAOHAN LIKELY TO VISIT TAIWAN IN MARCH: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: A visit by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based intermediary Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to Taiwan will most likely take place in next March, an official in charge of mainland affairs said on Monday.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks in a two-day seminar on cross-strait relations at National Taiwan University.

Chang noted that Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), during his visit to mainland China in October, invited his counterpart, Wang, to visit Taiwan. Wang agreed and said he would visit in due time.

The top charter of mainland policy also said that the government is sincere in inviting Wang to visit, but the timing of his visit will have to be discussed between SEF and ARATS, the two intermediary bodies set up to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Chang also noted that the government will continue to push for exchanges and consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, especially for normal exchanges between SEF and ARATS.

Meanwhile, Chang also said that he regretted that mainland scholars who had agreed to attend the seminar were absent. He urged the mainland not to refuse scholarly exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
NTU, which sponsored the seminar, contacted Beijing University a full year ago in regards to the event, which several mainland scholars had agreed to attend.

The scholars submitted several papers and were preparing to travel to Taiwan when they notified last week that they would not be able to attend the seminar as the conference might touch on substantial matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE SCIENTIST DEVELOPS BETTER PIGS FOR ASIAN TASTES

TEXT.P: Australian pig farmers can now breed a better class of swine for export to Asia and elsewhere after an Australian scientist made a major breakthrough in the development of a new insemination technique.

Professor Ranald Cameron of the University of Queensland said the embryo-freezing process would allow pig breeders to get around Australia's tough quarantine laws and compete with Canadian pig breeders.
He said the process would provide a boon for Australian pork producers who would be able to grow the redder, more marbled meat that appeals to Asian tastes.
"Australia urgently needs a fresh gene pool to compete with the high meat quality and large litter producing strains in America and Europe," Cameron told reporters.

"Because of quarantine regulations in Australia, we can't import genetic materials other than by frozen embryos, so this will open up the whole field as far as introducing new genetic material into the Australian industry," he said.

Australian pork producers have been calling for more trade protection from the federal government, claiming the market is being swamped by cheaper Canadian imports. Australia's producers have said they are struggling to survive.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MINERS STRIKING OVER CUT IN COAL PRICES TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Australian miners are launching a two-day strike as a "straightforward political protest" against an 18 percent cut in the benchmark coal price agreed between local exporters and Japanese importers.

The strike, which began on Sunday night, followed weekend reports that Shell Australia and MIM Holdings Ltd., two major Australian producers and exporters, had signed contracts with Japanese steel mills under which they cut coking coal prices by US$9 a ton.
The negotiated prices between Australia and Japan are expected to be applied to other major importers, including Taiwan and South Korea.
The Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union of Australia said the strike was designed to force the Australian government to intervene in the coal market to implement an industry policy.
Australia is the world's largest coal exporter with Japan as the leading buyer. Taiwan and Korea are major importers as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA INTERESTED IN BUYING STAKE IN ANSETT AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA), one of the world's leading airlines, is considering whether to buy a stake in Ansett Australia, the second-largest airline in Australia.

SIA chief executive Cheong Choong Kong, who is currently visiting Melbourne, told The Australian Financial Review that his company is interested in buying a stake in Ansett, which now has a code-sharing agreement with SIA.
Ansett, owned jointly by Air New Zealand and News Corp. of Australia, has leased three SIA Boeing 747s to operate international flights to Taipei, Japan and some other Asian routes.
Cheong said SIA would approach the Australian government in a bid to increase the number of its flights into Australia under the bilateral air services agreement between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC ASKED TO LOOK INTO BRIBERY ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia, angry over allegations of Olympic-related bribery, has demanded that the International Olympic Committee (IOC) make an inquiry into a claim that Sydney spent millions of dollars to buy votes to secure the right to host the 2000 Olympic Games.

The demand was made by Phil Coles, an Australian delegate on the IOC after Mark Hodler, a member of the IOC board, told journalists in Lausanne, Switzerland, on Sunday that Sydney (2000), Atlanta (1996), Nagano (1998) and Salt Lake City (2002) were involved in the offering of bribes to win the rights to serve as host sites to the Olympic Games.

Coles told Australian media on Sunday that the corruption allegation was unqualified and unjustified and demanded an apology from Hodler, who said: " I would be surprised. I know what happened, but I don't want to disclose it. I can't imagine that Sydney is different from the others. Sydney pretends it is completely clean, clean, clean."
Coles told the Australian Broadcasting Corp. on Monday that Hodler had backed down from his comments against Sydney, saying Australia had done well in securing the right to host the Olympic Games.
IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranchi on Sunday distanced himself from Hodler, saying Hodler's comments were his personal views.
Kevan Gosper, an Australian member of the IOC executive board, said he was "surprised" by Hodler's allegations, which he said were unsubstantiated and not helpful.

"I have been associated with three Australian Olympic bids and I have never been approached by an agent. There is no evidence that we were being pushed for a bribe. Bribery never entered into the minds of the bidding city," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 14, or Oct. 26 under the lunar calendar. Folllowing is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: George Washington, the first president of the United States, dies at the age of 67.
1906: German's first submarine, the U1, is launched in the military port of Kiel in northern Germany.
1910: Scottish-born American steel industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie establishes the Carnegie Peace Foundation.
1911: Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian explorer, becomes first man to reach the South Pole.
1916: People of Denmark vote to sell Danish West Indies to the United States for US$25 million.
1918: Six million British women cast their votes for the first time in general elections n Britain.
1927: The Republic of China beaks relations with the Soviet Union.
1937: Japan sets up puppet Chinese government in Peiping (Beijing).
1939: The Soviet Union is expelled from the League of Nations for invading Finland.
1941: During World War II, the US Marines make stand in battle for Wake Island in the Pacific.
1959: Archbishop Makarios is elected the first president of Cyprus.
1972: After three days of exploration on the lunar surface, US Apollo 17 astronauts blast off from the moon.
1978: The ROC armed forces manufacture missile-carrying vessels capable of traveling at 40 knots.
1981: Israel annexes Golan Heights, which was captured from Syria in 1967.
1990: Chang Chun, senior advisor to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 102.
1991: Former East German leader Erich Honecker, facing extradition to Germany and trial on manslaughter charges, is offered asylum in North Korea.
1994: Engineering work on water conservancy project begins in the Yangtse Gorges.
Confucius: "At fifteen I had made up my mind to give myself up to serious studies. At thirty I had formed my opinions and judgment. At forty I had no more doubts. At fifty I understood the truth religion. At sixty I could understand whatever I heard without exertion. At seventy I could follow whatever my heart desired without transgressing the law."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS EDUCATION WILL BE TARGETED AT YOUNGSTERS: DOH

TEXT.P: The average age of a person in Taiwan infected with AIDS is falling, and the Republic of China's Department of Health (DOH) has indicated that adolescent sexual relations is the cause of most youngsters' infections.

AIDS education will therefore be targeted at youngsters, said DOH officials. In line with the World Health Organization's international AIDS day promotional campaign, the DOH will launch a series of activities to better educate young people about AIDS.
Under the initiative, medical experts, government officials, public figures and movie stars will be invited to speak out on behalf of AIDS prevention, DOH officials said at a press conference Monday.

The young are the country's future and Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome has no cure, said the wife of ROC Premier Vincent Siew, Chu Shu-hsien, who was invited to attend the conference. She noted that every day 7,000 youngsters aged between 10 and 14 are reportedly infected with the AIDS virus.
She said the best means of preventing infection was to make youngsters aware of safe sexual behaviors.

From 1984 when Taiwan's first AIDS case was discovered, 2,131 people have identified as being infected with AIDS. Of that number 1,908 were ROC nationals, most of whom were older than 13, said DOH Bureau of Communicable Disease Control Director Hsu Kuo-hsiung. Most of these infections were reportedly related to sexual intercourse, Hsu added.
The most effective means of preventing the further spread of AIDS among youngsters is to teach them of the need to practice safe sex, he said.
Hsu also called for everyone in society to help young people in the fight against AIDS.
TV stars Hsu Hua-feng and Liu Han-chiang attended the press conference. Their arms colored red, the two held hands in a depiction of the red ribbon often worn to promote AIDS awareness.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS HUALIEN AS TORRENTIAL RAINS HIT NORTHEAST

TEXT.P: An earthquake of moderate intensity shook northern Taiwan Monday morning, while an approaching cold front promises continued rain and even cooler temperatures for much of northern and eastern Taiwan.
The quake, measuring 5.2 on the Richter Scale, struck at 8:59 a.m., and its epicenter was located off shore 59 kilometers north of Hualien, on Taiwan's eastern coast.
Tremors were felt throughout northern Taiwan, in areas as far west as Taoyuan and as far south as Nantou, according to the Seismology Center of Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
Meanwhile, the CWB on Monday warned of continued torrential rains in the northeastern part of Taiwan, while temperatures continue to fall as a new mass of cold air hits the island.
The CWB said that the weather in the northern, northeastern and eastern parts of Taiwan will be rainy due to the cold front. Weather in the rest of Taiwan, meanwhile, will range from cloudy to clear.
Starting Tuesday, the northern and eastern parts of Taiwan will be hit by showers brought by a monsoon from the northeast.

The island's lowest temperature Monday morning was 15.8 degrees Celsius, which was registered in Tamshui. Temperatures islandwide are expected to drop by two degrees this afternoon as the cold air mass approaches.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWS REPORTS ON MATTERS OF CABINET RESHUFFLE DENIED

TEXT.P: Republic of China Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on Sunday denied media reports that he is likely to replace Vincent Siew as premier.

According to a local newspaper on Sunday, the ROC government has reached a consensus on having Premier Vincent Siew and his Cabinet resign before the new legislature takes office on Feb. 1, 1999. The paper also added that Chiang will take over Siew's post.
Chiang also said that Siew's Cabinet should be credited for its overall performance and especially for its policy to deal with the Asian financial crisis.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General John Chang said on Monday that top government leaders had not reached a consensus on the matter of Cabinet reshuffle and denied that he would be named prime minister.

As to the nomination of KMT candidates for National Assembly speaker and deputy speaker, Chang said it will be decided on Dec. 16 during a meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee. Incumbent Speaker Fredrick Chien will leave his post to serve as president of the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG HERALDS 'DOCTRINE OF NEW TAIWANESE'
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's most prominent dissident, said on Sunday that the "concept of a new Taiwan people" espoused recently by Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, is a doctrine full of political wisdom.

Wei, who is currently visiting France, said the Kuomintang demonstrated commendable political wisdom during the "three-in-one" elections held in Taiwan on Dec. 5, retaining its status as Taiwan's ruling party and regaining political ground lost over the past several years.
President Lee is particularly praiseworthy for his timely espousal of the "concept of a new Taiwan people" or the "doctrine of the New Taiwanese" before the elections, Wei told CNA.

Lee's latest doctrine, which calls for a sense of esprit de corps among all the Chinese people who have settled in Taiwan -- however recently or long ago -- has helped erase ethnic rifts and create a harmonious atmosphere among the Taiwanese people, Wei pointed out.

Wei rejected suggestions that the doctrine would promote Taiwan independence, which will in turn affect the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He said the sovereignty of Taiwan resides with all the people in Taiwan, just as the fate of mainland China is held in the hands of all mainland Chinese people.
Wei said he did not think reunification should be the ultimate goal of mainland China. He said happiness and good living are what the Taiwanese and, in fact, all Chinese are striving for.

The "new Taiwanese" concept cannot hamper efforts to reunify China, he added, noting that there had been no trouble when people in the mainland referred to the "new Shanghai people" or the "new Beijingese."
It has been rumored since January 1998 that Wei would visit Taiwan, and he said he will likely pay a visit in early 1999.

During his stay in Taiwan, Wei said, he will have two messages to people in Taiwan. One is that while emphasizing they are "new Taiwanese," the Taiwan people need not stress that they are not "Chinese." By saying they are not Chinese, the people of Taiwan people would disappoint people in mainland China, and such a pronouncement could have disastrous consequences, he warned.

Another message, he said, is that while Taiwan independence may be the right of the Taiwan people and something that would be supported by Chinese democracy activists overseas, it is not and will never be acceptable to the authorities in mainland China.
For the moment, Wei said, he suggests that people in Taiwan help with democracy activities in mainland China so as to help accelerate democratic development there.
Wei, a former Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is visiting Paris, mainly for activities marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Wei on Sunday joined groups calling for the formation of an Asian human rights alliance.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.026 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 32.258.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.273, and had a high of 32.238.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$436 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC LEAVES MARKET TO DECIDE CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) would only intervene in currency markets if the New Taiwan dollar was affected by seasonal factors or short-term fluctuations or if rumors of irrational expectations continue hanging around the market, said CBC Chairman Perng Fai-nan on Monday.
Perng made the remarks at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's budgetary, financial, diplomatic and judicial affairs committees screening the CBC budget for the next fiscal year.
In response to questioning by a legislator of the opposition New Party, Perng said Taiwan has a small-sized developing economy that is easily affected by other economies.

The fact that many people rushed to exchange New Taiwan dollars for foreign currencies in June amid the region's financial crisis best illustrates how influence-prone Taiwan's economy is and the irrational expectations of the people, he said.
There is therefore a need for the CBC to intervene to moderate fluctuations, Perng added.
Perng said such moves are in line with international practices, pointing out that the United States, Japan and other Group of Seven countries have enacted similar controls on currency exchange rates.
He reiterated the importance on keeping the New Taiwan dollar stable, but he agreed to leave foreign exchange rates to the market.

A lawmaker from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party questioned the CBC, saying that interest rate reductions in the second half of the year were aimed at helping Kuomintang candidates in the island's "three-in-one" elections on Dec. 5.

Perng answered that the CBC would decide to cut the interest rates to stimulate the economy according to the principles of stable prices and exchange rates and that such decisions are not influenced by political factors.

He said the CBC was under strong pressure to cut interest rates last June, but it did not do so, because the foreign exchange markets were still vibrant at that point. This shows the central bank's neutrality when it comes to politics, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGARY HOPES TO DEVELOP SUBSTANTIAL RELATIONS WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Hungary is positive of the economic clout of the Republic of China and would like to develop substantial relations between the two countries, ROC Representative to Hungary Rock Leng said on Monday.

Leng said Hungary is impressed with the ROC's economic development over the past five decades and its economic strength amid Asia's financial crisis over the past two years, which he said will be conducive to the strengthening of bilateral ties.

Reporting to the joint Foreign and Overseas Affairs Committees in the Legislative Yuan, Leng also said that Hungary has set the joining of the European Union (EU) as its top foreign policy priority. This has hampered the development of ties with the Republic of China because its laws, regulations and policies will have to be in accordance with those of the EU.
But Leng said that Hungary would consider strengthening substantial relations between the two nations so long as such exchanges will not violate its "one China" policy.

On whether it is possible to promote high-level visits, such as ones involving presidents, vice presidents or ministerial-level officials, between the two nations, Leng said that the possibility of high-level exchanges is there so long as such visits do not violate Hungary's "one China" principle.
Leng also reported that Hungary has criticized mainland China's human rights record on occasion, but it has been unwilling to confront the mainland on other issues.

In view of the mainland's status as a regional power, and because of the trade opportunities it affords, Hungary has believed that it should maintain normal and positive relations with the mainland, Leng said.
But Hungary hopes Taiwan will invest in its manufacturing industry and has chosen automobile parts and electronic parts as the areas targeted for bilateral cooperation.
Leng also said that Hungary is scheduled to join the EU in 2002, which means that it will enjoy preferential treatment when doing business with EU countries.
The Taipei Representative Office in Hungary is willing to provide all assistance to Taiwan businessmen who want to invest in Hungary and use it as a base to make inroads into the European market.

Statistics show that two-way trade between Taiwan and Hungary totaled US$196.3 million in 1997, up 56.3 percent from the same period the previous year. Taiwan's exports to Hungary totaled US$135.3 million, while its imports from Hungary totaled US$61 million.

Leng said that bilateral trade accounted for only a fraction of the overall trade of the two nations. Hungary, however, has complained about the trade deficit it is suffering in trade with Taiwan, while Taiwan has agreed to increase its imports from Hungary to lessen the imbalance.

He also said that Hungary has changed its attitude toward bilateral trade after Taiwan increased its imports from Hungary twofold last year, especially since Hungary's exports to Taiwan were three times the amount of its exports to mainland China.

Leng said that Hungary hopes especially that Taiwan businessmen will invest in its manufacturing industry, noting that there are 15 Taiwan businessmen investing in Hungary, mainly in the import of consumer goods and in computer sales. But so far no Taiwan businesses have invested in its manufacturing industry.
Speaking on the same occasion, Leng also said that there is "ample room for development" between the Republic of China and the former Yugoslavian republic of Slovenia.

He noted that a Double Ten party was held in Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia, to mark the ROC's national day, Oct. 10, this year. Many Slovenian parliamentarians and academics were invited to the party, he said.
The Taipei Representative Office in Hungary also covers Romania, Bulgaria and the five former Yugoslavian republics.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWYERS GATHER FIRST-HAND INFO ON WARTIME SEX SLAVES

TEXT.P: An eight-member group of lawyers from Japan arrived in Taipei on Monday to gather first-hand information from former Taiwan comfort women in an effort to collect a larger compensation from the Japanese government.

The Japanese members, all of whom are working voluntarily, are here to collect relevant data which will be used in lawsuits against the Japanese government next spring, said Attorney Yukiko Shimizu, leader of the mission.

Wang Ching-feng, leader of a consortium of lawyers representing the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF), said the Japanese mission's visit here will help accelerate efforts in seeking justice for former comfort women in Taiwan.

Wang, a 1996 vice presidential election candidate who teamed up with presidential candidate Chen Li-an, said she and the TWRF group have visited Japan six times this year to express Taiwan's concerns in this issue and meet with relevant Japan interest groups to form a cohesive strategy.
So far, she said 30 of the 44 surviving comfort women in Taiwan have contacted the TWRF lawyers, who are also working on a voluntary basis, to fight for their rights.

Comfort women are the Japanese euphemism for some 200,000 Asian women who were forced into working as sex slaves for the imperial Japanese army during World War II. Many comfort women were from Taiwan, South Korea and other Asian countries.

The Japanese government admitted in 1993 that the Japanese army did recruit comfort women and operated military brothels during wartime. While some Japanese officials have on several occasions apologized for such practices, the Japanese government has been reluctant to offer legal compensation for surviving comfort women.

Japan set up an Asian Women's Fund in 1995 which offers each surviving comfort woman 2 million Japanese yen (about US$14,285) in compensation. However, most surviving comfort women have turned down the offer because the money does not come from the Japanese government.

Other members of the Japanese mission also include Kunio Aitani, a lawyer and a senior official with the National Lawyers' Association of Japan; four other lawyers; Yoshiaki Yoshimi, a history professor with Chuou (Central) University of Japan who is also the author of a book about wartime comfort women; and Yoko Shiba, a social worker who has spent years on the comfort women issue.
During their four-day stay, the Japanese delegation will meet all 30 comfort women individually in meetings to be held in northern, southern and eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 81 NEW AIDS CASES REPORTED: DOH

TEXT.P: An additional 81 patients with the AIDS virus were reported in Taiwan from October to November, bringing the total number of AIDS patients in the island to 2,131, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced on Monday.

Of the 81 recent cases, 76 are ROC nationals while five are foreigners, according to the DOH. Seventy-five of the carriers are male and the remaining six are female. Twenty carriers contracted the virus through heterosexual activities while 17 and five contracted the virus through homosexual and bisexual activities respectively. The other 39 people contracted the disease through other means.

The AIDS virus appears to be spreading among the younger population with 251 of the total 1,908 Taiwan nationals diagnosed with AIDS aged between 10 and 24 years old, the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control said.

It added that of the 251 young AIDS patients, 81 are heterosexual, while 131 are male homosexuals and 41 are male bisexuals. The other 116 cases involve hemophiliacs, drug users, and those infected through injections.

Of the 1,908 infected patients, 692 have shown symptoms of the disease and have fallen sick. AIDS stands for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. It involves the attack of the victim's immune system by a virus which leaves the victim susceptible to a variety of infections and cancers.
The DOH reported a total of 349 new AIDS cases in the first 11 months of this year, up 13 percent from the same period last year. There were an average of 29 new cases reported each month.

Among the young AIDS patients, about 70 percent contracted the disease through sexual activity, the bureau said, adding that the DOH has stepped up efforts to promote safe sex among youths to counter the fatal disease.
According to the bureau, about 50 percent of sexually active youths do not use condoms when having sex with their partners for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SHIPPING MEETING SLATED FOR JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China have tentatively agreed to hold a fourth cross-strait shipping meeting early next year, the ROC Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Monday.

Hsu Hung-lie, secretary-general of the Taiwan Strait Shipping Association (TSSA), said the meeting may be held next month in Hong Kong but the actual date and meeting venue are still under negotiation between the TSSA and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Shipping Across the Taiwan Strait (ASATS).

The TSSA and ASATS held the third cross-strait shipping meeting in January this year in Bangkok. The two sides agreed to exchange indirect cross-strait shipping services through a third area or country between Taiwan's southern Kaohsiung port -- Taiwan's offshore transshipment center -- and Fuzhou and Xiamen ports in mainland China's Fujian province.

Wu Jung-kuei, head of the MOTC's Navigation and Aviation Department, said the planned meeting will focus on opening more ports on both sides to conduct conditional direct shipping services across the Taiwan Strait. Wu added that he may attend the meeting as a TSSA advisor.

As current cross-strait shipping volumes remain low because of the small handling capabilities of Fuzhou and Xiamen, Wu expressed the hope that the mainland will allow larger ports such as Shanghai and Guangzhou to exchange shipping ties with Taiwan, while Taiwan will open its central Taichung port in response.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK PRICES DROP DESPITE GOVERNMENT SUPPORT; FUTURE PRICES MIXED

TEXT.P: Share prices fell on the Taipei stock market on Monday despite the government's earlier declaration that it would take every effort to support the market.
The Taipei Stock Exchange's (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropped 50.24 points to close at 6,889.5.
Finance Minister Paul Chu conveyed a task force meeting on Monday morning, aimed at formulating strategies to pump up stock buying.
However, the market failed to respond positively to the effort, registering a 0.7 percent loss.
Chu said the drop in Taipei was smaller than a 1.7 percent plunge in Hong Kong's stock market in Monday's session, a 1.1 percent loss in Japan, and a 1.71 percent drop in Thailand.
Compared with the region's stock trading, Chu stressed, Taiwan's share prices were relatively stable with the support of the government stock-stabilization fund.

The fund, established on Dec. 12 to shore up share prices against the expected impact of the Dec. 5 elections, will continue acting as a stock stabilizer, the minister said. He added that Taiwan enjoys more sound economic fundamentals than other Asian markets, calling on investors to keep their confidence in the Taipei market.

The Taipei bourse opened higher at 6,985.87 on Monday. It then saw drops as investors stayed on the sidelines with weak confidence following the index's slump to put it past the 6,900-psychological mark.
In all, 1.42 billion issues changed hands while the turnover of the market shrank to NT$50.66 billion (US$1.57 billion), against the previous session's NT$64.97 billion.

Electronic engineering stocks posted the largest drop of 1.5 percent followed by construction shares which plunged 1.1 percent; foodstuff issues, 0.7 percent; banking shares, 0.6 percent; and textile issues, 0.1 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares enjoyed the only gain of 0.8 percent among the eight major stock categories, while both cement stocks and paper-making issues remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures was mixed.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December posted a modest decline of six points, closing at 6,959, with 1,576 contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for January moved up 11 points to close at 7,062, with 1,524 transactions, while those for March declined 41 points to 7,041 with 74 contract transactions.
No trading was registered for June and September.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 6,965 points for December, 7,051 points for January, 7,082 points for March, 7,023 points for June and 6,950 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW RECEIVES FORMER US AMBASSADOR JAMES LILLEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to help the Southeast Asian countries hurt by the Asian financial crisis, Premier Vincent Siew said when he received former US ambassador to Beijing James Lilley Monday.
Taiwan is also willing to support the programs adopted by the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to help those countries overcome their financial difficulties, Siew said.

Taiwan is able to keep the effect of the Asian financial crisis to a minimum, because the government has taken several measures to increase domestic demand and help the financial market, the premier told Lilley.

Lilley, who has just visited Hong Kong, said people there are afraid that the rampant smuggling and corruption in southern China may hurt their economy. He also told Siew that Hong Kong's stock market is in poor shape and its unemployment is rising.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPECTED WAVE OF ASIAN TAKEOVERS FIZZLES OUT

TEXT.P: Predictions that western multinationals were going to pick up some bargain assets during the Asian financial crisis this year have fallen short of expectations, The Business Times reported on Monday.

The total volume of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) for 1998 is significantly lower than in 1997. Latest figures from Securities Data Company, a New Jersey-based company whose data is widely used by banks, put the value of deals up to Oct. 25 at US$49 billion in Asia-Pacific region excluding Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

However, there has been a spurt of activity since October. Estimates by Morgan Stanley Asia, a leading bank in M&A, showed that the year is likely to finish off with about US$60 billion worth of deals, down a fifth from 1997.

Bankers and management consultants interviewed by The Business Times all agreed the pace of M&As this year has been disappointing. A record 1997 had buoyed expectations early this year and many investment banks and accounting firms had diverted resources into the business. But thus far, the hype has exceeded the reality.

The most active target countries for M&A deals are Japan, South Korea and Thailand. Bankers noted that there have been more transactions announced in South Korea than actually completed. This is the same for Indonesia where none of the major bank mergers announced early in the year have come to fruition except for the interest consolidation of the Bank Bali group.

The fall-off in transactions is not for a want of buyers. Indeed, soon after the economies of Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia tanked last year, many multinational companies rushed into Asia with their check books.

There are two reasons often cited in explaining why deals are not getting done. One is the huge gap that still exists between sellers' asking price and what buyers are prepared to pay; and two, the slow progress in debt restructuring across Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BACKS THAILAND'S WTO PRESIDENCY BID

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities threw their support behind Thai Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi in his bid to head the World Trade Organization (WTO), reports said on Monday.
Although mainland China is not a WTO member, it issued a statement following Vice Premier Li Lanqing's meeting with Thai Deputy Prime Minister Bhichai Rattakul, backing Supachai's candidacy.
Bhichai reportedly asked Li to help persuade countries with which the mainland has ties to support the Thai bid.

Li, who was in Thailand on a four-day official visit last week, was quoted as saying the mainland wants to see an Asian head the world trade body. He also said he hoped Thailand would support mainland China's bid to join the WTO.
"(Mainland) China is ready to follow WTO requirements as a developing country," Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT WANG CE ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Wang Ce, a dissident who sneaked back to mainland China via Macao in mid-October, was formally arrested on Dec. 11 on charges of "sneaking" into the country and "helping criminal activities that endanger national security."

According to a press release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, Wang, 50, left the mainland for the United States in 1984, won his Ph. D. in Hawaii in 1992, and settled down in Spain later. He sneaked back to the mainland two months ago to help promote democratic reform in the country. He is not a citizen of the United States or Spain.
Mainland Chinese authorities detained him on Nov. 2 soon after he met with another dissident Wang You-cai. Li Li, a mainland dissident from France, was also arrested at that time.

The information center said that mainland Chinese authorities used to expel the dissidents who had sneaked back to the country, but this time they chose to arrest Wang and Li. It is possible that the authorities did this to warn overseas dissidents not to sneak back to the country to make trouble, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SELECTS CANDIDATES FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER, DEPUTY SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang has selected Su Nan-cheng as the party's candidate for National Assembly speaker and Chen Ching-jang as deputy speaker, party Secretary-General John Chang said on Monday.
The decision will be submitted on Wednesday to the KMT's policy-making body, the Standing Central Committee, for approval in a move seen as a formality, according to Chang.

Both Su and Chen are currently National Assembly deputies. If elected, they will replace outgoing Speaker Fredrick Chien, who has been designed as the new Control Yuan president, and Deputy Speaker Hsieh Lung-sheng who has fallen sick and has been confined to bed for a long time.
Chien is expected to offered his resignation on Tuesday.

To ensure that the party's nominees will cruise through the floor of the assembly, the KMT will mobilize its deputies to support Su and Chen after their nominations are formally presented, said a party official.

Although the opposition Democratic Progressive Party countering the KMT's decision by announcing that it will put forward its own candidates before the year end and another opposition the New Party saying that the deputy speaker would be better to be an opposition, the passage of the KMT's nominees is almost certain given the party enjoying a majority of 183 seats in the 334-seat assembly.
Meanwhile the three parties at the assembly have decided through negotiations on Monday to cast ballots for speaker and deputy speaker on Jan. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ENVOY TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF BURKINA FASO LEADER

TEXT.P: Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih of the National Security Council, in his capacity as a presidential envoy, will lead a delegation to Burkina Faso to attend the inauguration of President Blaise Compaore to be held on Dec. 21.
Burkina Faso President Compaore won in his reelection bid in elections held on Nov. 15.
Ding is scheduled to leave for Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, on Dec. 18.

In addition to attending the inauguration ceremony, Ding will meet with President Compaore, deliver a letter from ROC President Lee Teng-hui, and extend President Lee's congratulations. Ding will also call on other ranking Burkina Faso officials.
Ding is scheduled to proceed to Senegal, another ROC West African ally, on Dec. 22.
While in Senegal, Ding will call on Senegal President Abdou Diouf and other ranking officials to exchange views on bilateral relations and various cooperation projects.
Ding's mission is scheduled to leave Senegal on Dec. 24 for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TEAM WINS ITS FIRST TRACK AND FIELD BRONZE
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Wei Shu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei team on Monday won its first track and field medal in the 13rd Asian Olympic Games.

In the women's heptathlon event, Taiwan's Ma Chun-ping received the bronze with a total of 5,659 points. The gold went to Shen Shengfei from mainland China who earned 5,817 points. The silver medal winner was from Kazakhstan.

Ma scored 957 points in the 100-meter hurdles, 700 points in shot put, 774 points in long jump, 903 points in high jump, 858 points in the 200 meters, 663 points in javelin, and 804 points in the 800 meters.

Meanwhile, Chou Miao-ling beat Ho Yen Wah of Singapore in the two-game women's masters bolwing shaowdown to earn a gold for Taiwan, while Wu Fu-lung lost to Hui Cheung-kwok of Hong Kong in men's masters final, wining a silver.
With the addition of Monday's three medals, the team from the Republic of China on Taiwan has so far won a total of 15 golds, 10 silvers, and 23 bronzes.
ROC National Sport Council Chairman Chao Li-yun said she expected the team to win 17-20 golds during the Bangkok games.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDISH GIRL ARRIVES IN TAINAN TO SEEK HER BIOLOGICAL MOTHER
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: An ethnic Chinese girl who was born in Taiwan and taken to Sweden by a missionary couple 22 years ago, arrived in Tainan city on Monday in a bid to find her biological mother.
Hanna Andersson said she hoped her biological mother, who is probably still living in Tainan, will take the initiative and try to communicate with her.
Shortly after her arrival, Andersson distributed copies of her baby photos in downtown Tainan and marketplaces to publicize her cause.
The police have also posted the photographs at each of their branches with the hope that people who knew Andersson or her mother would come forward with details.

Based on information from the missionary, Andersson said she was born between March and June of 1976. She said in a news conference in Taipei last Wednesday that she was told she was born out of wedlock to a 16-year-old girl from Tainan.

Her mother was taken to the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu to give birth and a midwife reportedly sold the newborn to a Swedish missionary couple. The baby later was taken to Sweden and given to the Andersson family for adoption.

Prior to going to Tainan, Andersson, who has been in Taiwan since October, sent a sample of her DNA to the National Police Administration (NPA) along with that of Tseng Lee Jung-mei, the woman who is named as Andersson's birth mother in her adoption papers.
It will take several days for the NPA to complete the DNA comparison.

It is the third such case where a Taiwan-born girl who was sold then adopted by an overseas family has returned to the island in search for her birth mother. Kartya Wunderle and Eimee Butler, both ethnic Chinese living in Australia, came to the island separately to find their birth mothers. Both were successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES HAVING BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday denied that the island is developing biological and chemical weapons.
A MND spokesman made the official statement in response to an Associated Press report on Saturday that identified at least 10 countries including Taiwan suspected of developing biological weapons.
The spokesman stressed it has always been the ROC's consistent policy to adhere to the Chemical Weapons Convention put into effect on April 29, 1997.
While the ROC is not a signaorty to the CWC, as a member of the international community, it will follow and respect the rules of the United Nations convention, the spokesman stated.

He reiterated Taipei's pledge of not making or owning biological weapons as the country is devoted to the development and manufacture of equipment and the training against the threat of biological warfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST KEEP WATCHFUL EYE ON REGIONAL ECONOMIC CRISIS: CBC

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan has been the least affected economy amid the Asian crisis, it should avoid complacency and keep a watchful eye on the storm, said Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC) on Monday.

In an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Perng said Taiwan's steady economical expansion -- marked by its sizable current account surplus, which reflects increasing debts owed by other countries to the island -- is more than its Southeast Asian neighbors can hope to match.

A series of defaults by some high-profile listed companies which sent shock waves through the island's financial markets last month stemmed from isolated failed speculation which reminded the CBC the need to tighten its financial inspection of listed companies, Perng noted.

The governor acknowledged the attraction of financial liberalization, but since a Washington-led campaign promoting open markets in Asia was seen as a cause behind the Asian financial crisis, there is no question of a hands-off approach by the CBC "when the market overreacts to an extreme extent," Perng said.
Arguing that central banks routinely intervene in the United States and Japan, Perng emphasized the questions of when and to what extent the government should step in.

He dismissed the problem of capital exodus, pointing out that Taiwan holds foreign assets totaling over US$160 billion, including US$90 billion in the government and US$70 billion in the private sector.
Most of these private sector's funds are invested in mainland China and Southeast Asian countries, while some have been funneled into the real estate markets in the United States, said Perng.

As to the coming launch of the single European currency, the euro, Perng said the central bank is weighing the possibility of converting part of the country's foreign reserves into euro, but he did not believe it will acquire a status equal to that of the greenback because of the relatively small share it has in the world's foreign reserves mix.
Perng made the remarks in defense of the CBC's NT$60.64 billion (US$1.86 billion) budget for fiscal year 1999 which cruised through the joint review of several committees on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE PLEDGES EFFORTS TO EXPAND TRADE TIES WITH FOREIGN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said the Republic of China will make three-pronged efforts to expand its trade and economic relations with foreign countries.

"We will aggressively seek to take part in international organizations, to increase exchanges and cooperation with foreign countries and to make contributions to the international community," Lee told a dinner party in honor of some 160 foreign ambassadors and representatives stationed in Taipei.
Lee also called on foreign countries to throw their support behind Taiwan's membership in the World Trade Organization.

He urged all countries and international organizations concerned to adopt effective measures to help weather the financial turmoil that has battered countries beyond Asia, including Latin America and Russia.
Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, who hosted the party at the Taipei Convention Center, thanked the foreign envoys for their support of Taiwan over the past year in the trade and economic arena.

He pointed out that Taiwan attended 21 regular governmental or non-governmental economic conferences with 21 countries, and struck strategic alliance relationships with over 60 leading international companies.

Wang said the Asian financial crisis will also serve as a turning point for the world to reform its existing economic and trading systems. He added that Taiwan hopes to enhance its cooperation with other countries so as to jointly create greater prosperity.
Citing President Lee's comments made at a charity fund-raising event on Nov. 24, Wang said, "Love is borderless as long as we keep the world in our heart."
He added that Taiwan will spare no effort to strengthen its ties with all countries to make the world better.

At the end of the party, Wang presented his guests with a crystal rabbit, an animal symbolizing swiftness, wisdom and optimism on the Chinese lunar calendar. The coming lunar new year in 1999 is the year of the rabbit. (Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Su Nan-cheng and Chen Chin-jang selected by ruling Kuomintang as the party's candidates for National Assembly speaker and deputy speaker, respectively.
The China Times:
Premier Vincent Siew is expected to be retained while part of his Cabinet will be reshuffled.
The United Daily News:
Four alternatives to compulsory military services to be introduced; The first is scheduled to take effect in July 2000.
The Liberty Times:
Premier Vincent Siew hints that his Cabinet may resign en masse on Feb. 1.
The Independence Morning Post:
Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang confirms that Su Nan-cheng and Chen Chin-jang are nominated as speaker and deputy speaker of the National Assembly.
The Commons Daily:
The Ministry of Finance reaches three-point consensus on measures to stabilize the local bourse.
The China Post:
'I shall return,' vows Taiwan Governor James Soong at final Taiwan provincial government meeting.
The China News:

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS FLOCK TO EXHIBITION OF ITEMS THOUGHT TO BE MADAME CHIANG'S
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By David Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Thousands of people, most of them Chinese, flocked to New York's Long Island last Sunday to view an exhibition of furniture and other household items in a residence once occupied by Madame Chiang Kai-shek, even though the objects on display had no connection with either Madame Chiang or the Republic of China government.

Some 4,000 people converged on the house, located on a 27-acre plot of land, in Long Island's Locust Valley. Protests from neighbors resulted in the pre-auction exhibition being wrapped up earlier than scheduled, as police tried in vain to clear clogged roads and maintain order. In all more than 20 police cars and helicopters were called in try to direct traffic.

The items, which are to be auctioned on Jan. 2-3 by Braswell Auction Company of New York, belong to the house's present owner, who bought the property from Madame Chiang's niece last year and who has put the house up for sale.
The sponsors of the exhibition were asked to call a halt to the activity, which was scheduled for Saturday through Monday.
An admission fee was charged on the exhibition's first day, in which about 400 people showed up. On Sunday admission was free and the number of visitors swelled tenfold.

Some of the people who visited the residence drove for five or six hours to see the exhibition, motivated mainly by their interest in Madame Chiang, who played an important role in the Republic of China's history during and after World War II.

But Kung Ling-yih, Madame Chiang's niece, sold the house last summer for a sum believed to be slightly less than US$3 million. After the sale, all of Madame Chiang's belongings were removed from the house.
The house has been put on the market by its owner, who expects to sell it for more than US$6 million.
