DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WRAPS UP 'LOVE' TRIP TO 4 CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that his visit to four Central American nations has expressed the love and concern felt for them by the Republic of China.
Lien made the remarks in a press conference after returning from a 10-day visit of the four Republic of China allies hard hit by Hurricane Mitch recently.

Lien led on a visit to the four nations a delegation, which left on Dec. 5, to express the ROC's love and concern for them and to submit substantial plans to help them rebuild after the ravages of the hurricane.

Lien said the visit by the delegation is significant in that it included charity, religious and industrial groups. The visit not only conveyed the concern of the ROC government but also showed the love of the ROC people toward its allies.
During his visit to Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala over the last 10 days, Lien observed that the level of damage varied from country to country, he said.
Lien added that it is hard to comprehend the degree of damage, the death toll and the number of people injured in the two most seriously hit countries, Nicaragua and Honduras.

Lien said that after the hurricane, droves of countries came to the rescue of the four nations, but the wave has since subsided. The visit by the ROC delegation was warmly welcomed by the four Central American allies.

The vice president is also positive of enthusiastic responses from private groups called on to participate in the relief efforts, adding that "love knows no boundary, and the heart of Taiwan goes toward the world."
Lien said that his visit to Central America also reflects President Lee Teng-hui's idea of people diplomacy.

He said that a nation of love will not be alone, and a nation of love will not be isolated, noting that even the US government has lauded the Republic of China as a country that exports love, adding that he was proud of the nation and its people.
At the press conference, Lien was again asked if he intends to run for president in 2000.

Lien, considered an heir apparent to President Lee Teng-hui, would not answer the question directly, saying only that the most important thing now is to "talk less and do more," adding that the time is "not yet ripe" to announce anything on the matter.

As to why the ROC government did not do more to provide relief to flood victims in mainland China, Lien stressed that private groups from Taiwan have more than once traveled to the mainland to assist in relief efforts in the past. The ROC government itself could not get involved directly in relief efforts because of political concerns, he said.
The aid to Central America was purely out of humanitarian, not pragmatic, concern, Lien said in response to suggestions that diplomacy has taken precedence over cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 15, or Oct. 27 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1711: Plague breaks out in Copenhagen, Denmark.
1806: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte enter Warsaw, Poland.
1915: Taiwan's noted folklore writer, Chung Li-ho, is born.
1916: French defeat Germans in the Battle of Verdun in World War I.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires in the interests of party unity.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under the Sino-American tung oil loan agreement.
1946: The United Nations General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC's Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1965: The US Mariner spacecraft relays to Earth data about Venus as it flies past the planet.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the American animator, showman, and film producer known as "Walt," dies at the age of 65.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to The International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1979: Deposed shah of Iran flies from the United States to exile in Panama.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The United Nations General Assembly calls overwhelmingly for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: British and Irish leaders sign a complex framework for negotiating peace in Northern Ireland, ending 25 years of conflict.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, which gives more autonomy to colleges and allows students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jing-sheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
Confucius: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty towards them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY HAS MATURED: US SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's recent "three-in-one" elections shows that its democracy has matured, said Stephen Yates and Robert Sutter, two US experts on Chinese affairs, on Monday.

Yates, a senior policy analyst with the Heritage Foundation, a US think-tank, said at a round-table discussion held by the foundation that the US government is likely to make a statement in support of Taiwan's participation in international organizations during the next Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) review, which is an annual event.

The US government's attitude toward the Taiwan question is still that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should solve their disputes through "peaceful means," said Yates. Democracy is gaining in significance in discussions about the Taiwan question, which indicates that the will of the Taiwan people will be respected to a greater extent, he said.
But the US government's conservative attitude toward changing the TRA suggests a supplement, rather than an amendment, will be added to it, he said.

Meanwhile, Sutter, a senior researcher at the United States' Library of Congress, said the US administration has "shaved" its relations with Taiwan during the past 30 years in order to establish cordial ties with mainland China. But Taiwan's democratic development will make it harder for the US government to maintain this policy, he said.

Sutter called on Taiwan to be a "responsible" democracy and to work to prevent large-scale military conflicts. Taiwan must not provoke any military attacks from the mainland, he said, adding that a responsible Taiwan is the precondition for stable US-ROC relations.

Both men commented on the "new Taiwanese" concept espoused recently by ROC President Lee Teng-hui. Yates said the idea reflects the maturation of the Taiwan people's sense of self-identity, though he said the issue should not be over emphasized so as not to annoy Beijing.

Sutter added that while the "new Taiwanese concept" is widely supported in Taiwan, the New Party's advocacy of unification is "dead." Although this does not amount to a push for Taiwan independence, it does show increased support for the separatism of Taiwan from mainland China, Sutter said.

Concerning a re-election bid by President Lee, Sutter noted that several people, including officials within the ruling Kuomintang, consider such a move possible, especially if it appears the surest means of preventing a victory by the most likely candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Chen Shui-bian. Both Sutter and Yates, however, said that there is less than a 10-percent chance Lee will run again.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONTARIO TO OUTLAW BUDGET DEFICITS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Angel Liu) (By S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The premier said all Cabinet ministers, including the premier, who run a deficit will be fined 25 percent of their pay. Subsequent deficits would result in a 50 percent pay cut.

The legislation stipulates that politicians will not be able to hike taxes or create new taxes without voter approval by referendum. That idea is modeled on a similar law in the province of Manitoba. Four other provinces have also banned government deficits. "You can't just keep taking more and more and more of taxpayers' money," he told a news conference. "Families work hard to manage their household budgets and make ends meet," he said. "The government should manage taxpayers' money the same way." The legislation fulfills one of the last major promises outlined in the Ontario Conservative Party's Common Sense Revolution, the campaign blueprint they used to gain power in 1995. Harris provided details of the Balanced Budget and Taxpayer's Protection Act during an informal meeting with a group of taxpayers Monday morning at a Toronto coffee shop. The new law is aimed at preventing future governments from "recklessly spending their way into deficit," he said.
Harris also said he wants a constitutional amendment to force all Canadian governments to always balance their budgets.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STRUGGLES AS GLOBAL PRICES CRASHING (1)

TEXT.P: Australia is struggling after the crash of global commodities prices to 21-year lows last weekend and the country's exporters, particularly exporters of coal, oil, nickel and copper, are growing increasingly worried in the face of shrinking sales and plunging profits.
Industry analysts said Australia's coal exporters are expected to substantially reduce export volumes, as some of their main markets, such as Japan, are in recession.
To make matters worse, the prices of crude oil, copper, nickel and aluminum have also dropped, which has further impacted Australia's economy.

Precious metal prices are also softer, cotton prices have crashed to five-year lows and grain markets have retreated as well -- pushing all commodities-listed company prices lower on the Australian stock market.

Two major coal producers -- Shell Australia and MIM Holdings Ltd. -- have been forced to reduce the price of their coking coal by as much as 18 percent to win contracts from Japanese steel mills after a series of hard-fought negotiations between Australian exporters and Japanese buyers.
They said other major coal companies, including BHP Coal Ltd., will have to follow the lead of Shell and MIM and substantially reduce the prices of their coking coal to win Japanese orders.

The 18 percent drop is expected to cost Australia about US$1.3 billion in export revenue, and it could even force some mines to shut down, analysts said. Shell and MIM have agreed to lower their coking coal prices by US$5.60 a ton to US$25.60 per ton, they said.
The report of a sharp cut in coal prices on Monday affected Australia's financial and securities markets, driving the All Ordinaries Index down 53.5 points on Monday to close at 2,676.5.
The Australian currency also ended lower, dropping 0.23 US cents to close at 61.85 US cents during the same period.

The Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union on Sunday night launched a two-day strike in order to pressure the government to intervene to demand that coal mining firms secure contracts before developing new mines or expanding existing ones so that production will not greatly exceed demand.
The union has claimed that there is an excess of 20 million tons in Australia's coal production. This has driven down prices in international markets and could cost jobs, they said.

A spokesman for Australian Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith has condemned the strike, saying it has not only resulted in a production stoppage but has also hurt Australia's image as a reliable supplier of coal and other energy products.
"All they are doing is threatening our reputation as a reliable supplier, and they are putting in jeopardy their members' jobs," he said. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STRUGGLES AS GLOBAL PRICES CRASHING (2)

TEXT.P: The Australian Coal Association said the market outlook in the traditional market in Asia is very tough because the Japanese steel industry is still depressed.
Coal is Australia's important export earner and Japan is its largest market, followed by Taiwan and South Korea.

Australian iron ore producers and thermal coal producers will also face a similar fate and encounter difficult negotiations with Japanese steel mills and power utilities this week, analysts predicted.
Japan's coal imports from Australia are expected to drop by as much as 30 percent because its steel production is set to fall to 92 million from 102 million tons next year.

Demand for Australian coal from other countries, including Taiwan and Korea, is expected to drop because their economic growth rates are slowing as a result of the impact from the Asian financial crisis.
Crude steel production in the West in October also fell nearly 7 percent year-on-year, the biggest monthly decline since January 1987, analysts said.

This has made it a tough environment for any suppliers of raw materials to the steel industry. These include the iron ore suppliers, which are lined up for discussions with Japanese steel mills, they said.

Gold prices also fell, though the fall was not much smaller than those of most other commodities. Australia is the world's third-largest gold producer and exporter with an annual production of about 300 tons.

Analysts believe commodity prices could fall still further because of no apparent supply adjustment as Japan and other major Asian countries are set to reduce production of their steel and other industrial products in response to weakening demand.

Oil prices are also on a downward trend due to slackening demand and the inability by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce daily production in order to rein in prices, analysts said.

So far cotton prices have dropped by nearly one-fourth over the past five months, and they are now at their lowest levels in five years. This does not bode well for Australia's struggling wool industry, they said.
In the United States, orders for aluminum sheets and plates in October were down a year-on-year 16 percent. Total orders from the United States for mill products were down 6 percent, analysts said.

The base-metal markets have fared poorly as well, as copper prices have fallen to their lowest levels since May 1987, while nickel is at its lowest level in nearly 12 years. Aluminum, meanwhile, is at its lowest level since February 1994, they said.
"The past two months have brought a considerable deterioration in the orders for copper and aluminum products in Europe and the USA," said commodity analysts.
Commodities sales account for about 60 percent of Australia's overall exports, so lower commodity prices and slackening demand could affect the country's economy, they said.
"Australia is entering a difficult time now and it will be a long way for us to substantially reduce dependence on commodities," one analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT TUNNEL 30 YEARS AWAY: MAINLAND EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Disregarding political and economic factors, a tunnel linking Taiwan and mainland China could be built in 30 years, the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Po daily quoted mainland experts as saying on Tuesday.

In a purely construction point of view, it would take about 30 years to build the tunnel if the governments and private sectors on both sides of the Taiwan Strait work together, the pro-Beijing daily quoted Professor Fang Hueijian and Professor Wu Zhiming as saying. The professors are part of a mainland Chinese academic group studying the feasibility of a cross-Taiwan Strait undersea tunnel.
It is hoped that Qinghua University of Beijing and National Taiwan University will collaborate to jointly study the development of an undersea tunnel, the Wen Wei Po article said.
Taiwan is separated from the Chinese mainland by the Taiwan Strait which is about 220 kilometers at its widest point and 130 kilometers at its narrowest.

According to Wu, mainland Chinese experts have identified four possible routes that a cross-strait tunnel can be built. One links Fujian province's Pingtan and Taiwan's Hsinchu, the second links Fujian's Nanri and Taiwan's Miaoli, the third links Fujian's Jinjiang and Taiwan's Nantou, and the fourth links Taiwan's front-line Kinmen Island, which is located off mainland China's Fujian province, and Taiwan's Chiayi.
The linking or starting points across the strait were chosen in consideration of their geographical and geological characteristics, as well as their transportation and economic functions.
Wu said he personally favors the first route which he described as the most feasible and cost-efficient to build.

If planning were to begin today, it would take about 16 years for the first-stage of research and designing work to be completed, and another 16 years will be required for the actual construction and trial, Wu said. It would mean that cars could be expected to drive across the Taiwan Strait by 2030, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FEARS DEMOCRACY INFECTION FROM TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taipei may worry about an unlikely mainland Chinese invasion, but the old men in Beijing have far more to fear from the democratic virus drifting across the Taiwan Strait, a major Canadian newspaper commented Monday.

The Globe and Mail was commenting on Taiwan's latest elections, held on Dec. 5, saying the vote was "free and fair, the campaign was intense and vigorous, and national and international media were unhindered by state censorship. Just another day in the democratic China."

"Or just another day in the China that is democratic: the Republic of China, otherwise known as Taiwan." The piece, written by Anthoy Keller, assistant editor of the paper's editorial board, appeared in The Globe and Mail's "Free Expression" column.

He noted that Taiwan has had free elections for more than a decade. "Year after year, Taiwan successfully practices the democratic politics that China -- or rather mainland China, the People's Republic -- has always maintained is unsuitable to the Chinese people," he pointed out.

In Taiwan registering political parties and sending out political publications over the Internet is "how you play politics, not how you end up in jail," he said, referring to Beijing's arrests of Wang Youcai and Lin Hai.
Taiwan's democracy is far from perfect, but these imperfections can be discussed openly in the media, thereby helping to bring about changes that deepen democracy's foundations, Keller said.

He quoted the once-vilified Chiang Kai-shek as saying, "The kind of freedom and way of life that people enjoy on Taiwan have not only become the object of envy and hope for their compatriots on the Communist mainland, but more important, the assurance [that] the great enterprise of anti-Communist national recovery and restoration shall be realized in the near future."
Though Chiang was long ago discredited by his critics, yet on this point about China's future "he was probably right," according to Keller.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY SUBSTITUTIVE SERVICE TO BE ENACTED IN 2000

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has drafted a substitutive military services plan to address the excess in manpower that will result from a new streamlined conscription plan by the Ministry of National Defense (MND).
The new plan is to be implemented in 2000, ministry officials said on Monday.

Under the plan, those who fail their military physicals, as well as those who constitute an excess in manpower, may be assigned to serve under one of four different categories designed by the MOI's Conscription Department: national defense and construction, social security, public health and social services.
Service terms would range from two years to three years.

Under the streamlined conscription plan of the MND, the MOI and the MND have agreed to determine by drawing lots who may opt for substitutive service. A preliminary calculation indicates some 20,000 people may serve in the substitutive services.

Under the national defense and construction category, a "technological service" suggested by Academia Sinica will be included. Due to the difficulty of this type of service, applicants will be admitted into the program not by random drawing but based on their qualifications.
The social security services category comprises service in either fire or police departments. As this type of service tends to be more dangerous, the service term would last only two years.

Those who are unwilling to serve in the military service for religious reasons may work in the social service sector for a period of three years. The MOI will draft regulations to ensure that people do not come to view a stint in this sector as a way of dodging traditional military service.

As this plan involves several ministries and departments, the MOI will therefore establish a special committee to keep track of the manpower needs of various institutes and handle the substitutive service assignments for all counties, as well as for the cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Payment for those in the substitutive service will be on a par with what those performing conventional military service earn.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% SAY CAMPAIGN LITERATURE DOESN'T AFFECT VOTE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of respondents in a recent survey said campaign literature did not affect their decision of which candidate they would support, the results released on Tuesday said.
The survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University at the commission of the Quality Life Foundation.
Chien Hsi-chieh, president of the foundation and an opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislator, said local elections typically require astronomical spending by each candidate.
Such practices have stopped many enthusiastic candidates and minority groups from taking part in politics, he said.
To improve the quality of elections, Chien suggested that legislation be drafted to set a ceiling on campaign literature and provide equal access to media among the candidates from all parties.
According to the survey, up to 60 percent of those polled believe that elections cost a lot of money compared with only 10 percent who said they do not cost much money.
Some 41 percent of those polled said candidates must spend a lot of money if they want to be elected.

Nearly 70 percent of respondents said campaign literature does not affect their decision of which candidate they will support. The ratio of DPP and New Party supporters in this category is much higher than Kuomintang supporters, according to the poll results.
Among all the campaign tools, 39.4 percent said they believed television ads have the greatest impact on voters, while the influence of flags and banners was less than 2 percent.

Over 67 percent said the legislature should set a ceiling on the number of campaign literature a candidate can produce, and the government should provide equal access of electronic and graphic media to candidates.

Regarding the effect of the large quantity of campaign literature has on the environment, 44.9 percent said the impact was "big." The effect on the city's landscape and the waste of valuable resources were ranked 1st and 2nd on the list of bad effects.

On whether campaign activities have any good effects, 28.1 percent said they can advance democracy while 26.4 percent said they are beneficial to public understanding of policy and administrative ideals.
Poll respondents said the bad effects of campaign activities included the proliferation of rumors and smear campaigns (35 percent), and the waste of resources (13.1 percent).

The survey was conducted between Dec. 7 and 8, after the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections. It offered questionnaires to 23 counties and cities across the island and received 1,087 valid responses with a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed NT$0.007 to the US dollar in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 32.251.
The local currency opened at 32.253 and was traded between 32.236 and 32.255.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$331 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN PROUD OF 'LOVE MISSION' TO CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan should be proud of the love and care the ROC mission conveyed to the four hurricane-hit Central American countries, Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday.

Lien made the remarks in a news conference at the Taipei Guest House after returning from a 10-day visit to Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador, which were seriously devastated by Hurricane Mitch in October.

Lien, at the head of a delegation composed of ranking government officials and representatives from private charity and religious organizations, offered financial aid and presented concrete reconstruction assistance and projects to the four Central American countries.
The ROC mission's donations and assistance were not only warmly received by hurricane victims, but were also highly praised by the international community.

According to Lien, Nicaragua and Honduras were the hardest hit. The damage and devastation caused by Mitch in the countries' agriculture, public construction, property and lives of the local residents were beyond imagination, he noted.

In Honduras, more than 7,000 people were killed and around 15,000 remain missing. A city mayor lost his life during a damage-control tour, and the Honduran Education Ministry building was washed away by torrential rain, Lien continued.

About 80 percent of the ROC delegates also fell sick after touring the "land of death" in those four countries, as described by the international media, Lien noted. Many victims' bodies in some areas were not yet buried, and everything within eyesight was highly polluted, he added.

The "quick and comprehensive" love and care that the ROC delegation demonstrated has touched many people and their countries, the ROC vice president claimed, stressing that such an act is without border and has put to practice the type of "all out push by all people" toward pragmatic diplomacy President Lee Teng-hui has advocated.
"A country with love will never be left alone, and we are very proud that Taiwan is a 'love export' country," Lien said.
Speaking of his transit stops in the United States, Lien said he was well treated and there were no difficulties experienced during his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO FINANCE CRISIS-HIT SME'S

TEXT.P: Government officials and representatives from small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will attend a meeting hosted by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday to address the financing of troubled companies.
Several large conglomerates in Taiwan have experienced financial problems recently, leaving their SME business partners affected as well, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said.

The MOEA has planned several measures to help bail out troubled SMEs. Plans include providing loans, assisting them with production technology, offering research and development as well as marketing and accounting, officials noted.

Taiwan's economic growth is expected to remain above 5 percent in 1999, the ministry said, adding that SMEs can combat the economic downturn if the MOEA's expansion policy is successfully implemented.

An estimated NT$20 billion (US$620 million) worth of business opportunities will be created by MOEA's expansion policy, said officials from the Medium and Small Business Administration under the MOEA. Under the plan, SMEs will be offered investment opportunities in the government's purchases of civil engineering, office facilities, and computers.

The government will spend some NT$460 billion annually on this expansion policy, MOEA officials said. On top of this expenditure, an estimated NT$1 trillion will be added to accelerate its implementation in 1999 and 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATRIATES TAKE TO THE STREETS OVER RESIDENCE ISSUE

TEXT.P: About a dozen expatriates, mostly foreigners working in Taiwan and those with local spouses, took to the streets on Tuesday to fight for their children's right to reside in Taiwan.

The group, waving banners saying "We love Taiwan," "Our foreign spouses are new Taiwanese," and "No age restriction on permanent residence," converged at the Legislative Yuan where they appealed to lawmakers to not let their children become "international orphans."

They said Taiwan's restriction against automatic residence to children of international parents violated the principles of human rights. They demanded an overall amendment to the Republic of China's statutes governing immigration and relevant affairs.

Under existing ROC laws, children of international couples enjoy no automatic rights of residence in Taiwan and can legally stay in Taiwan until they are 20. After that age, they become foreigners illegally staying in Taiwan. Children of ROC-national women who are married to foreigners are also not entitled to ROC nationality.

Wang Chu-huei, chairperson of the Taiwan-Japan International Exchange Promotion Association, said under existing ROC rules, if the father of children from an international marriage is an ROC national, the children will receive their ROC citizen identification card by the age of 10 and are later able to work legally when they are older.

But children who have mothers of ROC nationality and foreign fathers are not that lucky, Wang said. They cannot stay after they are 20, and there is no mention of their legal rights to work in Taiwan.
Wang said the practice is not only violating international human rights, it is a form of sexual discrimination as well.

Wang and others argued that there is no age restriction on expatriates' application for permanent residence in the United States, Japan, Canada and Britain. They appealed to the ROC government to amend relevant immigration statutes which rule that children of international marriages can apply for permanent residence in Taiwan only after they are 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARITY ORGANIZATION GIVES THANKS TO TAIWAN CONTRIBUTORS

TEXT.P: Each donation from Taiwan is helping people all over the world wherever the sun rises, World Vision International (WVI) President Dean Hirsch said on Tuesday in giving his thanks to Taiwan residents.

Hirsch, who is currently visiting Taiwan prior to the World Vision of Taiwan's 35th anniversary next month, said about 51,000 donors from Taiwan have helped more than 10 million poor children around the world over the past. He added that he would like to express his appreciation to the Taiwan public personally.
Hirsch, who was speaking at a news conference, said the WVI's 1999 world campaign hopes to find 3,500 new Taiwan sponsors for an additional 10,000 underprivileged children in other countries.

According to the WVI president, a total of 1.4 billion children live in poverty worldwide because of war and an average of 35,000 children die from malnutrition and disease every day around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF MEETS WITH JOURNALISTS IN NY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made considerable progress in democratization as can be seen from the "three-in-one" elections held on Dec. 5, Director General Chen Chien-jen of the Government Information Office said here Monday.

Voters went to the polls on that day to elect members of the Legislative Yuan as well as the mayors and city councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung. Voter turnout was about 80 percent. The ruling Koumintang won an absolute majority in the Legislative Yuan and continued to be the majority party in the councils of the two cities.

Chen said the elections have won the applause of opinion leaders at home and abroad. The results of the elections have indicated that most voters want stability, progress, prosperity, and reform, and that they have confidence in the ruling party's moderate and effective policies and reform programs.
He also said that the government will vigorously carry out its policies, including the policy to improve cross-strait and international relations.
He made the remarks when he met with Chinese-language media reporters in New York.
Chen, who arrived here Sunday, is busy visiting American news media leaders in the city. He will leave here for Washington Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES AUSTRALIAN GOODWILL AMBASSADOR TAN LE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received Australia's goodwill ambassador Tan Le on Tuesday.

President Lee welcomed Le and said he hoped she will introduce aspects of Australia's diverse culture and society here as well as enlighten people in Taiwan about the living situation of Australia's population.
President Lee added that Australia now has a reputation for discriminating against foreigners, and Australians should spare no effort to eradicate such misunderstandings.
Ties between the Republic of China and Australia have made great progress in recent years as trade, investment, and tourism between the two sides have increased, Lee said.
Although Australia's natural resources makes it a suitable country for investment, it is the country's diverse society and culture that are major factors that attracts foreign funds, Lee said.
Le, agreeing with the president, said during her visit she hoped to gain insight into the ROC's culture and folklore in an effort to make various exchange between the two sides more cohesive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS TO BUY MORE PATRIOT MISSILES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to purchase additional Patriot defense systems to enhance its anti-missile capability, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense confirmed on Tuesday.
Taiwan already has three sets of the US-made Patriot anti-missile systems deployed in the northern part of the island.
If the purchase goes through as planned, the new missiles will be deployed in the central and southern parts of the island, Major General Chiang Ming, a senior ministry official, said.
Mainland Chinese missiles still pose a great threat to Taiwan, he said, "But it would be the people's psychology that is the most fragile in case of a Beijing missile attack."

Beijing's missile test-firings in waters around Taiwan in the run-up to Taiwan's presidential election in early 1996 caused panic in the island, sending the local foreign exchange and stock markets into a nose-dive.
The mainland's middle-range M-family missiles is currently the greatest threat to Taiwan, but such missiles would cause only limited damage to the island, Chiang said.

For example, an M-family missile with a 500 kg warhead would create a hole only 10 meters in depth and 20 meters in width after hitting the ground. If were the case, it would take at least 50 missiles to destroy a military airport, he explained.
Currently, Beijing owns 200 M-9 (DF-15) missiles and 48 M-11 (DF-11) missiles, which have a range of 600 kilometers and 300 kilometers, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENTS TO DEMONSTRATE AT U.N.

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissidents will stage a demonstration outside the United Nations headquarters in New York Thursday to highlight the trial of dissidents Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin in mainland China on the same day.

An organizer told the press that the demonstrators will urge people in the free world to give Wang and Qin a helping hand, protest against the imprisonment of other dissidents and Christians in mainland China, and urge the Beijing regime to release all political prisoners.

Wang has been arrested for his efforts to form the would-be China Democracy Party (CDP), while Qin was arrested for publishing the newsletter "China Human Rights Observer." If it is eventually established with government approval, the CDP will be the first opposition party in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA SET TO DECLARE CHRISTMAS CEASE-FIRE WITH REBELS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government is set to declare a 45-day cease-fire with communist rebels which will begin Tuesday at midnight, according to reports.

President Joseph Estrada is expected to approve a recommendation by Gen. Joselin Nazareno, chief of staff of the armed forces of the Philippines, to continue the yearly tradition of holding a Christmas truce with rebel groups, Executive Secretary Ronaldo Zamora said.

"We're communicating this with the president. We expect the president will approve this sometime this afternoon, so by midnight tonight this should be effective," Zamora said after a meeting of the Office of the President Executive Committee in Malacanang on Tuesday.

Zamora chairs the committee, a multi-agency body tasked by Estrada to advise him on critical national issues while he is abroad. The president is currently in Vietnam to attend the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 6th leaders summit.

Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense stressed that the cease-fire does not cover regular law enforcement activities and security functions undertaken by the police and military to ensure peace and social order.
He said the government has yet to receive a response from the National Democratic Front Communist Party of the Philippines New People's Army over the truce.
Under the terms of the cease-fire, the government will suspend offensive military operations against the National Democratic Front and all its factions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TRADE BETWEEN OFFSHORE ISLANDS, MAINLAND NOT PERMITTED: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will not open offshore islands to low-level trade with mainland China, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Tuesday.
Chang made the remarks in response to questions by Tsaur Eel-jong of the ruling Kuomintang in the Legislative Yuan.
Tsaur asked the MAC to address the issue of allowing offshore island residents to trade in small amounts with their counterparts on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
Although Taipei bans all direct trade with the mainland, it is an open secret that offshore island residents have been trading fish and agricultural products with people from the mainland.
The government must first consider cross-strait relations, Chang said, as the offshore islands shoulder the responsibility of guarding the safety of Taiwan.

He also said the reason why there are still no "three direct links" -- no direct trade, communication and transportation links -- between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is because the time is not yet ripe for such links.
A "small amount of trade" is basically smuggling, the MAC chairman said, adding that such activities have created new problems for both sides.

Chang explained that the "go slow, be patient" policy was not targeted at the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu, but was mainly aimed at the large investments in the mainland which has little to do with trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 CASES OF INDIGENOUS HEMORRHAGIC DENGUE FEVER FOUND IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: Two cases of indigenous hemorrhagic dengue fever were reported in Tainan, leading the Department of Health to issue a warning to residents to prevent the further spread of the disease, reports said on Tuesday.
Symptoms include headaches, painful joints, and most noticeably, hemorrhaging beneath the skin. Dengue fever is transmitted by mosquito carriers.
The National Institute of Preventive Medicine said the mortality rate for adult victims of hemorrhagic dengue fever range from 10 percent to 30 percent, while that for infants is a mere 50 percent.

There are four different types of dengue fever and they are not immune to each other, which means a victim of one type of tengue fever can be susceptible to another type thereby exacerbating their condition.

Repeated infections to dengue fever can also make a victim more susceptible to the dangerous hemorrhagic tengue fever, the institute warned, as some victims can develop an allergic reaction to the disease.
Up to now, a total of 71 cases of dengue fever have been reported in Tainan, exceeding the 51 cases reported in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: AN FENG KINGSTREAM TARGETS TAIWAN AS KEY BUYER AFTER RESTRUCTURING

TEXT.P: An Feng Kingstream will continue to target Taiwan as its major market following its restructuring which frees the group from its Taiwan entity under a new deal.

The Australian Associated Press on Monday reported An Feng Kingstream will lose its chief shareholders and its 92.3 percent stake in the Kaohsiung-based An Feng Steel Co. after the group implements a fresh debt and equity plan to turn around a first-half loss of about A$111.6 million (US$77 million).
The deal puts a cloud over the future of An Feng Kingstream's proposed A$1.5 billion Midwest Iron and Steel Project at Oakajee in Western Australia.

Despite its restructure, An Feng Kingstream will target Taiwan as its main export market, selling about 2 million tonnes of steel slab a year to An Feng Steel at a commercial price after its mill comes on stream by 2000.
However, the restructure will see the cancellation of up to 435.8 million or 64.7 percent of An Feng Kingstream's fully paid ordinary shares.

Under the new deal, An Feng Kingstream will acquire and cancel the 435.8 million shares from its major stockholders, Chu An-hsiung and his wife, Wu Teh-wei. In turn, An Feng Kingstream will transfer back to Wu Teh-mei its 92.3 percent stake in An Feng Steel Co.
All loans owed by An Feng Kingstream to An Feng Steel or any associated party will be forgiven in full and all unexercised options held by Wu Teh-mei in An Feng Kingstream will be canceled.

Wu Teh-mei's interest in An Feng Kingstream will be dismantled, but other Taiwanese shareholders, including Central Investment Holdings Co., Ltd., would remain as shareholders of the steel group, the AAP reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARMING TREND COULD DESTABILIZE CANADA'S NORTH

TEXT.P: Warmer temperatures in Canada's northern region could displace wildlife, increase pollution and destabilize infrastructure across the country's sub-Arctic, a study warned on Monday.

"The Canada Country Study," released by Canada's Department of Environment, outlined how northern indigenous people would be affected by the ecosystem shifts that may be outside the limits of historical experiences.

Warmer temperatures could reduce the size and stability of ice floes which may push many species out of traditional habitats. Also, over many years forest ranges could spread further north, reducing range land available to caribou herds.

Hunters, fishers and trappers depend on their knowledge of animal migration, snowfall patterns, and timing of freeze-up and breakup. Changes in climate make it almost impossible for hunters to know where to find game and when the ice is safe to hunt on.
Many Inuit communities depend on hunting as both a source of income and protein. If less fresh meat is available, the Inuit would likely suffer from less nutritious food.
In the northwest corner of the Northwest Territories, where the MacKenzie River flows into the Beaufort Sea, temperatures have been nine degrees Celsius above normal this year.
One of the few benefits of major ice-melting could free up the Northwest Passage for shipping, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CAPABLE OF SUSTAINING HIGH GROWTH: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Mainland China will not be derailed in its economic growth rate and can maintain growth of 7 percent to 10 percent for several more decades, a prominent Australian economist said on Monday.

However, Professor Ross Garnaut, director of the Asia Pacific School of Economics and Management at the Australian National University in Canberra, warned that mainland China will not be able to sustain the current deficits it is running to offset recessionary effects of the Asian financial crisis.

He said as in the past 20 years, "the realization of the national and personal benefits of growth and of the conditions that sustain it will be sufficiently widespread and strong to return China to a growth path whenever it is temporarily knocked from it."

He said the mainland's average 7 percent to 10 percent growth in the past two decades will be sustained for several more decades. "Output will double each decade. In another two decades, China will be the world's second largest economy by conventional national account measures in output and foreign trade, or third if the European Union by then is seen as a single entity," he said.

Garnaut said Asia's financial crisis was the greatest external challenge of the past 20 years to the mainland's stability and growth. But it had come at a good time because mainland's inflation was low, the balance of payments was in strong current account surplus, its foreign reserves were high and foreign direct investment was high, he said.

"So far, China has had a good crisis, sustaining growth at high levels (although slightly down from the 20-year average) in the second half of 1998 through massive fiscal expansion, and winning much international kudos for this and for holding the pre-crisis US dollar value of the renminbi," he said.

The economist added that it was unlikely that economic, political and social problems would "crystallize into a collapse of growth in the East Asian crisis. But there will be plenty of other risks and challenges, some arising when China is less well placed to handle them than in 1997."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMES SECOND LARGEST INVESTOR IN MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan investment in Malaysia totaled US$8,490 million as of the end of September, making it the second largest investing country in Malaysia, an official said here Monday.

Tzou Chi-kuo, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia, also said that there are now 1,500 Taiwan investors operating in Malaysia, and that two-way trade between the two countries amounted to US$7,250 million last year. A total of 246,000 Taiwan tourists visited Malaysian cities last year, an increase of 10 percent over a year earlier, he added.

He said the amount of Taiwan investments approved by Industrial Development Bureau of Malaysia in the first seven months of this year reached US$583 million, a hike of 27 percent over the same period of 1997. The increase was 89 percent, when calculated in Malaysian dollar.
These figures indicate that Taiwan investment in this country keeps growing amid the Asian financial crisis, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EURO LIKELY TO DECREASE TRADERS' EXPOSURE TO EXCHANGE RATE RISKS

TEXT.P: The introduction of the euro, the single European currency, on Jan. 1 will decrease Taiwan traders' exposure to fluctuating foreign exchange rates, said Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade on Tuesday.

In a seminar organized by a local business association to inform businessmen how to take advantage of the new currency, Chen, who just returned from Europe, said the launch of the euro is the most important international event after the Y2K computer issue. Many European restaurants have already reprinted their menus with euro prices.

Noting that the deutschemark is the strongest and the lira the weakest currency in Europe, Chen said the circulation of the euro will cut red tape and the cost of trading with European states by sparing dealers the trouble of exchanging currencies.

Chen said the birth of the euro will consolidate the strength of the European Union which with a population of 295 million people and an economy of US$6.57 trillion, is almost the equal to the United States in terms of market size. Taiwan investors should diversify their business by aggressively exploring European markets, he added.

Na Ho-chung, a vice manager of the Taipei Branch of Deutsche Bank, predicted at the seminar that the euro, currently fixed at about US$1.10, will compete with the greenback as a tender of international trade and a reserve currency. He said it will probably replace the dollar's role in 35 percent of the world's international trade in the first year of its debut.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S RICHEST MAN & BIGGEST GAMBLER IN BID TO BUY CASINO

TEXT.P: Australia's richest man and one of the world's leading gamblers, Kerry Packer, has offered to buy the financially troubled Crown Casino in Melbourne.

In the past, Packer has been thwarted in his efforts to buy a casino, including Star City Casino in Sydney. This time, he is determined to cash in on Crown Casino, the largest gambling operation in the Oceania and one of the largest in the world.
Packer plans to buy a 37 percent stake in the casino in exchange for a 5.5 percent stake in his Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd. media empire and he plans to merge the two companies.

The latest offer is Packer's second attempt since shareholders of Crown Casino turned his first offer about three months ago. But the second offer is designed to buy out Crown's chairman Lloyd Williams, Packer's close friend.

The offer is worth about A$750 million (US$470 million), up from Packer's initial offer to buy the casino at about US$290 million in September. Gambling industry experts said the offer was too good for Williams and other shareholders to refuse.
For years, Packer's exploits at the gambling tables in Las Vegas, Europe and Australia, of winning or losing tens of millions of dollars a night have been legendary.

On one of his visits to Las Vegas, Packer sent the desert town into a frenzy as he made away with about US$27 million from one of the casinos, making him a formidable gambler feared by gambling operators not only in the US, but in other countries as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMY SET TO GROW FASTER WITH LOW INFLATION

TEXT.P: Australia's economy is performing better than many Asian countries as its growth rate will reach 4 percent in 1998 which is higher than the earlier forecast of 3 percent, the governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia said.

Speaking at the House of Representatives on Tuesday, Ian Macfarlane said the current account deficit appears to average at 5 percent of the country's gross domestic products in calendar 1998, which is lower than 5.5 percent projected earlier.
Australia's inflation is low at 2 percent and the unemployment rate has continued to edge down rather than staying flat, he said.
Macfarlane said in a statement faxed to the CNA that the country's economic performance exceeded the bank's expectations and those of virtually all other forecasters.
He attributed the economic performance to several factors. One was the timing. The Asian crisis hit at a time when the Australian economy was in good shape, partly for cyclical reasons.
Australia benefited from the flexibility of its exporters who switched from the contracting Asian markets into the expanding North American and European ones and into a number of other markets.
Australia also benefited from a greatly improved perception of the soundness of its economic policies, including good regulation of banks, other financial institutions and stock exchanges.

The country's economy seems to be more flexible and adaptable than before because of rising productivity. Another reason is the depreciation of the Australian dollar against the US dollar, which has helped local exporters improve their competitive edge in the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-5F CRASH DUE TO BIRDS, BAD WEATHER, BROKEN ENGINE: AIR FORCE

TEXT.P: Flying birds, bad weather conditions and a broken down engine were the factors that caused an air force F-5F fighter to crash in early December, air force headquarters said on Tuesday.

Chin Ping-ho, head of the flight security department of the air force headquarters inspection office, said at a news conference held by the Ministry of National Defense that investigators found the blood and carcasses of birds inside the crashed fighter's engine.

In addition, bad weather conditions on the night of the training mission led to low visibility. There was also an instant breakdown of the left engine and hydraulic system, which contributed to the accident, Chin said.
The F-5F fighter crashed on Dec. 3 as it was making its way back to the Chihhang air base in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, killing the pilot and co-pilot.

Air force headquarters urged residents living near the air base not to breed pigeons and urged authorities concerned to crack down on the illegal breeding of pigeons in a bid to maintain general aviation safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES AND FUTURES REBOUND

TEXT.P: Share prices rebounded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, boosted by the government's commitment to support the market.
Buying by the government stock stabilization fund encouraged the confidence of investors despite a big drop on Wall Street, whose stock trading has been a weathercock of Taiwan investors.
TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key indicator, climbed 47.32 points to close at the day's high of 6,936.82.
The bourse opened at 6,847.01 points and fell as low as 6,752.5.
A total of 1.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.28 billion (US$2.09 billion), against the previous session's of NT$50.66 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 261 to 136, with 92 issues unchanged.
There were more gains than losses among the eight major stock categories, with textile shares posting the largest appreciation of 3.7 percent.

Plastic and chemical stocks surged 3.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares, which moved up 1.8 percent; construction issues, 0.7 percent; cement issues, 0.3 percent; and electronic engineering stocks, 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff shares dropped 0.4 percent, and financial stocks posted a modest loss of 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter stock market registered a 0.77-point rise to close at 175.25. The turnover totaled NT$3.85 billion in value.
Meanwhile, official determination to pump up stock buying also affected trading of Taipei's stock index futures.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December rose 41 points, finishing at 7,000, with 2,067 contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for January climbed 86 points to close at 7,148, with 3,453 contract transactions, while those for March surged 96 points to 7,129, with 77 transactions.
No trading was registered for June, while the TAIEX Index Futures for September surged 100 points to close at 7,060, with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 6,959 points for December, 7,062 for January, 7,033 for March, 6,960 for June, and 6,960 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AID TO HURRICANE-HIT COUNTRIES CONTINUES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Aid from Taiwan to hurricane-devastated Central American countries continues even after ROC Vice President Lien Chan returned from a mission to the region offering long-term loans and donations.

Three relief teams from Taiwan's private Tzu Chi Association are currently helping the Honduras Red Cross Association clean up the environment and with some of the reconstruction work, according to a Tzu Chi report.

Honduras sustained the worst damage and the greatest loss of life in Hurricane Mitch which struck in late October. Since the disaster, the Buddhist compassionate organization has shipped at least one cargo container filled with relief supplies to the stricken areas from Los Angeles each day, the report said.

In the past one and a half months, the Tzu Chi group has shipped a total of 1,200 gallons anti-dengue serum, 30,000 kilograms of medicine to fight mosquito bites, 10,000 portions of quinine to combat malaria, 10,000 antibiotics, and equipment for emergency treatment and sterilization, according to the report.

In addition to the Tzu Chi Association, the Hsi Lai Temple in Los Angeles has also held several charity events to raise funds aimed at helping the four storm-ravaged Central American countries -- Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala and El Salvador -- recover.
The Hsi Lai Temple is a branch of Taiwan's prestigious Buddhist Fukuangshan Temple.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESTIGIOUS SCRAP COLLECTOR WANG KUAN-YING DIES

TEXT.P: Wang Kuan-ying, an honored resident of Taipei who raised a small fortune to promote literacy and Chinese culture by collecting recycled goods, died on Tuesday of heart failure at a local hospital at the age of 96.
The one-time Kuomintang soldier will be granted a funeral service complete with national and party honors in recognition of his chivalrous contributions to society, KMT officials said in Taipei.
The veteran, who never married, began scrap collecting since he concluded his service in the army.
It was during China's eight-year war against Japan that Wang pledged to devote the rest of his life to the promotion of Chinese culture in an effort to strengthen the nation.

Since then, rain or shine, Wang became a familiar sight in the streets of Taipei. The retiree, who suffered from poverty, drove a simple cart through the streets and alleys, collecting garbage to be sold for recycling.
Although he earned only small change, he collected enough to spend tens of thousands of dollars on books of Chinese culture and philosophy.
In a period of 50-odd years, the scrap collector donated a total of more than 300,000 books to domestic and foreign academic institutions. Over 30 countries have benefited from Wang's donations.
In addition, Wang helped build a private library in downtown Taipei in 1976 and set up a scholarship for underprivileged students.
When President Lee Teng-hui was Taipei mayor, he granted Wang with the title of honored resident in recognition of Wang's enormous efforts, making him the first such person in Taiwan's capital city.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA EXPLORE FREE TRADE

TEXT.P: Unprecedented efforts to expand economic relations between Japan and South Korea are underway following recent improvements in political relations, according to reports from the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday.
The developments come as South Korea tries to pull itself out of an economic recession and encourage the inflow of foreign capital.
In recent weeks, Japanese and South Korean officials have agreed to begin negotiations over what would be a free-trade zone between the two countries.
Japanese officials see a stronger relationship with South Korea as a way of helping balance mainland China's increasing strength in the region, the WTO report said.

"Japan and South Korea traditionally had been unable to hold comprehensive trade and investment talks," Junich Wada, deputy director of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry's international trade policy bureau, was quoted as saying. "But the relationship between Japanese and South Korean governments has become completely different from what it was. We will take this opportunity to achieve economic integration between the two nations."
By economic integration, Wada referred to the free movement of goods, capital and people. He also referred to the development of close relations between companies of the two countries.

Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry is working to push Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi to endorse the initiatives. The positions of other Japanese government ministries are still uncertain, but some are expected to vigorously resist the removal of protection from South Korean imports, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CONTRIBUTION TO LATIN AMERICAN RELIEF PRAISED

TEXT.P: Dean Hirsch, president of World Vision International, paid tribute on Tuesday to Taiwan's generosity in offering aid to the Central American victims of Hurricane Mitch.
He urged Taipei authorities to help relieve the Latin American countries' foreign debts with the same vigor.

During a news conference held by World Vision Taiwan, Hirsch expressed appreciation for the donations of tents, blankets, and medicine made by the local public to those in Honduras, as well as the offerings made during Vice President Lien Chan's recent visit to the storm-devastated region.

There are more than 300 million children worldwide who are on the verge of death due to malnutrition or a lack of medication, another 300 million children who go to bed hungry every night, about 200 million between 4 and 15 work in mines or plantations every day, some 800,000 children in Asia are forced into the sex trade every day, and about 2 million children died in wars in the last decade, he said.

In Ulan Bator, the capital of the Mongolia, Hirsch said the local World Vision found nine runaway children living in the sewage system who survived by stealing, begging or doing odds jobs. They bathed with water that leaked from a hot water pipe and were often burned by the sudden burst of steam.

As a Christian body, the World Vision believes that no one, much less child, should live in such a misery, Hirsch said, adding that children also have an inalienable right to have access to an education.
Hirsch, who arrived in Taiwan on Monday to promote the organization's cause, urged the public to dig deep into their pockets to help relieve those living in misery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GARNERS ADDITIONAL MEDALS IN ASIAN GAMES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's athletes on Tuesday continued their medal collection drive in the Asian Games being held in Bangkok.

Li Wan-yu beat her opponent from Vietnam in the final of the women's 60 kg-class karate event, pocketing a gold, the 17th, for Taiwan. Meanwhile, teammate Chiang Ching-chih won a bronze in the women's 53 kg-class competition.

In the finals of the men's soft tennis doubles, Kuo Hsi-tung and Feng Tung-hsien edged teammates Liao Nan-kai and Yeh Yu-ming, in a gold-and-silver medal sweep. But in the women's soft tennis doubles, Taiwan's Lin Li-jung and Cheng Shu-cheng lost to their South Korean rivals, leaving them with a silver.
In men's volleyball, Taiwan for the first time in 28 years defeated Japan to earn a bronze.
In men's table tennis matches, Taiwan players obtained two bronzes.
Taiwan has so far won 17 golds, 12 silvers and 28 bronzes in the Games, ranking fourth, after mainland China, South Korea and Japan, in terms of the number of gold medals. . (by Wei Shu and Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANCE RESUMES INVESTIGATION IN TAIWAN FRIGATE GRAFT CASE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: French authorities on Tuesday resumed their investigation into a graft scandal involving a 1991 Lafayette-class frigate sale to Taiwan.

Judge Eva Joly summoned Christine Joncour, a key figure in the case, for further questioning with the hopes of determining whether former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas abused his post and received a commission or bribes from parties involved in the frigate deal

Court sources noted that Joly's questioning focused on Joncour's role in distributing the commissions, particularly on whether she had succeeded as a public relations broker in bribing Dumas, then foreign minister, to give his consent to the frigate sale.

In a previous probe, French judges sought to establish the former state-run oil company ELF's role in lobbying France's Foreign Ministry, on behalf of the Lafayette-class frigate maker Thomson-CSF Group, to approve the sale of the warship to Taiwan.

Investigation results showed that in 1991, after Thomson-CSF Group decided to sell six Lafayette-class frigates to Taiwan, Dumas introduced Joncour, his friend, to work at ELF as a PR executive. Joncour proceeded to exclusively lobby the government for its consent in the frigate deal.
In early 1992, according to the probe, Joncour obtained 45 million French francs (US$8.2 million) in commissions.
Joncour said under questioning that ELF hired her as a PR executive because she maintained close relations with Dumas, who was then known to strongly oppose the frigate deal.
Joncour admitted that she received a total of 66 million francs (US$12 million) from ELF since the deal was struck. The amount included commissions, her salary and other PR expenses, she said.
In 1991 and 1992, despite Dumas' opposition, the French government approved the sale with the consent of then President Francois Mitterrand.
Joncour was taken into police custody last November for five months on the grounds that there was no reason for her to obtain such a large amount of money from the deal.

Meanwhile, Dumas -- who now heads France's highest judicial watchdog, the Constitutional council -- has been stripped of his right to leave the country since April 29 this year due to charges of fraud and abuse of corporate assets.

Dumas told Le Figaro daily earlier this year that he never changed his position, stressing that the go-ahead was given by the then French president and prime minister. He further said that the details concerning the deal had been consigned to a secret file, and called for it to be made public "to wipe away all doubts."
