DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED OVER TOXIC DUMPING REPORTS FROM CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is paying close attention to reports from Phnom Penh stating that Cambodia is being used by other countries as a toxic dumping ground.
According to foreign wire service reports, 3,000 tons of waste believed to be toxic were left 185 kilometers southwest of Phnom Penh on the outskirts of the port town of Sihanoukville last week.
The waste materials, reportedly imported from Taiwan by a Cambodian company, pose a serious risk of contaminating water sources in the area, said Cambodian Environment Minister Mok Mareth on Tuesday.
If the shipment is found to be toxic and indeed from Taiwan, it will be shipped back to the island, Mareth added.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said on Wednesday that the ministry has instructed officials stationed in Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to look into the allegations to determine whether the shipment originated from Taiwan.

Once the findings are delivered and if Taiwan is the source of the waste, MOFA will contact the Environmental Protection Administration, the Ministry of Finance and the Directorate General of Customs to work out a suitable course of action, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES AND FUTURES BOTH SLUMP

TEXT.P: Share prices on Wednesday opened low and traded even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX), with the bourse slumping amid bearish sentiment.
The TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, plunged 167.3 points to close at 6,769.52 despite government pledges to pump up stock trading.
Dealers said investors showed no confidence in the Ministry of Finance efforts, which includes establishing a stock stabilization team to help bail out the flagging bourse.
A total of 1.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.76 billion (US$1.79 billion), shrinking from the NT$67.28 billion of the previous session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 370 to 52, with 67 stocks unchanged.
All eight major stock categories posted losses, with plastic and chemical issues losing the largest margin at 3.1 percent.

Electronic engineering shares dropped 2.8 percent, followed by both foodstuff issues and banking stocks, which declined 2.5 percent; textile shares, 2.4 percent; construction stocks, 1.8 percent; cement shares, 1.5 percent; and paper and pulp issues, 1.1 percent.
The over-the-counter stock market dropped 1.13 points to close at 174.12, with turnover totaling NT$5.73 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also suffered heavy drops.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for December plunged 240 points, closing at 6,760 with 1,701 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for January fell 289 points to finish at 6,859, with 3,364 contract transactions, while those for March moved down 231 points to 6,898, those for June dropped 129 points to 6,951, and those for September declined 92 points to 6,880.
Transactions for the three months totaled 45, 10, and four, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday registered 7,000 points for December, 7,148 points for January, 7,129 points for March, 7,080 points for June, and 6,972 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 16, or Oct. 28 under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Boston residents dump 342 chests of tea worth 9,000 British pounds overboard from a British ship in Boston harbor in the so-called "The Boston Tea Party" incident.
1921: Charles Camille Saint-Saens, a French composer whose works include symphonies, operas, such as "Samson et Dalila", and symphonic poems, including "Danse Macabre," dies in Algiers, Algeria at the age of 86.
1922: Tu Chung-ming graduates from Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to earn a doctorate during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan.
1944: German troops begin the "Battle of the Bulge" in Ardennes area of Belgium in World War II.
1949: Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung visits the Soviet Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite, the first satellite purely for the purpose of meteoric research.
1971: After a war with its rebels and their Indian allies, Pakistani forces surrender East Pakistan which soon becomes the independent nation of Bangladesh.
1975: Kang Sheng, deputy chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo strongly condemns the US decision to sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in favor of the Peking regime.
1988: The United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization hold their first meeting in Tunis.
1989: A hijacked Air China plane is forced to land in Japan's Fukuoka airport. Hijacker Chang Chen-hai, who was injured after being pushed off the plane, is arrested by Japanese police.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan presides over the inauguration ceremony of the South Link Railway.
1991: The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits is set up in Beijing, with Wang Daohan as its chairman.
1992: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl announces 17.6 billion marks (US$11.2 billion) worth of debt relief for Russia.
1995: Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia sign a peace treaty in Paris, ending many years of civil war in the Bosnian region.
1995: British geologists say they have pinpointed the location of the biblical cities of Sodom and Gomorrah on a Dead Sea peninsula.
1996: A South Korean court of appeal reduces sentences for former President Chun Doo-hwan to life in the prison, and former President Roh Tae-woo to 17 years in the prison on the grounds that they have contributed to the democratic development in South Korea.
Confucius: "You look at how a man acts; consider his motives; find out his tastes. How can a man hide himself; how can he hide himself from you? If a man will constantly go over what he has acquired and keep continually adding to it new acquirements, he may become a teacher of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY TO RECOVER IN SECOND HALF OF 1999

TEXT.P: The slumping global semiconductor industry will likely rebound in the third quarter of 1999, IDC Japan predicted on Tuesday.

Akira Minamikawa, IDC Japan's senior analyst in the semiconductor industry, said during a seminar on Tuesday that the world's microchips production will continue to exceed market demand during the first two quarters in 1999.

Contributing to the oversupply in the world market is a huge production increase of semiconductors by South Korea's Hyundai Group and Samsung Group, as well as a moderate expansion in the world's PC market, Minamikawa added.

However, excess supply will turn to excess demand in the second half of 1999, the IDC Japan analyst predicted, as microchip makers have been cutting their capital investment budgets and production rates will remain level due to little advancement in production technology.

While the global semiconductor market is expected to recover, Taiwan's DRAM makers will continue to be challenged by Samsung Group and US-based Micron Technology, both of which have more advanced production technology than Taiwan, Minamikawa noted.

Although Taiwan is not strongly competitive in DRAM production, there is something to be learned from the island's microchip industry, IDC Japan said. For example, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company is recorded as earning the world's highest profit margin against such stiff competition as Micron Technology, Motorola Electronics, Texas Instruments, and Philips Electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: AN FENG KINGSTREAM SHARES PLUNGE TO RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: Share prices for An Feng Kingstream Steel Ltd. fell 31 percent on Tuesday to record lows following the announcement of a major company restructuring, the Australian Associated Press reported.
An Feng shares plunged 4.5 Australian cents (28 US cents) to 10 cents following reports that the company would be cut off from its debt-stricken Taiwan steel company.
Under the restructuring deal, An Feng will relinquish its Taiwan steel assets and reclaim 65 percent of its major shareholder, Chu An-hsiung, head of the Kaohsiung-based An Feng Steel Co.

Kingstream Resources of Western Australia is to cancel the shares acquired from Chu while he and the other Taiwan Steel representatives will resign from the board of the previous joint venture between An Feng Steel and Kingstream Resources.

The move will leave Kingstream with 100 percent control of the Mid-West Iron and Steel project, the development of which has been suspended pending the refinancing of the troubled Taiwan steel company.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA COMMODITY EXPORTS SEEN FALLING IN 1998-99

TEXT.P: Australia's commodity exports will drop 3.3 percent to A$64.6 billion (US$40.4 billion) between July 1998 and June 1999, according to the Australia Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.
The bureau's chief analyst, Terry Sheales, said slower world growth would be reflected in weak demand from Asia and continued low world prices for most commodities.

Despite some success in switching its sales to North America and Europe, Australia's commodity exports remain tied to the economic turbulence in Asia which is expected to experience continued lower demand for commodities.

Sheales said the fall of Australia's commodities exports would have been greater if the Australian dollar had not depreciated against the greenback to make prices more competitive in the world market.

He noted that the value of minerals and energy exports are expected to fall 2.3 percent to A$40.2 billion although minerals and metals producers should be better off than energy producers. The average prices for minerals and metals exports are tipped to drop 0.5 percent, compared with a 7.5 percent fall for energy exports.

Aluminum, copper, lead, nickel and uranium prices are all expected to drop, but gold should firm slightly. Iron ore exports are expected to rise 2 percent on rising demand in China and Japan and steel markets are expected to remain depressed, resulting in a 4 percent drop of Australian steel exports, Sheales said.
Australia's wool exports are expected to plunge about 26 percent due to a weakening demand from major markets, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POWER COMPANY ADJUSTS PRICE SYSTEM TO CONTROL LOAD

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (TPC) presented plans to adjust its pricing system to the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA) Energy Commission for approval.

Under the new scheme, the three-category pricing system will be changed to a four-category system whereby high-end energy users will be charged higher rates than low-end users, TPC officials said on Tuesday.

The fourth category of users, namely those who consume more than 500 kilowatt/hour per month, will be charged NT$0.3 more per kilowatt/hour while those in the first category, who consume less than 110 kilowatt/hour per month, will have their charges reduced by NT$0.2 per kilowatt/hour.

TPC officials estimated that 9.8 million users islandwide will benefit from lower rates while nearly 3.3 million users will fall into the fourth category and pay higher rates. If calculated based on peak season prices, category-four users will pay 35 percent more than category-one users, they noted.

The new pricing scheme has been devised to promote more resourceful energy consumption particularly as plans for a fourth nuclear power plant and a thermal power plant have met with strong opposition among residents living near proposed sites. Such construction projects have also been hindered by environmental protection regulations, the TPC officials noted.

Both residential and industrial energy users will be affected by the new pricing program as peak-hour and off-peak-hour charges have also been adjusted. As industrial users normally operate during peak hours, they will likely face higher charges.

Another aspect of the program includes the limitation of power use for central air condition systems for whole buildings and the voluntary disconnection of service for high-end users such as steel plants during summer months. These two moves will save ordinary users from being limited in their use of energy, officials stated.
The plans for the new pricing scheme must first be checked by the Energy Commission's Consultant Committee of Petroleum Product and Electric Power Price before being put forward for approval.

Meanwhile, lawmakers expressed concern over the new scheme and the joint conference of committees in the Legislative Yuan's budget and economic affairs requested that the MOEA explain the new program.
The MOEA said this draft for the new pricing program will be thoroughly discussed by the Consultant Committee prior to any further progress in obtaining approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MILLION VISA GOLD CARDS ISSUED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More than 3 million Visa Gold Cards were issued in Taiwan as of October, accounting for 34 percent of the total number of cards issued on the island, Visa International reported on Wednesday.
The total of all types of Visa cards issued n Taiwan as of October reached 8.96 billion. Visa cards represent 66 percent of the total number of credit cards issued in Taiwan, the company said.
Visa International attributed the 50 percent growth in Visa Gold Cards to Taiwan consumers' preference for gold, a symbol of wealth.

Visa Gold Card holders enjoy more privileges than regular Visa card holders such as higher credit and free travel insurance. Additional services include being able to borrow cash from abroad, as well as free legal and medical consultation, the company said.
According to Visa International, it has issued 650 million Visa cards worldwide, making it the world's largest credit card provider.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAY REVISE PARTY PLATFORM IN A BID TO WIN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) may revise its party platform in a bid to win the presidential election in 2000, party sources said on Wednesday.
Calls have been made for the DPP to revise its platform, chapters and relevant statutes following the party's dismal performance in the Dec. 5 "three-in-one" elections.

The DPP Central Standing Committee met on Wednesday to establish a "party reform task force," to discuss strategies in winning the 2000 presidential election and further reflect why voter support was lower than expected.

Members of the committee said no matter who is selected to run on the party ticket for president, the primary source of concern and doubt of most constituents is the DPP's platform supporting Taiwan independence. The issue must be dealt with if the party intends to win elections in the future, they added.

Chen Chao-nan, former director of the DPP's Organization Affairs Department, suggested that action guidelines be added to the party's platform to clearly state the fact that Taiwan already has de facto independence. The only part left to be completed to that end is a nationwide plebiscite to decide the new name of the "independent" nation, Chen said.

Sisy Chen, former DPP publicity chief, recommended that provisions be added to the platform to define the DPP's efforts in seeking conciliation with the ruling Kuomintang and other opposition parties.

The DPP Central Standing Committee meeting, which was continuing at press time, may also discuss a cancellation of Article Seven of the DPP statute governing the candidacy of elections for public jobs. It rules that party members can choose to run in only one among the presidential election and mayoral election in Taipei and Kaohsiung in four years.

If the revision, called the "Chen Shui-bian statute," is approved, it will be a move by senior DPP members to pave the way for outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian to run on the DPP ticket for president in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA EYEING LATIN AMERICAN MARKETS

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) announced on Wednesday that it will organize a trade promotion delegation to explore Latin American markets early next year.
The move is part of a package designed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to edge into the world's emerging markets and falls in line with CETRA's plan to open new offices in Honduras and Paraguay.

CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo, leading a delegation composed of representatives of 30 Taiwan firms, is scheduled to tour Brazil, Honduras and Paraguay from Jan. 23-Feb. 6. Lin will also take part in the inauguration of CETRA's offices in Honduras and Paraguay during his stay in those two countries.

As part of its efforts to explore other Latin American markets, CETRA will also dispatch seven missions to the region to promote Taiwan-made products, ranging from automobile accessories to electronic goods.

Taiwan exports to Latin America fell by 16.6 percent to US$2.1 billion in the first 10 months of this year, while imports from Latin American countries declined by 23 percent to US$1.5 billion, CETRA statistics showed.
Taiwan shipments to Brazil, Chile, Panama and Paraguay registered larger drops, while those to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Venezuela posted some growth, according to CETRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWYERS TO REPRESENT TAIWAN COMFORT WOMEN

TEXT.P: A group of voluntary Japanese lawyers said on Wednesday it will file a lawsuit against the Japanese government in the spring on behalf of former comfort women in Taiwan.
Members of the group said they are aware it will be a tough fight, but added that they will hold on until the end to achieve their goal of winning compensation for the women.
The eight-member group arrived in Taiwan on Monday to collect information and meet with women who were forced into working as sex slaves for the Japanese army during World War II.

So far, they have visited about 30 former comfort women in Kaohsiung, Hualien and Taipei, and will call at the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Thursday to exchange opinions with relevant officials.

Kunio Aitani, spokesman for the group and head of Japan's National Lawyers' Association, said a number of lawyers in Japan have voluntarily teamed up and divided into several groups to defend those filing complaints against the Japanese government over wartime offenses.

At present, they are preparing to file eight lawsuits on behalf of former Asian comfort women, including some from Taiwan, he added. The lawyers are also representing an additional 30 plaintiffs involved in incidents which occurred during World War II.

Wang Ching-fung, a well-known Taiwan lawyer and a long-time anti-child prostitution advocate, said she hoped the Japanese group will be able to speed up the pace of progress in the case as former comfort women on Hainan Island in southern mainland China will also launch a suit next year.
In a public declaration, the Japanese group stated that it will sue the Japanese government next spring on behalf of surviving comfort women in Taiwan.

Japan established the Asian Women's Fund in 1995 providing 2 million Japanese yen (about US$14,200) worth of compensation to each surviving comfort women. But most of the former sex slaves, about 200,000 from across Asia, have refused to accept the money because it is not from the Japanese government.
Tokyo has long been reluctant to offer legal compensation for surviving wartime comfort women despite the fact that some government officials have apologized for such practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: Prompted by active buying, the New Taiwan dollar gained NT$0.003 against the greenback in Taipei on Wednesday, closing at a nine-month high of 32.248.
The local currency has experienced gains for 12 consecutive days and has appreciated a total of NT$0.181 over the period.
Dealers predicted that the NT dollar will appreciate further as there are no signs of the weak US dollar recovering pending the expected impeachment of US President Bill Clinton.
The NT dollar opened at 32.25 against the US dollar on Wednesday, and traded between 32.242 and 32.264.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$328 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG ATTENDS LAST KMT MEETING AS GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who is scheduled to step down from his post on Dec. 21, attended his last Kuomintang Central Standing Committee meeting as governor on Wednesday.

President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui expressed his gratitude to Soong for his performance and said he hoped Taiwan's first and only elected governor will continue to work for the party and country.
Speaking at the meeting, Soong said the Taiwan Provincial Government has done its utmost in serving the residents of the island over the past four years.

President Lee said the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government -- including the adjustment of its functions, operations and structure -- is a major part of government restructuring and will require careful planning and implementation.
Lee also asked that the interests of those employees affected by the downsizing be well protected.
President Lee is expected to personally meet with Soong on Thursday morning.

Chao Shou-po, who has been nominated as governor of the streamlined Taiwan Provincial Government, had a brief exchange with Soong about his experience in running the provincial government. Chao added that he hoped to meet again with Soong before the outgoing governor goes on vacation to the United States after stepping down.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN QUALIFIED FOR WTO MEMBERSHIP: ECCT HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is well qualified for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO), said Paul Scholten, newly elected chairman of the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) in Taipei, on Wednesday.

Scholten, who was named president of the Taiwan branch of ABN, AMRO Bank of the Netherlands in 1996, said that the Executive Commission of the European Union (EU) has decided to set up a Taiwan office to deal with the sharp increase in trade and mutual investment between Taiwan and EU member countries.

Saying the ECCT will serve as a "bridge" between Taiwan and the EU, Scholten said that Taiwan's WTO membership will benefit not just Taiwan but also European businesses with connections to the island.

He said that Taiwan has made great progress in economic liberalization and that its WTO membership should not be connected with mainland China's. Mainland China is also seeking WTO membership and has insisted that it be admitted into the world trade regulatory body ahead of Taiwan.

Scholten suggested Taiwan revise its outdated regulations on allowing the marketing of newly developed medicines, improve its build-operate-transfer systems and give greater protection to intellectual property rights.
The banker also praised Taiwan for being more willing to accept suggestions from foreign businessmen than Japan is.
Saying Taiwan is a country full of dynamism, Scholten said that European businesses have attached great importance to the Taiwan market, especially in regard to large public infrastructure projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEN READY TO QUIT KMT FOR CONTROL YUAN PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, who has been nominated as Control Yuan president, said on Wednesday he plans to resign from his posts in the Kuomintang once the National Assembly approves his appointment.
Chien made the remark during a National Assembly session in which 29 nominated members of the Control Yuan introduced themselves, a required procedure before they are approved by the assembly.
He told assembly deputies that after having served as speaker for the last three years, he found his political sense, which is considered necessary in the National Assembly, had weakened.

As the Control Yuan is Taiwan's highest watchdog body and must remain neutral, Chien said he would resign from his posts as KMT Central Standing Committee member, KMT Central Committee, and as senior consultant in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Chien, who is currently a professor of political science at National Taiwan University, said he would not continue teaching once this semester is finished so he can pay his full attention to his new job.

As Control Yuan president, he pledged to conduct a thorough investigation of government graft, implement the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, and strengthen the government's role in maintaining social security and public order.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY VOWS TO IMPROVE TAIWAN-ISRAELI RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Republic of China Representative to Israel R. T. Yang on Wednesday vowed to push for increased exchanges of visits by high-ranking officials of the two nations.

Yang, during his report at a parliamentary meeting, said he will also make a concerted effort to gain support from Jerusalem for the ROC's membership in international organizations, and to provide smooth communication channels between two sides.
The Republic of China, which has no official diplomatic relations with Israel, established its representative office in Tel Aviv in June 1993.
Despite a lack of formal ties, officials from Taiwan in Israel have been granted a number of diplomatic privileges, a fact that reflects Israel's friendship with Taipei, Yang noted.
It is still difficult, though, for ROC officials to contact Israel's vice foreign minister or other ministerial-level officials due to Beijing's political pressure.
Beijing forged official links with Israel in November 1992, and continues to thwart Taipei's efforts to boost its international profile.

Yang told the legislature that he is prepared to strengthen the mutual trust and friendship between Taipei and Jerusalem, and to break down barriers set up by Beijing to block the island's participation in the international arena.
Yang, a senior diplomat currently serving as director of European Affairs in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will officially assume his new post in late January.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING NOT TO CHANGE ITS COOPERATION PROJECT WITH TAIWAN'S AIDC
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Boeing Co. said on Tuesday that it has received orders for 105 Boeing B/717s and that it will not change its cooperation project agreement with parts and components providers such as Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC).

News reports from Taiwan had indicated Boeing would shut down its B/717 assembly lines if new orders were not received within the next four months. The reports said only 56 planes are currently on order and that Boeing would stop production of the planes once those orders had been met. AIDC would bear the brunt of such a closure, according to reports.

But a Boeing spokesman said Tuesday that the company has so far received orders for 105 B/717s and that Boeing is planning to produce 12 such planes in 1999, 33 in 2000 and five per month starting in 2001.
The spokesman said Boeing has no intentions of scaling down production of the planes and that the cooperation project between parts and components providers and Boeing would remain unchanged.
The Boeing B/717 is a 100-seat regional plane, and the only new plane to be developed after Boeing merged with MacDonnell Douglas Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ANNOUNCES AD HOC COMMITTEE TO COORDINATE PARTY AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: The Central Standing Committee of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) adopted a resolution on Wednesday to form an ad hoc committee for the development of party affairs.
At that meeting outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian was appointed head of the section of the committee that will focus on the party's civil servants.
The goal of the committee is to ensure the implementation of party policy. The ad hoc committee will comprise five sections:
-- a section responsible for the organization of the DPP's civil servants, to be headed by Chen;
-- a section responsible for the development of party strategies for the 2000 presidential election, to be headed by Wu Nai-jen; and
-- a section responsible for the review of the party's platform and regulations, to be headed by Yu Hsi-kun.

Tsai Tung-jung, a Central Standing Committee member, suggested at Wednesday's meeting that the party set up a task force to push for the integration of pro-independence forces into the party. Meeting participants decided to send the proposal to the ad hoc committee's third section for further study.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH ESTIMATED AT 5.08 PERCENT NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will reach 5.08 percent next year, a higher level than will be seen this year, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) said on Wednesday.
TRI said that faced with a financial crisis in Asia, Taiwan's economy will not bottom out until the second half of next year.

TRI, working with Japanese research institute Daiwa, made the forecast. The growth figure is slightly lower than those from most private forecasting institutions, and is much lower than economic growth forecasts by government agencies.
The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research have put Taiwan's economic growth next year at 5.35 percent and 5.41 percent, respectively.

Meanwhile, the government's Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics and the Council for Economic Planning and Development have estimated next year's growth will amount to 5.24 percent and 5.32 percent, respectively.

TRI said world commodity exports have, in the past two months, achieved negative growth, indicating that the world economy has slowed. In addition, economic growth in mainland China this year is not as good as in past years, and Taiwan's indirect trade with the mainland via Hong Kong has slipped. All these factors have affected Taiwan's overall export performance.
But Premier Vincent Siew's push to expand domestic demand will result in dramatic investment increases by the government and state enterprises, TRI said.

TRI estimated that quarterly economic growth next year will be 4.84 percent, 4.24 percent, 5.33 percent and 5.84 percent, respectively. This means the economy's downward slide will bottom out in the third quarter of 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA TO PUSH AT ASEAN MEETING FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF REGIONAL COUNCIL

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada said Wednesday the Philippines favors a multilateral agreement among claimants to the Spratlys group of islands as a way of resolving the long-standing dispute, a Malacanang press release said.

Estrada said his proposal for the establishment of a high council to resolve these types of potential conflicts among countries in the region might be taken up Wednesday afternoon when the heads of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) meet high-level representatives of their dialogue partners, South Korea, Japan and Mainland China, in separate closed-door conferences.

In his opening statement at the sixth ASEAN leaders' summit, Estrada called for the establishment of such a council to help defuse conflicts that strain relations among its members and affect regional peace and security. One of the issues such a council would contend with are overlapping claims to islands in the South China Sea.

The Philippines and three other ASEAN members -- Brunei, Malaysia and Vietnam -- have laid claim part or all of the Spratlys. Mainland China and the Republic of China on Taiwan have also laid separate claims on the island chain.

In a press briefing on Tuesday, Presidential spokesperson Jerry Barican said the ASEAN leaders' declaration, to be issued Wednesday afternoon, would include a statement calling on Spratly claimants to exercise prudence and to avoid any activities that may raise tensions in the disputed area.

"As far as the Spratlys is concerned, the ASEAN leaders are going to issue a statement which calls on all parties in the South China Sea to be very prudent, to be careful and to avoid any approaches that may increase tension in the area," Barican said.
He said the Hanoi declaration will be directed "in general at all the parties to the dispute."

The remarks came in response to questions as to whether the ASEAN leaders' statement would contain a direct reference to Beijing, which has recently made its presence felt in Mischief Reef, a portion of the disputed area that the Philippines considers as part of its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND DISSIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Top mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jing-sheng is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Dec. 21 or Dec. 22 for a four-day visit at the invitation of the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD).
During his visit Wei will call on President Lee Teng-hui, government officials and leaders of major political parties, said WLFD Chairman Jao Ying-chi.

Jao said the WLFD has long planned to invite Wei to visit Taiwan, but the plan could not be acted upon until recently due to Wei's sensitive status as a mainland Chinese dissident living in exile in the United States.
He said that Wei originally was scheduled to come to Taiwan just days before Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections on Dec. 5 to see for himself Taiwan's democracy.
But the trip was postponed, as Taiwan's political parties were busy campaigning for their candidates at the time, Jao added.
Until his release on medical parole and his deportment to the United States last year, Wei had served all but six months of the last 18 years in jail for his pro-democracy stance.
Since going into exile, Wei has urged the world to take a tougher stance against human rights abuses in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS ONE MORE GOLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan athletes won one gold, one silver and six bronze medals on Wednesday, the 11th day of the Third Asian Games, currently being held in Bangkok.
Chan Ming-shui won a gold medal in men's Taijiquan (shadow boxing), beating Toshiya Watanabe of Japan by a small margin of 0.13 points.
In billiards Taiwan's Chang Hao-ping and Lai Chia-hsiung took the silver, after losing to Romeo Villaneuva and Gandy Valle of the Philippines 2-13.
Meanwhile, Thailand's Anan Terananon and Worawit Suriyasriw beat Chao Fong-pang and Yang Chin-shun to take third place.
Taiwan athletes won bronze medals in cycling, women's softball, tennis, karatedo, baseball and table tennis.
So far Taiwan athletes have accumulated 18 golds, 13 silvers and 34 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN LEADERS PLEDGE PEACEFUL RESOLUTION OF SOUTH CHINA SEA DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada and eight other leaders of Association Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states pledged Wednesday to support peaceful and diplomatic efforts to settle territorial disputes in the South China Sea, even as they called on all parties concerned to refrain from disturbing the peace in the region, a Malacanang press release said.

This commitment forms part of a "package of bold measures" intended to move the 31-year-old organization to a "higher plane" of regional cooperation and solidarity to combat enemies such as poverty and the Asian economic crisis, and to meet the challenges of the 21st century.

Estrada and his co-leaders signed the Hanoi Declaration of 1998, which also sealed their decision to admit Cambodia as the 10th member of ASEAN, at the end of the two-day sixth ASEAN leaders summit at Ba dinh Hall in Vietnam.

They likewise adopted the Hanoi Plan, which puts flesh onto ASEAN Vision 2020, and directed their respective ministers and senior officials to implement this "package of bold measures" starting Jan. 1, 1999. They agreed to review its progress in 2001.

To highlight ASEAN's key role in the well-being of individual members, the leaders declaration reaffirmed their view of the group as "indispensable to regional peace and prosperity, an association with a history of demonstrated dynamism and close cooperation, a force for peace and stability in our part of the world."

The ASEAN leaders also vowed to "promote efforts to settle disputes in the South China Sea by peaceful means in accordance with international law, including the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, and the spirit of the 1992 ASEAN Declaration on the South China Sea."

"We call on all parties concerned to exercise restraint and to refrain from taking actions that are inimical to the peace and security and stability of Southeast Asia-Pacific region," according to the statement.

"We welcome efforts to develop long-term constructive relationships among the major powers. ASEAN shall enhance its dialogue partnership and cooperation with other countries as well as with other regional and international organizations, on the basis of equality, non-interference, mutual respect and mutual benefit," the leaders said.
They agreed, moreover, to prevent disputes and resolve current problems "in the ASEAN way and in accordance with international law and practice."

In pursuit of this goal, they agreed to strengthen the ASEAN Regional Forum as a venue for political and security dialogues in the Asia-Pacific region; to expedite the rectification of the second Protocol to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia; and to intensify consultations nations possessing nuclear weapons, with an eye toward their accession to the Protocol to the Treaty on the Southeast Asia Nuclear Weapons-Free Zone.

Aside from President Estrada, the declaration was also signed by Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah of Brunei Darussalam, President Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie of Indonesia, Prime Minister Sisavath Keobounphanh of the Lao Peoples' Democratic Republic, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, Prime Minister Than Shwe of the Union of Myanmar, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore, Prime Minister Chuan Leekpal of Thailand and Prime Minister Van khal of Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHIPPING, FLIGHT SERVICES CONTINUE DESPITE AIR STRIKES

TEXT.P: Joint US-British air strikes against Iraq on Thursday have not led to any cancellation of Taiwan's air and marine transportation services to or over the Middle East.

EVA Airways has adjusted the flight path for its European-bound flights that passes over Bahrain's flight control area to one that passes over southern Iran, company representatives said, adding that all other EVA flights will remain in normal operation.

EVA is one of two Taiwan airlines that operates flights over the Middle East. China Airlines (CAL) reported on Thursday that all its flights destined for Europe will go through Abu Dhabi as scheduled.
CAL and EVA each operate 10 daily flights from Taipei to major European cities including Paris, London, Rome, Amsterdam, Zurich, Brussels, and Frankfort.

Meanwhile, Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yangming Marine Transport Corp., which provide shipping services to Jiddah and Dubai, said their services to the Middle East were operating on Thursday according to regular routes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SPOKESMAN IN US TO SPEAK ON JUST CONCLUDED ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Although mainland Chinese authorities are relieved over the Dec. 5 election results in Taiwan, they continue to harbor hostility toward the island, the Republic of China's top spokesman said here on Wednesday.

Government Information Office Director General C. J. Chen, who is visiting the United States to discuss the three-in-one election results, noted that mainland China has not changed its practice of isolating Taiwan internationally.
He said that the prospects for cross-strait dialogue could be described as "lukewarm," adding that there is nothing to indicate that relations are warming.

During a lunch with editors and reporters from the Washington Times, Chen said Ma Ying-jeou's victory in the Taipei mayoral election showed that voters were unwilling to confront the mainland directly. Ma, who is from the ruling Kuomintang, is said to symbolize the status quo while outgoing Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party advocates Taiwan independence.
In legislative elections, the KMT's wide-margin majority proved that 80 percent of the population want to maintain the status quo, the GIO director general said.
Later, during a visit with the Heritage Foundation, a US think tank, Chen said the success in holding the elections proved once again that democracy has triumphed in Taiwan.
The ROC's accomplishments in democracy should earn the praise, encouragement and support from the United States, he added.

Taiwan voters have embraced the moderate and rational course as reflected in the results of the elections, Chen said, adding that voters are supportive of the KMT in democratic reforms, national development and its mainland policy.

The KMT's victory also showed that Taiwan will continue to promote a constructive dialogue with the mainland according to the agreement reached in October between the heads of the two intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan will also work toward maintaining peace in the strait, increasing cross-strait exchanges, and creating more opportunities to enhance bilateral understanding.
Stephen Yates, a senior analyst from the Heritage Foundation, suggested that Chen Shui-bian's defeat had actually cleared the way for him to run in the 2000 presidential election.
Yates added that Chen was elected four years ago because of a split within the KMT, while Ma's victory was due in part to an undivided support from the KMT leadership.

The ROC's top spokesman, who arrived here on Tuesday, met with US officials from the State Department in charge of Southeast Asian policy over breakfast on Wednesday. Although the contents of the meeting is unknown, it is believed that the US has expressed satisfaction over the Dec. 5 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRAQ TENSION SAID UNLIKELY TO AFFECT TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Escalated tension in the Middle East will not likely severely affect Taiwan's economy as the impact of crude oil prices on the local economy has been minimized in recent years, statistics officials said on Thursday.
Crude oil futures on Wednesday posted their largest gain in six months as the United States and Britain were on the brink of launching air strikes on Iraq which took place Thursday morning.

Even if a war breaks out in Iraq, a nation located in the oil-producing Middle East, the affect to Taiwan's economy is seen to be limited as world oil prices have little impact on local inflation and commodity prices, said Hsu Chang-yao, a bureau chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Hsu said if the joint US-British air strikes do not continue for long, the impact on world markets would be limited. But if Iraq and the United States engage in an all out war, turning the Middle East into a war zone, the impact could be sizable and the aftermath remains to be seen, he added.

Hsu noted that in 1996 when the US-Iraq war erupted and Iraqi crude oil was embargoed, world oil prices skyrocketed to US$21.7 per barrel but growth in Taiwan's consumer prices remained a stable 3.1 percent.

In November this year, when the price of Taiwan's imported oil averaged at a low of US$11.1 per barrel, the local consumer prices did not consequently decline, indicating that the impact of world oil prices on Taiwan's inflation and economy is limited, Hsu noted.
Meanwhile, Chen Chao-wei, chairman of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), said domestic oil prices are expected to remain unchanged in the next week despite the Middle East tension.

Chen said although Brent North Sea crude prices on the International Petroleum Exchange rose US$0.77 on Wednesday to US$11.23 per barrel, Taiwan has a 70-day stock of crude oil. Coupled with CPC's higher-than-expected revenue surplus in December, the local oil prices are expected to remain unchanged at least for one week, he added.
Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said the attack on Iraq launched by the United States and Britain on Thursday morning should be a temporary development.

Yen also termed Taiwan's bearish stock market on Thursday as a temporarily psychological situation. He said investors should have confidence in Taiwan's economy which has been weathering the regional financial storm fairly well compared with other Asian economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINCENT SIEW HONORS TPG GOVERNOR, TAIPEI AND KAOHSIUNG MAYORS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday awarded Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih with the highest honor for public servants on Thursday.
The three men, who will soon leave public office, were commended for their performance during their service, which Siew described as concrete and worthy of respect.
Almost all Cabinet members, including National Palace Museum President Chin Hsiao-yih who rarely appears in Executive Yuan meetings, were present at the awards ceremony.
Soong is due to step down from elected office on Dec. 21 as a part of plans to downsize the provincial government.
Both Education Minister Lin Ching-jiang and Minister Without Portfolio Kuo Wan-jong made a point to shake hands with Soong after the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, INDONESIA REACH AGREEMENT ON AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Indonesia on Wednesday reached an agreement on bilateral cooperation in agricultural technology, upgrading the status of ROC agriculture missions traveling to the Southeast Asian country, reports said.

In the agreement, signed by Indonesian Agriculture Minister Soleh Solahuddin and ROC Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, Indonesia will grant ROC agriculture experts de facto diplomatic treatment boosting their status to a higher level, while both sides will enhance fishing cooperation.
Bilateral agricultural cooperation between the two sides was launched in 1995 when a memorandum on agricultural cooperation was first signed.
The latest pact also calls for Taiwan to promote investment in Indonesia's agricultural industry in the Palau Buru area.

Taiwan expertise in agricultural development is expected to help Indonesia recover from its recession, Solahuddin said. He added that depreciation in the rupiah has made the country's agricultural exports more attractive in the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES BOTH FALL DUE TO US AIR STRIKES

TEXT.P: Taipei's share prices fell on Thursday, affected by the US-British joint air strike against Iraq.
The military attack in the early morning further jolted investors' confidence, which has been weak due to concern over the financial troubles of local companies and banks.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's (TAIEX) weighted price index, the key indicator of the market, plunged 118.88 points, closing at the day's low of 6,650.64.
The bourse opened at 6,695.17, 74.35 points lower than the close of the previous session. Trading fell further as news of the air strikes in the Middle East overwhelmed the market.
A total of 1.72 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.05 billion (US$1.8 billion) on the Thursday session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 406 to 37, with 48 shares unchanged.
All eight major stock categories suffered losses, with paper and pulp issues registering the largest fall with 3.2 percent.

Construction issues dropped 3.1 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks, which declined 2.5 percent; cement shares, 1.9 percent; electronic engineering issues, 1.7 percent; financial stocks, 1.6 percent; plastic and chemical shares, 1.1 percent; and textile stocks, 1 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a 3.65-point decline, closing at 170.47, with the turnover reaching NT$3.91 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also plunged.

Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January sank 177 points, closing at 6,682, with 5,263 contract transactions, the largest single-month amount since the island opened futures trading in July.

The Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange started February trading on the TAIEX Index Futures. Its reference level for the Thursday session was listed as 6,869 points for January, 6,822 points for February, 6,879 points for March, 6,840 points for June and 6,732 points for September.

The TAIEX Index Futures for February slumped 117 points to close at 6,705, with 73 contract transactions, while those for March moved down 179 points to 6,700, those for June dropped 174 points to 6,766, and those for September declined 66 points to 6,666.
Transactions for the three months were 89, 1 and 3, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY 'SORRY' ABOUT ATTACK

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed sorrow over the joint US-Britain air strikes on Iraq on Thursday over Iraq's refusal to cooperate with the United Nations' arms inspection team.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the ROC government was sorry over the latest development, adding that it hoped Iraq will soon change its attitude and cooperate with UN personnel on weapons inspections so as to avoid being attacked further.

Wu said although none of the 700-800 ROC nationals currently residing in the Middle East makes Iraq their home, MOFA has instructed its liaison offices in the region to closely monitor the situation and report to Taipei with the latest developments.

The spokesman also said despite the attack, Taiwan's crude oil stock can satisfy domestic demand for at least two months, and fresh imports of oil from the Middle East can still be made through the western coast of Saudi Arabia.

Meanwhile, sources from Hong Kong said as of noon on Thursday, neither the mainland Chinese Embassy nor Hong Kong's liaison office in Baghdad have received any calls for help from Chinese people living in Iraq.
Currently, there are two Hong Kong tourist groups traveling in the Middle East, but Iraq has not been included in their itineraries, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE CHINA MOVEMENT RALLIES IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: A coalition of over 30 Chinese dissident organizations on Wednesday called on Beijing authorities to release all dissidents and urged governments to condemn the regime's recent crackdown on dissidents.

The Free China Movement, which represents dissidents both in and outside the mainland, also urged the US Congress to pass a resolution condemning the Chinese government and called for the termination of mainland China's most-favored-nation trading status until Beijing abides by international human rights obligations.

Lian Shengde, executive director of the Washington-based Free China Movement, said in a news conference, "It would be a tragic mistake for the Clinton administration and the European Union to believe that China has improved its human rights record and legal system."

"This is an absolute myth. The recent crackdown on the Chinese Democratic Party members and the trial of Lin Hai shows that the PRC is still a brutal communist dictatorship that only holds power through the barrel of a gun. The only realistic way to pressure the Chinese government to abide by international human rights treaties is through economic sanctions," Lian added.
Lin Hai, a Shanghai software engineer, was arrested last March for sending 30,000 mainland Chinese e-mail addresses to VIP Reference, an on-line magazine published by the Free China Movement.

"The Free China Movement strongly condemns the Chinese government's recent wave of arrests of political opposition leaders, and calls on Congress to speak out on behalf of those dissidents who are asserting their legal rights of free speech and assembly in China," movement lawyer Ye Ning said.
Ye recently won a lawsuit preventing Adidas, a sports equipment manufacturer, from using a mainland Chinese prison labor camp to make soccer balls.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DECLARES MARCH 21 INTERNATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Australia's Immigration Ministry, in a bid to mend the country's reputation for multicultural intolerance, has called on citizens to participate in International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination.
Australians will be able to celebrate the country's unique and diverse society in a series of events planned for March 21.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock, in a faxed statement to CNA, said, "It is your opportunity to promote factual and informed debate and to take an active part in nurturing a tolerant, inclusive and harmonious community."

"It will be a powerful expression of community harmony and acceptance of our cultural diversity. It is important that the values and principles that underline our society are not taken for granted. We are united and cohesive community because of, not despite, our multicultural population," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 17, or the 29th day of the 10th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: Pope Paul III excommunicates King Henry VIII of England.
1718: England declares war on Spain.
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy, and appoints Ting Ju-chang as commander-in-chief.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: School is open at the National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the first sustained flight over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, in a heavier-than-air vehicle they invented. It was the first airplane flight in history.
1909: Belgium's King Leopold II, who succeeded his father in 1968 and established the Congo Free State (now Zaire), dies at the age of 70.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can," and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1939: "Graf Spree," a German battleship, is scuttled off Uruguay by its captain to prevent it from falling into British hands in World War II.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo in World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war, with India in charge in East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who was put in charge to succeed Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of US forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: Some 20 Tupac Amaru guerrillas take hundreds of diplomats and government officials hostage and demand the release of 300 imprisoned comrades after seizing the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMBODIA TO RETURN TAIWAN WASTE DUMPED OFF COAST

TEXT.P: Over 3,000 tons of waste found dumped in Cambodia will be shipped back to Taiwan and the local company responsible for importing it will be heavily fined, Cambodia's environment minister said on Wednesday.
Mok Mareth, speaking on national television, added that the material -- a mixture of rubble and dirt -- may be incinerated toxic waste and contain heavy metals or hazardous chemicals.

The waste was found last week on the outskirts of Sihanoukville, 185 km southwest of Phnom Penh. According to a customs invoice, the material was described as construction waste shipped from Taiwan last month by a local company which has not yet been named.

Cambodia's government has been approached several times by companies interested in disposing their industrial waste, including a proposal for the construction of a sophisticated waste incineration plant in the country.
Mok Mareth has repeatedly said the government will turn down any waste-related business proposals.

"Industrialized nations have difficulty in finding space within their countries to discard toxic waste, that's why they dump it in poor countries. Cambodia is well aware of this and cannot let this happen on a whim," he said.
Deputy Prime Minister Sar Kheng has ordered the creation of a government commission to investigate the dumping, Mok Mareth noted.

Those found responsible for the dumping will face millions of dollars in fines for environmental destruction, and will be forced to pay compensation to anyone living in the area whose health has been affected by the mess, Sar Kheng said.
Whether the material is found to be toxic or not it will be shipped back to Taiwan, Mok Mareth stated.
"As a lesson for waste exporters it must be cleaned up and transported back, regardless of whether it is toxic or non-toxic," he said.

A chemical expert from Singapore's environmental protection agency examined the site on Tuesday and samples of the material were flown to Hong Kong on Wednesday for analysis, Mok Mareth said. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY PRESENTS CREDENTIALS TO PANAMA'S BALLADARES
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Newly-appointed Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-min presented his credentials to President Ernesto Perez Balladares of Panama on Wednesday.

During the presentation ceremony, held at the Presidential Office, Lan conveyed President Lee Teng-hui's regards to Balladares and said the ROC strongly wishes to further enhance the friendly ties between the two countries.

In response, Balladares asked Lan to convey his best regards to Lee, whom he called an old friend. The Panamanian president also expressed his heartfelt gratitude to the ROC for all the assistance it has given Panama over the years.

Speaking on the coming general elections in Panama, Balladares told the ROC envoy that candidates from the ruling Revolutionary Democratic Party will be victorious, and relations between the ROC and Panama will remain unchanged.

Lan was accompanied by Councilors Felipe Wang, Ingrid Hsing and Protocol Chief Ernesto Sarmiento. Panamanian Foreign Minister Jorge Eduardo Ritter, who is also minister of Panama Canal Affairs, was also present at the presentation ceremony.
