DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH MADE IN TAIWAN COLOR FILTER PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: In what has been described as a breakthrough in Taiwan's production technology, Chi Mei Electronics announced on Thursday that it will produce about 30,000 color filters in the first quarter of 1999.

Color filters are a required layer in the colorization of liquid crystal displays (LCD) most commonly found in notebook computer monitors. They have traditionally been imported from Japan, but local LCD producers have been troubled by a language barrier and technology gap in dealing with such importers, Chi Mei Deputy General Manager Wu Bin-sheng explained.
With advances made in the local production of color filters, Chi Mei can make Taiwan a self-sufficient source of key computer components, company president Hsu Wen-long said.
Unlike production in the petrochemical industry, the production of color filters can be accomplished without seriously polluting the environment, Hsu noted.
Plans are underway for Chi Mei's second plant located in the Tainan Science Park. Once completed, the plant is expected to produce 60,000 color filters a month, he added.

The initial investment for such an undertaking is substantial as technology in LCD development continues to change rapidly, a company representative said. Chi Mei Corporation has invested NT$20 billion (US$619 million) in its subsidiary Chi Mei Electronics and Chi Mei OPTO Electronics, a TFT-LCD producer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR NO COMMENT ON HIS FUTURE POST

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong remained tight-lipped on Thursday over his future plans but said when he meets President Lee Teng-hui he will thank the president for nominating him as a candidate in elections four years ago when the two are scheduled to meet.

Soong said he was grateful for Lee's support and the Kuomintang's assistance over the years, but declined to say whether he would accept the post of senior adviser to the president after Dec. 21 when he is due to step down from the post due to government downsizing.

The governor was speaking to reporters after being given the country's highest public servant award along with Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Deng-yi in a ceremony at the Executive Yuan.
He added that he expects the Executive Yuan will honor its promise to take care of those employees who will lose their jobs due to downsizing plans.
Soong also urged all ROC nationals to commit themselves to Taiwan's future.
Soong was later received by Lee at the presidential office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS OUTGOING TAIWAN GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday met with Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and encouraged the outgoing official to show further support for the nation's goals.

Seeking the Republic of China's survival and sustainable development are universal goal of all ROC citizens, Lee said, adding that, "The goal is not negotiable, and most importantly, it requires the concerted efforts from all of us."

Lee gave Soong, who is scheduled to bow out from his post on Dec. 21, a scroll of eight Chinese characters he wrote personally in calligraphy. The words read, "Everything, solid or subtle, is empty, and you should feel free and easy at every moment."

According to a Presidential Office statement, Lee spoke to Soong about his future after stepping down from office. Lee agreed that Soong's new appointment would not be discussed or decided until Soong returns from his vacation overseas, the statement said.

It was the first time the two had met since early last year when Soong voiced his intention to resign after the ruling Kuomintang decided to downsize the provincial government in an effort to boost administrative efficiency and the island's competitiveness.
Since then, rumors have circulated over a rift between the two.
During the meeting, Lee thanked Soong for his devoted service to the provincial government over the past five years and nine months.

Soong, Taiwan's first and only elected governor, was sworn in on Dec. 20, 1994 after winning an overwhelming victory in the first popular gubernatorial election. A year and nine months prior to that, Soong was appointed by the Cabinet to head the provincial government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO TAKE ACTION ON NON-PROFITABLE INVESTMENT PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will conduct an overall evaluation of its investment projects in January during a board of directors meeting, company chairman Chen Chao-wei said on Thursday.

The CPC will take decisive action against those investment projects that are losing money, he added. These include a prospecting project in Kazakhstan as well as others that the CPC has tried to offload without success.

Chen made the comments during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Ming-hsieh over the return rate of 17 local and overseas CPC investment projects.

According to DPP statistics, a total of NT$515 million has been invested in mines in Kazakhstan over the last five years, but the rate of return on the investment has been zero. The same is true for NT$533 million invested in Ecuador mines, Tsai said.
The rate of return in US mines reached 11.08 percent over the past five years, while that for the United Arab Emirates was 8.4 percent, and Ecuador was 52.57 percent, Chen stated.
He noted that if the CPC withdraws all investments in overseas companies that do not register profits, it will greatly affect the handling of CPC employees during the company's privatization process.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SUPPORTS US-UK MILITARY ACTION AGAINST IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard threw his support behind the joint US-British military action against Iraq, saying there were no other alternative after Iraq refused to comply with United Nations resolutions.
Neither Washington nor London had asked Australia to send any troops to the Middle East in the latest offensive, Howard said, but he would consider it if asked to do so,
Australia dispatched two warships to help blockade the Red Sea in the 1991 Gulf War when the US and its allies attacked Iraq after Baghdad invaded Kuwait.

In early 1998, Australia also sent its elite troops to the Middle East to stand by as rescuers of injured American and British troops in the event of conflict. Iraq backed down and allowed the UN team to resume inspections of its military installations.
Howard on Thursday described the joint military action as "unambiguous" and "necessary."
In the meantime, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on Thursday urged all Australians to refrain from traveling to Iraq in light of the recent military action there.
Australia does not have diplomatic ties with Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE URGES IRAQ TO END CRISIS QUICKLY

TEXT.P: The US-Britain joint air strikes against Iraq are an unfortunate turn of events, but Iraq can still resolve the matter quickly, said Singapore Foreign Minister S. Jayakumar.

Over the last year, Singapore has consistently urged the Iraqi government to comply with the United Nations Security Council resolutions and to fully cooperate with UNSCOM, said Jayakumar who is currently in Hanoi to attend Association for Southeast Asian Nations meetings.
Singapore has done so with the hopes that the present situation, which will further prolong the suffering of the Iraqi people, could be avoided, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DONATES RELIEF GOODS TO HURRICANE-HIT CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Thursday donated relief supplies to the hurricane-devastated Central American countries Honduras and Nicaragua on behalf of the city and the pharmaceutical industry.
A total of NT$40 million worth of medicine and US$10,000 was presented to the countries' ambassadors to Taiwan in a donation ceremony.
Chen urged the two countries -- whose capitals, Tegucigalpa and Managua, are Taipei's sister cities -- to support Taiwan in its bid to enter the World Health Organization as soon as possible.
Upon leaning of the disastrous health conditions suffered in these countries, the Taipei City Government requested its Bureau of Health to approach pharmaceutical companies for donations.

The mayor said during the ceremony that Taiwan does not enjoy international status in proportion to its economic and democratic achievements which is why he began practicing "city diplomacy" after taking office.
Mayor Chen has visited 19 countries during his 4-year tenure and sponsored a "international capital forum" in May to boost Taiwan and Taipei's international profile.

Chen also attended an inauguration ceremony for a "community health consultant station" under the Bureau of Health. The stations have been devised to disseminate health information with the cooperation of city hospitals across the city. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.029 to the US dollar in Taipei Thursday, closing at 32.277.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.246, and had a low of 32.29.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$309.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DEBATES OVER PLATFORM AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party, on Thursday was overwhelmed by debate over whether to change its official platform which advocates independence.
Calls for an amendment emerged after the party's dismal performance in the Dec. 5 "three-in-one" elections for lawmakers islandwide, as well as mayors and city councils in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, who chairs the DPP's faction "Justice Alliance," led the calls for changes in the existing platform.

Shen suggested that the wording be revised from "whether or not to realize Taiwan independence should be decided by national referendum" to "whether or not to deal with the issue on changing the national flag and the state name under the laws should be decided by the whole people in Taiwan."

The heavyweight DPP legislator from Taipei, who won in his reelection bid, said his idea was triggered by the fact that the party has always been criticized by opponents as being a "violent party for Taiwan independence" during elections.
Changing the platform's wording will help the DPP be more acceptable to voters, while continuing to be consistent in supporting de jure independence, Shen said.

Opposing Shen's view, DPP lawmaker Lin Chuo-shui said the party should not have to amend its official platform merely because of setbacks in elections. What should be changed are the party's campaign strategies, he insisted.
The legislator from Taipei said he believes the DPP's basic attitude illustrated by its existing platform is quite mild, rational and pragmatic.

What the voters disliked in the latest elections were the party's radical strategies used in promoting Taiwan independence, rather its Taiwan independence stance, Lin said, adding that this is the aspect the party should be re-examining in depth.
He argued that the act of revising the DPP's political platform will raise doubt and be translated as the party's move away from its basic stance -- supporting the island's independence.

Lin's opinions were echoed by Yeh Chu-lan, another DPP heavyweight in the legislature. Yeh stated that the DPP should not change its "founding spirit" only to please voters in the 2000 presidential election.

Even if the DPP were to revise its Taiwan independence platform, no voter would believe the party, which has been a consistent supporter of Taiwan independence, will keep its hands out of independence issues, Yeh said.
She added that the best way to decide Taiwan's future is still mentioned in the existing DPP platform -- allowing the public to make a decision through a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: UIGHUR YOUTHS PLEDGE TO WORK FOR INDEPENDENCE OF XINJIANG

TEXT.P: Some 300 representatives of Xinjiang dissident groups from more than 10 countries pledged here Wednesday to do their best to oppose mainland Chinese "imperialist rule" in Xinjiang.
An informed source, who asked for anonymity, said they made the pledge in a declaration issued at the conclusion of the "Second World Conference of Uighur Youths," which opened here four days ago.
In the declaration, they said that Uighur youths will be the main source of strength to strive for the independence of Xinjiang, which is also called "East Turkistan" by the Uighurs.

"All Uighur youths will oppose Chinese communist invasion and rule of East Turkistan in a more active way," they said, adding that they will try to win the support of the United Nations and various human rights organizations in the world for the Xinjiang independence movement.
The declaration also called upon the mainland Chinese government to stop persecuting the Uighurs and release Uighur political prisoners immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG ADDRESSES EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng said here Wednesday that he will fast with other dissidents Thursday to show support to Wang Youcai, who will be tried in Hangzhou on the same day on charges of "subverting state power."

Wei, a dissident, who had been imprisoned for 18 years before being released in 1997 on a medical parole, made the announcement when he addressed the European Parliament on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the World Human Rights Declaration by the United Nations.

Wang was arrested after he and other dissidents applied for registering the Hangzhou branch of the would-be China Democracy Party earlier this year. Wei said the mainland Chinese government decided to put Wang on trial soon after it signed the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights. "This is an open challenge to human rights."

Wei said mainland Chinese authorities have arrested many democracy campaigners recently, making it more and more difficult to strive for human rights. "Nevertheless, more and more people have risen up for the sake of human rights."
He urged European parliamentarians to give spiritual support to the mainland Chinese democratic movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE SLATED TO BEGIN JANUARY 1

TEXT.P: The handing out of unemployment insurance is set to begin Jan. 1, said Chang Hou-sheng, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, on Thursday.

In explaining the council's budget to the legislature, Chang said the council has reversed an earlier decision not to accept claims for compensation until one year after the program's inauguration. The change was made to demonstrate the government's concern for workers, he said.
The regulations, however, must be approved by the Executive Yuan, and that approval should come before year's end to ensure the program can begin as scheduled, said Chang.

Kuo Feng-yi, general manager of the Labor Insurance Bureau, which will oversee the program, estimated NT$3 billion in unemployment compensation would be awarded during the first year of the program. That figure is based on a government estimate of 2 percent unemployment next year.

To allay legislators' suspicions that the program would prove short-lived because of a lack of funding, Kuo said the Labor Insurance Bureau can cover the claims that will be made and that 1 percent of employees' wages would go toward the program. An additional NT$11.1 billion in reserves has been earmarked by the government's budget.

Meanwhile, those who lose their jobs will remain covered by the government's national health insurance program, with their premium payments coming from a government-created Employment Security Fund pool, said Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENTS TO START A RELAY OF FASTS FROM N.Y.

TEXT.P: New York, Dec. 16 (NA) Mainland Chinese dissidents will start a relay of fasts Thursday from New York to Washington, Los Angeles, and cities in Canada and Japan in protest against the arrests of dissidents Wang Ce, Wang Youcai, and Qin Yongmin in mainland China.

An organizer said 11 dissidents will fast in New York, one on each day. During the 24-hour fast, they will only drink water. Seven dissidents will fast in Los Angeles, Canada, and Japan each, also one on each day. They will write down their thinking during the fasting period for the promotion of democracy in mainland China.
The fast will be held by Yen Jiaqi, Wang Bingzhang, Wan Rennan, Wang Hanwan, and other well-known dissidents from mainland China.
The organizer said that during the relay of fasts they will call upon the mainland Chinese government to release the three dissidents as soon as possible.

Want Ce was arrested after sneaking back to mainland China from Spain earlier this year to help promote democracy in the country. Wang Youcai and Qin Yong-min were arrested separately for their attempt to establish an opposition party.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIBANK PLANS TO STRENGTHEN ITS PRESENCE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Citibank, N.A. plans to invest NT$30 million in Taiwan in the near future to form a life insurance company and an investment trust company and to establish two more Citibank branches, a high-ranking company official said Thursday.

The banking official said in a year-end news conference that Citibank decided to carry out the investment plan because Taiwan's economy is expected to recover in 1999 and because Taiwan's investment outlook remains attractive to Citibank.

Asked about Bank of America's (BOA) plan to sell its consumer banking operations in Taiwan, the Citibank official said the move is merely an adjustment of the bank's operating strategy and that it has nothing to do with BOA's earnings or deficits. And while other banks are reducing the scale of their operations in Taiwan, Citibank will increase its staff in the near future to bolster its presence in Taiwan, the official said.
The Citibank-affiliated life insurance company is to be set up in February 1999, while the investment trust company is scheduled to be formed in May 1999.
The establishment of two additional Citibank branches will bring to 11 its number of branches in Taiwan.

Affected by general declines in global stock markets, earnings for Citibank's Taiwan branches were down in this year's third quarter. But cumulative earnings for the first three quarters have been enough for Citibank to achieve its 1998 growth target, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ADOPTS ROC-CHADIAN AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY COOPERATION ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved at its regular meeting on Thursday an agricultural technology cooperation agreement between the Republic of China and the Republic of Chad.

The Republic of China and Chad restored diplomatic relations in August 1997. The agricultural technology cooperation agreement was reached in accordance with a memorandum signed upon the restoration of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Under the agreement the Republic of China will dispatch a 10-member agricultural technology mission to Chad to help the north African country develop its agriculture.
The agreement was signed by Chiu Chung-jen, the ROC's ambassador to Chad, and by Chadian Foreign Minister Annadif in Chad's capital of N'Djamena on Oct. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WALKS AWAY WITH THREE SILVERS ONE BRONZE

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei earned three silver medals and one bronze during the 12th day of the Asian Games in Bangkok on Thursday.
Taiwan archers Chang Chia-pin, Wu Tsung-yi and Chiu Po-han, won a silver in the team event with a combined score of 238, only 8 points behind South Korea, which took the gold.

Chen Teng-ting, who competed for Taiwan in the 65-kilogram division of the Asian Games' karate competition, had to settled for a silver after being defeated by Japan's Norihide Narazaki in the finals.
Hsu Pei-chin of Taiwan pocketed a silver in the women's 400-meter hurdles with a time of 55.71 seconds. She broke her own record of 55.75 seconds, set at the last Asian Games.
Chen Tien-wen won the island's only bronze on Thursday in the men's 400-meter with a time of 50.46 seconds.
So far Taiwan has earned 18 golds, 16 silvers and 35 bronzes at the games, which will end Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY 40 PERCENT OF TAIWAN'S YOUTH OPTIMISTIC ABOUT COUNTRY'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: Although about 70 percent of Taiwan's youth are optimistic about their futures, only 40 percent are as confident about the future of the country, according to a survey released on Thursday.

In a survey designed to ascertain the thinking, values, concerns and preferred lifestyles of those in Taiwan aged 18 to 39, 25.3 percent of respondents said they are "very optimistic" about their future, while 43.1 percent said they were "a little optimistic," 14.9 percent "not very optimistic" and 2.4 percent "not at all optimistic."

Respondents were less confident about the country's future, with only 8.3 percent saying they were "very optimistic." Meanwhile 29.1 percent said they were "a little optimistic," 29.7 percent "not very optimistic" and 7.8 percent "not at all optimistic."

The average age at which respondents first had sex was 20.21, and although 40.8 percent of respondents admitted to having sex before marriage, 48.8 percent said they opposed the idea of a "trial marriage." The idea was supported, however, by 42.5 percent of the respondents. The survey also indicated 24.8 percent of respondents said they would divorce their spouse for having an affair.
The survey, commissioned by the non-profit Youth Foundation and carried out by National Chengchi University, involved 1,241 telephone interviews, conducted between Nov. 28 and Dec. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA CONTINUES TO OFFER ATTRACTIVE INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: Despite the region's economic downturn, Asia continues to provide attractive investment opportunities, according to the results of a poll conducted by the NUS Center for Business Research (CBRD).
Mainland China was cited as the country with the best business opportunities followed by Singapore, the United States, India and Malaysia, the poll conducted in mid-1998 of 139 local companies said.
Malaysia fell from third place in an earlier survey to fifth in the latest while Indonesia dropped out of the top five ranking altogether.
The United States, on the other hand, is seen providing better opportunities as it moved up from fifth place to third.

The difference in the results of the two surveys "can be interpreted as the impact of the financial crisis on investment opportunities," said the CBRD in a report published in the latest issue of the Stock Exchange of Singapore's SES Journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Air raid sirens sent shivers through Baghdad as the Iraqi capital braced for the second wave of a punitive US-British campaign to smash the country's weapons of mass destruction.
The China Times:
American and British forces attacked Iraq again.
The United Daily News:
The US-led forces launched two rounds of punitive air strikes against Iraq.
The Liberty Times:
US-British forces launched two waves of air raids against Iraq in 20 hours.
The Independence Morning Post:
US-led forces launched surprise attacks on Iraq.
The Commons Daily:
US-led air strikes against Iraq drew criticism from the Vatican.
The China Post:
Sirens send shivers through Baghdad.
The China News:
US-led forces pound Baghdad.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND PHASE OF KINMEN DE-MINING OPERATIONS UNDERWAY

TEXT.P: The second phase of de-mining operations on the Republic of China-held front-line island of Kinmen formally kicked off Friday, according to the Kinmen Defense Command.

British de-mining company Specialist Gurkha Services UK Ltd. has begun removing mines from the No. 1 and No. 2 minefields of Hsiputou village and have called for people in the vicinity of the Gen. Lee Kuang-chien Temple, located behind the fields, to keep away from the work site.

The de-mining is scheduled to be completed before Feb. 13, 1999, according to the staff of Gurkha Services, which won a US$1.7 million contract through an open tender in 1997 to clear the minefields scattered in front of the temple.
Gurkha Services said the company will ensure the de-mining operations proceed safely, with traffic possibly being redirected during the course of their work.
Gurkha Services completed in May this year the first phase of the de-mining operations, which concentrated on the No. 6 minefield, also located in front of the temple.

Over the nearly five-decade rivalry between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Kinmen command has deployed thousands of anti-personnel and anti-tank mines on the front-line island's beaches to deter an invasion by mainland forces.
The ROC Ministry of National Defense has budgeted US$14 million for the removal of all landmines from eight abandoned minefields on Kinmen.

Gurkha Services is staffed mainly by retired Nepalese veterans from Britain's famous Gurkha Regiment. The company has undertaken de-mining work in more than 10 countries, including Mozambique, Afghanistan, South Korea, Cambodia, Swaziland and Kuwait.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 18, or the 30th day of the 10th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan, which had been proclaimed capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa in World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan, and Thailand.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by party secretary Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting from 1988.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1992: Kim Young Sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, was elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
Confucius: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND AND HONG KONG CALLED ON TO ENHANCE COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Wang Man-na and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong trade official has suggested that Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China further enhance cooperation to help one other overcome their economic difficulties amid Asia's financial storm.

T.H. Chau, Hong Kong's supervisor of the Trade and Industry Bureau, made the suggestion in a trade and economic conference with representatives of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and Hong Kong on Wednesday.

He explained that mainland China enjoys abundant technological resources, which Hong Kong can import to help to upgrade its industrial technologies. Moreover, mainland China and Taiwan can cooperate on research in such areas as Chinese medicine, computer software and biological technology, Chau said.

In addition, competitive businesses from Taiwan and Hong Kong can help mainland Chinese state-run companies improve productivity, while Hong Kong can provide not only capital but also its legal knowledge and know-how in international business operations, the Hong Kong official said.
Chau's views on cooperation among the three Chinese economies were echoed by the conference's participants, most of whom were members of chambers of commerce in Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China.

Mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong are all major trade partners of one another, while Hong Kong is the mainland's largest source of foreign capital and Taiwan the second-largest source, according to the Association of Chinese Businesses in Hong Kong.
A representative of the association revealed at the conference that investments from Hong Kong and Taiwan in the mainland account for more than 60 percent of all foreign investment in mainland China.

Affected by the Asian financial meltdown, Taiwan's exports dropped by 9 percent in the first 10 months of this year, while those of Hong Kong slid 5 percent. Mainland China, however, achieved modest export growth of 1.3 percent over the same last-year period.
Boosting the level of trade and cooperation among the three economies would help them the combat the ill effects of the region's crisis, the representative said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT STABILITY IS IN US INTEREST: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday that the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait has a direct bearing on the well-being of all Chinese and is also critical to the stability of the entire Asia-Pacific region.

"At the moment, maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is crucial and complies with the US national interest," Lee said while meeting with a US congressional delegation headed by Senator Tim Johnson (SD-D).
Lee told his guests that the Republic of China has continued promoting democratic reforms and human rights protection over past years.
"In other words, the ROC's persistent political ideals are consistent with the traditional US spirit of upholding democracy, fairness and justice," Lee noted.

The president went on to say that although Taiwan has limited arable land and natural resources, it has managed to emerge as an economic powerhouse in East Asia. "For instance, the ROC outpaces mainland China in per capita purchasing power," he added.

For his part, Senator Johnson said this is his second visit to Taiwan. "I first visited here in 1991. I found that the ROC has made phenomenal progress in various fields over the past seven years," Johnson said, adding that he was particularly impressed by the ROC's strength and resilience in withstanding the year-long Asian financial turmoil.

In reply, President Lee said the Asian financial and economic woes have resulted from a variety of factors. "The basic reason behind the ROC's ability to shun the brunt of the Asian financial crisis is its pragmatic and down-to-earth economic development strategy," he said.

Lee pointed out that he personally does not agree with the so-called "Asian value" concept. "All men are created equal. All people, regardless of their races or colors, should be subject to same human rights and behavior standards."

Noting that political democratization and economic liberalization and globalization are the ROC's consistent national policy and stance, Lee said the ROC will continue striving for sustained economic growth and for entering major international organizations.

Lee also expressed his heartfelt gratitude for the long-term US congressional support for the ROC's national cause. "We'll always remember the friendship and goodwill the American people have shown to us," he added.
Johnson arrived in Taipei on Thursday for a four-day visit. He told Lee that he will continue to promote closer economic exchanges and cooperation between the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: STABLE GROWTH, INDUSTRIAL UPGRADING KEEP TAIWAN ANCHORED AMID STORM

TEXT.P: Stable and steady economic growth and the continual upgrading of Taiwan's industrial structure are two reasons why Taiwan's economy has been among those least affected by the Asian economic crisis, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Friday.

Other factors that have enabled Taiwan to weather the present storm better than many of its Asian neighbors are the island's sizable current account surplus, large foreign exchange reserves, low levels of foreign debt, dynamic development of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and correct government policies, Yen said.

Speaking at a seminar on Taiwan's monetary market development, Yen said Taiwan's well-established economy, whose foundation is sound and which has sustained stable growth over recent decades, is the major reason Taiwan has remained relatively unscathed by the regional economic turmoil.

Taiwan's economic growth, which has averaged 6 percent annually over the last 10 years, is the second highest in Asia, behind only that of mainland China. It is also among the world's top 10 economies in terms of sustained growth, Yen said.

The successful upgrading of Taiwan's industrial structure, from labor-intensive industries to capital- and technology-intensive ones, is another source of strength for Taiwan's economy, Yen noted. Taking companies listed on the Taipei Stock Exchange as an example, Yen said most of the high-performing blue-chip companies on the market 10 years ago are no longer stars.

The island's sizable two-way trade surplus and current account surplus, which reflects a rise in debts owed by other countries to Taiwan, have also made it financially strong, he added. The current account is composed of merchandise and service trade, as well as unrequited transfers.

Compared with Taiwan, Yen said most of the hard-hit Southeast Asian countries have high levels of foreign debt. On the contrary, Taiwan holds foreign assets totaling more than US$160 billion, including US$90 billion owned by the government and US$70 billion owned by the private sector, he said. But Taiwan's foreign debts, owed as the result of public development projects, total only US$74 million.

SMEs have been the backbone of Taiwan's economic growth, Yen noted. Unlike South Korea, whose government encouraged the development of business and industrial conglomerates, Taiwan's government gave full support to SMEs, he said.
Because Taiwan's SMEs stress profit and flexibility in their operations and management, they have been able to withstand the adversities encountered during the region's financial troubles, Yen said.

Meanwhile, Yen said the results of the government's efforts to expand domestic demand are expected to become apparent in the second half of next year. By then, Taiwan's economy will outperform by an even wider margin those of other Asian countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: USING FORCE WILL NOT RESOLVE IRAQI DISPUTE: S. AFRICA

TEXT.P: South Africa does not believe the use of force will resolve the dispute over Iraq's non-compliance with UN resolutions, South African Minister of Foreign Affairs Alfred Nzo said Thursday.
In a statement on the air strikes launched by the United States and Britain against Iraq, Nzo said South Africa fully supported all UN Security Council resolutions on the need for Iraq to comply.
The lack of unanimity by the members of the UN Security Council on the decision to strike was of concern to the South African government, Nzo said.
He said these actions would inevitably lead to greater human suffering for the people of Iraq.
Nzo called on all sides to seek a negotiated settlement and to avoid any further actions that would aggravate tensions in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TONES DOWN SUPPORT FOR MILITARY ATTACKS ON IRAQ

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien toned down his initially enthusiastic support Thursday for US-British air strikes against Iraq.
Chretien qualified his position by saying the situation did not make him happy. His initial response to the first bombings Wednesday in Baghdad was that Saddam Hussein "asked for it."
The change in language a day later brought Chretien's position closer to that of visiting French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who has expressed concern over the human costs of the military action.

"We also deplore to a certain point that the Americans and the English were forced to act," Chretien told a news conference, using Jospin's words. "We wish Saddam Hussein had not caused this attack by the British and the Americans."

While Chretien felt the attack was inevitable, his guest did not think so. "We have from one side American frustration, on the other side Iraqis' irrationality. It looked in the last few days that it was inevitable, but inevitable does not mean necessary," said Jospin.

"Of course, we hope that Saddam Hussein eventually respects the obligations that the international community imposed on him, so that the situation can become normal and the embargoes can come to an end and the population will not suffer as it suffers," said Chretien.
Chretien played down any differences in the French and Canadian response to the attacks after meeting Jospin, saying it was a matter "we interpret somewhat differently."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 70 PERCENT OF TAIWAN YOUNGSTERS HAVE SEEN PORNOGRAPHIC FILMS

TEXT.P: Youngsters in Taiwan are greatly curious about sex, and up to 71.5 percent have seen a pornographic film, a survey released by the Youth Development Foundation on Friday showed.

The survey, conducted by National Chengchi University at the request of the foundation, also found that the number of male youngsters who have seen pornographic films is higher than that of female youngsters, with 81.6 percent of young men and 60.7 percent of young women saying they have seen one.
In terms of age, 80.9 percent of those between 18 and 22, and 56.8 percent of those between 15 and 17 have seen pornographic films.
Seventeen percent of the youngsters polled said they have had sex. The number was significantly higher among those aged 18-22 (25 percent) than among those aged 15-17 (4.5 percent).

Wang Li-jong, one of the scholars who participated in the survey, said that several surveys have shown that Taiwan youngsters have an attitude toward sex that is more open than the attitudes of youngsters in some other Asian countries.
The survey also said that youngsters worried most about their school homework (41.2 percent), followed by jobs (11.3 percent) and their individual financial situation (6.2 percent).

Some 17.5 percent said that they have thought of committing suicide. The youngsters also said they would seek opinions from friends (48.6 percent) and their families (22.6 percent) if they have problems. While only 0.4 percent said they would confide in their teachers.

Wang said a worrying phenomenon is that youngsters are seeking views from their peers, who are considered the least able to offer solutions to problems. This indicates that youngsters have no trust in their families and schools.

As for future careers, 9.9 percent said they would like to work in the information sector, 7.1 percent in the education sector, 4.9 percent in the service sector, 4.8 percent in the commercial sector. 4.1 percent in the financial or banking sector and 3.7 percent in the arts.
The survey was conducted between Nov. 28 and Dec. 3 with 824 youngsters interviewed by telephones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES DOWN, FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but then fell lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday amid bearish sentiment.
The TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropped 13.98 points, closing at 6,636.66.
Trading remained weak following falls over the past two days, despite government efforts to pump up the market through an injection of funds.
A total of 1.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.3 billion (US$1.99 billion), compared with the previous session's NT$58.05 billion in turnover.
Losers outnumbered gainers 306 to 100, with 79 stocks unchanged.
Electronic engineering shares increased 0.6 percent and financial issues climbed 0.2 percent.
The over-the-counter market registered a 1.75-point loss, closing at 168.72, with a turnover of NT$3.23 billion.
Meanwhile, trading on Taiwan's stock index futures saw gains in Friday's session.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January surged 78 points to finish at 6,769 with 5,258 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for February climbed 65 points to close at 6,770, with 91 contract transactions, while those for March rose 68 points to 6,768, those for June moved up 38 points to 6,710 and those for September surged 234 points to 6,798.
Transactions for the three months were 52, six and one, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 6,691 points for January; 6,705 for February; 6,700 for March; 6,672 for June; and 6,564 for September.
