DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES IN MIDDLE EAST HEIGHTEN ALERT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that it has ordered all of the Republic of China's representative offices in the Middle East to heighten alert in the wake of fresh air strikes against Iraq by US-led forces.

"We have instructed our representative offices in the Middle East to strengthen protection for ROC nationals in the region as the US-British forces launched two rounds of punitive air raids on the Iraqi capital of Baghdad on Thursday," said MOFA spokesman Roy Wu.
Wu said even though the ROC is not a member of the United Nations, it hopes Iraq will allow special UN inspection teams to examine its arsenal in line with UN resolutions.

"Only an immediate compliance with the UN resolutions can save the Muslim country from further punitive attacks and restore regional peace," Wu noted, adding that the ROC fully supports the UN resolutions on the inspection of Iraqi weapons.

In order to protect the personal safety and property of ROC expatriates in the region, Wu said the ministry has ordered its nine outposts in eight Middle East countries to reinforce contacts with and services with ROC nationals there.
MOFA officials said the ROC's representative offices in Jordan, Kuwait, Israel and Saudi Arabia have informed the ministry of their various protective measures for ROC expatriates in those countries.

"All those offices have set up emergency hotlines to facilitate contacts with expatriates," a MOFA official said, adding that the ROC's representative office in Israel has advised people there not to travel to that country for the time being.

Meanwhile, the two Taiwan carriers that provide flight services over the Middle East said on Friday that US-British air strikes against Iraq have so far not incurred any traffic disruption apart from a few detours.

EVA Airways has adjusted its routes for European-bound flights that fly over the controlled zone of Bahrain, while China Airlines reported no change as all its flights destined for Europe have always flown over Abu Dhabi instead of Bahrain.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERMENT HEADS TO BE APPROVED TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Friday relaxed restrictions on visits to mainland China by mayors and county chiefs.

The Executive Yuan amended regulations governing mainland China visits by Republic of China residents, permitting visits by the mayors of such cities as Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as by county chiefs.
The amendment will be implemented after obtaining approval from the Cabinet.

Chao Shou-po, who was appointed Taiwan provincial governor by the Executive Yuan, met with officials from the Ministry of the Interior, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of National Defense to examine the regulations, which were approved without objection.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO EXPLORE OIL IN MAINLAND CHINA, SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is substantially reshaping its overseas oil exploration plans, abandoning non-profitable projects and accelerating those in mainland China and the Southeast Asia.

CPC Chairman Chen Chao-wei, who was delivering a report at the Legislative Yuan, said the CPC will take decisive actions against those investment projects that are losing money, such as the one in Kazakhstan, and others that it has tried to offload without success.
Meanwhile, the CPC has decided to accelerate cooperative projects in mainland China, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, South America and North America, Chen noted.

The projects in mainland China are likely to kick off first if the two sides agree that joint ventures will be undertaken on equal footing and the sovereignty issue will be put aside, the CPC chairman said.

Initially, the CPC's offshoot, the Overseas Petroleum Investment Corp. (CPIC), and mainland China's National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) will jointly pitch in US$900,000 into a project on physical prospecting in the Chaoshan oil structures near mainland China's coastal Guangdong province, Chen said.

Under an agreement signed by the CPIC and CNOOC last March and has been endorsed by the ROC Mainland Affairs Council, the two sides will conduct physical exploration in an area of 15,400 square kilometers to the south of Zhuhai to determine the volume of oil and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) deposits in the area.

During a series of questions at the Legislative Yuan, legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed skepticism over the CPC's efficiency in designing and engaging in exploration projects overseas. They said the return rate of the prospect project in Kazakhstan, valued at US$515 million, was zero, while a similar one in Ecuador, which cost US$533 million, was also zero.
Currently, the CPC maintains 10 oil-drilling and related exploration projects in six countries overseas, which include Indonesia, Ecuador, the United States, and the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CONCERNED OVER AIR STRIKES' EFFECTS ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui expressed concern Thursday on the possible effects US-British air strikes on Iraq may have on cross-strait relations.
Lee said ROC ministries should monitor the situation in the Gulf, as well as mainland China's response to the US military strikes against Iraq.
He made the remarks after listening to briefings from officials with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Present at the briefings were ROC Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, Secretary-General to the President, Huang Kun-hui, National Security Council Secretary-General, Ding Mou-shih, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, deputy Secretary-General to the President, Su Chi, and National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Yin Tsung-wen.
The United States and Britain launched a series of air strikes against Iraq on Thursday.

At the same meeting, Lien reported on his recent visit to the ROC's four allies in Central America hard hit by Hurricane Mitch. He also reported on how Washington is assisting nations in the region, as well as on mainland China's attempted diplomatic suppression of Taiwan, according to a high-ranking ROC official. Lien conveyed during the meeting the US State Department's appreciation of Taiwan's efforts in providing relief to Central American countries.

Meanwhile, the ministries of defense, economic affairs and foreign affairs, as well as the NSB, submitted evaluation reports on the air strikes' effects on Taiwan's domestic oil supply, on regional security and on cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH TO SLOW IN 1999: ECONOMIC INSTITUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy faces tough times ahead which will put the estimated rate of economic growth below 5 percent in the first quarter of 1999, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research predicted on Friday.
However, the economy could rebound in the second quarter after it reaches a record low of 4.43 percent growth in the first quarter, according to the institution.

The dismal expectations are based on low investor confidence in the local economic situation in the new year, Chung-Hua representatives said. They added that a decline in investments will lead to decreases in production and imports.

Another reason for the pessimism is an expected downturn in global trade in 1999, leaving Taiwan's export and import growth rate stagnate at 2.95 percent and 2.79 percent respectively, the institute noted.

However, Chung-Hua economists foresee a 9.43 percent growth in private sector investment in the new year. The figure will likely reach only 0.21 percent in the first quarter of 1999 due to the delay in construction of an express railway and businesses postponing their investment plans, the institute added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW DENIES VYING FOR VICE PRESIDENCY NOMINATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday asserted that he was not seeking to run as vice president on the ruling Kuomintang ticket in Taiwan's vice presidential elections slated for 2000.

Siew was responding to questions from Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Yu Hong over his possible role as the running mate for incumbent Vice President Lien Chan, outgoing Provincial Governor James Soong, and outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian from the DPP.
The premier reiterated that he was committed to his current post and had never considered running for vice president.
Speaking at the Legislative Yuan's plenary session, Siew also said he would announce his decision on the cabinet's resignation before the new legislature convenes on Feb. 1, 1999.

Previously, appointment of cabinet members required approval by the legislature and the Executive Yuan traditionally resigned en masse to facilitate such an approval after a new legislature was elected. However, amendments to the ROC Constitution do not include regulations on a Cabinet resignation.
Siew said he will consult with constitution experts, legislators and President Lee Teng-hui before making a final decision on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: GULF TENSION WILL NOT AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The current tension in the Persian Gulf will not have any adverse impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.
Siew made the statement in response to questions in the legislature from Legislator Lin Jui-ching from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Lin said while Beijing has angrily denounced US-British air strikes against Iraq, Taiwan has thrown its support behind the attacks due to the Middle Eastern country's refusal to allow United Nations inspection teams to examine its arsenal.

"I suspect that the conflicting attitude toward the Iraqi issue may strain cross-strait relations," Lin said, adding that he was also concerned whether the government has made an overall review of the possible impact of the current Persian Gulf situation on crude oil prices.
In reply, Premier Siew said the United States and Britain have launched air raids on Iraq in line with UN resolutions.

"While not a UN member, the Republic of China is a member of the international community. We respect UN resolutions and therefore support the US-British bombing of Iraq for its defiance of the UN rules," Siew explained, adding that the ROC is hopeful that Iraq will cooperate with the UN weaponry inspection teams and abide by all related rules to restore peace in the region as soon as possible.

The premier further said even though the ROC's stance on the US-British air strikes against Iraq differs from mainland China's, such differences are not expected to have any negative bearing on cross-strait relations.

As for the crude oil price issue, Siew said the current Persian Gulf tension is a temporary phenomenon. "As long as the weapons inspection dispute can be resolved soon, crude oil prices are not expected to fluctuate drastically," he said, adding that the government will closely monitor the situation.
The ROC relies heavily on imports for its crude oil supply and Middle East countries are its major source of import.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said it has ordered all of the ROC's representative offices in the Middle East to heighten alert in the wake of fresh air strikes against Iraq by US-led forces.

"We have instructed our representative offices in the Middle East to strengthen protection for ROC nationals in the region as the US-British forces launched two rounds of punitive air raids on the Iraqi capital of Baghdad on Thursday," said MOFA spokesman Roy Wu.
Wu said even though the ROC is not a member of the United Nations, it hopes Iraq will allow special UN inspection teams to examine its arsenal in line with UN resolutions.

"Only an immediate compliance with the UN resolutions can save the Muslim country from further punitive attacks and restore regional peace," Wu noted, adding that the ROC fully supports the UN resolutions on the inspection of Iraqi weapons.

In order to protect the personal safety and property of ROC expatriates in the region, Wu said the ministry has ordered its nine outposts in eight Middle East countries to reinforce contacts with and services with ROC nationals there.
MOFA officials said the ROC's representative offices in Jordan, Kuwait, Israel and Saudi Arabia have informed the ministry of their various protective measures for ROC expatriates in those countries.

"All those offices have set up emergency hotlines to facilitate contacts with expatriates," a MOFA official said, adding that the ROC's representative office in Israel has advised people there not to travel to that country for the time being.

Meantime, the two Taiwan carriers that provide flight services over the Middle East said on Friday that US-British air strikes against Iraq have so far not incurred any traffic disruption apart from a few detours.

EVA Airways has adjusted its routes for European-bound flights that fly over the controlled zone of Bahrain, while China Airlines reported no change as all its flights destined for Europe have always flown over Abu Dhabi instead of Bahrain.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCIAL ASSEMBLY PASSES INTO HISTORY

TEXT.P: The last meeting of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Friday marked the end of the 52-year-old assembly which was downgraded to the Provincial Advisory Council in a bid to increase government efficiency.

The mood during the last meeting, which lasted only 30 minutes, was far from gloomy as 46 of 70 deputies succeeded in their bids for legislative seats in the Dec. 5 elections. Deputies quickly approved the budget auditing report for 1998 and several proposals.
Assembly Secretary-General Huang Min-kong, after his farewell speech to deputies, formally declared the end of the assembly that had held 231 regular and provisional meetings over the years.
Afterward, Speaker Liu Ping-wei hit the gavel with the hammer three times to conclude the meeting.

A deputy of the ruling Kuomintang suggested presenting the hammer, as a symbol of Taiwan's democratic achievements, to Liu as the speaker gave every deputy a set of commemorative gold coins of the assembly as souvenirs.
Liu expressed his gratitude to deputies during the meeting and vowed to help those who succeeded in their bid for legislative seats to carry out campaign promises when they take office.
After the meeting, assembly deputies took photos outside the assembly building and held a ceremony for the opening of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly Commemorative Park.
A placard in the assembly's park identifying it as the "Taiwan Provincial Assembly" was replaced with one which read "Taiwan Provincial Commemorative Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 32.274.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.265, and had a low of 32.33.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$464 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS POOR RECORDS IN PROTECTING WOMEN, CHILDREN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has poor records in protecting women and children, according to a study by the World Vision of Taiwan released on Friday.
The study shows that an average of 112 child abuse cases and 65 women abuse cases has been reported in Taiwan per month over the past three years.
The World Vision of Taiwan issued the report to mark the third anniversary of the founding of its children and women protection center.

The organization said it has handled a total of 4,067 appeals for sheltering abused children through county and city governments over the past three years. During the same period, it has also received 2,259 applications for protecting abused women through various local governments.

Among the child abuse cases, 27.8 percent were related inappropriate parental nurturing; 15.5 percent related to physical maltreatment; 7.1 percent related to spiritual abuse; 6.3 percent related to sexual abuse.

Of the child abusers, 1,841 were men and 1,395 were women. Moreover, the study shows that parents accounted for 75.8 percent of alleged child abusers, with fathers making up 56.1 percent and mothers forming 19.7 percent.
Among the reported women abuse cases, 68.8 percent were related to physical abuse; 25.6 percent related to spiritual abuse; and sexual abuse accounted for 3.6 percent.

Most noteworthy was that an overwhelming majority of 95.5 percent of the women who have sought the World Vision's assistance over the past three years have been abused by their husbands. About 3 percent were abused by their live-in lovers and slightly more than 1 percent were abused by their former spouses.

The study also found that 34.9 percent of those women began to endure domestic violence within the first year of their marriage and that about half of the abused women aged between 31 and 40. Some 16 percent of abused women had married for more than 20 years.

The World Vision of Taiwan said it will expand its current youngsters and women protection center into a family protection center. Under its expansion project, the organization will open a new women's counseling hotline on Dec. 28.
Meanwhile, the Chinese Association for Human Rights also said on Friday that Taiwan has failed to live up to the world children's rights standards this year.
The non-profit organization uses four measurements to gauge the children's rights situation in Taiwan in 1998 -- basic human rights, social rights, education rights and health rights.

The organization sent questionnaires to 100 experts in eight related professions. According to their evaluations, Taiwan received a score of 2.7 points for its children's rights protection in 1998. The minimum passing score is 3 points.
The organization said the outbreak of the enterovirus epidemic earlier this year was to blame for the retrogression in Taiwan children's health rights.
Nevertheless, the survey found that Taiwan has made progress in children's social rights over the past year, with youngsters enjoying increased opportunities to take part in social activities.
The association also said that local mass media's failure to pay attention to their role or function in children's education has undermined local youngsters' educational rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRADE DEFICIT WITH TAIWAN HITS NINE-YEAR HIGH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: US exports to Taiwan have dropped for eight consecutive months, a rarity in the last 20 years of bilateral trade, according to the latest US trade report released on Thursday.
A further decline is expected to increase the US trade deficit with Taiwan to a record high since 1989, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) report said.

While Taiwan was the top Asian tiger in terms of total export value and export growth to the United States in the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan imports from the US posted negative growth from March to October.
US exports to Taiwan did not begin to undergo negative growth until March, with double-digit figures appearing in the months from June to October.
US exports to Taiwan dropped by 24 percent in June, 27 percent in July, 24 percent in August, 19 percent in September, and 10 percent in October, according to the DOC report.
During the January-October period, US exports to Taiwan fell a total of US$1.72 billion, or 10.4 percent, from record levels set during the same period last year, the report showed.

Due to lower demand in Taiwan for US goods and moderate growth in Taiwan export to the United States, the US' trade deficit with Taiwan reached US$12.67 billion in the first 10 months of this year, the highest compared to the same period over the last nine years.
Taiwan is now the US' fourth largest source of trade deficit, following Japan, mainland China and Canada. Last year, the island was the US' sixth largest source of trade deficit.

The growing trade imbalance has reportedly raised concern in Washington. DOC Undersecretary David Aaron recently said that Congress will take a more active role in setting up bills in support of trade protection measures to help US businesses compete with their foreign counterparts.

According to the DOC's trade statistics during the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan is at present the United States' seventh largest trading partner after Canada, Japan, Mexico, Britain, mainland China and Germany.
Taiwan was listed as the US' seventh largest market for exports, and the seventh largest import resource, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MRT PASSENGERS TO HIT 100 MILLION NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The number of passengers who travel on Taipei's Mass Rapid Transport (MRT) system is expected to reach the 100 million mark on Tuesday, the Taipei Mass Rapid Transport Corp. (TMRTC) said on Friday.
The one hundred millionth passenger will be awarded with a set of gold coins commemorating the soon to be opened Chungho line and 60 free rides on the MRT, according to the TMRTC.
The passengers in front and behind the lucky winner will each receive a set of silver coins commemorating the MRT's Mucha and Tamsui lines and 30 free rides.
Meanwhile, the newly built Chungho line is expected to begin operations in the days before outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian hands over the post to Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou on Friday.

A task force from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has found 68 defects along the Chungho line after conducting engineering tests last week. Thirteen of these major defects must be corrected before the opening.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLIGHT EXPERTS CALL FOR GREATER SAFETY

TEXT.P: Noting that Asia has a higher air accident rate than other parts of the world, participants at a flight safety conference on Friday called for greater efforts to improve flight safety.
The 8th Annual National Airline Safety Conference, sponsored by Formosa Airlines, included representatives from airlines, scholars and government officials in charge of aviation.

Yuan Hsin-yuan, president of Flight Safety Foundation in Taiwan, said according to statistics collected by aircraft manufacturer Boeing, there is an average of 1.4 air accidents in the world for every one million flights.

In terms of regions, Africa is the most dangerous with 9.5 accidents per million flights followed by Latin America with 4.7, 2.7 in mainland China, 2.3 in Asia (not including the mainland), 1.9 in the Middle East, 0.8 in Europe, and 0.5 accidents in North America and Oceania, Yuan said.

With the recent advances in technology, accidents have been kept to relatively low rate over the past decade but as air transportation volume is expected to double in the next 15 years, accident rates are expected to increase. Therefore, it is important that flight safety be effectively increased along with volume to minimize accidents, Yuan noted.

Speaking at the conference, Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, agreed that the air accident rate for Taiwan is too high. He added that the CAA has set as its target zero accidents in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL URGES BEIJING TO INITIATE DEMOCRATIC REFORM

TEXT.P: Taiwan is concerned about the recent arrests of Wang Youcai, Qin Yongmin, and other dissidents in mainland China, Vice Chairman Hseu Ke-sheng of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in Taipei said Friday at a press conference.
Wang and Qin were recently arrested and put on trial for attempting to set up an opposition party called the "China Democracy Party."

Hseu said that democracy is based on the respect for human rights and the rule of law, and that democratization has become a trend in the whole world. He expressed the hope that mainland China will initiate democratic reform as soon as possible.

He also refuted certain mainland Chinese articles criticizing Taiwan for playing the "democracy card." Taiwan is pursuing national unification under the principles of democracy, freedom, and an equitable distribution of wealth for all Chinese people, he said, adding that the results of the elections held in Taiwan on Dec. 5 will not affect Taiwan policy toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NEW TAIWANESE' IS NOT PRECURSOR TO INDEPENDENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui's "New Taiwanese" is in line with his support of an "esprit de corps" and is not a precursor to a declaration of Taiwan independence, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.
Lee first coined the phrase during the campaign period for the Dec. 5 elections, calling for people from all walks of society in Taiwan to unite under a common identity.
It is a natural derivative of Lee's calls for a united front rather than a trick to gain support from voters, Siew said in an interpellation session at the legislature.

He rejected a suggestion by a pro-independence legislator that the idea of a "New Taiwanese" should be developed as a basis for Taiwan independence, saying that Lee used the term to create a common identity for various parochial groups on the island.

Siew said any attempt to fit the concept of a "New Taiwanese" into a pro-independence platform would be taking it completely out of context as Lee has stated that, "Taiwan independence does not make any sense" because the Republic of China on Taiwan has long been a sovereignty recognized by at least 27 nations around the world. Siew was referring to comments Lee made to the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELEVATED BY DEMOCRATIC ELECTIONS: SINGAPORE PAPER

TEXT.P: Although the democratic process in Taiwan is young and full of flaws, the Dec. 5 elections proved that democracy can be implemented in an East Asian setting, the Straits Times said on Friday in a commentary.
If democracy means that people get to exercise the right to elect the candidate they like best, then the Taiwanese model has surely passed the test.
In the run-up to elections for legislators, as well as city councils and mayors in Taipei and Kaohsiung, a variety of people ranging from scholars to the man on the street engaged in active debate.
Voters were eager not only to cast their ballots, but were also engaged in expressing their views -- even dissenting non-mainstream ones, the daily noted.
The recent elections showed that people were not coerced in any way in their selection of candidates, for this, the Taiwan government can truly be proud of its democratization efforts.

Another aspect of democracy displayed in Taiwan was the multi-party system in which parties compete to win support for their platforms. Theoretically, such competition ensures that the most suitable, if not the best, candidate holds public office, the paper said.
This was true in the Taipei mayoral race. Ideological issues aside, almost all Taipei residents agreed that they were lucky to have such a high quality of candidates running for the post, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC SEES NO NEED TO LOWER INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) sees no immediate need to lower its rediscount rate, secured loan rate or bank reserve requirement, Deputy Governor Hsu Yi-hsiung said during a regular news conference.
As the current interbank offered rate is at around 4.9 percent, down more than 2 percent from early January's 7.33 percent, the CBC considers this level reasonable, Hsu said.
He indicated that the CBC has proceeded with offsettings in the capital market which has resulted in a glut in Taiwan's capital market -- another reason why the CBC does not need to lower rates.

With regard to the Cabinet's request for the CBC and other related Cabinet-level units to offer their plans for the recovery of domestic economy, Hsu said the CBC has been adopting a loose monetary policy, including lowering bank deposit reserves, rediscount rates and secured loan rates on numerous occasions, as well as releasing NT$30 billion from the postal savings deposits into the capital market.

The CBC has even proceeded with open-market operations in conjunction with the aforementioned measures in a bid to create a loose capital climate which is conducive to the recovery of economic prosperity, Hsu said, adding that there are no more additional measures to stimulate a slumping economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY OFFER TAX CREDIT TO INVESTMENTS DEALING WITH Y2K

TEXT.P: The government is considering offering tax credit to businesses invested in solving the Y2K issue which is expected to cripple computer systems worldwide on Jan. 1, 2000, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.

In an opening speech at a seminar organized by a local business magazine, Siew said the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Finance are working out a program to relieve the burden in dealing with the problem, in addition to soft loans offered by several local banks to help industries update their computer systems.

Noting that the Y2K bug -- which stems from the computer's failure to differentiate the year 2000 from zero due to a two-digit dating system -- was one of the most urgent issues facing the world, Siew said the Executive Yuan has set up a panel to deal with the problem.

Noting that the magnitude of the issue cannot be overstated, Siew cited experts' estimates that the bug will seriously affect about 90 states worldwide, crash the computer systems of about half of the world's firms, and wipe out about 10 percent of them outright at the start of 2000.
Although Taiwan ranked third in the world in the manufacture of computer hardware and 10th in the manufacture of software, it lags far behind in 20th place in software development, noted the premier.

Warning industries not to make little of the problem, Siew said the complexity and difficulty of the Y2K bug were underlined by the unexpected glitches in software designed by Microsoft to tackle the problem, and the US$1 trillion set aside by the United States government to cope with it.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC POISED TO STEP UP REFORMS: SIEW

TEXT.P: One of the reasons why Taiwan has escaped the Asian financial crisis is due to its reforms, and the island is poised to continue with them, ROC Premier Vincent Siew said recently in an interview with US-based Business Week magazine.

In the magazine's latest issue released on Friday, Siew stressed that the Republic of China government has undergone a series of reforms and the ruling Kuomintang's victory in recent elections showed that the people of Taiwan has strong confidence in the KMT.
The party's success in winning over a majority in the 225-seat legislature will help the government boost political stability in Taiwan and forge stable relations with mainland China, Siew stated.

Asked whether the election results will help forge closer ties with the mainland, Siew said the ROC government has always been very pragmatic in its dealings with mainland China and the future of bilateral ties depends on whether Beijing will respond with the same attitude.

Turning to the impact of Taipei's pragmatic diplomacy on Washington-Beijing ties, the premier made it clear that Taiwan should enjoy a higher standing in the international community as the island is the world's 18th-largest economy, is the seventh-largest investment source, and has the third-largest foreign exchange reserves.

Stressing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are ruled by two separate governments and each is a political entity, Siew said he does not understand why the international society cannot accept this fact. Foreign nationals wishing to visit Taiwan must apply for visas through Taipei, not Beijing, and the currency used in Taiwan is New Taiwan dollars, not renminbi, he added.

The KMT's victory in the Dec. 5 elections has ensured its position as Taiwan's ruling party, and the island's outstanding performance amid the Asian financial turmoil is a major reason why voters showed such wide support for the KMT over the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, Business Week pointed out.

With only 15 months left until the next presidential election, KMT leaders including President Lee Teng-hui are fully aware that they cannot afford to make any mistakes in the run-up to the race, the magazine said, adding that Siew, one of Lee's top aides, is also doing his best to continue Taiwan's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EARNS ONE GOLD, TWO BRONZES IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei team on Friday won a gold and two bronze medals in the Asian Games in Bangkok.
In individual nine-ball competition, Taiwan billiard players Yang Ching-shun and Chao Fong-pang finished with the gold and bronze medals respectively.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's rugby team earned a bronze after defeating Sri Lanka, 38-20. Taiwan, which ranked third in the Asian Rugby Championships earlier this year, trailed Sri Lanka 18-9 at the end of the first half.
With only two days left before the end of the games, Taiwan has already brought in 19 golds, 16 silvers and 36 bronzes, which is the island's best performance in the Asian Games.

The Chinese Taipei delegation is slated to return on Dec. 21 aboard two separate flights to a gala reception in Taipei that night. Celebrations will include a parade featuring the athletes along the capital city's streets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
A third wave of US-British air attacks on Iraq on Friday inflicted substantial damage to the Muslim country.
The China Times:
Continued US-British air strikes have caused serious damage to Iraq.
The United Daily News:
The US House of Representatives began on Friday the first presidential impeachment debate in 130 years.
The Liberty Times:
US President Bill Clinton said on Friday that air strikes against Iraq will not be affected by the history-making House debate on whether to impeach him over his sexual relationship with a White House intern.
The Independence Morning Post:
The United States continued air raids on Iraqi military installations on Friday.
The Commons Daily:
Legislators from both ruling and opposition parties voiced support for a single-parliament system.
The China Post:
Third wave of Iraq attacks was seen on Friday while 'substantial damage' noted.
The China News:
Bombardment on Iraq enters second day.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ANTI-DUMPING DUTIES FOR TAIWAN LOWEST AMONG 8 COUNTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Anti-dumping duties imposed on stainless steel plate coils from Taiwan are the lowest among the eight countries accused of dumping such products into the US market, the US Commerce Department said on Friday.

Duties levied on steel coils from Taiwan are 2.94 percent while those for Japan are 35.61 percent, Mexico 23.27 percent, Germany 21.34 percent, Britain 13.45 percent, South Korea 12.35 percent, France 11.73 percent and Italy 6.25 percent.

Of the Taiwan companies targeted in the US anti-dumping measures, Yeh-lien Co. and Tachen International Stainless Steel Co. must pay 2.94 percent duty, Dong-mong Developing Co. 0.07 percent, and Chang-ming Ltd. Co. 0.57 percent, according to the US Commerce Department.

The department also announced that all of the German companies and three of the Japanese firms were seen as committing the "worst mistakes," and will therefore be required to pay duties retroactively from Sept. 18.
Stainless steel plate coils are widely used in a variety of products such as automobile exhaust pipes, ovens, dish-washers, thresholds and elevators.

The US International Trade Commission made a preliminary determination on July 25 that imported stainless steel plate coils were dumped into the US market at unfair market prices which harmed the US stainless steel industry. A final determination is scheduled to be made on April 16, 1999, the commission said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE BUSINESS EXPECTED TO EXCEED EXPECTATIONS

TEXT.P: A consultant company has predicted that the amount of online business trade will expand from US$43 billion this year, to US$1.3 trillion in five years.
A report by US-based Forrester Research Inc. said online trade will find its way into a wide variety of industries once companies recognize the efficiencies that can be created by the Internet.

Last year, the research firm had predicted US$327 billion in online business trade by 2002. But it significantly revised that amount upward because the pace of growth has accelerated in the last 18 months.

Forrester said leading online industries by 2003 will include aerospace, defense, petrochemicals, utilities and automobiles. More than 9 percent of all business sales are expected to be conducted online by that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 19, or the first day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He was overthrown by the Uganda army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: US Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent and the Democratic Progressive Party 31.03 percent of the popular vote in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments in the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae Jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAYS IT MUST JOINT WTO BEFORE 2000

TEXT.P: Mainland China, the world's tenth largest trading power, must joint the World Trade Organization (WTO) before 2000, a mainland trade representative told the world trade body on Friday.
"It is of the utmost importance that (mainland) China becomes a WTO member before the year 2000," Li Zhongzhou, deputy permanent representative of the mainland Chinese mission, was quoted as saying.
If the mainland becomes a member by the start of the WTO's next session, it would help the trade body reach its goal of "achieving universal membership," Li said.
For almost 12 years, the mainland has tried and failed to meet entry requirements for the Geneva-based WTO, which call for broad liberalization in the trading of goods and services.

WTO members are duty-bound to start liberalization negotiations in numerous sectors including agriculture and services by 2000 under agreements made at the end of the seven-year Uruguay Round in 1994.

Beijing's efforts to secure a seat on the trade body have been noticeably absent recently as the financial crisis in Asia has turned the focus of attention on domestic concerns, including meeting an 8 percent growth target for 1998. Mainland trade negotiators have not met in Geneva since July.
Twenty-nine other countries apart from mainland China are pushing for WTO membership, including Russia and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA CALLS FOR CLOSER PHILIPPINE-VIETNAM TIES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada called for closer and stronger ties between the Philippine and Vietnamese legislatures during a visit to Vietnam's National Assembly in Hanoi on Thursday.
Estrada, accompanied by members of the Philippine Congress as well as trade and foreign ministry officials, met with Vietnam's National Assembly leaders.
The meeting involved discussions on improving relations between the two legislatures, according to Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican, a member of Estrada's entourage.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA URGES IRAQ TO COMPLY WITH UN RESOLUTIONS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada reiterated on Friday his hope for a quick resolution to the crisis in Iraq following air strikes on Baghdad by the United States and the United Kingdom.

Although the Philippine government supports the United Nations resolution allowing a UN special inspection team to examine Iraqi armament sites for weapons of mass destruction, Estrada said he does not want innocent people killed or injured in the process.

"I would say it is really unfortunate that it happened. I hope they can immediately settle the dispute so the innocent blood of people will not be sacrificed," he said in an interview with reporters aboard a plane which took them from Vietnam to Thailand. He added, "I believe that we should support the resolution of the UN, and Iraq should comply with that."

Estrada has just completed a two-day stay in Vietnam, during which he attended a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Hanoi. He will be in Thailand for three days on a state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORERS THREATENING PUBLIC SECURITY

TEXT.P: The increasing number of foreign laborers and illegal immigrants poses a serious threat to public security in Taipei County, police authorities said on Saturday.

According to Taipei County police, there are currently about 45,000 foreign nationals living in the county, 38,000 of whom are legal foreign laborers. However, there are 1,657 reported cases of foreign workers who have illegally left their places of employment and have fallen into a black hole, they added.

Since the beginning of this year, Taipei County authorities have arrested 2,029 illegal foreign laborers, as well as 71 foreign nationals involved in 42 criminal cases. Of the 71 foreigners, 49 were Thai workers suspected of involvement in 25 criminal cases.

Over the past 18 months, 42 foreign women were arrested on prostitution charges in Taipei County. Thirty of them entered Taiwan under the guise of marrying ROC nationals, the county police said, urging relevant authorities to take more effective action since the number of such cases represents a big jump from the same period last year.
Of the 30 "false foreign brides," 26 were from Thailand and four were from Malaysia, police said.

Hsintien precinct officials said the government should pay more attention to rampant smuggling and health problems which may occur from the rise of illegal immigrants in Taiwan. One Thai prostitute was found to have entered Taiwan with a forged passport after having been deported, while another Thai woman entered the island as a stowaway, they said.

In a bid to further crack down on foreign prostitutes, the Taipei County police said they will increase their inspection of hotels, Thai restaurants and pubs under their administration, and prosecute operators found harboring prostitutes.
County police also called for greater cooperation from the public, adding that any valuable information they receive from the public will be rewarded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPAN ECONOMIC AND TRADE CONFERENCE TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: The 23rd economic and trade conference between Taiwan and Japan is scheduled to open in Taipei on Monday.

The three-day meeting, jointly sponsored by Taiwan's East Asian Relations Association (EARA) and Japan's Interchange Association, will focus discussions on improving Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan.

Other topics on the agenda include export restrictions, international convention, competition policies, intellectual property rights, the promotion of trade and investment, certification, technology cooperation, agricultural trade, as well as forestry and fishery products.
Conference members also hope to establish communications between high-ranking officials on both sides to promote policy coordination and cooperation.

Leading the Taiwan delegation will be EARA head Lin Chin-ching. Other conference members will include EARA Standing Supervisor Koo Chen-fu, ROC representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao, Council for Economic Planning and Development Economic Research Department Director Thomas Yeh, Council of Labor Affairs representative Yang Sun-der, Council of Agriculture representative Wang Ming-dong, MOFA Asian & Pacific Department representative Nien Hsin-Shih, MOEA representatives Yu Zui-deh and Hsu Chun-fang.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO FURTHER DEMOCRATIC REFORMS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui reaffirmed his commitment to furthering Taiwan's democratic reforms under the principle of the "new Taiwanese" during an interview with a Japanese daily on Friday.

Lee said in the two-hour interview with the mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun that the outcome of the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections indicated that Taiwan's democratization and multi-party political system have gradually matured.

"In the future, all of our people, regardless of their origins, will continue to stand united and pursue further political reforms and national development under the principle of 'new Taiwanese,'" the outspoken, strong-willed president said.

Stressing that the people of Taiwan will create their own future, a confident Lee said the Republic of China government has moved in right direction toward democratization and "Taiwanization" over the past 10 years.
"We will continue these policies and promote further reforms in various fields in a pragmatic, gradual manner," Lee stressed.

Lee coined the phrase "new Taiwanese" during the campaign period for the just-concluded elections for the national legislature and the mayorships and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung in an effort to foster a common identity for various parochial groups on the island.

The Yomiuri Shimbun said the principle of new Taiwanese embodies Lee's basic political ideas and concepts. Under his leadership, the paper said, Taiwan has forsaken its unrealistic sovereignty claim over the Chinese mainland and has managed to accomplish Taiwan-centered democratic reforms over the past decade.
The Japanese daily pointed out that all these developments will certainly influence Taiwan people's views and opinions about the island's relations with mainland China.

Lee made it clear in his interview with the paper's editor-in-chief Shouichi Oikawa that a declaration of Taiwan independence will not make any sense since the Republic of China on Taiwan has long been a sovereign state.

On the other hand, Lee also stressed that he is in no hurry to consider the issue related to the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "Only when the time is ripe should the issue be tackled," he asserted.
Nevertheless, Lee emphasized the need to conduct regular dialogue with Beijing to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Lee said even though there is only one China, the Beijing government should recognize that Taiwan and the Chinese mainland have been separately ruled by two equal political entities since 1949.

While explicitly ruling out any radical, extremist policies and strategies, Lee said Taiwan will continue promoting cross-strait dialogue and exchanges through the two semi-official intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Lee went on to say that the two sides of the strait will be unified only under the principles of freedom and democracy. "And before that goal is realized, Taiwan and mainland China must be treated on an equal footing," he stressed.
Touching on the possibility of a cross-strait summit meeting, Lee said he hopes to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin whenever the opportunity presents itself.

"I will not mind meeting Jiang at any place," Lee said, adding that the most feasible setting for the proposed cross-strait summit will be the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.

Lee further stated he will not seek re-election after his current term expires in May 2000, saying "I'll do my best to complete Taiwan's full democratization during the rest of my four years in office."

After completing his presidential term, Lee will have two years left to serve as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang. He said he will continue to dedicate himself to national service in his capacity as KMT chairman after ending his presidential stint.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar on Saturday rose NT$0.009 against the greenback in Taipei to close at 32.265. It opened at 32.276 and traded between 32.263 and 32.278 amid thin trading.
The value of interbank US dollar trading reached a total of US$33.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING TAIWAN GOVERNOR BIDS FAREWELL

TEXT.P: Expressing his deep gratitude for the public's support, outgoing Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong bid farewell to all Taiwan Province residents on Saturday, his last day in office.

Wearing the same red tie which he wore when he was sworn into office as the first popularly elected Taiwan provincial governor four years ago, Soong thanked President Lee Teng-hui and the ruling Kuomintang for nominating and supporting him, and the public of the Republic of China for voting for him.

Soong, who loses his job due to the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government, stressed that the feelings he has for all the people of the Taiwan Province will never fade away. Voicing the hope that the public has been satisfied with his past service, Soong wished the public good luck and health and made his final farewell.

Soong's emotional speech in Mandarin, Taiwanese and Hakka was interrupted several times by enthusiastic applause from the audience which packed the stadium in Chunghsing Village, headquarters of the Taiwan Provincial Government in central Nantou County.
Recounting that when he was first elected governor, Soong said he vowed to do his best to learn to speak Taiwanese fluently and he has accomplished what he had promised.
He also said although he was not born in Taiwan, he felt "completely Taiwanese."
Explaining why he was wearing the same red tie from four years ago, the governor said he wanted to show that Taiwan is a place where there is justice, love and tolerance.

The new Taiwanese will respect and love each other and have a high degree of self-esteem, he claimed, concluding that "we may have a different past, but it is certain that we will share a common future."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES TUMBLE

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices fell sharply on Saturday due to concern over investors' failure to honor settlements on stock trading deals involving a local textile company, dealers said.
The defaulted settlements on Ta Jiang Textile Company stock further shook confidence in the Taiwan stock market which has been weak due to the recent financial troubles of local companies and banks.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key indicator, plunged 158.55 points to close at the day's low of 6,478.11.
A total of 1.70 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$3.80 billion (US$117.3 million) in the Saturday session.
All eight major stock categories suffered losses, with textile issues registering the largest fall of 4.4 percent.

Plastic and chemical issues dropped 4.3 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks which declined 2.9 percent; cement shares, 2.8 percent; construction shares, 2.8 percent; paper and pulp shares, 2.7 percent; financial stocks, 2.3; and electronic engineering shares, 1.5 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a 4.55-point decline and closed at 164.17, with the turnover reaching NT$3.80 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also plunged.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January sank 157 points, closing at 6,612, with 4,491 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 6,769 points for January, 6,770 points for February, 6,768 points for March, 6,681 for June, and 6,732 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS WITH US SENATOR

TEXT.P: ROC Premier Vincent Siew met with visiting US Senator Tim Johnson on Saturday for wide-ranging talks.

Siew thanked the senator for US support of the Republic of China, and urged the United States to back Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) as all bilateral negotiations with member states have been completed.

Johnson, who was accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, said he will continue to support Taiwan's bid to enter the WTO as well as other international economic organizations because it would be mutually beneficial.
On the issue of how Taiwan has managed to survive the Asian financial crisis, Siew mentioned four reasons.

First, he said the island's economy is supported primarily by small- and medium-sized enterprises which can easily adapt to market fluctuations. Second, Taiwan's banks and financial institutions are healthy. Third, the government's policy is transparent. Fourth, Taiwan has been able to sustain a trade surplus and abundant foreign exchange reserves.
Despite the island's relative economic success, the government is cautious and prepared to respond to any unexpected situation, Siew added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE OPPOSE EXTENDING TENURE OF INCUMBENT PRESIDENT: POLL

TEXT.P: Over half those polled oppose a proposal to extend the tenures of the incumbent president and National Assembly (NA) deputies so elections for the posts would coincide with those for legislators, an opposition NA deputy said on Saturday.
Liu Ming-lung, a member of the right-wing New Party, said he commissioned the Public Opinion Poll Foundation earlier this month to look into public opinion about the tenure extension proposal.

Results from a telephone poll of 1,062 adults residing across the island found that 57.3 percent of the respondents opposed extending the tenures of the incumbent president, vice president and NA deputies to match that of newly elected legislators.
Only 22.6 percent of those interviewed threw their support behind the proposal, according to the poll results.

Meanwhile, 42.1 percent gave a thumbs-down to the suggestion that the tenure of newly elected legislators be shortened by a year and seven months to match that of the incumbent president, vice president and NA deputies. In contrast, 37.7 percent voiced support for the proposal.
Liu said the extension of tenure usually symbolizes the expansion of power. "If the proposal is really adopted, it would mark a setback to Taiwan's much-touted democratic reforms," he noted.
The NA deputy from the minor opposition New Party went on to demand that President Lee Teng-hui clearly express his opposition to the extension proposal.
Liu also urged the public to stop discussing or speculating on this "unjustifiable" topic immediately.
The same survey further found that 48.4 percent of the respondents supported the proposal to abolish the National Assembly, compared to 27.9 percent who opposed the idea.
"The figures indicate that the National Assembly has failed to fulfill its functions or to live up to public expectations," Liu commented.

The dispute over the presidential term and parliamentary system arose recently after reports suggested that the ruling Kuomintang was considering amending the country's Constitution to make the tenures of the president, NA deputies and legislators coincide by changing the term of legislators from three years to four starting with the next legislative election.

In what would be a transitional step, the KMT reportedly planned to extend the four-year tenures of the incumbent president, vice president and NT deputies by 19 months until December 2001 so elections for the posts would be held at the same time as those for legislators, who were elected on Dec. 5.
Also as part of the constitutional reform package, the KMT reportedly is thinking about "improving" the existing parliamentary system to make it resemble a bicameral legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDENCE IN SINGAPORE HIGH: POLL

TEXT.P: Singaporeans polled recently are more confident about the economy now than when the economic crisis first broke out in mid-1997, The Straits Times reported.
Eight in 10 respondents said they were more confident, while nine in 10 said Singapore will recover more quickly than other Asian countries.

Despite the rising number of layoffs, eight in 10 said they were "quite confident" or "very confident" that they would keep their jobs. A total of 15 percent said they were not worried about losing their jobs while 4 percent said they were "not at all confident" that they would still have a job by March.

While the majority of the 451 people polled were confident about Singapore's long-term prospects, many were bearish about the next three months. Six in 10 said they expected the job market to worsen in the next three months and one in three said the economy would be in worse shape than it is now.
About half of those polled expect the economic situation to remain unchanged and do not think their own financial position will be affected.

These generally cautious sentiments were also reflected in respondents' answers on how they planned to spend their money. The vast majority were in no mood to part with their money, saying that they did not plan to buy property, cars, brand goods or go overseas on holidays in the next three months.

The survey was conducted by the Singapore Press Holdings Research and Information Department earlier this month and involved telephone interviews with Singaporeans and permanent residents aged 21 and older.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOK ON SOONG SOON TO HIT BOOKSTORES

TEXT.P: A book featuring the political rise of James Soong and the possibilities for his future will soon hit local bookstores as the outgoing Taiwan provincial governor ends his four-year tenure on Saturday.
The book was written by senior journalist Hsia Chen and will be published by the China Times Publishing Corp.

The book describes how Soong went from an appointed governor by the central government to the first popularly elected governor after easily defeating Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Ting-nan.

Hsia goes into vivid details of Soong's personality traits and describes his path to political limbo. Also mentioned is Soong's estranged relationship with President Lee Teng-hui as a result of constitutional amendments over the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
The book also analyzes Soong's possible future plans, including a possible run as Vice President Lien Chan's vice presidential candidate in the 2000 election.
Citing comments Soong made in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation, Hsia writes about Soong's faith in pursuing the democratic process and fulfilling his political ideals.
Subsequent disputes which arose from his performance in office and problems sparked by the central government's decision to streamline the provincial government are also detailed in the book.
Describing Soong as a 100 percent man of power and an undying rising star, Hsia also describes the Taiwan provincial governor as a expert in crisis management who knows how to stand against the odds.
"Having such a friend is a heavy burden, let alone having such a rival -- it is awful," Hsia jokes in his book.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RULES OUT SEEKING RE-ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui explicitly ruled out the possibility of seeking re-election after the expiration of his current term during an interview with a Japanese daily on Friday.
Lee said in his two-hour interview with the Yomiuri Shimbun that he will not seek re-election after his tenure expires in May 2001.

The top Republic of China leader also stressed that his successor must be a person who "extremely loves Taiwan and is willing to wholeheartedly work for Taiwan and commit himself to pushing for Taiwan's complete democratization."

"I hope my successor will also be a far-sighted, broad-minded, visionary and composed person who can deal with contingencies calmly and wisely," Lee said, adding that the next ROC president must not only be able to consolidate Taiwan but also be able to enhance Taiwan's clout with mainland China.
The outspoken ROC president went on to say he will do his best to further Taiwan's democratization during the rest of his four-year tenure.
Lee, who concurrently heads the ROC's ruling Kuomintang, said he has two years left to serve as KMT chairman after he ends his presidential stint.

"I believe the KMT will be able to keep its grip on power after the 2000 presidential election. If so, I'll continue to promote Taiwan's reforms in various fields in my capacity as KMT chairman," he added.

The largest Japanese daily published Lee's interview on the front page of its Saturday issue. The article, titled "Expect the Substantiation of the Principle of New Taiwanese," was complemented with a photo of Lee.
Lee gave the interview with the paper's editor-in-chief, Shouichi Oikawa, at the Presidential Office in Taipei on Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By M. C. Tzou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's most prominent political dissident in exile, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Monday for a 10-day visit, a source here said on Friday.

A spokesman for the Paris branch of the Mainland Chinese Overseas Democratic Alliance confirmed speculation that Wei will visit Taiwan next week at the invitation of C. Y. Rau, president of the World League for Freedom and Democracy's ROC chapter.
While in Taiwan, Wei will receive an honorary doctorate from the National Taiwan University and meet with political leaders to exchange opinions on the island's democratic achievements.
Also, arrangements are said to be underway for Wei to meet with President Lee Teng-hui.
Wei, who now lives in the United States after being released by Beijing in 1997, is currently visiting France at the invitation of the European Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND, OUTBOUND ROC FOREIGN INVESTMENTS DOWN IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The amount of foreign investments in Taiwan and Taiwan investments abroad registered declines in November, according to official statistics released on Saturday.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs listed investments from abroad in November at 66 cases, up four cases from the same month last year, with a value of US$160 million, down 22.37 percent.
This represents a 36.99 percent increase in the cases of foreign investment and a decline of 18.13 percent in total value for the January-November period.
At the same time, Taiwan's investments abroad in November totaled US$85.48 million, down 69.66 percent from the same period last year.
The accumulated value of investments abroad for the first 11 months was up 15.5 percent, with the number of investment cases rising 22.2 percent.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's indirect investment in mainland China in November reached US$48.25 million, down 49.48 percent, with the number of investment cases declining 64.42 percent to 37 cases.
The number of investments made in the mainland for the January-November period was down 6.6 percent, with the total value dropping by 3.65 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S SHORTEST WOMAN VISITS TAIWAN AGAIN FOR X'MAS CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Madge Bester, the shortest woman in the Guinness World of Records, is visiting Taiwan again to attend Christmas celebrations in the central Taiwan city of Taichung.
Bester, who is 65 centimeters tall, signed a "super" Christmas card at the Guinness World of Records Museum in Taichung on Saturday to wish all Taiwan people a merry Christmas.
Ten children from a Taichung kindergarten assisted Bester in displaying the super-large Christmas card, which stands 183 centimeters long and 109 centimeters wide.

Bester, a South African national, said she wants to express her gratitude for the friendship extended to her by local people during her last Taiwan visit by sending the specially designed Christmas card.

During her first visit to the island from September 1997 to March 1998, Bester lived in a small house built especially for her by the Guinness World of Record Museum in Taichung. During her six-month stay, she met with some senior ROC officials and visited many working places of handicapped people in Taiwan.
While in South Africa, Bester didn't need government support because she worked in a factory to support herself.
Bester will attend many festive activities to celebrate Christmas and the New Year sponsored by the Taichung Guinness Museum during her current visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR ADDRESSES ASIA-PACIFIC SECURITY FORUM IN MANILA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top banker said here on Saturday that Taiwan has been relatively immune to contagion from the Asian financial crisis mainly because of its robust economic fundamentals.
Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, made the statement in a keynote speech delivered at the 1998 roundtable of the Asia-Pacific Security Forum being held in Manila.
The forum is co-sponsored by four international organizations, including the French Institute for International Affairs and the Institute for Strategic and Development Studies.

Perng said although Taiwan, like many other Asian countries, has also experienced currency depreciation, rising interest rates and falling stock prices in the past two years, these problems have not crippled the Taiwan economy to the same extent.

"Despite the turmoil, the Taiwan economy last year still grew by 6.8 percent with consumer prices rising by only 0.9 percent. While the impact of the crisis will become more evident this year, an economic growth rate of 5.1 percent with an inflation rate of 1.6 percent is still projected," Perng noted.

As the manufacturing sector in Taiwan is mainly made up of small- and medium-sized firms, its resilience and ability to adapt have made it capable of responding to external shocks quickly, Perng said, adding that efforts by both the government and the private sector in research and development since the early 1990s have also helped set up Taiwan as the technology island.

"This competitive edge, along with low inflation, has helped sustain high economic growth and a current account surplus since 1981," Perng said, adding that the huge foreign exchange reserves built up over the years have enabled Taiwan to weather the currency crisis.

In his speech titled "the security implications of the East Asian financial crisis," Perng said the ROC, as a member of the international community, fully understands its obligation to offer assistance to afflicted countries.

"Beginning from this year, we have deposited a total of US$1 billion in the branches of our commercial banks in Southeast Asia to aid the business community there. The total credit extended by these banks adds up to US$2.4 billion. Our commercial banks have also contributed to the co-financing programs of the Asian Development Bank and the syndicated loans arranged by leading international banks," Perng said, adding that by the end of 1998, Taiwan's direct investment in Asia had already reached US$58 billion.

In addition, Perng said, Taiwan has initiated a proposal on a collateralized bond obligation (CBO) scheme at the 1998 meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in Kuala Lumpur in November.
"As asset-backed securities, CBOs can effectively diversify risks and inject the foreign funds needed to reconstruct economies in Southeast Asia," Perng noted.
He further said major Asia-Pacific countries should implement a variety of policies to enhance the international cooperation mechanism to resolve their financial woes and promote economic well-being.

"These include strengthening the information exchange system in the international economy, establishing a regional early-warning system and firewalls, and proposing programs for the international division of labor and cooperation. These are future directions for policy that deserve our attention," Perng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW RECEIVES OFFICIALS FROM MALAWI, SWAZILAND

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday that the government of the Republic of China is grateful to Malawi and Swaziland for their strong support in the United Nations.
Siew made the remarks after receiving David Rubadiri and Moses Dlamini, respective permanent representative of Malawi and Swaziland to the UN.
The ROC will eventually be readmitted to the world body with the help of such friendly countries, Siew added.
During the visit, Rubadiri said Malawi is thankful for Taiwan's assistance, and expressed the hope that Taiwan enterprises will make investments in his country.

Dlamini said the ROC is one of the founding members of the UN, and it is eligible to join the world body and other international organizations. Swaziland will continue to do all it can to help the Republic of China join these organizations, he added.
Siew also said Africa is a market with great potential for development and his government will encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in Africa.
