DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 20, or the second day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Kim Young Sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by US Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of cerebral apoplexy at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The nation chooses 26 new members to the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Artur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 US troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae Jung pardons Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
Confucius: "Now if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment, even if you would."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GAINS 19 GOLD MEDALS IN ASIAN GAMES, FINISHES SIXTH OVERALL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 19 (CNA) (By Wei Shu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: In its best performance since first taking part in the Asian Games in 1954, Chinese Taipei won a total of 19 gold, 17 silver and 41 bronze medals in the 13th Asian Games, held in Bangkok from Dec. 6 to 20.
Mainland China came away the big winner, earning 129 gold medals, more than one-third of the 377 gold medals awarded during the two-week regional games, according to the sponsor of the games.
South Korea came in second with 65 gold medals, followed by Japan with 52.
South Korea also grabbed the last gold of the competition in the men's marathon competition on Sunday morning. Japan, meanwhile, won the silver in the event and North Korea the bronze.
The Chinese Taipei team finished sixth in the rankings, following Thailand and Kazakhstan, both of which finished with 24 gold medals.

Some 6,000 athletes from 41 countries took part in 36 sports in the games, which included such Asian specialties as kabaddi and sepak takraw. The closing ceremony for the games will be held Sunday night.
The 143-strong Chinese Taipei team is scheduled to return home Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN ORDERS EXPECTED TO DECLINE IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The total value of Taiwan's export orders in November is expected to shrink some US$300 million from the amount in October, officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Sunday.
MOEA statistics show that Taiwan received US$10.38 billion worth of foreign orders in October, down 5.8 percent from the same month of last year.
October's figure, however, was US$5 million higher than in September.
The economic officials, citing MOEA surveys that indicated fewer orders from foreign buyers would be placed with Taiwan in November, predicted the island would see lighter exports that month.

DOC.HEADLINE: 83 PERCENT OF TAIWAN RESIDENTS SATISFIED WITH SOONG: POLL

TEXT.P: Eighty-three percent of the people of Taiwan polled in a recent survey said they are satisfied with Taiwan Governor James Soong's administrative performance over the past four years.

Though Soong, who is Taiwan's first and the only elected provincial governor, stepped down Sunday, he is one of the few top administrators who has consistently received a high approval rating from the public.
The most recent poll was conducted by the United Daily News from Dec. 15 to 16.
If Soong chooses to remain in politics, a run for president in Taiwan's 2000 presidential elections is what the public most expects from him.

As for rumors that he will be appointed senior adviser to the president after "retiring" as governor, 43 percent of those polled said they would be dissatisfied with the arrangement, while 31 percent said they would be satisfied and 25 percent said they had no opinion.

In the poll 87 percent of respondents said they felt there existed a closeness between Soong and the ordinary people of Taiwan. Meanwhile, 82 percent said Soong's leadership while governor was his most praiseworthy quality, while 73 percent said he should be lauded for his administrative performance.
Less than 10 percent of respondents said Soong is unkind or his leadership insufficient, and an equally small number had an unfavorable view of his administrative performance.
Seventy-nine percent of respondents said they hope Soong will remain in politics, while 5 percent said he should retire.

If Soong were to remain in politics, 39 percent said they hope Soong will run for president, 20 percent said they hope Soong will be appointed premier and 12 percent said he should run as Lien Chan's vice-presidential candidate in the 2000 presidential election. Meanwhile, 25 percent said they did not have an opinion on the matter.

The United Daily poll of 1,440 people around the island was carried out on the evenings of Dec. 15 and 16. A total of 1,182 people participated in the poll, which had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

Soong was sworn in on Dec. 20, 1994 after an overwhelming victory in Taiwan's first popular gubernatorial election. One year and nine months prior to that, he was appointed head of the provincial government by the premier.

During the time he served as a governor by appointment, his approval rating was around 65 percent, according to polls conducted at the time. During the first two years of his term as an elected governor, his approval rating rose to 78 percent.
His approval rating shot up to 90 percent in early 1997 after he submitted his resignation in the wake of the ruling Kuomintang's announcement of plans to downsize the Taiwan provincial government.
Soong later agreed to serve out the remainder of his term, and his approval rating remained at around 83 percent, with only 5 percent of those polled expressing dissatisfaction with him.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 WELL-WISHERS TOUR TAIWAN SAILBOAT BOUND FOR WORLDWIDE JOURNEY

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 people in southern Taiwan over the weekend toured a Taiwan sailboat that will embark on an around-the-world voyage starting Thursday.
Visitors signed their names on the mainsail and the jib of the "New Era" as they wished the boat success on its journey.

The 16-foot long, two-sail "New Era" is a white sloop. Sailing aboard the ship will be four crew members, including former painter Liu Ning-sheng, who will be the boat's skipper, and a German sailing friend of his.

The "New Era" is scheduled to sail Thursday from Kaohsiung and will visit 20 major ports around the world during its 21,250-nautical mile journey, which is to last 82 weeks. It is scheduled to return to Kaohsiung in November 2000.

A marine corps brass band will perform Thursday as the boat pulls out of the harbor, and well-wishers will hang strings of tiny paper cranes from the boat in a gesture indicating wishes for a safe and pleasant journey.
Liu said he and his friends have prepared for three years for the cross-century trip, which is expected to further attest to the bravery of those Chinese living in Taiwan. (Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANKS TO BEGIN LISTING ECUS ON JAN. 1, 1999

TEXT.P: The euro, the single European currency, will be listed on local banks' foreign exchange tables beginning Jan. 1, 1999 under the name European Currency Unit (ECU), sources from the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Sunday.

Beginning on Jan. 1, a total of 879 banks around the island, including 807 local and 72 foreign-invested banks, will have ECUs listed on their daily foreign exchange lists for free trade, officials from the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department said.

To cope with the introduction of the euro on Jan. 1, the CBC set up an ECU task force in May to provide Taiwan banks authorized to conduct foreign exchange deals with all necessary information regarding the new single European currency.
The 20 percent of government-held foreign exchange reserves that are held in Deutsche marks -- about US$18 billion worth -- will automatically be converted into ECUs on Jan. 1, CBC officials noted.

Noting that the Deutsche mark is the strongest and the lira the weakest currency in Europe, CBC officials said the circulation of the euro is expected to cut red tape and the cost of trading with European states as fewer currency exchanges will be required.

The birth of the euro is also poised to consolidate the strength of the European Union, which has a population of 295 million people and an economy worth US$6.57 trillion -- making it nearly equal in terms of market size to the United States. Taiwan investors should diversify their businesses by aggressively exploring the European market, CBC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIG MAINLAND DRUG SMUGGLER SEIZED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A suspected drug ring was apprehended on Saturday in Taoyuan and its alleged mastermind, Yang Chien-wu, was arrested, Taoyuan police said.

Acting on a tip, Taoyuan police arrested Yang, who has allegedly smuggled drugs into Taiwan from mainland China several times using phony travel documents. Sources indicated that another drug smuggler was preparing to smuggle 300 kilograms of amphetamines into Taiwan or into other neighboring countries.

According to police, Yang, who has a previous criminal record for drug dealing and assault, started to mass produce amphetamines with his conspirators in the mainland's Guangdong province three years ago. He also bought heroin in the mainland and shipped it to Taiwan, and his customers can be found in many Asian countries.

Yang became wanted two years ago when the Investigation Bureau captured some 40 kilograms of smuggled amphetamines from Yang's factory. But the bureau was unable to capture him, because Yang was traveling under phony travel documents, different from the ones he had used previously.

The police suspect there exists another crime ring, which provided Yang with a stolen car and a phony driver's license and ID card. That ring is suspected of backing Yang up while he smuggled drugs into Taiwan.

Several drug dealers were arrested in Taoyuan and Taipei County, and police believe Yang is the source of all the dealers' drugs. The police arrested him in Taipei last week, at which time he was still struggling to escape under a phony ID card and driver's license.
Yang admitted that he mass produced amphetamines in the mainland and that he took charge of transporting the drug. Yang's conspirator is still wanted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGAR'S INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIA STARTS GENERATING PROFIT

TEXT.P: A cow-breeding plan by Taiwan Sugar Co. and an Australian company is beginning to generate profits, and Taiwan Sugar plans to introduce its frozen beef product to Taiwan markets in the beginning of next year, Taiwan Sugar officials said.

Those raising livestock in Taiwan face various challenges, such as environmental regulations, increasing breeding costs and pressures for the market to be further opened amid Taiwan's drive to join the World Trade Organization. To survive the challenges, Taiwan Sugar moved its breeding operations abroad, opting to cooperate with Australia to breed 30,000 cows per year.
Marketing channels and promotional plans for the beef products have been fully developed.

Taiwan consumers have a preference for fresh, rather than processed, meat. Taiwan Sugar therefore plans to market mainly freshly packaged meat, while a certain proportion will be processed, according to market demands.

Taiwan Sugar also plans to engage in a cooperative pig-breeding and processing project with Australia. Already a working group has been dispatched to Australia to study the operational and administrative aspects of the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR TO SETTLE STAFFING ISSUE

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shou-po vowed on Sunday to attend to the disposition of the staff of the provincial government.
The new governor made the remark after he attended a seminar on caring for young people, sponsored by the Youth Development Foundation.

Chao will take office on Dec. 21. He indicated that his first job is to make inquiries with the heads of departments and bureaus in the old provincial government regarding their willingness to remain at their posts.
Anyone who wishes to stay is most welcome, Chao said.

Regarding the future employment of the former provincial government staff, he reiterated the central government's pledges to take good care of them. He said that the Fair Trade Commission of the Executive Yuan will set up a branch in central Taiwan, while the Council of Aborginal Affairs, whose clients mostly live in central Taiwan, also has the need to set up a branch here.

The Bureau of Water Resources under the Ministry of Economic Affairs can make good use of water experts from the old Water Conservancy Department of the provincial government and establish a branch there as well, Chao suggested.
With the establishment of these three branch institutions, there will be many vacancies that could be filled by former provincial government staff, Chao added.
Chao has long been viewed as Vice President Lien Chan's confidant, and his appointment is seen as a means of paving the way for a presidential run by Lien.
Chao, however, said that as a member of the ruling Kuomintang, he will campaign for anyone the party orders him to.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURIST INDUSTRY DISCUSSES WAYS TO REVITALIZE MARKET

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China Sightseeing Management Society convened a general meeting on Sunday to discuss ways of revitalizing the tourist industry, which has been hard hit by the region's financial chaos.
Lee Ming-hui, president of the society, told the meeting that following the Asian financial crisis, consumers have cut back on spending, which has affected the tourist industry.
He quoted reports from the Tourism Bureau as saying that the number of outbound Taiwan tourists will register negative growth this year.
Some delegates to the meeting voiced pessimism about future prospects, as many travel agencies have gone bankrupt this year.

But Tourist Bureau Deputy Director Su Cheng-tien told the convention that although the number of inbound foreign tourists and outbound Taiwan tourists has dropped this year, the domestic tourist market is returning to normal.
Saying that some overseas destinations for Taiwan tourists have registered growth, Su encouraged the industry not to be pessimistic.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE GLASS EXHIBITION TAKES PLACE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Liuligongfang glassworks studio, a pioneer of Taiwan's modern glass industry, is holding its 1998 exhibition in Taipei.
The Taipei exhibition represents the last leg of a tour that included exhibitions in London in April, Shanghai in May and Beijing in August.
More than a hundred glass works created with the "pate-de-verre" technique are on display, including a number of sculptures depicting the Buddha by Loretta Yang, a Liuligongfang founder.

Around 20 large glass sculptures, some several meters tall, are being displayed from Dec. 18 to 27. The exhibition showcases the workshop's efforts to challenge existing glass casting and carving techniques.
The exhibition, titled "Solely Propping up the Flag of Chinese Glass," also marked the Liuligongfang's ambition to put Chinese glass on the world's cultural and artistic map.

Yang has called the exhibition another milestone in her struggle to find new territory in which to express herself after deciding to quit the movie industry at the peak of her career. The former movie star received Taiwan's Golden Horse Festival award for best actress two years in a row and has been named best actress at the Asia-Pacific Film Festival.

Yang, along with her film director husband Chang Yi and several other friends, in 1987 established the Liuligongfang (formerly named the Newworkshop) -- Taiwan's first professional glass arts studio -- not knowing that they would one day revolutionize the glass industry on the island.
Nearly NT$75 million (US$2.32 million) has been pumped into the studio's glass sculpture research and development efforts, according to Liuligongfang members.

Yang's glass works, often featuring her favorite images of Buddhas and Buddhisattvas, have been displayed in Asia, America and Europe. Her London exhibition, which took place at the Victory and Albert Museum, was the museum's first display by a Chinese artist since 1857.
In addition, seven of Yang's sculptures were added to the collection of Beijing's Palace Museum in honor of her contribution to the promotion of the beauty and spirit of Chinese culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'BEIJING SPRING' NIPPED IN THE BUD: GLOBE AND MAIL

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin made a hard-line announcement Friday that puts the final chill on the recent flowering of democratic rights that was dubbed the "Beijing spring," a major Canadian newspaper reported Saturday.

The Globe and Mail was referring to Jiang's speech in which he vowed that ,mainland China will not copy Western-style democracy and stressed that the Communist Party must remain the guiding force in mainland China.

After pro-democracy dissidents were rounded up and put in jail in recent weeks, Jiang told mainland China's 1.24 billion citizens that they need to fight against foreign influences seeking to erode the Communist way of life, the Mail said in a story with a Beijing dateline.

"The system must not be shaken, weakened or discarded at any time," he was quoted as saying. His 75-minute, nationally televised speech signals that mainland China's government wants to keep a tight lid on dissent for next year, which will mark the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre as well as the 50th anniversary of the Communist revolution, the report said.
"The government wants to avoid domestic protests on the anniversary of the Tiananmen massacre, in which soldiers killed hundreds or thousands of pro-democracy students," the daily added.
The speech was meant to commemorate 20 years of economic reform, but lacked any major pronouncements of economic or political reforms, the Mail pointed out.

In sharp contrast to his usual image as an aggressive reformer, Jiang chose the high-profile moment to warn against foreign influences that might destabilize the country from within or disrupt the Communist Party's grip on power, it noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAO SHOU-PO SWORN IN AS TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, central Taiwan, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government's structure and functions is an important milestone in the nation's modernization.

Siew made the remark in a swearing-in ceremony for newly appointed Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shou-po, Vice Governor Chiang Ching-hsian, seven commissioners of the Provincial Council, Secretary-General Chen Wu-hsiung of the provincial government, and the heads of all provincial government departments.

With Premier Siew presiding, the ceremony began at 9:17 a.m. at the archives of the provincial government and was attended by the heads of counties and cities under the provincial government's jurisdiction and by other dignitaries.
Chao met the press after the swearing-in ceremony and outlined his plans for pushing provincial administrative affairs.

Chao said in the ceremony that the adjustment of the provincial government's organization and functions is the first step in, and will serve as a locomotive for, the reconstruction of the entire government. Trifling matters must not derail the process, and the methods that will be used to bring the reconstruction about must be well explained, he said.
The Provisional Statute for the Adjustment of the Taiwan Provincial Government's Organization and Functions is effective from Dec. 21. Chao vowed to spare no efforts in completing his mission.

Chao said he will listen carefully to the opinions of provincial government employees, as well as coordinate actions with the central government and respect the points of view of the heads of counties and cities under the jurisdiction of the provincial government in the implementation of provincial affairs.

Chao thanked past provincial governors, especially his predecessor, James Soong, and the staff of the provincial government for their contributions to provincial administrtion and development. He said their contributions and efforts have been the biggest impetus in creating the "Taiwan economic miracle."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA, TAIWAN SET TO STRENGTHEN COOPERATION ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Bilateral cooperation on aboriginal affairs between Canada and Taiwan is set to be further strengthened after the two sides signed a memorandum of understanding Sunday in Taipei.

The memorandum of understanding on cooperation in addressing aboriginal affairs -- signed jointly by David Mulroney, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, and Hua Chia-chih, chairman of the Republic of China's Cabinet-level Aboriginal Affairs Commission -- took effect Sunday and will remain valid for 10 years.

Under the memorandum of understanding, the two sides will alternately hold workshops on issues involving the educational, cultural, economic and social development, as well as the environmental protection, of Canada and Taiwan's aboriginal populations.
In addition, the two sides will strengthen exchanges in activities, including handicraft production and marketing, contests in traditional skills, and traditional festivals.

Witnessing the signing ceremony were several Canadian guests to Taiwan, including Inuit President Okalik Eegeesiak, and Indian chieftain Larry Sault. Also witnessing the ceremony were R. Axwell, a parliamentarian from New Zealand, and representatives from Japan's Ainu people.

Mulroney said that with the signing of the memorandum, exchanges and cooperation between peoples of Taiwan and Canada will become closer, which will consequently further bolster bilateral relations between the two countries.
Shen Lyu-shun, North American affairs director at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, also attended the signing ceremony and wished the cooperation project great success.

Shen said there are many things common to the aboriginal peoples of both Taiwan and Canada. For example, the Canadian natives have a famous ice wine while Taiwan's aboriginal people have millet wine, and the number of aboriginal people in each country constitutes 2 percent of that country's total population.

One difference between the two countries is the relative size of their economies: Whereas Taiwan is a small island and Canada a very large country, Taiwan has a gross national product (GNP) that is about half that of Canada, Shen noted.
