DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL ADMINISTRATIVE AFFAIRS TO CONTINUE WITHOUT CEASE: SIEW
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, central Taiwan, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The advancement of the Taiwan Provincial Government's (TPG) administrative affairs will continue without cease, and the government will have a brand new look as it serves as an example for the entire government's reconstruction, Premier Vincent Siew said Monday.
Premier Siew made the remark in a swearing-in ceremony for newly appointed Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shou-po.

The Provisional Statute for the Adjustment of Taiwan Provincial Government's Organization and Functions goes into effect Dec. 21, after the swearing-in of Chao, the first officially appointed Taiwan governor since the government was streamlined and the 15th appointed governor in the history of the TPG.
Siew said the provincial government's achievements in the construction and development of Taiwan province in the past 50 years are known to everyone.
He said public demands for a high-quality and fast-moving government are an international trend. If the government does not actively proceed with its work, there will be a regression, Siew said.
Siew noted that people in Taiwan will see and feel in the future the government's efforts to reconstruct itself, to establish new mechanisms and to the strengthen the quality of its public service.

Premier Siew praised Chao for his educational background and for his political experience. Siew said he is sure Chao will be a bridge between the central and local governments in regard to the reconstruction of the entire government.
Siew also gave Chao four instructions:
--Promote the prosperous development of localities and areas under the provincial government's jurisdiction;
--Allow no cessation in the advancement of provincial administrative affairs after the adjustments to Taiwan provincial government's structure and functions have been completed; and
--Continue to supervise localities as they are given greater autonomy and coordinate with all levels of governments to solve problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU HOSPITAL CELEBRATES 105TH HEART TRANSPLANT

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital threw a party on Monday to mark the successful completion of its 105th heart transplant operation.
A number of recipients of heart transplants at the NTU Hospital and their families also attended the party to celebrate their "rebirth."
NTU Hospital Vice President Chu Shu-hsun, who also heads the hospital's heart transplant panel, said the biggest obstacle to organ transplants in Taiwan is the limited supply of healthy organs.
"Organ donation, particularly heart donation, has remained rare in Taiwan. As a result, many local heart patients have died in waiting for a suitable organ for transplant operations," Chu regretted.

The heart disease expert said he hopes heart donation will become increasingly prevalent here to facilitate transplant surgery. At present, only five out of every 1 million people here would donate hearts. "We hope the ratio of heart donation would increase to 25 out of every 1 million people to match the US level in the not too distant future," Chu said.

NTU Hospital completed the island's first heart transplant on July 17, 1987. It has since completed a total of 105 heart transplants. The oldest surviving transplant recipient is aged 68, while the youngest surviving recipient is only 3 years old.

Meanwhile, 19-year-old Hou Ching-sung is the longest surviving recipient of heart transplant at NTU Hospital. He received the transplant at the age of 13 with a heart donated by a female student died of a car accident.
The youngest recipient is 3-year-old Hsu Wei-chun who received a heart transplant when he was just 14 months old.

Among the heart transplant recipients at NTU Hospital, four were aged under 10, and 20 aged between 60 and 69. Shu Fu-hsien, now 68 years old, was the oldest recipient who underwent a heart transplant two years ago at the age of 66.

Chu said the success rate for heart transplants stands at 95.5 percent. The five-year survival rate is 74 percent, while the 10-year survival rate is about 73 percent. According to Chu, major reasons for those who died after heart transplants included rejection, infection and suspension of taking medicine.
NTU Hospital tops other domestic medical institutions in terms of the number of completed heart transplants.

A medical team headed by Wei Cheng, incumbent president of Chen Hsin General Hospital in suburban Taipei, has completed 131 heart transplants. But the figure included those performed when Wei still worked at Tri-Service General Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 21, or the third day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims from the ship Mayflower go ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony.
1846: Anesthetic is used for the first time in a British hospital when Scottish physician Robert Liston amputates a leg at University College Hospital in London.
1898: Scientists Pierre and his wife Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases to publish after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the jazz age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany in World War II, dies as a result of a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the US' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to Earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG ARRIVES TAIPEI FOR NINE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland China's exiled leading dissident, Wei Jingsheng, flew into Taipei Monday for a nine-day visit, the first of its kind by the "father of democracy in mainland China."

Wei, 48, is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of C.Y. Rau, president of the World League for Freedom and Democracy's Republic of China chapter. Wei was met at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Rau and Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Research.
Now living in the United States after being released by Beijing on medical parole in 1997, Wei will view for himself during his stay the development of democracy in Taiwan.
He will also meet with President Lee Teng-hui, receive an honorary doctorate from National Taiwan University and speak on how he has strived to bring democracy to mainland China.

But an in-depth analysis of Wei's visit by Taiwan's China Times indicates his main goal is to seek concrete support from Taiwan for the burgeoning democratic activities that mainland Chinese activists have been promoting overseas.
If Taiwan cannot provide financial support or hands-on assistance for the Chinese democracy movement overseas, the visit to Taiwan will be meaningless, Wei was quoted as saying.
Born in 1950 in the northern mainland Chinese province of Anhui to parents who were both high-ranking Communist officials, Wei was a typical Red Guard who was raised up on the "Communists' milk."

Wei, however, became disillusioned with the Chinese Communists in the wake of the Cultural Revolution. He started the Xidan Democracy Wall movement in 1978, advocating the implementation of the "fifth modernization" -- the modernization of politics -- and was subsequently imprisoned for subversion in 1979.
Wei was released in 1993 as a goodwill gesture by Beijing, which wanted to be chosen as the host site for the 2000 Olympic Games.
In February 1994 Wei met with US Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor John Shattuck in Beijing. The visit greatly angered Beijing's apparatchiks.
In March of that year, Wei was detained when then US Secretary of State Warren Christopher visited Beijing. He was released shortly after Christopher's visit ended.
On April 1, 1994, he was again arrested. In December 1995 Beijing authorities sentenced him to 14 years in jail on charges of "conspiring to subvert the government."
He was released in November 1997 on medical parole.
Wei's release is good, said a local political observer, but the release does not mean that Beijing has changed its attitude in regard to mainland China's human rights situation.

Wei has been imprisoned on-and-off for 18 years in mainland China. An internationally acclaimed spokesman for democracy in mainland China, he has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, and has received the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Foundation Award for Human Rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD REGIONAL EDUCATION SYMPOSIUM

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan will serve as host to the 16th Southeast Asia and Pacific Region Educational Administrators and Managers' Symposium (SEAPREAMS) in December 1999.

In an interview with CNA on Sunday, Li Chen-ching, director-general of the Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations under the Ministry of Education, said the symposium would be held in Taipei from Dec. 13 to 18, 1999.

"This is the first time we win the right to host the symposium in Taiwan. We are glad to have that opportunity because it would help us promote the cooperation of cultural and educational exchanges among the 28 member countries," he said.
He said about 60 delegates from 27 other members countries will go to Taipei to attend the meeting.
Li, who flew into Canberra on Saturday, held a meeting with academics at Australian National University.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PLEASED AIR STRIKES AGAINST IRAQ HAVE ENDED

TEXT.P: Australia on Sunday expressed pleasure that the air strikes launched against Iraq recently by the United States and the United Kingdom have ended.
"We are pleased to see the end of the US-UK military action against Iraq," said Foreign Minister Alexander Downer.
He said Australia was also glad to see that the bombing missions were successful.

Australia sent two warships into the region during the 1991 Gulf War to help with a blockade of the Middle East sea lane. It also sent elite troops in early 1998 in support of a US-UK military buildup in preparation for an attack against Iraq for their refusal to allow UN weapons inspectors unrestricted access in their search for weapons of mass destruction.
Iraq later backed down and promised to allow the UN inspectors unrestricted access.

This time, however, Australia was not asked to send any troops or warships into the region. Canberra nevertheless expressed its full support for both the United States and the United Kingdom in their military action against Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE SAYS NO GOVERNMENT CAN OPPRESS ITS PEOPLE FOR LONG

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told a Paraguayan newspaper that, sooner or later, mainland China will have to change, that the Chinese are born free, and that no government can oppress them for long.

The Paraguayan newspaper Noticias cited President Lee as saying that the first popular elections for the president of the Republic of China were held two years ago. This is the basis of the country's present democracy, and in the future the Republic of China aims to continue to advance and to cooperate with more friendly nations.
The Republic of China is now pursuing a more efficient government with the help of its legislature. The country also wants to elevate the spiritual lives of its people, Lee said.
The Republic of China has a democratic political system that is not a mere facade, and the country wants its democratic spirit to reach all people, not just in form but in substance, he said.
He emphasized that the question of Taiwan independence is not an important issue for its people, adding that the Republic of China is a sovereign country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA RETURNS FROM ASEAN MEETING AND STATE VISITS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada reported Sunday that his week-long trip to Hanoi and Bangkok, in which he further consolidated the Philippines' key role in promoting and maintaining peace and stability in Southeast Asia, has been a success.
The president arrived Sunday afternoon with first lady Loi Estrada and his delegation from Bangkok, the last leg of a two-country, weeklong journey.

He attended the sixth formal summit meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) from Dec. 15 to 16. Afterward he made a state visit to Vietnam from Dec. 17 to 18. He then flew to Bangkok on Dec. 18 and spent three days in the country on a "special working visit."

The sixth ASEAN summit in Hanoi, he said, helped to further consolidate ASEAN leaders' resolve and determination to further strengthen their unity and cooperation "for the future of peace, stability and sustainable development in Southeast Asia."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.018 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market to close at 32.247 on Monday.
Turnover amounted to US$288 million.
The local currency opened at 32.256, the day's lowest level and experienced a high of 32.241.

DOC.HEADLINE: SANTA CLAUS COMES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Santa Claus came to Taiwan Sunday from Finland's Santa Claus village, bringing goodwill and best wishes to Taiwan.
The long-bearded Santa was invited to Taiwan by Finnish telecommunications giant Nokia to promote the company's products and to celebrate Christmas with children in orphanages islandwide.

Wearing his traditional red and white suit, Santa stirred up merriment at CKS International Airport. He gave the customs officer a brassard reading "Merry Christmas." People at the airport rushed to have their pictures taken with him, while giggling children gathered around him.
Santa said that because he is 400 years old, everyone is a child in his eyes. He also thanked Nokia for inviting him to Taiwan on this special occasion.
Santa will visit orphanages in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung and will stay in Taiwan for one week.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE RECEIVES FORMER VATICAN AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: The Vatican's ambassador to the Republic of China from 1970 to 1979 recently returned to Taiwan for a tour of the island's central and southern regions, and met with President Lee Teng-hui in Taipei on Monday.

His Eminence Cardinal Cassidi, head of the Pontifical Commission for the Unity of Christians, told Lee that while serving as ambassador, he was deeply impressed with the industriousness and frugal spirit of the people here.
President Lee told his guest about the ROC's achievements over the years including its economic development and educational reforms.

As Taiwan's economy strengthened, it was able to assist in the economic development in other nations, Lee noted. He said the introduction of over 200,000 foreign laborers to the island from Southeast Asia is an indication of such assistance, and over a million family members have indirectly benefited from such employment.
The ROC is also willing to provide developing nations with its experience in economic development, Lee added.

The president also extended his thanks to the Vatican for its long-term support. He made special mention of Pope John Paul II's enjoyment of a special aborigine performance led by Lee's wife a month ago.
President Lee asked Cardinal Cassidi to extend his respects to Pope John Paul II.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGING POPULATION TO BECOME A GREATER BURDEN TO WORKERS: CLA

TEXT.P: The burden of supporting Taiwan's elderly population is growing as approximately every 3.8 worker will have to support one retired person by 2025, largely reduced from the recent record of eight to one, statistics revealed on Monday.

According to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), Taiwan marched into the so-called "aging society" in September 1993. The United Nations defines a society as old-aged or aging when the number of people over 65 accounts for at least 7 percent of the total population.

Due to a reduced fertility rate, advances made in medical treatment and a higher life expectancy, Taiwan's population is getting old, with the number of people between 45 to 64 expected to increase from 23.3 percent in 1996 to 31.7 percent in 2004.
Taiwan's population aged over 65 will soar to 16 percent while the burden for workers will double by 2025, the statistics indicated.

Many of today's younger generation prefer to further their education to joining the labor market soon after earning their first degree. This can result in a reduction in the total labor force participation rate.

The CLA indicated that if the situation remains unchanged, the gross national product will decrease and workers, or producers, will have to support more and more retired people who become strictly consumers, unless productivity is boosted.

Meanwhile, statistics also showed that unemployment among the middle- to old-aged group within the last 10 years was unstable. Unemployment among this group was 17,000 in 1986, 9,000 in 1991 and 25,000 in 1996. In June 1998, the figure surged to 31,000 which has been attributed to the recent spate of bankruptcies among factories amid the region's financial crisis.

Those in charge of hiring often have the misconception that older candidates are less capable, less efficient, harder to communicate with and demand higher salaries than their younger counterparts, the CLA said. It added that an increase in age does not necessarily lead to inability.

The council stressed the importance of amending rules governing compulsory age retirement and the pension plan system requiring companies to pay pensions in one lump sum to make it easier for elderly people to be hired. (Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS CONTINUE TO FALL IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers received a total of US$9.75 billion worth of orders from around the world in November, down 5.31 percent or US$550 million from the year-earlier level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Monday.

Export orders usually pick up in the last quarter of the year because of seasonal factors. However, the value of export orders received in November hit a low of US$9.76 billion compared to October's US$10.38 billion.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general the MOEA Statistics Department, blamed the Asian financial crisis as the culprit of November's drop. The economic turmoil has battered the economies of most of the countries in the region, leading the overall decline of demand and imports, he noted.
Chang estimated that the value of annual export orders for 1998 may show a decline of about 4 percent.
Cumulatively, he said, Taiwan received US$108.85 billion worth of export orders in the first 11 months of this year, down 3.86 percent from the same period in the previous year.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's industrial production in the January-November period this year grew 4.18 percent over the same months of 1997, with the manufacturing sector expanding the most at 3.97 percent.
The information technology and telecommunications industry, the backbone of Taiwan's manufacturing power, continued to grow in the face of the regional crisis, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN GOVERNOR VOWS TO SERVE AS COMMUNICATION BRIDGE

TEXT.P: Moments after he was sworn in as Taiwan provincial governor, Chao Shou-po on Monday vowed to serve as a communication bridge between the central and local governments.

Speaking at a news conference, Chao said he will make a concerted effort to gain a better understanding of the public's needs. He said while his primary obligation is to protect the interests and foster the well-being of the public, his top priority is to smoothly oversee the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG).

Premier Vincent Siew presided over the swearing-in ceremony, which saw Chao replace James Soong, the first and only popularly elected provincial governor of Taiwan. Soong's term officially ended on Saturday as a result of constitutional amendments made last year to downsize the provincial government.
Chao said there was no need to compare him with Soong as Soong was elected by popular vote and he was appointed to the post by the central government.

His mission is to restructure the TPG in compliance with the Provisional Statute for the Adjustment of the Taiwan Provincial Government's Organization and Functions, effective beginning on Monday, he stated.

As a government official and a member of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), the new Taiwan provincial governor said in serving the interests of the public, he is also duty bound to seek public support for the KMT. However, he noted that he will serve all members of the public equally regardless of their political affiliation.

Voicing the hope that all heads of the old TPG's 29 departments and bureaus would remain at their posts to help him continue with the provincial administration, he called on the 146,369 TPG employees not to worry about their future as the central government will protect their interests.

Turing to the question of whether the streamlined TPG will have less power than previously, Chao denied this was true. He said the TPG will have a brighter future as it is still a juridical entity and has the same status as a Cabinet-level ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES REBOUND

TEXT.P: The Taipei stock market rebounded on Monday with the weighted price index finishing at 6,558.28, or 80.17 points higher than the previous session's close.
Turnover totaled NT$50.13 billion.

The rebound was mainly due to action taken by the Ministry of Finance, which launched a strategy to cope with the instability of the local stock market. Unconfirmed reports stated that the ministry was ready to inject another NT$10 billion to safeguard the bourse.
Of the eight major stock categories, only construction shares declined, falling by 0.5 percent.

Financial shares recorded the highest gain with a 2.7 percent rise, followed by paper and pulp issues with 1.7 percent, textiles issues, 1.5 percent, plastic and chemical shares, 1.4 percent, cement issues, 0.6 percent, electric engineering shares, 0.3 percent, and foodstuff issues up 0.2 percent.

Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also rebounded. The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January climbed 93 points closing at 6,705, with 3,869 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 6,612 points for January, 6,626 points for February, 6,640 points for March, 6,525 for June, and 6,575 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR HOLDS LAST CITY GOVERNMENT MEETING

TEXT.P: Outgoing Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih on Monday met for the last time with city department heads during the 824th regular city government meeting as he wraps up his final week in office.
Wu thanked members from each department for their cooperation over the years and encouraged them to dedicate themselves to the city's development.

He also made mention of several important construction projects which are underway such as the multi-functional economic and trade park as well as the South Star project. He expressed the hope that Kaohsiung Mayor-elect Frank Hsieh and other city officials would continue with these projects and commit to improving the city.
After the meeting which was described as having a melancholy atmosphere, Wu posed for photographs with department heads.
He is scheduled to hold a news conference on Dec. 24, a day before he officially steps down. A banquet party will be held in his honor at city hall later that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL CRISIS TAKES TOLL ON US MNC'S ASIAN PROFITS

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis which started in July 1997 has hit US investments in the region, with income from investments falling in every Asian country except for Singapore, mainland China and Taiwan.
US investment income increased by 2.3 percent to US$648 million in Taiwan, but the rate of return (the ratio of income to fixed investment) fell from 14 to 13.

Taken as a whole, US multinational corporations (MNC) saw their profits in Asia fall by US$300 million to US$18.3 billion in 1997. This compares with a rise of US$500 million to US$18.6 billion in 1996, according to the US Department of Commerce.

In contrast, US MNC profits in the same period shot up from US$43.2 billion to US$47.9 billion in Europe, from US$17.8 billion to US$19.9 billion in Latin America, from US$1.8 billion to US$1.9 billion in Africa and from US$1.4 billion to US$1.6 billion in the Middle East.

In Thailand, where the Asian financial first erupted, yields on investments fell 28 percent to US$581 million in 1997. Pullouts by some MNC also slashed US fixed investments in Thailand from US$4.8 billion to US$3.5 billion in the same period.

US MNC profits fell the sharpest -- 42 percent -- in South Korea, one of the hardest-hit by the crisis. Profits sank from US$924 million to US$538 million. Investment income also fell in Japan (-6 percent), Hong Kong (-8 percent), Indonesia (-9 percent) and Malaysia (-3 percent).
US investment rose 15.5 percent to US$3.3 billion in Australia and climbed 20 percent to US$616 million in New Zealand. It remained unchanged at US$552 million in the Philippines.

The rate of return for Asia as a whole was 13 percent in 1997, down from 14 percent. It rose from 11.3 to 11.4 percent in Europe, but fell from 12.1 to 11.6 percent in Latin America and 18.1 to 17.4 percent in the Middle East.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM COURTS TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (VECOT) jointly held an investment seminar on Monday in a bid to attract greater Taiwan investment.
VECOT head Dang Dinh Luu, on behalf of the Vietnamese government, described Vietnam's investment climate to the local business community.

Stressing that his country highly welcomes Taiwan businesses to invest in Vietnam by providing them with a sound investment environment and handsome incentives, Dang singled out the newly developed Tan Thuan Export Processing Zone near Ho Chi Minh City as an example.

The 300-hectare complex, which includes a container harbor and a complete traffic network, is jointly run by the MOEA's Nantze Export Processing Zone in Taiwan's southern Kaohsiung County, according to Dang.

DOC.HEADLINE: HENRY LEE PROMISES TO HELP PROBE ALLEGED MURDER CASE

TEXT.P: Dr. Henry Lee, a forensic scientist-turned US state police chief, promised here on Monday to look into the mysterious death in Canada of the nephew of a murdered ROC naval officer in charge of weaponry procurement.

Lee, commissioner of the Public Safety Department of the Connecticut State Government, made the vow at the request of Yin Hsing-wen, a younger sister of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng who was murdered in 1993.
Yin Hsing-wen told Lee that she suspects foul play was behind her son's sudden death two years ago when he was studying at a university in Quebec, Canada.

"I suspect my son, Yang I-li, was murdered by the same criminal ring that also murdered my elder brother a few years ago over a controversial weaponry trading deal," Yin Hsing-wen claimed, adding that she believes the two deaths were related to the French Thomson-CSF military equipment manufacturing group.
Yin presented photos showing the crime scene where her son was found dead and other data to Lee for his reference.
In response, the respected Chinese-American forensic expert said although he is a specialist in crime scene investigations, he cannot determine the cause of Yang's death solely based on the photos.

Nevertheless, Lee promised to consult with some American experts in related fields after he returns to the United States. "I'll give you a reply on some of the dubious points you mentioned after discussing them with some American specialists in related fields," he told Yin.
Yang I-li was found dead in his bathtub on Nov. 1, 1996. Canadian coroners said after an autopsy that Yang died of electrocution on Oct. 28 after a hair dryer fell into the bathtub.

At the request of Yang's mother, the Republic of China's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) sent officers to Canada to look into the cause of his death. CBI officers also concluded that Yang died in an accidental electrocution.

The Yin family at one time also hired private investigators to determine the cause of Yang's death. All the details collected by those investigators were sent to Yang Jih-sung, then director of the CIB's Medical Jurisprudence Office, for further scrutiny.

After a comprehensive review of the reports, Yang Jih-sung tentatively concluded that the cause of Yang's death required further investigation as the photos showed that Yang's head still had residue of shampoo.
"It is unreasonable to assume that Yang would try to dry his hair before he finished washing his hair," the retired coroner said.

Henry Lee, a graduate of the ROC's Central Police University, is the first US state police chief of Chinese origin. He is currently here to attend a seminar on criminal investigations and to promote a book on his achievements in the field.
Lee, 59, delivered a speech at Taipei's prestigious Chienkuo Senior High School on Monday.
In his speech, Lee said the key to success is "working a bit harder than others." He encouraged Taiwan youths intending to enter his profession to study hard and to be curious about everything.

Earlier in the day, Lee said in an interview with a local radio station that an urge to pursue justice and truth was the driving force behind his wholehearted devotion to forensic study and criminal investigations over past decades.

Lee went to the United States for advanced study in the late 1960s after several years of service in Taiwan's police force. He received a Ph.D. in biochemistry from New York State University in 1975 and went on to serve in many US law enforcement agencies.
During his decades of service in Taiwan and the US, Lee has received a number of honors and citations for his outstanding achievements in criminal investigations.
He has helped investigated over 6,000 felonies around the world and has testified in more than 1,000 civil and criminal court hearings, including high-profile O. J. Simpson case in California.

Lee has traveled to Taiwan several times in the past two years to assist in the investigation of two serious criminal cases -- the Mafia-style execution of former Taoyuan County Magistrate Liu Pang-you and seven of his aides as well as the rape and murder of Peng Wan-ju, a women's rights activist.

Lee said on Monday that he has presented a report on evidence analysis related to the Liu Pang-you case to the ROC's police authorities. The report mentioned the suspect's age, height and other traits. Lee, however, would not divulge any other details.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNERAL HELD FOR 2 F-5F PILOTS

TEXT.P: A public funeral was held in the eastern Taiwan city of Taitung on Monday for two ROC Air Force pilots who died in a plane crash on Dec. 3.

Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min personally presided over the funeral to pay tribute to Lieut. Colonel Lee Ying-chuan and Lieutenant Lin Ying-chih, who died after a F-5F jet fighter they were flying was hit by a pigeon and crashed during a night training flight.
The fighter was on its way back to the Chihhang air base in Taitung after completing a night training mission. The warplane crashed after its left engine was hit by a pigeon.
Gen. Chen said the death of the two trained pilots was a great loss not only to the Air Force but also to the nation.
The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said it will step up efforts to disperse pigeons in the surrounding areas of all of its air bases to prevent recurrence of similar tragedies.
It also called on people residing in the off-limits areas not to raise pigeons any more to stem such bird strike cases.
"We hope law enforcement authorities will intensify crackdown on illegal pigeon raising in areas near all air bases," the AFGH urged in a press statement.
Taiwan is about to retire its aging F-5 fleet, once the backbone of its air force, now that it has purchased 150 F-16s from the United States and 60 Mirage 2000-5s from France.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF NAMES HEAD OF PANEL FORMED TO STABILIZE BOURSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Monday named a banker as the convenor of a panel formed to stabilize the local bourse in an attempt to calm investors scared away by the recent series of financial crises.

Following a meeting of the panel, Minister of Finance Paul Chiu announced that Lee Yung-san, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China, has been appointed convenor of the panel of business tycoons and local banks heads charged with working out ways to boost the sagging stock market, which is weighed down by both the international financial crisis and a series of local business irregularities.

With the new convenor in place, Chiu said the panel, which was set up just prior to the Dec. 5 elections, will meet regularly to monitor the bourse's movement, and will assign panel members to prop up stock prices by bidding for blue-chip stocks.

In order to encourage institutions to invest in the stock market, Chiu also announced that financial institutions will be allowed to hold stocks as long term investments, and that banks will not be faulted by the Central Bank of China for holding stocks as security for loans, even if stock prices fall below the level of collateral required for the loans.
The relaxed measures will also apply to stocks received by banks as collateral for loans to securities brokers, Chiu said without elaborating.

The panel is part of MOF efforts to shore up the local bourse which saw its benchmark index rise by 80 points to 6,558 on Monday. The ministry has already funneled billions of NT dollars in government-managed funds into the bourse in the last couple of weeks, to no avail.
Later in the day, Lee Yuan-san announced that his panel has set a benchmark index target of 6,300, which represents the 10-year average level.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PUSH FOR EXCHANGE OF OFFICES WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will push for the exchange of representative offices with Mongolia and the signing of an investment guarantee agreement to boost bilateral substantive relations, a senior official said on Monday.
Kao Kung-lien, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC), made the statement at a seminar on trade and investment in Mongolia sponsored by the Cabinet-level commission.
Kao said the ROC government has attached great importance to the development of substantive relations with Mongolia because it has great growth potential.

"To facilitate trade and other substantive exchanges, we'll push for the signing of an investment guarantee agreement and the exchange of representative offices with Mongolia at an early date," Kao said, adding that he hopes the two goals can be realized in the coming year.

The MTAC has sponsored a Mongolia-bound investment and trade promotion meeting in Taipei annually since 1992. The conference scale was expanded this year by inviting officials, academics and business executives from the two sides to take part in the discussion.
The agenda included Mongolia's general economic climate and trade policy as well as Taiwan investors' operations and management in Mongolia.
Former Mongolian Ambassador to the United Nations L. Erdenechuluun, and several incumbent Mongolian officials and parliamentarians have come here to attend the ongoing meeting.

Taiwan's investment in Mongolia remains limited. According to official Mongolian tallies, there are only seven legally licensed Taiwan companies in Mongolia at present and their total capital investment accounts for a mere 1 percent of accumulated foreign investment in that country.
Kao said a lack of information about trade and investment opportunities in Mongolia is the main reason behind the slow growth in Taiwan's investment there.

Nevertheless, Kao said optimistically that bilateral economic relations will continue to grow smoothly in line with Mongolia's progress in economic reforms and market opening. Two-way trade between Taiwan and Mongolia increased from US$150,000 in 1994 to US$1.41 million in 1997. "Although the amount was limited, the growth rate was encouraging," Kao noted.

Kao managed to make a visit to Mongolia in May this year, marking the first high-level encounter between the two sides. "We believe high-level official exchanges of visits will increase in the future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENTS GIVEN LONG PRISON TERMS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai, who applied to establish the local branches of the would-be "China Democracy Party (CDP)" earlier this year, were sentenced to 13 and 11 years in prison on charges of "subverting state power."

According to a report by the Xinhua News Agency of Beijing, the mainland Chinese government defined the CDP as an illegal organization. Each of the two dissidents also received a three-year deprivation of political rights.

Analysts here pointed out that the Constitution of mainland China, the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights signed by Beijing in October, and the mainland Chinese regulations governing the registration and administration of civil organizations have all stated that the people in mainland China have freedom of association and assembly. The conviction of the two dissidents has made people in the whole world doubtful about mainland China's policy on human rights, they added.
The two dissidents were also accused of seeking and receiving funds "from hostile overseas organizations in order to organize, plan, and conduct subversive activities."

If it were eventually established with government approval, the CDP would be the first opposition party in mainland China. But the communist government in Beijing has never permitted the formation of any opposition party since its founding in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS:
MAINLAND CHINA AT CROSSROADS FOR DEMOCRACY: WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: Mainland China is now at a crossroads in the road to a democratic system, top mainland dissident Wei Jingsheng said on Monday at the start of a visit to Taiwan.

"The Beijing regime must either undertake political reform by allowing the establishment of political parties and freedom of speech and assembly, or risk the eruption of riots and even the danger of being toppled," Wei said at a press conference upon his arrival.

He noted that mainland China's current unemployment figure stands at around 100 million, posing a great threat to social stability. "If Beijing fails to accelerate the pace of its reforms, serious social unrest, and even the collapse of the Beijing regime, is likely to take place," Wei warned.
"If this happens, then the Chinese Communist Party, Asia and even the whole of the world will suffer," he added.
Wei, who was released on medical parole last year after spending nearly 18 years in jail for his pro-democratic stance, also rejected the term "Western democracy."
"The principles of democracy are applicable to all parts of the world," Wei stressed, citing Taiwan's success in democratization as an example.

He said that due to the joint efforts of the government and people, Taiwan has successfully established a sound democratic system, which is clear evidence that Chinese people are as entitled to democracy as any other race.

He pointed out that it has been 20 years since the pro-democracy movement in mainland China was first suppressed by the Beijing authorities, and added that greater efforts must be made to promote democracy there, as this is very important to the peace and security of Asia.

Wei, who is now living in exile in the United States, claimed that the mainland's ongoing economic reforms have not met with as much success as has been thought. "It (economic development) did not benefit the general public, but just created a class of wealthy and corrupt officials and bureaucrats," he added.
He attributed this to the fact that the Beijing leadership has been reluctant to engage in political reform.

Commenting on Beijing's habit of making mass arrests of dissidents and then releasing them one by one, Wei said that the move is just a "smoke screen" to attempt to hide the regime's bad human rights record. "Actually, there has been no change at all in Beijing's human rights abuse," he added.

On whether there should a timetable for China's reunification, Wei said that it would be meaningless for any unification timetable before the Communist Party abandons its doctrine of "one party autocracy."
Wei is in Taipei for a nine-day visit at the invitation of the ROC chapter of the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD).

He described cross-strait negotiations as a positive step, but said that they have to be conducted on an equal footing. If the mainland continues with its attempts to annex Taiwan, then any talks will be fruitless, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR FINALLY TAKES VACATION
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong arrived in San Francisco on Sunday, shortly after leaving his post.
Speaking to a CNA reporter at the airport, Soong said this is his first US visit as a private citizen in three decades.

He recalled that when he first stepped on US soil to further his education, he felt himself to be standing on the threshold of a boundless world. Today, he said, he still has this feeling, and is well aware that he has many things to do for the rest of his life.

Asked of his understanding as to the true meaning of two phrases -- "Everything, solid or subtle, is illusory" and "You should feel free and easy at every moment" -- that President Lee Teng-hui wrote down on a scroll as a gift for him, Soong answered that man is supposed to be free, especially in the United States.

Although he declined to talk about a meeting he had with Lee on Friday, the former Taiwan governor expressed his deep appreciation to Lee and the ruling Kuomintang, which promoted him in his service to the nation.

Soong lost his job due to the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government, a move promoted by Lee's leadership as a way of boosting administrative efficiency, although rumors have been rife that a behind-the-scenes political battle has long raged between Lee and the popular Soong.

Questioned on whether he intends to take part in the presidential election in 2000, Soong, who was Taiwan's first and only elected governor, was reluctant to comment, saying that he has had no time to think about the issue.

Describing his political career over the past few decades as "so busy, I've forgotten what its like to have a good sleep or a good meal," Soong said that not until he quit his official duties did he realize that sleeping can be comfortable, and that a meal prepared by his wife can taste like ambrosia.

He said his US holiday will allow him a much-needed rest, and give him time to think over many issues, including his future. "Most important is to think of how I can treat my wife better," he added. His wife is accompanying him on his vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DISPROVES BEIJING'S ARGUMENT AGAINST DEMOCRACY: WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: Taiwan's democratization disproves Beijing's persistent denunciation of democracy as alien to and thus incompatible with Chinese culture, exiled mainland Chinese dissent Wei Jingsheng said on Monday.

Wei, who arrived in Taipei on Monday for a nine-day visit, said at a press conference that Taiwan's successful transition to democracy has exposed the falsehood of Beijing's contention that the "Western" concept of democracy can't take root in the East, much less in China.
This partly explains Beijing's hostility towards the island which mainland China never ceases to try to shut out of the international community and make into an international pariah, said Wei.

He attributed the island's successful democratic transformation to three elements -- namely an active popular campaign for democracy; a group of brilliant political leaders receptive to new ideas ; and the ability of the island to respond to international calls for democracy.
Mainland China lags far behind in the movement toward democracy because of the absence of the latter two elements, Wei said.
He denounced Beijing's attempts to squeeze Taiwan out of all international groups, which he described as a move intended to render Taiwan passports "useless" throughout the world.

The ploy is especially wicked viewed against the background of Beijing's persistent calls for their "fellow countrymen in Taiwan" to "return to the arms of motherland," said Wei, who has lived in exile in the United States since being freed by Beijing on medical parole in December, 1997.
He admonished Taiwan to struggle for its own survival rather than rely on Beijing's mercy, since the "communist regime has never been lenient toward its rivals."

In reply to questions from reporters, the mainland's most renowned dissent, who has spent almost 18 years in jail, gave mixed comments on US President Bill Clinton's Beijing trip in June, saying that although Clinton's journey has to some extent pressed Beijing into mending its human rights records, it sent the wrong signal to the world that Washington backs the communist dictatorship.

Asked to comment on the campaign for Taiwan independence by some local political figures, Wei said it is a question which should be answered by the public rather than politicians, adding that the well-being of the people should be the main priority when deciding the island's status.

Wei, who was invited to Taiwan by the World League for Freedom and Democracy, ROC Chapter, is slated to pay calls on the Legislative Yuan and several government agencies. A meeting with President Lee Teng-hui has also been planned before he departs on Dec. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES EFFORTS TO REDUCE TRADE IMBALANCE WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficits against Japan are expected to surge to US$18 billion, a historic new record high, officials from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Monday.
The officials said that the figure has alerted them to the need to enhance the promotion of Taiwan products, in order to try to reduce the trade imbalance.
To this end, the officials added, CETRA has recently been pursuing Best Corp., Japan's largest electrical appliance chain, and one of its subsidiaries, to stock Taiwan-made products.
CETRA said that 36 local heavyweight manufacturers, including Tatung and First International Computer, have been invited to attend an upcoming meeting with Best.
Best owns now 510 chain stores in Japan and 13 overseas branches. Its 1998 operation value totaled NT$79.2 billion (US$2.46 billion).

CETRA officials revealed that the continuing appreciation of the Japanese yen has made Best interested in buying Taiwan products, while the rising yen benefits Taiwan's export to Japan. They urged local exporters to grab the opportunity to penetrate the Japanese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced four measures to prop up shaky stock market.
The China Times:
The MOF unveiled a four-point package to buoy stock transactions.
The United Daily News:
The Stock Market Stabilization Fund will prevent the weighted share price index from falling below the psychologically important 6,300-point barrier until the lunar New Year holiday.
The Liberty Times:
The government is expected to unveil a corporate relief package on Thursday.
The Independence Morning Post:
The MOF is determined to bolster the stock price index at above the 6,300-point level.
The Commons Daily:
President Lee Teng-hui said the ROC's Constitution does not allow dictatorship or despotic rule.
The China Post:
Exiled mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng arrives on nine-day visit.
The China News:
The ruling Kuomintang-owned Central Investment Holding Corp. will take over Pan Asia Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONFIDENT OF STEADY ECONOMIC GROWTH: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government is determined to take every effort to move the domestic economy toward the course of steady growth, Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday in a legislative interpellation session.

He said while many other Asian nations have been unable to reach any level of economic growth, Taiwan will likely record 5 percent growth for the year, adding that the public should have confidence in the government.
Siew was responding to questions from Legislator Cheng Feng-shih of the ruling Kuomintang. Cheng asked how the government planned to deal with the slumping stock market and sluggish economy.

Although the island's economy is indeed in a slump, the premier said the public should not lose confidence in the government as the fundamentals and the economic structure of the nation are still good.
It is good that the public is aware of the possibilities of an economic crisis, but people should not be deterred by setbacks as the government is working to strengthen the economy, Siew noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TECHNOLOGY PACT NEGOTIATIONS DELAYED AGAIN

TEXT.P: Members of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) information technology agreement (ITA) have again postponed the deadline for completing talks on extending its scope to other products, reports said on Monday.

Further negotiations will be held in February with the aim of completing an ITA-II pact that would remove duties on 200 high-tech products by 2002. Some poorer nations will have until 2007 to comply for certain items.

Although most ITA members, including the US and European Union, support the proposed list, some developing countries continue to have objections. Malaysia wants more consumer electronic products included, while India is objecting to the inclusion of non-IT items, such as radar and navigational equipment, and satellite parts.

In 1997, WTO members accounting for more than 90 percent of the US$600 billion-plus annual trade in information technology products agreed to eliminate tariffs on a wide range of computer and telecommunications goods by 2000. However, talks on ITA-II, which should have ended in June, have proved more difficult even though the additional product list has been more than halved in the search for a consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONK DRAWS SIMILARITIES BETWEEN PRISONS FOR TIBETANS, JEWS

TEXT.P: A Tibetan monk who spent 30 years in prisons and labor camps drew similarities between his experiences and those of Jews in World War II after visiting the Holocaust museum in Washington, The Globe and Mail reported on Monday.
"Everything I saw was familiar. Everything the Jews were going through, my people are going through now," Palden Gyatso told The Globe's foreign affairs editor Marcus Gee.
"If it doesn't stop, they will be commemorating us in a museum soon," Gyatso said, adding that all the cultural traditions he grew up with are being wiped out by mainland Chinese authorities.
The monk described five tools of torture used by his Chinese guards, they included three electric batons and two types of self-tightening handcuffs, one for the wrists and another for the thumbs.

Gyatso, 67, who became a monk when he was 10, said of all the boys who were ordained with him, he is the only survivor. By 1990, he had spent 30 years in prisons and labor camps. In 1983, when he landed in the notorious Drapchi Prison, rations were so small he was forced to eat mice, worms, grass and even his own leather shoes.

He was released in 1992 with the help of Amnesty International and other human rights groups. When he was freed, his only thought was to find his way to the Dalai Lama, "tell my story and die." Instead, he ended up turning it into a book titled "Fire under the Snow."
Despite all that he endured, Gyatso said he feels no anger toward his torturers. "They were only doing their job," Gee quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE MILITARY WARNS OF SITUATION IN SPRATLY

TEXT.P: Mainland China's continued construction on Mischief Reef indicates Beijing's intentions to make it its forward base to prevent other countries from exercising military control over the area, the Philippine military said on Monday.
Mischief Reef is an area of the disputed Spratly Islands which are claimed in part or wholly by mainland China, the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, Vietnam and the Republic of China.
The Philippine military said the situation in the area remains volatile as mainland China continues to build on Mischief Reef which Manila insists is part of its Kalayaan Island Group.

"The on-going extensive construction on Mischief Reef indicates that Beijing is bent on making the islet a forward base to prevent any claimant country from exercising full and effective military control of the area," the military said in a statement.

"The reef could be used as a staging base for Beijing's eastward operations in the Spratlys in an effort to assert claim in Reed Bank among others, the building of a pier and a structure which appeared to be barracks, attest to China's real motive," it continued.
The statement also said it is "highly probable" that mainland China will make Mischief Reef its primary base to support oil exploration and drilling operations.

The Philippine navy has intensified its sea patrol of the Mischief Reef area where Chinese construction resumed two months ago. The Philippine air force has been conducting reconnaissance flights over the area to monitor the activity.

Two weeks ago, US Congressmen Dana Rohrabacker flew over the area aboard a PAF C-130 plane and saw the Chinese buildup on the disputed reef. Rohrabacker is expected to report to the US Congress on what he saw, including three Chinese warships stationed in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN MINISTER ARRIVES FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Malaysian Transport Minister Ling Liong Sik arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a two-day private visit.
Stressing that he is here to meet with old friends, Ling declined to answer CNA's questions over whether he would call on ROC government officials.
Malaysia, which has no formal diplomatic relations with Taipei, maintains close substantive ties with the Republic of China due to geographic proximity and cultural links.
A large number of ethnic Chinese reside in Malaysia. Ling is also of Chinese origin.
