DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAUTIOUS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The ROC government is willing to conduct mutually beneficial exchanges with mainland China but cross-strait military exchanges must be very carefully assessed, Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday.

Siew made the remarks when fielding questions in legislature from lawmaker Yen Chin-fu of the Democratic Progressive Party about Hong Kong media reports that Taiwan and the mainland are preparing to launch military exchanges.
Stressing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently under separate rule, Siew said the government's top priority is to ensure Taiwan's continued survival.

Taiwan is willing to cooperate with mainland China in peaceful activities, but Beijing has so far been reluctant to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, constituting a major obstacle to bilateral military exchanges, he noted.

The ROC government's established policy is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must be unified under democracy, freedom and prosperity, the premier stated, adding that Taiwan never has deviated from this stance.
Wei Jingsheng, who arrived on Monday for a nine-day visit, was visiting the Legislative Yuan at the time of the interpellation session.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT SEEKS TO IMPROVE REFUGEE ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Australia's Immigration Ministry is calling for community groups to respond to a discussion paper on improving the assistance for newly-arrived refugees to settle in the country.

In a statement faxed to CNA on Tuesday, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock announced the release of the paper, which listed the provision of material assistance to entrants under the Humanitarian Program.
He said the paper would be distributed to key groups working in the area so they can determine whether the current program meets the needs of refugees when they arrive in Australia.
Ruddock said areas to be looked at include accommodation on arrival, food and clothing and assistance with establishing a household.

"This paper aims to stimulate discussion on these issues and the development of possible models for the future delivery of material assistance to refugees and humanitarian entrants," the minister said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURISTS PREDICT END OF MODERNISM

TEXT.P: As the end of the century draws near, futurists have been predicting what trends will dominate 1999, the Australian reported on Tuesday.
When the clock strikes midnight on New Year's Eve, modernity will be out, individuality in, and morality will dominate public debate, the paper reported.
People will find comfort in the objects and morality of the past as paranoia about technologies such as the Internet builds ahead of the next millennium, futurists predicted.
These are the views of researchers at the advertising firm Young and Rubicam, which has defined the trends that will shape the world in 1999.
"Many people are becoming obsessed with righting what they perceive as society's wrongs," US futurist Marian Salzman of Young and Rubicam's Brand Futures Group predicted.
"In 1999, voices of moderation and reason will be drowned out as extremists wrest control of social and political organizations," she said.
Salzman, co-author of "Next: Trends for the Future," predicted mass marketing and production lines, which revolutionized the 20th century, have had their day. Individuality will be back in vogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESERT FOX SEEN AS A FAILURE: AUSTRALIAN PAPERS

TEXT.P: Operation Desert Fox was a failure and has left the world divided over its purpose and effectiveness, while its key target remains a threat to the western world, Australian dailies said in editorials on Tuesday.
"The military assault on Iraq by the United States and Britain has failed by the measures that many outside observers would apply. It has not immediately removed Saddam Hussein," the Australian said.

Instead, the operation has "killed an unknown number of Iraqi civilians, people with whom the US and Britain are keen to stress they have no dispute. It has also forced a split within the United Nations Security Council."

"Russia and China have accused the UN Special Commission of tailoring its report to allow the US to carry out air strikes, showing that some damage has been done to international relations as well as to Iraqi infrastructure," the editorial continued. "The operation has probably also achieved the effective end of the UNSCOM inspection mission within Iraq."

In its editorial, the Sydney Morning Herald said: "Operation Desert Fox has left the world divided over its purpose and effectiveness. The timing of the four-day air strike on Iraq will remain forever controversial, enmeshed with the constitutional travesty perpetrated by the short-sighted representatives who voted to impeach President Bill Clinton. But this should not cloud assessment of its necessity.
"President Clinton and the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, have been criticized for failing to articulate the purpose of Desert Fox.

"Yet as time passes and the threat posed by President Saddam Hussein is no longer seen through the distorting prism of an abnormal political situation in Washington, it will become plain that Desert Fox, though it has no mark of victory to distinguish it, was neither misguided nor futile, but an essential precursor to a sadly inevitable new kind of preventative warfare," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 22, or the fourth day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Willhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty on Manchuria affairs with Japan in Peking, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways, and appoints Liang Shih-yu as director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Sian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: US heavy bombers raid Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as US President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement in the Southeast Asian country.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the US intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes secretary-general of the United Nations.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China, after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RULES OUT ADJUSTMENTS OF CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC POLICY

TEXT.P: The ROC government will not adjust its current trade and economic policy toward mainland China until the Beijing government ease its hostility toward Taiwan, a senior mainland affairs official said on Tuesday.

"As long as Beijing fails to forsake its recalcitrant, unrealistic and hegemonic attitude toward Taiwan, we'll not adjust our current 'no haste, be patient' policy on investment and other commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait," said Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Sheu made the statement in a keynote speech delivered at a two-day seminar on the problems and prospects for cross-strait trade and economic exchanges being held in Taoyuan county, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei. The seminar was co-sponsored by several private trade associations with interests with the mainland.
Sheu said Taiwan has spared no efforts to drive cross-strait relations to move in a peaceful, constructive direction and to promote bilateral economic exchanges.
According to ROC statistics, Taiwan business people had launched 21,000 investment projects, worth about US$13 billion, in mainland China as of the end of October.
Sheu said mainland China-bound investment now accounts for 42 percent of Taiwan's total outbound investment.

In terms of official mainland tallies, Sheu said, the number of Taiwan-invested companies on the mainland even had reached 40,600 by the end of September, with a combined capital infusion of US$20.9 billion. According to mainland tallies, Taiwan is now mainalnd China's third largest source of foreign capital.
Meanwhile, Sheu said, indirect cross-strait trade amounted to US$157.2 billion in the first three quarters of this year, accounting for 11 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade for the same period.

Sheu went on to say Taiwan's exports to mainland China increased 6.8 percent in the first nine months of this year as compared with the corresponding period of 1997. "The growth rate was the highest among all of mainland China's major trading partners," he noted.
In addition, Sheu said, Taiwan products made up 12.2 percent of mainland China's total imports for the nine-month period, the highest ratio for the past five years.
Despite these encouraging developments, Sheu said, Taiwan business people should remain cautious and prudent in launching ventures across the Taiwan Strait.
Sheu pointed out that mainland China's economic uncertainties have become a great obstacle to further growth in cross-strait commercial exchanges.

To make up for its slow growth in foreign exchange accumulation and tax revenues, mainland authorities have intensified factory inspections and crackdown on tax evasion and illegal foreign exchange transactions since the beginning of this year. "All these mainland actions have inflicted problems and financial losses to Taiwan-invested companies on the mainland," Sheu said.
He said Taiwan is more than willing to cooperate with mainland China in resolving various problems arising from cross-strait commercial exchanges so as to establish a sound cross-strait market order.
Sheu further stated that mainland China, while continuing its military intimidation and diplomatic suppression against Taiwan, has attempted to use trade as a "united front" tactic.

"Mainland China has deliberately courted Taiwan entrepreneurs and forged direct ties with them in an attempt to alienate them from our government or to drive wedges between them and the ROC government," Sheu observed.

Against this background, Sheu said, the government cannot adjust its "go slow" policy toward mainland China-bound investment activities. "We still have to give the top priority to our own national interests in formulating trade and economic policy toward the mainland at the moment," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING A LONG WAY FROM WTO ENTRY: REPORT

TEXT.P: Foreign trade negotiators in Geneva said mainland China's commitment to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) is losing momentum as its trade ties with the United States are worsening, the Australian reported on Tuesday.
Major problems between the two sides are the mainland's surging trade surplus with the United States and the lack of US access to the mainland's attractive markets.
US trade officials are unhappy with the way Beijing is going about trade negotiations with Washington -- making mainland China's WTO entry as elusive as ever, the daily reported.
US Commerce Secretary William Daley last week warned Beijing that "trade issues could lead us to substantial disengagement from China."

Daley reflects a growing discontent in US Congress about China's trade practices and some congressmen want Washington to threaten trade sanctions if Beijing fails to act on reducing trade barriers, according to the US Congressional Research Service.

China has the world's second largest trade surplus with the US, behind only Japan's. The US trade deficit with China has surged from US$3.5 billion in 1988 to US$60 billion in 1998 and the figure is expected to grow to US$70 billion in 1999.
In recent years, US companies have made public disputes with Chinese joint venture partners over what they saw as unfair treatment, the daily reported.

Daley told his Chinese counterparts last week that US companies had gone to China, played by Chinese rules, and had invested and transferred know-how, capital and technology. But China threw up barriers, including "harmful rules" on export performance, local content and technology transfer and equity requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF SAYS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH WILL REACH 4.9% IN 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Angel Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will likely reach 4.9 percent in 1998, the third highest of 28 developed countries, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Monday.
Behind only Ireland with 9.1 percent growth and Iceland's 5 percent, Taiwan outperformed all other Asian countries, the IMF's World Economic Outlook report noted.

The economic growth rate of developing economies in Asia reached an average 2.6 percent in 1998, a record-low since World War II. However, Asia's developing economies are expected to rebound next year with a 4.3 percent growth rate.

Taiwan recorded the highest economic growth rate, lowest unemployment rate and most stable inflation rate among the four Asian tiger economies, the IMF report said. Singapore's economic growth reached only 0.7 percent, Hong Kong's was -5 percent and South Korea's was -7 percent.
According to the fund, Taiwan will see a lower economic growth rate of 3.9 percent, a higher inflation rate of 2 percent and a lower unemployment rate of 2.4 percent in 1999.
The IMF estimates are in contrast to the Taiwan's own higher predictions of 5.07 percent economic growth rate in 1998 and 5.24 percent in 1999.

Meanwhile, the IMF said mainland China had contributed to stabilize Asia's economies with its economic growth estimated at 7.2 percent for 1998 and 6.6 percent in 1999. Inflation rates in 1998 and 1999 are forecasted at -0.8 percent and 2 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MISERY INDEX THIRD LOWEST WORLDWIDE: IMF

TEXT.P: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) rated Taiwan the third least "painful" economies among 100 worldwide, the fund said in its twice-yearly World Economic Outlook Report released on Monday.

Taiwan's misery index in 1998 reached 4.2 percent, behind only Singapore's 3.6 percent and Switzerland's 4 percent. The misery index refers to a combination of inflation and unemployment rates of an economy. As the cost of living and joblessness increase, the more difficult or "painful" one's life is.
Taiwan's consumer price index dropped from a preliminary estimation of 2 percent to 1.5 percent, while its unemployment rate rose slightly from 2.6 percent to 2.7 percent.

Maintaining stable market prices and a low unemployment rate is the hardest task for any government in the world to achieve as these two counteract each other, according to John M. Keynes' economic theory.

Before 1980, Taiwan's misery index reached double-digit figures and did not fall until 1982. The IMF said Taiwan's low index in 1998 can be attributed to a reduction in imported goods prices which benefits deflation.
Meanwhile, among economies whose misery index falls under 5 percent, Taiwan had the highest economic growth rate of 4.9 percent, illustrating the complete structure of Taiwan's economy.
Japan, which has enjoyed a low misery index for many years, saw its index rise last year to 4.1 percent and again to 4.6 percent this year.
With its rising unemployment rate and negative growth in gross domestic product, the IMF predicted that Japan's recession-mired economy will not rebound for quite some time.

Spain was ranked the most painful country in Europe with a misery index over 20 percent. Some economists put it down to the social welfare scheme that pays unemployment compensation to the jobless which causes a lack of willingness to work.

The misery index for the United States fell to a 27-year record low of 6.1 percent, which the IMF noted was one of the Clinton administration's most pronounced political achievements. The index once reached 17 percent during the Carter administration. (by Herman Pan and Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOLDS SEMINAR ON ELECTRONIC SIGNATURES

TEXT.P: The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) of the Executive Yuan held on Tuesday a seminar on digital signatures and certification in hopes of the eventual passage of legislation that would help to protect the mushrooming number of electronic documents in Taiwan.

Three representatives from the US state of Utah, where the first digital signature act was signed into law, attended the forum to offer suggestions. In all some 200 representatives of Taiwan's industrial, academic and government sectors took part in the meeting.

Lee A. Hollaar, a professor of computer science at the University of Utah, said Utah passed its act in 1995, which made it the first in the world to protect electronic business through the recognition of legitimate digital signatures. Seven US states and five countries, including the governments and banking and finance sectors of Malaysia and Singapore, as well as Japan's intellectual property sector, visited Utah to learn about the state's act, he said.
Digital signatures protect documents by ensuring their authenticity and establishing the identity of the authors of the documents, said Hollaar.

RDEC officials said that a digital signature act is being drafted, while a public hearing on the importance and specifics of the technology is also being prepared. The draft is expected to be presented to the Legislative Yuan for approval by February of 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.006 against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, closing at 32.253.
The local currency opened at the day high of 32.246 and had a low of 32.269.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$252 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO ACTIVELY PROMOTE TRADE

TEXT.P: In a move to actively promote trade, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will target Turkey, Japan, Mexico, and central and eastern Europe in its trade development efforts next year.

CETRA Chairman Lin Cheng-kuo said on Tuesday that to break down regional economic barriers, CETRA is planning to target strategic or core nations in certain economic blocks and to pool together all its resources to help Taiwan manufacturers gain footholds in those regions.
Lin said that in Japan alone, CETRA will launch 77 trade promotion activities next year, and expects to increase exports to the country to as much as US$850 million.

CETRA is also looking to promote exports of machine tools, plastic machines and metal products to Turkey. Between September and the end of this year, at least 15 groups will have gone to Turkey to promote trade between the two countries.

In addition, CETRA will mobilize six trade groups to Mexico, and will cooperate with the Mexican trade Services in Taipei and Latin American trade development council to organize groups to inspect the investment environment in Mexico next March or April so as to help Taiwan businessmen to make inroads into the zone covered by the North America Free Trade Agreement.
CETRA will also help Taiwan's information technology, textile, and bicycle industries to make inroads into central and eastern European markets.
CETRA has stepped up its international trade promotion activities after Taiwan's foreign trade was affected by the world's economic turbulence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANK HSIEH NAMES KAOHSIUNG DEPUTY MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor-elect Frank Hsieh on Tuesday named Lee Teng-mu, a veteran real estate developer, as one of his deputy mayors.
Lee, 63, was formerly honorary chairman of the Kaohsiung City Business Council, director of the Rotary Club and national president of the Junior Chamber.

He is currently president of the Baihsing Construction Company, Royal Lee's Hotel and Lee's Hotel in Kaohsiung. He is also a noted antique and art collector. Lee is currently abroad on business, according to one of his employees, who added that Lee was a surprising choice for deputy mayor as he has always been indifferent to politics. Hsieh said while his choice for a second deputy mayor has not yet been decided, he would select someone from the current administration as the candidate should possess a civil servant certification and be familiar with the city's administration. (By Angel Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE HAS YET TO DECIDE WHETHER TO MEET WEI

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has yet to decide whether to meet with Wei Jingsheng, the most prominent exiled mainland Chinese dissident who is currently on a nine-day visit to Taiwan, a Presidential Office official said on Tuesday.
The official was responding to a newspaper report that President Lee has ruled out the possibility of meeting with Wei during his stay in Taiwan.
"The report was premature," said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The official said President Lee's working schedule for this week has long been arranged. "As Lee was busy stumping for candidates in the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang in the past few months, many of his activities have been postponed to this week."
The official went on to say that President Lee will decide in the next few days whether to meet Wei.
President Lee has so far not met with any visiting mainland Chinese dissident due in part to avoid provoking Beijing authorities.

Many local observers, however, have been calling on President Lee, who is dubbed by Western media as "Mr. Democracy" for his achievements in leading Taiwan's democratization, to meet Wei to signify the Republic of China's firm support for democracy.

Wei, who was released from a Chinese prison last year after spending much of the last 18 years in a cell for championing democracy in mainland China, paid a visit to Taiwan's legislature on the second day of his first trip to this island.
Wei, 48, lauded local legislators for their contribution to the island's democracy by replacing once-notorious fistfighting and brawls with serious debate.
Wei said mainland authorities had used pandemonium at the island's parliament as proof that democracy could not take hold in a Chinese society.
However, Wei said he found that Taiwan's democracy has since matured. "And I think even brawls are much better than a closed society where you could not express your views freely.
According to Wei, more mainland Chinese people have come to understand that the unanimous votes being taken at the mainland's parliament -- the National People's Congress -- are false.

Wei said Taiwan's democratic experience is highly treasurable because its democratization was voluntarily developed, adding he believes that mainland China has much to learn from Taiwan in its democratic development.

From his talks with local politicians of different party affiliation, Wei said he found that Taiwan's democratic development has fully matured. "Despite their different views and stances on various policy issues, they can respect each other and coordinate among themselves in working out feasible action plans," he noted.
While here, Wei, currently living in exile in the United States, will take part in a Christmas Eve seminar, exchanging views with local scholars on freedom, democracy, and human rights.
National Taiwan University is to present Wei with an honorary doctorate, to be followed by Wei's speech on how he has strived to bring democracy to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES AND FUTURES SKYROCKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices skyrocketed on Tuesday, prompted by strong government support for the market and by overnight gains on Wall Street.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's (TAIEX) weighted price index, the key barometer of the market, surged 224.4 points, finishing at the day's high of 6,782.68.
A total of 22.77 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$88.5 billion (US$2.75 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 406 to 56, with 32 stocks unchanged.
All eight major stock categories posted gains, with electronic engineering issues rising the most at 5.5 percent.

Textile shares climbed 3.4 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks, which moved up 3.1 percent; paper-making issues, 3 percent; foodstuff stocks, 2.5 percent; cement shares, 2.4 percent; construction issues, 2 percent; and financial stocks, 1.7 percent.
The over-the-counter market climbed 4.9 points, closing at 170.8, with a turnover of NT$4.53 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures all posted big gains.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January rose 235 points up to close at 6,940, with 4,617 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for February surged 239 points, finishing at 6,948, with 133 contract transactions, while those for March moved up 238 points to 6,920, those for June rose 232 points to 6,850 and those for September gained 140 points, closing at 6,890.
Transactions for the three months totaled 100, two and five, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 6,705 points for January; 6,709 for February; 6,682 for March; 6,618 for June; and 6,750 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS:
WORLD'S SHORTEST WOMAN CELEBRATES WINTER SOLSTICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The world's shortest woman, Madge Bester, got together Tuesday with two of Taiwan's shortest women at the Guinness World of Record Museum in Taichung.

Bester, along with Taiwan's Tsai Mei-ling and Tsai Shu-hui, rolled balls of glutinous rice (Tang Yuan) in celebration of the traditional Chinese festival marking the winter solstice, which is scheduled on Dec. 22 this year.

This is the second visit to Taiwan for Bester, a South African national. She was invited by the museum's president, Dai Sheng-Yih. Dai and the three women made a variety of rice balls in the shapes of turtles, birds, flowers and cats. The balls were stuffed with such fillings as beef, chocolate, chicken and salad, and onlookers applauded the group for their efforts.
The museum prepared rice balls for some 60 children studying at an area kindergarten.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN POLICE BREAK HUMAN SMUGGLING RING

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait human smuggling ring was broken by police on Tuesday who nabbed two stowaways from mainland China, one snakehead, and one outlaw from Taiwan trying to board a Taiwan-bound plane on offshore Kinmen island.

Police said Chang Yung-hsiang, a 27-year-old snakehead from the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien, Chen Lichun, 28, and Li Yixing, 27, both from mainland China, as well as Lee Ming-teh, 27, a Taiwan resident wanted by police who went into hiding in the mainland, were detained by police at Kinmen airport for possession of forged national identification cards which they showed to security officers before boarding the Far East Air flight.

The four men were turned over to the Kinmen District Prosecutors' Office on charges of document forgery and violation of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, police said.

An initial police investigation showed that Chang was hired by a man surnamed Yen to smuggle the other three men from Kinmen to Taiwan to work and visit relatives here. According to police, Chen, Li and Lee paid 50,000, 90,000 and 12,000 renminbi, respectively, to snakeheads in mainland China in a bid to enter Taiwan.

The ring is the second human smuggling ring smashed by Kinmen police in a month, and the fact that no Kinmen natives were involved in either case indicates that human smugglers on both sides are already very familiar with smuggling routes across the Taiwan Strait, police authorities said.

As the number of mainland Chinese people attempting to enter Taiwan with forged documents has increased noticeably in recent months, police said they will strengthen inspection and security measures at harbors and airports across Taiwan to crack down on smuggling and illegal immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA ASKS CAMBODIA TO PROVIDE DETAILS ABOUT ALLEGED TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) sent a letter to the Cambodian government on Tuesday asking it to provide a comprehensive report on a Taiwan firm's export of possibly toxic waste to Cambodia.

The agency said it has never received any official notice or report from Cambodian authorities concerning the shipment of allegedly toxic waste to the Indochinese country by Taiwan's Formosa Plastic Group (FPG).
All information about the controversial shipment has so far come from foreign wire service reports, the agency said, adding that action was impossible without fuller details of the incident.
"We are willing to assist in the inquiry to determine where the responsibility lies," the Cabinet-level agency said in its letter.

EPA officials said neither the Republic of China nor Cambodia is a signatory to the multilateral Basal Convention. "Against this background, neither of the two countries is subject to the the Basal Convention which bans cross-border transfer of toxic waste," the officials said.
Nevertheless, the officials said the ROC is willing to fulfill its obligations as a responsible member of the international community.
If necessary, the officials said, the EPA will send a team to Cambodia to help assess the nature and toxicity of the waste, which was found dumped outside the port of Sihanoukville early this month.

The FPG, Taiwan's largest petrochemical group, has acknowledged being the source of the 3,000 tons of waste. The group stressed that it was certified in Taiwan as safe for landfill disposal and that the shipment to Cambodia was conducted completely legally.

"We had legally acquired an import permit from the Cambodian government before exporting the industrial waste to that country," an FPG executive said, adding that the mercury residues in the waste met the internationally sanctioned standards.
The FPG executive also insisted that the waste was not toxic as claimed by Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.
Meanwhile, a group of environmental activists and television reporters left for Cambodia on Tuesday to collect first-hand information about the controversial waste shipment.
The ROC does not maintain diplomatic ties with Cambodia.
ROC's Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu on Monday refuted Hun Sen's allegation that Taiwan is a "pollution" exporting country.

"It is irrational for the Cambodian government to make such an allegation before it makes any investigation into the waste shipment incident," Wu said, adding that Hun Sen should not have played up the incident purely based on unconfirmed reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR-ELECT ANNOUNCES NEW 'SMALL CABINET'

TEXT.P: Taipei mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday announced members of his city government's staff, who will be sworn in, along with Ma, on Dec. 25.
Of his new staff, three are social activists who will head the departments of civil affairs, labor affairs and public employee training, Ma said during a press conference.

Ma said his aministration will be a constructive and practical government that will demonstrate service-oriented teamwork. The average age of those in his team is 48, and nine of them hold doctorates.
Six of the members who will head some of the 33 agencies under Ma's direct jurisdiction will be women, according to Ma.

Ou Chin-der, chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission, was appointed by Ma as his political deputy mayor, while Pai Hsiu-hsiung, current administrative deputy mayor, will be retained.
Chen Yu-chang, an Executive Yuan counselor, was named secretary-general of Ma's city government administration.

Liu Pao-kuei (female), who is currently deputy director of the Taipei Bureau of Education, was appointed deputy secretary-general of the city administration, while current deputy secretary-general Hsieh Wei-tsai will be retained as well.
Lin Cheng-hsiu, an urban reformist, was named director of the Bureau of Civil Affairs.
Lee Shu-teh, commissioner of the National Tax Administration of Kaohsiung City, was appointed director of the Bureau of Finance.
Huang Jung-feng, director of the Kaohsiung Bureau of Reconstruction, was named director of the Taipei Bureau of Business Management.
Lee Hung-chi, an associate professor at Chinese Culture University, was named director of the Taipei Bureau of Public Works.
Tsao Shou-min, a civil engineering professor at National Taiwan University, was named director of the Bureau of Transportation.
Hsieh Hsiu-fen (female), a sociology professor at Soochow University, was named director of the Bureau of Social Affairs.
Cheng Tsun-chi, a business management lecturer with Fu Jen University, was named head of the Bureau of Labor Affairs.
Wang Chin-wang, currently director of the Taipei City Police Headquarters, will be retained.
Yeh Chin-chuan, a public health professor with the Tzu Chi College of Medicine, was named head of the Bureau of Health.
Shen Shih-hung, international cooperation director under the Cabinet-level National Science Council, was named to head the Bureau of Environmental Protection.
Chen Wei-jen, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan Provincial Government prior to its downsizing, was named to head the Bureau of Urban Development.
Chang Po-chin, deputy director-general of the Fire Administration, was named director of the Taipei Fire Department.

Other appointments include those of Soong Ching-chuan as director of the Department of Land Administration; Kuo Yao-chi (female) as director of the Department of Public Housing; Wu Huei-mei (female) as director of the Department of Information; Huang Yun-sheng as director of the Department of Military Service; Shih Su-mei as director of the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The head of the Bureau of Education, however, has not yet been selected, Ma noted.
The appointments must be approved by the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang, of which Ma is a member.
Ma won an overwhelming victory on Dec. 5 over incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who is a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC TO COOPERATE WITH AIR ASIA IN PLANE REPAIR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) and the private Air Asia Company Limited are to forge a bilateral cooperation agreement in the field of airplane maintenance and repair.
The two local companies will sign a memorandum on the cooperation on Wednesday in Taipei, witnessed by Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming.

The cooperation agreement is part of government efforts to build an Asia-Pacific aircraft manufacture and repair center in Taiwan, and is also aimed at avoiding "duplicate investments" among domestic enterprises in the aeronautic sector, according to the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).

The agreement will cover various fields, such as the development of new aircraft for military and commercial use, the repair, maintenance and alteration of airplanes and related systems, and the exchange of personnel, equipment and technology, the IDB said.

AIDC, an enterprise under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, originated from the former military-run Aero-Industry Development Center which built the locally designed Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF).

The Taichung-based AIDC is also undertaking the manufacture of commercial aircraft in conjunction with world leaders in aircraft manufacture such as McDonnell Douglas. The AIDC has produced more than 600 aircraft to date.

Air Asia Company Limited, founded in 1946 in the southern city of Tainan, is Taiwan's oldest professional aircraft repair and maintenance factory. It provides services to most of the island's domestic and foreign commercial air carriers, as well as government and military institutions.

The company has official airplane maintenance and repair certification issued by the United States, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, the Czech Republic, and Russia. It is also authorized by Boeing and Bell aircraft makers as their plane repair and maintenance provider in the Asia-Pacific area.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TAIPEI MAYORAL VICTORY TOPS LIST OF DOMESTIC NEWS STORIES IN 1998

TEXT.P: The victory of Ma Ying-jeou, the former justice minister who beat incumbent Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian in the Dec. 5 Taipei mayoral election, is the top local news event of 1998.
The list of the top ten news stories, chosen by chief editors, senior writers, and other Republic of China media executives, including the CNA, is as follows:

1. The ruling Kuomintang scored big gains in the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections, in which Ma Ying-jeou, the KMT candidate, defeated Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the second Taipei mayoral race.

2. After nearly three years of hiatus, Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, held a meeting in Shanghai, paving the way for further exchanges.

3. The Legislative Yuan approved a set of temporary regulations governing the readjustment of the functions, administration and the organization of the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG). Under the regulations, various agencies under the TPG will be maintained until June 1999.

4. On Feb. 16, a China Airlines flight from the Indonesian island of Bali carrying 196 passengers and crew crashed just outside Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. Everyone aboard, and six people on the ground, were killed, including Y.D. Sheu, governor of the Central Bank of China.
5. Seventy-two local people, mostly children and babies, lost their lives in an enterovirus epidemic.

6. Lin Feng-cheng, minister of transportation and communication, and Tuan Chi, chairman of Taiwan High Speed Rail Consortium, signed an agreement on the construction of the high speed railway which is scheduled to begin in the spring of 1999 and to be completed in 2003.

7. Angered by the Taichung County Government's reluctance to issue relevant documents, Germany's Bayer Company decided to terminate an investment project worth NT$50 billion in central Taiwan's Taichung harbor.

8. The Ministry of Education announced on May 1 the abolishment of the join entrance examination for the enrollment of high school and other secondary school students, starting from the 2001 academic year. Enrollment of students will change to a basic test of scholastic ability for national secondary education.

9. Career criminal Chen Chin-Hsing, one of a gang which kidnapped and murdered Pai Hsiao-yen, the daughter of a noted local actress, was sentenced to five death penalties by the Panchiao district court.

10. The ST-1 satellite, Taiwan's first commercial telecommunications satellite, which was launched on Aug. 26 and moved into its final orbital position over the Indian Ocean on Sept. 7, began commercial operations on Dec. 1 to improve the island's telecommunications systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO FURTHER SUPPRESS PUBLICATION

TEXT.P: Newly-interpreted provisions of criminal law that limit freedom of publication in mainland China will come into force Wednesday, according to a report in Chinese language by the Xinhua News Agency in Beijing.

The provisions, which were interpreted in early December by the Supreme People's Court, stipulate that people who publish, print, duplicate, circulate, or spread messages that advocate national separatism, undermine national unification, instigate the subversion of state power, or agitate for the abolition of socialist systems may be convicted of "splitting the nation, or instigating the subversion of state power."

The report was made by the mouthpiece of the mainland Chinese government after dissidents Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai, and Qin Yongmin were sentenced to 13, 12, and 11 years in prison respectively earlier this week for their efforts to establish the first opposition party in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL CHANGE IN MAINLAND CHINA LONG OVERDUE, SAYS PAPER

TEXT.P: The evident brittleness of mainland China's reforms should be a warning that political change is overdue, an Asian Wall Street Journal editorial said on Tuesday.

The 20th anniversary of the "reform and opening" era, which was celebrated in mainland China last Friday, serves as a useful reminder that as long as the question of political reform remains unsolved, the legacy of Deng Xiaoping and his successors remains uncertain, the editorial said.
President Jiang Zemin, in a recent televised speech marking the anniversary, promised that "his country would never build Western-style democracy," according to the newspaper.

Once again "stability" is the watchword in the mainland Chinese official press, while dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai were sentenced to 13 years and 11 years, respectively, in prison for "subverting the government."
Xu and Wang are being punished in order to frighten increasingly outspoken advocates of political reform and multiparty democracy into silence, the editorial pointed out.

Jiang, according to the paper, didn't let down his hair and cover himself in glory by striking more jubilant notes in his speech. Instead, his notes conveyed an impression of a tough political line, as well as a slowdown in reform in order to avoid aggravating a growing unemployment problem.

He doesn't want to raise expectations of greater liberalization, the paper noted. As the central government grapples with problems of sluggish foreign investment and exports, combined with horrifying inefficiency in the state sector, it has chosen to switch tack, it continued.
It went on to say that after 20 years of economic reform, mainland China's political climate is still mercurial, as the long prison sentences for the democrats show.

True, the peaks and troughs of the political cycle are less stomach-churning since Deng secured the future of his economic reforms by scoring a decisive victory over party conservatives in the early 1990s. But these swings are still an anachronism in a world where change is increasingly driven by the free flow of ideas, rather than the whims of elderly leaders who rose to power in secret factional struggles, the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NOMINATES CANDIDATES FOR TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL SPEAKERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang on Tuesday announced its candidates for the speaker of Taipei City Council, and the speaker and deputy speaker of Kaohsiung City Council.

Wu Pi-chu, incumbent Taipei City Council deputy speaker, will run for the speakership of the city council on the KMT ticket, while Huang Chi-chun, currently Kaohsiung City councilman, and Wang Chih-hsiung, incumbent legislator, will vie for the top two posts of the city council of southern Taiwan's largest city.
After being sworn in on Friday, the newly elected members of the two city councils will cast votes to elect speakers and deputy speakers.

KMT Secretary General John Chang said that the ruling party has decided not to nominate a candidate for deputy speaker of Taipei, as the KMT controls only 23 of the 52 seats in the new council, making it essential that the party cooperate with the opposition party in the election of speaker and deputy speaker.
The ruling party controls 24 out of the 44 Kaohsiung City Council seats.

Chang said that before making the announcement, he met with Chen Cheng-chung, an incumbent KMT councilman who has made known his strong desire to seek the KMT nomination for Taipei speaker, and told him the party's decision.
Chen later told the press that he would throw his support behind any KMT candidate in order to ensure victory for the party.

Questioned as to why the KMT nominated Huang, who reportedly quit the party years ago, for the Kaohsiung speakership, Chang said that Huang, who joined the KMT in 1978, is actually a party member "at large" and has regained his party certification since being reelected to the council.
He said that he will also urge Chu An-hsing and Chang Jui-teh, two others who had vied vigorously for the post of Kaohsiung speaker, to follow the party's decision.
The KMT Central Standing Committee is expected to approve the nominations at its weekly meeting on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER, PRESIDENT PRAISE PERFORMANCE OF ROC ASIAN GAMES ATHLETES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday praised the performance of the Republic of China's athletes who took part in the 13th Asian Games which closed on Sunday.

Describing the athletes as ambassadors of sport, Siew said it is cooperation among athletes that enables the ROC to give sound performances and make many international friends. He said he hoped that they will strive to win more medals in future Asian Games.
Five hundred and eighty-nine ROC athletes competed in 30 events at the games, garnering a total of 77 medals -- 19 golds, 17 silvers, and 41 bronzes -- the largest number ever won by an ROC team.

Siew made his remarks at a reception held at Taipei Guest House to entertain the athletes. Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Chairman Nancy Chao of the Cabinet-level Sports Commission, honorary member Henry Hsu of the International Olympic Committee, and other dignitaries also attended to extend their congratulations.
The reception ended at 1:30 p.m. and the athletes proceeded to the Presidential Office to attend a tea party hosted by President Lee Teng-hui.

Lee commended the outstanding performance of the athletes and expressed the hope that the various branches of the sports sector will strengthen cooperation in order to strive for greater glories, and create a new era for the nation's sports development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR AWARDS 100 MILLIONTH MASS RAPID TRANSIT PASSENGER

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday awarded the 100 millionth user of Taipei's mass rapid transit (MRT) system with a set of gold and silver commemorative coins.

Chen was making what will probably be his last MRT trip as mayor of Taiwan's largest city. He was defeated by Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang in the Dec. 5 elections, and will withdraw from the administration on Friday.

At the Taipei train station, the main MRT station, the outgoing mayor who presided over the opening of the Tamshui line in March 1997, said he never dreamed that the number of MRT users would pass the 100 million mark so soon.
The record is "the greatest gift that the citizens have given me and all the members of my administrative team," Chen said.
Promotion of the MRT system has been Chen's key strategy in his efforts to improve the city's atrocious traffic conditions.
Taipei currently has two MRT lines, running to the suburbs of Tamshui and Mucha, with further lines to Chungho and Hsintien scheduled to be inaugurated in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS CHAIRMAN OF INTERCHANGE ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday described the Republic of China's economic development as a process of "seeking progress with stability," saying that his government "will never do anything that is unrealistic."

Progress built on economic pragmatism is Taiwan's motto in its pursuit of sustainable growth, Lee told Reijiro Hattori, chairman of Japan's Interchange Association, during a brief meeting at the Presidential Office.

Lee said the world has become a borderless global village with democracy as the mainstream system of rule. In addition to striving to bolster its economic development and political reform, Taiwan hopes to contribute more to the world as a member of this global village, he noted.

Hattori for his part said he notices further evidence of Taiwan's progress every time he visits the country. He said he was particularly impressed that Taiwan has managed to sustain its substantial economic growth in the face of the Asian financial turmoil which has battered most of the economies in the region.
He attributed this to the island's solid economic prowess and correct government policies, which he said are worth emulation by other countries around the world.
Hattori, accompanied by Toshio Goto, president of the Interchange Association, is leading a Japanese delegation at the 23rd Taiwan-Japan Economic and Trade Convention taking place in Taipei.
The Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan, was established to represent Japanese interests here after the ROC and Japan severed formal diplomatic relations in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang nominated Wu Pi-chu and Huang Chi-chuan to run for the speakerships of the Taipei and Kaohsiung City Councils, respectively.
The China Times:
Taiwan will stop purchasing additional Stinger missiles.
The United Daily News:
The KMT named Wu Pi-chu and Huang Chi-chuan to seek speakerships of the Taipei and Kaohsiung City Councils, respectively.
The Liberty Times:
The Stock Market Stabilization Fund purchased shares, intending to drive the weighted price index to the 7,000-point level.
The Independence Morning Post:
The local bourse staged a major rally on Tuesday as the market stabilization fund actively bought blue-chip electronics stocks.
The Commons Daily:
The KMT announced its candidates for speakerships of the Taipei and Kaohsiung City Councils.
The China Post:
IMF cites five key risks to global economy in '99.
The China News:
Taiwan's stock index jumped 224.4 points on Tuesday; government fund purchases drive market up.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEEK MFI OBSERVER STATUS, AS MAI TALKS SUSPENDED

TEXT.P: Taiwan will seek to join consultations held under the Multilateral Framework of Investment (MFI), a new working arm of the World Trade Organization (WTO), an official with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

The move comes after the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) announced earlier this month that talks regarding the OECD-proposed Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI), which Taiwan had sought to join as an observer, would be suspended indefinitely.

Lin Neng-chung, director-general of the MOEA Industrial Development and Investment Center, made the announcement that Taiwan's efforts to join the MAI, initiated in 1996 and touted as an agreement that would open doors around the world for investors, were likewise being suspended.

Taiwan has since 1996 strived to become an observer within the MAI, hoping that by joining the group, Taiwan would solicit more foreign investment and gain protection for its overseas investments, as well as for its business and trade interests abroad, Lin noted.

By signing the MAI, Taiwan would directly declare itself a liberalized and global economy, which is conducive to attracting more foreign investment. That would accelerate the adjustment of its domestic economic structure and raise Taiwan's international competitiveness, Lin added.
According to the latest United Nations World Investment Atlas, as of the end of 1996, Taiwan is the world's 17th-largest capital source in terms of overseas investments.
If Taiwan were to join the MAI, local businessmen with investments abroad could use the agreement's international arbitration body to settle international disputes, Lin said.
Taiwan would also be entitled to treatment equal to those of other signatory members.
Talks on the MAI's formation have lagged as major OECD member states have been divided on some key points.
Some economies said the goals set under the agreement are too high, while some countries are skeptical of its function, accusing it of being a "political and corporate orgy" for big businesses.
After suspending MAI talks, the OECD proposed that MAI signatories continue the international program under the MFI.

While countries that have joined the MAI are now MFI members, several countries, which were MAI observers, are expected to become MFI observers. Such countries include Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Slovakia, Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES TV STATIONS NOT TO PLAY UP JUVENILE CRIME

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday urged local television stations to refrain from giving sensational reports on juvenile criminal activities for the sake of common well-being of domestic youths.

Lee made the appeal in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang after listening to a report on the promotion of youth voluntary services. The report was delivered by Lee Chi-chu, chairperson of the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC), at a weekly KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.
The president said young people are prone to imitate what they see on TV. "Many juvenile delinquents or criminals have learned criminal actions from TV programs," he noted.

Lee said he hopes local TV stations will report more positive sides of society, including youth voluntary services and healthy recreational programs, while avoiding playing up juvenile delinquency problems.

"This is not an order, but my sincere request," Lee said, adding he is hopeful that local TV stations will produce more educational, sensible and meaningful programs catering to the needs and tastes of adolescents to help curb juvenile crime.
Lee went on to say that he is delighted to learn that the NYC has launched a series of programs to promote youth voluntary services.
"The NYC's efforts to create an environment suitable for young students to join varied, diversified social services are worthy of our government's recognition and commendation," the president said.
Lee also urged relevant KMT and government agencies to coordinate and cooperate with the NYC in recruiting young volunteers to join various social services at home and abroad.

"Expanded youth voluntary services will not only help broaden young people's vision but will also facilitate spiritual reforms," Lee said, adding that encouraging young people to join overseas voluntary services will also help promote international friendship and cooperation and upgrade the Republic of China's national image.

Juvenile delinquency and crime have become increasingly rampant in local society. Many have blamed excessive media reports on criminal activities or the dark side of society for rising youth crime rate here. The trend has prompted President Lee to call on local media, particularly television operators, to refrain from showing shocking crime scenes or giving graphic accounts of criminal episodes.
