DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 23, or the fifth day of the 11th month in year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: Andrew Jackson halts British forces at New Orleans.
1832: French troops take Antwerp, forcing Holland to recognize the independence of Belgium.
1888: Vincent van Gogh, Dutch post-impressionist painter whose works included "The Potato Eaters" and "Starry Night," cuts off his earlobe in a fit of madness. His long struggle with depression ended in suicide.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen meets in Kweilin, Kwangsi province, with Marin, a representative of the Comintern (Communist International), to discuss such issues as cooperation with Russia. The Comintern, which was established in 1919 by V.I. Lenin, founder of the Communist Party in Russia, helped Outer Mongolia set up a Communist government in the early 1920s.
1922: German statesman Helmut Schmidt, former chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is born.
1933, Akihito, emperor of Japan, is born.
1934: Chen Sao-pai, one of an early supporters of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in the Chinese revolution, dies in Peiping (Beijing) at the age of 66.
1941: US forces on Wake Island in Pacific surrender to Japan in World War II.
1948: Japanese Prime Minister Hideki Tojo and six other Japanese leaders are hanged in Tokyo as World War II war criminals.
1957: The Control Yuan impeaches Premier Yu Hung-chun for transgressions and negligence of duty.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter-high Tokyo Tower is completed.
1972: An earthquake strikes Managua, Nicaragua, killing 10,000.
1972: Elections for members to the National Assembly, the Legislative Yuan and the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, as well as elections for mayors and country magistrates, are held in Taiwan, Kinmen, and Matsu.
1974: The first test-flight of the United States' B-1 bomber is successful.
1986: The US aircraft Voyager lands in the Mojave desert in California after becoming first aircraft to circumnavigate the globe nonstop without refueling.
1986: Dr. Andrei Sakarov, the Soviet dissident and physicist who was released on Dec. 19 from the closed city of Gorka, returns to Moscow with his wife Yelena Bonner.
1989: The Romanian army announces the capture of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena, both of whom fled Bucharest on Dec. 22.
1996: The five-day National Development Conference begins. Discussion focuses on three major topics: enhancing constitutional systems of government and multiparty politics; economic development; and cross-strait relations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not know how men get along without good faith. A cart without a yoke and a carriage without a harness, how could they go?"

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL SWISSAIR CRASH VICTIMS IDENTIFIED

TEXT.P: All 229 crew members and passengers aboard Swissair flight 111, which crashed off Nova Scotia on Sept. 2, have been identified, Canadian police said Tuesday.
Investigators used X-rays, DNA, fingerprints and dental work to identify the 229 victims.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) told a news conference that dragging operations under the ocean will continue as authorities search for airplane debris, body parts, cash and a container of diamonds.
The RCMP recommended to the Canadian Transportation Safety Board that flight crews provide samples for DNA identification in the event of similar crashes in the future.
A spokesman for the RCMP said the cash they are looking for totals more than US$1 million and is in US funds. Much of the money was newly circulated money that was part of a bank transfer.

The RCMP reported that some precious gems have been found, but did not estimate their value. The RCMP, working with the Canadian Coast Guard, has patrolled the search area, which has been designated a restricted zone.
The total cost for the search operations so far is C$3.1 million (US$2 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN NAVY REFUSES TO ACCEPT NEW SUBMARINE

TEXT.P: The Australian Royal Navy has refused to take delivery of the third of six Collins-class submarines it planned to purchase from Australian Submarine Corp. (ASC) because of problems in the first two submarines delivered.
The navy has a US$3.2 billion plan to buy six of the submarines from the Adelaide-based company as it seeks to bolster its ability to defend Australia's sea lanes.

Since taking delivery of the two submarines, however, the navy has discovered a string of difficulties. The navy wants ASC to solve the problems before it accepts delivery of the third submarine, according to The Australian on Wednesday.

The daily quoted Eoin Asker, head of the submarine project at the navy, as saying, "It's unfair to put it all on the ASC's foot, but having said that we want to focus their attention on further improving the boat."
Defence Minister John Moore last month demanded an urgent report from the navy on "what the faults are and how we are going to fix them," the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN SHOULD RETAIN KAOHSIUNG BRANCH: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: The service center set up by the Executive Yuan in the southern port city of Kaohsiung has performed well and therefore should not be abolished, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang said on Wednesday.

On the contrary said Chiang, who also doubles as head of the Executive Yuan's service center in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, the establishment should further expand its services to the public as it has served southern Taiwan residents well over the past six months.

Referring to criticism by outgoing Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih and an editorial by the Liberty Times that the Executive Yuan should close the office as it has become no more than an inefficient "complaint center" which does not fall in line with the central government's plan to streamline its administration, Chiang said he felt disappointed and sad to hear the comments after he put so much effort into the center.

Saying that his CEPD duties in Taipei made him too busy, Chiang said he has already expressed his intention to quit the Kaohsiung post to Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, and voiced the hope that another government official will take over.

Explaining that the Executive Yuan Kaohsiung service center is only in charge of coordinating local affairs in southern Taiwan rather than being a policy-making government agency, the CEPD head said that many things passing through the center must still be approved by the relevant government authorities in Taipei, which "requires time and must go through due process."

Stressing that the center has functioned well since its opening six months ago, Chiang pointed out that the eight-floor establishment is planning to rent two additional floors to expand its services to the public. Some other government agencies, including the Fair Trade Commission under the Executive Yuan, are also planning to open their southern branches within the center, he continued.

According to Chiang, the service center has received a total of 20,017 passport applications over the past month alone, four times the previous average level. In addition, it also handled 38,620 entry and exit cases, 5,694 cases of international trade affairs and 6,279 cases of personnel affairs, he added.
Meanwhile, ranking Executive Yuan officials said they were unaware of Chiang's intention to quit, but added that in any case, Premier Vincent Siew will not approve the resignation.

Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen hailed Chiang's performance and the opening of the government's Kaohsiung service center, saying that it has helped the Taipei-based central government to better serve Taiwan's southern residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CONDEMNS BEIJING'S TREATMENT OF DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: Australia has joined in the global condemnation of mainland China's treatment of political dissidents after a mainland Chinese court sentenced a third democracy activist to a long jail term on Tuesday.

Qin Yongmin, 43, was sentenced to 12 years in prison after being found guilty by the Wuhan Intermediate People's Court of subversion for his involvement in setting up mainland China's first opposition political party since the Communists took power in 1949.
Two of Qin's colleagues in the China Democracy Party -- Xu Wenli, 55, and Wang Youcai, 33 -- were imprisoned for 13 and 11 years, respectively, on Monday.
Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Tuesday condemned the sentences and ordered Australia's embassy in Beijing to lodge a protest, according to a Beijing dispatch of The Australian daily.

The daily quoted a spokesman for Downer as saying: "The government is deeply concerned about the severity of the sentences handed down over the past week in the trials of Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin. We are raising our concerns about these latest developments with the Chinese government."

The daily also quoted an official at the Australian Embassy in Beijing as saying, "We will express our deep concern about the campaign against these individuals, who have simply been expressing, in the most peaceful manner, their own political beliefs."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SAYS 18 FOREIGN COMPANIES SET TO INVEST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday that 18 foreign companies are set to invest a total of NT$28.4 billion (US$876.5 million) in Taiwan.

The foreign companies from the United States, the Netherlands, Japan, Australia, France, and Switzerland will invest in a variety of industries, including semiconductors, telecommunications, vacuum pumps, frozen foods, shopping malls, engineering plastics, photo-electronics, compact disks, and biotechnology, said the MOEA.
In addition to the 18 companies, IBM is to embark on a joint venture with Taiwan's Pacific Electric Wire & Cable Company in a deal worth NT$48 billion (US$1.48 billion), the MOEA added.

The ministry said that main task of its Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) in 1999 will be to invite more foreign companies from North America and the European Union to invest in Taiwan. IDIC officials noted that the center will continue to promote cross-border strategic cooperation in the aerospace, semiconductor and biotechnology industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA THREATENS TO RETALIATE OVER RICE TRADE WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: Australia has threatened to retaliate if Japan imposes a proposed 390-percent tariff on Australian rice imports.
Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer on Tuesday told reporters that the 390-percent tariff represented a "bamboo curtain with some pretty spiky bamboo."
He said Japan risked sparking a trade war by its decision to impose such a high tariff.
"This is about 15 times higher than the highest tariff applied by Australia to any of our imports from Japan or elsewhere," Fischer said.
Japan is Australia's No. 1 trading partner.
Fischer said it would be wrong for Australia to abandon free trade and impose new high tariffs on Japanese goods.
Instead, he said, Australia would study its trade with Japan and seek to find other ways of retaliating.
Fischer said the Japanese tariff on Australian rice would simply block Australian rice exports from entering the Japanese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTS THREATEN EU FARM REFORM PLANS

TEXT.P: The cost of European Union (EU) plans to reform farm policy could be higher than predicted and could put "the whole reform at risk", the European Court of Auditor, the EU's financial watchdog, said in a report to be published this month.
The Court of Auditor's opinion that the European Commission may be underestimating reform costs will increase pressure for limits to EU spending at an EU summit meeting in Vienna.
Farm spending accounts for nearly half the EU's annual budget of ECU$85 billion. The planned reforms will initially raise costs, but will reduce the cost of the Common Agricultural Policy over time.

The court takes the Commission to task for farm reform proposals that contain "few innovations and are not sufficiently wide-ranging." It is critical of Commission assumptions about world prices and demand for agricultural products, which it believes may be overly optimistic. It suggests wealthy farmers are receiving too much support and overall spending should be cut.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 TRADE SURPLUS MAY HIT NEW LOW, SAYS FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall trade surplus is expected to total about US$7 billion in 1998, a 14-year low, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Wednesday.
The island's exports totaled US$6.44 billion in the first 19 days of December, down 15.7 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports amounted to US$5.83 billion, down 23.3 percent.
As a result, Taiwan had a trade surplus of US$611 million in the Dec. 1-19 period, said Hsu Kuo-tung, director of the MOF's Department of Statistics.

Hsu estimated that Taiwan's overall annual trade surplus may diminish to a record low of US$7 billion this year, as export trade in the last quarter, usually the peak season for exports, continues to decline.
Hsu quoted MOF tallies as showing that daily exports averaged US$444 million in the first half of December, compared with the average US$475 million posted in November.

Although the decline in December's exports have aroused close attention by domestic economy watchers, Hsu said it is too early to say that inflation has set in. The picture of Taiwan's real economic performance in 1998 will not be clear until March or April of next year, he noted.

In the first half of December, Hsu said, the decline was more apparent in exports of electrical engineering and machinery products, while he attributed the decline in import trade during the period to a reduction of military supplies and crude oil imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES HIGH MARKS ON MOODY'S SOVEREIGN DEBT RATING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Tuesday scored a rating of Aa3 on the "sovereign ceiling for foreign currency debt" by the New York-based Moody's Investors Service, proof of the island's brilliant economic performance.
It was Moody's first sovereign debt rating for Taiwan, and the Aa3 rating represents a very high mark.
Commenting on the result, Vincent Truglia, in charge of Moody's rating affairs on sovereign risk, said that the island's strong export performance is the engine which pushes its economic growth.

Taiwan's foreign trade has never been thwarted by its political difficulties, and it remains one of the world's major trading economies, despite the small number of countries which grant Taipei political recognition, Truglia said.

Due to its positive efforts in promoting economic growth, Taiwan has been able to maintain the value of its currency, even as the currencies of its Asia-Pacific neighbors have tumbled because of the Asian financial crisis.

Truglia praised Taiwan enterprises' contributions to the island's economic growth, but warned of an impending impact as international demand declines, the country's neighboring competitors become stronger, and domestic demand also falls.
Truglia also reminded the Taiwan authorities to pay close attention to the high-risk loans being made by local banks, and their problems with expanding credit.

Making a forecast on Taiwan's long-term economic development, Truglia further said that he believes the issue of how Taiwan deals with its relations with mainland China is an unpredictable factor which will play a key role on its financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY APPROVES SINGAPORE BANK'S REQUEST TO SET UP BRANCH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has approved a request by Singapore's Keppel Tat Lee Bank to set up a representative office in Taipei, said MOF officials on Wednesday.

According to the Bureau of Monetary Affairs, the bank started to operate in 1990 under the name Keppel. Among banks worldwide Keppel was No. 307 in terms of self-owned capital and No. 506 in terms of assets. The bank's risk asset ratio reached 14.82 percent in 1997.
The current Keppel Tat Lee Bank is the result of a merger between Keppel Bank and Tat Lee Bank. With total assets of US$18.94 billion, it is the fifth-largest bank in Singapore.
In 1995 Tat Lee bank was given permission to establish an office in Taipei.

The Bureau of Monetary Affairs indicated the merger between the two Singaporean banks will be effective starting Dec. 26. Keppel Tat Lee Bank will take oer the office established by Tat Lee Bank in Taipei in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALARY INCREASES DROP TO RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: The economic slowdown has affected the growth of salaries in the private sector, causing a drop to 3.28 percent in the first 10 months of 1998, a record low in Taiwan's history, the government reported on Wednesday.

In the Jan.-Oct. period, average total monthly salaries in the private sector stood at NT$40,322 (US$1,252), up 3.28 percent over the year-earlier level, while basic monthly salaries averaged NT$32,028 (US$995), up 3.31 percent, officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) said.
The average salary growth in the first 10 months of 1998 was a record low since the DGBAS began to calculate the ratio between wages and productivity 25 years ago, the officials said.
The officials estimated that annual salary growth for the whole of 1998 will also post a record low, as a result of the economic sluggishness.

In October, employees in Taiwan's private sector received an average total monthly salary of NT$35,551 (US$1,104), up 1.75 percent over October 1997, while basic monthly salaries averaged NT$32,253 (US$1,001), up 2.5 percent from the same month of the previous year, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC, AIR ASIA SIGN COOPERATION MEMORANDUM TO EXPLORE MAINTENANCE MARKET

TEXT.P: The state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) and the private Air Asia Company on Wednesday signed a maintenance cooperation memorandum to jointly explore the domestic and international aircraft maintenance market.
The cooperation plan is part of a government bid to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific aircraft manufacture and maintenance center.

The memorandum was signed by AIDC General Manager Hu Chin and his Air Asia counterpart Chen Iou-ming . The signing was witnessed by Kao Yi-hsing, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council.

AIDC specializes in aircraft maintenance and related work, while Air Asia has long been Taiwan's biggest player in the domestic maintenance market. Working together, the two companies will be able to avoid a resource-wasting overlap of services, the AIDC said, adding that integrating Taiwan's aerospace maintenance companies is the key to building an Asia-Pacific aircraft maintenance center.
Air Asia focuses on aircraft, engine, engine accessories and component maintenance, and has certification from nine countries around the world, including the United States.
The company is also the exclusive regional maintenance provider for the Boeing and Bell aircraft companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN; FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices declined on Wednesday due to heavy profit-taking by investors anxious to make a profit in the wake of the government's move to boost stock trading, according to dealers.
They added that this shows that the government needs to take greater efforts to build investor confidence.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, lost 94.03 points to close at 6,688.65. A day earlier, the bourse had posted a 3.4 percent gain.
A total of 1.86 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.28 billion (US$2.18 billion), down from the previous session's NT$88.5 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 315 to 111, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.
All eight major stock categories fell, with plastic and chemical issues plunging the most, at 2.4 percent.

Textile shares dropped 2 percent, followed by financial stocks, which declined 1.9 percent; paper-making issues, 1.6 percent; both cement and foodstuff shares, 1.1 percent; electronic engineering stocks, 1 percent; and construction issues, 0.9 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a 1.68-point decline, closing at 169.12, with turnover reaching NT$3.27 billion.
Meanwhile, trading on stock index futures was mixed, with both losses and gains registered.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January slumped 105 points, closing at 6,835, with 3,868 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for February dropped 78 points to 6,870, with 151 transactions, while those for March fell 97 points to 6,823, those for June rose 70 points to 6,850, and those for September fell 70 points to 6,820.
Contract transactions for the three months registered 70, five, and two, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 6,940 points for January, 6,948 points for February, 6,920 points for March, 6,780 points for June, and 6,890 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC HINTS AT POSSIBILITY OF FURTHER INTEREST CUT

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will hold its last board meeting of 1998 on Thursday, leaving room for a possible interest cut.
It is also expected to release postal savings as funds for capital-thirsty small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), bank officials said.
The decisions made at the board meeting will play a critical role in Taiwan's economic and financial markets in 1999, so the meeting has attracted widespread attention, according to the officials.
The CBC is expected to exercise an eased credit policy and release a greater amount of money to bail out enterprises struggling in the mire of the current recession.

Several hundred billion new Taiwan dollars have already been released as bailout projects to SMEs, in the form of low-interest loans for the purchase of machinery, loans for technological investment, and favorable-rate loans for the purchase of automation equipment.

The CBC is also expected to earmark another NT$30 billion for loans for first-time home buyers and other housing projects. This plan will also be presented to the board meeting for approval, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST 1999 VOLUNTEER CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will host a regional conference of the International Association for Volunteer Effort (IAVE) next year, the National Youth Commission (NYC) said on Wednesday.
NYC Chairman Lee Ching-chu said that the hosting of the conference shows that a local campaign to promote volunteer work and concern for society have won recognition from the international community.
She also said that volunteer service is one of the most important functions of the NYC, and deserves further promotion and development in Taiwan.
The conference will be held in Taipei in November 1999, and will be attended by IAVE officials from its Washington, D.C. headquarters, and representatives from the Asia-Pacific region.

Lee, who went to the Canadian city of Edmonton to attend an IAVE meeting this August, has been actively bidding for Taiwan to host the regional conference, and her efforts beat out Hong Kong, India, and South Korea for the right to host the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG TO STUDY FEASIBILITY OF RETRIEVING WASTE FROM CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said on Wednesday it has demanded Formosa Plastic Group (FPG) try its best to retrieve alleged toxic waste from Cambodia.
"The petrochemical giant has agreed to evaluate the feasibility of taking back the controversial industrial waste that the FPG shipped to Cambodia earlier this year," said an EPA official.

The official said no matter whether reports of the waste-related deaths in Cambodia were true or not, the incident has tarnished the Republic of China's international image and marred the FPG's business reputation.

"Therefore, the EPA has asked the FPG to recall the alleged toxic waste from Cambodia," the official said, adding the EPA is hopeful that the Cambodian government will assist in cleaning up the waste and take other necessary steps to facilitate the return of the waste to Taiwan.

FPG executives said as the waste shipment to Cambodia was handled by a shipping company and customs brokerages in both countries, the company itself was not aware how the waste was disposed of in Cambodia.
"Against this background, we need make a comprehensive evaluation of the planned retrieval of the waste, including the content, quantity and shipping process," an FPG executive was quoted as saying.

The executive reiterated that the 2,700 tons of waste the FPG shipped to Cambodia was certified in Taiwan as safe for landfill disposal and that the shipment to Cambodia was conducted completely legally.

"We had legally acquired an import permit from the Cambodian government before exporting the industrial waste to that country," the FPG executive said, adding that the mercury residues in the waste met the internationally sanctioned standards.
Nevertheless, the executive said, if the Cambodian government demands, the FPG is willing to take back the controversial waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER JOBLESSNESS AT SINGLE-MONTH HIGH SINCE 1985

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment hit 2.93 percent in November, the highest single-month level since 1985, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Wednesday.

The figure translated into a total of 282,000 jobless workers across Taiwan, 86,000 of whom were out of work as a result of business closures or streamlining. Some 85,000 workers left their workplaces citing inadequate working conditions, while 26,000 temporary workers lost their jobs because of expiring contracts, according to the DGBAS.

Meanwhile, the number of first-time job seekers dropped to 64,000 in November from previous levels of more than 70,000, while the number of self-employed workers had amounted to around 130,000 since May, the DGBAS added.

In terms of education levels, the DGBAS said unemployed people with a high school education posted the largest growth last month, while in terms of age groups, those aged between 15 and 24 registered the most noticeable rise in unemployment.
There were a total of 9.338 million workers across Taiwan in November, up 38,000 from October, and an increase of 63,000 compared with the same month of last year, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SENDS MEMORANDUM TO CAMBODIA OVER WASTE INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has sent a memorandum to Cambodia expressing its intention to cooperate with the Indochinese country in handling an alleged toxic waste incident, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.
Hu told a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is very concerned about a local petrochemical group's export of possibly toxic waste to Cambodia.
"The ministry has instructed the ROC's representative office in Ho Chi Minh City in neighboring Vietnam to send a memorandum to the Cambodian government over the waste incident," Hu said.

The memorandum contained three key points, Hu said. "First of all, we tell the Cambodian government that it should discuss things related to Taiwan with the ROC government through official channels because the ROC is an independent sovereign state."
Secondly, Hu said, the memorandum stressed that it needs further investigations to determine whether the waste shipped by Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to Cambodia is toxic or not.
"Thirdly, we stressed that the incident was a completely isolated case and that the ROC has consistently opposed shipment of toxic substances to other countries," Hu said.
The minister went on to say that MOFA and the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) have launched a joint inquiry to determine where the responsibility lies.

"We want to know whether local governments have illegally approved the shipment of toxic waste to other countries as well as whether the procedures for the FPG's waste shipment to Cambodia were completely legal," Hu said, adding that the EPA is also probing whether any Taiwan nationals have colluded with Cambodians in illegally shipping the FPG's waste to the Indochinese country.
Hu said the ministry has so far not obtained any data concerning the death of Cambodians related to the FPG's allegedly toxic waste.
Hu said it is regretful that the incident has been "politicized." "It remains unclear whether the FPG's waste is lethal or not and how serious the damage caused by the waste is," he noted.

The incident came to the limelight earlier this week after Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen claimed in Phnom Penh prior to his departure for a visit to Beijing that the FPG's waste poses great health threat to Cambodian people and several residents in the vicinity of the garbage dump in the coastal resort Sihanoukville might have died because of touch on the toxic waste.

Cambodian authorities have so far not served the ROC any official notice or report concerning the toxic waste. Cambodia diplomatically recognizes Beijing and is not friendly toward Taiwan. Hun Sen forced the ROC to close its representative office in Phnom Penh last year.
ROC's Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu on Monday refuted Hun Sen's allegation that Taiwan is a "pollution" exporting country.

"It is irrational for the Cambodian government to make such an allegation before it makes any investigation into the waste shipment incident," Wu said, adding that Hun Sen should not have played up the incident purely based on unconfirmed reports.
Meanwhile, at the EPA request, the FPG said Wednesday it will evaluate the feasibility of retrieving the controversial industrial waste it shipped to Cambodia in November.

FPG executives said as the waste shipment to Cambodia was handled by a shipping company and customs brokerages in both countries, the company itself was not aware how the waste was disposed of in Cambodia.
"So we need make a comprehensive evaluation of the planned retrieval of the waste, including the content, quantity and shipping process," an FPG executive was quoted as saying.

The executive reiterated that the 2,700 tons of waste the FPG shipped to Cambodia was certified in Taiwan as safe for landfill disposal and that the shipment to Cambodia was conducted completely legally.

"We had legally acquired an import permit from the Cambodian government before exporting the industrial waste to that country," the FPG executive said, adding that the mercury residues in the waste met the internationally sanctioned standards.
Nevertheless, the executive said, if the Cambodian government demands, the FPG is willing to take back the controversial waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: GM TO SET UP ITS OWN CAR DEALERSHIP IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Chinese Automobile Company (CAC) and General Motors (GM) Taiwan branch announced on Wednesday that GM has set up its own car dealership network in Taiwan, and the entire operation will be operational by April 1999.

GM made the announcement in the wake of CAC's severe financial problems, said GM representative, who added that CAC can still opt to buy the new company's stock. CAC was formerly the distributor for GM vehicles.

GM's Taiwan branch representative said the new dealership network, GM AutoWorld, will include 54 showrooms and 61 repair and maintenance facilities which formerly belonged to CAC. GM will establish an additional branch in Taipei to monitor the network, the representative added.

However, GM and CAC will not reach consensus on whether or not GM will buy or rent CAC's assembly lines in Taiwan until mid January of 1999, CAC's general manager Chang Che-wei said, adding that CAC intends to buy some 30 to 40 percent of AutoWorld's stock.

Chang Chi-cheng, who has been with GM for four years, will be responsible for the sales network in Asia and the establishment of a quality network system, as well as an operation team for the Asian market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS HITS AUSTRALIAN MINERAL INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has hit the mineral and oil industry in Australia significantly as spending on exploration fell in the third quarter of 1998, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

The ABS figures showed mineral exploration in Australia dropped by 23 percent in the third quarter of 1998 from the peak recorded in the second quarter of 1997. It also fell about 5 percent to US$144 million in seasonally adjusted terms in the third quarter.
Petroleum exploration also took a hit from the Asian crisis as spending plunged 42 percent from the second quarter to about US$121 million, according to the bureau.
Industry sources said the decline in exploration spending was due to weakening demand from foreign importers.
Australia is a major producer and exporter of minerals and oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: PURCHASE OF US MISSILES NOT SUSPENDED: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's defense minister on Wednesday refuted media reports that the military would cancel its order of US-made Stinger surface-to-air missiles.
Chiang Chung-ling, speaking at the legislature, said the order will go ahead as planned, but whether there would be follow-up purchases would depend on the military's requirements.
A local newspaper had reported that Taiwan would cut back its purchases of Stinger missiles from 220 to less than 30.
Legislators voiced concern that such move would seriously affect the defense capability of the island which is believed to be particularly vulnerable to missile assaults by mainland China.
Beijing has not renounced the possibility of using force in achieving its goal of reunification with Taiwan which broke away from the mainland in the 1949 civil war.

Chiang said it has been the military's consistent policy to give priority to weapon systems which can be developed and produced domestically. For this reason, the Chungshan Institute of Technology and Science was established, he added.

The defense minister said the air force has ordered the locally-produced Sky Sword surface-to-air missiles from the military-run institute, stressing that the military has developed a similar air defense system to that of the United States.
The China Times daily also said in its Wednesday edition that the US missile purchase cut was aimed at saving funds ahead of the island joining the US-proposed theater missile defense program (TMD).
Chiang insisted that the purchase of Stinger missiles and participating in the planned TMD system are two separate issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK DIPS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped slightly on the Taipei foreign exchange on Wednesday, falling NT$0.006 TO NT$32.247, despite rallying around the world following the end of the US-British bombing of Iraq.

The US currency opened at NT$32.251, and was traded between NT$32.245 and NT$32.255, extending a 15-day trend of fluctuating around the NT$32 mark, which had been declared a reasonable price by the Central Bank of China.
A total of US$148.5 million changed hands in Wednesday's trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN TO STEP UP SECURITY AHEAD OF NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: As smuggling and the entry of illegal immigrants through offshore Kinmen Island grows in the past month, authorities there have vowed to step up security measures before the new year.

Kinmen military and police reported that in the past month, they apprehended four illegal immigrants from the mainland, several locals who smuggled agricultural products from the mainland, and broke up a human smuggling ring.

Since the beginning of the year, Kinmen authorities have cracked 36 smuggling cases, nabbed 31 illegal immigrants from the mainland and five Kinmen residents who sneaked into the mainland, and broke three human smuggling rings as well a case of liquefied amphetamine smuggling from the mainland.

Kinmen magistrate Chen Yung-tsai said after he reported the situation to Premier Vincent Siew late last month, National Police Administration Director General Ting Yuan-chin promised to establish a marine police base in Kinmen as soon as possible to protect its shores from smuggling operations and other criminal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO ADJUST OVERSEAS OFFICES

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will adjust its operations overseas in a bid to further explore foreign markets and collect the latest trade information for Taiwan businesses.

The semiofficial trade-promotion organization will open or close some of its 38 offices in 28 countries next year as part of the efforts to streamline its overseas operations, CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo said on Wednesday.

According to Lin, CETRA will open a Taiwan Trade Center in Asuncion of Paraguay and San Pedro Sula in Honduras in January. It will downgrade its official offices in Vietnam, Lagos, Caracas and Lisbon before the end of this year but CETRA officials will remain to address trade concerns there.
While CETRA will not open official offices in Kiev, Bucharest, Colombo and San Jose in California, it will send officials to these locations and offer trade services to Taiwan businessmen, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: THIS IS TO REPLACE ITEM 20. TKS
DOC.TEXT:
The Republic of China will host a regional conference of the International Association for Volunteer Efforts (IAVE) next year, the National Youth Commission (NYC) said on Wednesday.
NYC Chairperson Lee Chi-chu said that the hosting of the conference shows that a local campaign to promote volunteer work and concern for society have won recognition from the international community.
She also said that volunteer service is one of the most important functions of the NYC, and deserves further promotion and development in Taiwan.
The conference will be held in Taipei in November 1999, and will be attended by IAVE officials from its Washington, D.C. headquarters, and representatives from the Asia-Pacific region.
Lee, who went to the Canadian city of Edmonton to attend an IAVE meeting this August, has been actively bidding for Taiwan to host the regional conference, and her efforts beat out Hong Kong, India, and South Korea for the right to host the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA, TAIPOWER DENY NUCLEAR WASTE DEAL WITH MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has never touched on the nuclear waste disposal issue in the process of negotiating the establishment of diplomatic ties with the Marshall Islands, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.
"We have also not discussed the nuclear waste issue after forging official ties with the central Pacific island nation," Hu told a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

The minister was responding to a newspaper report that the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) has struck a preliminary deal with the Marshall Islands on the shipment of its low-grade radioactive waste to that country for permanent disposal.
Hu said the report was not true, stressing that the Republic of China government has never had such a plan to ship nuclear waste to the Marshall Islands for storage.

"It is not our policy to encourage shipment of nuclear waste abroad for permanent disposal," Hu noted, adding that it is regretful that some people have purposely used the topic to sabotage the ROC's relations with the Marshall Islands.
The ROC established full diplomatic ties with the Marshall Islands in eastern Micronesia on Nov. 20, 1998.
Meanwhile, Taipower issued a press statement Wednesday afternoon, denying that the company will pay the Marshall Islands NT$3 billion (US$93.17 million) for disposing of its nuclear waste.
"The newspaper report that we have struck a deal with the Marshall Islands on the storage of our nuclear waste is completely unfounded," the statement said.
Taipower said no new development or progress in its overseas nuclear waste treatment plan.
The state monopoly said it has offered to give NT$3 billion in development funds to any domestic township or village that would provide it with a small piece of land for construction of nuclear dump.
"The newspaper might have misunderstood our offer to prospective local land suppliers," the statement said.
It went on to say that the ROC's Foreign Ministry has never consulted with Taipower on the nuclear waste storage problem before and after the ROC forged diplomatic ties with the Marshall Islands.

Taipower officials said the Marshall Islands once contacted Japan, South Korea and Taiwan over the possibility of cooperation in setting up a low-grade radioactive waste dump on its territory. However, the government of the Marshall Islands announced a halt to the plan in June 1997. "It remains unclear whether the Marshall Islands has decided to revive the program," said a Taipower official.

"Even if the Marshall Islands brings up the issue again, we must study the feasibility of the proposed cooperative plan from various viewpoints, including technology, cost and international political factors," the official said, adding that the reported agreement with the Marshall Islands is nonexistent at the moment.

Taipower has difficulties finding a new nuclear waste dump. It once forged an agreement with North Korea to ship up to 200,000 barrels of low-grade nuclear waste to that country for permanent disposal. The shipment, however, has so far not been materialized because of a combination of complicated factors, including strong opposition from South Korea and international environmental activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 PERCENT OF SINGAPORE'S AD AGENCIES EXPECTED TO FOLD

TEXT.P: Singapore's advertising industry is expected to see up to 10 percent of its agencies close over the next year, Leo Burnett Singapore's managing director said.
John Borzi estimated that the industry's client billings declined by between 10 percent and 40 percent this year.
The recession has already resulted in fee undercutting and layoffs in the fiercely competitive industry.

Singapore arguably has the highest number of ad agencies per capita in the world. The Association of Accredited Advertising Agents has about 80 members, of which about a quarter are international agencies.
Telecommunications is the top dollar spender in Singapore, accounting for about 7 percent of the total S$587 million spent on advertising in the first half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S CENTRAL BANKS AT ODDS WITH IMF

TEXT.P: Leading central banks are putting pressure on the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to water down proposals aimed at securing more transparency in monetary policymaking, the World Trade Organization (WTO) reported on Wednesday.
Their objections to an IMF draft code of conduct have promoted accusations that they are trying to rewrite the rules to suit themselves, the WTO report said.

IMF officials drafted the code in response to a call from the committee of finance ministers that oversees the fund. It is one of several international initiatives to improve the quality and transparency of economic policymaking.

Several leading central bankers have objected both to the code's content and the way it was drawn up. The IMF, in turn, is upset the central bankers are complaining about a process they were happy to sign up to in October's joint Group of Seven statement with finance ministers.

Officials said the code has been much more controversial than its fiscal policy counterpart, agreed this year. There was little disagreement about the scope for extra transparency in budgetary matters but the central banks are much more wary of transparency in monetary policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAC PROMISE TO AID OVERSEAS MAINLAND DISSIDENT GROUPS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Wednesday that he has not made any promise to aid overseas mainland Chinese dissident groups.
Chang made the statement after meeting with Wei Jingsheng, the most prominent exiled mainland Chinese dissident who arrived in Taipei on Monday for a nine-day visit.
"While meeting with Wei, I expressed my respect and admiration for his long-term dedication to Chinese people's freedom and basic human rights," Chang said.
The ROC's top mainland policy planner said he also encouraged Wei to continue his fight for mainland China's democratization to enable billions of mainland people to enjoy freedom and human rights.

Wei, who was released from a mainland Chinese prison last year after spending much of the last 18 years in a cell for championing democracy in mainland China, is currently living in the Untied States.

Chang said he welcomes Wei's visit to Taiwan. "I hope the visit will help Wei gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan's economic development, social reforms and political democratization in the past few decades."

Chang said he also exchanged views with Wei on a broad range of issues, including the current state and development of major overseas mainland dissident groups, the ROC's policy toward mainland China and the present relations across the Taiwan Strait.

During the talks, Chang said, Wei had mentioned the financial demand of overseas mainland dissident groups. "Nevertheless, I didn't make any promise on financial assistance for those groups," he added.

Wei himself said after delivering a speech at the Grand Hotel that he doesn't think that the Mainland Affairs Council would give any financial aid to overseas mainland dissident groups because the council is restricted by the ROC's budget regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC TELECOM FEES TO BE LOWERED

TEXT.P: Chung Hwa Telecommunication Corp. will lower its telecommunication fares in due time, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng said on Wednesday.
Lin made the announcement in a report on the fee structuring plan at the legislature's transportation and communications committee.

According to the plan, charges for local telephone calls will be changed from the current NT$1.7 per five minutes to NT$1.5 for the first two minutes, an additional NT$0.5 for each minute between 2 and 10 minutes, and NT$0.25 for each minute exceeding 10 minutes.
Monthly dues for telephone set renters will be raised to NT$90 from the current level of NT$50.
If enacted, the new local telephone fees for the first 30 minutes will be more expensive than the current level, but will be increasingly cheaper for calls exceeding 30 minutes.

Cellular phone charges will be lowered by 25 percent and will be charged on a per second basis instead of a per minute charge as is currently the case. For example, if a call is 1 minute and 30 seconds, the user will be charged for the real time used compared to the nearest minute.
Fares for domestic long-distance calls will be lowered by 17 percent, while international long-distance calls will be decreased by 8.6 percent.
The fares for directory assistance will be raised to NT$3 per call from the current NT$2.
The new pricing scheme has yet to be studied by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and has not been approved by the Cabinet. It may be implemented around Feb. 1, 1999.
Meanwhile, Minister Lin also indicated that Chung Hwa Telecom will improve the quality of telecommunications for cellular phones beginning with 090, 0937, 0932 and 0933 by the end of March 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILLIAM LI TO BE TAIWAN'S FIRST REPRESENTATIVE TO MACAU

TEXT.P: William Li, director of the Department of Hong Kong & Macau Affairs, will be the first representative of the Republic of China to Macau after the enclave reverts to Beijing's rule next year.

In an interview with CNA, Li confirmed reports that he will be the representative after the Portugal colony reverts to Beijing's rule on Dec. 20, 1999. He is due to travel to Macau next month and will temporarily act as the head 12 the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office.

He said Macau could make up for any deficiency in having Hong Kong as a conduit between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Li added that he was optimistic that Taiwan-Macau relations will surpass that of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations in the future.
The ROC's representative office in Macau is the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office, and falls under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
After the handover, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), following the pattern set by Hong Kong, will establish the Macau Affairs Bureau under the MAC with Li as its head.
Li said Taiwan has had long-standing close relations with Macau over the years. Some 900,000 Taiwan nationals visited Macau last year, the second most popular destination after Hong Kong.
Looking forward, Li said that he will make every effort to promote bilateral relations between Taiwan and Macau, and expand the level of exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS EXPECTED TO AFFECT AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY FOR 15 YEARS

TEXT.P: The effects of the Asian financial crisis will linger on in the Australian economy for at least 15 years, according to new long-term projections.
The projections by Monash University in Melbourne show that Australia's national income in 2010 will still be 0.2 percent below what it could have been if the Asian crisis had not happened.

On Wednesday, Prime Minister John Howard said the Australian economy in 1998-99 will be the best in three decades, despite the impact of the Asian economic crisis, although the Monash model shows the Asian crisis will see Australia's gross domestic product dip over the next year or so before economic growth reverts to its long-term trend of around 3.2 percent.

Australia is expected to experience continued strong growth in international trade, with export volume rising at an average annual rate of 5.8 percent and imports at 5.4 percent over the next 15 years, according to the Monash projections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HELP MAINLAND CHINA DEMOCRATIZE: WEI

TEXT.P: Taiwan should use its clout to push for democratization of mainland China to save itself and other neighboring Asian countries from a big disaster, a visiting mainland Chinese dissident said on Wednesday.
Wei Jingsheng, the most prominent exiled mainland dissident, said he admires Taiwan as the island has managed to complete democratization totally on its own.

"Nevertheless, Taiwan should not be complacent with its own democratization. It should use its influence to inspire mainland China to move toward democracy. If democracy cannot take roots in mainland China, it will spell a disaster to Taiwan and other neighboring Asian countries as well," asserted Wei, who is currently on a nine-day visit to the island.

Wei made the remarks in a Central Broadcasting System (CBS) talk show hosted by CBS Chairman Chu Wan-ching. Legislator Chang Chun-hung from Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party also took part in the program, which was simultaneously broadcast to mainland China and the international community.
In the program, Wei said the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be based on a sound foundation.

"The two sides must respect each other and treat each other on an equal footing. As long as the two sides have common interests, unification will benefit both sides," he noted, adding that at the moment, the two sides must increase mutual understanding through increased exchanges.
Wei further said as Taiwan is already an independent political entity, its relations with mainland China will certain remain tense, no matter whether it declares de jure independence or not.
Later in the day, Wei paid a visit to the Republic of China's Government Information Office (GIO).
Wei told GIO Director-General Chen Chien-jen that there should be amply room for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to cooperate because they share a common language and cultural backgrounds.
"I hope to work out some feasible cooperative programs with friends here during my first visit to this island," the outspoken mainland dissident said.

For his part, Chen said he admires Wei's courage to publicly advocate a "fifth modernization," -- namely democratization, shortly after the late mainland leader Deng Xiaoping unveiled an ambitious "four modernizations" program in late 1978.
Following his visit to the GIO, Wei also called at the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.
Wei exchanged views with MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh on a range of issues, including the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait and the development of overseas mainland dissident groups.

Meanwhile, Wei told local reporters after his MAC visit that he hopes to meet with Taiwan's top three political figures -- President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew -- during his stay here.
President Lee reportedly will meet with Wei in his capacity as chairman of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang at the KMT's headquarters next week.
On Wednesday evening, Wei was presented with two silver plaques "Human Rights Fighter" and "Democracy Vanguard" by two local freedom and democracy promotional groups.
Wei, who was released from a mainland Chinese prison last year after spending much of the past 18 years in a cell for championing democracy in mainland China, is now residing in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC TO ESTABLISH HUMANITIES AND SOCIAL SCIENCE CENTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) said on Wednesday that it will set up two research centers, for humanities and social science, respectively, by Feb. 10, 1999.

The NSC has long focused on the development of natural science, said Director of the NSC Humanities and Social Sciences Department Huang Zhong-tsun, citing the past establishment of research centers for physics, chemistry, mathematics, biology, engineering, earth sciences, theoretic science, and oceanography.
Huang noted that the establishment of the two research centers will form one of the NSC's millennium celebrations.

Huang also pointed out that Taiwan society has experienced significant changes in recent years, and that the number of local experts in humanities and social science is increasing. Now is therefore the best time to carry out thorough research in these two fields, he said.
The NSC has set up review committees for both research centers, and has invited scholars and administrative officials to begin preparations for their establishment.
The location of the two centers will be decided after review committees have evaluated applications submitted by research institutes interested in becoming involved in the scheme, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS: CNA WILL SUSPEND ITS CEP BROADCASTING SERVICE FOR
FLOODS TOP MAINLAND-RELATED STORIES OF 1998

TEXT.P: Floods caused by the overflow of major rivers which left over 3,000 people dead and over 230 million homeless in mainland China was the most important news event of the year in the mainland.
The list of the top 10 mainland-related news stories chosen by chief editors, senior writers and other media executives in the Republic of China, including CNA, is as follows:

1. Major rivers in central and northern China, including the Yangtze River, the Sungari River, and the Nenchiang River, overflowed their banks during the summer, causing widespread floods and leaving over 3,000 killed and more than 230 million people homeless. Economic losses were estimated at more than US$20 billion.
2. During a visit to Shanghai, US President Bill Clinton verbally and unofficially referred to the so-called "three-noes" policy with regard to Taiwan.

3. The first plenary session of the Ninth "National People's Congress" (NPC) and the first plenary session of the Ninth "Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference" (CPPCC) were held in Beijing. Zhu Rongji was approved as premier, succeeding Li Peng who was appointed chairman of the Standing Committee of the NPC, who replaced retiring Qiao Shi. Jiang Zemin was re-elected as president, while Li Ruihuan retained the post of CPPCC chairman.

4. Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), visited Shanghai and Beijing and met with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), for the first time after a nearly three-year hiatus. Koo also met with Jiang Zemin, president of mainland China.

5. Mainland China continued its isolationist strategy against the Republic of China in the international arena by establishing diplomatic ties with ROC's allies, including the Republic of South Africa, Central African Republic, the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, and the Kingdom of Tonga. Meanwhile, the ROC established diplomatic relations with the Marshall Islands.

6. Financial turmoil wrecked havoc on Asia. However, mainland President Jiang Zemin and other high-ranking Beijing officials reiterated many times that they would not devalue the renminbi within the year. However, a slowdown in export growth has made it very difficult for Beijing to reach its goal of 8 percent economic growth.

7. Jiang Zemin visited Japan and met with the Japanese emperor, and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi. Both sides expressed different views on such issues as Japan's apology over war atrocities, the inclusion of the Taiwan Strait in the new US-Japan defense guidelines, and the request for Tokyo to support the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan. The visit ended without the signing of a joint statement.
8. Hong Kong held its first legislature election, with voters electing 20 of its 60-member Legislative Council. The democratic faction gained an overwhelming victory in the race.

9. Public security authorities in mainland China arrested four Taiwanese businessmen -- Kou Chien-min, Han Yueh-ting, Chen Chao-yu and Chou Chang-ming -- on spying charges. A Beijing court later sentenced Kou to four years in prison while the other three were released and allowed to return to Taiwan.

10. Mainland authorities held a working meeting on Taiwan affairs to draft new guidelines on dealing with the island. Qian Qichen, deputy head of the Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs, pointed out that political negotiations between both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been submitted and scheduled for discussion, and that ARATS and SEF should widen their contact to promote consultations on procedures and a program for political negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TELEVISION STATIONS PROMISE TO CUT DOWN ON CRIME REPORTS

TEXT.P: Major local television stations have responded positively to calls by President Lee Teng-hui to reduce the number of crime stories they report.
Television executives said they would be more careful in reporting criminal activities and emphasize more positive stories on Taiwan.
President Lee urged local TV stations to refrain from airing sensational reports on criminal activities during a meeting on Wednesday morning.
Pai Shi-li of Taiwan Television Enterprise said the station has already started reporting on more positive stories about society since September.

Taiwan Television has attached great importance to events, individuals and groups that are newsworthy, Pai said. A recent series highlighted the needs of several families which received enthusiastic response from viewers, he added.

Pai said crime reporting is one kind of news and the company cannot ignore such stories, but Taiwan Television has adopted strict guidelines in showing crime scenes and the wording of reports on major crime stories.

Chen Hao, of the cable station TVBS, said his news department handles crime reports with great care. Instead of reporting on the results of the crimes, it emphasizes possible reasons behind such crimes so as not to unduly influence impressionable youths.

Chen said that in the next year, the TVBS news department will focus more on compassion, whether it is reports on young delinquents or minority groups. The company will step up investigative reporting teams or conduct in-depth reporting to provide a more full picture of events.
He stressed that some news reports are upsetting, but TVBS cannot avoid reporting on such events entirely because it is all part of the social phenomenon.

Lee Tai-ling of the Chinese Television System said he cannot agree with the president more. CTS has monitored the news reports of other electronic media and found that some reports on crime last for up to 30 minutes, he said.

He blamed those who were only concerned with achieving a high viewer rating and urged news media and viewers to shoulder some of the responsibility. News reporters must think beyond ratings while viewers must play the role of a watchdog, and voice objection to sensational news.

Tang Chien-ming of China Television Company (CTC) said CTC will be more selective about its crime reports in the future, saying that its evening news broadcasts now feature three positive reports on Taiwan each week.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES REVISES UPWARD PREDICTED LOSS

TEXT.P: After an air disaster earlier this year and several threatening epidemics, China Airlines (CAL) officials revised upward its forecasted losses from NT$900 million (US$30.43 million) to NT$2.85 billion on Wednesday.

At a news conference, CAL spokesman Yang Cheng attributed the poorer-than-expected performance down to the crash of a CAL Airbus-300 in Chiang Kai-Shek International Airport in February, the bird influenza which wreaked havoc in Hong Kong, the enterovirus which ravaged Taiwan, and the financial crisis which dogged Southeast Asian states.
CAL's passenger loads were down to an annual average of 69 percent of capacity compared to 72 percent in 1997, Yang said, adding that the crash seriously tainted the company's image.

However, the company's revenue from cargo traffic was expected to post an year-on-year increase of 10.4 percent. This is a result of a 10.2 percent increase in the "revenue tonne kilometers" rate which is more than offsetting the 4.6 percent decline in the volume of freight, said Yang.
"As a whole, the company's revenue is estimated to fall by 7.2 percent from a year earlier," the spokesman said.

He held bright prospects for 1999 after an alliance accord with Singapore Airlines takes effect in January. Under the pact, Singapore Airlines will take between 5 percent to 10 percent of CAL's stock and will likely take a seat on CAL's board of directors.
CAL hopes that Singapore Airlines' good safety record and management efficiency will rub off on the risk-prone Taiwan carrier, and boost its own image through the alliance, said Yang.

According to CAL's own estimation, the company will operate in the black next year on the strength of a 10 percent growth in transportation capacity, a 12 percent increase in transportation loads, and an 8 percent gain in revenue per kilometer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROCESS PASSPORT APPLICATION FROM CHARLIE TRIE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is fully aware of the application for an Republic of China passport by a Chinese-American charged in the United States for illegal fund-raising for the 1996 Clinton-Gore re-election campaign.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu told CNA on Wednesday that his ministry will adhere to the rules in reviewing the application of Yah Lin Charlie Trie, a former Taiwan resident who claimed that he has lost his ROC passport.
A US district court in Washington denied the demand from a US Justice Department attorney on Tuesday to jail Trie to prevent him from fleeing the United States.
The attorney told the court that Trie applied to obtain an ROC passport two week ago despite having surrendered his US and ROC passports.
Hu told CNA that Taiwan cannot deny issuing passports to its citizens, but an application based on false claims will certainly be rejected.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADERS TO DISCUSS PRO-INDEPENDENCE PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Factional leaders of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will meet Thursday to discuss matters relating to the amendment of its pro-independence platform.

The DPP incorporated Taiwan independence into its official platform several years ago, but many DPP candidates have tried to downplay the party's independence theme in recent elections in order to broaden voter support. In order to win the next presidential election some leaders of the party are talking about the amendment of the platform.

The people attending Thursday's meeting will elect members of the "Party Platform and Charter Studying and Amending Group" for further discussions on the matter. Members of the group will include legislators of the party as well as scholars in the financial, economic, social, legal, and political fields, an informed source said.

Leaders of the party's "Justice Alliance" have proposed to amend the platform, but leaders of another faction, the "Welfare State Alliance," have insisted that the party must uphold its pro-independence position, and said that the position has nothing to do with the party's loss in the elections of legislators and the mayor and city councilors of Taipei and Kaohsiung on Dec. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The central government will earmark NT$100 billion for corporate financing on a case-by-case basis.
The China Times:
President Lee Teng-hui agreed to set up a property market stabilization fund.
The United Daily News:
Pension payments under current insurance programs for government employees, laborers, farmers and military servicemen may be canceled.
The Liberty Times:
A special fund may be set up to help the recession-hit construction industry.
The Independence Morning Post:
President Lee Teng-hui promised to take various measures to help the troubled construction industry tide over their current difficulties.
The Commons Daily:
Unexpected developments emerged in the upcoming Kaohsiung City Council speakership election.
The China Post:
The immigration bill would achieve parity for aliens.
The China News:
Toxic waste cleanup, debate in Cambodia begin.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 24, or the sixth day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1508: London households receive piped water for the first time.
1798: Britain signs alliance with Russia against France.
1814: In Ghent, representatives of the United States and Britain sign a peace treaty, ending their state of war.
1851: Fires destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1871: The Italian Theater in Cairo stages the first performance of Giuseppe Verdi's opera "Aida."
1919: John Davidson Rockefeller, the American oil magnate who amassed great wealth through the Standard Oil Company, donates a record US$100 million for philanthropic works.
1921: Mohandas K. Ghandi, who became leader of the Indian National Congress in 1920, persuades the congress to adopt his program of "nonviolent disobedience" against the British.
1924: Germany's Leica company develops a high-tech mini-camera.
1937: Japanese forces capture the city of Hangchow in China.
1943: US President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower commander-in-chief of the invasion of Europe.
1945: Thomas Tien, bishop of Tsingtao, Shantung Province, in China, is appointed by Pope Pius XII as a cardinal, making him the first Asian cardinal bishop.
1951: King Idris I formally declares Libyan independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in the northwestern part of the mainland.
1976: The cabinet of Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda is formed.
1978: Noted local actor Ku Min-lun commits suicide by jumping from a high building.
1979: Some 80,000 Soviet troops invade Afghanistan to oust Communist Party leader Hafizullah Amin and replace him with the pro-Moscow Babrak Karmal.
1983: The Taipei Fine Arts Museum on Chungshan North Road is inaugurated.
1990: The China Democratic Socialist Party is granted permission to organize by the ROC Ministry of the Interior. The party was formally established on March 1, 1991, with Ju Gau-jeng as chairman.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev hands over Soviet nuclear codes to his former rival Boris Yeltsin.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius lesson of the day: "To worship a spirit to whom one is not bound by a real feeling of duty or respect is idolatry. To see what is right and to act against one's judgment shows a want of courage."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BLANKETED BY COLD WEATHER

TEXT.P: A blanket of cold air blowing east from mainland China is covering Taiwan as temperatures in Tamsui on Thursday morning dropped to as low as 15.2 degrees Celsius.
Meteorologists from the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) indicated that the cold air mass did not begin to hit Taiwan until Wednesday night.
Lower temperatures across the island are expected from Thursday to Monday, the CWB said, warning the public to be on guard against the colder weather.
Meanwhile, a strong northeaster brought gale-force winds and rough waves on the seas north of Taiwan, the CWB reported, warning vessels in the area to take precautions against expected storms.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT APPROVES 61 MAINLAND PRODUCTS FOR INDIRECT IMPORT

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has agreed to allow the indirect import of 61 additional items from the mainland to Taiwan in its latest review on opening the island's markets to mainland products.

BOFT reviewed 108 items suggested by local manufacturers and trade associations in a meeting on Wednesday. While members approved 61 items such as temporarily preserved agricultural products like tomatoes and asparagus, they rejected 33 items.
Board members deferred making a decision on certain items. These products included controversial agricultural goods such as green tea and black tea.

BOFT said it could not make a decision on the teas due to opposition from the Council of Agriculture (COA). The council argued that imported tea from the mainland would pose a serious threat to the already competitive domestic tea market.
During the meeting, the COA decided to continue to open the local market to mainland marble until Dec. 31, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100,000 PIRATED CD-ROMS SEIZED

TEXT.P: Police raided three locations in Chungli, Taoyuan County and seized 100,000 copies of pirated CD-ROM software on Wednesday in one of Taiwan's largest crackdowns on software piracy, Taoyuan police said.
The estimated street value of the pirated software was at about NT$100 million (US$3.1 million). The contraband included industrial and business software as well as pornography.

Police, acting under instructions of Taoyuan District Prosecutor Chang Shao-ping, conducted three pre-dawn raids simultaneously at three apartments in Chungli city, and busted a major source of pirated CD-ROMs and several CD-ROM publishers, the equipment used to copy the programs.
Chang said two men, identified as Liu Chien-hsin, 32, and Chang Li-min, 23, are believed to be the masterminds behind the piracy ring. The two had escaped capture during the raids.
According to Taoyuan police, they raided an apartment in Taipei County's Yungho city on Nov. 2 and seized 200,000 copies of counterfeit pornography CD-ROMs.
Meanwhile, the Anti-Counterfeiting Committee under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), has begun a new wave of anti-piracy activities as the end of the year approaches.
The New Year holiday is usually the peak season for sales of pirated software products around the island.

In a meeting on Thursday, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, who heads the Anti-Counterfeiting Committee, said a fresh round of anti-piracy actions will kick off anytime between now and the Lunar New Year holidays in mid-February to stem the spread of such illicit practices.
To make the crackdown more effective, Lin said, the MOEA has begun to promote the "identification of CD-ROMs" among local software manufacturers.

The committee has so far visited 42 leading local CD-ROM producers this year. It is promoting the practice of engraving identification marks on all CD-ROM products to help reduce the prevalence of counterfeit goods. This practice will help protect authentic products and save Taiwan's international image, Lin noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN CURRENCY DEPOSITS DECLINE TO SIX-MONTH LOW IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Outstanding foreign currency deposits at Taiwan's main financial institutions dropped to their lowest level in the past six months during the month of November, according to statistics released by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
Foreign exchange deposits fell to NT$643.5 billion (US$19.84 billion) at the end of November due to the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, CBC officials said.
Deposits will likely decrease further in December as the NT dollar is expected to continue to appreciate, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY DEVELOPS NEW TYPE OF TORPEDO

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy has successfully developed a new type of torpedo suitable for use in the Taiwan Strait to help safeguard Taiwan's security, military authorities said on Thursday.
The multipurpose torpedo was jointly developed by the Navy Logistics Command and the military-operated Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology.
"The Wan Hsiang (Panorama) I has become the most advanced standard torpedo used by our naval ships," said a naval officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

While the navy would not divulge any details concerning the design or function of the new weapon, the naval officer said the Wan Hsiang I torpedoes are designed to counter various types of mainland Chinese warships and submarines.

"They are also tailored to suit the special geographical features of the Taiwan Strait. They can be mined at varied depths and can be detonated by remote control based on magnetism and pressure," the officer explained, adding that the navy has no immediate plans to export the new torpedoes.
Meanwhile, the Navy Logistics Command has also received the ISO-9002 quality certification for its fuel, ammunition and equipment supplies management.
The Navy's equipment supply depot is the first military warehouse to receive the ISO-9002 quality control recognition.
An ISO-9002 certificate presentation ceremony was held Thursday at the command's headquarters at the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan.

Chen Tso-chen, director-general of the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine, said at the ceremony that he is impressed by the Navy's pursuit of quality in the ISO-9002 examination, auditing and certification process.
"We believe the Navy's efforts to upgrade logistic support quality will help beef up our country's naval defense capabilities," Chen said.

Navy Logistics Commander Kan Ke-chiang said logistic support forms an integral part of naval combat capability. "As the logistics command is responsible for repair and maintenance of various naval warships as well as fuel and ammunition supplies, it must standardize its management and operations to ensure service quality and prompt delivery and avoid hindering overall naval combat preparedness," Kan said, adding that this is the main reason behind the command's pursuit of ISO-9002 certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILL NOT DONATE CASH TO MAINLAND DEMOCRATIC CAUSES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng on Thursday categorically denied that the council is planning to make any cash donations to democratic activities on the Chinese mainland.

Sheu, spokesman and vice chairman of the nation's highest agency in charge of formulating government policies on mainland China, said all MAC expenditures are made in accordance with its approved budget which does not include funds for donations, and certainly no donations to mainland China.
Sheu was responding to reporters' questions over whether prominent mainland dissident Wei Jingshing, who is currently on a nine-day visit to Taiwan, will receive a cash donation from the MAC.

While the MAC budget allows for the financing of work with mainland China, it only contributes to efforts which accelerate cross-strait exchanges and negotiations, the two major tasks that the MAC is authorized to engage in at present, he added.
However, the MAC occasionally provides financial aid to private Taiwan organizations that sponsor activities aimed at accelerating exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Sheu noted.
The Chung-hua Development Fund, an MAC offshoot, is authorized to sponsor such financial aid programs, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CRACKDOWN DUBBED 'GREAT LEAP BACKWARD'

TEXT.P: Beijing's recent sentencing of three pro-democracy activists has put a dark shroud over flashes of a more open atmosphere in mainland China, the Los Angeles Times said in an editorial on Wednesday.

The message authorities there sent was clear -- organized opposition to the communist regime will not be tolerated, the paper said, after Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin were arrested, tried and sentenced for trying to register what they called the China Democracy Party.

Beijing's latest and harshest crackdown flies in the face of its signing of the UN International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which requires signatory nations to protect peaceful political expression and association. Beijing also committed to similar obligations under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Xu, Wang and Qin had promised authorities they would not challenge the Communist Party's ruling status or violate any laws, then embarked on registering their party in locals from the coastal province of Zhejiang to the inland industrial center of Wuhan.

After a mere three-hour trial, Xu, 55, a prominent dissident who served a 12-year prison term for his involvement in the Democracy Wall movement in the late 1970s, was sentenced to 13 years for "subversion of state power." Wang, 32, a leader in the 1989 Tiananmen protests, was sentenced to 11 years. Qin was sentenced to 12.

With these verdicts, Beijing has taken a major leap backward, the editorial said. Its attempt to divert criticism by releasing another dissident, Liu Nianchun, and exiling him to the US cannot expunge the regime's determination to erase the word "democracy" from "Chinese affairs". This course will cost Beijing."

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY FIGURE IN MILITARY SCANDAL DIES

TEXT.P: Maj. Gen. Wo Chi-kao, one of the key figures in a high-profile military graft scandal earlier this year, died in hospital due to liver complications early Thursday at the age of 51.

Wo, former director of the Engineering Department under the Combined Service Force (CSF), was detained after the scandal came to light early this year. In November, a military court sentenced him to four years in prison on bribery and bid-rigging charges in the construction of a military compound.
Because of Wo's high rank, the military court has automatically filed an appeal in the case.

After suffering from health problems, Wo's family applied for his release on bail on Dec. 3 so he could seek medical treatment. He died of acute fulminating hepatitis at Taipei Municipal Chung Hsing Hospital at 3:07 a.m.
The Ministry of National Defense said it will no longer pursue the case due to Wo's death.
The case first came to light on Jan. 16 when Wo's house in the southern city of Kaohsiung was firebombed and one of his subordinates Lee Cheng was beaten by unidentified gangsters.

Lee, fearful for his safety, suspected that the beating was a vendetta by bidders who failed to win a contract for an air force munitions bomb-shelter in Taitung County.
