He then asked military authorities for protection and confessed that his superior instructed him to rig the tender for bidding on Jan. 13 in favor of a certain bidder.
The scandal received wide report and raised calls for investigations into other possible graft in the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATORS SAID ACTIVE PLAYERS IN AUSTRALIAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Wealthy speculators such as George Soros are giving way to major US fund managers and banks with long-term investment decisions in influencing Australia's currency market, the Australian Financial Review reported on Thursday.

While Soros is still a major player in the foreign exchange market, US hedge funds are increasingly active and were behind the Australian dollar's plunge to its record low of 55.30 US cents on Aug. 28, the daily reported.
The record drop of the Australian dollar this year forced the Reserve Bank of Australia to intervene by selling billions of US dollars to prop up the Australian currency.
Large Australian companies were also among the active players in the Australian currency market.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S LIFE EXPECTANCY AMONG HIGHEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Australians enjoy one of the longest life expectancies in the world, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The ABS figures showed a boy born in Australia in 1997 can expect to live for 75.6 years and a baby girl can live 81.3 years, marginally lower than Japan's 76.4 years for men and 82.9 years for women.
However, Australian men aged from 20-69 who had never married had death rates two to four times higher than those who married.

The nationwide suicide rate, which is among the world's highest, was alarmingly steep among young Australians. In 1997, 510 suicides by men between 15-24 were reported, an increase of 25.3 percent from the 407 deaths by suicide in 1996, according to the ABS.

The victims of youth suicide continue to be predominantly men with the figures showing a national ratio of about 4.5 male deaths to every female death, the ABS says. There were 2,146 suicides recorded in 1997, an increase of 11 percent over the previous year.

The most common causes of death in Australia were heart disease which claimed 28 percent, followed by cancer with 27 percent. Accidents, including motor vehicle crashes, falls, drownings and suicides accounted for about 6 percent of the overall deaths, the ABS noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES OUTGOING MAYORS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday encouraged two outgoing mayors to continue to serve the country even after they step down.

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, both of whom will step down Friday, met with Lee at the Presidential Office. Also present at the meeting was presidential secretary-general Huang Kun-huei.
Both Chen and Wu reported to President Lee on various construction projects in their respective cities. President Lee inquired about the progress being made in major projects in each city.

The president was also concerned about the future career plans of the two outgoing mayors. Both replied that they need more time to think about the question and will report back to President Lee in due time.

Lee also said that although the country has made considerable progress in its democratic development, it still needs to work hard to become more mature and rational. Education and culture will be very important in achieving this goal, he said.

Lee stressed that the survival and development of the nation will be the ultimate goal, adding that the interests of the nation and the welfare of the public will come before the interests of parties and individuals.
The president encouraged the two to continue to serve the country to the best of their abilities.
Chen of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be replaced by Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), while Wu of the KMT will be replaced by Frank Hsieh of the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL MANUFACTURERS CONSERVATIVE OVER ECONOMIC OUTLOOK

TEXT.P: Local manufacturers were conservative in their outlook for Taiwan's economic prospects in the next six months, results of a business climate survey conducted by the Institute of Economic Research indicated on Thursday.

Only 9.8 percent of local manufacturers surveyed thought the economic conditions in November were "good," down from 14.9 percent in October. Over 47 percent viewed the conditions as "bad," up by 5.7 percent from October. Meanwhile, 42.4 percent thought the conditions were "moderate."

The survey also showed that output in November remained the same as the previous month but inventories were on the increase; the falling number of new orders led to a drop in the total amount of current orders; and prices for domestic and export goods shrank, resulting in a reduction on profit.
Worse yet is the belief among manufacturers that the situation will not improve in the next three months as costs are expected to soar while total sales will decline.
Meanwhile, despite the overall gloomy economic outlook, electronic consumer products are seen rebounding in the next six months, the survey noted.

Industries which are expected to remain moderate are food products, artificial fibers, steel, machinery, telecommunication facilities, textiles, plastic products, cement, wire, electric appliances, automobile and bicycle accessories and components, construction, retail and hospitality industries.
Continued difficulties will likely be seen in the garment, sophisticated machinery, porcelain and glass, nut processing and information technology industries, poll respondents said.

They also predicted that US economic growth will fall from 3.5 percent in 1998 to only 1 percent in 1999, while that in Europe will likely reach 2.5 percent and Japan's will rebound to 0.1 percent in 1999. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN, FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices slid 0.1 percent on Thursday as late profit-taking wiped out early gains ahead of the long weekend, analysts said.

The index posted gains early in the session on reports that the goal of a government stabilization fund was to push the weighted index above 7,000 points and that the central bank was set to inject funds to help local companies tide themselves over amid the current economic slowdown after the bank's board meeting Thursday afternoon.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index fell 5.65 points to 6,683, following a 1.4-percent drop in the previous session.
Volume was 2.01 billion shares worth NT$72.25 billion (US$2.24 billion), compared with NT$70.28 billion in the previous session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 154, with 90 unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the plastics sector posted the steepest losses and the construction sector enjoyed the largest gains.

The government through its stock market stabilization fund will aggressively intervene in the market, while the Central Bank of China will exercise an eased credit policy next year. Both actions will benefit Taiwan's rebounding economy and have a positive influence on the stock market, one dealer said.
The over-the-counter market declined 1.17 points, closing at 167.95, while turnover amounted to NT$3.14 billion.
Meanwhile, stock index futures finished the day higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January rose 5 points, closing at 6,840, with 3,721 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for February were up 9 points, closing at 6,879, with 125 contract transactions, while those for March climbed 27 points, closing at 6,860, with 64 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for June rose 128 points, closing at 6,803, with three contract transactions, and those for September were up 15 points, closing at 6,800, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALANDER COMES TO TAIWAN TO LOOK FOR MISSING SON

TEXT.P: The father of Reuben Philippe Tchernegovski, a young man from New Zealand who came to Taiwan in mid-November but has not contacted his family back home since he arrived, on Thursday met with local media and pleaded for help in finding his son.
The senior Tchernegovski, Phil, flew into Taipei Wednesday from the New Zealand capital of Auckland.

At a press conference held at the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei on the morning of Christmas eve, a teary-eyed Tchernegovski said his family has not heard from Reuben since he left home for Taiwan on Nov. 15.

Tchernegovski said his 23-year-old son, a student at a university in Auckland, told him that he intended to scale several mountains in Taiwan, including ones in Shueipah National Park in north-central Taiwan. Reuben was to return home before his birthday on Dec. 4, his father said.
Reuben's trip came amid his university's summer vacation.

Three of Reuben's classmates are from Taiwan, and his father speculated that Reuben may have attempted to contact them after his arrival. But it was learned Thursday that none of the three classmates had been contacted by Reuben.
According to National Police Administration (NPA) records, Reuben entered Taiwan through Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on the afternoon of Nov. 15.

NPA officials, to whom Tchernegovski turned for help, said there is no record of the cashing of US$1,000 in the traveler's checks held by Ruben, nor have any transactions been recorded on his ASB VISA credit card. Reuben also left home with US$1,200 in cash, Tchernegovski said.
Tchernegovski urged the NPA to authorize helicopter search missions to help find Reuben, an experienced and avid mountain climber.

Reuben, who stands 185 centimeters tall, weighs about 70-75 kilograms, has short, light-brown hair and wears gold-rimmed glasses. He is studying denistry, and married to a Chinese-Malaysian woman, who is expecting their second child. The couple have a 2-year-old daughter.

Tchernegovski pleaded for help from the Taiwan government and the public in finding his son, who brought with him a Canon camera and a green cotton hat often worn by New Zealanders when they went mountain-climbing.

Any information related to the man's whereabouts is urged to contact the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office at (02) 2757-6725, extension 204, or the NPA Foreign Affairs Office at (02) 2321-8673 or (02) 2393-0989.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANIMAL PROTECTION URGED AFTER MISTREATMENT BY TV PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Thursday asked the Government Information Office (GIO) to step up efforts to monitor television stations after complaints that animals are being mistreated on some TV programs.
The Life Conservation Association and other animal rights organizations filed complaints with Taipei police Wednesday about the improper use of animals.

Association officials said that to raise viewer ratings, China Television Co. has exploited animals through their use in variety programs. In one such instance, an entertainer was bitten by a beaver and passed out on the spot.
Such programs have grossly violated the rights of the animals, the officials said.

They said the COA, as the government agency in charge of the protection of animal rights, should take the initiative in punishing the TV station in connection with the violations. The council should also step up its campaign to protect animals, they said.

Chen Pao-chi, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, said the COA has asked the GIO, which is responsible for the regulation of TV programs, to step up the regulation of such programs and to review them before they are aired.
Chen said that the COA is collecting information on such programs and will deal with the TV stations in accordance with the law.
The Life Conservation Association and other groups are planning to call upon the COA soon to request the further protection of animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 25, or the seventh day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
440: The leaders of the Christian Church decide that the date of the birth of Jesus Christ should be fixed. The date chosen is Dec. 25, the day that the Romans celebrate the winter solstice.
1800: Britain's first Christmas tree is put up at Windsor by Queen Charlottee.
1818: The Christmas carol "Silent Night" is sung for the first time in Austrian village of Oberndorff.
1863: Spain declares war on France.
1913: A couple are arrested for kissing in the street in New York.
1914: Tsai O, Tang Chi-yao and Li Lieh-chun revolt against Yuan Shih-kai in Yunnan province.
1926: Hirohito accedes to the throne of Japan on the death of his father, Emperor Yoshihito.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang accompanies Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Madame Chiang to Loyang, en route to Nanking, after mutinous warlords kidnapped Chiang and held him for 12 days.
1941: British troops in Hong Kong surrender to Japan in World War II.
1945: National Taiwan University makes public the results of its first entrance examination and accepts 36 students who have passed the examination.
1946: The National Assembly completes the drafting of the Republic of China's new constitution.
1947: The Constitution of the ROC, which was promulgated on Jan. 1, 1947, goes into effect.
1948: The Gwoyeu Ryhbaw (Mandarin Daily News) publishes its premier issue in Taipei, becoming the first and only daily newspaper to publish stories written in the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1950: The 15-year-old Dalai Lama, the temporal and religious leader of Tibet, flees the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.
1962: The government formally proclaims Dec. 25 Constitution Day, a public holiday.
1969: The first Taipei City Council is established, with Lin Ting-sheng serving as speaker.
1969: Luo Chia-lun, senior advisor to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1973: Construction of the Suao-Hualien railroad is launched.
1977: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, the British-born actor, director and producer who gained fame for his role as a tramp in baggy trousers and a bowler hat, dies at his home in Switzerland at the age of 88.
1986: Sixty-two people die as an Iraqi Airways jetliner with 107 people aboard explodes and burns when it attempts a forced landing at a remote desert airstrip in Saudi Arabia.
1989: Deposed Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena are executed by the Romanian army after a secret court-martial in Romania.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev formally resigns as president of the Soviet Union.
1996: A tropical storm lashes the Pacific island of Borneo, killing at least 120 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man is without moral character, what good can the use of the fine arts do him? If a man is without moral character, what good can the use of music do him?"

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO PROP UP HOUSING MARKET: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: A presidential office spokesman on Thursday rejected a media report that President Lee Teng-hui has agreed to set up a fund to prop up the island's dull housing market.
Local newspapers reported Thursday that Lee made the promise during a Wednesday meeting with representatives of the Taiwan Building Investment Association.

The government housing-stabilization funds would be used to buy units in buildings that the buildings' developers were unable to sell, to lower the rates for housing loans and to provide compensation for a new town development in Taichung City of the central Taiwan, according to the reports.
The presidential spokesman said Lee met with the building investment association representatives because he is concerned over the state of Taiwan's housing sector.

Because the issues raised and demands made by the representatives involve a range of authorities and laws, Lee suggested moves to prop up Taiwan's housing market should be handled by a group comprising representatives of relevant authorities and developers, the spokesman said.

Meanwhile, Ying Nai-ping, a finance professor at National Chengchi University, said on Thursday that such a fund could play a key role in helping Taiwan's housing sector. Not all the money in the fund, however, should be used to buy building units, he said.
Ying suggested that the best way to take advantage of such funds is to promote the security of mortgage loans provided by banks.
He stressed if the government decides to establish such a fund, it should at the same time limit the construction of new buildings.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MRT LINE OPENS AMID PROTESTS

TEXT.P: After six years of construction, the Hsintien-Chungho line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System (MRT) formally opened to traffic Thursday afternoon.
Transport services on the new 7.9-kilometer MRT line, also known as Hsingchung line because it passes both Chungho City and the northern section of the MRT's Hsintien line, began at 1 p.m.
Many people flocked to take a ride on the new MRT line, the third of its kind in the greater Taipei area.

A ribbon-cutting ceremony was held in the morning at the line's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall station in downtown Taipei, with the participation of Premier Vincent Siew and outgoing Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian.
Also participating in the ceremony were Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng, former Taipei Mayor Huang Ta-chou and Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang.

Addressing the ceremony, Premier Siew said the MRT network is the most important transport artery in metropolitan areas. Quoting a TV commercial, Siew said "Keep the arterial traffic network running smoothly, life will be colorful."

With the inauguration of the Hsinchung line, Siew said, Taipei now has an additional traffic artery. "I believe the new MRT service will enable residents in Taipei City and Taipei County to lead a healthier and more convenient life," he added.

Mayor Chen, who will step down from the mayoral post on Friday, said he appreciates the devoted services of all staff members of the municipal government's Department of Raid Transit Systems and construction workers. "Their efforts have made it possible that the Hsinchung line was completed one year ahead of the schedule."

The festive inaugural ceremony, however, was overshadowed by protests from some 100 residents in the Chungho-Yungho area whose houses were damaged during construction of the new MRT line and construction workers suspected of having developed decompression sickness because of their work for constructing the underground MRT line.

Angry residents and construction workers blamed the city government for failing to offer them adequate compensation. They pelted the new MRT line's major stations with eggs and threatened to conduct long-term demonstrations or boycotts if the city government fails to resolve the issue as soon as possible.

Taipei's MRT network comprises five lines -- Mucha, Tamsui, Hsinchung, Nankang and Panchiao lines. Mucha and Tamsui lines were already inaugurated in 1996 and 1997, respectively. The Chingmei-Hsintien section of the Hsinchung line and the Nanakang and Panchiao lines are still under construction.

The Hsinchung line starts from the Tamsui line's Taipei station and passes through Taipei City's Kungyuan Road, Roosevelt Road, Shuiyuan Road and several major streets in Taipei County's Yungho City and ends at Chungho City's Nanshichiao district.
Servicing seven stations, the line is all located underground. It also feature a 1,100 meter-long riverbed tunnel beneath the Hsintien Stream.

The new MRT line is connected with the Tamsui line. Passengers now can travel from Nanshihchiao to the scenic coastal township of Tamsui within 46 minutes. It takes only 14 minutes to travel from Nanshihchiao to the bustling Taipei Railway Station.

The municipal government-run Taipei Rapid Transit Co. has planned a series of activities to celebrate the opening of the new line, including exacting only NT$20 for a ride on all MRT lines until Dec. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TIMES CONDEMNS MAINLAND CHINA IN EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: The Japan Times, the largest English-language newspaper in Japan, condemned Thursday in an editorial mainland China for its trials of three mainland Chinese promoters of democracy this week and urged the world to ensure that Beijing pays the price for ignoring its international obligations.

The Times in an editorial titled "China's spring is over" said that hopes for an improvement in mainland China's human rights policy in the wake of a state visit by US President Bill Clinton came to an abrupt end this week with the convictions and prison sentences of 10 years or more for Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin.

There were signs of growing tolerance of some dissent in mainland China during President Clinton's tour of Beijing this summer, which was followed by mainland China's signing of the United Nations International Convention on Civil and Political Rights in October. That agreement enshrines freedom of association among its basic tenets, noted the Times.

The heavy sentences handed down this week have dashed whatever expectations the outside world may have had of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin. It had been suggested in the past that once Jiang was comfortably in power, he would liberalize the country's political system to match its economic reforms. Moreover, it was thought he had gained the necessary leverage to pursue limited political reforms.

"That is no excuse for Beijing's flagrant violation of its international obligation and its duties to its citizens," argued the Times. "The (Beijing) government's willingness to put its interests ahead of those of its citizens exposes Beijing's democratic pretensions as a sham."

The newspaper lamented Japan's reaction to the trials, saying: "Although more countries are willing to denounce them (mainland China) ... and even European countries like Germany and France, which have traditionally muted their public criticisms of China, have joined the United States in condemning the trials. Sadly, thus far the Japanese government has been silent."

Beijing's signing of the UN convention and its desire for greater international recognition mean that its behavior is subject to international scrutiny, claimed the Times. "The rest of the world must ensure that China pays the price for ignoring those obligations."

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA CALLS ON NATION TO PERSEVERE AMID TRYING TIMES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada has called for unity, hard work and perseverance to enable Filipinos to meet the challenges of the new millennium and to help carry out his centerpiece programs for restoring peace and order, as well as ensuring food security and social equality.
In his Christmas message to the nation, the chief executive also urged Filipinos to "seize the moment" and shun the negative traits that have hampered the nation's progress.

He noted that Filipinos should be grateful because in spite of the extreme economic crisis that has gripped Asia since last year, the country escaped recession and will be able to register mild positive growth next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN SAYS INDEPENDENCE ISSUE SHOULD BE CLEARED UP BY 2000

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman Lin Yih-hsiung said on Thursday that issue of independence should be cleared up before the 2000 presidential election.

After Chen Shui-bian's failure to win a second term as Taipei mayor, DPP members now more than ever expect him to run for president, Lin said. The independence issue, however, should be resolved in accordance with the DPP's party platform before any changes to its policy are made, said Lin.

Lin also made the remark that disputes on amending the Taiwan independence article of the DPP's party platform should be resolved through the DPP's platform amendment committee, which will hold a thorough discussion on amended articles approved by the DPP National Congress.

In response to remarks that the party's stand on independence is what is preventing it from becoming the ruling party, Lin argued that people do not understand the real meaning of the article. He added that opinion polls have shown rising support for Taiwan independence, although the number of people supporting it has not yet exceeded half the population.

As for recent disputes over the ethnicity of various groups in Taiwan, Lin said political figures should visit with different ethnic groups. For instance, Kaohsiung mayor-elect Frank Hsieh and Lin visited the villages of military dependents, many of whom are loyal to the pro-reunification New Party, 10 times during the election campaign, he said.
Concerning the presidential election in 2000, Lin noted that the DPP is willing to cooperate with the New Party against the "corrupted" KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S ARMY SLOW TO LET ITS BUSINESSES GO

TEXT.P: The handover to the mainland Chinese government of the armed forces' business interests has not been smooth, nor has it been completed, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Thursday.

The drive to divest the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the People's Armed Police of an empire of up to 20,000 enterprises was begun in July by President Jiang Zemin. The initiative was one of the most important and boldest announced during his tenure.

One of the main aims of the campaign was to make the army, which brought the party to power in 1949, more reliant on state finances and more obedient to state directives. The army has been one of the main perpetrators of rampant smuggling this year, an activity that has helped bring many state enterprises to their knees, the WTO report said.

An official in the State Economic and Trade Commission (SETC), the state body responsible for the divestiture of army enterprises, was quoted as saying that the finances of all military companies would fall under the auspices of the Ministry of Finance.

But a senior executive at Sanjiu, one of mainland China's largest pharmaceutical companies and a PLA business, was quoted as saying that no such thing had taken place. He said that a team from the company was in Beijing to negotiate details of the transfer.

Military company executives also rejected the common official claim that no government compensation was required because all military assets had originally belonged to the mainland state. This, PLA executives said, ignored the contributions to enterprises of many individuals over several years.

Analysts said it was likely that several months of wrangling would be required before any genuine transfer of ownership was completed. Some of the issues now expected to occupy the Take-over Office for Military, Armed Police, Government and Judiciary Businesses -- a body under the SETC -- include the clearing of inventories, auditing and staff settlements, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 COMPUTER VIRUSES TO "GREET" USERS ON CHRISTMAS

TEXT.P: Six computer viruses will greet computer users on Christmas when they send electronic greeting cards to friends, said information technology company Ggeat on Thursday.
To prevent infection users should make sure they use anti-virus software, the company said.
The six viruses are named Christmas Chu-Chi, Christmas Tree, Father Christmas, Christmas, Merry Christmas and Japan Christmas.

According to Ggeat, if a computer user's word processing software is infected by the Christmas Chu-Chi virus, it will infect all the user's documents. On the 25th of each month, the virus will destroy all the documents, as well as the files related to the word processing software.
A growing number of Internet users are using electronic mail to send greetings, the company noted.
Ggeat will provide computer users with a free, authorized version of its anti-virus software for 60 days. The company's web site is located at www.ggeat.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS TO NINE-MONTH LOW IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar slid to a nine-and-a-half-month low of NT$32.243 on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday after falling NT$0.004 from the previous day.
The greenback opened at NT$32.239 and fluctuated between NT$32.232 and NT$32.249.
A total of US$219 million changed hands during the trading session.

Analysts attributed the US currency's drift to the upcoming launch of the single European currency, which will threaten the dominance of the US dollar and prop up the value of the Japanese yen and the Deutsche mark.

The NT dollar's rise is being mitigated, however, by slack domestic businesses and the upcoming three-day weekend, not to mention the Central Bank of China's moves to curb the pace of the NT dollar's appreciation, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SAILBOAT STARTS GLOBAL JOURNEY AMID BLESSINGS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan sailboat left Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday afternoon for a round-the-world voyage amid blessings from hundreds of well-wishers.

The adventurous voyage will be led by Liu Ning-sheng, a son of the respected 88-year-old painter Liu Chi-wei. Liu, 52, will be accompanied by four other crew members, including a German sailing friend of his and a female crew member, on the two-year voyage.
This is the first round-the-globe maritime journey ever mounted by Republic of China nationals.
Among the well-wishers was outgoing Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, who said the adventure will manifest Chinese people's courage, determination and guts to overcome challenges and tests.
The ROC government, the ruling Kuomintang, the Kaohsiung City Government and many local enterprises have offered financial support for the voyage.
The 16-foot long, two-sail boat, dubbed "New Era," is a white sloop. The sailboat will call at 20 major ports around the world during its 21,250-nautical mile voyage.

The "New Era" will sail through all major oceans and the noted Suez Canal and the Panama Canal in its 82-week journey. Its first port call will be at Manila. It will also stop over in Singapore, Jidda of Saudi Arabia and many other major ports.
The sailboat is scheduled to return to Kaohsiung in November 2000.
The boat's departure for the voyage was delayed for one hour because its propeller unexpectedly tangled with a fishing net.

A Marine Corps brass band performed pleasing music as the "New Era" pulled out of the southern Taiwan harbor under a setting sun. All ships berthing in the harbor rang their sirens to bid farewell to the sail boat, and well-wishers hung strings of tiny paper cranes from the boat in a gesture indicating wishes for a safe and pleasant journey.
Skipper Liu said he and his friends have prepared for three years for the trans-century trip, which is expected to further attest to the bravery of Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISLANDWIDE OUTCRY AGAINST ILLEGAL CYPRESS LOGGING

TEXT.P: More than 100 environmental protection and religious organizations around Taiwan raised an outcry on Thursday against government measures to clear dead cypress trees in Ilan County's Chilan forest district in eastern Taiwan.

The outcry was triggered by allegations that numerous living cypress have been illegally logged by the Vocational Association Commission for Retired Servicemen (VACRS), which was contracted to carry out the clearing of dead trees in state-owned forests.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Fong-sheng made the allegation Thursday in Ilan, when he revealed that earlier in the day he had discovered two newly felled live cypresses in the Chilan forest.

Lin stressed that he will unify the island's environmental preservation forces to demand the Council of Agriculture (COA), Taiwan's highest authority for agricultural affairs, to suspend the VACRS's logging rights, which allow the commission to sell timbers of cypress.

Chen Jen-chih, a Hsinchu district prosecutor, held a recent press conference during which he unveiled an investigation carried out in 1996, which found that during the period from April to September that year, more than 300 live cypresses had been felled.

Cypress, a valuable forest resource, is fully protected by law. Due to its scarcity and suitability for making high-quality furniture and sculptures, a single tree can be worth more than NT$1.5 million (US$46,580) on the market, while the value will be far higher if the timber is processed.
The VACRS's forest development department should be held fully responsible for the illegal logging, despite the fact that there is no direct evidence linking the department to the crime, Chen said.
The Chilan cypress forest, covering around 20,000 hectares, is one of the most precious original forests in the world.
Most of the island's wildlife preservation and environmental protection organizations are calling for a national campaign to save the Chilan cypresses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PACKAGE ANNOUNCED TO HELP RECESSION-HIT FIRMS

TEXT.P: With only a few days left until the beginning of a new year, the government on Thursday announced a comprehensive loan relief package to help financially troubled local businesses.

The Executive Yuan approved the package in a Cabinet meeting, during which Premier Vincent Siew announced that the government will allocate NT$120 billion-worth of loans to help crisis-hit enterprises to purchase machinery and obtain soft bank loans.
A special bank fund worth NT$40 billion was also announced at the meeting, aimed at providing small- and medium-sized businesses with soft loans.
The required capital reportedly will come from postal savings funds redeposited at the Central Bank of China (CBC), according to local press reports.

The premier instructed that the CBC, in conjunction with the Ministry of Finance and participating banks, should make concerted efforts to fully implement the package in order to create a "win-win" situation for both the business and banking sectors, in the hope that the series of measures will help those recession-mired businesses overcome their short-term difficulties.

The approved package had been finalized by CBC Governor Peng Fai-nang, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, and Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang at a Wednesday gathering, based on a draft worked out on Nov. 4.
Concrete measures contained in the package include:

-- Companies which have paid their interest as required but will have difficulty repaying their previous loans for machinery purchases before the end of July next year will also be given a six-month grace period.

Siew stressed that the government will review the capital requirements for the package at any time, and that it will earmark more budget if necessary in order to meet demand. The government will also consider setting up a task force to help serve those enterprises which are qualified under the terms of the package.

The premier said it is important to assist legally run companies to continue operating and to give them greater access to bank loans, as the local business community has been mired in recession ever since a dozen financially troubled companies reported settlement defaults over the past few months.

Siew gave high marks for the performance of Taiwan businesses since the Asian financial troubles broke out more than a year ago, but called on people to remain on the alert, as the crisis has not yet blown over completely.

He urged all government agencies and the public to cooperate with the government and allow it to carry out its plan to revive the local economy in order to maintain steady growth in the country's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SPEAKS ON ALLEGED TOXIC WASTE INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday that he has asked a ruling Kuomintang legislator with extensive connections with the Cambodian leadership to assist in resolving the controversy surrounding a waste shipment to Cambodia.

Hu told a news conference that Legislator Tseng Chen-nung has agreed to travel to Cambodia on Friday to look into the Cambodian government's stance on the waste disposal issue involving Taiwan's petrochemical giant, Formosa Plastics Group (FPG).

Hu said Tseng is expected to transfer his letter to the Cambodian government. The letter stressed three key points, including that the Republic of China, an independent sovereign state, hopes to discuss directly with Cambodian authorities issues related to the FPG's controversial shipment of possibly toxic waste to the Cambodia's coastal resort of Sihanoukville.

"The letter also said that the ROC has traditionally supported the international environmental protection policy and regulations and that the FPG shipment was just an isolated case," Hu said, adding that the letter also assured Cambodia that the ROC government will properly handle the issue.
The minister further said he is hopeful that the Cambodian government will respond to the ROC's offer for assistance in resolving the issue as soon as possible.

Hu went on to say that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Environmental Protection Administration, the Government Information Office and the FPG will form a joint task force to handle the dispute.
Hu said the MOFA may send officials to Cambodia to handle related affairs after Tseng's return.
Meanwhile, the FPG offered a public apology for having caused the controversy.

FPG President Lee Chih-tsun said he hopes the Cambodian government will allow the waste to be stored in Sihanoukville if tests in Singapore and Thailand on the samples of the waste show that the waste's mercury content is not lethal.
Lee denied that the company had ever bribed any Cambodian officials for the waste shipment.
He also reiterated that the 2,700 tons of waste the FPG shipped to Cambodia was certified in Taiwan as safe for landfill disposal and that the shipment to Cambodia was conducted completely legally.

"We had legally acquired an import permit from the Cambodian government before exporting the industrial waste to that country," the FPG executive said, adding that the mercury residues in the waste, 269 grams in total, will not cause any harm to human health.

The incident came to the limelight earlier this week after Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen claimed in Phnom Penh prior to his departure for a visit to Beijing that the FPG's waste poses great health threat to Cambodian people and several residents in the vicinity of the garbage dump in the coastal resort Sihanoukville might have died because of touch on the toxic waste.

Cambodian authorities have so far not served the ROC any official notice or report concerning the toxic waste. Cambodia diplomatically recognizes Beijing and is not friendly toward Taiwan. Hun Sen forced the ROC to close its representative office in Phnom Penh last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD TO REMAIN AT KAOHSIUNG POST

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development Council Chairman P.K. Chiang has decided to remain at his post as head of the Executive Yuan's Kaohsiung Service Center after meeting Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday.
In the brief meeting of just over ten minutes following a regular Cabinet meeting, Siew hailed Chiang's performance at the post and persuaded him to continue in the job.

Chiang expressed his desire to quit the post on Wednesday to Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan after learning of outside criticism, some of which came from former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, that the Executive Yuan's Kaohsiung Service Center has become little more than a "complaint center," and has failed to really serve the people of southern Taiwan.

The center was set up six months ago to provide people in southern Taiwan with an alternative to traveling to Taipei in the north of the island every time they had to conduct business with the central government.

Chiang's intention to quit the post aroused grave concern among ranking Executive Yuan officials. But government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Wednesday that Premier Siew would not approve Chiang's resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC MOVEMENT IN CHINA MUST BE ACCELERATED: WEI

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng said here Thursday that the number of mainland Chinese people awakening to the idea of freedom and human rights is increasing very quickly.
Speaking at a seminar on "freedom, democracy, and human rights" in Taipei, Wei also pointed out that dissident groups in mainland China are growing rapidly.
Under such circumstance, the democratic movement in mainland China must accelerate, otherwise the people in desperation may resort to violence, he added.
Taiwan's success in democratization has proved that the Chinese people are able to establish democratic systems, he added.

Wei, who had spent 18 years in prison in mainland China before he was released on a medical parole in 1997, also said the democratization in Taiwan is faster than in Hong Kong, when he was received by Secretary General John Chang of the ruling Kuomintang in the day.
The results of the elections held on Dec. 5 are indications that Taiwan is making great progress in democratization, he told the Kuomintang official.
Wei, who is now a resident in the United States, arrived here Monday for a nine-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS:
CBC TO MAINTAIN LOOSE MONETARY POLICY

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Peng Fai-nang said on Thursday that the CBC will continue with its current loose monetary policy in 1999.

Speaking at a year-end news conference after the CBC's last board meeting of 1998, Peng said the CBC will adjust its growth target range of M2 monetary supply for 1999 downward to between 6 percent and 11 percent.
M2, a major indicator of a country's economic health, consists of cash in circulation as well as demand and savings deposits.
As capital supply remains abundant in the domestic market, Peng said the CBC will not cut its bank deposit reserve requirements at present.

Judging from the financial situations both at home and abroad, the CBC governor predicted that Taiwan's export sector will not fully regain momentum next year. He said the Taiwan economy will grow by 5.1 percent in 1999, while the inflation rate will increase only by 1.8 percent.
Although the new Taiwan dollar has rebounded noticeably since October, Peng said the central bank will allow the market mechanism to decide the value of the local currency.

Since business conditions remain sluggish in the domestic market, the CBC head called on the banking sector not to squeeze its loan services to local firms, in order to ease their short-term financial difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTORIOUS KIDNAPPER'S DEATH SENTENCE UPHELD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's most notorious kidnapper and murderer, Chen Ching-hsing, had his three death sentences and two life terms upheld by the Supreme Court on Thursday, paving the way for his execution.

The sentences were meted out for a series of robberies, rapes, and killings committed by Chen and two accessories while they were on the lam after kidnapping and killing Pai Hsiao-yen, daughter of well-known TV star Pai Ping-ping near Taipei on April 14, 1997.
Chen's two accessories, Lin Chun-sheng and Kao Tien-min, were killed in separate confrontations with police in August and November in Taipei.
Chen himself was arrested on Nov. 18 after he broke into the residence of a South African diplomat and held the diplomat and his family hostage, surrendering to police after a tense 24-hour standoff.
Another death sentence, handed down to Chen for his role in the Pai case by the Taiwan High Court, was thrown out by the Supreme Court, which ordered a retrial in this respect.

Criticizing the High Court for failing to explain thoroughly the dismissal of proof favorable to the defendants, the Supreme Court ordered the reopening of a probe into whether Chen's brother-in-law Chang Chih-hwi had helped detain the victim, and whether his wife, Chang Su-chen, had helped Chen to elude arrest.

Although acquitted by a district court, Chang Chih-hwi was given a life sentence by the High Court, while Chang Su-chen was sentenced to nine months, later extended to 15 years. The sharp difference in the sentences has undermined the credibility of the judiciary and prompted the Supreme Court to demand careful reexamination.
A high court retrial was also demanded for Chen's role in the hostage-holding.

The Supreme Court, however, let stand an eight-year jail term imposed on another female defendant, Hsu Chia-hui, who became Chen's girlfriend after Chen broke into her house and raped her. She was convicted of helping to conceal Chen and Lin Chun-sheng by renting a room for them.

Chen's retrial will not prevent the carrying out of the death sentences upheld on Thursday. However, it is up to prosecutors to decide whether to carry out the execution before Chen has been tried for his other crimes, said the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Taipei and Kaohsiung City Councils elected new speakers and deputy speakers on Friday.
The China Times:
The ruling Kuomintang candidate for the Kaohsiung City Council deputy speakership, Wang Chih-hsiung, was unexpectedly defeated by independent councilor Tsai Sung-hsiung.
The United Daily News:
Taipei and Kaohsiung swore in new mayors; Wu Pi-chu of the ruling Kuomintang and Fei Hung-tai of the minor opposition New Party were elected speaker and deputy speaker of the Taipei City Council; and Huang Chi-chuan of the KMT and independent councilor Tsai Sung-hsiung will serve as speaker and deputy speaker of the Kaohsiung City Council.
The Liberty Times:
The KMT shares leadership with the New Party in the Taipei City Council and cedes deputy speaker post to independent.
The Independence Morning Post:
Wu Pi-chu became the first female speaker of the Taipei City Council, while independent councilor Tsai Sung-hsiung was elected Kaohsiung City Council's deputy speaker unexpectedly.
The Commons Daily:
Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian expressed his wish to visit mainland China on a "journey of dialogue" to help achieve peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The China Post:
Tests show Taiwan waste highly toxic.
The China News:
Taipei and Kaohsiung new mayors take office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR, SPEAKER SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Wu Pi-chu of the ruling Kuomintang was elected as speaker of the Taipei City Council on Friday, becoming the first woman speaker of a municipality in the history of the Republic of China.
Wu, 50, beat Lan Mei-chin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 33-19 for the post.
The unassuming Wu, who has been elected to the Taipei City Council for the fifth consecutive time, is said to be a modest and well-rounded person who gets along with her friends and foes alike.

Analysts said that Wu's election is related to the political ecology of the Taipei City Council, where none of the three major parties, the KMT, the DPP and the New Party, have been able to garner more than half of the seats.
Against this background, Fei Hung-tai of the New Party was elected as deputy speaker of the Taipei City Council, the first member of the tiny opposition party to reach such a high official level.

Fei, 45, is said to be a savvy politician who is close to his constituency and quick to respond to their needs. With his background as a professor of statistics, he is also eloquent in his intepellation of city government officials.
Also on Friday, Taipei City Mayor-elect Ma Ying-jeou was sworn in at a ceremony presided over by Premier Vincent Siew.

Before the swearing in ceremony, Ma called upon outgoing Mayor Chen Shui-bian, and the two exchanged views on issues ranging from cultural activities to city construction works. Ma stressed that he will continue some of the popular projects initiated by Chen.

Both men then attended the changeover ceremony, during which Ma vowed to integrate and take care of all ethnic and minority groups, and to promote a city government with integrity that is close to the people.

He also vowed to keep the promises he made during the election campaign, to conduct regular monitoring of the city government, to promote a more transparent and democratic process in formulating policies and to get along with Taipei City Council to create a win-win situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG DEPUTY SPEAKER DEFEATED

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's candidate for Kaohsiung City Council deputy speaker Wang Chih-hsiung was defeated by independent Tsai Shung-hsiung on Friday, repeating a surprise result of four years ago.

Tsai, a three-term councilman who has been jailed in the past for gangster-related activities, garnered 23 votes against Wang's nine in the 44-seat council. The result stunned many pundits because the KMT, which controls a majority 25 seats, should have had more than enough votes to assure Wang of victory.
The outcome was reminiscent of the last deputy speaker election in 1994, when the KMT-nominated candidate Chu An-hsiung lost to party rival Chang Rui-teh in a surprise defeat.
Earlier in the day, the KMT's Huang Chih-chuan was elected speaker as expected, with the support of 31 councilmen.
He and Tsai, both of whom are said to be strongly supported by just-retired speaker Chen Tien-mao, were immediately sworn in.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang, who visited Kaohsiung one day before the election to canvass votes for the KMT candidates, said in Taipei on Saturday that he would respect the election outcome.
Meanwhile, at a separate ceremony in Kaohsiung on Friday, mayor-elect Frank Hsieh took office in a gala inauguration held on the city's waterfront.
Surrounded by supporters, Hsieh faced the sea and vowed to build the port city into a shipping-friendly metropolis.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROMISES TO LOOK INTO VOTE-BUYING ALLEGATIONS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's secretary-general John Chang said on Friday that his party will look into allegations of vote-buying in the elections of council speaker and deputy speakers in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

To the embarrassment of the KMT, its candidate for deputy speaker of Kaohsiung City Council, Wang Chih-hsiung, was defeated by independent candidate Tsai Shung-hsiung, despite the party's 25-seat majority in the 44-seat council.
Chang told reporters that KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who also serves as the nation's president, made no comment after learning of the result on Friday.

As to suggestions that vote-buying was involved in the Kaohsiung elections, Chang said that the party's Kaohsiung branch will look into the allegations and ascertain the truth before making any decision on the matter.

Although the KMT lost the election for deputy speaker in Kaohsiung, the party can take comfort in its grip on the council speakership in the southern port city, and also in its control of the capital, Taipei, where it is only four seats short of an outright majority in the 52-seat council.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 26, or the eighth day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger under the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1791: Charles Babbage, English mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1893: Mao Tse-tung (Zedong), chairman of Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establish of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay, Sydney, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back US$11 million, the remainder of a large sum of indemnities China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of the National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye's statement clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The Royal Navy of Britain sink the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen US veterans of Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: Harry S. Truman, American statesman and Democratic president (1945-53), dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE LAYOFFS COULD AFFECT 10,000: UNION OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Singapore's unemployment for the fourth quarter is expected to reach some 10,000, the head of Singapore's largest union, Cyrille Tan, said on Thursday.
This will bring the year's total to more than 30,000, exceeding the Ministry of Manpower's projection of 25,000 to 30,000.
Tan made the statement at a briefing to announce a job fair next month for laid off electronics workers.
Official statistics show that the number of layoffs in the first nine months of this year was 21,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE EXPEDITIONS TO TAKE ON ANTARCTICA

TEXT.P: Walking across Antarctica to the South Pole or scaling one of its highest mountains is a dream expedition even for the hardiest.
But two Singapore teams are aiming to do just that by the dawn of the new millennim on January 1, 2000.
Their expedition, named Antarctica 2000, will be the first of its kind organized by a Southeast Asian country, according to The Straits Times newspaper of Singapore.
The teams, likely to be made up of four to five members each, are expected to set off separately in October next year.
They may well include Everest heroes Khoo Swee Chiow and Wdwin Siew, sources told The Strait Times.
Khoo, 33, a systems analyst with Singapore Airlines, and Siew, 27, an Outward Bound School instructor, reached the summit of Mount Everest in May.
Fewer than 50 people are known to have reached the South Pole on foot.
Antarctica, covering an area of 14.2 million square kilometers, is the world's fifth-largest continent.
Sources said that one team plans to walk more than 1,000 km, braving fierce winds that can reach over 150 km per hour and temperatures of minus 60 degrees Celsius.
The other team is planning to climb the 4,897-meter Mount Vinson Massif.
The trekking team is expected to take about 60 days to reach the destination.
It is believed that sponsors include the National Geographic Channel, the Singapore Sports Council, and the National Youth Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHONE AND INTERNET DATES TURN OUT TO BE SEX TRAPS

TEXT.P: Between January and November this year, nine sexual offenses were reported to Singapore police by girls and women who dated men they had met via 1-900 services or Internet chatrooms.
All the offenses were committed on the first date, according to a statement issued by the police.
The victims, aged between 13 and 23, had each set up dates with men they had met through a voice messaging service or over the Internet.
A phone-dating services allows customers to leave and retrieve phone messages, and is often used as a match-maker. There are at least five such services in Singapore.
Internet chatrooms offer an online meeting place where people of similar interests gather to chat.

According to the statement, the police have contacted the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore, which regulates the telecommunication industry, and the Singapore Broadcasting Authority, which regulates the use of the Internet, about the offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIRACY AND TURF WARS SLOWING BEIJING'S Y2K EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's efforts to deal with the Y2K millennium computer bug are handicapped by its widespread intellectual piracy and turf wars between the central and provincial governments, according to an Australian newspaper.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the Australian reported that although mainland China has made enormous efforts to catch up with the West since it launched its program of economic reforms 20 years ago, it is still a long way behind.
The daily said that mainland China could face disruption out of all proportion to its computer usage, because it is only now scrambling to deal with the bug.

Only last August did the mainland Chinese government come to grips with the need to address the problem seriously, with the State Council ordering all ministries to have the bug under control by March 1999, the daily reported.

Mainland China's banks and its stock exchanges have aggressive Y2K programs under way with the help of international firms, yet mainland Chinese ministries do not accept orders from each other and therefore have not been complying with a State Council order that they make monthly reports to the Ministry of Information Industry on their progress.

On top of the political problems is the widespread piracy, the daily reported. "More than 90 percent of the software used in China is pirated, and so vendors are less interested in helping users of copies of their product," said an Australian government computer analyst.
"The computer systems used by Chinese government agencies and companies combine hardware and software from nearly every country in the world, and many of these systems are undocumented," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGED TO REVIEW RIGHTS DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The New York-based Human Rights Watch has urged Australia and other industrialized countries to rethink their human rights dialogues with mainland China in protest against Beijing's harsh sentences imposed on three dissidents.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the Australian Associated Press (AAP) reported the 11-13 year sentences given to dissidents Xu Wenli, 55, Qin Yongmin, 45, and Wang Youcai, 32, show that mainland China does not respect its international obligations.

Human Rights Watch urged Australia and Western countries, including the United States and Canada, to make immediate, high level appeals to Beijing for a commutation of the sentences handed down to the three dissidents who tried to establish an opposition China Democracy Party to promote democracy in the mainland.
It also urged Australia and other countries to suspend any high-level trade delegations scheduled to visit mainland China in early 1999.
"China's signature on a human rights treaty isn't worth the paper it's written on if this is what it does to peaceful political activists," said the Human Rights Watch Asia director Sydney Jones.
Mainland China signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights 10 weeks ago amid much fanfare, according the AAP report.

Human Rights Watch said under such circumstances, it is time for governments such as Australia and the United States which are engaged in human rights dialogues with mainland China, to rethink the purpose of these dialogues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG CITY MAYORS BEGIN TERMS

TEXT.P: New Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou took part in a fun run on Saturday, one day after being sworn in as the chief of Taipei City.

Ma, an avid jogger, showed up at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall at 6:50 a.m. to a warm reception by the participants in the run which was sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior and a civil group to mark the 70th anniversary of the Republic of China's first copyright legislation.
Ma took 28 minutes to complete the route from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in eastern part of Taipei City.

Ma later described his time as far from his personal best, and blamed it on a lack of practice due to his hectic election campaign schedule. However, he added that in the future, he will go back to his habit of jogging every morning.

The mayor also used the occasion to urge the public to pay attention to the issue of copyright, saying that protecting copyright is protecting individual creativity, which is a sure sign of an advanced society.

Ma later attended "a festival of wheels" at a downtown department store which featured remodeled jeeps, all-terrain vehicles, sedans and motorcycles. The mayor urged the motorcyclists to be aware of the compulsory insurance project for motorcyclists which will be put into practice next month.
Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh said on Saturday that the first priority will be to deal with the garbage problem in the harbor city.

Hsieh said that over the past two years, he has observed the heaps of garbage bags which are dumped by residents in the city streets and ripped open and scattered by stray dogs and cats. These sights, he pointed out, are not scenes which befit a metropolitan city.
Hsieh spoke of the urgency of grappling with the garbage problem during a visit to former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chen Tien-mao.
He said that he will start to push a project which will see daytime dumping of garbage banned, and trash collections taking place at nighs.
Hsieh said that he will also try to help the working rights of more than 60 laid-off employees of the Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE LAUNCH ALL-OUT SEARCH FOR MISSING NZ YOUTH

TEXT.P: Police in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi on Saturday launched an all-out search for a missing college student from New Zealand in the scenic Alishan mountain region.

Twenty police officers and 30-plus aboriginal youths formed four search parties to hunt for Reuben Philippe Tchernegovski along four separate popular mountain trails which lead through passes linking Alishan to scenic spots known as Fengshan, the Fairy Dream Garden, Chitou. and Laichi.

Police had received reports from several local residents saying they had seen a foreign youth answering Tchernegovski's description walking alone toward Tashan along the Mienyueh branch line of the Alishan Mountain Railway between Nov. 25 and November 26.
According to the residents, the foreigner was wearing a green sweater and cut-off jeans, and was carrying a small backpack.

"Cashing in on today's sunny weather, we decided to send rescue teams to comb the Alishan area for the missing 23-year-old New Zealander, who lost contact with his family after he came to the island in mid-November," said a spokesman for the Chiayi County Police Bureau.
He said the bureau has checked registration records of all hotels and hostels in the Alishan region, but has found no valuable information or clues.

The bureau has set up a temporary command center at its Alishan outpost to facilitate coordination and rescue operations, the spokesman said, adding that the bureau on Saturday also dispatched a police helicopter on a search mission over the Alishan mountain region.

Meanwhile, the National Police Administration (NPA) has taken a number of measures to help in the search for Tchernegovski, including publishing special "inquiry" pamphlets and ordering all police offices around the island to contact hospitals and clinics in their duty areas to check whether he has been admitted or treated.
NPA Director-General Ting Yuan-chin met on Friday with the youth's father, Phil Tchernegovski, to express the ROC government's concern for the incident and its willingness to assist in the search.
The senior Tchernegovski arrived in Taipei on Thursday to search for his missing son, a dentistry major at a New Zealand university.
The NPA has provided a room at its Taipei police officers' club for Tchernegovski to live in during his stay here, and has assigned a staff member to offer counseling services.
Tchernegovski said he will travel to central and southern Taiwan in the next few days to join the search for his son.

Reuben Philippe Tchernegovski arrived at Taiwan's main gateway, Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, at around 3 p.m. on Nov. 15. He has not called family members or three of his Taiwan friends since his arrival.
The well-built young man, who stands 185 centimeters tall and weighs 70 to 75 kilograms, has short, light-brown hair and wears gold-trimmed glasses.
His father said Reuben left home with a green cotton hat, a Cannon camera, an ASB Visa card, a travelers' check worth US$1,000 and some US$1,200 in cash.

Local bank records show that Reuben has not yet used the credit card or the travelers' check. Reuben failed to return home by his birthday, Dec. 4, as scheduled. Local customs records also show that Reuben has not yet left Taiwan.
According to his father, Reuben is fond of visiting tropical rain forests and planned to take trips to the Kenting, Shei-pa and Taroko National Parks during his Taiwan journey.
Reuben has married and has a two-year-old daughter. His wife is expecting their second child.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONOPOLY TAX ON EUROPEAN SPIRITS TO BE LOWERED

TEXT.P: The monopoly tax for imported spirits from Europe will be lowered beginning on Jan. 1, 1999, the Department of National Treasury under the Ministry of Finance said on Friday.

Taxes for European brandy and whisky, such as French Cognac and Armagnac, will see the largest reduction of over 60 percent. Prior to the new year, such items will be taxed NT$490 per liter compared to NT$198 beginning next month. Irish and English whisky will be charged NT$198 compared to NT$350 per liter, the department said.

The reduction is the second round of its kind in half a year since Taiwan and the European Union (EU ) signed a formal agreement on the island's membership to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in mid-1998.

However, the department pointed out that prices of European spirits may fluctuate again after the new rates, currently being drafted as a part of the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Law, pass legislature which is set to begin a new session on Monday.

Taiwan had promised the EU that it would slash its monopoly tax on imported European spirits if the Legislative Yuan fails to approve the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Law before the end of this year. The chances of that occurring are slim as there are only a few days remaining in 1998.
National coffers will suffer a loss in revenue of an estimated NT$1.5 billion following this round of tax reduction, officials with the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW TEMPERATURES PREDICTED THROUGHOUT WEEKEND

TEXT.P: Temperatures across Taiwan are expected to remain low as a cold front continues to hover over the island, bringing clear and cool weather for the remainder of the weekend, the Central Weather Bureau said on Saturday.
Temperatures in Tamsui, suburban Taipei, dropped to 12.3 degrees Celsius early on Saturday, the island's lowest temperature of the day, weathermen said.
Other low temperatures included 13.2 degrees Celsius in Hsinchu, western Taiwan, and 13.3 degrees Celsius in Chiayi during the early morning.

The weather will remain clear with the exception on the northeastern region which will be cloudy, the bureau said. Temperatures in the north averaged at about 22 degrees during the day, while the average temperature for the southern region was 26.

Weathermen said skies are expected remain clear until Sunday, but the northeastern region of the island will likely experience some drizzle over the next three days. Cloud cover is expected to return to the island by Thursday or Friday, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR INSPECTS MIAOLI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Taiwan Province Governor Chao Shou-po arrived in Miaoli County, central Taiwan on Saturday for his first fact-finding trip in the area after taking office six days ago.
The government-appointed governor visited various sites of major projects as well as a private nursing home where he chatted with senior citizens and donated NT$50,000 toward their meal service.

He also assured local officials who accompanied him on the tour that the provincial government's aid to local construction projects will not be halted because of the downsizing of the Taiwan Province Government.

"There are no holidays in the province's development," Chao said in a speech which sought to dispel local government concern that the restructuring of the provincial government would affect the flow of funds. Chao said his island-wide inspection tour is partly intended to press home his inauguration promise that the province's agenda will not be negatively affected in anyway by the streamlining plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND PRO-DEMOCRACY ACTIVISTS TO GO HUNGER STRIKE IN NYC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A dozen pro-democracy activists from mainland China are planning to launch a three-day hunger strike on Sunday in New York to protest against Beijing's suppression of political dissidents.
The hunger strike, in sympathy with a hunger strike which kicked off in mainland China on Thursday, will begin at 10 a.m. in front of the United Nations' headquarters in New York.

The Washington-based Free China Movement, comprised of prominent mainland Chinese dissidents such as Wang Xizhe, Fu Shenqi and Lian Shengde, also wrote letters to both US President Bill Clinton and US Congress, asking them to take countermeasures against Beijing.

In its letter to Clinton, the group said Beijing's recent harsh sentencing of pro-democracy dissidents rebuffs Clinton's trust at a time when Washington wishes to encourage Beijing to improve its human rights record amid a warming bilateral relationship.
The dissidents demanded that Clinton issue a statement condemning Beijing's human rights abuses and urge Beijing leaders to release all political prisoners.

The letter to US Congress called for US support for plans to establish the "China Democratic Party" as an opposition party in the mainland, and expressed the group's opposition to the US extending normalized trade status to mainland China.
In addition, the Free China Movement in its letters asked Clinton and US Congress to review the World Bank's loan policy toward mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG URGED TO SEND STAFF TO CAMBODIA TO HANDLE WASTE ISSUE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Saturday formally ordered Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to send a special team to Cambodia to handle the controversial waste shipment issue.

Fu Shu-chiang, director of the EPA's Solid Waste Control Bureau, said the Republic of China government has on many occasions offered to cooperate with Cambodian authorities in dealing with the thorny waste issue.
"As the Cambodian government has so far failed to make any replies to our offer, we have decided to pool resources with the private sector to resolve the issue in a pragmatic manner," Fu said.
As the first step, Fu said, the EPA has demanded that the FPG immediately send a fact-finding team to Cambodia to discuss with relevant Cambodian agencies feasible ways to settle the issue properly.
The team should comprise lawyers, technical experts and other related professionals to facilitate identification of facts and determine whether the FPG is obligated to compensate Cambodia, Fu said.
He added that if the mercury level in the solid waste shipped to Cambodia last month exceeds safety standards, Taiwan's petrochemical giant will be required to retrieve the possibly hazardous waste.

In response to the EPA's demand, the FPG issued a press statement Saturday afternoon, reiterating its regret over the controversy and expressing its willingness to respect the Cambodian government's opinion in handling the issue.

The statement said if the FPG is required to retrieve the 2,700-ton allegedly toxic waste from Cambodia, it will not rule out the possibility of shipping the waste to a third country for permanent disposal.
"The waste may either be taken back to our plant in Jenwu in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung or shipped to a third country for landfill disposal," the statement said.

The FPG also stressed that the waste had been certified by the Cabinet-level EPA and the Kaohsiung County Government as safe for landfill disposal before being shipped to Cambodia. "We fully abide by law in shipping the solid waste to Cambodia," it asserted.

The conglomerate said it will call a meeting on Monday to discuss the EPA's demand. "We'll decide whether or when to send an investigation team to Cambodia after the Monday meeting," a company spokesman said.
Meanwhile, Joyce Fu, chief executive of the Green Formosa Fron (GFF), presented samples of the solid waste sent to Cambodia by the FPG in November to the EPA on Saturday for tests.

The samples were taken back by GFF members who visited the FPG waste dumping site in the coastal resort of Sihanoukville in southern Cambodia earlier this week to collect first-hand information about the controversial waste shipment.

The GFF executive asked the EPA to publicize its test results in two days. EPA officials, however, insisted that the laboratory test to determine the waste's mercury content needs at least three days.

The FPG has said the mercury residues in its solid waste shipped to Cambodia weigh about 269 grams in total. However, foreign wire service reports said on Friday that the first of three analyses of the waste shows a mercure content of 675 parts per million (PPM), a level more than 3,000 times higher than the limit allowed by the ROC government.

The reports also quoted a Japanese expert as saying on Friday that the FPG's mercury-contaminated solid waste is probably toxic. Mineshi Sakamoto of the Japanese Environmental Agency's Minamata Institute said: "According to the available test results, the waste is dangerous, but at the moment it's still difficult to say more than that."

Sakamoto said tests on samples he would take back to Japan would determine if the mercury was organic or inorganic. He said organic mercury could cause nerve disorders, while the inorganic type could cause lung and skin problems.

The waste incident came to the limelight earlier this week after Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen claimed in Phnom Penh prior to his departure for a visit to Beijing that the FPG's waste poses great health threat to Cambodian people and several residents in Sihanoukville might have died because of the touch on the waste.

Cambodia has so far not served the ROC any official notice or report concerning the incident. Cambodia recognizes Beijing and is not friendly toward Taiwan. Hun Sen forced the ROC to close its representative office in Phnom Penh last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN BEEF TO BE ALLOWED INTO TAIWAN IN FEBRUARY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Dec. 25 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beef imported from Paraguay is expected to be available in Taiwan beginning February 1999, according to the Paraguay Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock.

The ministry told reporters recently that Taiwan inspectors were satisfied with the quality of Paraguayan beef which is expected to be exported to Taiwan beginning in February after the two sides finalize some details.

The move comes after the Paraguayan Commission of Export Industries and Derivatives put forward an assessment report to relevant Taiwan authorities proving that Paraguayan beef has not been contaminated by the foot-and-mouth disease.
The report, based on inspections by officials from South Africa, Colombia, Uruguay, Israel, Russia, and the European Union, said Paraguayan beef is suitable for outbound shipments

According to the report, Paraguayan beef has been exported to Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Hong Kong, Peru, the EU, the Middle East as well as African countries. In August 1997 alone, as much as 20,000 metric tons of beef was shipped to Argentina.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO MEET WEI JINGSHENG ON TUESDAY

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui is expected to meet with visiting mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng on Tuesday, Wei's press secretary Qi Mo said on Saturday.
Qi said Wei, the most prominent exiled mainland dissident, will focus its talks with President Lee on issues related democratic reforms on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to Qi, Wei's current visit to Taiwan has brought a significant impact on the establishment and development of relations between mainland China's democracy movement and the Republic of China on Taiwan.
"I hope Wei's planned meeting with Lee will not be sabotaged by mainland China's overseas agents," Qi said.
Qi further divulged that Wei may postpone his return to the United States until Jan. 3 because he wants to hold extensive contacts and dialogue with social celebrities here.

"Through such contacts, Wei hopes to gain a better understanding of various developments in Taiwan as well as to win more support from local people for mainland China's overseas pro-democracy movement advocated by exiled mainland dissidents," Qi explained.
Wei returned to Taipei on Saturday after visiting the tightly guarded Green Island prison off the eastern Taiwan coast, which was used to jail "political prisoners" during the martial law era.
Wei is scheduled to meet with Premier Vincent Siew on Monday.
Wei arrived in Taipei on Dec. 21 for a nine-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Chapter of the World League for Freedom and Democracy.
Wei, who was released from a mainland Chinese prison last year after spending much of the past 18 years in a cell for championing democracy in mainland China, is now residing in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON IMPEACHMENT TOP INTERNATIONAL NEWS STORY OF 1998

TEXT.P: The Congressional impeachment process against US President Bill Clinton topped the list of the 10 most newsworthy stories in 1998 selected by chief editors, senior writers and other Republic of China media executives, including CNA.
The list is as follows:

1. Sparked by a sexual harassment lawsuit filed by Paula Jones, US President Bill Clinton was impeached by the House of Representatives for lying about his affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky and faces Congressional impeachment. The investigation report released by independent counsel Kenneth Starr created a sensation around the world, raising praise and condemnation.

2. Riots erupted in Indonesia due to the deteriorating political and economic situation. Former President Suharto, who ordered a crackdown on the protesters, was forced to step down in May. President B.J. Habibie took his place and promised to hold general elections in June 1999 and dismantle the authoritarian legacy of his predecessor. The minority Chinese Indonesians became obvious scapegoats and the biggest losers in the riots.

3. The Asian financial crisis resulted in domino effect on the global economy. International organizations such as the International Monetary Fund and the Group of Seven industrial nations have held meetings to discuss ways to cope with the situation and to revive economies.

4. US President Bill Clinton visited the Chinese mainland and met with President Jiang Zemin to discuss strategic alliance relations between the two countries. During a visit to Shanghai, Clinton verbally and unofficially referred to the so-called "three-noes" policy with regard to Taiwan.
