5. On Sept. 2, Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minster Anwar Ibrahim was fired by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad who said his onetime heir apparent was unfit to lead. Supporters for both men have engaged in continued clashes, sparking a serious political crisis in Malaysia.
6, The US Food and Drug Administration approved the marketing of Viagra, a drug for the treatment of impotency. The new drug has quickly become a bestseller around the world.
7. The 11 nations in the European Union decided to issue the euro in 1999, a major step forward for the single currency in Europe.
8. The United States and Britain jointly carried out military air strikes against Baghdad, after the Iraqi government announced it would no longer allow UN weapons inspectors to work in the country.

9. Hurricane Mitch wrecked havoc in seven countries in Central America, killing more than 11,000 with over 13,000 still missing. A strong earthquake and subsequent tsunami killed 8,000 people in the northwest coastal area of Papua New Guinea. The two events claimed more lives than any other natural disaster in 1998.
10. The representatives of peace talks in Northern Ireland reached an historic accord, ending 20 years of conflict and turning a new leaf for peace in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Alternative military services to take effect from 2000.
The China Times:
Expanded domestic demands, which will be publicized through the Internet, are expected to create NT$360 billion (US$11.2 billion) worth of business opportunities.
The United Daily News:
Vice President Lien Chan instructs four major directions for economic development, adding that the 'go-south' strategy should continuously be adopted.
The Liberty Times:
Taipei is skeptical of Beijing's sincerity as rumors said there will be preconditions to top mainland negotiator Wang Daohan's visit to Taiwan.
The Independence Morning Post:
Formosa Plastics ordered by Environmental Protection Administration to immediately and effectively handle allegedly mercury-contaminated solid waste which the company has sent to Cambodia and caused widespread protest there.
The Commons Daily:
The Ministry of Justice to probe alleged vote-buying in the elections of council speaker and deputy speaker in Kaohsiung City.
The China Post:
Police nab leading member of pigeon kidnapping gang.
The China News:
Waste samples in Taipei for test -- Environmental Protection Administration says results will be ready in three days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 27, or the ninth day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1831: Under the command of Captain Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1904: The Abbey Theater, the first state-subsidized theater in the world, opens in Dublin.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference ends in Moscow, announces agreements on a commission and Allied council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and US troops from China.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Chinese communist atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who was the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by US Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviet Union. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council, and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN TOP CONCERN OF TAIWAN PEOPLE IN 1998: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic slowdown, coupled with difficulties encountered by job seekers, was the public's main concern this year, a recent survey showed.

The survey, conducted by The United Daily News, found that 91 percent of those polled thought the economy was bad in 1998, while 78 percent said they had trouble finding jobs over the past year. In a similar poll in 1997, only 79 percent of respondents said the economy was bad and 66 percent said they had trouble finding a job.
Thirty-two percent of respondents said their lives were difficult in 1998, while 62 percent said their lives were not.
The annual United Daily News poll was first conducted in 1987 to determine how satisfied Taiwan residents were with their lives and with society.

In this year's survey, 45 percent of those polled said times were getting worse economically compared with in previous years. Forty percent of respondents agreed with that statement in 1997 and 42 percent in 1996.
While many of the respondents said they have been affected by the country's economic sluggishness, they were more dissatisfied over a deterioration in public morality and in public order.
Seventy-nine percent of those polled said they were dissatisfied with Taiwan's social morals in 1998, compared with 86 percent in 1997, when the level of social satisfaction was at a five-year low.
The degree of public order in Taiwan was said to be inadequate by 74 percent of respondents this year, compared with 84 percent in 1997.
Meanwhile, 63 percent of respondents said most people in Taiwan do not respect the rule of law, compared with 67 percent in last year's poll.
The gap between the rich and the poor was said to be widening by 68 percent of the population, while 60 percent said society is filled with injustice. Both figures represented five-year highs.

About 45 percent of those polled said they believe their children will lead better lives than they, while 35 percent said their own lives will improve during the next three years. Both figures were almost the same this year as in the 1997 survey.
Fifty-one percent of respondents in this year's poll characterized Taiwan's political status as stable, compared with 34 percent last year.
The United Daily poll was conducted by telephone from Dec. 17 to 19, and about 1,300 people around the island were queried. The poll had margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA RECOMMENDS MORE INVESTMENT IN COUNTRIES ADOPTING EURO

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) on Sunday recommended Taiwan investors explore more deeply European Union (EU) countries, specially the 11 countries that will adopt the euro as their national currency beginning Jan. 1, 2000.

CETRA, which has completed a market survey of 26 countries worldwide and which will present the findings from that survey to the Board of Foreign Trade for the formulation of trade promotion policies, suggested investors strengthen their presence in Britain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany and France on the grounds that abundant business opportunities will emerge in tandem with the coalescence of the EU market.

Even though the EU will be a single market, there is a need to devise different marketing policies for each country in the union. CETRA therefore suggested setting up assembly factories in Britain, distribution centers in the Netherlands and Belgium, and technology support and maintenance centers in Germany.

Despite the global economic downturn, the economic achievements made in Europe cannot be underestimated. According to the Board of Foreign Trade, Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Spain, the Netherlands, Germany and France are all enjoying double-digit import growth, while Europe's first-largest importers -- Germany, Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands -- account for 70 percent of all imports into Europe.

Machinery and transportation facilities account for about 30 percent of imports into Europe. CETRA said information technology products; semiconductors; motorcycle, bicycle and car parts; and anti-theft locks are ideal products for Taiwan companies to produce for European markets.
CETRA also suggested investors regard EU member states as separate sales regions to avoid sales channel overlap, and that they manufacture products in accordance with the demands of each market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CALLS ON TAIWAN PHYSICIANS TO WORK IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Doctors and physicians in Taiwan are being urged to join Taiwan's medical missions to Africa to help ease manpower shortages in the region, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported Sunday.

MOFA has contacted the China Medical Association, charity organizations and medical institutions around the island to ask for recommendations of qualified doctors who might be willing to serve in Africa.

MOFA officials are optimistic that the ministry will source enough qualified doctors to work in Republic of China medical missions in Africa, as they believe many doctors in Taiwan have the "spirit of Albert Schweitzer."

Schweitzer (1875-1965), a man of many accomplishments, decided to study medicine in 1905, two years after he became principal of St. Thomas Theological College at the University of Strasbourg. In 1913 he began serving as a medical missionary in Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa (now Gabon).

His first consulting room was a chicken coop. Over the years, he built a large hospital and a medical station where thousands of Africans were treated each year. Schweitzer was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and used his US$33,000 in prize money to expand the hospital and establish a colony for lepers.
MOFA urged Taiwan doctors who are compassionate and wish to broaden their international perspectives to contact the ministry for interviews.
For those assigned to ROC medical missions in Burkina Faso, Chad or Sao Tome and Principe MOFA will offer NT$280,000-NT$350,000 (US$8,750-NT$US,938) per month in financial compensation.

In the past, MOFA recruited its missionary doctors from the armed forces. But military regulations stipulated that doctors could work for only one year in foreign countries, such as Africa, on a contract basis. The ministry determined that a one-year tour of duty did not give doctors enough time to familiarize themselves with their new surroundings or to learn French, the lingua franca of those three countries, MOFA officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT TO DEAL WITH PROSTITUTION ISSUE BY LAW

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government will resolve the long-standing problem of licensed prostitution according to the law, said Cheng Tsun-chi, the newly appointed chief of the Bureau of Labor Affairs of the Taipei City Government on Sunday in a television program.

Cheng; Ou Chin-der, the political deputy mayor; and Wu Huei-mei, director of the Department of Information, were invited onto the program "Questions to Government," produced by the Taiwan Television Co. and the Broadcasting and Television Foundation.
Cheng noted that the issue of licensing prostitutes is no longer a question of how policies related to the sex trade should be formulated, but merely a moral issue.
The Taipei City Council has agreed not to revoke the licenses of prostitutes for two years, and Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will definitely handle the situation according to the law, Cheng noted.

Wu, meanwhile, said the issue should be regarded from a social welfare viewpoint and should center on what the government could do to compensate the licensed prostitutes once their licenses are revoked.

Speaking on construction projects in Taipei City, the political deputy mayor said the completion of important construction projects would benefit Taipei and help advance the city's internationalization, which he said was a significant mission.
Ou said there are many things to be done in Taipei, and that the only way to do them is to go step by step.
Ou also mentioned that the government will definitely crack down on sex and gambling operations, as well as on other illegal business.

As for the image of the new city government, Wu indicated that the Department of Information will play the role of a bridge between citizens and government, informing all the city's residents about what the government has done.
She also said her department is competent and will handle crises properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD FLEX ITS MUSCLES AT BEIJING: WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: The Republic of China should flex its muscles before Beijing, showing Beijing's rulers its determination to protect the interests of the 21.4 million people in Taiwan, said a leading mainland Chinese dissident on Sunday during a visit to Taiwan.

Wei Jingsheng, who has been heralded as the father of democracy in mainland China, said Taiwan has seemed to bow to Beijing's efforts to suppress the island throughout much of the last decade. This has made Beijing's leaders believe they are in control of the situation, he said.

Now is the time for Taiwan to show Beijing its real muscle and to demonstrate that the ROC government is determined to protect the interests of the people of Taiwan, Wei said during a meeting of the Wei family clan Sunday in Taipei.
The meeting brought together people surnamed Wei from all over the world.

The Republic of China need not always act in a way that pleases Beijing, Wei said, adding that too much capitulation can embolden the other side. Taiwan's softness in the past may be responsible for the roots of the present instability across the Taiwan Strait, he noted.

Wei was referring to reports that Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, had said recently he would not visit Taipei if reunification is not discussed in meetings during his visit with ROC government representatives.

Wei said Taipei should categorically tell Beijing that "you have your aims while we have our conditions," adding that discussions cannot be called negotiations if one side is not even given the chance to place conditions on agreements and proposals.

As to a planned meeting between Wei and President Lee Teng-hui, who will meet with Wei not as president but in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, Wei said he does not care under what title Lee meets with him. What is important is the substance of the talks, Wei said.
He said he is interested in knowing how the Republic of China will keep its promises to help mainland China and countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region reshape their political futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP ROC ECON. PLANNER TO VISIT AFRICA IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), is scheduled to lead a Republic of China delegation to Africa in mid-January to promote agricultural and economic exchanges.
The ROC's top economic planner said tentative plans call for him and his mission to embark on a two-week visit to the Gambia and Senegal in mid-January.

Chiang said his schedule may be changed if necessary. For example, he said, Premier Vincent Siew instructed last week all Cabinet agencies to submit within one month drafts of plans to invigorate the domestic economy. This would require Chiang's presence, he said.
Chiang decided to visit Gambia after Gambian President Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh personally invited Chiang to visit the African country when Jammeh visited Taipei in November, Chiang said.

He decided to include a trip to Senegal because the Senegalese government has invited him to visit three times in recent months in hopes that he would help push for the materialization of several major cooperative projects between the two countries, Chiang added.
Chiang said he will be accompanied by officials from the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Kuomintang-owned Central Investment Holding Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY CONCERNED ABOUT THEFT BY AIT OFFICIAL'S SON

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Sunday expressed its concern over a theft allegedly committed by the son of a US official stationed in Taiwan.

Dasalla Vicent, an 18-year-old son of an official of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), was intercepted by police at a roadside checkpoint in Taipei Saturday evening. He was then detained, along with the son of a British national, for riding a stolen motorcycle. The two were also found to be carrying a knife, which is prohibited under Taiwan law.
Acting on information provided by Vicent during questioning, police recovered two other stolen motorcycles and apprehended two other American students, both 15 years old.
Ministry spokesman Roy Y.Y. Wu said that under an accord signed between Taiwan and the United States in 1982, AIT staff and family members are entitled to diplomatic immunity.
The AIT represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of official relations.
Vicent's father, who is currently studying Mandarin in Taipei, is considered a member of the AIT's staff, he said.
He said that this is the first criminal case involving a son of a foreign diplomat and that his ministry would cautiously handle the case in accordance with the law.
Wu said that the ministry is waiting for the result of a further investigation and will seek to determine whether diplomatic immunity privileges are applicable in criminal matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 99 PERCENT OF TAIWAN'S TIMBER IMPORTED: COA

TEXT.P: More than 99 percent of the timber that Taiwan uses each year is imported, as keeping domestic forests intact is a set policy of the government, a Council of Agriculture (COA) spokesman said Monday.

Chen Shi-chou, director of the COA's Department of Forestry, said the third stage of forest management work on Mt. Chilan in Ilan County, eastern Taiwan, will be halted until a further assessment is made.

The operations on Mt. Chilan, which includes the removal of dead and fallen trees from the forests by workers contracted by the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen (VACRS), was halted amid protests from wildlife conservationists islandwide over the past several days.
It has been rumored that VACRS workers have cut down live, precious teak trees from Chilan forests.

On Sunday, about 1,000 people took to the streets in Taipei. Waving banners saying "keep nature intact," "nature is priceless," and "save the forests from cutting," the demonstrators demanded that the government not "condone forest killers in the name of conservation."

Chen said the goal of managing timber resources is to achieve an approximate balance between the annual harvest and the growth of trees. This balance, called a sustained yield, ensures a continuous supply of timber by requiring that the amount removed during one year's harvest be replaced -- either through growth or reproduction -- before the next harvest.
The removal of dead and fallen trees from the forests to make room for new and younger trees is also necessary for a sustained yield, Chen noted.

Although government policy calls for no felling of trees in forests around the island, Chen said the forests must still be managed. Taiwan needs to nurture its tree-cutting technology and its ability to create man-made forests, he added.
Chen noted Japan's domestically produced timber constitutes about 20 percent of all the timber used in Japan each year, while all the timber used in Germany is homegrown.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 28, or the 10th day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1692: England's Queen Mary II dies of smallpox.
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing over half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tsunami.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, the United States, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang Army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter-high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: American Professor Harold Urey of Columbia University and a group of colleagues announce the discovery of a heavy form of hydrogen known as heavy water or deuterium.
1937: Maurice Ravel, a French composer of the Impressionist school whose works include the ballet "Daphnis and Chloe," dies in Paris at the age of 62.
1942: In World War II, Japanese planes bomb Calcutta, India.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1957: Japan's NHK begins to broadcast in color.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan illegal and non-binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank in the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is discovered.
1989: Alexander Dubcek, secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist Party in 1968 and instigator of liberal reforms that were crushed by a Soviet invasion in August of that year, is elected chairman of the parliament after 20 years of political obscurity.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMY FLASHES 'YELLOW-BLUE' LIGHT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan economy flashed "yellow-blue" in November, slightly better than October's "blue" light which indicated an economic recession, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Monday.

A "yellow-blue" light, which signals an economic slowdown under a CEPD-devised, color-coded economic assessment system, indicated that the local economy gained steam in November compared with the previous month, said Thomas Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department.

Despite the slight upturn in November, Yeh noted, it is still too early to say that the Taiwan economy is bottoming out amid a steep regional decline, as the index of leading economic indicators, which gauges economic prospects for the next three to six months, dropped 0.3 percent from October, while the index of coincident indicators, which reflects the country's present economic activity, also slid 0.1 percent.
Yeh estimated that the first quarter of 1999 will be a crucial period in determining whether the Taiwan economy picks up speed.
He attributed the slight upturn in November to the growth in exports, and a more stable stock market, which was the result of a government intervention in the market through a stabilization fund.

Under the CEPD system, a "red" light means the economy is overheated; "yellow-red" indicates the economy is heating up; "green" reflects steady growth; "yellow-blue" signals an economic slowdown; and "blue" represents a recession. The minimum score for a healthy "green" rating is 23 points.
November's overall economic performance received 18 points, up 2 points from October.

In assigning a rating, the CEPD measures nine major areas of economic activity: industrial production, export value, new orders, manufacturing inventories, non-farming employment, the check default rate, the M1B money supply, bank lending and the stock index.
Only two indicators -- those for exports and the stock market -- received a safe and satisfactory "green" rating in November, while the others received a "yellow-blue" score.

Meanwhile, according to the latest CEPD survey of Taiwan's business and industrial sector, less than 10 percent of members of the sector believe the island's economic prospects will improve in three months' time.
The poll found that only 2 percent of surveyed manufacturers and exporters said business was good in November, about the same number as in a similar poll in October.

Thirty percent of respondents said business was bad in November, about 1 percent less than the number who said so in October. Sixty percent said business was okay, compared with 59 percent in October.
In the same poll, only 9 percent of respondents said business prospects would take a turn for the better in the next three months, compared with 10 percent in October.

Sixty-five percent said they expect business to remain unchanged, compared with 62 percent in October. Meanwhile 26 percent said business would take a turn for the worse, compared with 28 percent in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE FIRM PRODUCES MANUAL ON MAINLAND CHINESE LAW

TEXT.P: A Singapore law firm has become the first in the region to produce an operational manual on the legal system of and legal practices in mainland China, with detailed explanations and guidelines on doing business with the mainland Chinese.

The manual was written in English by Colin Ng and Partners (CNP), a leading legal firm in Asia, and covers a comprehensive range of topics from dispute resolution and arbitration to financial and accounting procedures.
The manual was written jointly by nine lawyers, including three mainland Chinese legal consultants, from the firm's mainland practice group.
Unlike books on specific aspects of mainland law, the manual includes practical advice based on cases handled by the firm, said Tan Chong Huat, who headed the group and led the project.
His team had also opted for a binder concept to allow for yearly updates, as mainland laws have been undergoing rapid changes in the last few years.

"Although much has been written on foreign investments in China, there is no consolidated and focused manual on Chinese corporate governance," said Tan, who has been cited in this year's Asia Law Leading Lawyers Profile for his experience in mainland China.
Priced at S$495 (US$309), the publication is not intended for the small investor, but is targeted at major corporations and Singapore firms with mainland interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: 51 BOAT PEOPLE FOUND TO HAVE LANDED IN N. AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Fifty-one boat people landed recently at Cobourg Peninsula at the top of Australia's Northern Territory, according to customs officers.

The Australian on Monday reported Australian police and customs and immigration officers were investigating infra-red heat patterns detected from a spotter plane on the peninsula, 150 nautical miles northeast of Darwin.

The 51 people were the second group of refugees to have landed in Australia since Christmas Eve. Police earlier found 29 people who had snuck onto the shores of Araru Point, west of Black Point in Northern Territory.
The daily reported immigration officials refused to identify the 51 boat people or to reveal where they had come from, saying only that the interview process could take several days.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO PROBE VOTE-FLASHING

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo on Monday reaffirmed his determination to probe "vote-flashing" charges related to the elections for the speakerships and deputy speakerships of the city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

Cheng said the Ministry of Justice has ordered relevant prosecution offices to investigate allegations that some Kaohsiung and Taipei councilors have publicly displayed or "flashed" their votes in the Dec. 25 city council leadership elections.

"It's the Justice Ministry's unshirkable obligations to curb any irregularities in all domestic political elections, vote-buying and vote-showing alike," Cheng said, adding that as long as law-enforcement officers can collect enough evidence, all those involved in the rule-breaking vote-flashing cases will be bring to justice.
The grand justice-turned-minister went on to say that law breaking on the part of elected representatives will set a wrong model for democracy.
"Therefore, law-breaking elected representatives must be punished harshly in order to substantiate democratic development and rule of law in our country," Cheng stressed.

Cheng, who has been nominated by President Lee Teng-hui to serve as vice president of the Judicial Yuan, made the above statements before co-chairing a meeting of city mayors and county magistrates with Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen.

Meanwhile, Cheng Lung-chao, a chief prosecutor with the Taipei Prosecutor's Office, has been authorized to investigate the alleged "vote flashing" by some councilors in the Taipei City Council speakership election.
Cheng said he will carefully review all of the available video tapes concerning the election. If necessary, the prosecutor said he will summon councilors for questioning.
"We'll handle the issue strictly according to the law, regardless of the identity of those suspected of involvement in unlawful activities," Cheng said.

In the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Chief Prosecutor Chiang Hui-min, after review of the video taping of the Dec. 25 election, said on Sunday that 10 councilors were suspected of having openly shown their ballots and will be called by the municipal prosecutor office to explain the matter.
Under current law, votes in any elections should be cast confidentially.

Chiang said the 10 Kaohsiung councilors, instead of sealing their ballots completely before going to the ballot box, allegedly displayed their votes when passing by the vote supervisor of their own political party.
"I'll prosecute any councilor who did so," Chiang said.

The speakership and deputy speakership of the Kaohsiung City Council was hotly contested among major factions in the council which was elected on Dec. 5. The ruling Kuomintang's speaker nominee, Huang Chi-chuan, was elected while its candidate for the deputy speakership post, Wang Chih-hsiung, was defeated by independent councilor Tsai Sung-hsiung.

Some four years ago, several members of the 13th Hsinchu County Council were either given suspended four-month prison terms or were fined for publicly "flashed" their ballots in the council's speakership and deputy speakership elections on March 1, 1994. They were convicted of divulging non-military secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: EURO SEEN AS COSTING SOME AUSTRALIAN BUSINESSES DEARLY

TEXT.P: Australian businesses are being urged to be ready for the introduction of the euro, a currency that could prove highly costly to some Australian businesses, according to banking analysts.
The euro will cost hundreds of millions of dollars for some Australian companies, they said.

Financial markets in Sydney will start trading euros next Monday, when the new currency will become legal tender for non-cash transactions, including commercial invoices, corporate accounts, tax returns and dealings in bonds and equities, analysts said.
A recent survey shows only 18 percent of Australian businesses were worried about the introduction of the euro, and only 11 percent of businesses have actively addressed the issue.
The Reserve Bank of Australia said it understood what the euro's introduction meant for Europe, but it had not heard anyone who could explain the impact on non-European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREE FROGS SAID USEFUL IN FIGHTING CANCER

TEXT.P: Tree frogs from Western Australia can provide a powerful weapon against cancer and virulent Bacteria, according to Australian scientists.

They said chemicals distilled from secretions from glands on the back of the head of the magnificent tree frogs have eradicated a form of leukemia and a type of solid tumor cell in the laboratory, according to The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday.

The tree frogs were discovered in 1974 in a public toilet in the Australian outback. The frogs do not blister in the sun, nor do get bitten by mosquitoes. This suggests the frogs' secretions include a form of sunscreen and insect repellent that may apply to humans, according to the scientists, including Professor John Bowie, a chemist at the University of Adelaide in South Australia.

The chemicals, called neuropeptides, are now being evaluated to determine their effects on 50 types of cancerous cells. They are even more promising as an antibiotic. Doctors may be able to use the chemicals to combat infections such as staphylococcus aureau or golden staph, which can prove fatal, he said.
He said the chemicals penetrate the membranes of human cells much more easily than other forms of chemotherapy, making them potentially deadly to some types of cancer.
The chemicals would also be tested for toxicity in normal cells to determine whether they could be used in new forms of chemotherapy, Bowie said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S DEMOCRATIZATION KEY TO TAIWAN'S SECURITY: WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng said on Monday that democratization in Asia and mainland China is of vital importance to Taiwan's security.

Democratization in Asia and mainland China will not only help boost security in the region but will also be of great significance to Taiwan's security, Wei said in a meeting with Wu Kuan-hsiung, vice chairman of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
Wei is currently visiting the island after arriving on Dec. 21 for a nine-day stay.
He denied reports that he is in Taiwan to raise funds for mainland China's pro-democracy movement, adding that his visit should be viewed from a political perspective.

On his planned meeting Tuesday with President Lee Teng-hui, Wei said the topic of conversation will center on the promotion of democracy in Asia and mainland China. They will not likely discuss the unification of China or Taiwan's independence as they both share the same views on these matters, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIAN & TIBETAN COMMISSION URGED TO PROMOTE ACADEMIC RESEARCH

TEXT.P: Celebrating the 70th anniversary of the founding of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, Premier Vincent Siew on Monday urged the organization to continue with its academic research and cultural activities.
In doing so, the commission could establish Taiwan as a base for international academic research on Mongolian and Tibetan affairs, Siew said.

Despite limited manpower and budget, the commission has successfully hosted several cultural activities such as the Genghis Khan academic seminar and the Tibetan and Han medical research seminar, the premier said.
He noted that such activities enhanced understanding of Tibetan and Mongolian societies, promoted multiethnic harmony, and injected new vitality to the nation.

Siew also lauded the performance of the commission for uniting Tibetan and Mongolian people at home and overseas, expanding Tibetan and Mongolian cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and promoting bilateral relations with outer Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.016 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 32.259.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.25 and experienced a low of 32.265.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$223 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS AND INDUSTRIAL LEADERS DECRY ADMINISTRATIVE INEFFECTIVENESS

TEXT.P: Domestic business and industrial leaders on Monday complained to the government over ineffective measures aimed at assisting financially strapped companies.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said although the Executive Yuan approved the release of NT$120 billion (US$3.73 billion) for soft loans to help financially strained business and industrial operations, the move has turned out to be "water too distant to extinguish a nearby fire" due to the ineffectiveness in the administrative and banking systems.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Monday met with 15 local business and industrial magnates for a breakfast meeting, during which the businessmen offered complaints and suggestions concerning the current economic slowdown and gloomy economic forecast.

Relevant government agencies are rumored to be revising corporate law to prevent companies from making cross-investments, an operation being blamed for a recent spate of stock settlement defaults, embezzlement cases, and bounced checks.

Kao said if the law is revised to prevent affiliated companies from making cross-investments, it would be tantamount to giving up eating for fear of choking. He said affiliated companies are allowed to make cross-investments under the current law with aims at encouraging companies to direct extra funds to other affiliated companies to develop multiple operations.
The participating businessmen also expressed their concern over the stability of Taiwan's currency as well as worsening labor shortages in the domestic manufacturing sector.
Wang promised that he and his staff will look into the problems raised by the business and industrial leaders and contact relevant agencies for possible solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG VACATIONING IN BAY AREA
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 28 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said he is enjoying his newfound free time with friends and family after having stepped down from office earlier this month.
Upon his arrival in San Francisco on Dec. 21, Soong said he was strictly on a vacation as he planned to meet with friends, get some rest and see his son and daughter-in-law in the Bay area.
Meanwhile, Soong's wife Chen Wan-shui arrived in San Francisco on Sunday. The two are awaiting the birth of their grandchild who is due next month.
Joking with reporters, the former governor said he did not realize how blissful it would be to get some good sleep and eat his wife's cooking after spending a hectic decade as a civil servant.
During his vacation, Soong said he will try to treat his wife better and think about how best to put his future plans into action.

Although he is absent from Taiwan, Soong continued to be the focus of attention in the media. According to a survey in the Taipei issue of Cosmopolitan magazine, Soong topped the list of preferred presidential candidates with 45 percent support.
Soong has been seen driving around the San Francisco area, and would not comment on any reports from Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNG HWA TELECOM LAUNCHES E-CALL CARDS

TEXT.P: Chung Hwa Telecom Ltd. on Monday launched a campaign offering discounts on long distance calls to selected international destinations in a bid to maintain its competitiveness in the local market.

The new service, which requires customers to purchase "E-Call Cards," will offer 20 percent to 30 percent discounts on long distance rates to 10 foreign countries and areas, according to Chung Hwa Telecom. The cards, valid for two years, are priced at NT$300 each.

At present, E-Call Cards can be used for directly-dialed calls to Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, and the United States, Chung Hwa Telecom said, adding that it will consider putting mainland China on the list of destinations pending market demand.
The new card will most benefit foreign workers, overseas students, local small companies and families with children who study overseas, the company noted.

Currently, Japan's KDD, Singapore's SingTel, and America's AT&T all provide such services to their clients, Chung Hwa Telecom said, adding that it decided to launch the E-Call Card amid its diversification efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU OUTLINES MEASURES TO COPE WITH BEIJING'S 'BIG POWER DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will form a special task force early next year to map out feasible strategies and measures to cope with mainland China's "big power diplomacy," Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday.

Testifying before the Legislative Yuan's foreign and overseas Chinese affairs committee, Hu said mainland China has forsaken its previous low-profile diplomatic strategy and adopted a far more aggressive policy dubbed "big power diplomacy."

Mainland China will mark its 50th founding anniversary in 1999. "After five decades of development, mainland China now regards itself as 'the world's largest developing country' and has decided to promote the so-called 'big power diplomacy' to upgrade its international clout and further squeeze Taiwan's diplomatic frontier," Hu noted.
In the face of Beijing's heightened diplomatic offensive, Hu said MOFA has worked out a package of measures to address the new situation.

"First of all, the ministry will set up a special task force composed of senior ambassadors and relevant staff members to monitor the situation regularly and formulate suitable counterstrategy to break out of the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation and further upgrade our international stature," Hu said.
Secondly, Hu said, MOFA will strengthen the ambassador-at-large system and intensify contacts and dialogue with major countries around the world.

"In addition, the ministry will coordinate with other government agencies to boost 'trade and economic diplomacy' with other countries no matter whether those countries maintain formal diplomatic with the Republic of China or not," Hu said.

The ministry will also join forces with the private sector to offer more humanitarian aid to countries falling victim to natural disasters, Hu said, adding that MOFA will launch an all-out Internet diplomatic offensive by loading information about the ROC's diplomatic, political, trade, economic and defense policies and major developments in these fields on the Internet for publicity purposes.
Meanwhile, Hu said Beijing's "big power diplomacy" is also aimed at allaying world apprehension about its military threat to regional security and peace.
The minister pointed out that mainland China has encountered some difficulties in promoting its "big power diplomacy."

"The biggest obstacle to Beijing's new diplomatic offensive is various regional security mechanisms, including NATO, the US-Japan security cooperation treaty and a US-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) system now under development," Hu noted, adding that mainland China's poor human rights records are another major hindrance to its "big power diplomacy."

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SHARE AND FUTURE PRICES SINK ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices slumped on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday as investors dumped their holdings for cash ahead of the new year holidays.
The TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dipped 201.35 points to close at 6,481.65.

In selling sentiment, the bourse opened at 6,615.38, and saw a further drop to 6,452.13, Monday's lowest level, before rebounding at the close of the session. During one point in trading, the market fell by 231.89 points.

A total of 1.3 billion issues changed hands on a market turnover of NT$45.74 billion (US$1.42 billion), the second lowest amount this year. The lowest record of NT$44.13 billion was recorded on Sept. 28.
Losers led gainers 432 to 20, with 32 stocks unchanged.
All eight major stock categories posted losses, with construction issues falling the most at 5.4 percent.

Plastic and chemical stocks sank 4 percent, followed by financial stocks and paper-making shares, which lost 3.4 percent; textile and electronic engineering stocks, 2.8 percent; and cement and foodstuff shares, 2.7 percent.
The over-the-counter market posted a 4.06-point decline, closing at 163.89, with a turnover of NT$3.17 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also saw comprehensive drops.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January slumped 249 points to finish at 6,591, with 4,403 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for February plunged 259 points to close at 6,620, with 206 contract transactions, while those for March fell 252 to 6,608, with 87 transactions; and those for June dipped 272 to 6,531, with two transactions.
No trading was registered for September.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 6,840 points for January, 6,879 for February, 6,860 for March, 6,803 for June, and 6,800 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SHOULD HAVE A SAY IN FATE OF LOCAL ELECTIONS: HUANG

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Interior will respect the new legislature's decision on whether the next elections for township and county chiefs should be abolished, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said on Monday.

Despite a consensus reached at the non-partisan National Development Conference (NDC) in December 1996 that all local elections should be abolished when the current terms expire, Huang said the issue should be decided next year to allow the new legislature, which will be sworn in on Feb. 1, 1999, to have a say in the matter.

However, Huang's remarks provoked strong criticism from Democratic Progressive Party Lawmaker Cheng Pao-ching, who raised the issue during a draft review of the "local government system" in the Legislative Yuan.
Cheng argued that Huang's response was an indication that the ruling Kuomintang was planning to use the newly elected lawmakers to revoke the 1996 NDC consensus.
In a separate development, police records showed that the number of election-related crimes dropped this year.

Statistics compiled by the National Police Administration under the Ministry of Interior indicated that high-profile violent crimes totaled 965 in November during the run-up to December's "three-in-one" elections. The figure is down 20 percent, or 1,206 cases, from the same period last year.

The number of criminal cases solved by police in November rose by 5.21 percent from 73.55 percent to 78.76 percent over the same month of 1997, a reflection that public order did not deteriorate due to the elections, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SPEAKS ON CASE OF ARRESTED US DIPLOMAT'S SON

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday he does not think that the son of an official with the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) allegedly involved in a case of motorcycle theft is eligible for diplomatic immunity.
Hu made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan committee meeting in response to an inquiry from a ruling Kuomintang legislator about the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' stance on the issue.
Hu said the ministry certainly will respect police and prosecution authorities' handling of the case.

The minister cited two prerequisites for diplomatic immunity -- foreign diplomats must have committed the crime while fulfilling their official duties, and the countries they represent must have signed immunity accords with the Republic of China on a reciprocal basis.

According to an accord signed between Taiwan and the United States in 1982, AIT staff and family members are entitled to diplomatic immunity. The AIT represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of official relations.
However, as the suspect is underage, he is unlikely to have been performing official duties when he was arrested by local police on Saturday evening.

Hu also said it is premature to talk about the immunity issue as the family of 18-year-old Vincent Dasalla, who was detained by Taipei police late on Saturday for allegedly riding a stolen motorcycle and possessing an illegal flick knife, has not applied for diplomatic immunity.
"As many details of the case have not been clarified, we do not need to bother to mull the immunity issue at the moment," Hu said.

Vincent is the son of an AIT staff member who is studying mandarin Chinese in Taipei. Also detained on Saturday was the son of a British national for alleged involvement in the same motorcycle theft case.
Acting on information provided by Vincent during questioning, police later recovered two other stolen motorcycles and apprehended two other American students, both 15 years old.

This is the first criminal case involving a son of a foreign diplomat. All four teenage suspects were released on bail on Monday. Law-enforcement authorities said they will handle the case appropriately.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY IS IMPORTANT TO UNIFICATION: PM SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said democracy is an important condition for national unification, when he received prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng Monday.

During their meeting, Siew also said that freedom, democracy, and human rights are important values of all mankind, and that the Chinese people on Taiwan have been able to realize their hope for these values. "The Chinese in other parts of the world should also be able to do so," he told Wei.

Wei, who had spent 18 years in prison before he was released on a medical parole and allowed to leave the Chinese mainland in 1997, said during the meeting that Taiwan has made great progress in economic and political development, and that Taiwan's achievement in promoting political reform without bloodshed is admirable.
Wei, who is now a resident of the United States, also said that mainland Chinese dissidents should pool their efforts to quicken the democratic movement on the Chinese mainland.
Wei, who arrived here on Dec. 21 for a nine-day visit, also met with Minister Chiao Jen-ho of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission of the Executive Yuan Monday.

Chiao said during their meeting that he has come to understand the Chinese proverb "Despotism can not last long," and that he strongly believes all dictatorships in the world will certainly disappear in 10 to 20 years.
Wei told Chiao that mainland Chinese dissidents staying abroad have won the sympathy and support of many Western countries for their cause to bring freedom and democracy to the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AGREES TO STORE USED NUCLEAR FUEL RODS FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States Department of Energy has agreed to accept used nuclear fuel rods from Taiwan's research institutes over the next ten years, the Atomic Energy Council said on Monday.
An accord which capped five years of laborious negotiation is expected to be signed between Taipei and Washington in the near future, said council chairman Hu Ching-piao.

The pact will form part of a US program to take delivery of used fuel rods from research institutes in East Asian states to solve these countries' problems of treating and storing the radioactive waste.

The used fuel rods, in which the uranium nuclei have split into fragments with a very long half-life, contain radiation stronger than that of unused rods, and are the most dangerous by-products in the process of harnessing nuclear energy.

Two Taiwan institutes are currently engaged in nuclear energy research -- National Tsinghua University, which uses about 60 rods per year, and the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the Atomic Energy Council, which uses around 40 rods per year.

The nuclear-waste disposal pact with Washington will spare Taiwan the trouble of storing the used rods which, along with the nuclear waste of other East Asian states, will be shipped to the United States once every several years, said Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER TO VISIT CARIBBEAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew is set to pay a 10-day visit to the country's Caribbean allies in early January, government sources revealed on Monday.
The sources said that the planned visit is aimed at strengthening ROC ties with the countries which recognize Taipei politically.
A total of seven Caribbean countries have diplomatic links with the ROC, and Siew is scheduled to visit three of them, the sources noted, adding that the premier is expected to set off on Jan. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTERS CO-CHAIR SEMINAR ON SOCIAL ORDER, LAND DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen and Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo on Monday co-chaired a seminar on islandwide crackdowns on crime and illegal land development.
All the 23 county magistrates and city mayors, including newly elected Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, attended the two-hour seminar held at Grand Hyatt Taipei Hotel.
Minister Huang said the anti-crime crusade requires joint efforts of the central and local governments as well as the private sector.
He pointed out that the government has given the top priority to maintaining law and order.

Noting that the domestic social order has deteriorated in recent years, Huang said more than 200,000 criminal cases were reported in 1997. If motorcycle theft cases were calculated, the total criminal cases exceeded 400,000.

Against this background, Huang said, the government has adopted a series of anti-crime measures over the past year. "Through such efforts, the local social order has improved significantly this year, with the number of violent crimes declining by 30 percent from the 1997 level."
Speaking on the same occasion, Justice Minister Cheng said the anti-crime drive should become a social movement which requires concerted efforts from both the public and private sectors.

Cheng said law-enforcement agencies under the Ministry of Justice have spared no efforts on cracking down on organized crime, drug trafficking, smuggling of contraband goods and illegal firearms trading and possession.
"We hope all city and county governments will join forces with the Justice Ministry and other relevant central government agencies in fighting crime," said the grand justice-turned-minister.
Moreover, Cheng said cooperation from local-level governments is equally important in curbing illegal land development.

"Unscrupulous land development and illegal logging have caused repeated landslides and flooding in many regions around the island, causing many human casualties and property losses," Cheng said, adding such actions should be stopped and more environmental protection measures should be adopted to ensure a safe living environment.
He urged local government chiefs to devote more energies on soil and water resources conservation to sustain national economic development and improve living conditions.

All city mayors and county magistrates present at the meeting voiced their support for the interior and justice ministries' call for cooperation in fighting crime and cracking down on illegal land development.

Local government chiefs, however, urged the central government to legislate clear-cut and unified regulations and action guidelines for cracking down on certain controversial lines of business, such as bars, KTV parlors, video game arcades and saunas, to facilitate enforcement of laws and rules.

Many mayors and county chiefs also expressed hopes that the central government will delegate more powers and offer more financial grants to city and county governments to facilitate local government administration and delivery on their campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH US HOUSE REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met on Monday with visiting US House Representative Bobby Etheridge and his wife, and extended his welcome to them on their first visit to Taiwan.

The president also expressed his appreciation to Etheridge for his solid support in the US Congress to the ROC, evidenced by the fact that during the mainland China visit of US President Bill Clinton in late June, Congress passed three joint resolutions related to support for the ROC.
The resolutions helped maintain stability across the Taiwan Strait, Lee told his American quests.

Etheridge, who has been in charge of public education affairs in the North Carolina State government, and now serves on two House standing committees -- of agriculture and science -- appeared during the meeting to being particularly interested in issues relating to agriculture, science and technology, and education.

He told Lee that during his Taiwan stay, he would like to visit key establishments regarding the island's political and economic infrastructures. In addition, he said, he also hopes to enhance the agricultural and biotechnological exchanges between the two countries.
Lee said the ROC government has listed research and development in the field of biotechnology as key work for the nation in the coming century.
Addressing educational issues, the president and Etheridge agreed that education plays a crucial role in a country's development, since it takes a well-educated populace to build a strong nation.

Lee noted that in addition to the promotion of constitutional, educational, judicial, and spiritual reforms, the ROC government is also very concerned with the welfare of the underprivileged, and has never ceased its efforts to build a society governed by fairness and justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG WASTE ISSUE EXPECTED TO BE RESOLVE SOON: HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday he believes that the dispute related to the shipment of mercury-laced waste to Cambodia by a Taiwan company will be resolved in the not too distant future.
Hu made the optimistic forecast during a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

Quoting a report from the Republic of China's representative office in Ho Chi Minh City in neighboring Vietnam, Hu said the Cambodian government has come to understand the ROC's official stance on the waste issue.

"Cambodian authorities have now adopted a relatively low-profile approach to handle the issue and no longer rejects our proposal to send officials to assist in handling the dispute," Hu said, adding that there are signs that the issue can be settled in the near future.

Hu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will respect the opinion of a supra-ministerial task force concerning whether the ministry should send staff members to accompany a fact-finding team scheduled to visit Cambodia after the New Year holiday.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Monday ordered Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to ship back some 3,000 tons of mercury-laced waste it had dumped in Cambodia, saying its toxic level slightly exceeded safety standards.

The EPA said tests on the waste samples brought back by a local environmental group showed a mercury level of 0.284 parts per million (PPM), compared with the 0.2 PPM safety standard set by the ROC government.
The samples were taken back from the dump site in Cambodia Saturday by the Green Formosa Front (GFF).

"It poses no immediate health threat and we urge Cambodians not to panic,'' Fu Shu-chiang, director of the EPA's Solid Waste Control Department, told a news conference. ``But we want the waste to be shipped back to Taiwan before other alternatives can be considered.''
The Cambodian government has asked Taiwan to take the waste back, accusing Taiwan of trying to dump toxic waste in poor countries.

The FPG, Taiwan's largest private manufacturing conglomerate, however, questioned the sampling method used by the Green Formosa Front, insisting that previous government analyses showed the waste met the safety standards for landfill disposal.

FPG General Manager Lee Chih-tsun said it will send a team, composed of European and American specialists to Cambodia to conduct its own sampling and tests before deciding whether to ship the waste back.
The island's petrochemical giant said in a press statement that it will take full responsibility for this unfortunate incident, which has caused jitters among the Cambodian government and its people.
After the incident is settled, the statement said, the company will ``make consolations'' to the Cambodian people.

Meanwhile, Legislator Tseng Chen-nung of the ruling Kuomintang, who maintains extensive contacts with the Cambodian leadership, has agreed to head the special fact-finding team to Cambodia to handle the waste issue.

Tseng said the team may leave for Cambodia on Jan. 4. The team will comprise experts from Germany's Bayer Co. and PPG Co. and Olin Co. of the United States, as well as senior FPG executives and environmental officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN DEPUTY PRESIDENT URGES COUNTRYMEN TO RESPECT DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki has sent a strong warning to South Africans against misusing the country's newly found democracy.

Addressing a gathering in the province of Western Cape on Sunday, Mbeki said political liberation did not mean freedom to rape, to steal other people's property, to stay away from work, or to do as one pleased.

Mbeki appealed for political discipline among members of the African National Congress (ANC), of which he is president. He said the ANC should make 1999 a year of change -- even in the manner the country is ruled.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYSTEMS INTEGRATION MARKET IN ASIA PREDICTED TO GROW

TEXT.P: Asia's systems integration (SI) market is expected to grow 24 percent a year between now and 2002, when it will surpass US$1.25 billion, according to a new study by International Data Corp. (IDC).
However, Singapore and Malaysia's SI markets will grow by only 9 percent per annum during the period, because of their geographic limitations and the regional economic crisis, the study said.

IDC defines SI as the activity that allows complex computer systems running on different platforms to talk to each other. The IDC study examined market trends, opportunities, and prospects for SI in seven key markets in Asia -- Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, South Korea, mainland China, and India.
The highest growth in Asia will come from mainland China, India, and Taiwan, according to the study.
According to the IDC's global survey, the largest SI market remains the US, accounting for just under half of the worldwide market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER PAY FREEZE IN PUBLIC SECTOR

TEXT.P: Legislators on Tuesday expressed concern over reports that there will be no increases in salaries for military personnel, civil servants and teachers in the next fiscal year.
According to reports, the government is considering not to increase wages due to the sluggish domestic economy and a budget deficit of NT$10 million in the next fiscal year.
Some lawmakers said the move would adversely affect the public and damage morale. They urged the Executive Yuan to reconsider the matter.

As the start of the fiscal year for 2001 will be moved from July 1 to Jan. 1 under a new budget law, the next budgetary period will span from July 1, 1999 to Dec. 31, 2000, Tsaur Eel-jong of the ruling Kuomintang noted.

If there were a pay freeze, then civil servants would have to wait 18 months before their next pay raise, Tsaur said, adding that interval would be too long. He urged the government to act cautiously to avoid any misgivings from the public.

New Party Legislator Cheng Lung-shui said there have been salary increases in recent years, and if the government does not offer raises in the next budget planning, it would damage the morale and interest in the public sector.
Cheng said if the Cabinet were to impose a salary freeze, he would boycott the decision.

However, KMT lawmaker Hung Hsing-jung said in view of the current economic problems and at a time when civil servants in other nations are cutting salaries to help overcome difficulties, he believed a salary freeze would not be a bad decision after all.
Hung said the Legislative Yuan should take the lead by cutting their own salaries to set an example for others.

If pay increases for civil servants is not implemented, it would be the first time the sector has not received a raise in nearly a decade. Between 1991 and 1998, pay increases have ranged from 3 percent to 13 percent. Pay raises were the highest in 1991 and 1992 when salaries were increased 12 percent and 13 percent respectively.

At a time when local companies are faring badly, salary increases in the public sector would increase the pressure to raise wages in the private sector. This could in turn contribute to a possible wave of lay offs among private enterprises, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ACCUSES OF BEIJING OF LACKING SINCERITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party, accused Beijing on Tuesday of lacking sincerity in forging mutual trust with Taipei after it canceled a high-level visit.

Yen Wan-chin, head of the DPP's Mainland China Affairs Department, said Beijing's decision to cancel the visit to Taiwan by mainland China's top negotiator, Wang Daohan, is an indication that Beijing is insincere in its promise to build mutual trust across the Taiwan Strait.

Amid high international expectations that the two sides of the strait could resume talks as soon as possible, the canceled trip is additional proof that Beijing is the real source of problems in cross-strait affairs, Yen said.
The Hong Kong-based Ming Pao daily reported on Monday that Beijing has canceled Wang's planned visit to Taiwan in March as a result of a prominent mainland dissident's visit to the island.
Wei Jingsheng, who lives in exile in the United States after being released from a mainland prison in 1997, arrived in Taiwan on Dec. 21 for a nine-day visit.

Yen accused Beijing of using Wang's Taiwan trip as a bargaining chip in cross-strait negotiations. He added that Wang's visit should be viewed as a courtesy follow-up to Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu's visit to the mainland in October.
Taiwan views Wang's visit to Taiwan as a gesture promoting bilateral talks while the mainland sees it as a pre-condition in negotiations by giving it political connotation, Yen claimed.
