DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTANT EVENTS TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 29, or the 11th day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1170: Thomas Becket, archbishop of Canterbury, is murdered by four of King Henry II's knights at the altar in Canterbury Cathedral in England.
1503: Spain conquers Naples.
1860: Warrior, the world's first true ironclad warship, is launched at Blackwall on the River Thames.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed great wealth through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang, pledges allegiance to the national government, which leads to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei leaves for Hanoi and issues a statement advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan, and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Chinese Communists, is inaugurated.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Ghandi, wins a landslide victory in India's general election.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, is the first elected non-communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese boat people battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC air force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders which ended 38 years of civil conflict, bringing Central America's last and longest civil war to a close.
Confucius lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA WANTS TO TALK WITH ISLAMIC SEPARATISTS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Monday said he will exhaust all efforts to strike a peace pact with Islamic separatists but ruled out the creation of an independent state in the southern region of Mindanao.

He said his administration is ready to "meet violence with violence" if the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) insists on its demand to establish an autonomous state. Such an event would contravene the 1987 Constitution which Estrada said he has sworn to protect as president of the Philippines.
"We will maximize all remedies to win them over," he said. But then, if they will still insist, that's a different story."
Last Saturday, government officials said it is keen on resuming talks with the MILF in January after the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of daily fasting.
Retired Gen. Manuel Yan, presidential adviser on the peace process, said Estrada wants to speed up negotiations to reach an accord with the MILF before the end of 1999.

Estrada and Yan said the government wants to restart its separate peace talks with the MILF and the National Democratic Front (NDF), but said these negotiations should be held within the framework of the 1987 Constitution.
The NDF is the political umbrella group of the underground left-wing led by the Communist Party of the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPACE STATION VISIBLE FROM EASTERN CANADA

TEXT.P: If clear skies prevail on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, people in eastern Canada may be able to see a space station fly by -- for just three minutes at most.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said the station should be visible at 5:26 p.m. on Monday in Montreal. In Toronto, it should be visible at 6:07 p.m. on Tuesday, while one minute later, residents in Ottawa will be able to get a glimpse of the station.
While this is a novelty now, it is going to become routine in years to come, experts said.

"All the future shuttle missions that go to (the space station) will head (over Canada) too, so over the next number of years you're going to see a lot of the space station and a lot of the shuttles, too," said Phil West, a spokesman for NASA.
Those who are interested can check the station's Web site at the following addresses: http://www.spaceflight.nasa.gov/realdata/sightings/ http://www.spaceflight.nasa.gov/realdata/sightings/
The space station, now standing 23 meters high, loops around Earth in a west-to-east orbit that changes a little each time around.

It currently comprises only the first two modules that were assembled earlier this month by an American and Russian shuttle crew. Over the next five to six years, 43 missions are planned, in which more and more parts of the station will be assembled. When completed, it will be bigger than a football field, quite easy to spot.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 KILLED, ONE MISSING IN AUSTRALIAN YACHT RACE

TEXT.P: Five men were reported dead with one still missing in the deadliest Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race in its 54-year history, organizers said on Tuesday.
Amid 80-knot winds and high seas, the US-manned Sayonara won this year's race, but there was little to celebrate as the event turned disastrous for many of the participants.

A massive rescue operation was launched to pluck a number of crew members from the rough seas, while the search continues for a crewman of the Winston Churchill which lost five members near Merimbula in New South Wales.
At one stage on Monday night, the frigate HMAS Newcastle and about 30 aircraft, including helicopters and long-range Orions from the Australian Royal Air Force, joined the rescue mission.
Organizers said at least 30 sailors required treatment in New South Wales and Victoria for injuries ranging from hypothermia to broken legs and head wounds from flying masts.

Of the 115 yachts registered in the race, 69 pulled out due to the bad weather. Sayonara sailed into Hobart on Tuesday morning in first place with the Brindabela of Australia in second. Others are still making their way to the finish line.
Despite the tragedy, race organizers stood firm behind their decision to continue with the annual event.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S LIVE LOBSTER EXPORTS REMAIN STRONG

TEXT.P: Australia's live lobster exports to Taiwan, Japan and mainland China remained strong despite the Asian economic crisis, but its frozen cooked lobster exports to Japan plunged 50 percent, export figures showed.

Perth-based Kailis and France Foods, one of Australia's largest lobster exporters, told the Australian Financial Review the company sold its frozen cooked lobsters in Australia to make up for the decline in exports to Asia.

Company general manager Peter Fraser said his company was forced to sell its frozen cooked lobsters domestically at much lower market prices. The local market had accounted for 2 percent of production, but the figure increased to between 8 percent and 10 percent this year, Fraser said.
"Prices are the lowest in almost a decade," he said.
Rock lobsters are Australia's biggest fishery export product valued at US$275 million in 1997-98, or about 28 percent of such exports, ahead of pearls at US$205 million.

About 80 percent of Australia's lobsters are caught in Western Australia and more than a third are now being exported in their most lucrative condition, alive or more accurately in a coma-like state, induced by lowering their temperature over three days.
Fraser said the demand for live lobsters, unlike boiled lobsters, continued to expand strongly in Japan, Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BANK LOOKS TO BUY BOA'S BRANCHES

TEXT.P: The ANZ Banking Group, one of Australia's four big banks, is bidding for the purchase of Bank of America's retail business assets in Taiwan, Singapore and India, the Australian Financial Review said on Tuesday.
Others offering bids include ABN Amro, Citibank, Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp., Bank of Nova Scotia, and the Standard Chartered Bank, according to the report.

The Bank of America earlier announced plans to sell its retail operations in these three countries. If ANZ were to buy the branches it would be a considerable addition to its business operations, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST ANTARCTIC FISHING VESSEL TO RETIRE, GO ON EXHIBIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first experimental fishing vessel to travel to Antarctica in 1976 will retire from service and be put on permanent display.

The Taiwan Provincial Government's Department of Agriculture and Forestry is currently putting the final touches on the "Haikung" which will be on exhibit in Pisha, a fishing harbor in northern Taiwan's Keelung.

The 711.5 metric-ton fishing ship measures 56.6 meters in length and has 2,200 horsepower. It can travel at 13.5 nautical knots with a freezing capacity of 16 metric tons per day. Its trawl nets can reach a depth of 1,000 meters underwater.

The ship was inaugurated on July 12, 1975 and it traveled to the East China Sea in December 1975 to formally begin its experimental research mission by exploring deep sea fishing grounds and fishing resources.

Haikung began its first Antarctic voyage in early December 1976 when it crossed the Indian Ocean and sailed around Cape Town to the Antarctic Ocean. After exploring the area, it hauled 130 metric tons of shrimp back to Taiwan.

The successful trip to Antarctica proved that the vessel could withstand the freezing conditions. In December 1977, the Haikung traveled from New Zealand to the Antarctic region and came away with 700 metric tons of shrimp.
Taiwan became one of the 11 countries at the time which explored the Antarctic's shrimp resources.
Over the past years, the Haikung has completed 53 sea voyages and has traveled to the Antarctic four times for shrimp fishing. It has also become a source of pride for Taiwan people.
The government, to promote leisure fishing, has improved the Pisha fishing harbor and will move the Haikung there for permanent display.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS HUMAN RIGHTS PROMOTERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met with a group of former political prisoners on Tuesday to discuss the construction of a human rights monument on Green Island off Taiwan's southeast coast.

Lee told the former prisoners of conscience that Taiwan has come a long way to emerge as a pluralistic democracy. "In the process, we have endured many sorrows. This has enabled us to better understand what and where the problem is," the president said.
A confident, upbeat Lee urged his guests, all of whom had been jailed in the tightly-guarded prison on Green Island during Taiwan's martial law era, to forget their past ordeals.

"We should learn to forgive and forget. By so doing, we'll be able to find true happiness and turn sorrows into joys," Lee said. He added that this is why he has been advocating the concept of "new Taiwanese" which will help forge unity among all Taiwan residents regardless of their origin.

The president went on to say that all people in Taiwan should work to incorporate different ethnic cultures into a new culture. "Let us forget that dark period and work hand-in-hand to create a mature, civilized, nurturing and sensible society," he said.
The group was headed by Po Yang, the pen name of noted writer Kuo Yi-tung, who was once jailed on charges of sedition after criticizing the Republic of China's top leaders.

After a decade of democratic reforms, Lee said, Taiwan has become a full-fledged democracy. "Nowadays, no person here is likely to be convicted or jailed simply because of their thinking, ideology or speech. I myself have often been criticized. I don't care much about such criticism. I have learnt to respect and tolerate the opinions of critics or opponents."

Po Yang and dozens of other former political prisoners have pushed for the establishment of a human rights monument on Green Island to remind future ROC leaders never to repeat past mistakes and to dedicate themselves to upholding democracy and human rights.

President Lee originally promised to attend a groundbreaking ceremony for the monument on Dec. 10. However, due to his busy schedule, Lee was unable to appear and instead sent Premier Vincent Siew to attend the ceremony on his behalf.

"I'll push relevant government agencies to assist in the design and construction of the monument, including the funding and reservation of nearby land as well as other technical details," the president pledged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN TO JOIN WORLD VISION OF TAIWAN AS VOLUNTEER

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that he and his family have accepted an invitation to join a volunteer group that provides social services.

Lien said he will work with World Vision of Taiwan, a non-profit organization. He will travel to remote regions on the island to launch anti-smoking and anti-drinking campaigns for the aborigines, as well as to encourage them to meet other challenges.
Lien also revealed that he and his wife Fang Yu have applied to the Chinese Children's Fund to sponsor 10 children in need of assistance.
Lien made the remarks while he was attending a seminar on voluntary service and caring for minority groups, sponsored by several foundations at National Taiwan Normal University.

Speaking at the seminar, Lien stressed that volunteer services will make up for the deficiencies of government social welfare programs, and he urged society to pay more attention to taking care of minority groups.

Lien noted that in recent years, the concept of volunteer work has gained popularity in Taiwan, adding that this will be the nation's third social movement, following economic development and political democratization.

He also said that with the nation's per capita income reaching US$13,000, the concept of volunteer work needs to be further developed. He said the further development of volunteer work to help the government push for a more comprehensive package of social welfare programs and to care for minority groups is an urgent task.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO PUBLISH BOOK ON TAIWAN'S STANCE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday he will publish a book in mid-1999, detailing Taiwan's democratization under his leadership over the past decade.

Lee made the revelation while meeting with key figures of the Human Rights Education Foundation, which is pushing for the construction of a human rights monument on Green Island off Taiwan's southeast coast.
Lee said the book, based on his narration, will be printed in three versions -- Chinese, Japanese and English. The Japanese edition will be published by Japan's PHP think tank.

In addition to recounting many never-been-revealed episodes in Taiwan's democratic reforms over the past 10 years, Lee also recalled his personal experience in his teenage years when Taiwan was under martial law or in the so-called "white terror" era.

Lee also outlined in the book his work plans after his current presidential term expires in May 2000. As the book is based on his personal narration, it is believed to be highly valuable and readable. The book will also serve as the most important footnote to Lee's stint as the Republic of China's head of state.
Lee was quoted as having told his quest that he will vividly recount Taiwan's past ordeals and sorrows, as well as many twists and turns in Taiwan's democratic reforms.

In the book, Lee said he has also carefully analyzed Taiwan's relations with Japan, the United States and mainland China. "I have recounted all what I know in the book whose title is tentatively set as 'Taiwan's stance and tenet,'" the president told his guests.

Among Lee's quests were several former political prisoners, including Po Yang, the pen name of noted writer Kuo Yi-tung who was once jailed in a tightly-guarded prison on the offshore Green Island simply because of criticizing the ROC's top leaders.

Lee told the former prisoners of conscience that Taiwan has come a long way to emerge as a pluralistic democracy. "In the process, we have endured many sorrows. This has enabled us to better understand what and where the problem is," the president said.
A confident, upbeat Lee urged Yang and other former political prisoners to forget their past ordeals.

"We should learn to forgive and forget. By so doing, we'll be able to find true happiness and turn sorrows into joys," Lee said, adding that this is why he has been advocating the concept of "new Taiwanese" which will help forge unity among all Taiwan residents regardless of their origin.

The president went on to say that all people in Taiwan should work to incorporate different ethnic cultures into a new culture. "Let us forget that dark period and work hand-in-hand to create a mature, civilized, nurturing and sensible society," he said.

After a decade of democratic reforms, Lee said, Taiwan has become a full-fledged democracy. "Nowadays, no person here is likely to be convicted or jailed simply because of their thinking, ideology or speech. I myself have often been criticized. I don't care much about such criticism. I have learnt to respect and tolerate the opinions of critics or opponents."

Po Yang and dozens of other former political prisoners have pushed for the establishment of a human rights monument on Green Island to remind future ROC leaders never to repeat past mistakes and to dedicate themselves to upholding democracy and human rights.

President Lee originally promised to attend a groundbreaking ceremony for the monument on Dec. 10. However, due to his busy schedule, Lee was unable to appear and instead sent Premier Vincent Siew to attend the ceremony on his behalf.

"I'll push relevant government agencies to assist in the design and construction of the monument, including the funding and reservation of nearby land for vegetation as well as other technical details," the president pledged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISA CARD SPENDING EXCEEDS US$9.3 BILLION IN FIRST 11 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Despite a domestic and a regional economic slowdown, Taiwan VISA card holders charged NT$325 billion (US$10 billion) in goods and services during the first 11 months of this year -- a record amount -- sources from the VISA International Service Association reported Tuesday.

The NT$325 billion in charges made from January to November was NT$54.5 billion (US$1.7 billion) higher than the amount made during the same 1997 period. VISA International officials estimated that total charges to VISA cards in 1998 in Taiwan could surpass charges for 1997 by 30 percent.

As of Nov. 30 VISA International had issued 9.18 million VISA cards in Taiwan. VISA cards have remained the No. 1 credit card in Taiwan since their introduction in 1989, according to company officials.

To meet the growing demands resulting from an ever-rising number of VISA card holders and from the 170,000 stores islandwide that accept the card, VISA International established its second computer processing network in Taiwan in mid-1998 to facilitate its operations on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT RULES OUT CREATION OF SEPARATE ISLAMIC STATE

TEXT.P: The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) is ready to resume operations against communist or Muslim separatist rebel groups if they threaten the sovereignty of the Republic of the Philippines.

Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense (DND) made this clear Tuesday, even as he echoed the previously stated position of President Joseph Ejercito Estrada, who said his administration would exhaust all means in trying to strike a peace agreement with rebels.

"Well, we have no choice. If anybody wants to secede, we have no choice but to put down the rebels. That is our responsibility under the constitution. The AFP's job is to protect our territorial integrity, sovereignty, and the people of our country," he said in a radio interview Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui met with prominent exiled mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng on Tuesday to exchange views on democracy.
The China Times:
The legislature completed third reading of the anti-air pollution bill.
The United Daily News:
President Lee said in talks with mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng that reforms must be conducted in accordance with law in a stable climate.
The Liberty Times:
Both President Lee and Wei Jingsheng criticized the Beijing government in their 75-minute talks.
The Independence Morning Post:
The legislature will push for the passage of two measures to help the reeling property market -- reduction of property transaction taxes and increase of tax deductions for housing loan interest payments.
The Commons Daily:
The first encounter between the new Taipei City Government team and city councilors ended in disarray.
The China Post:
President Lee, in Wei talks, notes democracy.
The China News:
The stock fund is ready to bolster the bearish bourse.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIOLOGIST CALLS FOR MORE CONSTRUCTION TO COMBAT ECONOMIC DOWNTURN

TEXT.P: Accelerating public construction projects directly related to raising people's standard of living is the only practical way to revitalize Taiwan's sluggish economy, a leading local sociologist said on Wednesday.

Chu Yun-peng, director of Academia Sinica's Institute for Social Sciences and Philosophy, said he proposed to Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang Tuesday that the government shift its attention from financial-aid packages devised to invigorate the local bourse, to public construction projects that would improve the public's standard of living, as a way to prime the pump during a period of recession.

Chu was among a group of leading economists and sociologists invited by Minister Wang to a meeting Tuesday evening on what the government can do to put steam back into the local economy. Chu said the public construction projects he mentioned include water and land conservation projects, the development of urban sewage systems and community computerization.
The proposed urban renovation plans can be accelerated by first having relevant statues passed in the Legislative Yuan so as to give local governments free hands in carrying out the plans, he noted.

Another urban development plan, proposed by the Executive Yuan several years ago, should also be implemented soon to boost the number of public construction projects. As more public construction projects are launched, the real estate and property development businesses will pick up steam as well. This will in turn fuel operations in other sectors, he said.

Meanwhile, Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, warned that Taiwan's economy will not fare better next year than it did this year if no pump-priming measures are enacted.

Koo quoted a recent International Monetary Fund report as saying that overall economic growth in the United States may expand by a mere 1.5 percent in 1999, compared with 3 percent this year. The development will have a direct yet adverse impact on Taiwan's economy, which relies heavily on exports, particularly to the United States.

Taiwan's overall economy will still fare much better than neighboring economies if the government strives to improve Taiwan's investment environment so as to solicit more foreign investment, bolster exports, stabilize the nation's political picture and improve social order, Koo noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG HOSPITALIZED WITH BRONCHITIS

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, currently visiting in Taiwan, checked into Veterans General Hospital (VGH) in Taipei for emergency treatment Tuesday night after he was diagnosed as suffering from acute bronchitis and fatigue, according to VGH sources.

Wei, who coughed heavily and had difficulty breathing when he checked into the hospital, was doing fairly well as of Wednesday morning after being given antibiotics and cough medicine, and after having a nice, long sleep, VGH doctors said.
Wei, currently living in exile in the United States, is a chronic smoker who has weak lungs, according to Feng Chang-feng, a doctor from VGH's Section of Infectious Diseases.
Wei developed acute bronchitis after nine days of whirlwind activities during a visit to Taiwan. This, coupled with Taiwan's constantly changing weather, wore Wei out, Feng noted.

The mainland Chinese democracy promoter is expected to be discharged from the hospital Thursday morning, as an initial biochemical examination of his blood found that Wei is in a generally good overall condition, Feng added.
Wei, who has been described as "the father of democracy in mainland China," was scheduled to leave Taiwan Wednesday after a nine-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 30, or the 12th day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1887: Britain's Queen Victoria receives a unique celebration of her Jubilee year from the women of England, a memorial signed by 1,132,608 women in favor of the Sunday closing of English public houses and the banning of sales of intoxicating liquor on the Lord's Day.
1918: Dr. Sun Yat-sen finishes his book titled "The Tenets of Sun Yat-sen," and writes a preface to explain the philosophical principle that "it is easier to do something than to understand why."
1922: Russia is renamed the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or USSR.
1925: Hsu Soo-cheng, special envoy of the Peiyang government, is arrested and killed by troops loyal to Feng Yu-siang at the Langfang railway station in mainland China's Hopei Province.
1927: The first section of the Tokyo subway between the districts of Ueno and Asakusa is opened to traffic.
1929: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs proclaims the nullification of consular jurisdiction in China to rid China of foreign privileges.
1944: Romain Rolland, the French writer who won the 1915 Nobel Prize for literature, dies at the age of 78.
1946: The Chinese communists use the "Shen Chung incident" to instigate students in Peiping (Beijing) to launch an anti-US campaign.
1947: Romanian Communists, under the protection of Soviet troops, force King Michael to give up his throne and declare Romania an "independent people's democracy."
1949: The Republic of China announces severance of diplomatic relations with India.
1965: Ferdinand E. Marcos becomes president of the Philippines.
1975: The United States Little League Baseball allows teams from foreign countries to take part in its world series competition.
1979: Richard Rodgers, American composer known for his musical comedies, especially his collaborations with Oscar Hammerstein II, including "Oklahoma," "South Pacific," and "The Sound of Music," dies in New York City at the age of 77.
1989: The United States renegotiates with the Vatican to bring an end to the refuge of the Panamanian dictator General Manuel Noriega in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. Noreiga fled to the embassy on Christmas Eve to escape the clutches of US marines sent by President George Bush to arrest him.
1993: Israel signs mutual recognition treaty with the Vatican, ending nearly 2,000 years of antagonism between the Orthodox Jews and the Roman Catholics.
1997: South Africa establishes diplomatic ties with mainland China. The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs formally severed diplomatic relations with South Africa on Dec. 31, 1997.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A man without moral character cannot long put up with adversity, nor can he long enjoy prosperity. Men of moral character find themselves at home in being moral; men of intelligence find it advantageous to be moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA FACES RISING STOCKPILES OF GOODS AS DEMAND FALLS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is facing a mounting problem of growing stockpiles of goods, as demand continues falling in the wake of rising unemployment.

In a dispatch from Beijing titled "China's curse of bountiful times" The Australian on Wednesday reported mainland Chinese customers either do not want or cannot afford to buy these surplus goods, including televisions, washing machines, buses, plastic bowls and other consumer products.

Throughout mainland China, storehouses are full to bursting with corn and cotton, copper and coal while factories continue to churn out televisions, washing machines and other consumer products even as demand continues to lag, the daily reported.
The daily reported the demand for this burgeoning mainland Chinese output is flagging, both at home and abroad.

In the West, analysts have worried that mainland China would become an overly voracious consumer of staple commodities, such as grains and coal. But now the supply of staples is also in surplus, the daily reported.
Mainland China produced 250 million tons of coal this year, while it only needed 180 million tons to run its economy, the daily reported.
Urban unemployment alone in mainland China is approaching 9 percent, or 18 million, and there are more than 200 million laid off workers who are not earning wages, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO REMAIN WEAK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to remain weak, and with weakness in a wide variety of indicators and a general lack of confidence, there are few signs that the nation can expect a rebound any time soon, The Journal of Commerce reported from Taipei Tuesday, citing local economists and analysts.

The stock market is expected to continue suffering from weak fundamentals and from weak sentiment associated with the financial problems that have hit various companies in recent months, the Journal said, adding that export orders and industrial output are seen to be slowing again as the peak export season has ended.
Annual growth in the consumer price index is seen as slowing from November's 3.91-percent clip as food prices return to normal after earlier bad weather.
Taiwan is expected to continue posting a sizable trade surplus, due to imports falling at a faster pace than exports, rather than due to strong demand abroad for Taiwan-made products.
According to the New York City-based daily, annual growth in the M2 money supply is seen slowing on weak loan growth and the central bank's recent open-market absorption of funds.

Short-term interest rates are seen as likely to remain near current levels on ample liquidity in the money market, while US dollar-New Taiwan dollar exchange rates are seen as likely to fluctuate narrowly, as the central bank continues to wedge the pair in a tight range, it concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, OTHER ASIAN CURRENCIES OUTPERFORM AUSSIE DOLLAR

TEXT.P: Asian currencies, including the New Taiwan dollar, are outperforming the Australian dollar and other commodity currencies in 1998, according to the Colonial State Bank in Melbourne.

The survey, published by Thomas Cook, shows the worst performing currencies were those of Laos, Russia, Australia, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Indonesia, Romania, Canada, New Zealand, Turkey, Ecuador and Fiji.

The South Korean won took the lead among the best performing currencies; followed by the Thai baht, the Czech koruna, the Japanese yen, the German mark, the Austrian schilling, the Dutch guilder, the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the French franc and the New Taiwan dollar.
Colonial's chief economist, Craig James, found Asian currencies chalked up some of the largest gains against the US dollar this year.

East Asian currencies, which plunged toward the end of 1997 and early 1998, are finishing 1998 stronger against the greenback: The Philippine peso was up 6 percent, the Malaysian ringgit 3.5 percent, the Singapore dollar 2.3 percent and the New Taiwan dollar 0.9 percent against the US dollar.
The Australian dollar has lost about 15 percent of its value against the greenback.

Of the currencies of major industrialized countries, the Canadian dollar lost 8 percent against the US dollar, while the New Zealand dollar lost 10.2 percent of its value against the US dollar in 1998, James said.
The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday quoted James as saying, "Low commodity prices were the main factor undermining the Australian dollar, Canadian dollar and New Zealand dollar over 1998."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXPEDITES PROCESSING OF HIGH-TECH WORKERS

TEXT.P: Canada announced Tuesday that it will continue to expedite the processing of foreign software development workers for admission into Canada.
The announcement was jointly made by Lucienne Robillard, minister of citizenship and immigration; Pierre Pettigrew, minister of human resources development; and John Manley, minister of industry.
In May 1997 Canada launched a pilot project, scheduled to end Dec. 31, 1998, to address software industry concerns regarding skill shortages and to streamline the validation process.
The initiative facilitates the temporary entry of highly skilled software workers to fill positions for which no Canadian citizens or permanent residents can be found.
The expedited processing will continue for another 12 months, while the redesign of the Temporary Foreign Worker Program is being finalized, a spokesman for Immigration Canada said.

Some 1,000 workers have been admitted under the pilot project to date, and more than 90 companies have taken part. It is expected that the number will increase as more companies become aware of the initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PORTS TO FALL UNDER CENTRAL GOVERNMENT ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The ports of Kaohsiung, Taichung, Keelung and Hualien will come under central government management by the end of June as a result of the downsizing of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

The decision was made in an inter-ministerial meeting of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which ruled that its Navigation and Aviation Department will take charge of administration of the four ports in June, while a state-run company will be set up over the next year to handle the privatization of all four ports by 2002.

However, officials with the Economic Planning and Development Council attending the meeting voiced disagreement with the establishment of the company, arguing that the four ports should be directly privatized.

However, department head Wu Jung-kui explained that the number of workers employed at the four ports totals more than 5,000, and that many of them would lose their jobs if the ports were privatized directly.
Wu emphasized that it will be better to carry out the privatization plan gradually, and added that the ministry will submit the plan to the Executive Yuan for final approval.

Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan and Keelung Port in the north are Taiwan's two largest ports, while central Taichung Port is the third-largest on the island and Hualien is the island's most important eastern commercial port.
