DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S WAGES LOWEST OF 4 TIGERS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Singapore has become the most competitive of the four "Asian Tiger" economies in terms of the cost of wages, according to the Geneva-based Corporate Resources Group (CRG).
The hourly rates of managers, professionals and workers in Singapore are lower than those in Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan, the survey said.

"Singapore is a lot more labor-cost competitive compared especially to Hong Kong as a regional hub for Asia," said Elaine Ng, who tracks salary movements in the region for the CRG group. "More regional companies may relocate to Singapore to improve their bottom line," she added.

The hourly rate for managers in Singapore, for instance, was US$30.70 as of November 1998, compared with US$62.80 in Hong Kong. The rates for managers in South Korea and Taiwan as of November were US$40.20 and US$39.60, respectively. But wages costs in Singapore are still higher than in the rest of Asia, excluding Japan.

Wages costs in mainland China -- particularly in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou -- are rising fast, however. Managers there are making about US$17.70 an hour which, while still below the rates of the Tiger economies, are higher than those in Thailand, India, the Philippines, Vietnam and Indonesia.
Wages costs in Indonesia were the lowest among the countries surveyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC GAMES SHOULD BE SCRAPPED: FORMER AUSSIE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Olympic Games should be scrapped because it has been tarnished by bribery allegations and by allegations of mainland Chinese athletes engaging in doping, a former Australian sports minister said.
Speaking on radio on Tuesday, Andrew Thomson said any group organizing a global sporting event should be "ethically clean" with "no suggestion of financial taint."
He said the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens should be the last and that doping allegations would have killed off the Olympics if Beijing had won the right to play host to the 2000 Games ahead of Sydney.
Thomson's comments were attacked by members of Australia's International Olympic Committee (IOC).

Australian IOC member Kevan Gosper has called on Prime Minister John Howard to silence Thomson, who was removed as federal sports minister after the Oct. 3 election, because it was feared that remarks made by Thomson would risk damaging the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.

Another Australian IOC member, Phil Coles, said Thomson's comments about Beijing would be noticed internationally because the mainland Chinese capital was bidding to serve as host to the 2008 Olympic Games.
"It's a very undiplomatic statement he's made about China. They'll be jumping up and down about (it)," Coles told reporters.
The IOC has been rocked by bribery claims against organizers of the 2002 Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, who are alleged to have offered athletic scholarship programs in return for IOC votes.
IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranch has called for a meeting next month to discuss corruption allegations surrounding the bidding process.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, AUSTRALIA URGED TO PRESSURE CHINA TO RESPECT HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The United States, Australia and others in the international community seem unable to exert an influence on mainland China to respect human rights, though they should not stop trying to pressure Beijing, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

In an editorial titled "China and Civil Rights" on Wednesday, the paper wrote: "So far, though, the manifestations of the democratic spirit in China are more idealistic and, as far as can be seen, related to the new economic power centers. And the world's democracies seem helpless in the face of Beijing's obduracy."

"The US, for all its power to influence Beijing through trade, and its willingness to criticize human rights abuses, seems powerless. And other countries, such as Australia, which have chosen to engage in 'dialogue' with China on human rights are made to seem even more so," the editorial said.
That is all the more reason for members of the international community to maintain pressure on mainland China, the paper said.

"The latest demonstration of the Chinese leadership's contempt for world opinion on human rights -- the harsh prison sentences imposed on political dissidents -- is a cause for dismay," according to the editorial.
The mainland's recent actions show how easily a country that rejects democratic principles can maintain its grip on power through inciting fear and intimidating its people, the paper said.

The editorial noted that late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping put mainland China on the road to a market economy. "But any hopes that these measures would be accompanied by liberalization of the political system have come to nothing."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR DEMONSTRATES DETERMINATION TO CRACK DOWN ON ILLICIT BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: The city government's efforts to crack down on the sex trade and other illicit industries are not slackening off even slightly because of the change of mayor, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Wednesday.

To demonstrate his determination to crack down on prostitution, gambling and other illicit industries in the city, Ma personally sat through a shift from Tuesday night to Wednesday morning at the police precinct in Chungshan District, an area infamous for illegal businesses, to boost the morale of the law enforcement officers stationed there.

Ma, a former justice minister, did not actually participate in the crackdowns, contrary to some rumors reported in the local press. He said he fully respects the expertise and experience of the police force in cracking down on illegal businesses. "I am here only to boost their morale," he emphasized.

In Tuesday's midnight action, the first large-scale raid staged since Ma took office last Friday, police raided six nightclubs and pubs in the Chungshan District, arresting some 20 prostitutes and operators on charges of engaging in the sex trade.

Meanwhile, other police forces carried out similar raids in the Wanhua District, another area notorious for its large number of sex-related businesses, uncovering 18 illicit operations and making more than 25 arrests.
Police also nabbed nine people for operating gambling dens, and confiscated 125 pornographic CD-ROMs.
Ma's personal presence at the police station came as rumors are rife that this type of illegal trade is poised to revive now that he has taken over as mayor of Taiwan's largest city.

During the run-up to the mayoral election, Ma endorsed a Taipei City Council resolution, which was opposed by then-Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, by agreeing to grant licensed prostitutes a two-year grace period before their trade is prohibited.

Now that he is in charge, Ma has suggested drawing up a comprehensive set of measures to help licensed prostitutes change their jobs before the grace period expires, so long as they commit to obeying the ban on prostitution in two year's time.
In yet another attempt to clarify his position on the issue, Ma reiterated on Tuesday his policy of "protecting legal trade while cracking down on illegal ones."

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU TO SET UP `HUMANITARIAN CENTER' FOR CAMPUS STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) will follow in the footsteps of many top-rate universities around the world by setting up a humanitarian center to better treat the stray dogs which roam its campus, a faculty member said on Wednesday.
Professor Fei Chan-yung, who teaches at the NTU's Veterinary Science Department, said he has drawn up a blueprint for the proposed center.

"Construction will get under way after the blueprint is approved by the NTU's development planning commission," Fei said, adding that the center is scheduled to become operational by the end of next year.
Under the Fei-drafted plan, a four-story building with a total floor space of 1,000 pings, equivalent to 36,000 square feet, will be built on the university campus to accommodate captured strays.
The center will be staffed by a full-time veterinarian and several part-time veterinarians, plus 100 volunteer workers.

Staff members will first conduct "behavior evaluation" on all strays brought to the center to determine whether they can get along with humans. "If they can, they will be subject to further health checkups. Healthy dogs will then be cleaned up, vaccinated, sterilized, and presented for adoption by members of the general public."
Only those which cannot get along well with humans, have been infected with diseases, or cannot attract adoptive owners within a week, will be euthanized, Fei said.
At the moment, almost all the strays captured on campus are killed.

Fei said he and many NTU students have volunteered to capture campus strays over the past three years. "We have managed to seize 200 strays each year, and send them to the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Environmental Protection. It is regrettable that the municipal bureau has consistently gassed all those dogs."
With financial support from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, Fei went to Hawaii in August to study theory and practical measures for the humanitarian treatment of strays.
Fei said NTU will publish a manual on the humanitarian treatment of strays in the near future. "We'll print 10,000 copies for free distribution," he added.

Fei said he has found through his years of experience in handling strays that even though there are many sensible pet lovers here, the number of stray dogs has continued to rise. "This is mainly because many dog owners do not trust local environmental units. They would rather see their pets become strays than send them to government-funded accommodation centers."

Fei said the planned NTU center is expected to set a model for the humanitarian treatment of strays. "We'll make it a creditable place where local people can turn in their dogs when they no longer wish to continue keeping them."

Meanwhile, in another development, it was reported that the Taipei municipal environmental protection bureau has tentatively decided to stop capturing stray dogs in the city as a result of pressure from local environmental activists and academics.

Environmental activists threatened to organize a large-scale demonstration in front of the Presidential Office during the upcoming New Year holiday if the city government fails to cease its inhumane methods of capturing and killing strays until it manages to work out better ways to treat the animals. Taipei currently has about 200,000 stray dogs. In the first 11 months of this year, the municipal bureau captured more than 8,000 of them.

Many city councilors, however, criticized the city government's abrupt decision to suspend stray dog capture. "What the city government should do is to improve its capture methods and treatment of seized stray animals," said Teng Chia-chi, an opposition New Party city councilor. "Otherwise, Taipei's image will be tarinished."

DOC.HEADLINE: `GARLIC WAR' BREAKS OUT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A seesaw battle related to the import of garlic is under way among garlic businesses and processed garlic producers in Taiwan, where garlic is widely consumed.
The local wholesale price of garlic has so far climbed to NT$120 (US$3.73) per kilogram since September, while the retail price has soared to over NT$140.

It has been reported that a number of local garlic traders have stockpiled "garlic mountains" in the hope of selling at higher prices in the upcoming Lunar New Year festival, the most important festival in the Chinese year.

In the face of this monopoly, some garlic businesses from southern Taiwan have lodged protests at the Council of Agriculture (COA), demanding that the authorities reopen the door to garlic imports in order to eliminate this type of speculation, according to COA officials.
Garlic imports are carefully controlled by the government, in order to avoid gluts and shortages which can affect prices for local growers.

In September, the government launched a special package to import 8,000 kilotons of garlic in order to meet demand resulting from insufficient output from domestic farmers, which managed to cap soaring prices. However, prices began rising again in early December.
The outcry for further imports is opposed by the Processed Garlic Producers Association, which said new imports will lead to a slump in prices, as happened in 1996.

Huang Yiu-tsai, COA director of food and agriculture affairs, said on Wednesday that Taiwan has around 4,000 kilotons of garlic in stock. However, the COA has been informed that around half of that has been cornered by speculators, he noted.
According to the COA, Taiwan's garlic production is usually enough to cope with local demand, without the need to rely on imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RULES OUT PROPOSED IMPORT OF GRAVEL FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Wednesday turned down a request by the Kinmen County Government to import gravel from mainland China, citing current government laws which prohibit direct trade across the Taiwan Strait.

Officials with the MAC, the highest-level government agency in charge of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, ruled out the possibility of importing gravel from the mainland in an assessment seminar held here with officials of the Kinmen County Government.

The MAC officials said that the proposal is unlikely to be adopted in the short term, as the government still bans direct trade, postal deliveries, and transport between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

They added, however, that the MAC will suggest that the Executive Yuan consider subsidizing local constructors, hard hit by a serious shortage of gravel, on a case-by-case basis, now that MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh has gained an understanding of the situation on the Taiwan-controlled island stronghold during a fact-finding inspection tour in September.

According to local officials, the Kinmen County Government was eagerly hoping to import gravel directly from mainland China's Fujian province to ease a worsening shortage since a ban on extracting gravel on Kinmen went into effect in July.

The ban has caused prices of gravel imported from Taiwan to soar from the previous level of about NT$150 per cubic meter to the current level of nearly NT$1,000 per cubic meter, forcing construction of many public projects to halt because of the resultant sharp increase in production costs, the officials noted.

Kinmen's demand for gravel and rock is expected to hit around 3.5 million cubic meters in the near future, as two major public construction projects -- a commercial port and a bridge -- are planned to kick off within two years, they claimed.

Although the Kinmen County Government has agreed to relax the ban on gravel extraction, and is already planning to open a gravel and rock quarry, the officials said that the measures will still fall short of meeting the long-term demand, especially at a time when Taiwan is also increasingly facing a similar problem.

Against this background, the Kinmen County Government had therefore been hoping to import gravel from Fujian province, just a few kilometers away on the opposite side of the strait, the officials said.
Citing an investigation by an engineering company, they pointed out that imported Fujian gravel costs about NT$288 per cubic meter, much cheaper than Taiwan gravel.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HITS 10-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar surged on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, rising NT$0.012 to close at 32.234 against the greenback, the highest figure on record over the past 10 months.

Speculation that the US dollar will no longer be strong in international financial markets after the euro, the united European currency, officially begins trading at the beginning of next year, has led to the greenback's consistent weakness.
Dealers pointed out that the US dollar's weakness, along with the fact that exporters had been dumping their US dollars in exchange for local currency, resulted in the NT dollar's appreciation.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.246, and had a high of 32.192.
Interbank US dollar trading expanded to US$581 million, the highest single-day amount over the past three weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO CONCENTRATE ON ECONOMIC STIMULATION NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The economy next year should fare better than this year after an economic turnaround following the earlier financial turmoil, P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said on Wednesday.
Speaking at a year-end press conference, Chiang said that the top priority of the CEPD next year will be the mapping out of a strategy to stimulate the island's economy.
He said that the package of stimulating measures will begin with the promotion of production and marketing, stabilization of enterprises, and cutting of costs.

Chiang said the CEPD is planning to convene a staff meeting during the New Year holiday to compile a list of views of related government agencies, in order to have a basis for working out its draft. After a further intra-agency meeting next week, he said, he will then make a full report to Premier Vincent Siew.

The CEPD chief said that next year, the council will also work on legislation for National Annuity Insurance, the economic development prospects of the nation in 2011, middle- and long-term public construction projects, and the privatization of state-owned enterprises.

Chiang also said that the sluggish construction market was mainly caused by the construction boom in earlier years, resulting in more than 800,000 households standing empty in the real estate market, which he said also indirectly affects the operation of banking institutions.

He added that the Executive Yuan will discuss a relief plan for the construction sector on Thursday, which he believes should start with the controlled supply of housing, and incentives on house transaction taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWS MEDIA URGED TO SAY `NO' TO PORNOGRAPHY, VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday threw his support behind the Government Information Office's (GIO's) ongoing campaign to eradicate pornography and violence from local news media, particularly television programs.

Lee voiced his support for the anti-pornography crusade after listening to a report by GIO Director-General Chen Chien-jen on the current state and outlook of Taiwan's radio broadcasting and television industry during a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee.
Lee, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman, said local media executives should refrain from producing programs featuring erotic and violent themes.
"Media operators and professionals should abide by professional ethics, their personal conscience, and government regulations when producing and broadcasting their programs," Lee urged.

Noting that salacious television programs and sensational media reports on violent crimes are to blame for the country's moral decay and worsening social order, Lee said the GIO should intensify its anti-pornography and anti-violence campaign.

He said outdated laws and regulations governing the radio and television industries should also be phased out or revised to bring them into line with today's social demands and help upgrade all broadcasting programs.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng said the government is determined to complete digitalization of all domestic TV programs by the end of 2005.
The planned digitalization is expected to bring about an estimated NT$200 billion-worth of business opportunities to local enterprises over the next six years, Lin added.
In related news, the Television Culture Research Association launched a program to select the five most disgusting TV programs broadcast in Taiwan in 1998.

Lai Kuo-chou, executive secretary of the association, told a news conference that the program is aimed at reminding local TV stations not to present programs that are based solely on rumor and speculation, that rudely infringe upon privacy, or that feature prurient and violent themes.

In addition to the association, 15 members of the local print media and seven websites are co-sponsoring the program. Local people are welcome to give their recommendations for the selection of the five most disgusting TV programs of 1998. The vote started on Wednesday and will end on Jan. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP; MOST FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices slid on Wednesday on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, losing 16.24 points to close at 6,462.03.

Weak confidence wiped out early gains attributed to government support of the market, dealers said, adding that an overwhelming profit-taking sentiment struck a further blow to the government's stock-stabilization efforts.
The government's stock-support team has been ordered to prop the index up before the market closes for a four-day New Year holiday.
The bourse opened at 6,545.78, and saw an 88.28-point surge at one point before selling took over again.
A total of 1.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.95 billion (US$2.05 billion), against the previous session's NT$43.1 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 223 to 189, with 74 stocks remaining unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronic engineering issues saw an increase of 0.6 percent, paper-making shares rose 0.4 percent, and cement issues moved up 0.2 percent.

Financial stocks fell 1.6 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which dropped 1.3 percent; construction shares, 1.2 percent; textile stocks, 0.8 percent; and plastic and chemical issues, 0.2 percent.
The over-the-counter market posted a modest rise of 0.94 points, closing at 165.6, with a turnover of NT$3.53 billion.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures mostly slid.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January sank 22 points to finish at 6,608, with 4,600 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for February dropped 22 points to 6,625, with 314 transactions, while those for March moved down 19 points to 6,625, with 51 contract transactions, and those for June climbed 40 points to 6621, with three contract transactions.
No trading was registered for September.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 6,630 for January, 6,647 for February, 6,644 for March, 6,581 for June, and 6,561 for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD CREATE 'MAINSTREAM VALUES'

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should create "mainstream values" on its own to help inspire Taiwan's further political and economic advancement, a new party executive said on Wednesday.
You Hsi-kun, who was sworn in as the DPP's secretary-general Wednesday afternoon, further said the "mainstream values" that the DPP should create or uphold must not run against social justice.

"If the DPP slows or suspends its fight against the money- and gangster-linked politics prevalent in Taiwan, it will betray its secularization and moral decline. Such a development violates social justice and is not in national interests," You asserted.

You went on to say he supports an overall review of the DPP's controversial pro-Taiwan independence platform in order to expand the party's support base and facilitate its bid to become the island's ruling party.

Nevertheless, You said he does not have any pre-set stance on the issue. "I'll arrange for intraparty discussion on the issue to forge an internal consensus on whether the party's pro-independence platform should be revised, reworded or completely phased out," he noted.

The DPP's chapter includes a clause saying Taiwan's future should be decided based on the result of a plebiscite. The clause is widely seen as a proof that the party favors Taiwan independence. As mainland China has repeatedly said it will attack Taiwan should the island declare de jure independence, the DPP's pro-independence platform has hindered the party's efforts to largely expand its popular support.

Intraparty calls for a review of the pro-independence platform have arisen in recent weeks as many political observers and some DPP heavyweights blamed the clause for the party's lackluster performance in the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections.

You, who once served as magistrate of the northeastern county of Ilan for eight years, just ended his stint as chairman of the Taipei City Government-run Taipei Rapid Transit Co. after former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a DPP stalwart, lost his re-election bid.
You said he was invited by DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung to run the party's day-to-day affairs.

"I'm not appointed by Ah-bian (the nickname of former Taipei Mayor Chen) to serve as the DPP's secretary-general," You said, adding that his decision to assume the party's top secretarial post is also not aimed at paving the way for Chen to win the party's nomination for Taiwan's next presidential election in March 2000.
You said he will strictly adopt a neutral, impartial stance in handling the party primary for the next presidential election.

Noting that serving as the party's chief manager of day-to-day affairs is a tough task, You said he is determined to devote his full energies to his new job to help streamline the party apparatus and expand its support base.

Nevertheless, You, a self-effacing, soft-spoken politician with a common touch, said he will respect administrative rules and principles set by his predecessors in running the DPP's day-to-day affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG TO APOLOGIZE OVER MERCURY-LACED WASTE IN CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) said on Wednesday that it has decided to apologize to Cambodia over its shipment of mercury-laced waste to the Southeast Asian nation.
FPG officials said that FPG Chairman Y. C. Wang will fax a message of apology to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.

FPG General Manager Lee Chih-chun said in a press conference on Wednesday afternoon that FPG officials will accompany Legislator Tseng Chen-nung of the ruling Kuomintang, who maintains extensive relations with the Cambodian leadership, on a three-day fact-finding trip to Cambodia and to gather samples for analysis.
Lee said that FPG officials are expected to bring back 50 samples, and will then invite experts to conduct analyses of the waste.

Tseng said the FPG delegation will try to find out how the Cambodian authorities have been dealing with the waste, and will explain the company's stance and express their condolences to local officials.
He said that he has been in daily contact with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen and has learned that he wants the FPG to address the problem squarely.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Monday ordered the FPG to bring back to Taiwan the waste it dumped in the coastal resort of Sihanoukville in southern Cambodia, saying that the level of toxicity slightly exceeded safety standards.

The EPA said tests on waste samples brought back by a local environmental group, the Green Formosa Front showed mercury levels of 0.284 parts per million (ppm), compared with the 0.2 ppm safety standard set by the ROC government.

The FPG shipped 2,700 tons of the waste to Cambodia last month for disposal. The incident hit the headlines last week after Hun Sen claimed in Phnom Penh that the FPG waste poses a great health threat to the Cambodian people and that several residents of Shihnoukville might have died because of contact with the waste.

Over a third of business leaders polled believed next year's economy would recede while a large majority believed Taiwan's economic growth would not reach government projections, a recent survey indicated.

According to the survey conducted by the China Credit Information Service Ltd. of Taiwan's top 500 firms, 34.6 percent said Taiwan's economy would likely recede next year while 32.3 percent saw a slight improvement. Only less than 1 percent thought the economy would gain noticeable momentum in 1999.
Moreover, 85 percent said Taiwan's economic growth would likely be between 3 percent and 4.9 percent compared to government forecasts of 5.1 percent.
Different sectors were widely divided on local business conditions next year, the survey indicated. For instance, the service industry was more optimistic than the manufacturing industry.

Most businesses in the service sector, with the exception of the construction industry, were confident that Taiwan's economy will rebound next year. In the manufacturing sector, most of the survey respondents, other than those in the food-processing industry, believed the economy in 1999 would maintain stable or face a recession.
A majority of the 500 companies surveyed described their own business prospects for the new year as "cautiously optimistic," the results stated.

Some 64.2 percent predicted that their revenues would expand in 1999, and 31.6 percent of those said they would likely post increases of more than 50 percent. About 22.7 percent thought their businesses would remain stable while 13.2 percent said their businesses may contract by up to 10 percent.

On net profits, 56.1 percent of the businesses surveyed expressed confidence in making greater profits in the coming year, in contrast to 14.7 percent who said their profits would likely shrink by about 10 percent. Nearly 30 percent said they would maintain a similar level of profit as this year, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER OUTLINES WORK PLANS FOR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that the Republic of China will continue to promote its bid to re-join the United Nations and take part in functional international organizations to counter mainland China's "big power diplomacy."

Hu told a year-end news conference that as mainland China has been actively seeking to forge "strategic partnerships" with advanced countries, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is studying countermeasures to cope with the new challenges.

The minister pointed out that following a meeting in Shanghai in mid-October between the top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taipei's Koo Chen-fu and Beijing's Wang Daohan, mainland China, while stepping up its efforts to forge a false impression in the world community that the two sides have begun political dialogue or unification talks, has simultaneously intensifies its diplomatic strangulation strategy against Taiwan.

"If we fail to expose Beijing's two-handed strategy against us, major countries around the world may erroneously think that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could resolve their disputes soon and thus withheld their diplomatic support for us and even cease arms sales to Taiwan," Hu warned.

Against this background, Hu said, the ROC must strengthen international publicity to let the world understand the legitimacy and reasonableness of its diplomatic efforts as well as Beijing's "true face" and two-handed tactics against Taiwan.
"On the other hand, we should also make Beijing understand that its attempt to isolate Taiwan in the international community cannot succeed," Hu noted.
He pointed out that mainland China believes when it succeeds in taking away all of the ROC's diplomatic allies, the time will come for reunification.

"But I am afraid the more they push to leave us zero diplomatic allies, it will only mean zero chance of reunification," the minister said. "Their suppression only sparks antagonism among our people, and they must try to understand how our people feel about it."
Hu further warned Beijing against pursuing so-called "big power diplomacy" by striking strategic alliances with advanced nations while seeking their commitments to isolate Taiwan.
During his visit to Beijing this summer, US President Bill Clinton pledged not to support Taiwan's efforts to rejoin the United Nations or its independence.

"Despite their closer relations, Western nations will never ease their attacks on the mainland China's human rights violations,'' Hu said. "As Washington and Beijing get closer to each other, they will also realize the wide gaps between them."

Hu further said he hopes Beijing will understand that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must co-exist peacefully in the world arena to lay a solid foundation for China's peaceful unification under freedom and democracy.

As for the ministry work plans for the coming year, Hu said the ministry will coordinate with other relevant government agencies to expand the ROC's diplomatic frontiers through trade and economic cooperation.
"We will also respect public opinion and uphold the democratic principles in promoting diplomatic work and maintain peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait," Hu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE RATE COULD CONTINUE TO RISE: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: The growing number of people who are middle-aged and unemployed, and single elderly persons in Taiwan is leading experts to express concern over the possibility of a continued rise in the suicide rate.

Statistics released by the Department of Health indicated that the island's suicide rate has increased in the last five years. Last year, suicide was again listed as one of the top 10 causes of death in Taiwan.

Although there is no evidence linking unemployment with suicide, the number of people aged between 25 to 44 who took their own lives was the highest in recent years, and the suicide rate for this particular age group had increased the most. Suicide rates for men was 1.9 times higher than that for women, experts noted.
Compared to last year, the jobless situation in 1998 has worsened as youths entering the job market for the first time are also finding it difficult to find employment.

Experts also expressed concern over the high suicide rate among the elderly population in Taiwan. Every age group in Taiwan has a lower suicide rate than that of other countries, but for Taiwan residents over 65, the suicide rate is higher than neighboring Asian countries as well as European and American countries.

Statistics paint a gloomy picture of the elderly in Taiwan. About 50 percent of single elderly people suffer from chronic diseases, while those without children, living with their friends or relatives, or those living in nursing homes have an even higher ratio -- 85 percent -- suffer from chronic diseases.

A suicide hotline reported that in the past year, it received over 14,000 calls for help. Among them, over 12 percent of the callers have considered ending their lives or have attempted suicide. The figure a few years ago was less than 10 percent.

Psychiatrist Chang Chin-juei of the Cathay General Hospital said 12 out of every 10,000 deaths are caused by suicide. Meanwhile, the number of patients seeking psychological help at the hospital has also increased, he said. Those who are most likely to attempt suicide are those who are clinically depressed, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO RELEASE NT$150 B. TO PROP UP HOUSING MARKET

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC), in an effort to bolster the sluggish real estate market, will release an additional NT$150 billion in housing loans, Finance Minister Paul Chiu announced on Wednesday.
The Ministry of Finance and the CBC came to the decision after discussing on Wednesday possible measures to give the struggling real estate industry a shot in the arm, Chiu said.
He stated that the CBC will use postal bank deposits totaling NT$150 billion in addition to the NT$30 billion it earlier released to banks for low-rate housing loans.
The CBC's largest deal involving its postal deposits for housing loans is expected to fill 100,000 vacant units in Taiwan, the finance minister said.
Banks will offer a 5.95 percent lending rate to those who do not currently own a home over the next year. The repayment period will be 20 years with a grace period of three years.
The low interest rate means the government will subsidize the 0.85 percent difference between the special rate and the interbank rate currently set at 6.8 percent.
Eligible Taipei residents are entitled to NT$2.5 million in housing loans while those living outside Taipei may receive NT$2 million per household.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Central Bank of China will provide NT$150 billion for local banks to offer low-interest housing loans to help revitalize the recession-hit property market.
The China Times:
The central bank will release NT$150 billion (US$4.7 billion) for low-cost housing loans to boost market confidence.
The United Daily News:
NT$150 billion will be provided to local banks to lend out as preferential loans to woo investors back into the housing market.
The Liberty Times:
The annual interest rate will be only 5.95 percent for those who borrow money from banks to purchase new houses next year.
The Independence Morning Post:
In a surprise year-end move, the central bank announced last night it will offer NT$150 billion in low-cost housing loans to stimulate the listless property market.
The Commons Daily:
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party is mulling to form a shadow Cabinet.
The China Post:
Europe gears up for euro birth.
The China News:
Tests show the Formosa Plastics Group's waste shipped to Cambodia is toxic; four out of five samples are over the legal limit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRIMARY FOR PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE SET FOR JULY

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party is not expected to nominate its candidate for the 2000 presidential elections until July, DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said on Thursday.

Lin noted that the party development committee will work out pa rty reform goals before May 1999, and submit them to DPP national congress for discussion in July at the latest. Therefore, the DPP primary for presidential candidate can only be possible during or after July.

The party development committee is now divided into five groups. One group is assigned to review the results of the Dec. 5 elections, one is attempting to unite the political factions within the party, one is seeking to forge closer relations with the private sector, one is working on the presidential election strategy, and another is revising the party's platform and nomination regulations.
Wu Nai-jen, DPP Central Standing Committee member and convenor of the presidential election strategy group, said the group will hold its first meeting on Jan. 5.

The DPP presidential candidate will likely be promoted in a manner similar to the way a commodity is marketed, Wu said, adding that former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang and former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian will be invited to offer their valuable opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD TO VISIT GAMBIA, SENEGAL BEFORE MID-JANUARY

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is scheduled to visit Gambia and Senegal between Jan. 9 and 16 to promote economic and agricultural exchanges.
The ROC's top economic planner said he and his mission will primarily assess the feasibility of Taiwan's plans to create major economic and property development projects in Gambia and Senegal.
During their visit, the delegates, which include officials from the ministries of foreign affairs and economic affairs, will also meet with the leaders of the two African nations.
Chiang said he will spend two days in Gambia and three days in Senegal.
The trip to Gambia comes after Gambian President Yahya A.J.J. Jammeh, during a visit to Taipei in November, personally invited Chiang to the African country, the CEPD chairman noted.

He decided to include a trip to Senegal because the Senegalese government has invited him to visit three times in recent months. They are hoping that Chiang will help push forward several proposals for major cooperative projects between Senegal and Taiwan, Chiang added.
He noted that his African trip comes amid increased government efforts to invigorate the domestic economy.

Chiang said a CEPD-devised, pump-priming plan will be submitted to Premier Vincent Siew next week before his departure with the hopes that the plan will be approved by the Executive Yuan and be implemented soon after he returns to Taipei.

DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taichung police on Thursday said they suspected an organized smuggling ring is behind the growing number of Thai prostitutes found in the central Taiwan city.

Eleven of 15 foreign laborers charged with prostitution were from Thailand and legally entered Taiwan with certificates verifying their intention to marry Taiwan nationals, the police reported. This has led authorities to dub these cases "false marriage, genuine sex trade."

There are currently about 7,600 foreign laborers who make Taichung city their home. They work either at factories and construction sites or as domestic helpers. The figure is about 3 percent of the entire foreign worker population in Taiwan, which totals about 250,000.

In Taichung, the number of foreign laborers abandoning their work contracts has dropped to 3 percent this year, down from 9.3 percent in previous years, the police noted. However, the number of those found engaging in the illicit sex trade has increased.

According to a police survey of Taichung employers regarding foreign workers, Thais are generally favored because they are obedient and have a strong work ethic. Their shortcomings are that they like to drink alcohol and generally have a relaxed attitude about sex which can cause problems for their Taiwan employers, the police noted.

Meanwhile, the survey found that Filipino workers are also welcomed by Taiwan employers as they have a relatively higher level of education and can speak English. However, Filipino workers were often seen behind organized strikes and other related labor disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATOR LEAVES FOR CAMBODIA OVER WASTE DISPUTE

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation, led by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Tseng Chen-nung, left on Thursday for Cambodia to collect samples of waste which originated in Taiwan.

The delegation includes Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) investigators, and two ranking executives of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), the company behind a dispute regarding the toxicity level of the waste

About 2,700 tons of waste were found near the coastal city of Sihanoukville in southern Cambodia recently. Following the reported death of a man who came in contact with the waste, Cambodian officials raised concerns that the waste was toxic.

Preliminary tests conducted by a local environmental interest group, the Green Formosa Front, showed mercury levels at 0.284 parts per million -- higher than the set safety standard of 0.2 ppm established by the ROC government.
The EPA officials said as soon as they collect samples of the waste, they plan to return to Taiwan to conduct tests. The mission is expected to be completed in 48 hours, they added.
Tseng told CNA at Chang Kai-shek International Airport that he hopes his visit will help resolve the dispute and foster improved bilateral relations between Taipei and Phnom Penh.
Tseng, who maintains extensive links with the Cambodian leadership, did not discount the possibility of meeting with Prime Minister Hun Sen.

The lawmaker noted that he has spoken with FPG Chairman Wang Yiung-ching regarding the issue. Wang, who faxed three letters to Hun Sun on Wednesday, expressed sincere concern and a desire to resolve the dispute, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEN PARTY PROTESTS FPG'S SLOPPY HANDLING OF TOXIC WASTE ISSUE

TEXT.P: The Green Party of Taiwan staged a demonstration in front of the headquarters of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) on Thursday over the conglomerate's irresponsible, sloppy handling of the controversial toxic waste issue.

The environmentalist party demanded that the petrochemical giant set a timetable for resolving issues related to its shipment of some 2,700 tons of mercury-laced waste to Cambodia for landfill disposal in November.
A spokesperson said the Green Party will be pleased to see the FPG receive technical assistance from either the United States, Germany or France in treating the controversial waste.

"Nevertheless, we still hope that the FPG work out a timetable for resolving the issue which has not only marred the group's business reputation but also tarnished our country's international image," the spokesperson said.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) should also learn a lesson from the incident and formulate an effective system to monitor and control pollution of industrial land, the Green Party executive said.

"We believe that the FPG case is just the tip of the domestic toxic waste iceberg, he said, adding that several recent incidents, such as the dumping of hazardous waste in arable farmland in the southern county of Pintung and the groundwater pollution in a northern Taiwan township near a factory of the now-defunct Radio Corporation of America, have all spotlighted the many defects and improprieties in Taiwan's management of industrial waste.

The Green Party urged all local enterprises to set up a crisis management center to properly and timely handle issues similar to the current FPG toxic waste incident to uphold the general public's interests and protect their own corporate image and fame.
The demonstrators also gave theatric performances to signify their protests against the FPG's lousy handling of the waste dispute.
However, no FPG executives ever showed up to respond to the Green Party's calls. The demonstration ended peacefully at 10:20 a.m.

Meanwhile, the Green Formosa Front, a local environmental group which sent staff members to Cambodia to collect samples of the waste for EPA laboratory tests earlier this month, said on Thursday it will ask Japanese experts to conduct further tests on the samples collected at the Cambodian dump site.
In the meantime, a delegation of FPG executives and EPA officials, left for Cambodia Thursday morning to collect samples of the disputed FPG waste for further tests.
The fact-finding panel was led by Tseng Chen-nung, a ruling Kuomintang legislator closely connected to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.

Tseng said prior to his departure that the team's main mission is to collect samples of the waste. The lawmaker said the FPG is trying to accurately assess whether the waste is indeed toxic as suggested in previous analyses done by the EPA and a Japanese expert assigned by the World Health Organization.

Tseng further said the panel will also seek a basic agreement with Cambodian authorities over the future removal of the waste. FPG General Manager Lee Chih-tsun said on Wednesday the company will would work out a solution after the results of new analysis are known.
The FPG, which has admitted that the waste contains mercury but said it is below hazardous levels, has promised to remove the waste as the Cambodian government has demanded.
Lee said the waste may be shipped to the United States where the technology to process chemical waste is available.
Also on Wednesday, FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching faxed a message to Hun Sen, apologizing for causing unrest among Cambodian residents as a result of the waste dumping.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 31, or the 13th day of the 11th month in Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1869: Henri Matisse, French artist and a leading fauvist who employed pure color, simple shapes, and an exquisite sense of design to produce paintings, is born.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Teintsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: US President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of Word War II.
1946: Chang Hsueh-ling, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnap of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1946: Taiwan tea is exported to New York for the first time.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1981: Former Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings overthrows the government of President Hilla Limann and seizes power again in Ghana.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1996: Explosion on a train in India kills at least 300 people.
Confucius lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGES TAIPEI CITY TO ROUND UP STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: Responding to a temporary moratorium on the capture of stray dogs, the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Thursday urged the Taipei City Government to continue rounding up strays in line with regulations

Chen Pao-chi, director of COA's Animal Industry Department, said city laws required Taipei's Bureau of Environmental Protection, or registered private groups commissioned by the bureau, to be responsible for taking stray dogs off the streets.
The COA director said animal protection regulations also stipulated that stray dogs be handled by the county or city government.

The city bureau imposed a temporary moratorium on dog catching Wednesday, stating that there are about 200,000 abandoned dogs in Taipei but as it can only handle about 30-40 a day, it can hardly cope with the task.
The COA said the handling of stray dogs should start with the registration of pets, involve stricter regulations on stray dogs and the improvement of animal shelters.
The council estimated that 200,000 dogs will be registered and implanted with silicon chips for identification, while improvements are being planned for 10 to 15 shelters.

As Taipei lacks shelters to house the stray dogs, the COA will send officials to other cities and counties to scout for suitable alternative shelters with possible sites in Taipei County or Miaoli County, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ STRONGLY OPPOSES CREATION OF ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: A proposal by Taiwan lawmakers to establish an independent agency to fight corruption has met with strong opposition from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), sources from the Legislative Yuan reported Thursday.

The Legislative Yuan Legal Affairs Committee on Thursday proposed the establishment of an agency similar to Hong Kong's Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) as a means of combating corruption and related problems involving government employees.

In a position paper distributed Thursday to legislators, the MOJ voiced opposition to the proposal, saying the current anti-corruption system, which involves government prosecutors, investigators and agencies in charge of formulating government policies on ethics, are working efficiently. An additional, independent body is not needed, the ministry said.

MOJ officials said the establishment of an additional agency would only result in redundancies. It is doubtful that the system would operate more efficiently with the creation of an independent body than it does now, they said.
They instead recommended an overhaul and streamlining of the current agencies in charge of government ethics.

New Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua, one of the lawmakers who initiated the ICAC proposal, was disappointed at the MOJ's reaction, saying current administrative agencies are too conservative and lack the expertise to deal with changing world trends.
Lee characterized the MOJ's resistance to the lawmakers' proposal to establish an ICAC in Taiwan as indicating a lack of foresight and a sincere willingness to undergo reform.

Legislator Hsieh Tsung-min from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that although the MOJ's government ethics agencies are functioning sufficiently, it has not done a good job in detecting and curbing the current spate of financial irregularities in Taiwan. Examples of such irregularities include stock settlement defaults, embezzling and bounced checks.
Thursday could be Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's busiest day since he assumed office last week.
Ma's schedule for the last day of 1998 is filled with appearances, speeches and New Year's celebrations.

The mayor is due to deliver speeches at two separate occasions before visiting the Community University at 8:30 p.m. Then he is due to appear at a show at the Chung Shan Soccer Stadium at 9:30 p.m. During the event, sponsored by the Taipei Rapid Transit Co., Ma is expected to play the guitar.

Afterward, at 10:30 p.m., he will attend a concert held by the Broadcasting Corporation of China and the China Television Company at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where he will appear as a mystery guest.

He will then head to the Taipei City Government Square for a concert and a countdown to 1999. Ma is also expected to invite former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian, to join him at the city hall party.
Early Friday morning, Ma will attend a flag-raising ceremony held every year in front of the Presidential Office to greet the first day of the new year.

After the ceremony, the avid jogger will run from the Presidential Office to the Taipei City Government Square. At the square, Mayor Ma will join 40 civil groups in an exercise routine, which will be followed by performances by aborigines and choirs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHAIRS SENIOR MILITARY OFFICERS PROMOTION CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday that the Republic of China must continue to beef up its defense capabilities because of mainland China's constant military threats.
Lee made the statement at a high-ranking military officers promotion ceremony.
The president said although the Cold War ended several years ago, mainland China has continued to expand its military strength.

Noting that Beijing's incessant military build-up has become a major destabilizing factor in the Asia-Pacific area, Lee said Taiwan must further upgrade its combat capabilities to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
"In addition to renovating weaponry systems and military equipment, the ROC military has stepped up development of new defense technologies and enforcement of a troop-reduction program," Lee said.
Under the military streamlining plan, the ROC will trim the number of its regular military forces from 450,000 to about 400,000 and the number of high-ranking officers will be cut to around 400.
"The ongoing military modernization plan is aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force," Lee said, adding that faster-than-expected progress in the program has won much acclaim in local society.
Lee offered his personal felicitations to the 78 senior military officers who got promotions on Thursday, including 62 promoted to the major general ranking and 16 to the lieutenant general ranking.

"It is of great significance that you have managed to become the first batch of senior officers promoted to the major-or-lieutenant-general rankings since the 'streamlining' plan was implemented a couple of years ago," Lee said.

"The promotion marks a personal achievement on the one hand and an increase in official duties on the other. I hope you'll continue to work hard and contribute to the country's military build-up," the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES AND FUTURES BOTH DROP

TEXT.P: A bearish sentiment continued to dominate the stock market Thursday, the last business day of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) in 1998.
TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropped 43.6 points to close at 6,418.43.

Over the past week, the bourse has sustained a series of drops, despite government measures to prop up the market, such as the decision to release postal deposits to banks to provide low-interest housing loans. The loans are expected to bolster the island's housing market and invigorate its construction sector, the locomotive of Taiwan's economy.
Investors became pessimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects after several companies cut profit forecasts or announced plans to reduce the scale of their business operation, dealers said.
A total of 1.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.74 billion (US$1.61 billion), against the previous session's NT$65.95 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 282 to 139, with 66 stocks unchanged.
Only paper and pulp issues among the eight major stock categories posted a gain, rising 0.4 percent.

The government's Thursday announcement that NT$150 billion (US$4.66 billion) would be made available for housing loans did not excite the construction sector. Construction stocks remained unchanged in the session.

Textile shares, meanwhile, plunged 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues, which dropped 1 percent; plastic and chemical stocks and electronic engineering issues, both of which fell 0.8 percent; financial stocks, which fell 0.6 percent; and cement issues, which fell 0.4 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a slight increase of 0.2 points, closing at 165.8 on a market turnover of NT$3.95 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures also ended the day lower. The futures market will be closed from Friday to Monday for the New Year's holiday.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for January lost 77 points, finishing at 6,531, with 3,173 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for February dropped 55 points to 6,570, with 223 contract transactions, while those for March moved down 65 points to 6,560 and those for June slid 75 points to 6,555. Transactions for the two months amounted to 49 and six, respectively.
No trading was registered for September.

Reference levels provide by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 6,608 points for January; 6,625 points for February; 6,625 points for March; 6,630 points for June; and 6,562 points for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S R & I GIVES TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGN CREDIT RATING 'AA'

TEXT.P: R & I, a Japanese credit rating company, on Wednesday gave Taiwan's long-term foreign currency debt rating a AA, the second highest rating, and its short-term foreign currency debt rating an A1+, the highest rating, respectively.
R & I said Taiwan's rating is high because of its outstanding performance in its external-bound economy. For instance, the foreign asset as a percentage of its GDP at the end of June was 52 percent.

Meanwhile, R & I added that Taiwan's high economic growth rate and low inflation have contributed to its high ratings as well. Taiwan's public debt to GDP ratio was a mere 24 percent at the end of 1997 and the government budget deficit has been reduced to a reasonable level, R & I said.
Despite the fact that Taiwan's overdue loan ratio is expected to increase from 4.75 percent in 1998 to 7 percent in 1999, the figure is relatively low compared with other countries in Asia.

In addition, the ROC government has lowered interest rates and established a fund to stabilize the stock market and to boost the slumping economy caused by the Asian financial crisis. The government has also expanded investment in public construction to stimulate domestic demand, said R & I.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNTEX TO SHAVE NT$20 BILLION FROM ITS BUDGET BY END OF 1999

TEXT.P: Tuntex Group President Chen You-hau announced on Thursday that Tuntex will reduce its budget by NT$20 billion (US$617 million) in 1999.

To lessen the company's debt-to-asset ratio, Tuntex Group will sell 59 percent of the shares of the Tuntex Telecom, the most profitable company in the group, to KG Telecom at a cost of NT$6.5 billion, said Chen.
Chen said the reductions will be implemented step by step. The company will reduce its budget by NT$6 billion to NT$7 billion every three months in a bid to achieve a 1-to-1 debt-to-asset ratio.
Chen said the possibility of a merger between Tuntex Telecom and KG Telecom depends on other shareholders, such as Hong Kong's First Pacific and China Development Bank.
Tuntex will sell its shares to the KG Group at NT$27.5 per share and will earn NT$4.1 billion (US$126.2 billion) in profits from the sale, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREASURY ACTIVITY GENERATES RECORD PROFITS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Treasury profits in Singapore soared to a record high of S$3.1 billion (US$1.93 billion) in 1997, an increase of 116 percent , according to the Singapore Foreign Exchange Market Committee (SFEMC).

The figures also suggest that 1998 would remain a fairly good year for bank treasury business. Revenue for the first half of 1998 reached S$2.8 billion, which amounts to 60 percent of 1997's revenue of S$4.6 billion, and exceeds the entire 1996 revenue figure of S$2.7 billion.

Results from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) survey of treasury activity undertaken each year showed foreign exchange business generated almost half of the total revenue for 1997, a significant increase over the one-third share it contributed in both 1995 and 1996.

There were more banks among the high earners in 1997 than in previous years, but more banks incurred losses as well. The number of banks with profits in excess of S$20 million almost doubled to 32. There was an improvement in overall performance, with the median bank generating an average profit of between S$5 million and S$10 million, compared to 1995 and 1996 when the median bank profits were under S$5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ANNOUNCES MEASURES TO PROP UP HOUSING SECTOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Executive Yuan on Thursday passed a group of measures to prop up the flagging housing and construction sectors, the locomotive of the country's economy.
Those markets have remained sluggish since 1995, mainly due to an oversupply of housing and office buildings.

That has affected related industries, such as those that produce cement, steel and metal, furniture and electrical appliances. The sluggishness has also affected the island's financial order and stability, resulting in a weaker stock market, finance officials said.

The stimulus package includes a measure to make available NT$150 billion (US$4.66 billion) to local banks so that they may provide low-interest housing loans to house buyers and measures to suspend housing construction projects of state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp., as well as government public housing construction projects in a bid to limit new construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO BUILD UP MILITARY TRUST MECHANISM WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Mainland China should seriously consider the Republic of China's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait establish a "military mutual trust" mechanism to facilitate eventual reunification, a senior official said on Thursday.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the appeal at a year-end news conference.

Chang said the cultivation of military mutual trust is part of efforts to end hostility. "Some tasks in this domain can be done unilaterally, such as keeping military budget transparent and exempting each other from becoming the target of military exercises," he noted.

The country's top mainland policy planner also urged Beijing to mull other Taiwan-broached bilateral cooperative programs, including agricultural cooperation, exchanges of experience in the grassroots democratic development, and cooperation in resolving many practical problems related to interests of people on both sides of the strait.

"Taiwan has also offered to assist mainland China in reforming its bloated, money-losing state-owned enterprises," Chang said, adding that the two sides should cooperate in helping address the Asian financial crisis.

"We believe that through all these Taiwan-initiated joint efforts the two sides will be able to forge a mutually beneficial, constructive relationship to ensure peaceful co-existence and co-prosperity," Chang said.
The scholar-turned-MAC chief went on to say that he hopes the top mainland negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, will visit the island as soon as possible.

"We have sincerely invited Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to visit Taiwan. We hope Wang's visit can be realized before the end of August 1999," Chang said.

Wang, a former mayor of Shanghai and mentor to incumbent mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, agreed to visit Taiwan when he met with his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu in mid-October this year. Koo met a historic, ice-breaking visit to mainland China from Oct. 14 through Oct. 19.
However, ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei set some preconditions for Wang's planned Taiwan visit in his recent interview with a Hong Kong newspaper.

"If mainland China really imposes prerequisites for Wang's Taiwan journey, it is erecting obstacles to the development of cross-strait relations," Chang said, adding that Wang's trip is basically a return visit aimed at help boost cross-strait understanding and dialogue.

Chang said Taiwan will do its best to push for the realization of Wang's visit. "The ideal time is between February and August next year. We have authorized the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to join forces with its mainland counterpart, the ARATS, to work out a detailed itinerary for Wang."

As for a proposed meeting between the top leaders of the two sides of the strait, Chang said the MAC has proposed that ROC President Lee Teng-hui and mainland President Jiang meet in an international setting. However, Beijing has not agreed to such a proposal.
On the MAC's 1999 work plans, Chang said the council will first push for the substantiation of the four-point consensus reached between Koo and Wang when they met in Shanghai in October.

The four-point deal includes that Wang will visit Taiwan at an appropriate time; SEF and ARATS will gradually resume regular, systematic dialogue and exchanges as well as assist each other in handling emergency cases related to personal safety and property rights of people on both sides of the strait.
